DocsList.Data:
UMass Amherst 

“Cornerstone Christian Ministry”

: Constitution Fall 2010 

Name of Organization: 

Cornerstone Christian Ministry 

Mission Statement:   

The organization seeks to enrich understanding of Christianity and of the Stone-Campbell Restoration 
Movement among faculty and students; to foster an exchange of ideas concerning the identity and 
purpose of the Stone-Campbell Restoration Movement, both within Christianity and within the global 
religious community; to discuss issues of faith, reason, and spirituality and how these concern the 
UMass community; and to provide a center for fellowship among students and faculty interested in the 
Stone-Campbell Restoration Movement, especially for members of the Disciples of Christ, the 
Independent Christian Churches, the Churches of Christ, the International Churches of Christ, and the 
non-institutional Churches of Christ. The organization will pursue these goals through student led bible 
discussions, community building events, spiritual retreats, and on campus worship services. Over the 
next five years this organization hopes to grow in membership, allowing for the facilitation of more 
student led bible discussions and other events on campus. 

Membership:  

Membership is regularly open to all undergraduate and graduate students at the University of 
Massachusetts at Amherst and faculty of the University as well as the five college school system and 
schools in the area, regardless of race, creed, color, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, or physical 
ability. Each member shall be allocated one vote. 

Election of the four elected officers of the Executive Board by the members shall normally be held at the 
spring semester meeting of each year. The officers taking office immediately upon their election shall 
hold office for one year until the next election meeting.  

In order to be a voting member, individuals must maintain biweekly attendance for one semester. 

Meetings: 

The organization will host one meeting each semester. These meetings will be chaired by the president 
with the purpose of providing an open forum for voting members to express grievances and propose 
changes to the group's mission statement, constitution, or specific functions. The meeting held during 
spring semester will serve as an opportunity to elect and appoint Executive Board Officers for the next 
year. Decisions regarding alterations to organization documents are detailed below.  

​
​
 
 
 
 Officers Defined:  

The elected officers of this organization shall be the following: The president, the vice president, the 
treasurer and the Event Coordinator 

The President 
Duties and Responsibilities: 
​

-
-
-
-
-

Shall be in charge of leadership and management of the Cornerstone Christian Ministry 
Shall delegate organization of weekly bible discussions and other organization events 
Shall schedule and preside over the organization meeting each semester 
Shall communicate with university staff or delegate that authority 
Shall work with the executive board to nominate future officers 

The Vice President 
Duties and Responsibilities: 

-
-
-

Shall assist the President in the performance of his/her duties 
Shall work with the executive board to nominate future officers 
Shall hold signature responsibility 

The Treasurer 
Duties and Responsibilities: 

-
-
-
-
-

Shall be responsible for all financial matters pertaining to the Cornerstone Christian Ministry 
Shall draft and submit a yearly budget request 
Shall execute the financial business of the Cornerstone Christian Ministry 
Shall appropriate funding and order materials and food for events 
Shall hold signature responsibility 

The Event Coordinator 
Duties and Responsibilities: 

Shall be responsible for reserving rooms or other venues for all scheduled on campus events 
Shall communicate with the university staff regarding the reservation of rooms and venues 

-
-
-

Term of Office: The term of office each officer shall be for one year only, from the election at the annual 
meeting until a successor is chosen at the next annual meeting.  

Qualifications: Of the officers elected, all of them shall be undergraduates at the time of election and 
shall have been members at the time of the previous meeting. 

Process for Elections and Nominations:  

Elections will be held during the spring semester meeting which will occur the first Friday  of March. 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The process for elections will proceed as follows: 

1. The Current Executive Board will nominate voting members for each position and the President 

will present these nominees to the group as a whole 

2. Voting  members will then have the opportunity to nominate themselves for candidacy 
3. After nominees for each position are established voting will proceed by the raising of hands in 

favor of each nominee. 

4. The Vice President will record the number of votes each candidate receives 
5. Any candidate who receives ⅔ majority will be elected to the position for the following year 
6. The current executive Board will then communicate the results to the club advisor and update 

campus pulse. 

Vacancies: 

A. Should a vacancy occur in the office of President, the Vice President shall become President, and the 

new President, with the concurrence of the Executive Board, shall name a qualified person to 
serve as Vice President.  

B. Should any vacancy occur other than in the office of President, or should an officer default in the 
performance of his duties, the president, with the concurrence of the Executive Board, shall 
name a qualified person to serve for the remainder of the current term.  

C. If no candidate receives a majority of the votes, the newly elected officers, shall name a qualified 

person to fill the position.  

Removal from Office or Membership: 

A. Grounds for Removal: 

Cornerstone Christian Ministry

shall have the power to remove any of its 

officers as provided in this section. The grounds for such removal shall be the infraction of the 
rules of The University of Massachusetts at Amherst and/or serious negligence in the discharge 
of the duties of that office.  

B. Removal Procedures: The following procedures shall be followed in all proceedings leading to the 
possible expulsion of an officer and shall not exceed a 60-day time limit from the time of the 
resolution.  

1) The executive board must unanimously agree to the removal of an officer or an RSO member. In 

the case of the removal of an officer, the agreement must be unanimous among all the 
executive board officers except the officer in question. 

2) Once the above agreement has been reached, the executive board will contact said officer or 

member via telephone or in person communication to communicate the decision and offer said 
officer or member an opportunity to appeal the decision 

 
 
​
 
​
​
 
​
 3)

4)

In the case of an appeal, the executive board will meet with said officer or member to hear their 
appeal and revote. A unanimous agreement, excepting the officer in question, is once again 
required for their removal. 
If the executive board once again votes in favor of removing said officer or member, an 
organization meeting will be held within one week to present the case to all voting members. 
Members will vote whether or not to remove said officer or member, and a ⅔ majority will be 
required for their removal. 

Freedom of Speech/Expression: 

The Cornerstone Christian Ministry will allow each member and visitor of the organization the right to 
respectfully express his/her opinion. All members will have the opportunity to make their opinion 
known and heard. Under no circumstances shall a member’s freedom of speech or expression be 
. 
infringed

Non-Discrimination: 

Membership is regularly open to all undergraduate and graduate students at the University of 
Massachusetts at Amherst and faculty of the University as well as the five college school system and 
schools in the area, regardless of race, creed, color, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, or physical 
ability. The organization prohibits discriminations under Federal and State law based on, but not limited 
to, the above attributes. 

Amendments: 

The procedure for amending the organization’s constitution or charter is as follows: 

1) During the meeting held each semester voting members and officers may propose changes that 

2)

they wish to incorporate into the constitution or charter. 
If the proposed change is possible and favorable, the executive board will then meet 
independently to discuss and draft these changes.  

3) The executive board will then hold a second meeting within the same semester to present the 
proposed change to the voting members who will vote whether to incorporate the change into 
the club constitution or charter. A ⅔ majority vote is required for changes to be incorporated. 

Ratification of Constitution: 

 
​
 
 
 
 Shall be voted on by a 2/3rds majority of the organization, approved by the Secretary of Registry, and 
then the changes will be made and the new constitution will be printed and available for all members. 

Future Goals:  

Our goals for the future of this organization include continued annual growth of the group as well as to 
host events on campus that will stimulate the spiritual thoughts of the UMass body. These events will 
include ideas such as church services, religious and biblical lectures on how we can view the bible and 
current issues, presentations concerning evidence for the bible and Christianity, finding opportunities to 
serve the Pioneer Valley community, and many more. 

Reason for RSO Status: 

To demonstrate that our organization does not duplicate the mission of any of the existing organizations 
here at the college, this section will distinguish our organization from ten currently existing Christian 
organizations. Though there is much that unites us with these organizations, our specific emphases 
clearly distinguish us from them. 

Chi Alpha Christian Fellowship: 

“Chi Alpha is a community united by faith, love and commitment to Jesus Christ. We are a group of 

seekers, skeptics, and serious followers of Jesus.  We are students, staff, faculty, and others who 
get together on campus to draw closer to God and to one another. We welcome students, faculty 
and staff from all backgrounds to join us on our journey we call "life." 

The root of our organization is in the Restoration movement which is not the focus of Chi Alpha Christian 

Fellowship, which will distinguish Cornerstone Christian Fellowship from it. 

MERCY House Nights: 

“Vita Nova is an Acts 29 and 2020 Vision church in Amherst, Massachusetts that began in April of 2009.  
We are committed to loving the Pioneer Valley and making  it a better area to live in.  We desire 
to bring the hope of Jesus to the sick and suffering of our town, while at the same time engaging 
with culture, loving artists through our art gallery and art lessons, and helping local businesses 
” 
by encouraging our congregation to support them financially and tip generously
​

The focus of MERCY House Nights seems to be based in the arts, while the focus of Cornerstone 

Christian Fellowship is to be centered on the restoration movement and how that can be applied 
in the student body. 

Intervarsity Christian Fellowship: 

“Advancing God's kingdom through whole life conversion to Jesus Christ, moving students from cynics to 

seekers to followers to leaders to world changers.” 

 
 There is no focus from the Intervarsity Christian Fellowship on the unique Restoration movement, or any 

type of discussions on campus. Therefore there is no link to Intervarsity Christian Fellowship. 

Adventist Christians (ACTS): 

“Adventist Christians Together to Serve is a religious affiliated group that serves to provide the 

opportunity to become acquainted with and enjoy the fellowship of Christian students, faculty, 
and staff, to promote social and spiritual growth, to encourage members in personal service and 
community outreach and to provide opportunity for meaningful discussions by members of the 
group on-issues concerning, Christianity at large and the Seventh-day Adventist denomination in 
particular. It is an inviting opportunity to all.” 

The Restoration Movement is completely distinct from the Seventh-day Adventist Church; therefore, 
Cornerstone Christian Ministry is very different from the Adventist Christians (ACTS). 

Epic Movement at UMass: 

“The purpose of Epic Movement at UMass is to encourage, promote and foster the spiritual, emotional, 
and social health of Asian Americans students, through open dialog  and discussions about the 
person of Jesus Christ, and service, education and counseling for the Asian American student 
community here at UMass.  The discussions, while centering on Jesus Christ, will be separate 
form any organized church group or denominational identification in order that students at 
UMass may more readily bring logical, philosophical, cultural, historical and academic questions 
concerning Jesus Christ into open intellectual discussions in a open and neutral setting without 
reference to denominational affiliation.  This separation from any organized church group is for 
the achievement of more open discussion of Jesus Christ’s person and mission; this separation is 
certainly not of Epic Movement members from their churches.  Epic Movement will encourage 
member to participate in the service and activities of the church of their choice. In order to fulfill 
the purpose to which we organize ourselves, we plan to organize, weekly meetings, Bible studies, 
and events that will raise awareness of spiritual, social and emotional issues for Asian 
Americans.” 

Primarily, Cornerstone Christian Ministry is not specifically “Asian-American,   Cornerstone Christian 
Ministry’s emphasis on the Restoration Movement distinguishes it from Epic Movement at 
UMass. 

Campus Crusade for Christ (Campus Crusade) 

“Umass Cru is a community that loves Jesus and everything that he is about. His message, his person, his 

love and example has captured our hearts and we are changed forever. We exist to serve as a 
resource to the UMass community, intelligently communicating how the claims of Jesus Christ 
are relevant to everyone today. We also help students to grow spiritually, academically, in 
character, leadership and relationships. And we have lots of fun while doing it!” 

 While many of the goals of the Cornerstone Christian Ministry overlap with those of Christians on 
Campus, our unique emphasis on the Restoration Movement, a movement often times at 
doctrinal odds with “mainstream” Protestantism, distinguishes us.  

Brothers and Sisters in Christ (B.A.S.I.C.) 

“Our mission is to share the gospel of Jesus Christ to the students on this local campus as well as the 
surrounding areas; to see many souls being saved and won over to His kingdom, and lastly to 
help individuals that already have a relationship with Christ foster growth; and this is done by 
having Sunday services twice a month, weekly Bible study, weekly e-board meetings, and prayer 
meetings.” 

Again, Cornerstone Christian Ministry

will have a much more specific focus than B.A.S.I.C.; although both 
organizations share similar pursuits, Cornerstone Christian Ministry emphasis on the Restoration 
Movement clearly distinguishes it from B.A.S.I.C. 

​
 
​
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Central Objective of the “Cornerstone Christian Ministry” 

The central objective of CCM shall be to enrich understanding of Christianity and of the Stone-Campbell 
Restoration Movement among UMass faculty and students. 

To accomplish this, CCM would focus its efforts into small, weekly discussion groups about faith, 
spirituality, and religion. These groups would be designed not only to discuss Christianity, but also to 
allow people of all faiths to discuss what they believe. CCM would also seek to sponsor and organize 
occasional larger activities and events related to its purpose, such as church meetings and speeches. 

Members of CCM seek both a broader and deeper understanding of faith and spirituality as manifested 
in the realm of religious communities. We believe this understanding is vital to our educations and to 
our lives, regardless of our own religious views; through it, we gain insight into the cultures, identities, 
and philosophies of communities all over the world. 

Various religious organizations exist at UMass, many of which are designed specifically for certain faiths. 
In the same way, CCM exists primarily to contribute knowledge and perspective of the Stone-Campbell 
Restoration Movement to the ongoing interfaith dialogue at UMass, providing a unique religious voice 
that prior to now has been absent or silent. 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The Stone-Campbell Restoration Movement 

The Stone-Campbell Restoration Movement, also known simply as the Restoration Movement, is a 
Christian Protestant reform movement that became prominent in America during the Second Great 
Awakening of the 18th and 19th centuries. Several Christian denominations – the Disciples of Christ, the 
Independent Christian Churches, the Churches of Christ, the International Churches of Christ, and the 
non-institutional Churches of Christ, among others – trace their roots to this movement. All told, there 
are millions of Christians in the United States and across the world whose beliefs have been influenced 
by Barton W. Stone, Alexander Campbell, and other similar reformers. 

Several factors distinguish Restoration Movement denominations from other Protestant denominations. 
(Ironically, one of these is that churches within Restoration Movement often label themselves 
“non-denominational,” emphasizing the potential unity of the Body of Christ.) Almost all practice adult 
baptism for the remission of sins and a weekly celebration of the Lord's Supper; most reject original sin, 
predestination, and faith alone. The Restoration Movement is relatively unique in that its members have 
historically preferred autonomy and congregational polities, as opposed to episcopal or presbyterian 
polities. It is strongly associated with Christian primitivism, or the idea that modern Christians should 
attempt to restore (hence “Restoration movement”), in part or in full, the practices and beliefs of the 
original Christian Church; with this in mind, many denominations within the Restoration Movement have 
sought to avoid post-biblical traditions and creeds, and Restoration Movement scholarship often focuses 
on early Christian beliefs, writings, and practices. There is not, of course, complete unanimity within the 
movement; a spectrum of beliefs exists concerning issues such as the Trinity, instrumental worship, and 
rebaptism.

Alpha Tau Gamma Code of Conduct
Hip-Hop Culture 2015 Constitution.pdf
DocsList.Data:
Hip Hop Culture Organization 

Established September 2006 in Amherst, MA 

I. Mission Statement 

We’re on a mission to spread the positive aspects of the Hip-Hop culture throughout the 
Five College area, as well as to promote the Hip-Hop scene in the Western New England 
area and bridge connections with the Boston Area. 

II. Membership 

•  All students at the University of Massachusetts Amherst and the general public shall be 

eligible to be members of the Hip-Hop Culture Organization. 

III. Meetings 

•  The Hip-Hop Culture Organization shall have general meetings on a weekly basis. 

•  The meetings shall be chaired by the President, Vice President, Treasurer, and Secretary. 

•  The purpose of the meetings shall be: 

o  Group bonding 
o  Planning activities (Performances, fundraisers, etc.) 
o  Other topics deemed necessary 

•  Decisions will be made at meetings by a majority vote of the general membership. 

IV. The Executive Board 

•  The officers of the Hip-Hop Culture Organization shall be: 

o  President 
o  Vice President 
o  Treasurer 
o  Secretary 

•  Officers shall serve a term of one year, starting the day after the last day of classes in the 

Spring semester. 

•  Officers shall be eligible for re-election to multiple terms. 

1.  The President 

•  The President shall be the Chief Executive Officer of the RSO. He or she shall be 

responsible for all aspects of the functioning of the group. 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 •  The President shall have Signature Responsibility. 

2.  The Vice President 

•  The Vice President shall be the second in command of the RSO. 

•  The Vice President shall take over the President when he or she is not present. 

•  The Vice President shall be the liaison between the Hip-Hop Culture Organization 
and the SGA, Student Activities and Involvement, and other campus offices. 

3.  The Treasurer 

•  The Treasurer shall be the Chief Financial Officer of the RSO.  

•  The Treasurer shall be responsible for maintaining the group’s finances. 

•  The Treasurer shall be responsible for submitting an annual budget request to the 

SGA, if necessary. 

•  The Treasurer shall have Signature Responsibility. 

4.  The Secretary 

•  The Secretary shall be responsible for maintaining all records of the RSO. 

•  All advertising, and other documents relevant the functioning of the group shall 

be considered records. 

•  These records shall, in all possible cases, be collected electronically and shall be 
passed on from the current to the future Secretary during the transition period. 

•  The Secretary shall record all official group meetings. 

•  The Secretary shall maintain up to date membership lists. 

•  The Secretary shall be responsible for maintaining the group’s social media and 

Campus Pulse pages. 

V. Officer Elections 

•  Officers’ elections shall take place during the month of April. 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 •  Officer elections shall take place in two stages: the nomination meeting and the election 

period. 

•  The nomination meeting shall be the first meeting of April. 

o  The Executive board shall announce the exact date, time, and location of the 

nominating meeting no later than two weeks prior. 

•  The nominating meeting will be run according to the follow procedure: 

o  Any non-election business shall be dealt with first. 

o  Once all other business is taken care of, the President shall announce the 

nomination to be open. 

o  During the nomination period, any voting member shall nominate any voting 

member, including themselves, to a position: 

! 

In order for the nomination to be official, it shall need to be seconded by 
another voting member. 

!  A voting member may only be nominated to one position. 

!  The nomination period shall remain open until a motion is made, 

seconded, and approved by unanimous consent, to close nominations. 

!  After the nomination period is closed, the President will read the names of 
the candidates who have been nominated. Each member nominated may 
then chose to accept or reject the nomination. 

!  All nominees that have accepted the nomination will be given the 

opportunity to address the general membership for five minutes, and to 
take questions from the membership for five minutes. The nominees for 
President will go first, followed by Vice President, Treasurer, and 
Secretary. The nominees will present first by position and then by the 
order in which they were nominated. 

o  The second phase of the electron shall be the election period, and it shall adhere to 

the following procedure: 

!  Directly following the nominating meeting, the Secretary shall set up 

another group meeting, the following week after the nominating period. 
He or she shall include the names of the members that have been 
nominated at the nominating meetings; only nominated members may be 
elected. 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 !  The election shall be open from the start of the election meeting to the end 

of the election meeting. 

!  Following the closing of the election period, the Secretary shall prepare an 
election report, including the winners and the total vote counts for each 
candidate. This report shall be presented by the Secretary at the meeting 
directly following the closing of the elections. The Secretary shall ensure 
only voting members have voted. If any non-member shall have voted, the 
election will be deemed invalid and the election period will be re-done, 
under the supervision of the Secretary of the Registry. 

o  The Secretary may seek assistance from the Student Activities 

and Involvement Center of the Secretary of the Registry for any 
Campus Pulse or election related issues. 

•  The Executive Board shall use the time in between the election and the end of their terms 

to train the newly elected officers. 

•  The newly elected officers shall take power following the final day of classes of the 

Spring semester. 

• 

If any issues arise during this process, or if any member wishes to appeal the results, the 
question may be taken by any member or officer to the Student Judiciary. 

VI. Removal of Officers 

•  Any officer may be impeached from officer for failure to perform the duties of their 

office or for conduct that is detrimental to the group. 

•  The following procedure must be followed in order for an officer to be impeached: 

o  A motion must be made and seconded during an official and regularly scheduled 

general body meeting to impeach an officer. 

o  At the following general body meeting, the member making the motion of 

impeachment shall have fifteen minutes to present their case against the officer. 
This shall be the time to present any evidence and/or witnesses relevant to the 
impeachment. These fifteen minutes shall not be interrupted for any reason, other 
than if the petitioner decides to take questions from the membership. 

o  Following the presentation of evidence from the petitioner, the accused officer 
will have fifteen minutes to present their defense and any evidence or witnesses 
they wish. These fifteen minutes shall not be interrupted for any reason, other 
than if the officer decides to take questions from the general membership. 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 •  Following the presentations from the petitioner and the accused officer, a vote shall be 

taken, two thirds of the general membership must vote in favor of impeachment in order 
for an officer to be removed. 

• 

• 

• 

If the voting results in impeachment, the officer shall immediately surrender his or her 
office.  

If the officer in question is the President, the meeting in which the impeachment is 
considered shall be chaired by the Vice President. 

If any issues arise during this process, or if either party wishes to appeal the results, the 
question may be taken by any member or officer to the Student Judiciary. 

VII. Officer Vacancies 

• 

• 

If the President resigns or is impeached, the Vice President shall immediately take over 
as President. 

If the Vice President, Treasurer, or Secretary resigns or is impeached, a special election 
shall be held for that position, following the same procedures as section V. 

•  The remaining members of the Executive Board shall schedule the special election at a 
regularly scheduled meeting between one and three weeks from the date the office 
becomes vacant. The Secretary shall inform the general membership of the date of the 
special election no less than one-week prior. 

VIII. Resolving Disputes 

•  Disputes arising between members on matters of RSO policy shall be dealt with through 

majority votes of the general membership. 

•  Disputes arising between members on other matters shall be dealt with through 

mediation: 

o  Mediation consists of a meeting involving both parties and a mediator with the 

purpose of coming to a solution and putting the issue to rest. 

o  The President shall mediate disputes between members. 

o  Should the President be involved in the dispute, or should either party not be 

satisfied by the result of the mediation, any party may request that the Secretary 
of the Registry mediate. The results of mediation with the Secretary of the 
Registry shall be final. 

IX. Free Speech 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 •  All members of the Hip-Hop Culture Organization are entitled to freedom of speech and 
will not under any circumstances be deprived of the opportunity to share their opinions 
with the group. 

X. Amendment 

•  This organization may be amended by a two-thirds vote of the general membership at a 

regularly scheduled meeting. 

o  A motion to amend may be made and seconded by any member at a meeting of 
the general membership. The motion shall be presented at the meeting in which 
the motion is made. Voting on the motion shall take place at the following 
meeting. Prior to voting, the President shall allow for a period of debate. 

•  After being approved by the membership, the amendment itself, and an updated version 

of the Constitution, shall be submitted to the Secretary of the Registry for final approval.

Hip Hop Culture Organization

Established September 2006 in Amherst, MA

I. Mission Statement

We’re on a mission to spread the positive aspects of the Hip-Hop culture throughout the Five College area, as well as to promote the Hip-Hop scene in the Western New England area and bridge connections with the Boston Area.

II. Membership

All students at the University of Massachusetts Amherst and the general public shall be eligible to be members of the Hip-Hop Culture Organization.

III. Meetings

The Hip-Hop Culture Organization shall have general meetings on a weekly basis.

The meetings shall be chaired by the President, Vice President, Treasurer, and Secretary.

The purpose of the meetings shall be:

Group bonding
Planning activities (Performances, fundraisers, etc.)
Other topics deemed necessary

Decisions will be made at meetings by a majority vote of the general membership.

IV. The Executive Board

The officers of the Hip-Hop Culture Organization shall be:
President
Vice President
Treasurer
Secretary

Officers shall serve a term of one year, starting the day after the last day of classes in the Spring semester.

Officers shall be eligible for re-election to multiple terms.

The President
	
The President shall be the Chief Executive Officer of the RSO. He or she shall be responsible for all aspects of the functioning of the group.

The President shall have Signature Responsibility.

The Vice President

The Vice President shall be the second in command of the RSO.

The Vice President shall take over the President when he or she is not present.

The Vice President shall be the liaison between the Hip-Hop Culture Organization and the SGA, Student Activities and Involvement, and other campus offices.

The Treasurer

The Treasurer shall be the Chief Financial Officer of the RSO. 

The Treasurer shall be responsible for maintaining the group’s finances.

The Treasurer shall be responsible for submitting an annual budget request to the SGA, if necessary.

The Treasurer shall have Signature Responsibility.

The Secretary

The Secretary shall be responsible for maintaining all records of the RSO.

All advertising, and other documents relevant the functioning of the group shall be considered records.

These records shall, in all possible cases, be collected electronically and shall be passed on from the current to the future Secretary during the transition period.
		
The Secretary shall record all official group meetings.

The Secretary shall maintain up to date membership lists.

The Secretary shall be responsible for maintaining the group’s social media and Campus Pulse pages.

V. Officer Elections

Officers’ elections shall take place during the month of April.

Officer elections shall take place in two stages: the nomination meeting and the election period.

The nomination meeting shall be the first meeting of April.

The Executive board shall announce the exact date, time, and location of the nominating meeting no later than two weeks prior.

The nominating meeting will be run according to the follow procedure:

Any non-election business shall be dealt with first.

Once all other business is taken care of, the President shall announce the nomination to be open.

During the nomination period, any voting member shall nominate any voting member, including themselves, to a position:

In order for the nomination to be official, it shall need to be seconded by another voting member.

A voting member may only be nominated to one position.

The nomination period shall remain open until a motion is made, seconded, and approved by unanimous consent, to close nominations.

After the nomination period is closed, the President will read the names of the candidates who have been nominated. Each member nominated may then chose to accept or reject the nomination.

All nominees that have accepted the nomination will be given the opportunity to address the general membership for five minutes, and to take questions from the membership for five minutes. The nominees for President will go first, followed by Vice President, Treasurer, and Secretary. The nominees will present first by position and then by the order in which they were nominated.

The second phase of the electron shall be the election period, and it shall adhere to the following procedure:

Directly following the nominating meeting, the Secretary shall set up another group meeting, the following week after the nominating period. He or she shall include the names of the members that have been nominated at the nominating meetings; only nominated members may be elected.

The election shall be open from the start of the election meeting to the end of the election meeting.

Following the closing of the election period, the Secretary shall prepare an election report, including the winners and the total vote counts for each candidate. This report shall be presented by the Secretary at the meeting directly following the closing of the elections. The Secretary shall ensure only voting members have voted. If any non-member shall have voted, the election will be deemed invalid and the election period will be re-done, under the supervision of the Secretary of the Registry.

The Secretary may seek assistance from the Student Activities and Involvement Center of the Secretary of the Registry for any Campus Pulse or election related issues.

The Executive Board shall use the time in between the election and the end of their terms to train the newly elected officers.

The newly elected officers shall take power following the final day of classes of the Spring semester.

If any issues arise during this process, or if any member wishes to appeal the results, the question may be taken by any member or officer to the Student Judiciary.

VI. Removal of Officers

Any officer may be impeached from officer for failure to perform the duties of their office or for conduct that is detrimental to the group.

The following procedure must be followed in order for an officer to be impeached:

A motion must be made and seconded during an official and regularly scheduled general body meeting to impeach an officer.

At the following general body meeting, the member making the motion of impeachment shall have fifteen minutes to present their case against the officer. This shall be the time to present any evidence and/or witnesses relevant to the impeachment. These fifteen minutes shall not be interrupted for any reason, other than if the petitioner decides to take questions from the membership.

Following the presentation of evidence from the petitioner, the accused officer will have fifteen minutes to present their defense and any evidence or witnesses they wish. These fifteen minutes shall not be interrupted for any reason, other than if the officer decides to take questions from the general membership.

Following the presentations from the petitioner and the accused officer, a vote shall be taken, two thirds of the general membership must vote in favor of impeachment in order for an officer to be removed.

If the voting results in impeachment, the officer shall immediately surrender his or her office. 

If the officer in question is the President, the meeting in which the impeachment is considered shall be chaired by the Vice President.

If any issues arise during this process, or if either party wishes to appeal the results, the question may be taken by any member or officer to the Student Judiciary.

VII. Officer Vacancies

If the President resigns or is impeached, the Vice President shall immediately take over as President.

If the Vice President, Treasurer, or Secretary resigns or is impeached, a special election shall be held for that position, following the same procedures as section V.

The remaining members of the Executive Board shall schedule the special election at a regularly scheduled meeting between one and three weeks from the date the office becomes vacant. The Secretary shall inform the general membership of the date of the special election no less than one-week prior.

VIII. Resolving Disputes

Disputes arising between members on matters of RSO policy shall be dealt with through majority votes of the general membership.

Disputes arising between members on other matters shall be dealt with through mediation:

Mediation consists of a meeting involving both parties and a mediator with the purpose of coming to a solution and putting the issue to rest.

The President shall mediate disputes between members.

Should the President be involved in the dispute, or should either party not be satisfied by the result of the mediation, any party may request that the Secretary of the Registry mediate. The results of mediation with the Secretary of the Registry shall be final.

IX. Free Speech

All members of the Hip-Hop Culture Organization are entitled to freedom of speech and will not under any circumstances be deprived of the opportunity to share their opinions with the group.

X. Amendment

This organization may be amended by a two-thirds vote of the general membership at a regularly scheduled meeting.

A motion to amend may be made and seconded by any member at a meeting of the general membership. The motion shall be presented at the meeting in which the motion is made. Voting on the motion shall take place at the following meeting. Prior to voting, the President shall allow for a period of debate.

After being approved by the membership, the amendment itself, and an updated version of the Constitution, shall be submitted to the Secretary of the Registry for final approval.

DocsList.Name: ACS UMass Amherst Charter (Updated 2023).docx
DocsList.Data:
ACS UMass Amherst Chapter
Club Charter

ACS Charter Mission: 
The mission of the Student Chapter of the ACS is to aid students in acquiring the many skills required of those looking to make a career in the fields directly and indirectly related to chemistry. It aims to develop leadership, networking, presentation, and planning skills amongst its members. Additionally, the Student Chapter of the ACS aims to facilitate member access to conferences, faculty and research. 

A. Election process
Voting for elected positions will occur on Campus Pulse for a period lasting two weeks after students present their platforms in a meeting mid-Spring semester.
Issues involving commitment by elected officers will be monitored and discussed by other officers. After discussion between this officer and other officers, the position will become open for re-election if the officer in question does not improve their behavior.

B. Officer positions
President (SR) – Makes decisions based on feedback from members and officers. Oversees that necessary procedures are taken to meet chapter goals such as: booking rooms, planning outreach and fundraising events, inviting professors to give talks, applying for funding, providing educational and career development opportunities to members. The president should maintain communication between officers and to club members, and delegate to make sure that all administrative tasks are completed. 

 Vice President – Assists and supports the president with logistical procedures to achieve the above goals. Additionally, the VP should organize recruitment, engagement, and outreach events, as well as coordinate with other clubs on joint efforts.

Treasurer (SR) – Manages funds, advises on spending decisions. Keeps track of potential sources of funding. All spending must go through the treasurer, and the treasurer should be consulted on any spending decisions. Considerations include: pizza for meetings, fundraising events (collecting profits, reimbursing members for bake sale ingredients), and coordinating payment for club activities, conferences, etc. 

Secretary – Maintains correspondences on behalf of the chapter. Manages chapter gmail and google drive accounts. Keeps record of meetings, and files the records in the google drive account. Also responsible for keeping a calendar and entering it in the Student Chapter Report 

Social Media and Communications Coordinator – Maintains correspondences on behalf of the chapter. Manages chapter gmail and social media accounts.

Note: while these are the official roles, it is encouraged that officers divide work as evenly as possible. Each officer should have an area of expertise, but running the chapter should be more cooperative than hierarchical. 

C. Conflict resolution 
Member benefits will be awarded based on a point system for participation. Disputes will be handled by the officers, and brought to members for discussion if necessary.

D. Free speech and expression
Members are free to voice their opinions in ways that respect themselves, others, and the chapter.
 
E. Meetings
Meetings generally consist of a combination of one or more: a research talk given by faculty, a panel, chapter discussions, planning and brainstorming.
Other events include outreach and social events.

 F. Record keeping
The secretary keeps records of meetings, ‘Meeting Minutes’ and maintains records in the google drive account
Each officer is responsible for maintaining a document in the google drive account that outlines their responsibilities and the best procedures to complete their role in the chapter. 

G. Amending the charter 
Potential changes will be brought before members and voted on with a 50% +1 vote indicating success of the vote.
 
F. Transition plan
After elections in early to mid spring, newly elected e-board members will shadow their incumbent counterparts. This includes: addition to the officer group chat, participating in e-board meetings, having at least one officer-elect present to observe any official business, and CCing on all official emails to introduce officer-elects to the logistics of running the club.

E. Meetings 
     1. Meetings generally consist of a combination of one or more: a research talk given by 
faculty, a panel, chapter discussions, planning and brainstorming. 
     2. Other events include outreach and social events. 

F. Record keeping 
     1. The secretary keeps records of meetings, ‘Meeting Minutes’ and maintains records in the 
google drive account 
     2. Each officer is responsible for maintaining a document in the google drive account that 
outlines their responsibilities and the best procedures to complete their role in the chapter. 

G. Amending the charter 
     1. Potential changes will be brought before members and voted on with a 50% +1 vote 
indicating success of the vote. 

F. Transition plan 
     1. After elections in early to mid spring, newly elected e-board members will shadow their 
incumbent counterparts. This includes: addition to the officer group chat, participating in e-board 
meetings, having at least one officer-elect present to observe any official business, and CCing on 
all official emails to introduce officer-elects to the logistics of running the club.

DocsList.Name: UAC_Charter.docx
DocsList.Data:
UMass Arabs Club
(UAC)


Adopted 27 February, 2015 in Amherst, MA



































Mission Statement

The UMass Arabs Club’s (UAC) mission is to enhance awareness of Arab culture and heritage. We strive to create a tightly knit community where we can network and provide lasting support for each other to succeed academically, socially, financially, emotionally, and as students of our desired fields of study. 
The UAC holds various events throughout the academic year, some of which include film screenings, lectures, comedy shows, hookah nights, dances, socials, and most notably the annual Arab Cultural Night held every year.
Official membership for this club is open to ANYONE who is interested in Arab culture (language, art, music, dance, food, politics, etc). You DO NOT have to speak Arabic to be apart of the club. 













Membership
All students at the University of Massachusetts Amherst and the general public shall be eligible to be members of UAC.
Only University of Massachusetts Amherst undergraduates shall be eligible to vote.
Membership shall be established after a prospective member attends two meetings and informs the Secretary that they wish to be a member.
Meetings
UAC shall have general meetings on a bi-weekly basis.
Meetings shall be chaired by the President.
The purpose of the meetings shall be:
Group bonding
Planning activities
Watching Arabic videos
Other topics deemed necessary
Decisions will be made at meetings by a majority vote of the general membership.
Quorum (50% +1) of the voting membership must be present in order for votes to be taken.
The Executive Board
The officers of UAC shall be:
President
Vice President
Treasurer
Secretary
Officer shall serve a term of one year, starting the day after the last day of classes in the spring semester.
1. Founding officers will remain in position until they leave UMass Amherst. 
Officers shall be eligible for re-election to multiple terms.
The President
The President shall be the Chief Executive Officer of the RSO. He or she shall be responsible for all aspects of the functioning of the group.
The President shall have Signature Responsibility. 
The Vice President
The Vice President shall be the second in command of the RSO. 
The Vice President shall take over for the President when he or she is not present.
The Vice President shall be the liaison between UAC and the SGA, Student Activities and Involvement, and other campus offices.
The Treasurer
The Treasurer shall be the Chief Financial Officer of the RSO.
The Treasurer shall be responsible for maintaining the group’s finances.
The Treasurer shall be responsible for submitting an annual budget request to the SGA, if necessary.
The Treasurer shall have Signature Responsibility.
The Secretary
The Secretary shall be responsible for maintaining all records for the RSO.
All minutes, advertising, and other documents relevant the functioning of the group shall be considered records.
These records shall, in all possible cases, be collected electronically and shall be passed on from the current to the future Secretary during the transition period.
The Secretary shall record minutes at all official group meetings.
The Secretary shall maintain up to date membership lists.
The Secretary shall be responsible for maintaining the group’s social media and Campus Pulse pages.
Officer Elections
Officer elections shall take place during the month of March.
Officer elections shall take place in two stages: the nomination meeting and the online election.
The nomination meeting shall be the first meeting in March.
The Executive Board shall announce the exact date, time, and location of the nominating meeting no later than two weeks prior.
The nominating meeting will be run according to the following procedure:
Any non-election business shall be dealt with first.
Once all other business is taken care of, the President shall announce nomination to be open. 
During the nomination period, any voting member shall nominate any voting member, including themselves, to a position.
In order for the nomination to be official, it shall need to be seconded by another voting member.
A voting member may only be nominated to one position.
The nomination period shall remain open until a motion is made, seconded, and approved by unanimous consent, to close nominations.
After the nomination period is closed, the President will read from the minutes the names of the candidates who have been nominated. Each member nominated may then chose to accept or reject the nomination.
All nominees that have accepted the nomination will be given the opportunity to address the general membership for 5 minutes, and to take questions from the membership for 5 minutes. The nominees for President will go first, followed by Vice President, Treasurer, and Secretary. The nominees will present first by position and then by the order in which they were nominated.
The second phase of the election shall be the online election period, and it shall adhere to the following procedure.
Directly following the nominating meeting, the Secretary shall set up an election on the group’s Campus Pulse page. He or she shall include only the names of the members that have nominated at the nomination meeting; only nominated members may be elected.
The election shall be open from the day after the nominating meeting to the day prior to the next scheduled meeting. 
* The current officers of the club have to approve the elected nominee*
Following the close of the election period, the Secretary shall prepare an election report, including the winners and the total vote counts for each candidate. This report shall be presented by the Secretary at the meeting directly following the closing of elections. The Secretary shall also view the vote report available on Campus Pulse to ensure that only voting members have voted. If any non-member shall have voted, the election will be deemed invalid and the election period will be re-done, under the supervision of the Secretary of the Registry.
The Secretary may seek assistance from the Student Activities and Involvement Center of the Secretary of the Registry for any Campus Pulse or election related issues.
The Executive Board shall use the time in between the election and the end of their terms to train the newly elected officers.
The newly elected officers shall take power following the final day of classes of the Spring semester.
If any issues arise during this process, or if any member wishes to appeal the results, the question may be taken by any member or officer to the Student Judiciary.
Removal of Officers
Any officer may be impeached from office for failure to perform the duties of their office or for conduct that is detrimental to the group.
The following procedure must be followed in order for an officer to be impeached:
A motion must be made and seconded during an official and regularly scheduled general body meeting to impeach an officer.
At the following general body meeting, the member making the motion of impeachment shall have 15 minutes to present their case against the officer. This shall be the time to present any evidence and/or witnesses relevant to the impeachment. These 15 minutes shall not be interrupted for any reason, other than if the petitioner decides to take questions from the membership.
Following the presentation of evidence from the petitioner, the accused officer will have 15 minutes to present their defense and any evidence or witnesses they wish. These 15 minutes shall not be interrupted for any reason, other than if the officer decides to take questions from the general membership.
Following the presentations from the petitioner and the accused officer, a vote shall be taken. 2/3 of the general membership must vote in favor of impeachment in order for an officer to be removed.
If the voting results in impeachment, the officer shall immediately surrender his or her office.
If the officer in question is the President, the meeting in which the impeachment is considered shall be chaired by the Vice President.
If any issues arise during this process, or if either party wishes to appeal the results, the question may be taken by any member or officer to the Student Judiciary.
Officer Vacancies
If the President resigns or is impeached, the Vice President shall immediately take over as President.
If the Vice President, Treasurer, or Secretary resigns or is impeached, a special election shall be held for that position, following the same procedures as section IV of this charter.
The remaining members of the Executive Board shall schedule a the special election at a regularly scheduled meeting between 1 and 3 weeks from the date the office become vacant. The Secretary shall inform the general membership of the date of the special election no less than 1 week prior.
Resolving Disputes
Disputes arising between members on matters of RSO policy shall be dealt with through majority votes of the general membership.
Disputes arising between members on other matters shall be dealt with through mediation.
Mediation consists of a meeting involving both parties and a mediator with the purpose of coming to a solution and putting the issue to rest.
The President shall mediate disputes between members.
Should the President be involved in the dispute, or should either party no be satisfied by the result of the mediation, any party may request that the Secretary of the Registry mediate. The results of mediation with the Secretary of the Registry shall be final.
 Free Speech
All members of UAC are entitled to freedom of speech and will not under any circumstances be deprived of the opportunity to share their opinion with the group. 
Amendment
This charter may be amended by a 2/3 vote of the general membership at a regularly scheduled meeting.
A motion to amend may be made and seconded by any member at a meeting of the general membership. The motion shall be presented at the meeting in which the motion is made. Voting on the motion shall take place at the following meeting. Prior to voting, the President shall allow for a period of debate.
After being approved by the membership, the amendment itself, and an updated version of the Charter, shall be submitted to the Secretary of the Registry for final approval.

DocsList.Data:
UMass Archery Club Constitution
 
I.      	Purpose
 
The purpose of UMass Archery Club is to make archery a safe and enjoyable part of student recreational life, whether they have no prior experience or are advanced, veteran archers.
 
II.    	Safety Measures

Stay behind the safety line (marked by bright colored spray paint) until an officer says it is safe to cross the line to pick up arrows
Bows remain pointed towards the ground or Target only, with the exception of express permission for instructional purposes. They are never to be pointed towards people.
Make sure everyone has elbow room when shooting. In case practices get crowded, we will not let everyone shoot at once and use a rotating group system for safety and efficiency.
While retrieving arrows, bows are left behind the shooting line.
Bows are not to be held on the line until everyone has returned from retrieving and the range is deemed clear.
Obey officer commands at all times. Only shoot when an officer says so, only retrieve arrows when an officer says so.
 
Any violation of these rules may result in being asked to leave practice and a warning may be given. After a second instance where a warning must be given, membership may be revoked permanently. If any injuries result, that will result in an automatic dismissal from practice and the club. This is enforced through the paper and digital roster system (see section VI regarding roster), as well as requiring a school ID to be shown at practice.
 
III.   	Practice Location
 
The field is owned by the Physical Plant, who consented to using the land for practice. It is along Mullins Way, across from the athletic field in the Southern end of campus. For exact location, please plug in the following coordinates in google maps: 42.388203, -72.538589.
 
IV.   	Storage
 
The storage shed was built for Archery Club by the Physical Plant, also located on the practice field. It is combination locked, and only officers are given access. Members are permitted to store personal equipment, but must sign a waiver stating that if any equipment is lost or damaged, the university and any other involved parties are not responsible.
 
V.    	Public Equipment
 
Currently, the club owns the following equipment: recurve bows, compound bows, targets, arrows, and additional items such as arm guards, finger tabs, finger slings, etc. Public equipment may never leave the storage or the field, unless maintenance is needed, or unless removal has been sanctioned as part of an archery event (e.g. Archery competition). Maintenance is done by the Sattva Center for Archery Training in Florence, MA.
 
VI.   	Membership Dues Per Semester
 
No personal equipment owned: $30
Personal bow owned: $25
Personal arrows owned: $25
Both personal bows and arrows owned: $20
 
Membership rosters are updated in hard and digital copy, listing the following: Name, Student ID (All 5 Colleges may participate), School Name, Dues Paid, Waiver Signed, Safety Violations.
 
VII.  	Practice Schedule
 
Practice Schedule:
Friday 3-5 PM
Saturday 2-4 PM
Sunday 2-4 PM
 
No one is required to go to all practices, everyone comes as they please within the hours for any reason. If weather is inclement, practice may be canceled, please check the official Facebook group or contact an officer if unsure.
 
VIII.	Officer Requirements
 
In order to be recruited as an officer, a member must attend at least three practices per month and demonstrate a commitment to safety and proper archery form for teaching purposes. Friendliness and effective communication skills are vital for smooth club operations and promoting a fun and welcoming environment.
 
Officer responsibilities include: Supervising practices (calling line commands), teaching new members proper archery form, field setup and packup, communication with SA&I and SGA, storage cleaning and maintenance, and storage access.
 
Should an officer abuse storage privileges (e.g. stealing public equipment), dismissal from the club will follow.
 
IX.   	Managing Club Information
 
Club information such as practice schedules and general announcements are managed on the Facebook page titled “UMass Archers”.
 
X.    	Signing Waivers
 
Everyone is required to sign an RSO liability waiver, in that if any injuries or accidents occur, the university or any other parties are not held responsible. In addition, if personal equipment is owned and stored in the shed, one must sign a waiver in that the university or any other parties are not held responsible for damage or theft.
 
XI.   	Non-discrimination Statement

The club prohibits discrimination under Federal and State law, based on race, color, national origin, religion, sex, gender identity (including gender expression), sexual orientation, disability, age, marital status, family/parental status, income derived from a public assistance program, political beliefs, or reprisal or retaliation for prior civil rights activity. This list is not exhaustive, refer to SGA Policy for further information.

DocsList.Name: AAS MAP OF ORG F17.pdf
DocsList.Data:
ARNOLD AIR SOCIETY 
ALLAN B. BUNCE SQUADRON 
UNIVERSITY OF 
MASSACHUSETTS-AMHERST  

Mission: The Allan B. Bunce Squadron of the Arnold Air Society has 
adopted as its mission the following objectives, which enhance the Air 
Force ROTC program and project a positive image of the Air Force 
ROTC program on campus and in the Amherst community.  

a) To aid in the development of effective Air Force Officers 
b) To create a closer and more efficient relationship within AFROTC 
c) To support Aerospace Power and its role in National Security 
d) To further the traditions, purpose and concepts of the United States 
Air Force.  

To accomplish this mission, the squadron will use projects, which will 
be of a service nature. They will be conducted to promote the missions 
on a community, campus, city, national and international level.  

Executive Board Positions: Arnold Air Society spans the entire nation 
across 135 AFROTC detachments. The nation is divided into 11 Areas, 
and each area commands 8-16 Arnold Air Society squadrons. The Allan 
B. Bunce Squadron has been selected to command Area I for the 2017-
2018 school year. So in addition to our squadron staff, some of our 
members will be area staff.  

 
 
 
 
 SQUADRON STAFF: 

1.  Commander:  The Commander oversees all squadron activities. In this 

capacity, the commander will be present at all regular and special meetings. 
The commander has the responsibility and authority to execute all legislation 
lawfully enacted by the squadron or any higher unit. It shall be his/her duty 
to carry out the orders and commands from National and Area Headquarters. 
The commander is to receive full cooperation of his/her staff in keeping 
Area and National informed of the progress, plans, projects and ideas of the 
squadron. He/she is the delegate entitled to vote at all AAS Conclaves and 
Assemblies.  

•  Previous: Ryan Clark- rpclark@umass.edu 
•  Current: Emily Murray- emilymurray@umass.edu 

2.  Deputy Commander: The Deputy Commander is the second in command, 
and has authority to assume command in the absence of the commander. 
He/she shall also assume command if the position of commander is vacated. 
He/she is responsible for the coordination and activities of the squadron 
staff, for the execution of policies sent down by the commander and 
AFROTC affairs. He/she is also responsible for maintaining AFA relations 
and will serve as a liaison for Silver-Wings if a chapter develops on campus. 
In addition, he/she shall conduct an annual self-inspection of the squadron.  

•  Previous: Andrea Watson- acwatson@umass.edu 
•  Current: Dakota Delisle- dakotadelisle@icloud.com 

3.  Squadron Chief of Protocol: The Chief of Protocol promotes joint relations 
between AAS and Silver Wings and can be a key asset in developing a new 
chapter or squadron. Furthermore, the Chief of Protocol educates a squadron 
and/or chapter on basic protocol, uniform wear, etc. They report to the 
squadron commander and Area/Region Chief of Protocol. The Chief of 
Protocol does not necessarily have to be a member of Arnold Air Society, 
but rather he/she can hold said position as an Arnold Air Society or Silver 
Wings member, provided said member accepts the position.  

•  Previous: Graham Fortier-Dube- gfortierdube@umass.edu 
•  Current: Graham Fortier-Dube- gfortierdube@umass.edu 

4.  Director of Training:  The Candidate Training Officer will be responsible 
for all facets of the squadron candidate program, subject to the approved 
candidate operation plan and the commanders’ approval.  

 
 
 
 •  Previous: Leighann D'Andrea- ldandrea@umass.edu 

         Alexandre Pelletier- alexandrepel@umass.edu 

•  Current: Michael Travalent- mtravalent@umass.edu 
  Brett Autrey- bautrey.ba@gmail.com    

5.  Director of Operations: The Operations Officer is responsible for 

overseeing all projects undertaken by the squadron. He/she is responsible for 
taking suggestions from squadron members concerning possible service 
and/or fundraising projects, and studying the feasibility of such projects, and 
presenting them to the squadron. He/she is also responsible for ensuring a 
Project Action Report is completed as each project is executed.  

•  Previous: Josiah Douglas- josiahdougla@umass.edu 
•  Current: Patrick Mei- patrickmei@umass.edu 

6.  Public Affairs Officer: He/she is responsible for all public relation for the 
squadron. This includes articles sent to Area/National HQ for newsletters, 
articles in the Detachment newsletter, Excelsior, as well as other forms of 
public relations.  

•  Previous: Katie Cashin- cashin.katie5@gmail.com 
•  Current: Katie Cashin- cashin.katie5@gmail.com 

7.  Information Management Officer: The Information Management Officer 
is responsible for compiling and maintaining a telephone recall list and 
taking and distributing minutes for each meeting. He/she is also responsible 
for updating and maintaining the squadron by-laws and logistics.  

•  Previous: Jacob Francisco- jfrancisco@umass.edu 
•  Current: Victoria King- vmking@umass.edu 

8.  Financial Management Officer: The Financial Management Officer is 
responsible for maintaining all squadron financial records, preparing all 
regular financial reports such as AAS forms 3 and 9, maintenance of 
squadron checking account and payment of all bills. In addition, the 
Financial Management Officer is expected to plan and execute 2 fundraising 
events per semester with or without help from a planning committee.  

•  Previous: Emily Murray- emilymurray@umass.edu  
•  Current: Louis Huang- lehuang@umass.edu 

 
 
  
 
 
 9.  Director of Support: The Support Officer is responsible for completing the 
annual awards packet and nominating member of the month. He/she is also 
responsible for supporting the squadron in any way possible. The Support 
Officer is expected to plan and execute at least one social every month.  

•  Previous: Nicolle Vella- nicollevella7@gmail.com  
•  Current: Josiah Douglas- josiahdougla@umass.edu 

10. Webmaster: The webmaster is responsible for assuring that the website 

information is up to date and accurate. He/she will work with other squadron 
officers to ensure that this happens quickly and efficiently. Coordination 
with the cadet wing may be necessary to gain access to the website.   

•  Current: N/A 

AREA STAFF: 

1.  Commander:  
•  Current: Ryan Clark- rpclark@umass.edu 

2.  Deputy Commander:  
•  Current: Andrea Watson- acwatson@umass.edu 

3.  Area Chief of Protocol: 
•  Current: N/A 

4.  Director of Training:  
•  Current: Alexandre Pelletier- alexandrepel@umass.edu 

5.  Director of Operations: 
•  Current: Nicolle Vella- nicollevella7@gmail.com 

6.  Public Affairs Officer:  
•  Current: Jessica Joseph- jljoseph@umass.edu 

7.  Information Management Officer:  
•  Current: Jacob Francisco- jfrancisco@umass.edu 

 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 8.  Financial Management Officer:  
•  Current: Josiah Douglas- josiahdougla@umass.edu 

9.  Director of Support:  
•  Current: Wilson Chen- wilsonchen@umass.edu 

Election Process: Anyone interested in a staff position will write a letter 
expressing their desire two weeks before commander elections, typically 
three weeks before the National Conclave. Letters will be addressed to 
the current commander. Those interested in holding the position of 
squadron commander will give a brief to the squadron one week prior to 
elections. All positions of the Allan B. Bunce Squadron will be elected 
by the active membership in an annual election with at least 2/3 of the 
membership present.  

Special elections will be called by the commander if he/she plans to 
resign the position. Letters stating desire for this position will be due 
three weeks prior to the election. The commander will fill any other 
vacancies in his/her staff in a timely manner, subject to the approval of 
the squadron membership and the AAS Advisor.  

All staff positions will be replaced by new members at the conclusion of 
the National Conclave, unless a special circumstance arises where 
positions needs to be filled.
