 PREAMBLE 

As members of the Allan B. Bunce Squadron we do hereby adopt these by-laws in the interest of 
affirming and furthering the mission of the Arnold Air Society as set forth in the National 
Constitution (AASMAN-1). 

Section 1.  Definition of Mission. 

ARTICLE I 

The Allan B. Bunce Squadron of the Arnold Air Society has adopted as its mission the following 
objectives, which enhance the AFROTC program and project a positive image of the AFROTC 
program on campus and in the Amherst community. 

a)  To aid in the development of effective Air Force Officers 

b)  To create a closer and more efficient relationship within AFROTC 

c)  To support Aerospace Power and its role in National Security 

d)  To further the traditions, purpose and concepts of the United States Air Force. 

Section 2.  Fulfillment of Mission 

To accomplish this mission, the squadron will use projects, which will be of a service nature. 
They will be conducted to promote the missions on a community, campus, city, national and 
international level. 

Section 1.  Scope of Membership 

ARTICLE II 

The Allan B. Bunce Squadron, as a chartered squadron, is an organization of select AFROTC 
cadets of Detachment 370 at the University of Massachusetts Amherst. Cadets volunteer for the 
candidate program and individual members are inducted based on personal merit, academic 
performance, leadership abilities, and successful completion of the candidate program. 

Section 2.  Membership 

Any cadet who satisfies the requirements below qualifies to become a member of the Allan 
B. Bunce Squadron. Membership is not contingent upon sex, race, creed or national origin. 

a)  Must be enrolled in the AFROTC program as either a GMC or POC cadet 

b)  Must have at least a 2.50 GPA overall in all college courses 

3 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 c)  Must satisfactorily complete an interview or attend a squadron meeting to further 
familiarize themselves with AAS, its function and requirements. 

d)  Members transferring from another squadron will be granted membership. 

Section 3.  Induction 

All active members are required to attend the induction ceremony in service dress uniform or 
civilian equivalent. The squadron will use the induction ceremony stated in AASMAN-1, 
Attachment 2. The date for the induction ceremony will be determined by Commander and 
Candidate Training Officer. 

Section 1.  Active Membership 

ARTICLE III 

Active members or “actives” are those members who are currently participating in all squadron 
functions and are currently up to date on all financial obligations to the squadron. These 
members are eligible for all staff positions and benefits relating to the squadron. These members 
are also bound to the responsibilities and obligations associated with the squadron. These 
members will also wear either the AAS Pin and AAS fourrager while in blues and service dress 
uniform or other another organizational chord/fourrager. 

a)  Once members have achieved “active” membership, he or she is expected to perform the 
following. 

1)  Must attend at least 80% of all squadron activities to include meetings/social events. If 
a cadet falls below 80% attendance, they must complete make-up work determined by the 
squadron commander.  

2)  Actively encourage others to join. 

Section 2.  Inactive Membership 

Those members who wish to disengage from active membership in the squadron are designated 
as “inactive members.” These members are non-voting members, however, they may attend 
meetings. If they wish to regain their membership at a future time, they must continue to pay 
national and area dues. If they wish to retain their AFA membership, they must continue to pay 
those dues. Once a member becomes inactive, he/she is prohibited from wearing any AAS rank 
or fourrager for the duration of inactive status. 

a)  To become inactive, a letter stating their desire should be sent to the Information 
Management Officer. A member may be forced to go to inactive status if:  

1)  Their cumulative GPA falls below a 2.50 or forced to go on academic probation either 
by the university or by ROTC. 

4 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 2)  They accumulate more than two unexcused absences from a squadron activity or 
meeting. 

3)  A 2/3 vote of the squadron due to failure to actively participate in AAS functions, 
failure to carry out AAS objectives, failure to carry out AAS financial obligations, or if 
they hinder the squadron’s ability to carry out the mission.  

b)  The length of inactive status will be determined by the commander. It shall not exceed 
one semester. 

Section 3.  Honorary Membership 

The highest tribute that the squadron can pay an individual is to extend him/her the title of 
Honorary Member in the Allan B. Bunce Squadron. The Honorary Membership is good for life 
and is contingent on the unanimous decision of the Allan B. Bunce Squadron. 

Section 4.  Candidate Program 

The squadron Candidate Training Officer shall run the candidate program in accordance with 
the squadron candidate manual and other manuals superseding it. He/she shall adhere to the 
following. 

a)  Social Event. Prior to the start of the program, at least one social event or one formal 
interest meeting should be held. 

b)  Selection. Selection of members should not disclude anyone who has shown an avid 
interest. Only self-elimination or a 2/3 vote of the squadron will disenroll members. 
Members may be disenrolled due to failure to meet all requirements of the candidate program 
as a last resort where no other course of action can be taken. 

c)  Candidate Program (refer to the Squadron Candidate Manual) 

d)  Induction. Induction will be held soon after the test is given, subject to availability of a 
place to hold it. It shall be conducted in accordance with Article 2, Section 4 of the Squadron 
By-Laws and AASMAN-1 Section 2. 

Section 5.  Probation 

Unless overruled by a 2/3 squadron vote, any member who has been placed on academic 
probation by the university or has academic problems within ROTC must restrict their AAS 
activities and become inactive. If the member on probation is an AAS officer, he/she must resign 
the position for the duration of the probation period. This can only be overruled by the squadron 
once per member. 

Section 6.  Cadet Corps Positions 

5 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 As per AASMAN-1, AAS activities will not conflict with any position within the cadet corps. 

Section 1.  Squadron Headquarters 

ARTICLE IV 

The squadron shall be commanded by an AAS C/Major and his/her staff. The chain of command 
with respective rank is as follows: 

Commander (AAS/Maj.) 
Deputy Commander (AAS/Capt.) 
Chapter-Squadron Chief of Protocol (AAS/Capt.) 

Director of Training (AAS/Capt) 
Director of Operations (AAS/1Lt.) 
Public Affairs Officer (AAS/1Lt) 
Information Management Officer (AAS/1Lt) 
Financial Management Officer (AAS/1Lt) 
Director of Support AAS/1Lt) 
Webmaster (AAS/1Lt) 

Section 2.  Staff Duties 

a)  Squadron Commander (AAS/CC) 

The Commander oversees all squadron activities. In this capacity, the commander will be 
present at all regular and special meetings. The commander has the responsibility and 
authority to execute all legislation lawfully enacted by the squadron or any higher unit. It 
shall be his/her duty to carry out the orders and commands from National and Area 
Headquarters. The commander is to receive full cooperation of his/her staff in keeping Area 
and National informed of the progress, plans, projects and ideas of the squadron. He/she is 
the delegate entitled to vote at all AAS Conclaves and Assemblies. 

b)  Deputy Commander (AAS/CD) 

The Deputy Commander is the second in command, and has authority to assume command in 
the absence of the commander. He/she shall also assume command if the position of 
commander is vacated. He/she is responsible for the coordination and activities of the 
squadron staff, for the execution of policies sent down by the commander and AFROTC 
affairs. He/she is also responsible for maintaining AFA relations and will serve as a liaison 
for Silver-Wings if a chapter develops on campus. In addition, he/she shall conduct an annual 
self-inspection of the squadron. 

c)  Chapter/Squadron Chief of Protocol (AAS/CSCOP) 

6 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The CSCOP promotes joint relations between AAS and Silver Wings and can be a key asset 
in developing a new chapter or squadron. Furthermore, the CSCOP educates a squadron 
and/or chapter on basic protocol, uniform wear, etc. They report to the squadron commander 
and Area/Region Chief of Protocol. The CSCOP does not necessarily have to be a member of 
Arnold Air Society, but rather he/she can hold said position as an Arnold Air Society or 
Silver Wings member, provided said member accepts the position. 

d)  Director of Training/Candidate Training Officer (AAS/CTO) 

The Candidate Training Officer will be responsible for all facets of the squadron candidate 
program, subject to the approved candidate operation plan and the commanders’ approval. 

e)  Director of Operations (AAS/DO) 

The Operations Officer is responsible for overseeing all projects undertaken by the squadron. 
He/she is responsible for taking suggestions from squadron members concerning possible 
service and/or fundraising projects, and studying the feasibility of such projects, and 
presenting them to the squadron. He/she is also responsible for ensuring a Project Action 
Report is completed as each project is executed. 

f)  Public Affairs Officer (AAS/PA) 

He/she is responsible for all public relation for the squadron. This includes articles sent to 
Area/National HQ for newsletters, articles in the Detachment newsletter, Excelsior, as well 
as other forms of public relations. 

g)  Information Management Officer (AAS/IM) 

The Information Management Officer is responsible for compiling and maintaining a 
telephone recall list and taking and distributing minutes for each meeting. He/she is also 
responsible for updating and maintaining the squadron by-laws and logistics. 

h)  Financial Management Officer (AAS/FM) 

The Financial Management Officer is responsible for maintaining all squadron financial 
records, preparing all regular financial repots such as AAS forms 3 and 9, maintenance of 
squadron checking account and payment of all bills. In addition, the Financial Management 
Officer is expected to plan and execute 2 fundraising events per semester with or without 
help from a planning committee. 

i)  Director of Support (AAS/DS) 

The Support Officer is responsible for completing the annual awards packet and nominating 
member of the month. He/she is also responsible for supporting the squadron in any way 
possible. The Support Officer is expected to plan and execute at least one social every month. 

7 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 j)  Webmaster (AAS/Webmaster) 

The webmaster is responsible for assuring that the website information is up to date and 
accurate. He/she will work with other squadron officers to ensure that this happens quickly 
and efficiently. Coordination with the cadet wing may be necessary to gain access to the 
website. 

Section 3.  Change of Officers 

All staff positions will be replaced by new members at the conclusion of NATCON, unless a 
special circumstance arises where positions needs to be filled. 

Section 4.  Regular Election 

Any one interested in a staff position will write a letter expressing their desire two weeks before 
commander elections, typically three weeks before NATCON. Letters will be addressed to the 
current commander. Those interested in holding the position of squadron commander will give a 
brief to the squadron one week prior to elections. All positions of the Allan B. Bunce Squadron 
will be elected by the active membership in an annual election with at least 2/3 of the 
membership present. 

Section 5.  Vacancies 

Special elections will be called by the commander if he/she plans to resign the position. Letters 
stating desire for this position will be due three weeks prior to the election. The commander will 
fill any other vacancies in his/her staff in a timely manner, subject to the approval of the 
squadron membership and the AAS Advisor. 

Section 6.  Resignation 

Any officer within the squadron may submit his/her resignation to the Squadron Commander for 
reasons which he/she is not bound to disclose. Resignation from a particular office does not bar 
him/her form holding any office at a later date. 

Section 7.  Dismissal 

Any staff officer within the squadron may be dismissed by the commander for the improper 
conduct, neglect of duty, or failure to carry out the objectives of AAS. All dismissals are subject 
to approval by 2/3 the squadron and the AAS Advisor. 

Section 8.  Impeachment 

Impeachment is the formal accusation that an AAS Commander’s conduct has been improper, 
that he/she is neglecting his/her duty or that he/she has failed to carry out the objectives of AAS. 
Impeachment requires a 2/3 vote of all active members and a certification by the AAS Advisor. 

8 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 A copy of the Impeachment meeting minutes shall be sent to Area HQ. Impeachment may be 
appealed directly to the National Commander who is the final authority. 

Section 1.  Regular Meetings 

ARTICLE V 

The Allan B. Bunce Squadron will hold meetings during the academic year, on a schedule 
determined by the Commander. A regular meeting time will be established at the first meeting of 
each semester. These meetings will be used to discuss squadron projects and policies. 

Section 2.  Special Meetings 

The commander may call special meetings at any time as long as either: 

a)  Notification was posted five days in advance 

b)  An attempt to notify all members is made and 2/3 of the squadron are contacted. 

Special meetings constitute any of the following types: staff, joint business, and any other 
meetings that are not scheduled or considered regular. 

Section 3.  Regular Meeting Procedures 

a)  The commander calls the meeting to order. 

b)  Meeting topics will be addressed in the order of the commander’s discretion or by order 
of the meeting agenda created and distributed by the IM 

c)  Discussion of any ideas or issues within the squadron left unspoken for. This time is 
expected to be provided after all the proposed business has been taken care of.  

d)  The commander adjourns the meeting. 

Section 4.  Amendments 

a)  Amendments to the squadron are subject to the format outlined in the AASMAN-1 11.4.4 
and Robert’s Rules of Order. 

Section 5.  Attendance Policy 

Attendance at all squadron meetings and functions will be mandatory. If a member cannot 
possibly make a meeting, he/she must notify the commander of such a problem NLT 48 hours 
prior to the meeting or event. The commander will then rule if it is excusable. If it is excusable, 
no further action will be taken. If is not a valid excuse or no excuse is given for an absence, the 
following will occur. 

9 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 a)  The unexcused absence will be recorded and monitored by the IM 

b)  If more than two absences are reached per semester, the member will automatically 
become inactive. 

If an emergency condition exists, a letter of explanation will be turned in NLT 48 hours after the 
meeting or event unless otherwise noted by the Commander. Any member needing to leave a 
meeting early must notify the Commander at least one day prior to the meeting. 

Section 1.  Squadron Level Awards and Policies 

ARTICLE VI 

a)  The Arnold Air Society Medal. This medal is awarded to the outstanding members of the 
Society for distinguished service or achievement. The ribbon color is half-blue and half-gold. 
Procurement information is found in the AASMAN-1, paragraph 16-12. Selection is decided 
upon by the Commander and the AAS Advisor. Presentation is optional in any year. 

b)  The Arnold Air Society Medallion. The AAS Medallion is designated for presentation to 
AAS members and others for distinguished service (in lieu of certificates of appreciation). 
The medallion color is bronze. Procurement information is found in AASMAN-1, paragraph 
16-12. Selection is by the AAS Commander and the AAS Advisor. Presentation is optional in 
any year. 

c)  Outstanding Cadet Award. The Outstanding Candidate Award is presented as a symbol of 
recognition to the outstanding candidate. It is presented on the night of induction. 

d)  Arnold Air Society Outstanding Member Award. This award is used to motivate AAS 
Members, so that a level of sustained high achievement can be reached and maintained and to 
reward cadets who reach the required level of performance. The award will consist of a 
certificate of appreciation, which will be presented at the Detachment 370 Awards 
Ceremony. The Outstanding Member will be determined by the Commander and Vice 
Commander and voted on by a majority vote of the squadron. The following is required to 
achieve this award.  

1)  Must be an active member. 

2)  Must have at least a 2.5 GPA 

3)  Must be caught up on all financial requirements 

4)  Must have demonstrated outstanding service in the community, above average ability 
to work with others, and excellence work within the squadron. In addition, the recipient 
must have good oral and written communication skills. 

10 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Section 2.  Area Level Awards and Honors 

In compliance with Section VIII of the Area Manual, the squadron shall nominate members for 
Area Awards. The Deputy Commander, Information Management Officer, and one squadron 
member at large will form the committee. The Commander shall be the Chairman, with the AAS 
Advisor as and “ex officio” member. They shall write up the award nominations in time for 
delivery to Area HQ in time for their acceptance. 

Section 3.  National Level Awards and Honors 

The Squadron Commander shall write the nominations for the “”Outstanding Squadron 
Advisor”, the Prude Cup recommendation, and the Anderson Trophy. The committee will write 
the nominations of the other National Awards. 

Section 1.  The Definition of Quorum 

ARTICLE VII 

The number of members needed to constitute a quorum will be a simple majority of active 
members. 

Section 2.  Suspense Management 

The Deputy Commander will announce any suspense sent down by Area Headquarters. He/she 
will keep a record of compliance by requiring a courtesy email to be sent each time a suspense is 
met. Email counterpart at least 24 hours in advance in extension is needed. 

Section 3.  Correspondence 

All correspondence within squadron and Area HQ will be done via email. Any correspondence 
that needs to be mailed will be the responsibility of that individual. 

Section 4.  Project Adaptation 

New project ideas will be discussed at each meeting, and then decided upon by a quorum. The 
Director of Operations will then assign members to coordinate various projects 

Section 5.  Corrective Action 

This section establishes a measure and means of enforcing the Squadron By-Laws and general 
conduct standards. 

a)  Executive Board. Any member may be brought before the Executive Board as deemed 
necessary by the commander. The Board will consist of the Commander, Deputy 
Commander and one active member chosen by the Commander. The board is responsible for 
obtaining the facts concerning the situation and compiling suggested corrective actions for 

11 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 the members. The Commander’s decision is final. Serious matters should be discussed with 
the AAS Advisor before any decisions are made. 

b)  Apathy. Should any member exhibit a lack of interest or concern towards the squadron 
and its mission, will result in counseling by the commander. If this attitude continues, then 
the member will be placed on inactive status. 

c)  General. Any misconduct, attitude or other problem deemed by the commander to be 
destructive or harmful to Arnold Air Society, USAF or the American Flag can constitute 
immediate action by the Commander. 

Section 6.  Authority of Squadron By-Laws 

The Allan B. Bunce Squadron By-Laws are subject to compatibility with Area Headquarters’ 
planning and policy, National Headquarters’ planning and policy, AASMAN-1, and changes in 
policy at squadron meetings.  

12 

 
 
 
 
 
 RESOLUTIONS 

RESOLUTION # 1 

September 11, 2014 

SPONSER: 

C/Major Patrick Wiggers 

Allan B. Bunce Squadron 

SUBJECT: 

Amendment Format 

WHEREAS: 

The Allan B. Bunce Squadron would like to be recognized as an RSO on 
campus  

WHEREAS: 

An RSO needs to be open to the public civilian/cadets alike 

WHEREAS: 

The AASMAN and Squadron By-Laws do not allow for civilians to be a 
member of Arnold Air Society and let it be 

RESOLVED: 

That our By-Laws be temporarily amended to allow civilians to join 
Arnold Air Society under the stipulation that a Silver Wings chapter be 
established when it becomes viable. 

13 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 RESOLUTION 

RESOLUTION #1 

7 Feb 16 

SPONSOR: 

C/Maj LeighAnn D’Andrea 

Allan B. Bunce Squadron  

SUBJECT:  

Attendance Policy  

WHEREAS: 

Section 5 of the By-Laws currently require 48 hours of notice before an 
absence. 

WHEREAS: 

Section 5 of the By-Laws currently requires a “letter of explanation” 
pertaining to the absence.  

RESOLVED: 

The By-Laws be amended to require 12 hours of notice before an absence 
in any form of communication, including up to but not limited to email, 
phone call, or text message.

DocsList.Data:
The Official
ASIAN AMERICAN
STUDENT ASSOCIATION
CONSTITUTION
2019 - 2020


As of April 15, 2019



ASIAN AMERICAN STUDENT ASSOCIATION
2019-2020 CONSTITUTION

ARTICLE I: TITLE

The title of this organization established in 1975, and as of 2019, shall be declared as the “Asian American Student Association,” or otherwise noted, “AASA.”

ARTICLE II: MISSION STATEMENT

The Asian American Student Association’s mission is:
To create a supportive atmosphere that promotes the understanding and awareness of  all Asian and Asian American students at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.
To advocate unity among Asians and Asian Americans, and surrounding communities.
To promote the views, voices, and experiences of Asian and Asian American students.
To encourage the development and growth for Asian and Asian American student expressions of cultural, social, educational, and/or political ideas through a variety of mediums, such as cultural showcases, collaborations with other RSOs, editorial pieces, and more.
The group’s goals for the next five academic years: 
To cultivate leaders among current executive board members and future young leaders. 
To stimulate dialogue regarding current social issues within, but not limited to, the Asian American and Pacific Islander community. 


ARTICLE III: MEMBERSHIP

There shall be one type of membership to allow for an inclusive organization, offering opportunities for involvement in the association to all peoples.
This membership will be known as the General Body, and is defined as follows:
General Body Members are members who show an active interest in our organization’s mission and events, which include but are not limited to, undergraduate and graduate students of the 5-College area.
Any personal information of AASA’s members may not be released or disclosed to anyone outside of AASA’s Executive Board without prior consent of the involved member. The right to privacy should be observed.
Names, addresses, and phone numbers are considered personal information.


ARTICLE IV: THE EXECUTIVE BOARD

The Officers of the Executive Board will be decided at the discretion of the currently active Executive Board. They may consist of a President, a Vice President, a Treasurer, a Secretary, an Activities Coordinator: Events, an Activities Coordinator: Logistics, an Activities Coordinator: Fundraising, two Co-Publicists, a Videographer, a Co-Media Chair: Photography, and a Co-Media Chair: Magazine. The positions and descriptions  detailed below are scribed but are not limited to: 
PRESIDENT
The President shall be the Chief Executive Officer of the Asian American Student Association.
The President shall preside over all weekly and emergency meetings and most activities with the exception of general meetings and events which shall be led by the Activities Coordinator: Events. 
If the President is absent for whatever reason, the Vice President then holds Presidential authority for that meeting or event.
The President shall delegate non-role specific responsibilities to other members of the Executive Board when necessary.
The President shall make all final decisions that shall affect the association after consultation with the Executive Board. 
When necessary, the President shall call referenda for a decision to be made among officers. 
The President shall serve as the main representative and speaker of the association.
VICE PRESIDENT
The Vice President shall be the Chief Administrative Executive Officer of the Asian American Student Association.
The Vice President shall work closely with the President and event coordinator(s) to coordinate all activities.
The Vice President shall work in place of the President should the President be unable to execute their duties.
The Vice President shall coordinate all office procedures and shall manage all duties of the office with the Secretary.
The Vice President may have Signature Responsibility.
The Vice President shall be in charge of creating a friendly and close environment for the Executive Board through monthly bonding activities that are inclusive to all Executive Board Officers.
TREASURER
The Treasurer shall be the Chief Financial Officer of the Asian American Student Association.
The Treasurer shall handle all financial transactions and shall create a working budget as requested by the Executive Board.
The Treasurer is responsible for handling the Budget Proposal for the following fiscal year.
The Treasurer shall record all financial activities of the association.
The Treasurer shall be prepared to give accurate bi-weekly reports of the financial status of the association.
Although the Activities Coordinators may put forth a proposed budget for their organized events, the Treasurer shall have the final decision for the budget of each event.
The Treasurer shall be in charge of submitting SASP requests for the events the Activities Coordinators organize. 
The Treasurer shall have Signature Reasonability.
SECRETARY
The Secretary shall be the Chief Archivist Officer of the Asian American Student Association.
The Secretary shall record the minutes of all meetings and file them in an orderly manner.
The Secretary is responsible for the timely organization and storage of minutes in the Google Drive shared folder for the respective academic year.
Meeting minutes are to include detailed and comprehensive evaluations and tips for all events. 
The Secretary shall work closely with the Executive Board to create a functioning history of the association and a complete set of archives.
The Secretary shall be in charge of the organization’s email and all matters related to the email. 
This includes but is not limited to communication with Asian Night Guest Artists. 
The Secretary shall work closely with the Vice President to create a working office environment.
The Secretary, the Vice President, and the President will have the duty of setting up office hours.
ACTIVITIES COORDINATOR: EVENTS 
The Activities Coordinator: Events shall be responsible for all general body meetings and events in the interest of the general body members. 
The Activities Coordinator shall be responsible for creating a proposal of the event including the timeline of the event and responsibilities of all Executive Board officers during the event.
This proposal shall be presented to the Executive Board at least weeks prior during a weekly meeting. 
The Activities Coordinator: Events shall publish an event page for advertising purposes at least one week in advance for General Body Meetings, and at least two weeks in advance for General Body Events. 
The Activities Coordinator: Events shall be in charge of the Asian American Student Association General Body Events, General Body Meetings, and the annual Winter Ball.
The Activities Coordinator: Events shall be responsible for working closely with the President to plan and execute the Asian Night program.
The Activities Coordinator: Events is responsible for the directing and organization of Executive Board Officers and staff their respective events (i.e., the association’s annual Winter Ball).
The Activities Coordinator: Events is also responsible for enforcing the ban on bringing attention to one’s Greek letters, which give the audience a feeling of separation, unless it is part of the performance by that group. (Participants are required to sign a contract stating so. Failure to abide by this rule will result in a one year ban from performing in Asian Night).
The Activities Coordinator: Events shall delegate responsibilities to other Executive Board Officers for the preparation and execution of their organized events.
The Activities Coordinator: Events shall be responsible for communicating with the Executive Board the details of each function/event/programming of the events that fall within their responsibility. 
The Activities Coordinator: Events shall be in constant communication with the association’s Student Activities and Involvement Cultural Council Advisor (currently Miguel Tejada). 
ACTIVITIES COORDINATOR: LOGISTICS
The Activities Coordinator: Logistics shall be responsible for booking rooms for all events, with the exception of fundraising events which will be carried out by the Activities Coordinator: Fundraising. 
They shall ensure, through communicating with the person in charge of the event, that all equipment required for said events are accounted for. 
The Activities Coordinator: Logistics shall work closely with the SA&I scheduling team.
ACTIVITIES COORDINATOR: FUNDRAISING
The Activities Coordinator: Fundraising shall be responsible for all fundraising events and the logistical obligations required for these events.
The Activities Coordinator: Fundraising shall create a new fundraising event per semester in addition to previously existing events.
PUBLICIST
The Co-Publicists shall be responsible for publicizing all of the association’s activities and events through a variety of mediums which include but are not limited to, flyers, banners, table tents, etc. 
The Co-Publicists shall be responsible for making/designing all event promotional material.
The Co-Publicists shall be responsible for presenting created promotional materials to the Executive Board at least two weeks before the planned event. 
The Co-Publicists shall coordinate with the Activities Coordinators and the Executive Board.
COMMUNITY RELATIONS CHAIR
The Community Relations Chair shall act as liaison to all other Registered Student Organizations (R.S.O.), specifically the Asian cultural R.S.O.s on campus who express common goals as this association does.
The Community Relations Chair shall be required to attend all these common goal R.S.O.s general meetings to encourage open lines of communication to the association.
The Community Relations Chair shall also be in charge of creating feedback forms for AASA events, where members can address their constructive criticisms. 
The Community Relations Chair shall work closely with the Yuri Kochiyama Cultural Center.
The Community Relations Chair shall work to create a “mentorship/team-based” program to assist with member retention and cultivating member-to-member and member-to-executive-board bonding. 
The Community Relations Chair shall be in charge of hosting events to work towards making AASA members feel more included. 
CO-MEDIA CHAIR: MAGAZINE
The Co-Media Chair: Magazine shall be in charge of creating the annual Asian American Student Association magazine. 
The creation of this magazine shall be done throughout the academic year. 
The Co-Media Chair: Magazine shall be gathering submissions from students of the University of Massachusetts Amherst with the purpose of showcasing works within the Asian/Asian-American community. 
The Co-Media Chair: Magazine shall be meeting deadlines that are set throughout the academic year in regards to the magazine and ensure that magazine is published and printed prior to Asian Night. 
The creative direction of the magazine shall be given to the Co-Media Chair: Magazine. However, feedback from the Executive Board should be taken into consideration.
The Co-Media Chair: Magazine shall take pictures in the case that the Co-Media Chair: Photographer is absent at particular events.
CO-MEDIA CHAIR: PHOTOGRAPHER
The Photographer shall be responsible for attending all of AASA’s events and taking photos during the event.
The Photographer shall be in charge of editing and publishing photos from each event onto AASA’s social media platforms within two weeks after the event. 
	     L. VIDEOGRAPHER
The Videographer shall be responsible for attending all of AASA’s events and creating short montages of these events. 
For events, including Winter Ball and Asian Night, the Videographer shall create scripts and film promotional videos for advertising purposes. 
In the case of the absence of the Co-Media Chair: Photographer and/or the Co-Media Chair: Magazine, the Videographer will be responsible for executing the Photographer’s responsibilities of taking pictures at the event.  
Each Executive Board member may have one assistant, except for the President, the Vice President, the Treasurer, and the Secretary.
Any member of this association shall be eligible to be appointed as an assistant.
Assistants shall only be appointed by the Executive Board upon New Executive Board elections at the start of every academic year. 
Assistants shall assist in the duties and responsibilities of those officers whom they are directly working with, unless otherwise specified.
The Assistants shall have Executive voting status and are encouraged to express their opinions.
All assistants are required to attend all Executive Board meetings.
Assistants shall not have Signature Responsibility.

ARTICLE V: ELECTION PROCEDURE

The officers of the Executive Board shall be re-elected by the Executive Board.
All General Body Members are eligible to run for an executive position. 
Only current officers of the Executive Board members of AASA shall be eligible to run for the positions of President and Vice President. 
The officers of the Executive Board shall fulfill each of their respective duties as defined by this constitution and by the discretion of the President. 
 It is the duty of each officer to read the distributed minutes and to receive updates when they have missed a meeting.
Strikes will be given to officers who do not perform their respective duties, at the discretion of the President and Vice President:
Two strikes upon an officer puts them in a probationary period, where they will not be able to participate in executive board duties for a duration of time, as decided by the President. 
Three strikes make an officer ineligible to run for an executive board position the following years.
Specific organizational duties of the Executive Board are contingent upon the specified roles hereby described in this constitution.
The Executive Board shall determine the amount of association dues (currently $0).
All able members of the Executive Board are required to attend AASA events and meetings unless otherwise excused.
Executive Board members are required to volunteer for at least one shift of an event otherwise stated upon individual request for absence.
Executive Board Officers are encouraged to be present for all organizational obligations (events, weekly meetings, etc.) to their fullest ability/time. 
3 unexcused absences from organizational obligations result in a strike.
Unexcused absences can be defined as:
Uncommunicated or lack of reasoning for absence 
Invalid excuse provided (up to Vice President’s discretion for deciding invalidity).
If Vice President is absent, then the President has responsibility of determining invalidity.
Excused absences include but are not limited to: 
Health-related, family-related, or other organizational related obligations.
Reasons of absences that are not listed above will be determined by the Vice President for its validity. 
The Executive Board will hold weekly meetings throughout the academic year as determined by the Executive Board.
The first meeting will consist of at least exchanging contact information, scheduling a weekly meeting time, and reading through the constitution.
Special meetings may be called by the President of the Executive Board with a minimum of 24 hours notice.
All members of the Executive Board are required to attend all Executive Board Meetings.
If unable to attend a meeting, prior notice must be given to either the President or Vice President within 24 hours before the meeting, unless otherwise excused. 
An exposed lie is considered to be an unexcused absence.
Each Executive Board member should give the speaker their full attention and respect, including no side conversations, no cell phone activity, and laptops should be closed unless given authorization by President/board.
Each Executive Board member is responsible for arriving on time to the weekly meetings.
The Secretary is responsible for recording attendance of Executive Board Officers for events and meetings. 
The Secretary will establish the agenda for all general meetings of this association. The President will preside over each of these meetings.
In order for a motion to proceed, the Executive Board must approve it.
Approval by the Executive Board shall be described as two-thirds vote of the entire board.
Approval by the Executive Board may also be described as two-thirds vote of board members present at valid Executive Board meetings.
Quorum needs to be established to validate Executive Board meetings.
Quorum shall be described as half plus one of the Executive Board.
Only the Treasurer, Vice President, and President may have Signature Responsibility.
The number of officers with active Signature Responsibility shall follow in accordance with the limits cited by the Center of Student Development (C.S.D.).
In the event that the C.S.D. changes its name/title, Article IV Section 5-A shall be observed and remain in effect with the new name/title of the C.S.D.
The Executive Board shall decide which other officer is to hold Signature Responsibility.

NOMINATIONS
The Official Nominations done at the end of the academic year shall be completed anonymously through email and only disclosed to the President.
Candidates must be current Executive Board members.
Candidates for President must have two years of experience on the Executive Board of AASA.
In the event that there are no Active Members from the past or present Executive Board, Active Members of AASA may run for the available positions.
The candidates will then be elected through a two-thirds majority vote by the current Active Members.
All positions shall be nominated separately beginning with the President and continuing as listed by this Constitution.
The following nomination procedure shall be observed:
An Executive Board officer shall nominate a nominee for each available position.
If the nominee accepts the nomination, they are officially a candidate for the position that person is nominated for and may run for that position during elections. 
ELECTIONS
An Official Elections Meeting must be announced at least two meetings prior and the elected officers list must be submitted to the SA&I Culture Council Advisor by the given deadline.
Official Elections Meeting for the new Executive Board should take place at the end of April. 
All candidates must be present at the time the Official Elections are held.
Elections will take place at an Executive Board meeting.
If there are positions still open post-elections, those positions shall be open to Active Members to apply in the Fall semester of the following academic year.
Voting for a candidate shall be done through discussion at an Executive Board meeting.
All positions shall be voted upon separately, beginning with the President and continuing as listed by this Constitution.
All candidates running for an Executive Board position shall be elected to office by the present majority vote of Executive Board.
Elections for each position shall not begin until the result of the vote for the previous position has been publicly announced.
In the event that there is only one candidate nominee running for an executive board position in an Official Election Meeting, voting shall proceed through Vote by Acclamation.
Votes shall be privately counted by the President of the Executive Board (unless the position of the President is being reviewed). Numbers of votes shall not be disclosed unless permission is granted by all candidates for that position.
If numbers are to be disclosed, they must be made public to the members and the candidates.
RESIGNATIONS
All resignations have to be completed before an officer’s term ending, must be in writing, and brought before the President and Vice President.
The President and Vice President must then notify and discuss the resignation with the rest of the Executive Board. 
RECALL
Impeachment of a member of the Executive Board may be presented to the President by any fellow Officer and shall mandate an investigation by the President.
The Officer shall present the Impeachment to the President with a detailed explanation of the accused Officer’s violation of the Constitution. In turn, that Officer shall remain anonymous until the actual impeachment process has begun.
The President shall proceed with an investigation and shall meet with the accused Officer, to alert them of the charge of the impeachment, to discuss the issue, and to ask for a resignation if the President feels that there has been a violation of the Constitution.
The accused Officer has the option to refuse to resign and may ask for a closed hearing before the Executive Board.
The following guidelines shall be observed:
The President shall present the statement of impeachment before the Executive Board.
The accused Officer shall be allowed to defend their position before asked to leave the meeting.
Remaining members of the Executive Board shall debate and vote on the issue of whether a recall of the accused officer should take place.
The majority vote shall rule. The President shall abstain from voting.
Impeachment of the President shall be brought forward to the Vice President, and the Vice President shall follow the above guidelines as the President.
REFERENDA
Referenda may be initiated through two-thirds vote from any officer of the Executive Board of the Asian American Student Association.
Referenda may be initiated by the President with the consultation of the Executive Board.
Referenda may be initiated by a petition of no less than ten percent of the Asian American Student Association.
Once a Referendum is initiated, its wording cannot be changed.
A majority vote shall be sufficient to make a Referendum binding upon the Asian American Student Association.

ARTICLE VI: STATEMENT OF FREE SPEECH AND EXPRESSION

Under no circumstances shall a member’s freedom of speech or expression be infringed.

ARTICLE VII: STATEMENT OF NON-DISCRIMINATION

The group prohibits discrimination under Federal and State law, based on race, color, national origin, religion, sex, gender identity (including gender expression), sexual orientation, disability, age, marital status, family/parental status, income derived from a public assistance program, political beliefs, or reprisal or retaliation for prior civil rights activity. 

ARTICLE VIII: AMENDMENTS AND CONSTITUTIONAL POWERS

Amendments to the AASA Constitution shall be introduced by an Officer of the Executive Board. Amendments shall be examined by the Executive Board Officers of AASA and shall be passed by a majority vote by all present Executive Board Officers.

Constitution of the Association of Latin American and Caribbean Students and Friends 
University of Massachusetts Amherst

First Edition

ARTICLE I - Name and Purpose

Section 1 Name of the Organization:  The organization shall be named the Association of Latin American and Caribbean Students and Friends - ALACS & Friends. 

Section 2 Purpose: The purpose of ALACS & Friends is to facilitate and support activities that meet the academic, social, cultural, and professional needs of Latin American and Caribbean Students students at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.

ARTICLE II - Membership, Membership Fees, Non-Discrimination Policy

Section 1 General Definition of Membership:  Membership shall be open to any members of the community who are interested in exploring and discussing Latin American, Caribbean, and Latino issues at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.

Section 2 Active Membership:  Active members are those who express their willingness to participate in the meetings and activities organized by ALACS & Friends. Membership dues will not be required.

Section 3 Non-Discrimination Policy:  ALACS & Friends does not discriminate for any purpose on the basis of race, ethnicity, linguistic abilities, religion, sexual identity, political affiliation, disability status, or marital status.

ARTICLE III - Officers, Duties, and Terms 

Section 1: ALACS & Friends will appoint a maximum of hree coordinators, one also serving as  a treasurer, as their officers on a yearly basis. Persons appointed to these positions can hold them for more than one term. Other members will participate in the planning and execution of activities. 

Section 2: The coordinator is in charge of presiding over the meetings, preparing the minutes and organizing social events. For other activities special committees will be created according to the necessities of the organization. The coordinator should also ensure the maintenance of open lines of communication between Latin American and Caribbean graduate students, the administration and faculty and the community reached by the group. The coordinator should also organize a general meeting at the beginning of the academic year. 

Section 3: The treasurer should be in charge of all finance-related issues concerning the organization. On a yearly basis, the Treasurer along with the Coordinator(s) are required to produce a written report with a detailed description of the activities that have been accomplished, along with the expenses. 

ARTICLE IV - Election and Appointment Procedures 

Section 1 Election Schedule:  The election for all officers shall be held at the end of April of each year. The election day shall be announced in the general meeting held immediately prior to the day scheduled for election day. The number of coordinators will be decided at the election meeting based on members availability.

Section 2 Nomination Schedule:  10 days before the election, a notice shall be thoroughly distributed by the coordinator to announce the election and to invite nominations for each position.

Section 3 Nomination Eligibility:  Any active member may be nominated for any position. Any active member may nominate any active member including her/himself. Each nominee shall be given one day to accept or decline the nomination of her/his name. Each nominee shall be only permitted to accept a nomination for one full position only. Each nominee shall accept or decline the nomination of her/his name. Each nominee shall be only permitted to accept a nomination for one full position only.

Section 4 Election Period:  The coordinator and the treasurer will be elected by the members present in the meeting for which their election was scheduled. 

Section 5 Consensus election:  There will be no votes but the coordinator and the treasurer will be elected by common consensus. In case that consensus may not be reached during the meeting, the decision shall be tabled until the next meeting.  If consensus is not reached on this the next meeting, a decision will be made through a simple majority vote among the  members present at that meeting.

ARTICLE V - Meetings

Section 1 General Meetings:  At least one general meeting should be held each semester.

Section 2 Special Meetings:  The coordinator and the treasurer in agreement with the rest of the members will determine the necessity for any additional meetings. These meetings shall be announced with a minimum of three days in advance. 

Section 3 Rules of Conduct and Speech: Everyone may speak during meetings, and if translation is required, it  should be provided by anyone present from the organization. The common language that the majority of the members in attendance on that day feel is the most comfortable should be the one used as the language for conducting the meeting on that day. Communication among members should be based on mutual respect for different positions and ideas. Individuals with disabilities are invited to request reasonable accommodations including, but not limited to, sign language interpretation . Members who cannot attend the meetings can communicate their ideas to the group via email which will be read by the coordinator by the beginning of the meeting.

Section 4 Procedures for Decision Making: Regarding the different activities, consensus should be achieved by all present members. In case this is not possible, we will wait until the next meeting and if the disagreement continues, simple majority among the present members in that meeting will decide. In case that consensus may not be reached during the meeting, the decision shall be tabled until the next meeting.  If consensus is not reached on this the next meeting, a decision will be made through a simple majority vote among the  members present at that meeting.


ARTICLE VI - Rights and Privileges of Members 

Section 1 General Rights: Members can attend any meeting and participate in every activity programed or supported by the organization.
 
 Section 2 Voting Rights: Members have the right to vote in any decision making process conducted by the organization.

Section 3 Other Rights: Members are entitled to propose activities, committees, or any other concerns they want to bring to the organization.

ARTICLE VII – Committees 

Section 1: ALACS & Friends will create ad hoc committees in order to fulfill the objectives set by the organization. The activities of these committees will be specified if required. 

ARTICLE VIII - Amendments to the Constitution 

Section 1 Proposal:  A member may propose an amendment by distributing it in written format and reading it aloud in a meeting. Voting of a proposal may not take place in the same meeting as that in which the proposal was made. Following the meeting, the proposal shall be made known to all members of ALACS & Friends.

Section 2 Approval:  During the next meeting, and only after being discussed to the satisfaction of all members present for the voting of a proposal, a consensus should be achieved by all present members. In case this is not possible, we will wait until the next meeting and if the disagreement continues, simple majority among the present members in that meeting will decide. 

Section 3 Recording:  Any successful amendment shall be recorded and copies of the new constitution shall be distributed on the ALACS & Friends website and made available to all of its members via email.

PREAMBLE

We, a group of individuals with similar academic and future professional interests in
accounting and finance, desire to unite in a professional association to promote group
identity, to advance academic development, to create esprit de corps, to instill desire for
self-improvement, to foster moral and ethical standards, to encourage and recognize
academic achievement, to cultivate a sense of professional and civic responsibility and
service, to promote the study of accounting, finance and business related subjects, and to
provide opportunities for professional association. Therefore, we do hereby establish an
association and adopt these Bylaws to govern its activities.

 ARTICLE I - NAME, MISSION AND OBJECTIVES, AND SEAL

• NAME

The name of this association shall be ASSOCIATION OF LATINO
PROFESSIONALS FOR AMERICA, INC. ("Association" or "ALPFA").

The name of this chapter shall be the Association of Latino Professionals for America.
University of Massachusetts: Amherst Student Chapter. The Association shall be a
not-for-profit entity under the applicable rules of the Internal Revenue Code.

• MISSION AND OBJECTIVES

Our mission is to provide students with internship opportunities, a space to seek advice
from professional alumni, and to establish a network of peers that students can rely on for
support. We aim to provide opportunities and resources that empower latinxs and
hispanics across the general student body and community at large.

University of Massachusetts - Amherst Undergraduate

The ALPFA Student Chapter shall unite students through membership who are
committed to academic and future professional excellence, possess a sense of
professional and civic responsibility, and are concerned with enhancing opportunities for
minorities. In keeping with the Chapter's charter, its objectives shall be:

● To promote and develop the professional skills of its members
● To encourage community amongst minority students
● To provide opportunities for members to fulfill civic responsibilities
● To promote confidence in our members and their services
● To encourage the development of cordial relations among members and

cooperative relationships with other students

● To provide adequate resources to implement chapter programs
● To represent the interests of current and prospective minority students

 • SEAL

The seal of the Association shall be a red line that forms an open triangle, with the
abbreviation for the Association of Latino Professionals for America, Inc. ®, ALPFA,
exiting the triangles lower right side, and immediately below the seal, is written, in
italics, “Building Latino Business Leaders”, in quotations.

ARTICLE II - MEMBERSHIP

To qualify for student membership, a person must be genuinely interested in fostering the
objectives of the Association. A person may be a member through affiliation with a
chapter of
local area, a
member-at-large.

the Association, or where no chapter exists in their

• STUDENT MEMBERS

A full-time or part-time undergraduate or graduate student at a college or university
majoring in any field may qualify for admission as a member of the Association.

• STUDENTS WHO ARE NOT ELIGIBLE AS STUDENT MEMBERS

Graduate students, students who have associate degrees, and professional members are
not eligible to become student members of the Association. These individuals may
continue their professional membership and may work or affiliate with the Student
Chapter.

• MEMBER IN GOOD STANDING

A member in good standing as prescribed in these Bylaws for the purpose of voting,
nominating and candidacy shall be those members shown on the National records as paid
as of October 31 of each fiscal year.

• MEMBERS FROM OTHER STUDENT CHAPTERS
Members from other ALPFA student chapters who are in good standing, and who

 subsequently transfer to, and become students at this institution may affiliate with the
their
Chapter and be entitled to vote upon presenting satisfactory evidence of
membership. They shall not be assessed annual membership dues by the Chapter until the
expiration of the annual membership for which they paid.

ARTICLE III - DIVISIONS

• The Board of Directors shall designate Divisions of the Association from time to time to
address the needs of special interest groups within the membership. These Divisions may
be governed by their own Bylaws that are consistent with the National Bylaws.

ARTICLE IV - REGIONS

• The Board of Directors shall designate regions of the Association. The Board of
Directors may, from time to time, specify the jurisdiction of regions and adopt rules of
conduct for their affairs. A Regional President shall direct each region.

ARTICLE V - CHAPTERS

• TYPES OF CHAPTERS

The Association shall have two types of chapters: (a) professional and (b) student. The
National Board of Directors, may on occasion, authorize the establishment of
professional and student chapters, organize the chapters within regions, specify the
jurisdiction of chapters, and adopt rules for the conduct of their affairs.

Chapters are the basic organizational units of the Association. Admission to membership
in the Association is normally through membership in a chapter. The qualifications for
membership in a chapter are the same as those for membership in the Association.
Chapters of the Association shall be:

• Chapters of the Association at the effective date of these Bylaws and

• Groups that shall qualify for admission as provided under this Article.

• QUALIFICATION TO FORM A STUDENT CHAPTER

 A group of ten (10) or more persons who qualify as student members may petition the
Board of Directors to form a student chapter. Each chapter shall adopt Bylaws that are
consistent with the National Bylaws.

ARTICLE VI - EXECUTIVE BOARD

• COMPOSITION OF THE EXECUTIVE BOARD

The governing body of the Chapter shall be the Executive Board. The Executive Board
shall consist of the following:

• Chapter President

• Chapter Vice President (s)

• Chapter Secretary
• Chapter Treasurer

● Chapter Marketing Director
● Chapter Outreach Coordinator

The Executive Board may designate other committees and members as it deems
necessary. The Executive Board shall be a minimum of five (5) and a maximum of fifteen
(15).

• POWER OF THE EXECUTIVE BOARD

The Executive Board may exercise all powers requisite for the purposes of the Chapter,
not inconsistent with these Bylaws or with duly enacted resolutions of the membership of
the authority to prescribe policies and
the Chapter,
procedures for the Chapter and to enact resolutions binding upon the Chapter, not
inconsistent with the National Bylaws.

including but not

limited to,

• DUTIES OF THE EXECUTIVE BOARD

The Executive Board shall have no other specific duties other than those permitted in
Section 6.2.

• OFFICERS

 The officers of the Chapter shall be a Chapter President, Chapter Vice President(s), a
Chapter Secretary, a Chapter Treasurer, a Chapter Marketing Director, and a Chapter
Outreach Coordinator, all of whom shall be members of the ALPFA University of
Massachusetts – Amherst Undergraduate Student Chapter and shall serve without
compensation.

• DUTIES OF THE OFFICERS

Chapter President

The President shall serve as chief executive of the Chapter and shall perform all duties
that usually pertain to this office. In addition, the President shall preside over all meetings
of the Association, the Board of Directors and Executive Board. The President shall
report on the affairs of the Association at each meeting.

Chapter Vice President(s)

The Vice President (s) shall perform such other duties as may be assigned them by the
President or Executive Board. In the absence or disability of the President, the Vice
President shall have and exercise all of the powers and prerogatives of the President.

Chapter Secretary

The Secretary shall maintain the official records of the Chapter, including these Bylaws.
The Secretary shall record all resolutions and proceedings of meetings in the official
records of the Chapter. The Secretary shall issue notices of all meetings and distribute the
minutes of such meetings to the Executive Board. The Chapter Secretary shall perform
such other duties that usually pertain to this office.

Chapter Treasurer

The Chapter Treasurer shall serve as chief financial officer of the Chapter. Among other
duties, the Chapter Treasurer shall be responsible for developing, implementing and
monitoring the financial policies, investment policies, accounting procedures and internal
controls and financial reporting for the Chapter. The Chapter Treasurer shall be
responsible for the submission of periodic financial reports to the Executive Board.

 Chapter Marketing Director

The Chapter Marketing Director shall serve as the chief of marketing of the Chapter.
Among other duties, the Marketing Director shall be responsible for implementing all
channels of marketing, and developing and managing all advertising campaigns.

Chapter Outreach Coordinator

The Chapter Outreach Coordinator shall serve as a liaison between the Chapter and all
other groups or organizations. The Outreach Coordinator shall maintain adequate public
relations with the oﬃcers of the Chapter, the general body, and the public. The Chapter
Outreach Coordinator shall be responsible for community outreach, and search and create
opportunities that beneﬁt the community.

• TERM LENGTH

All members of the Executive Board shall hold office for one fiscal year following the
fiscal year of their election. Subsequent to the elections, this transitioning phase will be
viewed as an opportunity for the elected members to shadow and be trained by the
members in their future positions. In the event an Executive Board member graduates
before the end of their term, the remaining Executive Board members shall appoint a
successor except in the situations where the graduating Executive Board member is the
Chapter President. The Vice President (or first Vice President if there are multiple Vice
Presidents) automatically takes on the role of Chapter President if the Chapter President
is graduating before the end of their term.

• EXPENSES

The Chapter may reimburse expenses incurred by the Executive Board in the discharge of
their duties. The Executive Board shall prescribe policies and procedures for such
approval and payment.

• RESIGNATION, REMOVAL AND VACANCIES

Resignation

If any member of the Executive Board is absent from two consecutive meetings of the
Executive Board, he/she shall be deemed to have resigned. The Executive Board may

 re-elect the member deemed to have resigned. The voluntary resignation of an Executive
Board shall be tendered to the Board in writing.

Removal

The Executive Board may remove any Executive Board member from office for cause by
two-thirds vote for non-performance or conduct unbecoming of an Executive Board
member. The National Student Member Services Committee may also remove any
Executive Board member from office for non-performance or conduct unbecoming of an
Executive Board member. The member that is being removed will be notified, and will be
presented with an opportunity to address his or herself about why the organization wants
to make the switch.

A member of the Executive Board may be removed by a vote of twenty-five percent
(25%) of the chapter's membership at the time the vote is taken or by directive from the
National Student Member Services Committee.

A member of the Executive Board may be removed from office for non-payment of dues.
Dues for all elected Executive Board members shall be payable on or before April 15 of
the year elected. If elections are held after April 15, dues are payable immediately. If dues
are not paid by July 31 of the fiscal year the new Executive Board takes office, the
remaining Executive Board members shall appoint a successor except in the situations
where the Executive Board member being removed from the Executive Board is the
Chapter President. The Vice President (or first Vice President if there are multiple Vice
Presidents) automatically takes on the role of Chapter President if the Chapter President
has to be removed due to non-payment of dues.

Vacancies

If an officer position should for any cause become vacant, the Executive Board shall
appoint a qualified member to complete the unexpired portion of the term. The remaining
members of the Executive Board shall have the power, by majority vote, to elect a
qualified member to fill the vacancy for the unexpired term of an Executive Board
member removed from office.

ARTICLE VII - ELECTIONS

• The National Board of Directors shall prescribe the manner in which the annual

 elections will be held and the qualifications to hold office. Members in good standing
shall elect the Executive Board members.

• ELECTION DEADLINE

The call for nominations shall be sent out during the month of February each year.
Elections shall be held and completed during the month of March each year. Election
results shall be communicated to the National Student Member Services Committee and
the ALPFA National Office no later than April 15 each year.

• NOMINATIONS AND ELECTION MEETING

The nominations and election meeting shall both be chaired by the Nominations and
Election Committee. No member of the Executive Board of the Chapter or any candidate
for office shall serve on the Nominations and Election Committee or occupy the chair at
the nominations and election meetings. The Nominations and Election Committee shall
count the ballots and communicate the winners to the membership.

• ELIGIBLE VOTES

Quorum (50% +1) of the voting membership must be present in order for votes to be
taken.

• MEMBERS IN GOOD STANDING

Only members in good standing, as described in article 2.3 above, shall be eligible to run
for office or vote in the Chapter election.

• ELECTION CONTROVERSY

In the event of an election controversy, all parties thereto shall submit complaints to the
Faculty Advisor, designated Professional Chapter President, and designated Professional
Chapter Local Director of Student Member Services (LDSMS) and National Student
Member Services Committee in writing within five (5) days from the date of the election
in question. Complaints shall be submitted by twenty-five (25%) percent of the Chapter
members in good standing.

 Each person signing the complaint must list his or her permanent and temporary mailing
address, email address and phone number. The National Student Member Services
Committee or its designee will provide a summary of the complaints to the Student
Chapter.

Should the National Student Member Services Committee or its designee determine that
the complaint is frivolous or completely devoid of merit, or the election results could not
have been otherwise even if the matters alleged are assumed to be true, then the National
Student Member Services Committee or its designee shall, within twenty (20) days from
receipt of the charges, dismiss the complaint and inform the Chapter forthwith that it may
proceed with the installation of officers.

Should such complaints, in the opinion of the National Student Member Services
Committee or its designee warrant intervention, a new election may be ordered to be held
within thirty (30) days, in which case a ALPFA Professional, in conjunction with the
Faculty Advisor, shall preside. The designated presiding officer shall order the
procedures of the called election meeting, and the results of this supervised election shall
be final. In the event the National Student Member Services Committee or its designee
decides to intervene in a contested election for the office of President, Secretary, or
Treasurer, upon receipt of notice to that effect by mail or email, no officer of the Chapter
shall disburse funds from the Chapter treasury unless otherwise instructed by the National
Student Member Services Committee or the designated Professional Chapter President in
conjunction with pending settlement of the controversy.

ARTICLE VIII - MEETINGS

• MEETINGS OF THE MEMBERSHIP

Regular meetings of the Chapter shall be held at least once each month. Other special
meetings may be convened as necessary. The president or vice president will conduct
meetings and will have a structured agenda of topics that will be addressed.

• MEETINGS OF EXECUTIVE BOARD

The Executive Board shall meet at least once a month at such times and places as it may
determine. Special meetings of the Executive Board may be called by the President,
Secretary, or by two members of the Executive Board. Special meetings shall also include
conference calls.

Sixty percent (60%) of the Executive Board members shall constitute a quorum for all
meetings. In the event a quorum is not present at any regular or special meeting of the

 Executive Board, the meeting shall be rescheduled to a date where quorum can be
obtained. Chapter business that requires a vote cannot be conducted without quorum.

ARTICLE IX - COMMITTEES

• STANDING COMMITTEES

The standing committees of the Chapter shall be: Membership, Fundraising, Marketing
and Public Relations, Professional Development (Event Planning) or other committees as
deemed necessary. All committees shall consist of one or more members.

• DUTIES OF STANDING COMMITTEES

The duties of the Standing Committees are described in the Student Chapter Policies and
Procedures Manual (SCPPM). All committees shall report to the Executive Board at its
regular meeting.

• AD-HOC

COMMITTEES

● NOMINATIONS AND ELECTIONS COMMITTEE

The charge of the Nominations and Election Committee shall be to execute the elections
process in accordance with these Bylaws and the Student Chapter Policies and
Procedures Manual.

• The Nominations and Election Committee shall be formed at least two (2) months prior
to the annual election and shall not be composed of less than two (2) or more than five
(5) chapter members in good standing. No member of the Nomination and Election
Committee shall be members of the Executive Board or nominees for office.

• The Election Committee shall meet promptly to elect a Chairperson.

• The meetings at which the nominations and elections take place will be presided over
by the Nominations and Election Committee Chairperson. Additional ad-hoc committees
may be formed, as necessary.

ARTICLE X - DUES

• ANNUAL DUES AMOUNT

 The National Board of Directors shall determine the amount of annual dues which
chapters shall submit to the Association for each member. Student chapters may assess its
member’s additional annual dues to be retained by the Chapter; however, the assessed by
the chapter shall not exceed ten dollars ($10) more than the amount determined by the
National Board of Directors as the annual dues. A member’s dues must be received by
the ALPFA’s National Office to be recognized as member in good standing. Dues shall be
payable on or before the first day each fiscal year of the Association except for members
who are elected to the Executive Board. Dues for elected members shall be payable on or
before April 15 of the fiscal year elected.

• RECONCILIATION OF MEMBERS

The Chapter shall reconcile its members each month to the roster of members received
from the ALPFA National Office. The Chapter shall send notification to the ALPFA
National Office within the deadline specified indicating whether or not there are
reconciling items.

ARTICLE XI - FISCAL YEAR AND FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT

• Fiscal Year

The association shall operate on a fiscal year of twelve months beginning July 1 and
ending June 30.

• Financial Management

The National Board of Directors shall have authority to prescribe such procedures, as it
deems appropriate to assure financial controls, including the appointment of an auditor
and an Audit Committee.

• Annual Budget

The Treasurer shall submit an annual budget to the Executive Board prior to the
beginning of the fiscal year. The Executive Board shall approve the annual budget, which
it may amend from time to time during the year.

• Limitation of Personal Liability for Financial Loss

 No personal liability shall attach to any officer, member of the Executive Board, or
Committee, for financial losses resulting from the exercise of judgment, in good faith, in
the performance of assigned duties.

ARTICLE XII - AMENDMENTS

• All amendments to the Student Chapter Bylaws must be approved by the Board of
Directors before submission to the members of the Chapter.

ARTICLE XIII - SUSPENSION AND REVOCATION OF CHAPTERS

Chapters must adopt the Student Bylaws, comply with SCREP and maintain a
membership of ten (10) members each fiscal year. These are the minimum operating
standards for Student Chapters. Failure to comply with these standards could result in the
suspension of the Chapter or revocation of the Chapter's Charter.

• SUSPENSION OF THE CHAPTER

The National Board of Directors may suspend the Chapter for failure to maintain a
membership of ten members in a fiscal year or failure to submit two consecutive SCREP
packages. The National Board of Directors may also suspend the Chapter for failure of
the Chapter to conduct itself in accordance with ALPFA's goals and objectives or for any
other cause whenever the National Board of Directors shall deem it in the best interest of
the Association. If the Chapter is suspended, and continues to be non-compliant with the
minimum operating standards of the organization for a twelve (12) month period, this
will result in a vote by the National Board of Directors to revoke the Chapter's charter.

• REVOCATION OF THE CHAPTER'S CHARTER

The Chapter's may be revoked if the Chapter is suspended for twelve (12) months or
longer and continues to be non-compliant with the Association's minimum operating
standards. The Chapter's charter may also be revoked if the National Board of Directors
deems it in the best interest of the Association.

The dissolution of the Chapter shall not invalidate the membership of any member of the
Chapter. Such a member shall become a student member at-large in the region where the
Chapter resides. If the National Board of Directors approves the revocation of the

 Chapter's Charter, the Chapter shall cease to function and the Executive Board shall
forthwith forward all records, property, and monies of the Chapter to the college (or
university). Copies of this information should also be forwarded to the ALPFA National
Office.

• REINSTATEMENT OF A SUSPENDED CHAPTER

The National Board of Directors may reinstate a suspended Chapter that was suspended
for failure to maintain a membership of ten (10) members in a fiscal year or for failure to
submit two consecutive SCREP packages, if the Chapter demonstrates that it has
increased its membership to a minimum of ten members and submitted consecutive
SCREP packages for an entire 12 month period.

The National Board of Directors may reinstate a suspended Chapter that was suspended
for failure to conduct itself in accordance with ALPFA's goals and objectives, or for any
other cause that the National Board of Directors deemed it in the best interest of the
Association, if the Chapter demonstrates that it has conducted itself in accordance with
ALPFA's goals and objectives for a minimum of one year; and, in addition, demonstrates
that it has maintained a minimum of ten (10) members and submitted all SCREP
packages for the said year.

Chapters whose charter was revoked by the National Board of Directors shall have to
re-apply for a University of Massachusetts: Amherst Student Chapter Charter via the
New Student Chapter process.

ARTICLE XIV - INDEBTEDNESS AND USE OF NAME

• INDEBTEDNESS

No indebtedness or obligation shall be incurred by the Chapter or any of its officers or
agents in the name of the Association of Latino Professionals for America, Inc. and the
Association of Latino Professionals for America, Inc. shall not be responsible for any
indebtedness incurred by the Chapter or any of its officers or agents.

• LIMITS OF INDEBTEDNESS

No indebtedness or obligation of more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) shall be
incurred in the name of or in behalf of the Chapter unless by vote of the Executive Board.

 • USE OF NAME

The Chapter must at all times officially identify itself as the ALPFA Student Chapter. The
Chapter is an affiliated entity of the National organization and has no authority to
officially identify itself as the Association of Latino Professionals for America, Inc.
(ALPFA).

ARTICLE XV – FREE SPEECH AND NONDISCRIMINATION

● FREE SPEECH

The Chapter welcomes all perspectives and encourages its members to speak their
minds and voice their opinions.

● NONDISCRIMINATION

The Chapter embraces diversity and is open to anyone of any race, gender,
religion, etc.

ARTICLE XVI - LIMITATIONS

• LIMITATIONS

The Chapter is not organized for profit. No part of its income shall accrue to the benefit
of any private individual. The Chapter shall not carry on propaganda or otherwise attempt
to influence legislation. It shall not participate nor intervene in any political campaign on
behalf of any candidate for public office. It shall not accumulate unreasonable amounts of
money to carry out the Chapter's purposes.

Notwithstanding any other provision of these Bylaws, the Chapter shall not conduct or
carry on any activities permitted to be conducted or carried on by an organization exempt
under Section 501(c)(3) or the U.S. Internal Revenue Code and its regulations as they
now exist or as they may be hereafter amended.
