DocsList.Data:
Astronomy Club Constitution


Name of Organization

 Astronomy Club

Mission Statement

Objectives: 

The Astronomy Club's goals are to promote interest in astronomy and perform educational outreach.

Our organization is aimed towards any interested student especially astronomy majors, physics majors, and the general public.

  We will promote interest in astronomy and perform outreach by: running and maintaining the Orchard Hill Observatory, hosting informative and fun celestial viewing nights, traveling to observatories, planetariums, local high schools, and many other areas of interest, helping majors and non-majors alike to get involved in research and outreach, and lastly to provide support to majors and students interested in astronomy.

Voting Membership and Election Eligibility

A voting member (or election candidate) of the Astronomy Club must

Attend all MANDATORY meetings(with officer approved exceptions)

Attend at least 1/3 of ALL meetings

  Attend or participate in at least one major event per semester

  All students can be members. ONLY UMASS students may run for an official officer position.

Statement of Non-Discrimination signed by the officers

We, and the organization we represent, promise to uphold unalienable rights to all those within, and all those outside of our organization.  These rights include freedom from discriminatory phrases, actions, and words.  We will not withhold membership due to discrimination, we will not alienate, and we will not tolerate any deviance from non-discriminatory behavior.

- Signatures from offices -

Statement of Free Speech/Expression

All members of the Astronomy Club are allowed the right to free speech and expression.  Offensive or disruptive language and actions to other members or to guests by any member will not be tolerated.

Clear procedure for conducting meetings and planning activities
There will be at least two mandatory meetings per semester; one at the beginning and the other for elections at the close.  All other meetings will be activity based events.  There will also be additional mandatory meetings for officers.  All activities will be planned completely by the officers and coordinated by the event coordinator; these of course will reflect the opinions of club.

Meetings will be weekly.  The meetings will open with announcements for club members, followed by the activities planned for that meeting.  These activities may be academic talks, astronomy related entertainment such as games or movies, observing using binoculars and telescopes including the Orchard Hill Observatory, or a planned trip.

If we are having an event which requires us to travel, we will give at least two weeks notice to members.  It will be the responsibility of the officers to ensure a safe and enjoyable trip for all partaking members.  The conduct of all members reflects the university and our club as a whole, and misconduct will not be tolerated.  A tentative arrangement for travel, and expenses will be laid out at first notice and adjusted as necessary up until two days before the trip.  There will be a schedule for the event which is expected to be followed by all members unless specific notice is given to an officer. 

Reasonable procedure for resolving disputes among members

All members will have outstanding behavior and manners toward themselves and others.  If this is not the case, and two or more members have a dispute, they will settle it without violence or aggression, but with a mutual agreement to accept the differences between members.  If the dispute is unresolved one or more officers will end the dispute in a diplomatic matter.  If there is a physical threat to anyone in, or outside, of the organization due to a dispute, authorities will be notified.  Warnings may be given at first offences, and suspension from attending meetings (by 3rd offence) may be given should they be deemed necessary by at least two officers (at least one of which must not have partaken in the dispute).

Governance and Officer Duties

	I.  All Officers: The officers of the Astronomy Club shall be comprised of a 		President, Vice President, Secretary, and Treasurer.
		i. All officers shall serve as leaders to club members; either dealing with issues members 		may have themselves or directing members to another officer more capable of 				assistance.
		ii. All officers shall share the responsibility of promoting and recruiting for the club.
iii. All officers shall attend officer meetings and mandatory meetings (extenuating circumstances may excuse an officer).
	II. President
		i. The president shall serve as a leader for the officers, providing guidance and reference 		and/or filling the responsibility of other officers should they be unable to 	carry them out 		themselves.
ii. The president shall procure material for weekly meetings, and is responsible for coordinating with guest speakers, vendors, etc. to ensure that meetings run as promised to the club’s members
		iii. The president shall ensure the club’s members and its officers abide by the club’s 			constitution.
		iv. The president shall hold signature rights on behalf of the club.
	III. Vice President
i. The vice president shall act as a direct assistant to the president, performing actions assigned to them by the president and helping to ensure material for weekly meetings.
		ii. The vice president shall assume all responsibilities of the president should the 				president be unable to perform their duties, or an election of a new president be 				in progress.
		iii. It is the vice president’s responsibility to ensure elections are carried out effectively
and a set of officers will succeed the current set.
V. Treasurer
		i. The treasurer shall be responsible for the club’s finances 	including keeping an accurate 		history of all monetary transactions.
ii. The treasurer is responsible for updating the club’s roster to reflect new membership and purging the roster of graduated members at the end of each semester.
		iii. The treasurer shall hold signature rights on behalf of the club.
	VII. Secretary
i. The secretary shall be responsible for accurately recording the attendance of members during meetings and the results of the meetings. These recordings should be made available at the request of other officers or members.
ii. The secretary shall serve as the election monitor.
iii. The secretary shall be responsible for all communications to the club via email.

Process for Elections

	Elections

Any member who is eligible to vote may run for election.
Voting shall take place in a designated room, with the date set at least one month in advance of voting.  There must be at least two weeks after the election left in the semester in order to train new officers.  Any member who is eligible and wishes to vote but shall be absent may send their votes to the club email.
All candidates must declare their intentions to the officers to run before voting begins.  
In the event that there are not enough candidates (i.e. less than four running) the officers shall nominate members to be candidates.  These nominees may of course choose to decline.
It is the RESPONSIBILITY of the OFFICERS to inform the club of the candidates running at LEAST one week before elections.
At least TEN eligible club members MUST be present and WISH to vote.
A simple majority by all voting members (with at least 10 members) for any candidate is required to elect that candidate.
There must be an election PROCTOR who is not a candidate running for election.
IF the proctor is a club member, they must write their vote FIRST on a SINGLE, small sheet of paper, fold it, and place it into a container where all voting sheets will go.
Once the proctor has voted, they present the OFFICE and NOMINEES running, ask the members to write the first and last name of their choices on the paper, and to fold and place it into the voting container.
A ballot should be as simple as this with these officer positions available for election:
1. President:  Candidate 1
2. Vice President: Candidate 2
3.  Event Coordinator: Candidate 3
4.  Treasurer:  Candidate 4
The PROCTOR may then count and then announce the results.
There may only be ONE proctor.
Candidates may DROP from the running at ANY time except after being elected.
In the rare event that there is a position that has no candidates for elections; approval by the current year’s officers (whom are to be shuffled) may be given to consenting ineligible candidates to run.
Finally the officers will train any new officers-elect for the coming year.



Process for removal of an officer

An officer will be removed if they graduate or leave the university, if a vote finds a majority for another candidate, or if an officer is not performing their assigned duties.  If an officer is not performing their assigned duties, it is their responsibility to remove themselves from office.  In the event that they do not do so, then other members are allowed to vote to remove an officer.  This will be conducted in the same manner as an election.  All current officers must train new officers before removal.

Training will consist as follows:

Current officer MUST properly train the NEW officer.
Current officer MUST describe IN DETAIL the responsibilities AS WELL AS provide a HARD COPY of instructions on regular duties.

Amendments Section

Approval of greater than 50% majority vote submitted to the Sec. of the Registry.  This will be voted upon as previously stated.

Ratification of the Constitution

Shall be voted on upon majority vote of the 	organization, approved by the Sec. of Registry, and a copy must be made available to all members.

Autism Acceptance UMass Amherst -

Constitution

Autism Acceptance of University of Massachusetts - Amherst Constitution

I. NAME

The name of this organization will be Autism Acceptance UMass

Amherst

II. PURPOSE

The purpose of Autism Acceptance UMass Amherst is to further the

mission of organizations that support autism by engaging the campus

community and the local community through awareness, education and

fundraising and in so doing, positively affect the lives of those struggling

with autism spectrum disorders and their families.

A. The Autism Acceptance UMass Amherst chapter is not affiliated with a specific

organization but will work with autism support groups and organizations to aid in fundraising

and spreading awareness.

III. Statement of Free Speech and Expression

Under no circumstances shall a member’s free speech or expression be infringed.

IV. Statement of Non-Discrimination

The Autism Acceptance RSO prohibits discrimination under Federal and State law on the

Basis of race, color, national origin, religion, sex, gender identity (including gender

expression), sexual orientation, disability, age, marital status, family/parental status,

income derived from a public assistance program, political beliefs, or reprisal or

retaliation for prior civil rights activity.

 V. MEMBERSHIP QUALIFICATIONS

A. Requirements for Membership

100% of active membership must be UMass Amherst students. Associate membership

may be granted to non-UMass Amherst students under special circumstances; these

associate members shall not be given the rights and privileges of active UMass Amherst

students including, but not limited to voting rights, use of facilities or equipment, and/or

benefits from student funded resources. Minimum of 10 active students (may include

e-board officers) to remain an active organization with the Center for Student

Involvement. Active members must complete a current application for membership and

indicate committee(s) of interest.

B. Length of Membership

Active membership continues until either the individual graduates, expresses intent to

withdraw from the club, or has been removed by the organization.

C. Requirements for Continued Membership

It is required to uphold the objectives and mission of the organization as is demonstrated

by active participation in events and/or committee duties. Members are required to attend

over 75% of more of the chapter meetings under the conditions set by the current

semester’s e-board.

D. Removal of Active Members

If any member fails to uphold the purpose and objectives of the organization, does not

meet membership requirements, or does not comply with the school’s policies, they may

be held accountable and in jeopardy of losing their membership. Reasons for removal of

members must be presented to the e-board. Written notification shall then be presented

with reason for removal to the member in question. After the member in question has had

their right to speak to the board/membership on their own behalf, a vote is taken and they

may be removed by a 2/3’s vote of the active, voting members.

 E. Voting Rights

Voting rights are granted to only active students in the organization. Non-UMass Amherst

students are ineligible for voting rights.

VI. DUES/FEES

No national dues, fees, donations, or other charges shall be required for membership into the

chapter.

*Charging local chapter dues is up to the discretion of the chapter’s e- board members.

VII. QUORUM (Minimum number of members needed to approve a topic

that has been voted on). A quorum shall be composed of 50% + 1 of

current, active voting members.

VIII. OFFICER DESCRIPTIONS

All Officers and Chairs are required to register on the campus pulse Autism Acceptance page.

There are 5 required officer positions which make up the chapter’s e-board. Required officer

positions will be elected each Spring to serve a 1 year term starting during the fall semester. All

e-board members must be enrolled students and attend all events and meetings hosted by the

chapter.

A. Positions: All required officer positions are elected positions.

1. President

Requirements: Must have been an active member for one year. Time commitment of

7-10 hours per week for 2 semesters or 3 quarters.

Duties: Oversees chapter logistics and all e-board positions; organizes, plans and runs

meetings; acts as point of contact for autism organization or other groups that would like

our assistance with fundraising, as well as for the chapter, school and faculty advisor; in

charge of submitting all paperwork to the school and informing members of club on any

updates and changes.

 2. Vice President

Requirements: Time commitment of 3-5 hours per week for 2 semesters or 3 quarters.

Duties: Supports the chapter president; runs meetings if the president is unable to attend;

can step in as point of contact for outside parties, members, and school if the president is

unable to; manages chapter’s list-serve; assists the treasurer in securing rooms and venues

for chapter meetings/events.

3. Secretary

Requirements: Time commitment of 2-3 hours per week for 2 semesters or 3 quarters.

Duties: Keep detailed minutes from each meeting and records member attendance;

emails chapter 24-48 hours after all meetings and posts them on chapter’s facebook page;

distributes chapter announcements and reminders; reserves room and venues for general,

e-board and committee meetings and events.

4. Treasurer

Requirements: Time commitment of 1-2 hours per week for 2 semesters or 3 quarters.

Duties: Establishes and maintains chapter’s bank account; keeps records of all expenses

and deposits; prepares annual/large event budgets; processes reimbursements when

necessary; deposits all funds raised and sends a check to respective parties (autism

organizations) at the end of each semester/quarter; submits chapter’s semester/quarter

accounting spreadsheet to necessary parties/groups.

5. Event Coordinators

Requirements: Time Commitment of 1-3 hours per week for 2 semesters or 3 quarters.

Duties: In charge of planning entertainment for various events we will be holding. Will

work with other committees to help make things more fun and keep the spirit high.

IX. Elections of Officers

Chapter elections will be held midway through the Spring semester. Applications and

descriptions for available positions will be distributed to all members of the organization

one month before the election meeting. If a member is interested in an e-board position,

 they must fill out an e-board application. Information regarding the candidates will be

sent to the rest of the chapter.

At the election meeting, candidates will give a short speech, and the rest of the

organization will make the final vote. Whoever receives the majority of votes, wins and

will be appointed to the position.

In the event that a required officer position becomes vacant during the school year, the

President must motion for an appointment. The motion must be seconded. The motion

carries with a majority vote of the e-board.

X. REMOVAL OF OFFICERS

If any officer fails to uphold the purpose and objectives of the organization, fulfill their

duties, or does not comply with university policies, a vote of “no confidence” must be

presented to the e-board by a chapter member. Written notification shall then be

presented with reason for removal to the officer in question. After the officer in question

has had their right to speak to the board on their own behalf, a vote is taken from the

e-board. The officer in question does not have a vote. The officer may be removed by a

majority vote of the e-board.

XI. ADVISOR The faculty advisor must be a current full-time faculty or staff member at UMass

Amherst

A. Selecting an Advisor

Members of the e-board will review and meet with potential candidates for the

faculty advisor position and will choose one qualified individual to serve.

B. Duties of the Advisor

1. Attend at least one chapter and one e-board meeting per month.

2. Attend as many organizational events and fundraisers as possible.

3. Provide continuity as student leadership changes from year to year.

4. Signing or cosigning appropriate university forms as necessary.

5. Monitor chapter finances and provide appropriate advice.

6. Serve as liaison between chapter and university administration.

7. Determine advisor expectations with e-board each year.

 8. Generally, be available to the e-board.

XII. MEETINGS

Chapters will host general chapter meetings twice a month and e-board meetings twice a

month at a recurring date and time.

XIII. AMENDMENTS

Autism Acceptance UMass Amherst shall operate in accordance to all university

provisions. Any amendment changes shall be passed by a simple majority vote (i.e.: 50%

of current, active voting members and an additional one current, active member).

Amendments to this constitution must be reviewed by the school once adopted by the

chapter.

XIV. ORGANIZATION AGREEMENT

Chapter agrees to abide by Massachusetts laws regarding hazing. Furthermore, the

chapter agrees to abide by all school policies as outlines by UMass Amherst, including,

but not limited to:

● Checking the organization’s mailbox regularly.

● Communicating via email upon request.

● Updating the organization’s records whenever there is a change.

Autism Speaks U Chapter Constitution

Autism Speaks U University of Massachusetts - Amherst Constitution

I. NAME
The name of this organization will be Autism Speaks U UMass Amherst

II. PURPOSE
The purpose of Autism Speaks U UMass Amherst is to further the mission of Autism Speaks by engaging the campus community and the local community through awareness, education and fundraising and in so doing, positively affect the lives of those struggling with autism spectrum disorders and their families.

A. The Autism Speaks U UMass Amherst chapter is affiliated with Autism Speaks U’s national chapter program.

III. MEMBERSHIP QUALIFICATIONS 
A.	Requirements for Membership
100% of active membership must be UMass Amherst students. Associate membership may be granted to non UMass Amherst students under special circumstances; these associate members shall not be given the rights and privileges of active UMass Amherst students including, but not limited to voting rights, use of facilities or equipment, and/or benefits from student funded resources. Minimum of 10 active students (may include e-board officers) to remain an active organization with the Center for Student Involvement. Active members must complete a current application for membership and indicate committee(s) of interest.

B.	Length of Membership 
Active membership continues until either the individual graduates, expresses intent to withdraw from the club, or has been removed by the organization.

C.	Requirements for Continued Membership
It is required to uphold the objectives and mission of the organization as is demonstrated by active participation in events and/or committee duties. Members are required to attend chapter meetings under the conditions set by the current semester’s e-board.

D.	Removal of Active Members
If any member fails to uphold the purpose and objectives of the organization, does not meet membership requirements, or does not comply with the school’s policies, he/she may be held accountable and in jeopardy of losing their membership. Reason for removal of member must be presented to the e-board. Written notification shall then be presented with reason for removal to the member in question. After the member in question has had his/her right to speak to the board/membership on their own behalf and a vote is taken and he/she may be removed by a 2/3’s vote of the active, voting members.

E.	Voting Rights
Voting rights are granted to only active students in the organization. Non UMass Amherst students are ineligible for voting rights.

IV. DUES/FEES
No national dues, fees, donations, or other charges shall be required for membership into chapter.
*Charging local chapter dues is up to the discretion of the chapter’s e-board members.

V. QUORUM (Minimum number of members needed to approve a topic that has been voted     on). A quorum shall be composed of 50% + 1 of current, active voting members.

VI. OFFICER DESCRIPTIONS
All Officers and Chairs are required to register on the Autism Speaks U Website. There are 8 required officer positions which make up the chapter’s e-board. Required officer positions will be elected each November to serve a 1 year term starting on January 1. All e-board members must be enrolled students and attend all events and meetings hosted by the chapter.

A. Positions: All required officer positions are elected positions. 
1.	President
Requirements: Must have been an active member for one year. Time commitment of 7-10 hours per week for 2 semesters or 3 quarters.
Duties: Oversees chapter logistics and all e-board positions; organizes, plans and runs meetings; acts as point of contact for the Autism Speaks U national office and Autism Speaks contact, as well as for the chapter, school and faculty advisor; in charge of submitting all paperwork to the school and the Autism Speaks U national office.

2.	Vice President 
	Requirements: Time commitment of 3-5 hours per week for 2 semesters or 3 quarters.
Duties: Supports the chapter president; runs meetings if the president is unable to attend; can step in as point of contact for Autism Speaks, the Autism Speaks U national office and the school if the president is unable to; manages chapter’s list-serv; assists the treasurer in securing rooms and venues for chapter meetings/events.

3.	Secretary 
	Requirements: Time commitment of 2-3 hours per week for 2 semesters or 3 quarters.
Duties: Keeps detailed minutes from each meeting and records member attendance; emails chapter minutes 24-48 hours after all meetings and posts them on chapter’s Facebook page; distributes chapter announcements and reminders; reserves rooms and venues for general, e-board and committee meetings and events.

4.	Treasurer
	Requirements: Time commitment of 1-2 hours per week for 2 semesters or 3 quarters.
Duties: Establishes and maintains chapter’s bank account; keeps records of all expenses and deposits; prepares annual/large event budgets; processes reimbursements when necessary; deposits all funds raised and sends a check to the Autism Speaks U national office at the end of each semester/quarter; submits chapter’s semester/quarter accounting spreadsheet to the Autism Speaks U national office.

5.	Fundraising Chair (Co-Chairs)
	Requirements: Time commitment of 3-5 hours per week for 2 semesters or 3 quarters.
Duties: Plans and executes all of the chapter’s fundraising events; contacts clubs and organizations to partner on events; selects chapter members to serve on fundraising committee for large events and conducts committee meetings; delegates responsibilities and tasks to committee members.
 
6.	Marketing Chair 
	Requirements: Time commitment of 2-3 hours per week for 2 semesters or 3 quarters.
Duties: Creates annual plan that details how the chapter will get promoted on campus and in the community; posts weekly on the chapter’s official Facebook and Twitter; designs advertising materials (ex. t-shirts, handouts, banners, posters, etc.), and submits all design proofs to the Autism Speaks U national office for approval; contacts local and campus media outlets (newspaper, TV, radio) to secure coverage for the chapter’s events.

7.	Recruitment Chair (Co-Chairs)
	Requirements: Time commitment of 3-5 hours per week for 2 semesters or 3 quarters.
Duties: Engages students who express interest in joining; informs students on upcoming meetings and events; works with marketing chair to promote the chapter at freshman/transfer orientation and the club/activity fairs; reaches out to clubs and organizations to inform them about meetings, events and open e-board positions. Meets with clubs / organizations on campus to seek out potential sponsors for the 5k. Must go over guidelines for a club / organization sponsor and follow up to be sure they continue to meet all the requirements in a timely manner. 

8.	Volunteer Chair
	Requirements: Time Commitment of 1-3 hours per week for 2 semesters or 3 quarters. 
Duties: Secures partnerships with local school/center for members to volunteer and coordinates details; contacts clubs and organizations to participate in volunteer opportunities (ex. UMass Football Team); ensures chapter has at least one hands-on activity with individuals on spectrum each semester. You will also assist with scheduling chapter members to table at the campus center, Holyoke/Hampshire malls and DC’s. In charge of recruiting volunteers for 5k event. Must hold volunteer training sessions 1-2 weeks before the 5k. Must be diligent with answering emails and keeping numbers of volunteers up-to-date. On the day of the event oversees that the volunteers follow their assignments. All volunteers must check in and check out with the volunteer coordinator, the day of. 


9.	Awareness Chair (Co-Chairs)
Requirements: Time Commitment of 2-3 hours per week for 2 semesters or 3 quarters. 
Duties: Plans and executes the chapter’s awareness events; works with the fundraising chair to ensure awareness is incorporated in all fundraisers; tables on campus to distribute materials on autism and the chapter; secures monthly speakers for meetings to discuss their connection to the cause. Helps to plan our guest lecture series, and other events during autism awareness month. 
10. 	Event Coordinator 
	Requirements: Time commitment of 2-3 hours per week for 2 semesters or 3 quarters 
Duties:  Secure Kendrick Park for the 5k. Work closely with the town to turn in permits and other paperwork on time and correctly. On the day of the event they must oversee we are following town guidelines and meet with any inspectors (electrical, food). 
11. 	Race Logistics
Requirements: Time commitment of 2-3 hours per week for 2 semesters or 3 quarters 
Duties: Find a timing company for the day of the event. Oversee correct placement of line routers and water station. Ensure registration is going smoothly with walkers and runners. Appoint a volunteer to lead the walkers. Oversee any race logistics that make occur the day of and plan ahead to ensure it goes smoothly as possible. One day before the walk have volunteers or sponsor club members help chalk the route with arrows and circle/outline any cracks and potholes. 
12. 	Minor Board 
Requirements: Time commitment of 1-2 hours per week for 2 semesters or 3 quarters 
Duties: They must attend eboard meetings and be club members. Any club member is welcome to join this position. Most minor board members should assist and work closely with one or two positions to gain experience and help those that have the most work. Anyone that was removed as an officer may be a minor board member, as long as they did not break any university policies. Their only offense should be not keeping up with their position’s duties.  

VII. ELECTION OF OFFICERS 
Chapter elections will be held after the Annual 5K Race event.  
Applications and descriptions for available positions will be distributed to all members of the organization one week before the election meeting. All current eboard members must reapply for the same or different positions.  Whoever is interested in an e-board position, they must fill out an e-board application and send a resume. The e-board will decide on possible candidates for each position. Qualified candidates will be notified and information regarding the candidates will be sent to the rest of the chapter.
 At the election meeting, the current ebaord will be given access to each candidates’ application and resume, the candidates have the option (not required) of making a speech, and afterwards the eboard will take a vote. Whoever receives the majority of votes, wins and will be appointed to the position.
In the event that a required officer position becomes vacant during the school year, the President must motion for an appointment. The motion must be seconded. The motion carries with a majority vote of the e-board. 

IIX. REMOVAL OF OFFICERS
If any officer fails to uphold the purpose and objectives of the organization, fulfill their duties, or does not comply with university policies, a vote of “no confidence” must be presented to the e-board by a chapter member or an eboard member. Written notification shall then be presented with reason for removal to the officer in question. After the officer in question has had his/her right to speak to the board on their own behalf, a vote is taken from the e-board. The officer in question does not have a vote. The officer may be removed by a majority vote of the e-board.

IX. ADVISOR 
The Faculty advisor must be a current full-time faculty or staff member at UMass   Amherst 

A. Selecting an Advisor
Members of the e-board will review and meet with potential candidates for the faculty advisor position and will choose one qualified individual to serve.

B. Duties of the Advisor
	1.	Attend at least one chapter and one e-board meeting per month. 
	2.	Attend as many organizational events and fundraisers as possible. 
	3.	Provide continuity as student leadership changes from year to year. 
	4.	Signing or cosigning appropriate university forms as necessary. 
	5.	Monitor chapter finances and provide appropriate advice. 
	6.	Serve as liaison between chapter and university administration. 
	7.	Determine advisor expectations with e-board each year. 
	8.	Generally be available to the e-board.

X. MEETINGS 
Chapters will host general chapter meetings at least once a month and e-board meetings twice a month at a reoccurring date and time.

XI. ADMENDMENTS 
Autism Speaks U UMass Amherst shall operate in accordance to all university provisions. Any amendment changes shall be passed by a simple majority vote (i.e.: 50% of current, active voting members and an additional 1 current, active member). Amendments to this constitution must be reviewed by the school once adopted by the chapter.

XII. ORGANIZATION AGREEMENT
Chapter agrees to abide by Massachusetts laws regarding hazing. Furthermore, the chapter agrees to abide by all school policies as outlined by UMass Amherst, including, but not limited to:
Checking the organization’s mailbox regularly. 
Communicating via email upon request. 
Updating the organization’s records whenever there is a change.
XIII. FREE SPEECH 
	Free speech of any member will not be limited. We do not discriminate against race, creed, ethnicity, national origin, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender expression, age, height, weight, physical or mental ability, and marital status.

DocsList.Name: RSO info required sharing.pdf
DocsList.Data:
Beekeeping Club 
Here are all the things you have the right to know as a club member, and should know. 

Standards of Conduct 
Individual RSO members are obligated to conduct themselves in a mature and 
responsible manner that does not threaten the safety of others or detract from the 
reputation of UMass Amherst. Violations of federal laws, state laws, local ordinances or 
University policies, whether occurring on or off the UMass campus, are subject to 
disciplinary actions by the the SGA, SA&I or the Dean of Students Office and may 
jeopardize the individual’s/RSO’s active status. All participants are expected to know 
and adhere to the Student Code of Conduct found 

here

. 

Hazing 
The term “hazing” as used in this section shall mean any conduct or method of initiation 

into any student organization, whether on public or private property, which willfully or 

recklessly endangers the physical or mental health of any student or other person. Such 

conduct shall include whipping, beating, branding, forced calisthenics, exposure to 

weather, forced consumption of ay food, liquor, beverage, drug or other substance, or 

any other brutal treatment or physical activity which is likely to adversely affect the 

physical health or safety of any such student or other person, or which subjects such 

student or other person to extreme mental stress, including extended deprivation or 

sleep or rest or extended isolation. 

Notwithstanding any other provisions of this section to the contrary, consent shall not be 

available as a defense to any prosecution under this action. 

Whoever is the principle organizer or participant in the crime of hazing, as defined 

herein, shall be punished by a fine and/or imprisonment. Whoever fails to report such 

crime shall be punished by a sanction from the Dean of Students Office. 

Additional UMass hazing information can be found

 here

. 

Title IX 

Title IX protects people from discrimination based on sex in education programs or 

activities that receive Federal financial assistance. Title IX states that: 

 
​
​
 
​
​
 No person in the United States shall, on the basis of sex, be excluded from participation 

in, be denied the benefits of, or be subjected to discrimination under any education 

program or activity receiving Federal financial assistance. Title IX violations should be 

reported immediately to SA&I or the Dean of Students Office. Additional Title IX 

information can be found 

here

. 

Bullying 

Bullying is unwanted, aggressive behavior that involves a real or perceived power 

imbalance. The behavior is repeated, or has the potential to be repeated, over time. 

Bullying includes things like internet trolling or flaming, name-calling, threats, spreading 

rumors or threatening to release private information/photos, attacking someone 

physically or verbally, and purposefully excluding someone from a group.  Additional 

Bullying information can be found 

here

. 

​
​
​
​

DocsList.Name: Beekeeping Club Strategic Plan 2019.pdf
DocsList.Data:
Beekeeping Club Strategic Plan  

Mission Statement: 

The bee club is a club based on supporting our pollinators and educating others about
bees and beekeeping. With the decline of pollinators and the concerning state of bees in
the current environmental context, a primary goal of the Beekeeping Club is to promote
positive change to help “Save the Bees”. 

Beekeeping Club events will include but not be limited to activities such as education of
club members and the public about bees through educational events, bee-themed art
activities and crafts, planting events, doing outreach to raise awareness, and developing
hands-on beekeeping experience. It is our goal to gauge member interest in different
areas and move the club in those directions. 

Vision: 
Teach people about bees, get them involved in beekeeping, make people happy. 

Five Year Plan and Goals: 

Our five-year plan involves continuing our planned activities and projects, recruiting new
members and giving them opportunities for development to take on leadership positions,
and developing more opportunities to get students engaged learning about bees in both
conceptual and hands-on lessons. We will work on recruiting guest speakers from the
beekeeping community and work to develop lasting connections between them and the
UMass Beekeeping Club. 

Action Steps: 
-Create flyers to raise awareness about the club, including attractive images, contact
information, and meeting times 
-Creating a running list of things members care about, and developing activities that
reflect those interests 
-Being visible in the campus community 
-Give club members the opportunity to teach their peers about bees 
-Contact members of the beekeeping community, whether it be folks form UMass Dining
or the State Apiary Department, to tell them who we are, our goals, and develop lasting
collaborative relations with them to expand upon potential learning opportunities. 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Financial Strategy: 
Facilitate low to no-cost activities, use funds sparingly when needed for events. If extra money is
needed, the club will consider fundraising opportunities as needed. 

Recruitment: 
The club will recruit by posting flyers as needed, talking to other students who express interest in
bees, and attending the activity fair as members are able.

DocsList.Name: UMass Beekping (Bee) Club Constitution 2019.pdf
DocsList.Data:
UMass Amherst Beekeeping Club 

Mission Statement 
The bee club is a club based on supporting our pollinators and educating others about bees and
beekeeping. With the decline of pollinators and the concerning state of bees in the current
environmental context, a primary goal of the Beekeeping Club is to promote positive change to
help “Save the Bees”. 

Beekeeping Club events will include but not be limited to activities such as education of club
members and the public about bees through educational events, bee themed art activities and
crafts, planting events, doing outreach to raise awareness, and developing hands on beekeeping
experience. It is our goal to gauge member interest in different areas and move the club in those
directions. 

Five year plan: 
Our five year plan involves continuing our planned activities and projects, recruiting new
members and giving them opportunities for development to take on leadership positions, and
developing more opportunities to get students engaged learning about bees in both conceptual
and hands on lessons. We will work on recruiting guest speakers from the beekeeping
community, and work to develop lasting connections between them and the UMass Beekeeping
Club. Particularly, we hope to develop a strong relationship with the State Apiary Department of
the Massachusetts Department of Agricultural Resources and UMass Amherst’s Ag Learning
Center to be involved with their hives, and to have them provide support to the Beekeeping Club
in running hives of its own. 

Membership 
This is an open club, and anyone may join the inclusive community. All those present may vote. 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
   
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Meetings 
The club will meet biweekly during the season, and twice a month during the off seasons (with
the flexibility to make more meetings as needed) The casual basis of this club is intended to
respect students’ busy schedules and the seasonality of bees and beekeeping. During meetings
we will plan and execute activities. The executive board will chair the meetings, and decisions
will be made by group discussion with the President making the final say in cases of even ties. 

Executive Board 
President
: Plan and organize meetings for the club, basing decisions of when and where to meet
on the majority approval of other club members, but making the final decision themselves. The
president shall be the main correspondent for the club, and will work with other members to
coordinate activities. The president shall facilitate conversation and engage club members,
working to create a welcoming environment. The president shall have signature responsibility. 

: Assist the president in all related duties. These duties include but are not limited
Vice President
to planning and facilitating meetings, engaging club members, and communicating with outside
correspondents. 

Treasurer
: The treasurer shall be fiscally responsible, and shall be in charge of managing the
finances by keeping track of the budget and spending. The treasurer shall be in charge of making
payments for club purchases, based on the decisions on the group. 

Secretary
: The secretary shall take note of important events occuring in meetings, such that
there will be a record of significant events, motions, and major decisions regarding the club. The
secretary shall readily share this information so all may be informed.  

All officers will share the responsibilities of acting as club leaders. This entails working to
*
organize events and activities, consulting with other officers, promoting inclusion, doing
outreach, and making decisions to best benefit the club moving forward.  

Decisions will be made as a collective group, and responsibilities shall be shared among all
willing members.  

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
​
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
​
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
​
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
​
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
​
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Records, Elections, and Removal Procedure 
Applicable records will be kept by the secretary, and elections will be held at the end of each
term for the following semester during a regularly scheduled general body meetings with ⅔ of
the SGA members in the RSO in attendance. Members shall be notified by email of upcoming
elections. Office elections for the following year shall take place before April 1st. 

The executive board will work to find members to fill vacancies on the board as needed, and they 
will vote on these special elections. 

Officers or members can be removed only once they are notified; they also shall be given the 
opportunity to address the membership and correct their behavior. To remove an officer/member, 
a vote shall be made with a ⅔ vote of the general membership required to enact removal.  

Inclusion Statements 
The Bee Club is an inclusive community where all members have the rights of free speech and
expression, and are entitled to respect. Under no circumstances shall a member’s freedom of
speech or expression be infringed.  

tolerate discrimination, and it

is prohibited under Federal and State law.
We do not
Discrimination, bullying, or hazing of any kind based on race, color, national origin, religion,
sex, gender identity (including gender expression), sexual orientation, disability, marital status,
age, family/parental status, income derived from a public assistance program, political beliefs, or
reprisal or retaliation for prior civil rights activity.
This list is not exhaustive, if you are not being
a good person, it will not bee tolerated. 

Additionally, when addressing club members and guests, they shall be referred to with the proper
pronouns based upon their personal desires. 

Amendments 
Amendments to this document may be made with a majority vote during any meeting of the
Beekeeping Club, to be followed by approval from the Secretary of the Registry. 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
   
 
 
 
 
 
 
​

How to Use This Form

Recreation Club Allocation Committee - Budget Request Form

Review your entire budget breakdown and select those expenses that you would like paid for by the Univeristy of Massachusetts Amherst through an allocation of SGA funds from the Recreation Club Council Allocations Commmittee. Prioritize the items from most important (1) to least important (up to 10). All items, including individual trips 
or items of equipment, should be listed separately.

How the Recreation Club Allocation Committee Will Use This Form

The Recreation Club Council Allocation Committee will review this form and other resources for allocation.  Each club will have the opportunity to explain its priority list, provide additional information regarding budget expenses and estimated income, and clarify any items during its scheduled budget hearing before the Recreation Club 
Council Allocation Committee during the allocation process.

Allocation and Spending by Category

Clubs will be allocated money by category, with allocated funds required to be spent in that category. You may adjust expenditures within category (if you request to fund a trip to Miami and you change that to Atlanta, that is acceptable).  But, to move money between categories (such as from Travel to Equipment) will require a special 
request  to the Recreation Club Council for approval.

DocsList.Name: UBDC Constitution-UpdatedF2017.pdf
DocsList.Data:
Mission Statement 

The mission of the UMass Belly Dance Club (UBDC) is to teach and perform the beautiful and 
ancient art of belly dance at the University of Massachusetts Amherst. UBDC’s goal is to inspire 
and empower students to celebrate and love their bodies regardless of size, age, gender, race, 
ethnicity, sexual orientation, or ability; thus raising self esteem and promoting a community of 
acceptance. UBDC’s passion is to share these goals, values, and talents with the UMass Amherst 
community.  

All members of the UMass Belly Dance Club are entitled to freedom of speech and will not 
under any circumstances be deprived of the opportunity to share their opinion with the group. 
Under no circumstances will a member or potential member of the UMass Belly Dance Club be 
discriminated against due to race, ethnicity, gender, age, orientation, religion or other identities. 

I.

Membership 

nd prop repair, event planning costs, costume costs for those with financial 

A. All Five College Consortium undergraduate and graduate students are eligible to be a 
UBDC member. Any Non-Umass Student will have to pay to use the Recreation Center 
for practices as per Rec Center policy. The majority of this group must be made up of 
undergraduate UMass Amherst students. Graduate students and Five College 
undergraduate students are not eligible to hold UBDC leadership positions as per Student 
Activities and Involvement (SAI) policy. 
B. Membership shall be established after a prospective member signs the club contract/ 
liability waiver and pays dues. Prospective members will then be added to the Campus 
Pulse roster and will remain active members if they attend weekly meetings.  For liability 
and safety concerns, as well as according to SAI regulations, members who do not sign 
the contract or pay dues will be unable to be members of UBDC. 
C. Dues, the cost of which are subject to change every semester depending on club needs, 
are collected by the Treasurer at the beginning of every new semester to aid with the cost 
of props 
a
issues, etc. They are to be in a sealed envelope with the member's name and email written 
on it with exact change inside. All prospective members of UBDC are required to pay 
dues except for graduate students and Five College students (because they pay to use the 
rec-center each week) and those with demonstrated financial need. Any member who 
demonstrates financial need to the Treasurer will be exempt from paying dues. Once dues 
have been paid, the Treasurer will add members names to a Google document to keep 
track of who has paid. 
D. Club Contract: The UBDC member contract will be enforced by the general board and 
followed at all times by every member. It will be given to every new member at the start 
of each semester and kept on file by the Secretary for returning members until they 
graduate or leave UBDC (unless changes have been made to the contract each person was 
given in previous semesters). The Secretary is responsible for the collection and 
distribution of the contract and liability waivers from SAI. They will later input all names 
into a Google document to keep track of who has signed it. The forms will be put into a 
binder for the Secretary to maintain. The contract will be reviewed by the board who will 

 
 
 
​
 
​
​
​
 decide to make changes if necessary at the end of every semester. If changes are made, it 
will be re-distributed to the group at the start of the semester.  

The contract is as follows: 

UMass Belly Dance Club Member Contract: 

 I hereby agree to read, understand, and follow the guidelines set forth in this contract in 

order to be an official member of UBDC: 

1. During UBDC meetings and rehearsals, we have specific goals to reach: 

events to plan, and exciting news to share about 

choreography to teach and learn, 
performances.  So that we can reach these goals together and refrain from distracting 
others during our practice time, we ask that everyone gives the instructors their full 
attention and listens actively while they are speaking. Instructors will ask if anyone has 
questions or needs extra help while learning our group dances. Questions and comments 
are welcomed at this time. By raising your hand, an instructor can answer your 
question(s), take you aside to assist you or you may share your ideas with the group. 

2. To attend UBDC practices and perform, prospective members must sign forms 
and pay dues at the beginning of each semester, attend practices regularly, and come to 
practice on time. Forms will be collected by the Secretary on the date that they specify. 
Financial issues may be brought to the attention of the Treasurer who will assist should 
the need arise (please do not let cost keep you from joining UBDC).  5 College 
undergraduate students do not need to pay dues as they must pay to enter the Rec Center. 
All paperwork and dues need to be turned in within the time frame that the Treasurer will 
announce at the beginning of the semester. They are to be in a sealed envelope with exact 
change inside. The front of the envelope must include your  name and email address. 
 Dues that are not paid on time will result in a meeting with the Treasurer to discuss 
financial situations or an inability to attend practices/events. After paying dues, members 
will be invited to the Campus Pulse roster via email and need to accept to complete 
membership. They will also be invited to join our UBDC members-only Facebook group.   

3.

  UBDC’s members will be informed of performance opportunities as they arise. 

Performing is always optional. All members are expected to answer polls, posts, or 
emails regarding availability for performing in a timely manner. Even if you cannot 
perform, it is more helpful to know that you cannot make it than to have no idea if we 
will have enough members present to perform. At performances, members are expected 
to arrive on time and present themselves in a manner that is respectful to the club and 
belly dance as an art form. Costumes are ordered online by every performer individually 
(unless otherwise specified) and you must do it within a timely manner to be able to 
perform and avoid shipping issues. Again, should financial or ordering issues occur, 
contact the Costume Coordinator or the Treasurer for assistance. Never let cost keep you 
from performing!
practice spaces or the performance stage (for example, in a dining common while getting 
dinner after a show). Walking around in costume before or after events without a form of 
cover up is not permitted as it is unprofessional and we do not want our audience 

Members should not wear belly dance costumes anywhere other than 

 
​
 
 
​
 
 
​
 
​
 members seeing the costumes before we perform. Examples of exceptions include tabling 
at the activities expo or taking a picture with friends after a show.  Ask an instructor if 
you have any questions about this.  Performing is a privilege. If practices are not attended 
and choreography is not learned, a member will  lose the ability to perform. Valid 
excuses given in a timely manner (at least 24 hours in advance) for missed rehearsal time 
include papers/projects, exams, and emergencies like sickness, injury, family issues, etc. 
If three regular club practices are missed after the mid-semester date, a member will not 
be allowed to perform if they do not make up the time at an optional practice session.  

4.

 UBDC is not responsible for the individual actions and decisions of members at 

events that are not club-sponsored. This includes, but is not limited to social events, 
professional belly dance gigs, and outside practices led by members and not UBDC 
instructors (Executive Board).  Any UBDC member who performs professionally at an 
event that is not sponsored by UBDC is expected to perform as an individual under their 
own name and not as a member of UBDC. 

5.

Members who borrow props from UBDC will have to sign a contract before
they are allowed to take the prop from a club practice. The secretary will handle all
contracts. If the props are not returned by the end of the semester, the member who
signed them out will lose borrowing privileges and will have to pay to replace the prop.
They will not be permitted to take out another prop until the missing one is recollected or
replaced. Anyone who returns props damaged will have to pay the club for the
replacement of pieces or the entire prop. 

6.

      UBDC members are expected to be accepting and respectful of all races, 

ethnicities, religions, classes, gender orientations, and identities.   If a member of UBDC 
violates our atmosphere of mutual respect in any manner at any time or place, (whether at 
meetings, events or via social media, etc), they will be notified that their standing will be 
discussed by the UBDC Board and depending on the severity of the case, they may 
receive a formal warning or if necessary, may not remain a member of the club. 

In closing, our members uphold the mission of the UMass Belly Dance Club which is to 
teach and perform the beautiful and ancient art of belly dance at the University of Massachusetts 
Amherst. UBDC’s goal is to inspire and empower students to celebrate and love their bodies 
regardless of size, age, gender, race, ethnicity, sexual orientation, or ability; thus raising self 
esteem and promoting a community of acceptance. UBDC’s passion is to share these goals, 
values, and talents with the UMass Amherst community. Our goal this year is to have fun 
dancing together as a belly dance family and community, host great events, and help one another 
improve dance skills in an inclusive, fun and welcoming environment.   

By signing, I agree to the terms of this contract: 

Signature and Date: 
Printed Name:                                                     
​

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 II. Meetings and Rehearsals  

A. Active members are highly encouraged to attend weekly UBDC general body meetings to 
learn choreography and rehearse as a group.  If a member intends to perform, weekly rehearsals 
are mandatory as missing three practices without a valid excuses given in a timely manner (at 
least 24 hours in advance) for missed rehearsal time including: papers/projects, exams, and 
emergencies like sickness, injury, family issues, etc.; will result in the inability to perform. By 
participating in a Mullins Center cleaning shift, members can earn one free absence. Rehearsals 
and meetings are for the purpose of warming up, teaching choreography and technique, 
practicing, and/or event planning.  
B. Meetings and rehearsals will be instructed and led by the President and Vice President who 
will be assisted by the Secretary and Treasurer for clarity. The President and Vice-President are 
responsible for creating UBDC’s choreographies together. They must seek feedback from the 
Secretary and Treasurer, but will take on the majority of the choreographing responsibility. 
These teachers should be aware that movements or parts of the choreography may not always be 
liked or doable by the general body. Other members should be encouraged to give their input on 
the choreography during rehearsals as long as it doesn’t inhibit productivity during practices.  
C. Weekly board meetings will be attended by all board members for the purposes of planning. 

III. The UBDC Board: 

The UBDC board will be made up of UMass Amherst undergraduate students only: 

A. The Executive Board of UBDC shall be: 

President

:  

● They are the Chief Executive Officer of the RSO.  
● They are responsible for overseeing all aspects of the functioning of the group and must 

have Signature Responsibility and attend activation training yearly.  

● The President is responsible for being the primary contact of the group and booking 
performances for UBDC after checking in with the general board about each one. 

● They are responsible for facilitating our general body and board meetings.  
● They are responsible for reserving our space, time, and day at the Rec Center and are 

responsible for booking all meetings on the behalf of UBDC.  

● The President will be responsible for creating and teaching choreography for 

performances along with the help of the Vice President (they will check in with the 
Secretary and Treasurer for choreography feedback). 

● Monitors the UBDC email account and responds to emails in a timely manner. All board 
members will have access to the UBDC e-mail and drive account but only the President 
and Vice President will respond to emails unless they are responses to e-mails from other 
board members. 

● The President is eligible to sign off on prop sign out logs. 
● The President will be responsible for handling roles on social media, confirm or deny 

access to ubdc social media groups, and handle roles on campus pulse for board/general 
body members 

 
 
 
 
 
​
 ● They will monitor and assist with all aspects of the group’s functioning including, but not 

limited to: event planning, costume ordering, social media, publicity, finances, 
fundraising, and will be responsible for working on any difficulties within the group that 
may arise. 

● The President maintains the power to delegate event planning of festivals and showcases 

among the board members.  

● The President is expected to consult with the board or an adviser on major decisions 

regarding UBDC.  

● They are expected to write the board meeting agenda and send it to all board members at 
least 24 hours in advance so the board may add comments. Attendance to weekly board 
meetings is mandatory. 

● Finally, the President is responsible for writing the constitution and maintaining it 

throughout their time in their position. They are required to show it to the general board 
during a board meeting before the spring semester ends to get all input and approval on 
matters and make changes if necessary. If half of the board or more agrees that a point 
needs to be edited or deleted, it will be done. If the group cannot come to a unanimous 
decision, the adviser of the group will have the final say. 

Vice President

:  

● They are the second in command of the RSO.  
● They are eligible to attend activation training as a representative from UBDC. 
● The Vice President shall take over duties for the President when they are not present and 

will also assist the President in all duties related to the functioning of UBDC.  

● They will assist in teaching weekly classes/meetings and with creating choreography. 
● They will assist with all aspects of the groups functioning including, but not limited to: 

event planning, costume ordering, social media, publicity, finances, fundraising, and will 
be responsible for working on any difficulties within the group that may arise.  

● The Vice-President will be responsible for finding representation from the board for any 

council or SAI required meetings. 

● They are expected to attend weekly board meetings on time and be active, undergraduate 

members of UBDC. 

Secretary

:   

● They will be responsible for maintaining all records for the RSO including documents 
relevant to the functioning of the group (for example, the club contract, prop sign out 
forms, costume fund forms, and liability waivers). These records, in all possible cases, 
will be collected electronically and shall be passed on from the current to the future 
Secretary during the transition period.  

● The Secretary will record minutes at all official group-planning meetings with club 

committees.  

● The Secretary will record attendance at UBDC practices 
● They are eligible to attend activation training as a representative from UBDC. 
● They will assist in teaching weekly classes/meetings and will give input with 

choreography when asked by the President and Vice-President. They are responsible for 
knowing the choreography to assist in teaching when necessary as an assistant 
choreographer. 

​
 
​
 ● They along with the Treasurer, will monitor the campus pulse roster with those who have 
completed the contract and paid dues. The Secretary is expected to keep it updated with 
only active members who have both paid dues and filled out the contract.  

● The Secretary is responsible for keeping a log of the members who borrow props.  
● They are expected to attend weekly board meetings on time and be active, undergraduate   

members of UBDC. 

Treasurer

:  

● The Treasurer will be the Chief Financial Officer of the RSO.  
● They will be responsible for maintaining the group’s finances, including keeping current 
with our Summit accounts, and for all fundraising initiatives including the publicity and 
organization of them. Any other board member who needs to use UBDC funds must 
inform the Treasurer before they make purchases of anything necessary for events, 
apparel, etc. 

● They will be responsible for submitting an annual budget request to the SGA with the 

help of the President.  

● They will be responsible for the collection and recording of dues and any other payments.  
● They will be required to have Signature Responsibility and complete SR training. 
● They will be required to submit purchase requests or procard requests when necessary. 
● They will assist in teaching weekly classes/meetings and will give input with 

choreography when asked by the President and Vice-President. They are responsible for 
knowing the choreography to assist in teaching when necessary as assistant 
choreographers. 

● They will inform the Secretary of the list of those who have paid dues so that they can be 

added to Campus Pulse/UBDC Facebook group.  

● They will be required to inform UBDC members what UBDC will intend to spend money 

on in the current academic year, what members should expect to spend on 
costumes/apparel and what we will do with dues/ money donated to the club. 

● The treasurer is eligible to sign off on prop logs and costume fund forms as a board 

member with signature responsibility. 

● They are expected to attend weekly board meetings on time and be active, undergraduate 

members of UBDC. 

B. The 

General Board

 shall include the 

Executive Board

 and: 

1 Costume Coordinator:  

● They will choose the costumes for each semester with the assistance of the board via 

check ins. 

● They will assist members with ordering/delivery questions and are responsible for getting 
order links to all members as well as the distribution of any pieces that arrive in bulk. 
● They will troubleshoot should issues arise with ordering costume pieces and be the point 

of contact between UBDC and our costume sellers.  

● They will assist members who need help with costume fit. 
● They will also design the UBDC gear/apparel to be ordered each spring semester.  

 
​
 
​
​
​
​
 
 ● They are expected to attend weekly board meetings on time and be active, undergraduate 

members of UBDC. 

 Publicist:  

● They will be in charge of keeping UBDC’s social media representation active (at least 
three posts a week) and advertising for events with input from the general body via 
photos, videos, etc. 

● Their social media duties include: creating facebook events, uploading youtube videos on 
our account, advertising via posters, posting instagram photos, creation of table tent 
designs, tweeting, posting photos/statuses, and keeping all social media pages up to date. 

● They will be in charge of all event advertising including student union banners and 

facebook pages/events. 

● They are expected to be in communication with the board about posting and mindful of 

what they post. *
.   
publicist and President only if security issues arise
​

Passwords for Instagram and Twitter are to be shared among the 

● They are expected to attend weekly board meetings on time and be active, undergraduate 

members of UBDC. 

*
The President, Vice President, Secretary, Treasurer, and Publicist, will be the administrators 
on the UBDC Facebook fan page. The President, Vice President, Secretary, and Treasurer will 
be the only administrators in the UBDC member private group. Administrators must be UMass 
students who are active members of UBDC.  
**While each member of the board has specific responsibilities, it must be stressed that the 
board is a TEAM. The board must help each other as needed and sometimes do things that are 
not a part of their assigned duties. If it becomes so that any board member does not effectively 
perform their duties, please refer to section IV of this document.  

C. Election of Board Members:  

● The UBDC Constitution will be available on Campus Pulse for all members to read about 

the requirements of the election process.  

● UBDC board members are permitted to fill their positions for one year; however, 

provided that they complete their duties completely and efficiently, they may re-run for 
the retention of their position. If nobody chooses to run against them, they will be 
awarded their position if they have been found to complete their duties completely and 
efficiently in the previous year. 

● At the end of each year, the general body will be informed about elections; any member 
of UBDC who has been an active member of UBDC for two consecutive semesters may 
run for a board position.  

● Board Positions will not be awarded to members who are found to be unqualified for the 
position they are running for even if they are running unopposed. Every effort should be 
made to speak to qualified individuals and encourage their election participation if need 
be.If someone is qualified for a position that they did not run for and they lose the 

 
 
 
​
 
​
 
 
 election for the position they originally wanted, they may be invited to serve in another 
position if they are qualified and sent in the proper application materials.  

* New officers should be elected in the spring after spring break to ensure enough time to 
train under the current officers until they leave the position. New officers are officially in 
their position after the last day of classes during the Spring semester. 

1. The required traits for all UBDC board members are as follows: 

● A board member must be mature, warm, welcoming, responsible, trustworthy and 

positive. 

● Dedication to the club is a MUST. This member must have displayed dedication by 
coming to the majority of meetings every week on time for at least two consecutive 
semesters, perform often, volunteer, assist in fundraising efforts, etc. 

● Public speaking skills: this will be crucial when it comes to teaching the group. Board 

members should be comfortable speaking in front of a large group of people.  Teachers: 
(Executive Board) should be comfortable dancing, teaching, improving and performing in 
front of large groups. 

● Timely and organized: Board members must be dedicated enough to take on the 

responsibility of helping to run UBDC and be able to balance these responsibilities with 
other aspects of student life. 

● The member must be a positive role model inside and outside UBDC. 

Everyone who embodies these qualities is eligible for a leadership position: UBDC will 
never be biased against different gender identities, body types, class, race/ethnicity, 
backgrounds, etc. 

For the election of general board members positions

2.
: The President will inform the general 
body of when elections will be. They will then compile a list of the members who are interested 
in each position.  They will collect 1-2 paragraph long statements from each candidate stating 
why they want to be considered for the position and why they think they would be the best 
candidate. 

The board will later discuss and decide if the candidates are eligible and offer positions to the 
most dedicated, well-rounded candidate. This discussion will take place when the candidates are 
not present. Each board member will submit an anonymous vote which will be tallied by the 
board. These votes will determine the next elected board members. The President will inform all 
candidates of the election outcome via email.  They will also inform the general body members 
however they see fit (campus pulse, email, Facebook page, etc). If a current board member is 
leaving their position and wants to apply for a new one, they must go through the same statement 
process and will not be eligible for the discussion and selection of that position.  

3.

For the election of Executive Board Members:  

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
​
 
​
​
 
 
​
 
​
 The President will inform the general body of when elections will be.
They will compile a list of 
the members who are interested in the position. Candidates must submit a written statement (1-2 
paragraphs) to the board stating why they want to be considered for the position and why they 
think they would be the best candidate.They must teach the general board a short choreography 
for ten minutes and answer all questions that board members ask during and after the lesson (the 
choreography should not take ten minutes to learn, but the process of teaching it and having the 
board able to do it should take ten minutes). Finally, candidates must submit a video of a solo of 
at least two minutes in length to the board. After a final question and answer session, the entire 
board will meet to discuss the candidates and decide who will fill each position by filling out an 
anonymous rubric based on the candidate’s teaching and leadership.  The rubric scores will be 
tallied by the board together. This will determine the next elected board members. The President 
will inform all candidates and general body members of the outcome. Any current board member 
running for a position will not be included in the voting or rubric process for the election of the 
position they wish to receive.  

Along with the required traits for all UBDC officers: anyone who is applying for teaching 
positions within UBDC (Executive Board) must have the following qualities which will be 
included in the election scoring rubric: 

● They must be consistently present and on time to all general body meetings, 

performances, and board meetings (if they were previously a member of the board). 
*This point weighs heavily on the Executive Board rubric. 

● They should be able to display an ability to choreograph versatile dance pieces by 

participating actively in UBDC meetings/performances. Other ways to show an active 
interest in expanding one’s dance abilities can include:  Displaying a knowledge of belly 
dance and its numerous techniques and styles by research and by taking extra classes 
(such as belly dance group fit classes at the Rec-center or extra classes with a 
professional) and performing their own solos often.  *This point weighs heavily on the 
Executive Board rubric. 

● They must display an ability to balance teaching, choreographing, attending meetings 
(general body, board, SAI, RSO adviser, SAI trainings, etc) and leading UBDC. 

● They must show an ability to handle stressful situations and adversity should difficulties 

within UBDC arise. 

● They must have performed a solo (prior to the election process) that is their original 
choreographed work and at least two minutes in length. To count, the solo must be 
performed at a UBDC sponsored event (i.e. our Festival) or at an event UBDC has been 
invited to perform for. Events that have audiences made up of only UBDC members 
(such as our Hafla) do not count 

● Most importantly, the new elected Executive Board should have a passion for belly dance 

and sharing this beautiful art form with others. This member should exude a strong 
passion for the club and belly dance as an art. They should add to and maintain the club’s 
atmosphere of friendship and respect. 

 
​
 
​
 
 
 *UBDC teachers do not have to be certified belly dance instructors, however, the executive 
board is strongly encouraged to do at least one workshop with an area certified instructor to 
gain technique with a respected, researched and established instructor.  

IV. General Board/ Executive Board Member and General Body Member Removal: 

A.  Any officer who displays a lack in responsibility in their position or violates the 
contract of UBDC should be given a written formal warning by the President. Should the 
behavior persist after a written warning, the President will call a board meeting and the 
group will discuss and vote on the status of the board member. Any member who puts the 
safety of another board member or general body member in jeopardy will lose their board 
position and/or UBDC membership if there is proof of the incident. If the President 
violates the UBDC contract or displays a lack of responsibility in their position, the 
Vice-President is eligible to give them a written formal warning or call a board meeting 
to discuss their standing if the behavior persists. If the Vice-President and President are 
both in violation, any board member may contact the UBDC adviser to discuss the 
situation.  
B. If the board member in question has never received a written warning, but has behaved 
in a way that warrants a meeting about their status, the board must unanimously agree to 
remove them from their position. If the member has received one verbal and one written 
warning, one more than half of the board must agree to remove them from their position 
and the UBDC advisor must approve of the decision. If the group cannot make a 
decision, the member in question will state their case to the group's adviser who will 
make the final decision. 
C. General body members who behave in any manner that violates the contract of UBDC 
or puts the safety of a member of UBDC in jeopardy will immediately have their status as 
a member be discussed by the board. The member will receive a verbal warning about 
said behavior, then a written warning, and if the behavior persists, the board will vote on 
their membership status if there is proof of the incident.  If the group cannot make a 
decision, the member in question will state their case to the group's adviser who will 
make the final decision. 

V. Resolving Disputes 

● If anyone on the board witnesses or is made aware of behavior that makes other members 
uncomfortable and/or disrupts the club, every board member has the right to ask any 
member to engage in a private conversation about the behavior either before, during or 
after the club meeting in the most polite and discreet manner possible. This is to prevent 
further disruptions, address strife head on and prevent disputes in the future. 

● If a member feels they are being disrespected or feels uncomfortable, they should go 
directly to one of the board members as soon as possible.  It will be dealt with as the 
general board sees fit.   

● Any board member is allowed to contact the club’s adviser for assistance at any time for 

any reason.  

● Mediated meetings among members or board members with an adviser or the head of 
SAI may be called by the President or any other board member should they see fit. 

 
 
 
 ● The President with the assistance of the board if necessary, will mediate disputes between 
all members including board members. Should the need arise, a representative from SAI 
or adviser may mediate.  

● Should the President be involved in a dispute, or should any party not be satisfied with 
the result of the President's mediation, any party may request that the RSO adviser shall 
mediate. The results of mediated conversations with the adviser shall be final. 
● If the issue does not pertain to UBDC or belly dance, the President and the board if 

necessary should suggest resources and work with the UBDC adviser to suggest the best 
solution. 

● If a member has been found to be making threats against other members, or if any 

member is in physical, emotional, or mental danger, then an SAI advisor will be notified 
immediately.
