Alpha Gamma Bylaws
Updated July 2017

Article I: Purpose

The purpose of the Alpha Gamma Chapter of Beta Chi Theta, Inc., Inc. shall be to unite
undergraduates at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst in a fellowship of the founding
principles of this Fraternity, the most important being brotherhood.

Article II: Membership

Section 1. Membership in Alpha Gamma Chapter of Beta Chi Theta, Inc. shall be open
all Undergraduate students who fulfill the membership requirements prescribed by the
to
traditions of the fraternity and as outlined in the constitution. All members must be dedicated
to this grand fraternity and can not be a member of any other social fraternity. The official
of
shall
membership
http://www.betachitheta.com.

‘Brother-Only’

listed within

section

status’

the

be

as

Section 2. New Membership. A bid to commence the New Member Education process in
Alpha Gamma Chapter of Beta Chi Theta, Inc. shall be given with an eighty-five (85%)
approval voting by the active members. If the brotherhood consists of seven or fewer brothers,
then at least two nays are required to negate the bid. Each potential candidate must be voted on
individually and must have attained a cumulative and current GPA of at least 2.5 on 4.0 scale.
The New Member Education process will last no longer than 12 weeks (excluding holidays)
and must be completed before the next election period. The New Member Education process
may not extend beyond the respective Chapter or Colony academic year. The New
Member Education process may not extend beyond the academic year. All New Members and
members of Alpha Gamma must adhere to the principles and traditions of Alpha Gamma

Above All Else, Brotherhood

1

 Chapter of Beta Chi Theta, Inc. set forth during the New Member Education process, as well as
the guidelines set by the University of Massachusetts at Amherst regarding the New Member
Education process.

Section 3. Active Membership. Active members should be those who have completed the
New Member Education process in accordance with the traditions of Alpha Gamma Chapter
of Beta Chi Theta, Inc.. Active members must maintain the minimum cumulative GPA of
at least 2.50 on 4.0 scale; however, Alpha Gamma Chapter of Beta Chi Theta, Inc. highly
encourages a cumulative GPA superior to the set minimum. Active members must actively
participate in all activities dealing with the fraternity unless excused from the majority vote
of the Board of Directors.  Active members must adhere to the principles of the fraternity.

Section 4. Associate Membership. Associate member status may be requested by an active
member if he does not have the time to fully participate in fraternity related activities that is due
to either academic, financial, or personal reasons for an extended period of time. This extended
period of time shall last no more than one academic term (quarter, semester, or trimester) from
the time an individual becomes an active member of the fraternity until the time the member
graduates from his respective institution, barring extraneous circumstances. As an associate
member of Alpha Gamma Chapter of Beta Chi Theta, Inc., one cannot participate in voting,
though they may participate in National Convention voting. An associate member is allowed to
wear the Greek letters of this fraternity. An associate member may attend New Member
Education activities, however they may not directly benefit from New Members. An associate
member is allowed to attend all fraternity related social activities and meetings. A student doing
a cooperative learning experience or an internship outside the state of Massachusetts would
automatically be an Associate member. This will not count towards their one semester of going
Associate. The students that are staying in state will be given the option to stay Active if they
can meet the point minimum. An Associate Member is required to pay National Dues. In order
to attend any Brotherhood events, an Associate Member may pay a fee determined by the Board
of Directors.

Section 5.
Inactive Membership. A member is given inactive member status due to
disciplinary reasons. This inactive period of time shall last at least a minimum of one academic
term (semester, quarter, trimester). As an inactive member of Alpha Gamma Chapter of Beta
Chi Theta, Inc., one cannot participate in voting. An inactive member cannot attend New
Member Education activities, or meetings associated with the fraternity. An inactive member is
not allowed to attend fraternity related social activities.
Inactive membership is determined
through the judicial process as is outlined in Article IX Section 2 of the Beta Chi Theta,
Inc. National Bylaws. Inactive Members are required to pay National Dues.

Section 6. Affiliate Membership. Affiliate member status shall be granted to those Active or
Associate members who leave the host institution before reaching Alumni status. Affiliate
status can only be granted if a brother leaves the host institution as an Active or Associate
member and has not been expelled from Alpha Gamma Chapter of Beta Chi Theta, Inc.
itself. As an affiliate member of Beta Chi Theta, one cannot participate in chapter voting.
Affiliates may participate in national election voting. Affiliate members may participate in
New Member Education activities. An affiliate may request Alumni status if he has

Above All Else, Brotherhood

2

 graduated from another university where Alpha Gamma Chapter of Beta Chi Theta, Inc. does
not exist. This request must be submitted to the National Board via the National VP of Internal
If this request is granted, then an affiliate will be recognized as an alumnus of the
Affairs.
undergraduate chapter from which he was first previously a member.

Section 7. Alumni Membership. Alumni members are those who have graduated from
their respective institutions as active or associate members of Alpha Gamma Chapter of Beta
Chi Theta, Inc.. This is a lifelong membership. Members may apply for Alumni status, if they
remain undergraduates after four years (4) and if he does not have the time to fully participate in
fraternity related activities that is due to academic, financial, or personal reasons. To be granted
early Alumni status a vote of all active members must be passed by a two-thirds (2/3) majority.

Section 8.  Honorary Membership.  Honorary membership can be awarded in any of the
following ways:

8.1 Honorary membership status is given on the discretion of the board of directors of the

respective chapter.

8.2 Honorary membership is given to those who financially support the efforts of Alpha

Gamma Chapter of Beta Chi Theta, Inc..

8.3 Honorary membership is given to those distinguished individuals who actively and
enthusiastically support the efforts of Alpha Gamma Chapter of Beta Chi Theta,
Inc..

Section 9. Expulsion of Members.

9.1 Expulsion of members occurs when an individual blatantly disregards the principles
of the fraternity. This expulsion is left to the discretion of the chapter and requires
a  two-thirds (2/3) majority  by  the  active members of the Alpha Gamma chapter.

9.2 An expulsion of a member must go through the due process as is outlined in

the judicial process in Article IX of the National By-Laws.

Section 10. Active members will be allowed to transfer from chapter to chapter, if the member
is enrolled at the institution where the chapter exists and provided that the recipient chapter
approves the request of transfer.

Section 11. Previously Active members who fail to maintain the minimum GPA required by
Alpha Gamma Chapter of Beta Chi Theta, Inc., as set by Article II Section 3 of the
National Bylaws or that required by the host college/university, will be put on an Academic
probation period and will be subject to the following restrictions:

11.1 Members on academic probation can not attend any of their Chapters or Colonies
events not open to the general public. However, probationary members may attend

Above All Else, Brotherhood

3

 their Chapter or Colony’s brotherhood events and are required to attend all general
meetings.

11.2 Members on academic probation are not able to vote during the

probationary period.

11.3 Members on academic probation are allowed to wear “Beta”, “Chi”, and

“Theta” in letter and written form.

11.4 Members on academic probation will be responsible for sixty percent (60%) of
their Chapter or Colony’s dues. Probationary members will still be accounted for
National dues.

11.5 Members on academic probation can not hold positions on their respective

Executive Boards.

11.5.1 Current Executive Board members, who go on probation, must
step down, and a new election for the vacant position must be held.

11.5.2 If there are no candidates available for the position, the President
will absorb the vacant position.

11.6 The member on academic probation must adhere to Article II Section
10; until he meets the GPA requirements outlined in Article II, Section 3 or of that
set by the chapter or colonies college/university.

Section 12. The academic probationary period will last for one semester or term.

12.1 If at the end of one semester or term the member has yet to raise his cumulative
GPA as required in Article II Section 3, the Board of Directors may extend the
period of probation or take other actions.

12.2 All actions taken pertaining Article II Section 11.1, must be passed with an eighty

percent (80%) vote by the Chapter’s Board of Directors.

12.3 Actions pertaining to Article II Section 11.1 taken by the Board of Directors can
not constitute expulsion of the member, monetary fines, or violate Article II
Section 10.

Section 13. All of the above members shall be recognized as equal brothers with the exception
of honorary members and those individuals participating in the New Member Education
process.

Above All Else, Brotherhood

4

 Section 14. Only active, associate, inactive, affiliate, and alumni members of Alpha Gamma
Chapter of Beta Chi Theta, Inc. are allowed to wear the Greek characters “Beta” (B),
“Chi”(X), and “Theta” (Θ).

14.1 Honorary members of Alpha Gamma Chapter of Beta Chi Theta, Inc. and women
will be allowed to wear the Greek characters “Beta”, “Chi”, and “Theta” in the
written form only.

14.2 In the instance, where Alpha Gamma Chapter of Beta Chi Theta, Inc. National
Fraternity or any of its affiliates are sponsors or hosts to an event, which is open to
the general public; any offerings or merchandise bearing the name Alpha Gamma
Chapter of Beta Chi Theta, Inc. maybe worn or displayed by the general public in
the written form only.

14.3 In no circumstance may a person, other than those identified in Article IV, Section 6,
be allowed to display the Greek characters “Beta” (B), “Chi”(X), and “Theta” (Θ) on
their person or otherwise.

Article III: Officers and Duties.

Section 1. Alpha Gamma Chapter’s Executive Board positions and duties. In-depth and specific
responsibilities are are outlined in the “Alpha Gamma Executive Handbook”.

1.1 President. The President oversees the Board of Director, runs Board meetings,
assembles Board meetings, ensuring that each Board member is fulfilling their
respective duties, enforces rules and regulations of the chapter, and is the official
representative of Alpha Gamma Chapter of Beta Chi Theta, Inc.. Furthermore, his
duties shall include being present at the Board of Trustees meetings and conducting
voting procedures.

1.2 Vice President. The Vice President primary duty is to enforce Alpha Gamma
Chapter of Beta Chi Theta, Inc.’s fraternal objectives internally. He communicates
with other chapters and conducts fundraising efforts. The Vice President immediately
succeeds the President in his duties in times of absence. Moreover, he serves as a
liaison between the Board of Directors and General Body.

1.3 Secretary. The Secretary records all information of fraternity meetings, stores the
official documents of the fraternity, and handles all
legal documentation. The
Secretary reserves any rooms required, collects and organizes photos for each event,
and is the primary contact with the VP of Records.

1.4 Treasurer.

The Treasurer keeps and creates an accurate account of all the chapter’s
monetary funds and needs. The Treasurer also assesses the financial risk of the

Above All Else, Brotherhood

5

 chapter, and takes active measures to ensure financial stability. He will also be in
charge of setting and collecting member dues, as well as all fines.

1.5 Social Director. The Social Director organizes and supervises all social functions and
activities. This includes organizing mixers, a crossing event, and helping the
Brotherhood Chair coordinate any Brotherhood events. They will be the primary
liaison for Greek Week and Homecoming Week along with the President. The Social
Director is also a Multicultural Greek Council representative for Beta Chi Theta.

1.6 Service Director. The Service Director is in charge of setting up Philanthropy events,
keeping track of service hours, and must organize one chapter service event per
semester. The Service Director also must fill out any forms involved with community
service and contact the service provider to ensure the service completed is accurate.

1.7 New Member Director. The New Member Director (NME) coordinates and carries
out all New Member activities and relations with those individuals participating in
the new member education process. The NME is in responsible for budgeting the
pledge process, making bids, creeds, and binders, ordering B’s, tags, and shirts. The
NME will be in charge of conducting interviews, pledge activities, and making the
Pledge schedule. The NME will be in charge of getting newly crossed brothers access
to everything a General Body member has access to. The New Member Director will
be a semester long position, and both semesters will be voted during spring elections.
A semester long NME counts as a full year board experience.

Section 2. Board of Trustees

2.1 The chapter Board of Trustees shall be comprised of the six (6) Founding Fathers of
the Alpha Gamma Chapter of Beta Chi Theta, Inc.:

2.11 Roshan Patel, Winston Ho, Anwesh Yerneni, Pranav Chakravarthy, Kartike
Mathur, Vivek Iyer.

2.2 The Trustees will act as a judicial check for the E-board of the Alpha Gamma Chapter,

and will oversee all operations within the Chapter.

2.3 The Board of Trustees can remove or add a member to the board with a 100% vote by

the Board of Trustees.

2.3.1 This vote shall consist of all six (6) Board of Trustees.

2.4 The aforementioned founders must adhere to their respective Board of Trustees’ roles

and duties once they graduate UMass Amherst/respective host institution.

Above All Else, Brotherhood

6

 2.4.1 Any founder can still carry out his respective duties as a Board of Trustee

as an undergraduate student if required.

2.4 The President will be required to report to The Board of Trustees twice a semester.

Section 3. Chairs

3.1 In-depth and specific responsibilities of each chair are are outlined in the “Alpha

Gamma Executive Handbook”.

Section 4. The Alpha Gamma Chapter of Beta Chi Theta, Inc. must have a Board of
Directors that is elected by its active members. The Board of Directors must consist of active
members.

Section 5. Every chapter and colony of Alpha Gamma Chapter of Beta Chi Theta, Inc. must
have a Board of Directors that is elected by its active members. The Board of Directors must
consist of active members.

Section 6. The Board of Directors may appoint chair positions. Chairs shall assist
fraternity duties.  Chairs are not members of the Board of Directors.

in

Article IV. Elections

Section 1. Alpha Gamma Chapter Election Procedures

1.1 Board of Directors’ elections are to be held annually within the last two weeks of the
spring semester.

1.1.2 Chair position elections are to be held on a semester basis, within the

last two weeks of the fall and spring semester.

1.2 An application for candidacy for a position on the Board of Directors must be

completed and submitted to the existing Board of Directors.

1.3 All applicants for candidacy must be active members for the upcoming academic

semester/year.

1.4 Upon receiving all applications the existing Board of Directors will review the

applications and determine the top three most qualified candidates for every position.

1.5 If a current Board member wishes to run for a position on the Board of Directors he is

automatically a candidate for the position.

Above All Else, Brotherhood

7

 1.6 An active member who cannot stay at the host institution (UMass Amherst) for the full
academic year due to foreseen reasons (i.e. graduation, internship, study abroad, etc.) is still
eligible to run for any year long position except for President and Vice President and is
voted on as a regular candidate.

1.6.1 If said vote results in such a member being elected to the position, another

vote will be run to fill the position for open semester.

1.6.2 This procedure only applies if member is graduating or will not be in the

Western Mass area for a certain semester and will not be able to fully execute his duties as a
member of the E-Board. A member cannot just apply to a position for one semester just
because he does not want to commit to a full year. Any such cases can result in disciplinary
actions at the discretion of E-Board.

1.7 Candidates for President and Vice President can only be previously existing Board
members. Candidates must have at least a semester of experience on the Board. In
order to run for the New Member Director position, one must have at least one active
semester.

1.8 For each position on the Board of Directors there can only be a maximum of three (3)

candidates.

1.9 To be elected into a position on the Board of Directors, the candidate must receive
the majority of the vote.

1.10 All active members are required to vote in elections for Board of
Directors. No active member is allowed to abstain.

1.10.1 If all actives do not vote, the election is invalid.

1.10.2 The running candidates will not have a right to vote in their respective election.

1.10.3 Candidates competing for the same position must remove themselves from the
vicinity of the elections.

1.11 If no board member is willing to take the responsibility of president, the existing
president is obliged to fulfill the succeeding term.

1.12 The newly elected officers will take office on the next semester after said elections

are completed.

1.13 Voting must be held live through Google forms on “umassbct@gmail.com” account.

Above All Else, Brotherhood

8

 1.14 There must be be a “No Confidence” option added to every election.

Section 2. In the event that an undergraduate Executive Board member relinquishes his
position, other than the position of the President, an election must be held to fill the vacant
position.

2.1 If no active members are available or willing to run for the open position, the
President of the Executive Board will absorb the duties of the open position.

2.2 In the event that the President of the Executive Board absorbs the vacant position, the

President does not absorb the voting rights of the vacant position.

2.3 The Voting and Quorum percentages requirement outlined Article V Section 2

will still apply.

Section 3. If the President of Executive Board resigns his position the Vice President of
the Executive Board will take over the vacant position.

3.1 If the Vice President does not accept the President’s position, than the order of

succession will be the following: Secretary, Treasurer, Service, Social, and New
Member Director.

Section 4. If none of the executive board members agree to fill the President’s position, an
election must be held for the vacant President’s position.

4.1 If no active members are available or willing to run for the open position, the

Vice President of the Executive Board must absorb the duties of the open
position, and follow Articles IV Section 2.

Section 5. If the President’s position is filled by another executive board member, the
member’s now vacant position must be filled following the same procedures outlined in
Article IV Section 2.

Article V: Meetings.

Section 1. Alpha Gamma Chapter Meetings.

1.1 Every chapter must set

the minimum time of 1 hour per week for discussing
fraternity-related matters. This general meeting must take place weekly. The active
members of the Alpha Gamma Chapter shall determine the time and day of week of
the general meeting.

Above All Else, Brotherhood

9

 1.2 In addition to the weekly general fraternity meetings,

the Board of Directors
must also meet for an additional minimum of 1 hour per week to discuss the affairs of
the Board of Directors. The Board of Directors shall determine the time and day of
week of the Board meeting.

1.3 All actives are required to attend the weekly general meetings.

If a brother is unable
to attend the general meeting due to legitimate reasons, such as academic priority,
personal matters or religious commitments, then a twenty-four hour notice must
be given with the exception of emergency cases. Emergency cases are to be left to
the discretion of the board.
If a brother misses a meeting with no legitimate
reason, he will be fined fifteen dollars ($15.00). This fine will be allocated to
the general fraternity fund of Alpha Gamma Chapter of Beta Chi Theta, Inc.

1.4 All actives should be on time to the weekly general meetings. A grace period of five
minutes at the start of the meeting shall be given to all active members. After the fifth
minute, a five-dollar ($5.00) fine will be issued to the tardy brother. After the tenth
minute, a ten dollar ($10.00) fine will be issued to the tardy brother. This fine will be
allocated to the general fraternity fund of Alpha Gamma Chapter of Beta Chi
Theta, Inc.

1.5 The current President will conduct the general meetings and the board meetings. The

president opens and closes all meetings.

1.6 In general meetings and board meetings, any propositions must be passed with

an eighty-percent (80%) vote to be approved.

1.7

Two-thirds (2/3) of the active members must be present at a general meeting to

conduct a decision making body.

1.8 Eighty-percent (80%) of the board members must be present at a board meeting to

create a decision making body.

1.9 At general meetings a summary of the previous meeting will be given.

Any decisions reached in the Board of Director’s meeting will be shared with all the
active members.  Discussion of events for the week should take place.

1.10 During the Board of Directors meetings each chair will report any activity

pertaining to his position.

1.11 The President is allowed to veto any decision after it’s been through the process

of voting among the board members.

1.9.1 This shall be used no more than once per semester.

Above All Else, Brotherhood

10

 1.9.2 The decision is vetoed successfully if at least an additional board

member supports the case.

1.9.3 If no other board member supports the case then the veto is denied and

cannot not be used again for the rest of the semester.

Article VI: Finances

Section 1. Alpha Gamma Chapter Finances

1.1 New Member fees. New Member fees shall be $210, subject to change at the
beginning of each semester. These fees will be charged at the beginning of the New
Member Education period and shall be non-refundable. 50% of the required fees
must be paid within the first two weeks the New Member Education process. The
remaining fees should be paid prior to the beginning of the 6th week of the
process. If these fees are not paid in full by this deadline,
those individuals
participating in the New Member Education process will be dropped from the
fraternity. This penalty can be waived by a vote of eighty-percent (80%) by the Board
of Directors.

1.1.1 The final New Member count will be set ten days after the New Members
have been initiated. Each Member remaining after the tenth day will thus
be invoiced and responsible to pay New Member fees.

1.1.2 Any other special or unforeseen circumstances will be looked at by  the  Board
of  Directors  and  penalties  can  be  waived  or extensions can be granted with an
eighty-percent vote (80%).

1.2 Active member fees. The treasurer of the Board of Directors will determine
active member fees. This amount must be approved by an eighty-percent (80%) vote
by the Board of Directors. Active members must pay their fees within three weeks
of the start of the new semester. A payment plan must be issued by the 2nd week of
the semester. Payment plan cannot exceed 8 weeks. Brothers on the payment plan
must an interest of 10% fee of total dues by the end of their plan. If these fees are not
paid within the semester, then the member will be given probation. Any other late
fees are up to the discretion of the Board of Directors.

1.3   Associate member fees.  Associate members must be fifty percent (50%) of the
Active members dues, for the period which the Associate status is granted.  Associate
members will still need to pay National Dues, and will be charged the amount owed for
National dues by the chapter.

Above All Else, Brotherhood

11

 1.4

Inactive member will be exempt

Inactive member fees.
from their chapter or
colony dues for the period which they are inactive. Inactive members will still need
to pay National Dues, and will be charged the amount owed for National dues by the
chapter.

1.5 Affiliate member fees. Affiliate members will be exempt from paying chapter fees.
Affiliate members will still need to pay National Dues. In order to attend Alpha
Gamma events a fee may be chosen by the E-board on an event-to-event basis.

1.6 Academic Probationary member fees. Members on academic probation shall
pay sixty percent (60 %) of the active member fees. Probationary members must pay
their fees within three weeks after the start of the new semester. If fees are not paid
by the deadline, the same regulations and fines are assessed with active members.

1.7 If additional finances are needed,

the treasurer will determine the amount and
course of action to obtain the funds. The course of action must be approved by
eighty-percent (80%) of all active members. If a bill to obtain additional finances is
approved, then all fees must be due within fourteen days of passage. The same
regulations and fines are assessed as with the active members.

1.8 If fees and fines are not paid to the fraternity due to documented financial or personal
difficulties, the Board of Directors will assess the situation and take the appropriate
action.

Section 2. Alpha Gamma Chapter of Beta Chi Theta, Inc. will have their fiscal accounting
year begin September 1st.

Section 3. Alpha Gamma Chapter of Beta Chi Theta, Inc. must abide by the rules and
regulations of a 501(c)(7) tax exempt organization as stated in the IRS publication 557.

Article VII: Service to Humanity

Section 1. The Alpha Gamma Chapter’s active members and those individuals participating in
the New Member Education process must perform a minimum of 10 hours of community
service per semester. However, the Alpha Gamma Chapter of Beta Chi Theta, Inc. highly
encourages each member to set exceed the minimum for community service hours. Based on
the amount of service opportunities during the semester the Service Director can change the
amount of service hours per semester, upon approval of the Board of Directors.

Article VIII: Hazing

Above All Else, Brotherhood

12

 Section 1. Alpha Gamma Chapter of Beta Chi Theta, Inc. will not participate in Hazing.
The National Board will consider a period of probation for the chapter participating in hazing.
If probation is granted, then the National Board shall determine the period of probation.

Section 2.
University of Massachusetts Amherst and the Massachusetts government.

The Alpha Gamma Chapter must follow the anti-hazing laws set forth by

Article IX.  Judicial Procedures.

Section 1. Judicial procedures for Alpha Gamma Chapter:

1.1 A written complaint must be submitted to the Vice President.

1.2 The Vice President must then submit the complaint before the Board of

Directors.

1.3 The Board  of Directors will  review the complaint and  determine its merit.

1.4 If the Board of Directors finds the complaint to have merit and wish to proceed with

judicial  procedures,  they must  first  notify the National Board.

1.4.1 The National Board will only act as mediators and will have no bearing on the
decision made by the chapter or colony.

1.5 Than the Board of Directors will address the complaint before all active members in
the form of a hearing. Here, both sides will be given an opportunity to plead their
case.

1.6 After the hearing, a two-thirds (2/3) majority vote is needed to reach a decision.

1.7 After a decision has been reached, the Judicial Board has two days to execute the

decision.

1.7.1 Decisions taken by the Judicial Board can consist of putting the member
on Inactive status, expulsion of the member, or other sanctions.

1.7.1.1 Sanctions   may   not   violate Beta Chi   Theta,   Inc.’s
Constitution, National Bylaws, or Chapter Bylaws.

1.8 All active members are required to vote.

1.9 Voting must be done anonymously.

Above All Else, Brotherhood

13

 Section  3. The  Judicial  Board,  made  up  by the  Board  of  Directors  of  Alpha Gamma
Chapter, shall conduct the chapter hearings.

Section 4. If Alpha Gamma Chapter disagrees with a decision or action made by the
National Board, they may formally contest the decision.

4.1 Alpha Gamma must first formally appeal to the National Board, and present their case

to the National Board.

4.2

The National Board upon hearing the appeal may decide to overturn their own

decision by a (5/6) vote, or uphold their decision with a (5/6) vote.

4.3

If National board upholds their own decision, the chapter/colony can then appeal to
the Trustees in a formal written appeal, stating their case.

4.4 The Trustees will first review the appeal to establish if the case has merit.

If the Trustees decide that the appeal has no merit with a (2/3)
4.4.1
vote, the National Boards decision will be upheld and the case will not be
further reviewed by the Trustees.

4.4.2
If the Trustees, with a (2/3) vote, decide that the appeal has
merit and will be further reviewed, they will then ask for the National Board
to formally write it’s defense.

4.4.2.1 The National Board’s rebuttal statement

is to be submitted
within one week of the Trustees informing them that the appeal
will be heard.

4.4.2.2 After hearing both sides the Trustees with a (2/3) vote, will decide
to whether to uphold the National Boards previous decision or to
over turn it.

If the Trustees ruling are not in the favor of either the National
4.4.3
Board or the contesting chapter or colony and either wishes to further pursue
its case, they may appeal to the brothers of Alpha Gamma Chapter of Beta
Chi Theta, Inc. who are in attendance at the following National Convention.

4.5 At the following National Convention, a certain amount of time will be set aside to
allow both parties to present their arguments in front of the assembly of Brothers.

Above All Else, Brotherhood

14

 4.5.1
After the brothers have heard both arguments they will vote
anonymously whether to uphold or overturn the trustees decision with a (2/3)
vote. The votes will be tallied by one trustee, one National Board member,
and the president of the contesting chapter or colony.

4.5.2 If the Trustees decision is overturned than the contesting party’s
argument will be upheld.

4.5.3 All decisions made by the Brothers of Alpha Gamma Chapter of Beta Chi
Theta, Inc. at National Convention will be final.

4.6

If a party did not receive a ruling in their favor, they may make another appeal or
reestablish an overruled decision, only on the condition that there are new and
unequivocal facts to support their appeal or decision.

than an
the conditions in Article IX Section 4.6 are met,
4.6.1 If
appeal by a chapter or colony must again follow the procedures found in
Article IX Section 4.

Article X: Accountability

Section 1.

All Active members are required to follow the points system, and meet the

minimum requirements set by the Board of Directors each semester.

1.1 The minimum point requirement is determined by the Vice President and approved
by the Board of Directors by an Eighty Percent vote (80%).

1.2 Upon exceeding the minimum requirements, members will be receiving

incentives, based on the ranking based on the top 5-point holders.

1.2.1 Board of Directors will create incentives on a yearly basis.

Section 2.
to the same pedigree as an active member.
2.1.
necessary.

Alumni that visit Alpha Gamma will be held accountable for their actions

In case of misbehavior, Board of Directors will decide if repercussions are

2.1.1
The repercussions will be decided by the Board of Directors

2.2

The punishment’s severity must be passed with a 50% General Body approval.

Above All Else, Brotherhood

15

 Article XI.  Amendments

Section 1. Any member of the Alpha Gamma Chapter of Beta Chi Theta, Inc. can propose an
amendment to the Chapter By-laws. The proposal must be sent to the Board of
Trustees and the Board of Directors.

1.1 The Alpha Gamma Chapter may amend their Bylaws, with an (80%)
consensus from its active members, in order to shape their Chapter Bylaws to
better accommodate their goals.

Section 2.   The proposed amendment must not be contradictory nor conflict with the National
Bylaws or Constitution of Beta Chi Theta, Inc.

2.1

In the event a contradictory amendment must be made to satisfy the policies or
regulations of the host undergraduate school, the contradictory amendment must be
submitted to be reviewed and approved by the National Board.

2.2 The proposed amendment must be sent to the National Board, via their respective
Regional Director, to be approved and to allow the National Board to update their
Alpha Gamma Chapter records.

2.3 Upon approval of the National Board the proposed amendment will be effective

and enforceable by the chapter or colony.

Article XII.  Alpha Gamma Chapter Founding Fathers

Section 1. The Founding Fathers of the Alpha Gamma Chapter will remain as trustees in order
to further guide and assist their chapter. The Founding Fathers of the Alpha Gamma Chapter
can assist in the path in which the fraternity takes in order to preserve the fundamental
principles on which Beta Chi Theta, Inc. was founded.

Section 2. The Founding Fathers of the Alpha Gamma Chapter will be known as the Alpha
class.

2.1 All subsequent classes will be named based on the sequential order of the Greek

alphabet.

Section 3. The Alpha Gamma Chapter must include the names of its Founding Fathers into
their Chapter Bylaws.

3.1 Founding Fathers

Roshan Patel
Winston Ho
Pranav Chakravarthy

Above All Else, Brotherhood

16

 Kartike Mathur
Vivek Iyer

Above All Else, Brotherhood

­­
UMASS
Bicycle Cooperative
 
Worker’s Handbook
&
Procedural Guide
 

 
“And thirdly, the code is more what you'd call "guidelines" than actual rules”
 
-Captain Barbosa

Group Decision Making
Welcome
I. Introduction 
1. About the Bike Coop 
The UMASS Bike Coop is a student run business that serves the UMASS community.  We offer a convenient, low cost alternative to other area bike shops by providing reasonable prices, quality service, and by maintaining a forum for our Co-Managers to teach both our customers and each other about all aspects of bicycle repair. 
            The Bike Coop has enthusiasm for cycling and the maintenance and repair of bicycles, as well as a great interest in gaining the educational experience achieved through the operation of a successful, student run business.  We incorporate the diverse knowledge and the experience of our Co-Managers, emphasizing that while mechanical expertise is a plus, a strong desire to contribute to our business is our primary criteria.
            The Bike Coop operates on a payroll based system allowing for our Co-Managers to not only learn but to receive payment for their services.  Each mechanic is responsible for their own work. The UMASS Bike Co-op is an equal opportunity employer.
            In our efforts to ensure the democratic nature of our organization, we find that the maintenance of an effective formal structure is essential.  This ensures that decisions we reach as a group are effectively implemented with the knowledge and support of all Co-Managers.  For this reason, we are strict about our Co-Managers’ attendance at All-Staff meetings, their familiarity with our goals, and our expectations of professionalism in the performance of all services to the UMASS community.
        	
On-Shift Duties
 
To ensure the success of the Bike Coop in serving the community of UMASS this document should be read in full and updated at the end of every hiring process. As a business each co-manager at the Bike Coop is expected to do the following:
 
1. Co-manager Responsibilities
Show up for scheduled shifts and Be punctual!
Contribute at least 3 hours on schedule a week.
Get someone to cover for you if you are unable to be there!
Be Professional to Bike Coop Customers
Don't leave a customer floating: be proactive and ask if they need help.
Help the customer or point them towards a solution.
Be honest about your skill level. If you don’t know how to solve a problem seek help from another co-manager or direct the customer to other resources.
Under-promise over-deliver; anticipate the unknown extra charges and quote a higher price. A customer is always happier paying less than expected than more. 
Get your questions answered.
Communicate with all Co-Managers of the Coop
 
2. Mechanic Responsibilities
See that the repairs promised get done promptly.
Maintain a high standard of quality in your work as well as of your fellow Co-Managers
Ask your fellow Co-Managers for help or to check your work 
Assist New Hires in mechanical operations of the Coop
Help them to adjust to the new surroundings and anything they need help with
New hires must get their work checked by another co-manager.
 
3. Training and Overseeing of New Hires:
The training committee will organize at least the following training sessions:
Running the register and filling out tags
Basic mechanics: safety checks, fixing flats, adjusting brakes, adjusting derailleurs
Medium mechanics: Truing wheels, adjusting bearings (headsets, hubs, bottom brackets)
Mechanics are encouraged to make every opportunity to share their knowledge and info with new hires.
New hires are encouraged to ask questions and take the initiative to learn the ins and outs of the Bike Coop from the experienced Co-Managers of the Coop.
Assist New Hires in business operations of the Coop
Help them to adjust to the new surroundings and anything they need help with


4. Taking Bikes In/ Using Bike Tag
 All Co-Managers are responsible for logging in bikes during their shift.  When a customer brings in a bike, you need to do each of the following: 
Check the bike over.  Look for loose hubs, headset, BB, missing spokes, worn brake shoes, etc.  
Let the customer know if the bike needs more than the requested repairs.
Remove all unattached accessories from the bike (locks, helmets, etc.)
Fill out a tag and fasten the stub to the bike. 
Put the tag in the appropriate slot

5. Customer Complaints
If a customer is unsatisfied with the work the Bike Coop has done on his/her bike, follow these 2 steps:
1. Evaluate the problems they have with the work
2. If complaint is valid and caused by employee error, redo service at no cost
 
6. Checking Off Work Done
 It is imperative that all mechanics check off their work for any repairs done.  This is the only way that we can keep track of the work that you’ve done, so check mark and initial next to the job done on the tag. 
Indicate that the work was done, and note any work the customer confirms or denies.

7. Call Back System
To allow the Bike Coop to keep the flow of bikes going in and out of the Coop, we must use our call back system. Not only will it help with space problems but with customer service appreciation.
 
Call customer and inform them politely that their bike has been finished and what the cost will be. Inform them that they need to pick up their bike within 3 days or a late fee of $10/day will be charged.
Write down your initials and the date and time you called, in three days call again to inform customer of charges.
 
8. Working the Register
 We use lavu to track our sales, meaning all sales must be checked out through lavu.
Enter your pin to log in.
Go into the labor or parts tab depending on what work is being entered.
Select appropriate category, and the appropriate labor or part for the job.
BOTH THE PART AND LABOR FOR JOB MUST BE INPUTTED!
Once the correct amount of parts and work has been entered, select checkout in the top right corner.
Select the proper payment method (card, cash, or ucard debit).
If paying with cash, first enter the amount of cash they’re giving you (so if it’s a $15 job but they use a $20 bill, enter $20, not $15) and then hit the cash button.
If they’re paying with cash, give them the correct change.
If they’re paying with a card, hit sale, enter the amount of the purchase, hit enter, and follow the prompts on the screen.
Make sure the customer signs the receipt if prompted to.




9. Taking in Orders this all need to be redone
        	A. Special Orders
      	These are extremely important to our business. If a customer needs a part and we do not physically carry it in our inventory we can accommodate the customer by making a special order.  This function allows us to serve every customer’s parts needs and no customer should leave the shop feeling like they could not get the part from the Bike Coop. When a customer needs a part ordered that is not in inventory the way to do so is as follows:
            	1. Find the part in the Quality Bicycle Products or Action Bicycles
Weekly ordering should be done consistently on the same day each week by the Accounts/ordering position.  The order will consist mostly of inventory items that are out of stock, such as tubes.  Any special ordering can be done by both cooperative members and patrons.
 
The procedure for SPECIAL ORDERS  is as follows:
1.  	Identify the product to be ordered within the catalog.
2.  	Quote a reasonable price (or predetermined price) to the patron.
3.  	Get ALL of the money UP FRONT from the patron, including shipping and handling
4.  	Put the order in to the Accounts/ordering position.
 
Employee special orders must be paid up 50% front at cost plus 20%.
 
        	B. Team Purchases
All purchases by the UMASS Bike Racing Team are filed under Team Purchases. 
Team Purchases have a 30% markup on Wholesale prices.  Team Purchases can be entered using the Team Purchases Code for the Register.  *See Working the Register Section*
Do we want to offer this again? UMBRC kits are done for this year, but we may get on the kit next year
 
        	C. Employee Purchases
All purchases by the Bike Coop Co-Managers can be filed under Employee Purchases. 
Employee Purchases have a 10% markup on Wholesale prices.  Employee Purchases can be entered using the Employee Purchases Code for the register.  *See Working the Register Section*

III. Committee/Outside of the Shop Duties
1. Attend All-Staff Meetings
Get any missed information if you cannot attend as soon as possible.
Communicate and Participate in All-Staff meetings
Take notes when it is your turn in the rotation
Facilitate when it is your turn in the rotation
Send out new blank agenda when it is your turn in the rotation
Perform all tasks and duties associated with your Committee title and report out weekly
 
2. Committee Work
All Co-Managers of the Bike-Coop are required to take an active role in the committee structure of the Bike Coop
Remember that all work done on committees will be paid in full
Any work a co-manager is responsible for that they do not complete will be discussed as a dot-able offense
 
C. Snow Day Policy/Closed Policy
If the school is closed due to snow or any other reasons, the Bike Coop will not be open for that day.
If the school decides to cancel classes early due to snow  or any other reasons, the Bike Coop will not be open for that day, nor will All Staff occur

IV. Miscellaneous Notes
1. Co-Manager Benefits
By becoming a Co-Manager of the Coop, you have committed yourself to a business operation and are expected to uphold your portion of the responsibility in the daily tasks.  In addition, being a Co-Manager of the Bike Coop entitles you to certain privileges.
 
Free admission to any workshops, races, or rides sponsored by the co-op
Parts at cost plus 10%
Discounts from other student businesses
Valuable bike repair experience
Experience in business functions and decisions
 


V. Bike Coop’s Formal Structure
1. All-Staff Meetings
Day: Thursdays @ 7pm
All-staff meetings are mandatory and are held every week.  This is intended to keep all Co-Managers of the Coop abreast of new information and events.  Each week a Co-Manager of the Coop will volunteer to be the note taker and the following week that person will facilitate the meeting.  The meetings have a general structure including the following:
Opening Go-Around, Dot/Star Report, Consultant Report, BOsB Report, Marketing Report, Purchasing Report, Communication Report, Cash-Out, and any other issues or concerns that develop during the course of the semester.
At the beginning of each semester the Consultant needs to schedule meeting locations with the CSB.  These locations must be within the Bike coop or CSB.  No All-Staff can be held outside of these locations. 
 
2. All-Staff Procedure
Before every meeting, the Dot/Star Committee/Co-Manager should bring the Dot/Star Spreadsheet, along with the notebook for notes, and this handbook to the meeting.
Note taker Responsibilities
Read off Follow Throughs from previous week’s meeting when the Follow Through section is during the meeting  
Record any and all Follow Through during the meeting on the agenda document
Record each discussion point for each committee’s report and any other issues or discussion affecting the Coop
Employees are not allowed any unexcused absences. All absences must have a valid excuse like:
Medical appointment
Exam
Emergency
If you are REALLY sick
THEN UR FIRED
All shifts must be attended or covered.  There is no excuse for missing a shift except an emergency.  A missed shift will result in a dot

 
3. Dot Star Policy
 The dot star system allows for coop employees to evaluate the behavior of their co-managers.  It is an opportunity for individuals to speak up about issues and feelings they have, good and bad, with the behavior of fellow employees.  It helps to ensure no one’s hard work goes unnoticed, but also makes sure that individuals are held responsible for their actions.  If a co-manager has done or is doing something that you feel is detrimental to the business you have the responsibility to dot them.  Vice versa, if a co-manager is doing something that you feel is beneficial to the business you may reward them with a star.

DOTS
 The dots received by individuals during the week will be discussed at the next all-staff meeting.  The employee who received the dot(s) will have a chance to appeal at the meeting.  It will then be decided by a group vote if the dot was justifiably given or not.  If the group votes yes, the dot will remain.  If the group votes no, the dot will be taken off the chart. Employees that receive dots have a chance to remove them from their record by earning a star.  Dots will transfer over from the previous semester if they were received in the final month of the semester.  Because stars can remove dots, employees have many opportunities to clean up their record if they choose.  If the dot was received prior to the last month of the semester, it will be erased off the record. Dots should be given for careless, malicious and destructive actions, not honest mistakes.
 
Dot worthy actions include:
Skipping all-staff without valid reason
Skipping a shift without valid reason
Failing to follow through on a FT
Leaving the shop a mess
Unproductive during shift
Disorderly conduct:
Yelling with rage and use of profanity
Damaging property
Inappropriate behavior 
Exploiting or offending customers or co-managers
Improper or destructive use of the computer
Any suspicious money handling
Verbal or physical abuse of co-manager or customer
Stealing any coop property
 
Consequences upon the accumulation of 5 dots:
No personal orders
Mandatory 1 hour, unpaid, not on shift shop clean. One hour of cleaning will erase dot 5, Other four will need stars to replace
Meeting with HR 
 
Upon the accumulation of 4 dots, the dot-ee will be brought up for termination before the other employees at the next all-staff meeting.  For termination to occur, it must be voted at all staff by a majority of those present.
 
Half Dots
Half dots are also possible. Doing work not up to standards, calling a customer before work is done, and not filling out a tag completely are examples of half dot worthy offenses. Half dots are for mess ups that don’t quite meet full dot standards, but some disciplinary action is warranted.


STARS
 Stars are awarded to employees who do things that benefit and help the business.  As with dots, stars will be discussed at all-staff meetings to validate their distribution.
 
Star worth actions include:
Filling in for someone
Cleaning and organizing the shop
Starting a new project
Cutting that mullet
Doing any off shift work for the coop
Filling in for someone’s follow through
 
4 stars earns you a large beverage!

B.  Bike Coop Bookkeeping Procedure
 
Bookkeeping
-          Should be done once a week (Usually Thursday) and available for review by the consultant. The consultant may also wish to set up a weekly meeting with the bookkeeper to discuss the business. It is required by the CSB that the bookkeeper and consultant meet at least once per month
-          Bookkeeping consists of recording of the cashouts and purchases of the business on both the computers in the CSB, and in filing related paperwork.
 
Logging onto Computers at CSB:
Press control, alt, delete.
Enter username and password
Username: bikecoopcm1-sa or bikecoopcm2-sa
Password: Helmets4@LL!!
 
QuickBooks: dic
1.      Using QuickBooks comes with training and everyone with training who uses QuickBooks must have signature responsibility.
2.      QuickBooks is where all the Bike Coop’s records of accounts are stored; all money spent and earned is logged in QuickBooks. Those include: purchases, daily cash outs and weekly payrolls. Anyone who is going to be on purchasing, payroll, or bookkeeping committee must learn how to enter their given information into QuickBooks.
3.      QuickBooks is the nucleus of bookkeeping and money tracking in the Bike Coop, neglecting your duties for QuickBooks is a five dot offense.
 
Logging into QuickBooks:
1.  	Go back into the bike coop folder and hit quickbooks. Log into it.
Username: QBEBike
Password: $bikeQ4
 
 Entering Data on QuickBooks:
1.  	From the main page of QuickBooks you must go to the “general ledger” to get there go to “Lists” on the menu bar, pick the first thing under “Lists” (Chart of Accounts”) and from there select “General Ledger” (7th one down).
2.  	Now you get to enter data into QuickBooks! There are three different things we as the Bike Coop enter into QuickBooks: Payroll, Cash outs, and Pro-Card orders.
 
 
C. Cash out:
	Daily Cashout Duties: Cashout Committee:
 
Cashout involves counting the money from the register at the end of the day; comparing the Z tape to the transaction tape and actual money in till (Drawer) and logging it in the cashout form; leaving $100 for the next day’s operations; filling a deposit slip for the bank.
   
Count the total amount of money in the register: it should equal the amount of money in transactions since the last cashout + $50.  If this is not the case, you have a discrepancy.  
 If you find a discrepancy of $20 or more, it has to be filed with the Center for Student Business with an “Over/Short” form. 

To deposit at the bank, bring the cash bag if you feel compelled to present yourself as a mark) to the bursar’s office window.

Step 1: Counting the Cash in the Register
After closing, print out z tapes from credit card machine and lavu.
Lavu: log into lavu, hit lavu button (top left corner), hit manager options, and then print z tape.
Credit Card Machine: hit other, close batch.
Bring up cash out sheet template. This is located in google drive in the cash out folder.
Make a copy of the cash out sheet template (File>Make a copy) and rename it as the date that you are depositing for. Put this into the correct year and month folder for organization.
Fill out how many bills you have in this cash out form. You want to put the amount of money you have in bills rather than the number of bills. For example, if you have 4 $20 bills, you would input $80, not 4. Do this for all bills and coins.
Fill out the rest of the sheet.
Separate $100 out of the total cash in the register. The register must always have $100 in it. You only deposit what is left after the $100 is taken out.

To Get Ready to Deposit:
Go to the CSB with the money that you are going to deposit. Log into one of the computers with the bike coop login.
Username: bikecoopcm1-sa OR bikecoopcm2-sa
Password: Helmets4@LL!!
Go into the directory (if it isn’t already open, click start in the bottom left corner of your window and click documents). From here click on pubdir on the left side menu. Next hit All Business Files, and then Bike Coop. Next go into the cash out folder. From here there will be a document called Deposit Form Template (or something of that nature). Open this up.
The deposit form should look like the picture on the right. The highlighted areas are where you will be inputting information. Put in Bike Coop under group name and your name under depositor. Next, input your bills into the section on the top right hand side. This is just like the cash out sheet from before, except you are only inputting the bills that you will depositing. Again, put in the amount, not the number of bills (if you have 4 $20 bills, you would input $80, not 4). Into description put the date that the money was earned, not the date that you plan to deposit it (if this is the cash out for 2/27, put 2/27/20xx, even if you do it on 3/2). On the very bottom on the left side there is a large blank space. Here you put your name, email, and phone number. This is so you can be contacted if there is an issue with the deposit. 
The speed type, account, and dept id should already be saved into the document. The amount section will automatically tally up the amounts from when you inputted the bills.
How to do credit cards will be put in when figured out lol.
Next, SAVE AS the file. This makes a new copy with the information you just put in without getting rid of the template. Put this file into the correct folder corresponding with the year you are depositing for as well as the month.
Now, print out 3 copies to the CSB printers. Also go into the google drive and print out 1 copy of the cash out sheet. 
Staple the cash out sheet, 1 of the deposit sheets, and all of the z tapes together. These will be stored in the bike coop filing cabinet.
Before you file the stapled cash out stuff away, do Quickbooks and sales tracking.

Quickbooks:
Go back into the bike coop folder and hit quickbooks. Log into it.
Username: QBEBike
Password: $bikeQ4
Hit the chart of accounts button, general ledger, and make the window big. At the bottom of the window is where you input all of the information. 
In number, put your initials. In payee, put the name of what you are inputting (ie cash, credit card, ucard, etc). In account, it depends on what entry you are putting in. It is all under the revenue category, but if you are doing the cash, it will be revenue: cash, and so on for credit card and ucard. Under increase put the amount of that earned. The date should be the date that the revenue was earned, not the date you are entering it into quickbooks. When you want to submit the entry, hit the record button.
Cash, credit card, and ucard all get their own entry, so if you have purchases using all of them, you will have 3 entries.
Now you can exit out of quickbooks and do sales tracking!

Sales Tracking:
Go back into the cashout folder. Hit the current sales tracking.
Inside, go to the first tab. The columns have what you need to input. Make sure you are inputting it into the correct date. Basically put in what lavu says you made for credit card, ucard, cash, etc and then what you actually counted. 
On the second tab, it shows an overview. Here, if there is a discrepancy, there is a column where you put why that happened. There is also a column where you can put comments (ie it was a snow day or whatever). 
Save the document!

Now that you’re done in the CSB, put the stapled packet into the correct drawer (in the correct month/year) to file.

Now the Actual Depositing:
Put the money you are depositing in your money bag with 2 copies of the deposit form. Take this to the bursar’s office window (located in whitmore. It’s on the second floor, and on the directory in the entryway to whitmore it should give you the exact room number).
Give the teller the deposit form and your cash. Now you’re done!

A Few Notes:

Put the cash that stays in the register (the $100) into a separate money bag so you don’t mix the $100 with the money to deposit, and bring it to the business center for overnight safekeeping. The person who has the opening shift the next day will get it from the business center and put the $100 back into the register.

If you can’t do it for some reason and nobody on cash out can do it, ask the person who closes to print them out and put all of the money in the register in the safe, that way you get the daily reports and can count register money the next day.

The total can be found under “Total” on the right hand side of the Cashout Sheet, finally in the “Account” Column (under “Payee” column on the right) select “CASH” and hit “record” (located on the lower right hand side of QuickBooks)

To do this you first put the date of the day you are recording under the :Date: column, put your initials under the “Type” column, in the “Payee” column select “UCard Revenue” enter the total money earned that day (S&V total on Z-tape) in the “Increasing” column and finally in the “Account” column (under and to the right of “Payee” column) select “UCARD” then hit record (lower right hand side of QuickBooks).
5.  	Then you are done entering in the data from that day. Congratulations!

VII. HR Committee

A. Overview
The HR committee shall consist of 3 elected members who serve for two semesters at a time before elections are held again. The HR committee shall be responsible for handling interpersonal conflicts between co-managers at the Bike Coop that the co-managers are uncomfortable with bringing up at All Staff. The HR committee will also be responsible for meeting with underperforming co-managers who have received 5 or more dots over the period of one semester. 

B. Elections
At the end of Spring semester of each year, elections will be held to determine the members of the HR committee for the next two semesters. In order to be put on the ballot, a person must first be nominated by another co-manager, the nomination must be seconded by a third co-manager, and then the nomination must be approved by a majority vote of the co-managers. Once all nominations have been put in and approved or disapproved, a vote will be held in which each co-manager may cast two votes and those three candidates with the greatest number of votes will serve as the members of the HR committee for the following two semesters.

C. Responsibilities
The primary responsibility of the members of HR committee is to create an atmosphere in the Coop in which people feel safe and secure in addressing their grievances both with other co-managers and with the Coop culture. 
If a co-manager approaches a member of the HR committee with an issue, it is the responsibility of that member to handle in a way that both addresses the co-managers concerns and prevents unnecessary conflict. Members of the HR committee should respect co-managers requests for anonymity regardless of the situation as respecting the wishes of your fellow co-managers and making them feel comfortable is part of the primary responsibility of the HR committee. 
In the event where a co-manager has a grievance with another co-manager that they wish to have addressed, the member of the HR committee is responsible for arranging a mediation between the co-managers to come to an amicable conclusion. 
Members of the HR committee also have the responsibility to inform co-managers about complaints about them if the complainant wishes their complaint to be known. 
If issues arise among comanagers and two or less HR committee members, the remaining HR member/s should be approached with the issue. If the issue(s) regards all three members of HR, it shall be brought up at all staff or in some context outside of HR. 

D. Firing
Members of the HR committee are responsible for meeting with co-managers who have accumulated 5 or more dots in one semester at the Coop to inform them of their status and also discuss the issues addressed in the dots. In this case the members of the HR committee are responsible for informing the co-manager that they are in a probationary period in which they may not earn any more dots. If the co-manager receives another dot during this time, they are brought up for termination at the next All Staff and if a majority of fellow co-managers approve their termination then they are fired. 
Members of the HR committee also have discretion and responsibility in regards to co-managers whose behavior they believe is so detrimental to the Coop they cannot work there any longer. In the event where a co-manager engages in serious misconduct (assault, theft, etc.) and the HR committee is made aware of the misconduct, the co-manager will immediately be met with by the committee and based on the meeting, brought up for termination at the following All Staff. 


 VIII. Conclusion
A. Group Decision-Making
It is the ideology of the Bike Coop to make significant decisions collectively, in a Democratic manner.  This process ensures that each Co-Manager has a voice in the Coop and that no one person has more power than another. Responsibilities at the Bike Coop have tended to accumulate on a few of the managers, resulting in some burn out. Be sure to help out as much as you can.
            It is important for all of the Coop's Co-Managers to remember that anyone can serve on any committee or help to facilitate a meeting.  The only people who likely have the legitimate power to sway a group's decision are those who have been with the Coop for a semester or longer, and their experience and knowledge of how the Coop is run will lead them to their decisions and assumed leadership.  There is currently no formal quantification of such a person's legitimate power in influencing group decisions-- this tends to amount to the extent that a person's knowledge and voice is known and respected within the group.
All committees should report to the Coop routinely at weekly All-Staff meetings.  This is an important "checks and balances" device, to ensure that the committees are performing their functions to the satisfaction of the group as a whole.
 
We hope you enjoy your time here as a member of the Bike Coop.

9:50pm – Everyone heads to their stations, Steven checks with everyone who is assigned a task 
10pm – Doors open, Deejay KaiKai on set,
11:30pm – Comp list line closes 
12am – Doors close, Big Tunez the DJ takes over set, E-board and GB members wrap up stations, Steven checks entire perimeter to see if anything is needed 
12am-2am – E-board monitors party, checks in with advisors and security 
1:45am – Lights come on, E-board helps evacuate crowd 
2am – Clean up SUB
2:10am – Debrief meeting between E-Board, security, advisors 
2:20am – Everyone goes home
