DocsList.Data:
Black Women in Medicine  

 (BWM) 

The University of Massachusetts Amherst 
Chapter  

Constitution 

  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
 
 
 
 
 Article I-Organization Name 

The name of this organization shall be Black Women in Medicine. 
Article II-Purpose/Mission Statement 

Black Women in Medicine is an organization that strives to help provide underrepresented 
minority women with the skills, knowledge and experiences for professional participation in 
health care fields. We aim to uplift those in the minority community who aspire to obtain an 
occupation in medicine. Through volunteer, unity, mentorship and research, we intend to 
empower our future physicians and health professionals. By implementing sound strategies for 
our future physicians and health professionals, we seek to ensure they are trailblazers in the 
medical field 

Article III-Membership 

Section 1-Membership Statement
  Membership is open to all students enrolled at the attending 
university who are interested in pursuing a career in any major, especially STEM major..  A ⅔ 
majority of members must be members of SGA, no less than ten members must be active 
members of the RSO. Only Umass-Amherst  students shall constitute the general voting body. 
Non-voting membership is open to individuals apart of the 5-college community, faculty and 
alumni.  

This organization agrees to adhere to the Federal, state and  University non-discrimination 
statements: No university student may be denied membership on the basis of race, creed, color, 
sex, religion, national origin, age, gender, disability, veterans’ or marital status, sexual 
orientation, gender identity, gender expression, family/parental status, income derived from a 
public assistance program, political beliefs or reprisal or retalition for prior civil rights activity 
or any other protected group status outlined by the University of Massachusetts . This 
organization agrees to allow free speech and expression under no circumstances shall a 
member’s freedom of speech or expression be infringed upon, including freedom to debate. Also 
guaranteed by the US. constitution 1st amendment.  

  Membership is open every fall and spring semester for 3 weeks within 

Section 2-Recruitment
the first month of each semester (executive committee will determine 3 week span) . Active 
membership shall be granted, to any student who recognizes the existence of BWM, who 
believes in the ideas, aims, and purposes upon which it was founded,  and upon payment of 
prescribed dues. No university student may be denied membership due to inability to pay dues. If 
a member is not able to pay dues, other arrangements will be made. 

Section 3-Membership
notable and outstanding contributions to enhance the purpose and objectives of BWM, at least 

  Committee membership shall be granted to members having made 

 
​
 
 
​
 
​
 attend one meeting,  upon recognition of the officers or faculty/staff advisor with a simple 
majority vote. Anyone who wishes to become a committee member of BWM is required to 
express interest to any executive member or request membership thru an online request google 
form open to current members throughout entire semester except last 4 weeks of semester   have 
a minimum G.P.A. of 2.0 and serve on a committee of choice.  Executive member will then get 
individual in contact with the chair of that committee and individuals will be added the group 
chat for chosen committee. 

Section 4. HAZING 
used as a condition of membership in this organization or for any other purpose.  

 BWM is a non-hazing organization. No hazing or discrimination will be 

Voting Recognition 

Qualifications for upholding a voting position include no 

Section 5. 
disciplinary probation at any time, no soliciting money or favors on behalf of BWM without 
prior approval from the executive committee. Also including violations of the attendance or 
participation by laws. In such violation the member will be temporarily blocked from voting and 
their position will be re-evaluated by the executive body and recommendations made to be 
adopted, any disputes with the executive committee decisions shall be brought to the Secretary of 
Judiciary  . 

Section 6. General voting rules, all active members may vote,  in a tie the executive committee 
shall make the decision.  The majority of eligible voting members must be present when the 
matter is being voted on,  unless the executive committee is present in full capacity. Each 
member is granted one vote. 

Article IV-Selection of Officers 

The official executive committee of this organization at full capacity will have 10 members but 
must include a President, Vice President, Secretary and Treasurer. No officer will be permitted to 
hold more than one officer position.  All officers shall retain voting rights, however, the Advisor 
shall only vote in the case of a tie.  Any officer may be re-elected however not for more than two 
consecutive semesters, April 1st to March 31st constitutes the academic year. All officers of 
BWM shall be enrolled full time at the attending university and have a cumulative 2.5 grade 
point average. All officers must be full-time students and SGA members. Part Time students and 
non SGA members cannot hold officer positions. Elections must occur before April 1st.  

  President-Elect 

Section 1.
A.    The President shall be nominated by the previous president and confirmed by remaining 
executive board members, and shall serve as president throughout the following academic 
year  

 
  
​
 
​
​
 
 
  
​
 B.     Candidates shall submit the proper credentials to the Elections Committee, and present 

them to the present officers and faculty advisor. 

C.     If the President cannot carry out the duties of the office , for some reason, there will be a 

special election to be held by the remaining officers and faculty advisor. 

  Vice-President 

Section 2.
A.   The Vice-President shall be nominated by the previous Vice President and confirmed by the 
remaining executive, and shall serve as Vice-President throughout the following academic year 
B.    Candidates shall submit the proper credentials to the Elections Committee, and present them 
to the present officers and faculty advisor. 
C.    If the Vice-President cannot carry out the duties of office, for some reason, there will be a 
special election  held by the remaining officers and faculty advisor. 
D.   The Vice-President will carry out presidential duties in the President’s absence as the need 
arises. 

  Secretary 

Section 3.
A.   The Secretary shall be appointed from the Executive board majority vote and shall serve as 
secretary throughout the following academic year. 
B. Candidates shall submit the proper credentials to the Executive Committee, and present them 
to the present officers and faculty advisor. 
C. If the Secretary cannot carry out the duties of office , for some reason, there will be a special 
election  held by the remaining officers and faculty advisor. 

  Treasurer 

Section 4.
A.   The Treasurer shall be appointed from the previous Treasurer and shall serve as Treasurer 

throughout the following academic year. 

B.    Candidates shall submit the proper credentials to the Executive  Committee, and present it to 

the present officers and faculty advisor. 

C.    If the Treasurer cannot carry out their duties, for some reason, there will be a special 

election to be held by the remaining officers and faculty advisor. 

 Director of Public Relations 

Section 5.
A.    This Director of Public Relations shall be elected by Executive board through a majority 

vote and shall serve as Director throughout the following academic year. 

B.     Candidates shall submit the proper credentials to the Executive  Committee, and present to 

the present officers and faculty advisor. 

C.     If the Director cannot carry out their duties, for some reason, there will be a special election 

to be held by the remaining officers and faculty advisor. 

 
​
 
​
 
​
 
​
 
 . Director of Outreach 

Section 6
A.    The Director of Outreach shall be elected by Executive board through a majority vote, and 

shall serve as Director throughout the following academic year. 

B.     Candidates shall submit the proper credentials to the Executive Committee, and present  to 

the present officers and faculty advisor. 

C.     If the Director of Outreach cannot carry out their duties, for some reason, there will be a 

special election  held by the remaining officers and faculty advisor. 

. Director of Community Engagement 

Section 7
A.    The Director of Community Engagement shall elected by Executive board through a 
majority vote, and shall serve as Director throughout the following academic year. 

B.     Candidates shall submit the proper credentials to the Elections Committee, and present to 

the present officers and faculty advisor. 

C.     If the Director of Community Engagement cannot carry out their duties, for some reason, 

there will be a special election held by the remaining officers and faculty advisor. 

. Director of Membership 

Section 8
A.    The Director of Membership shall be elected by Executive board through a majority vote, 

and shall serve as Historian throughout the following academic year. 

B.     Candidates shall submit the proper credentials to the Elections Committee, and present to 

the present officers and faculty advisor. 

C.     If the Director of Membership cannot carry out their duties, for some reason, there will be a 

special election held by the remaining officers and faculty advisor. 

 Director of Fundraising 

Section 9.
A.    The Director of Fundraising shall be elected by Executive board through a majority vote 

and shall serve as Historian throughout the following academic year. 

B.     Candidates shall submit the proper credentials to the Elections Committee, and present it to 

the present officers and faculty advisor. 

C.     If the Director of Fundraising cannot carry out their duties, for some reason, there will be a 

special election to be held by the remaining officers and faculty advisor. 

Section 10. 

Faculty Advisor 

Apportioned by the President. 

Article V- Duties of Officers 

​
 
​
 
​
 
​
 
​
  
  
 All Umass Students may become an executive committee member if chosen through 
constitutional means (election or appointment), but must be a member for at least 2 
months.   

  President shall 

Section 1.
A.   Be the Chief Executive Officer of the RSO and shall be responsible for all aspects of the 
functioning of the group and, and have authority to act with the consent of the Executive 
Committee in the name of BWM and all matters of record which fall within the scope of the 
Board, as expressed or implied in the Constitution of BWM or in its Bylaws. 

B.   Appoint, subject to confirmation by the Board members, such committees as required for 

emergencies, and for purposes not otherwise provided by these Bylaws. 

C.    Take primary responsibility for the implementation of programs approved by the Board 

Members. Chairs the programming and activities committee. 

D.  Attend meetings of the Executive Committee without specific voting privileges. 
E.   Has signature responsibility 
F.   Effectively delegates duties and responsibilities  
G.  Acts as liaison between members and the university 
H.  Keeps Campus Pulse files up to date and the SORC 
I.   Keeps all records of BWM in a google file shared with all executive members  

  Vice President shall 

Section 2.
A.    Officiate for the President in the President's absence or at the request; shall assume the 
duties and powers of the President for the unexpired term in the case of the president’s 
removal by resignation, illness, death, or other cause. Shall work with the President for the 
advancement of BWM. 

B.   Serve as a member of the Executive Committee and Chairs the Social Committee 
C.   Maintain Correspondence with Physicians and Guest Speakers 
D.  Keeps Campus Pulse files up to date and the SORC 
E. Coordinates and publicizes social activities, including inquiring about necessary permits for 

events 

F. Submit annual report to Secretary of Registry on organizations progress of strategic plan  
G. Monitor online google request form submissions for committee membership   

  The Secretary shall  

Section 3.
A.   Maintain Correspondence with students, and other campus organizations, including forms 

for Travel and permits  

B.   Contact members to inform them of meetings or activities being held via email, telephone or 

by reasonable means . 

 
​
 
 
​
 
​
 C.   Type agendas; sign up sheets, flyers, etc. and distribute them at every meeting  
D.  Type full documented report of every executive board and programming board meeting 
E.   Report any prospective co-sponsorships at Executive Board meetings and conduct monthly 

newsletters 

F. Maintains Social media page  

  Treasurer 

Section 4.
A. Maintain Correspondence with physicians, students, and other campus organizations 

regarding finances  

 B. Be the Chief Financial Officer of the RSO on the finance committee , Keep accounts and 
record the organization's expenditures; Deposit the organization’s funds and complete 
necessary university forms for purchasing and spending. 

C. Monitors the budget and chairs the finance committee. 
D. Finding out more financial opportunities (for example UMASS gives)   
E.  Has  signature responsibility and ensures all reimbursements are approved by university and 

the university policies. 

 F. Provide monthly spending reports to the President and Vice President. And provide all 

financial documents to SGA 

G. Provide the SORC and other  University officials with information requiring the budget. 

 Public Relations 

Section 5.
A.   Record all of the BWM events ( with verbal or written consent on all individuals  attending 

to be recorded )  

B.    Take pictures and prepare an annual scrapbook/slide-show for the end of the year banquet. 
C.  Will be responsible for utilizing a webcam as well as a scanner to replenish the BWM 

website with photos from various BWM organizational events. 

D. Serve on the Social committee  

  Faculty Advisor 

Section 6.
A. Oversee the design and implementation of activities held throughout the academic year by 

BWM. 

B. Assist with the coordination of committee activities. 
C. Assisting in university policy interpretation for the group. 
D. Keep record of E-board member strikes 

 Director of Outreach 

Section 7.
A.   Responsible for gathering medical professionals for the monthly medical seminars. 
B.  Responsible for conducting Pro Bono tutoring session before finals 
C.  Responsible for Mentoring Programs 

 
​
 
​
 
​
 
​
 D. Serve on the Social committee  

. Director of Fundraising/Marketing  

Section 8
A.  Responsible for locating sponsors, hosting fundraising events, and concession opportunities 
B. Serve on finance committee   

. Director of Community Engagement /Communications  

Section 9
A. Responsible for locating community service projects within Hampshire County and for the 
annual service trip. The Director of Community Engagement must ensure at least one medical 
related community service project in a month. 
B. Serve on a social or programming and activities committee  

. Director of Membership/ Recruitment  

Section 10
A. Bring unity amongst members by being involved in General Meetings.  
B. Locating new member possibilities and posting when membership applications open. 
C.  Be consistent with conducting themes and games for tabling events, including the activities 
Expo 
D. Serve on the Social committee  

Section 11: Committees 
This organization shall have the following committees  
Each committee chair must make a group chat, via a means that all members of the committee 
can use, such as groupme, whatsapp or Imessage.  

- Committee members shall attend meetings called by their chair, with at least one week 

notice in the group chat. 

-

A.Programs and Activities: Executive Chaired by President  

During committee meetings and group chat dialogue this committee shall: Coordinates and 
evaluates ways to bring awareness to minority healthcare disparities and access to affordable 
healthy nutrition. Planning organization's activities and programs that align with the mission 
statement and follows the UMASS Student Conduct Code.  Ensure that events are approved by 
the University before the Social committee can start advertising.  

B. Social: Executive Chair by Vice President  

During committee meetings and group chat dialogue this committee shall: Coordinating and 
advertising all events. Developing and maintaining relationships between members   Coordinate 
team building activities. Planning events to attract new members and ensure the longevity of the 
club.  

C. Finance: executive Chaired by Treasurer  

 
​
 
​
 
​
 
 
 
 During committee meetings and group chat dialogue this committee shall: Responsible for 
fundraising activities and maintaining the budget  

E. Special committees can be Created/appointed by the President. 

Section 1- Dues 
A.   Each active, Associate, and Organizational/Institutional member of BWM shall be assessed 

Article VI-Finances 

Annual Dues.  

I.         Membership dues, of an amount to be determined by the executive board 
and advisor.  
II.        Membership dues will be collected during the Fall and Spring semester.   

B.     No university student may be denied membership due to inability to pay dues. If a member 

is not able to pay dues, other arrangements will be made. 

Section 2-Budgets and Disbursements 
A.  Means of raising funds shall be determined on the recommendation of the Executive board 
along with the Faculty Advisor.  Disbursements shall be made as provided in the Bylaws, on the 
basis of Budgets recommended by the Board of Officers. 
B.  The Board of Officers along with the Faculty Advisor shall  authorize all disbursements. 
C. The Treasurer will keep an accurate and up-to-date ledger and record of all transactions and 
receipts  
D The treasurer will submit the budget at general meetings. Voting members and executives will 
have 3 weeks to review the budget before a formal vote is conducted. The budget must be 
finished in time to meet the UMass financial board deadlines. 
E. To be reimbursed for a purchase on the organization's behalf the person who made the 
purchase must present the receipt to the treasurer. The treasurer  will reimburse the exact amount 
to the purchaser, while retaining the receipt for the record.  
F. Any voting member has the right to demand to inspect  the accounts at any general meeting. 

Section 3: Spending Organization’s Money 
For the protection of the organization and its officers it is required that two authorized signatures 
sign all monetary transactions. Only the President, Treasurer, and Umass Faculty/Staff Advisor 
can be signers on the organization’s account.  Organizational funds may be spent on items such 
as office supplies, events/activities, publicity, reasonable travel expenses, conference fees, etc., 
but will not be used for anything illegal under University, local, state, and federal laws. 

 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 Section 4: Officer Transition 

It shall be the responsibility of all account signers to exchange contact information as well as 
assist in the update of new account signatures with the organization's financial institution.  In 
addition, the Treasurer will be responsible to pass along all information regarding the budget to 
the their successor and executive committee.  

Section 5: Dissolution of Organization 
In the event that the organization ceases to exist, any funds remaining in the organization’s 
account shall be remitted back to the Umass Student Government Association. No funds shall 
inure to the benefit of individual members 

Article VII Voting. 

  President, Vice-president, and Board Members 

Section 1.
A.  Only Active members of Black Women of Medicine are eligible to seek an executive 
position. An Online form will be made available and after nominations have been have occurred 
at a regular schedule meeting. 

B. Appointment of Executive board: . Members seeking a position on the E-Board will be able to 
nominate themselves as candidates, by completing a nomination form and having active 
membership for 2 months.  Public nominations must be held prior to the elections for E-board 
positions. Nominees shall have the opportunity to speak on their own behalf prior to the vote 
during a specified time at a regular meeting. Once all the nominations have been made, the 
E-Board member who must appoint a successor will select a nominee and the other E board 
members will review the nominee and determine the eligibility of the candidate based on the 
membership status and participation, Then they will vote on the nominee, the nominee shall 
serve in position by majority vote of executive board, and the faculty advisor will break any ties. 
If a nominee fails to be approved, the current Eboard member leaving the office shall submit 
another name for executive board review from existing nominees. Nominations for executive 
officer positions shall occur each year beginning in February. Executive Elections for executive 
positions shall take place at the last meeting in March. Executive officers shall be elected by a 
simple majority affirmative vote of the executive  quorum. 

C.    Voting must be by roll call, voice vote, or secret ballot. Elections must be Secret ballot. 

1. Fifty percent (50%) plus one (1) vote will determine an election provided that two-thirds 
(2/3) of the official members are present.  If no candidate receives fifty percent (50%) 
plus one (1) vote a runoff, for that position between the two top candidates will be 
required. 

1. Newly elected officers of BWM shall be inducted at the end of the year banquet. 

 
​
 
  
 1. New Officers shall preside over the last BWM meeting of the year. 
1. All officers serve a term of one year. 

D. Elections must occur before April 1st, their term will officially began the last day of 
predecessor last semester in office.  

Article VIII—Officer Vacancies/Special elections  

Section 1:  Impeachment /Removal of Officers 
 Any officer may be removed from office upon a 2/3 majority vote of eligible general and 
executive  members.  The officers will be notified in writing of the possible termination or 
removal at least 72 hours prior to the vote and will be allowed to address the organization in 
order to relate to members any relevant defense prior to the voting for removal. We will be using 
the strike system for this organization, three strikes equate to the probation of your title and a 
meeting with the advisor and then vote by general members . Strikes include behaviors of the 
following 
· 
 Being absent from or late to any event or e-board meeting without discussing it with the 
President or Vice President 

· Not completing appointed duties 

· Any disrespect to any e-board member 

· Strikes vary by situation and severity, if any strike is appointed to an individual that isn’t 
subject to this list, a formal explanation and intervention will be in place. Strikes will be 
officially verified  by the faculty advisor.  

1.    If the officer in question is the President, the meeting in which the impeachment is 
considered shall be chaired by the Secretary. 

2.    If any issues arise during this process, or if either party wishes to appeal the results, the 
question may be taken by any member or officer to the Student Judiciary. 

Section 2: Resignation 

Officers no longer wishing to serve on the board must submit their resignation to the President at 
least two weeks in advance.  Prior to the officer's final day the officer  shall provide all 
documents relating to the organization and brief replacement officer  current projects and 
conditions of the office. 

  
  
  
 
 
 
 
 Section 3: Filling Vacant Officer Positions 

In the event an officer is removed or resigns, the nomination process will take place at the next 
scheduled meeting.  The election process will take place at the next scheduled meeting following 
nomination.  The newly elected officers term shall end at the annual election scheduled at the 
end of the spring semester. 

Article IX- Meetings 

General meetings will be held bi-monthly ( twice a month ) unless otherwise ordered by the 
assembly. 
Executive meetings during the first week of each month and also may call emergency 
meetings upon request, with at least 48 hours  notice.  
The quorum required to conduct any business is 50% +1  of the officers and 50 % + 1 t of the 
organization’s active members.  
 The President will be in charge of calling meetings and the Secretary and Communications 
Chair will be responsible to notify all members.  Members must be notified of meetings at least 
48 hours in advance and shall be notified via email and/or telephone.  The President shall preside 
over all bi-monthly  and executive meetings and conduct them in an organizational fashion. 
Decisions at general meetings will be voted on by general members with voting privileges. 
Executive meetings decisions will be voted on by the executive board.  Motions will go forward 
with a ⅔ majority of active voting members. 

Section 2: Executive board meetings must always discuss the budget, pending memberships on 
Campus Pulse and community involvement affairs. Towards the end of the term/end of year, the 
meetings must discuss the successors of their executive board position. 

Section 3: General body meetings must have each chair discuss their plans to further our mission.   
Input from all voting members is encouraged. 

Section 4: Resolving disputes  
Disputes on RSO policy shall be subject to majority votes of general membership  
Disputes between members  not involving RSO policy shall be mediated by faculty advisor and 
president of BWM. 
Disputes involving the President or above disputes not satisfied shall result in meditation by the 
secretary of registry or  SGA student judiciary , who shall have final call.  
. 

Article X-Advisor 

 
 
 
 
 
 Section 1: Nomination and Role 

The advisor shall be appointed by the President of the organization.  The advisor shall serve as a 
mentor to the organization providing guidance to the officers and members.  The advisor has no 
voting rights, unless breaking a tie in the executive board  The advisor position has no term limit 
other than must be a current Umass  faculty or staff member. 

Section 2: Removal and Replacement of Advisor  

The advisor will be notified in writing of the possible removal at least 72 hours prior to the vote 
and will be allowed to address the organization in order to relate to members any relevant 
defense prior to the voting for removal.  Upon a 2/3 majority vote of general eligible members 
the advisor  will be removed from their duties.  In the event that an advisor is removed or 
resigns, a new advisor shall be appointed by President within 14 calendar days and take office 
immediately upon acceptance  

Article XI- 

Amending the constitution and Bylaws. 

Section 1. 
 Any voting member of this organization can propose and discuss amendments to this 
constitution/by laws at a general body meeting. The proposed provision requires previous notice. 
A quorum  (50% +1 )is required for proposed amendments to be voted on. The amendment(s) 
should always require a ⅔ majority  vote of members present and voting. Amendments must be 
submitted to the Secretary of the Registry for approval.  Approved changes must be updated on 
campus pulse and where ever SGA requires, general members should be informed of changes.  

Article XII -Conduct and Activities  

 The Black Women of Medicine will abide by University obligations and regulations 

Section 1.
including those towards posting and chalking on campus
University of Massachusetts Amherst will be honored: “Solicitation and Posting Policy  
This policy is incorporated into the UMass Amherst Code of Student Conduct. Violations 
of this policy will be subject to action as provided for under the Code. The policies and its 
guidelines can be found here: 

https://www.umass.edu/dean_students/codeofconduct

.  The following statement from 

” .  

  
​
 
 
​
  
 
 
 
​
​
​
​
 BWM will uphold  all university policies and procedures and honor UMASS Student code 
of Conduct and all of the university's policies and procedures  regarding RSO active status
. 
 and 
As stated in  

University Policy and Procedure

Code of Student Conduct  

Section 2. Approval of campus posting will be performed by the Public Relations Chair 

Any member or executive board member seeking to post anything in reference to BWM will 
present it to the Public Relations Chair and from then on it will be determined if it abides by the 
University Posting Policy. 

Article XIII Establishment of Constitution 

Section 1: The ratification of this Constitution is dependent on the approval of  the entire 
executive committee.  The constitution must be approved by the Secretary of the Registry 
before ratification. After approval this constitution can be viewed by all members upon 
request. 

Section 2: Acknowledgment: Black Women in Medicine was founded on Florida State 
Universitiy Campus by Amber Balkcom, Ashlei Phillips with Kisha Cadet as founding 
secretary and Francesca St Hilaire as founding treasurer on October 14, 2017. 

​
​
​
​

How to Use This Form

Recreation Club Allocation Committee - Budget Request Form

Review your entire budget breakdown and select those expenses that you would like paid for by the Univeristy of Massachusetts Amherst through an allocation of SGA funds from the Recreation Club Council Allocations Commmittee. Prioritize the items from most important (1) to least important (up to 10). All items, including individual trips 
or items of equipment, should be listed separately.

How the Recreation Club Allocation Committee Will Use This Form

The Recreation Club Council Allocation Committee will review this form and other resources for allocation.  Each club will have the opportunity to explain its priority list, provide additional information regarding budget expenses and estimated income, and clarify any items during its scheduled budget hearing before the Recreation Club 
Council Allocation Committee during the allocation process.

Allocation and Spending by Category

Clubs will be allocated money by category, with allocated funds required to be spent in that category. You may adjust expenditures within category (if you request to fund a trip to Miami and you change that to Atlanta, that is acceptable).  But, to move money between categories (such as from Travel to Equipment) will require a special 
request  to the Recreation Club Council for approval.

DocsList.Name: The BOLTWOOD Project Constitution.docx
DocsList.Data:
ŸThe BOLTWOOD ProjectTMŸ
University of Massachusetts - Amherst

<<CONSTITUTION>> ©

I. Name and Office
The name of the organization shall be “The BOLTWOOD ProjectTM”.

The principal office of the organization (mailbox) shall be the Student Activities Office in the Student Union of the University of Massachusetts Amherst. The mailing address of the organization shall be: Box 45, Student Activities Office, Student Union, University of Massachusetts, Amherst, M.A. 01003. 

For further information or questions regarding the academic service-learning program, the primary contact is: Ellen Correa at 140 Hicks Way, Goodell Building, Room 611, University of Massachusetts Amherst, M.A. 01003-9272.

II. Purposes
The first aim of The BOLTWOOD ProjectTM is to augment efforts of: the Massachusetts Department of Developmental Services contracted Group Homes (i.e. Intermediate Care Facilities); the Farren Care Center of Montague/Turners Falls; the community service programs for the developmentally challenged sponsored by the Town of Amherst Leisure Services and Supplemental Education department at the Bangs Community Center; several school systems in Amherst and the surrounding areas; and The Berkshire Hills Music Academy (serving Williams Syndrome adolescents) of South Hadley - in providing care and habilitation to stimulate individuals who are developmentally delayed, cognitively impaired, mentally ill, emotionally troubled or physically challenged, as well as children of displaced families. The program is geared to serve as many residents/attendees of the participating community or facility in their efforts to participate in life in the greater community and to contribute to their efforts to build a satisfactory and useful life in a participating facility for those not able to leave the confines of said facility. 

The second aim of The BOLTWOOD ProjectTM is to act as allies with the Participant population to acquaint as many people (i.e. our student population) as possible, with those aspects of developmental disabilities, cognitively impaired, psychiatric/emotionally ill and homelessness - that are too frequently overlooked in our society. These aspects include the positive possibilities of community connections and normalization, as well as the negative effects of institutionalization with a particular emphasis placed on the need for comprehensive social education and integration wherever possible.

The third aim of The BOLTWOOD ProjectTM is to expand its role into the community for community-based, community-serving programs and as a means of expressing the needs of a large segment of the community’s own population. Additionally, The BOLTWOOD ProjectTM hopes to promote a system of reciprocity between the community and the participating groups and facilities.

The fourth aim of The BOLTWOOD ProjectTM is to provide students with opportunities to exercise their capabilities and expertise in the areas of their own chosen professions. While this goal also serves as an easy recruitment process for careers in the field of Human Services, it is hoped that the diversity of the individual BOLTWOOD programs will provide adequate experience for persons contemplating any of a range of professional vocations.

The fifth aim of The BOLTWOOD ProjectTM is to serve as a guide or model for other community-minded student education/service projects, especially those in the areas of community health and social welfare.

The sixth aim of The BOLTWOOD ProjectTM is to raise additional funds, to supplement SGA funding, for the development and implementations of programs that are in furtherance of the above stated goals. People that may be included within these programs can be any student, facility or persons that may want to participate. This does not disqualify those who are not Participants, Volunteers, Supervisors or Coordinators (see section “V. Officers”) but includes those who want to be part of an all-inclusive environment. Activities may include but not limited to hay rides, trips to the mall, bowling, Yankee Candle, etc..  

III. Membership
The BOLTWOOD ProjectTM is a service-learning organization. “Membership” in the organization shall consist of any students interested in carrying out the stated purposes of the organization, shall be members of the greater Five College Community or simply students from UMass Amherst who are accepted into The BOLTWOOD ProjectTM. 
There are two different sections of The BOLTWOOD ProjectTM.
First section consists of a course. The student must participate in the “Recruitment Night,” and in order to participate must be selected by one of the supervisors based on their leadership experience and time commitment. These students are enrolled in SRVCLRNG 390B and earn two credits per semester for the learning they do through their site work, weekly reflections, and participation in three Saturday seminars.
Second section is less of a time commitment and consists of any student who is interested in spreading awareness of disabilities. The activities of this section include hosting and attending different disability workshops and events. Students in this section may elect, as a group or individually, to participate in volunteer opportunities in the surrounding communities separately from students in SRVCLRNG 390B.


IV. Affiliation
The BOLTWOOD ProjectTM draws its greatest support, financial and personal, from the students and student organizations of the Five College Community, but more commonly from the University of Massachusetts. The BOLTWOOD ProjectTM agrees to abide by the rules and regulations of those institutions in regard to recruitment, fundraising and administration in exchange for their continued support of The BOLTWOOD ProjectTM.

The BOLTWOOD ProjectTM is a Registered Student Organization (RSO) of the University of Massachusetts and agrees to comply with all regulations governing RSO groups.

With regards to The BOLTWOOD Project’s program with the Massachusetts Department of Developmental Services, Boltwood must conform with the Department of Mental Health of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts’ rules and regulations regarding personal rights. BOLTWOOD programs must conform to service programs prescribed by law for its client population because the contracted group homes are the designated lawful service delivery agent for that client population. The BOLTWOOD ProjectTM may utilize students from any or all of the Five Colleges to participate and administer the BOLTWOOD volunteer programs. On May 7, 1978, the Government Affairs Committee gave The BOLTWOOD ProjectTM an exception to Chapter 9, Paragraph 3 SGA By-Laws. The student interns designated as BOLTWOOD Supervisors, and their activities, will be coordinated by the three BOLTWOOD Student Coordinators and the Faculty Director. The BOLTWOOD “Supervisors,” under the guidance of the Coordinators and Faculty Director, will develop, administer and staff the educational, social and recreational programs utilizing the services of BOLTWOOD “Volunteers.” Note: In September of 1990, the funding for paid part-time interns at the Belchertown State School was dropped. No longer are ANY members of The BOLTWOOD ProjectTM paid for their participation or services.

The BOLTWOOD ProjectTM is associated with an academic service-learning program under the Office of Civic Engagement & Service-Learning (CESL) at the University of Massachusetts Amherst. Through CESL, The BOLTWOOD ProjectTM provides an enriched recreation and social environment for adults and children with varying intellectual and physical abilities. The program offers a 2-credit seminar for students who are part of the team that organizes weekly engaging activities. In addition, a 4-credit leadership course is offered for students who have completed exceptional service work in the seminar and are selected as team supervisors. Through seminar and classroom activities, and through the weekly sessions at a variety of service provider sites, students develop a deepened understanding of the challenges, opportunities and complex lives of people with disabilities. 


V. Officers
The governing body of The BOLTWOOD ProjectTM is the Executive Board (i.e. the three Student Co-Coordinators, the Faculty Director and Club Advisor). The “Supervisors” are part of the “Administrative Team” and are selected on a semester-to-semester basis by the Executive Board from applications received from current or former “Volunteer.” Each “Supervisor” is responsible for a group of “Volunteers” with the selection of “Volunteers” previously described in Section III - Membership. Generally, the turnover of “Supervisors” is based upon attrition through graduation. In summary, the Supervisors are interviewed by the Coordinators and selected from those who previously were successful “Volunteers” (i.e. members) and who have applied for any open Supervisor positions. Supervisors are replaced as they graduate, leave for study abroad, transfer out of UMass or are deemed unsuccessful as a Supervisor by the Executive Board the previous or current semester. 

The top three officers of the organization making up the Executive Board shall include three “Student Coordinators” (Vice President/Treasurer/Secretary). When the time comes for new Executive Board officers, the current Executive Board Members will recommend students for the new (potential) Executive Board officers. The new Executive Board officers will come from those having served or who are currently serving as “Supervisors” within the program. Each potential Executive Board officer will fill out and turn in a Student Coordinator Application for review. 

The Faculty Director, in conjunction with the out-going Student Coordinator(s), shall choose the New Student Coordinators from among the current “Supervisor” applicants. In summary, the new Coordinator(s) are interviewed and recommended by the Executive Board for those positions as the current Coordinator(s) are about to graduate, transfer, take a semester studying abroad or do not meet the responsibilities as deemed by the Executive Board. 

The Administrative Team and Executive Board shall approve the list of “Volunteers” from their recruitment efforts at the beginning of each semester.

For any and all students, in the class and/or in the club, shall have the opportunity to consult with the Club Advisor. The Club Advisor is there as a resource for Club Members, Volunteers, Supervisors and Coordinators to go on a need-be basis. 

VI. Free Speech and Non-Discrimination 
All members of The BOLTWOOD ProjectTM are entitled to freedom of speech and will not under ordinary circumstances be deprived of the opportunity to share their opinion with the group. 
The BOLTWOOD ProjectTM does not tolerate and prohibits any and all hate speech by any Volunteer, Supervisor, Coordinator, Faculty Members and/or any guest speakers. Hate speech can include any expression that targets a certain race, religion, ability group, or other identifying characteristic in a negative and oppressive form. 
The BOLTWOOD ProjectTM encourages people to use Person-First language and updated, empowering language while discussing any topic and at each site. 

The BOLTWOOD ProjectTM is non-discriminatory meaning that it will not discriminate on the basis of race, color, religion, creed, sex, age, marital status, national origin, mental or physical disability, veteran status, or sexual orientation, gender identity and expression, genetic information and any other class of individuals protected from discrimination under state or federal law in any aspect of the access to, admission, or treatment of students in its programs and activities.
The BOLTWOOD ProjectTM will provide accommodations for those individuals that need it. The BOLTWOOD ProjectTM will need a couple weeks in advance to properly provide all accommodations needed for everyone.

UMass Boxing Club Constitution 
Updated: Spring 2017

Mission Statement

The UMass Boxing Club is devoted to helping its members develop self-defense skills, physical health, self-confidence and teamwork through the sport of boxing. We welcome students, staff, faculty, and UMass boxing alumni of all skill levels and backgrounds. We encourage every individual to be the best they can be, physically and mentally, through a professionally structured, safe training program. We strive to be an exceptional sport which embodies the spirit of UMass athletics. There is intercollegiate competition available for those interested in competing as well.


Core Values

Integrity
Comradery
Teamwork
Responsibility
Discipline
Perseverance























ARTICLE I:
Officers and Responsibilities

Officers


Officers must be fee-paying undergraduates who have been elected prior to the start of the semester through official nomination and election procedures. Each position is yearly (Fall - Spring semesters). In the event that there are not enough nominees to fill every position, each officer may also hold another officer position in the club so long as responsibilities for both positions are being met. In the event of a nominee studying abroad for a semester or as deemed appropriate during elections, two officers may be nominated and elected to share a position. All officers are required to read the UMass Boxing Club Handbook in its entirety. The eleven active officer titles and duties are as follows:

President
Responsible for meeting agendas, establishing meeting dates and places, running meetings, and overseeing the general flow of meetings.
Responsible for overseeing and leading on-campus practices including the teaching of technique and running drills and conditioning.
Responsible for aiding the coach in registration and renewal of club membership with NCBA boxing and USA Boxing. 
Works and communicates with school administration as the face of UMass Boxing
Coordinates activity of other officers and delegates tasks and responsibilities
In case of voting conflicts (ties, etc.) or a meeting impasse, the President has final say in making decisions and resolving conflicts.
President is required to attend all meetings.
President is required to complete signature responsibility training.
Due to USA Boxing regulations, the President must be a registered member of USA Boxing.

Vice President
Works in tandem with the president and shares responsibilities as delegated
Responsible for all presidential duties in the event which the president cannot fulfill said duties.
Vice-President is required to attend all meetings.






Team Captain
Liaison between the club and competition team.
Responsible for communications with USA boxing
The Team Captain will be working closely with the coach in order to communicate with members about upcoming bouts and other opportunities pertaining to competition. This includes recruiting new competing members, rallying support for competing members, and coordinating sparring times with the coach and the facilities where sparring will take place.
Must work to ensure that the coach attends all sparring practices. This includes organizing transportation for the coach if need be. Any transportation costs must be reported to the treasurer in a timely fashion.
Will work with executive staff to maintain a balance between the club and the competing team. This is to ensure that members participating in both aspects may have their needs met within the best of his or her ability.
Coordinating with the Treasurer in an effort to acquire funds needed for competition events without undermining the financial needs of the club as a whole.
Working with trainers to prepare competing members for each bout physically and mentally.
Team Captain is required to attend all meetings.

Treasurer (up to 2)
Responsible for handling all of the club financials such as: collecting membership dues and fees, collecting income from fundraising events, equipment purchases, coaching fees, and travel expenses. 
Keeping records of members with paid membership and resulting funds and makes these files available to all officers.
Club’s financial advisor is primarily responsible for the club’s official financial records on the SUMMIT finance system. The financial advisor can grant the treasurer access to SUMMIT. 
Organizing and recording a budget report for the club’s financials. Treasurer must periodically check the club’s records against the SUMMIT system for accuracy. A copy of the budget will be available to all officers (read only). 
Treasurer is required to attend all meetings.
Responsible for organizing travel schedule with club’s financial advisor.
Treasurer is required to complete Signature Responsibility training.
Only one treasurer can attain Signature Responsibility. This treasurer will be 	primarily responsible for the above responsibilities, with the other (ideally more 	experienced) treasurer to assist, serve as an advisor, and is responsible for 	ensuring communication and coordination with the coach and team captain 






Secretary
Keeps file of paid memberships and share this document with other officers 
Ensures all members become members of the official UMASS Boxing Club Facebook for		communications
Records meeting minutes and topics of discussion during club meetings along with 	any resolutions.
Facilitates the distribution of and collect member liability waivers and the anti-hazing 	form, and delivers them to the faculty advisor 
Coordinates with executive staff and other officers to keep official records of member 	activity including:
Meetings attended.
Training progress.
Event participation.
Secretary is required to attend all meetings.

Equipment Manager
Given key-card access to the Recreation Center equipment storage
Up to three other officers may also be given access
Keeps combinations for and maintains locks and equipment storage bin
Keeping inventory of club equipment on a bi-semesterly basis that is shared with executive officers at the beginning and end of each semester.
Will work closely with Treasurer for reporting and recording equipment costs.
May suggest new equipment that could be incorporated into practice and purchased within the confines of the club budget

Communications Officer
Works closely with Secretary to serve as a liaison between executive staff and general body of the club to relay important information about practices and events such as meeting times, club events, and alterations/cancellations of practice.
Will create and maintain list of members with updated contact information.
Club promoter
Advertising upcoming bouts that members will be competing in through social media and flyers.
Announcing the results of recent bouts and promoting a positive image of the UMass Boxing Club through social media and flyers.

Event Coordinator (up to 2)
Organizing and coordinating club events such as fundraising opportunities (security events, etc.), charity, and club socials (within the club and with other clubs).
Works closely with the Treasurer for reporting and recording income and expenses relating to fundraising events.
Documenting attendance, funds raised, and other information pertaining to club events.
Liaison to other clubs and organizations.

Head Trainer
Ensures all Trainers and other officers are informed on and teaching boxing technique with the same expectations and instructions in accordance with the Coach and the President
Coordinates with other Trainers to compile workouts and drills in a document
Keeps Trainers and officers focused on helping members and correcting technique during practice

Trainers (up to 5)
Responsible for developing drills, circuits, conditioning, and workouts for use in practice
Assist in the general flow of practice and teaching technique 
Interact on a more individual level with members to:
Encourage every member to master their skills and to adhere to the highest standards of UMass Boxing.
Motivate members to challenge themselves while also being mindful of their limits.
Attain feedback and opinions from members on club operations including practices, events, and club comradery

Safety officers
A minimum of two officers present at all club practices holding first aid/ CPR/ and AED safety certifications. 
May simultaneously hold another executive or non-executive officer position for the club
Responsible for administering temporary aid towards injured members during both club practices and sparring.
In close contact and with the current facilities safety coordinator in case of an emergency. Responsible for incident documentation in case of an injury.
Works with the secretary to keep record of injuries and monitor members with existing injuries that were medically cleared to participate.
Members, competitors, or those looking to spar are encouraged to get a physical before engaging in club activity.

Elections


Election Day
The Election Day will take place prior to the spring mid-semester date to establish officers for the following semester.
This date is set to allow officer-elects to be trained by the officers they are 	replacing before undergoing the position transfer 
It is the responsibility of the President to set the date and time for elections but he/she may delegate the acquisition of a meeting space and communicating meeting details to the Secretary, Communications Officer or Event Coordinator. 
Nominee Eligibility
Nominees must be due paying members and full-time undergraduate students.
Any member may recommend another eligible member (including themselves) for any officer position; that nomination must then be seconded by any other member, except the nominee, to become an official nomination.

Voting
During the voting process, ballots will be handed out on Election Day with a list of positions and a list of nominees made available; these ballots will be anonymously filled out by each voting member and collected by the active President to be tallied.
Majority vote rules and ties are decided by the President
























ARTICLE II:
Membership

Membership Eligibility


Membership will be open to all undergraduate, graduate and UMass Boxing alumni. For a person to become a UMass Boxing Club member they must:
Pay the established membership fee, which will be decided among officers from the previous semester.
Sign a UMass Boxing Club waiver before beginning any training, releasing UMass from liability.
Have access to the UMass Recreation Center

Dues


Membership dues are expected to be paid by all members of the club, including officers. For the first three weeks of the semester there will be an “open door” policy allowing prospective members to try the club without needing to pay. At the end of this trial period, all new members are required to pay the fee in order to participate in practice. No new members will be allowed to join the club after the end of the trial period. This trial period should end during the third week of practices.

Voting Rights


Members will be eligible to vote only if the following has occurred:
The membership due must be paid in full.
The UMass Boxing Club waiver must be signed.
The member must have trained a total of nine times (three weeks) prior to elections for that semester.




ARTICLE III:
Process for Member/Officer Removal

Resolving Disputes


A dispute is defined as a mutual impasse between two or more UMass Boxing Club members, either physical or verbal. The process for handling member disputes is as such:
A dispute should be reported to the President and the Vice President.
A meeting can be called, if necessary, to vote on the issue.
Ultimately, if a decision cannot be reached and a vote cannot be taken, the President will have final say in the matter using his/her best unbiased judgment by considering the interests of all parties involved, being true to the club values, and keeping integrity of the UMass Boxing Club and UMass Athletics in mind.

Membership Termination


All issues regarding the removal of members and officers shall be brought to the attention of the President who will then decide to issue a warning to the member in question or to leave the issue to a vote among club members.
The following issues shall result in a private verbal warning for the first offense, a public verbal warning for the second offense, and a vote for removal on the third offense:
Those who wish to compete in club tournaments and competitions fail to attend a significant amount of meetings and activities.
Those who wish to compete in club tournaments and competitions fail to attend the proper amount of workouts and sparring sessions.
Failure of an officer to perform a significant amount of his/her duties. This includes missing more practices than allowed by the guidelines for attendance; outlined in Article V, Section II.
Insubordination of a member or officer.
The following issues shall result in a public verbal warning for the first offense and a vote for removal on the second offense:
Jeopardizing the safety of oneself and of others during training and sparring sessions (not wearing the proper protective gear, unnecessary or illegal maneuvers during sparring, physical fights with malicious intent, etc.).
Abusing gym equipment (failing to use proper weight lifting techniques, failing to use or store equipment properly, etc.).


NOTE: Voting for removal will require a two-thirds vote for the member or officer in question to be removed from the UMass Boxing Club entirely. If an officer is relieved of his/her duties, nominations and elections will be held together at the following meeting. Some circumstances may permit an immediate vote for removal if the offense is of an illegal, serious, and/or malicious nature and may result in further disciplinary actions by the university. 






































ARTICLE IV:
Meeting Guidelines

Conducting Meetings and Planning Activities


Meetings and activities will be held as follows:
Meetings are called, organized, and conducted by the President; all officers must be present. Meetings may also be requested to the President by any officer.
The Team Captain shall plan, organize, and conduct bouts/tournaments (intramural and intercollegiate) in coordination with the Coach. Such agendas shall be reported to the board of officers.
Any member may suggest a club activity, submit it for approval by the board of officers, and present it to club members at a practice or via Facebook; the Event Coordinator is responsible for organizing, scheduling, and conducting that activity. This responsibility may be delegated to the person who proposes said activity by the Event Coordinator if need be.
Any member can present a topic to vote on at a group meeting; the topic must be presented to the active President and will be put on the agenda for the next scheduled meeting or discussed during the active meeting if time permits.
Any decision requires a majority vote.
A majority of eligible voters must be present at such a meeting for a vote to be taken on said topic.
When a majority of voters cannot attend a meeting, or the meeting topic requires immediate attention, voting can be conducted by the president through emails; he/she will email each voting member the topic and voting members shall email the president their decision.










ARTICLE V:
Club Records

Membership Information


The Secretary is responsible for recording membership records and for making them available to all members as well as adding a copy to the secretary’s record book. Books will be kept for each year and each semester. Membership information to be recorded include:
Names
Interest in Competition
Updates regarding sparring dates, sparring sessions, and upcoming bouts will be sent to these people by the communications officer.
Proof of membership
Once a member has paid his/her dues for the semester, they will receive a sticker initialed by the treasurer indicating receipt of payment that is to be put on the members UCard which must be presented to officers before permitted to join practice after the end of the “open door” policy. In the event that a member has lost their UCard or the sticker on it, they can be looked up on the active member roster list maintained by the club secretary.

Attendance


The Secretary is also responsible for recording club attendance. Guidelines for attendance are as follows:

Officers

President
Must attend at least 80% of practices (can miss 8 practices).

Vice President
Must attend at least 80% of practices (can miss 8 practices), should be present if president is absent.

Team Captain
Must attend at least 80% of practices (can miss 8 practices).

Treasurer
Must attend at least 80% of practices (can miss 8 practices), must be present at each practice for the first 4 weeks to collect dues.

Secretary
Must attend at least 80% of practices (can miss 8 practices), must be present at each practice for the first 4 weeks to record member registration, liability forms, hazing agreement.

Equipment Manager
Must attend every practice unless an arrangement is made with another officer to transport the equipment to practice.

Communications Officer
Must attend at least 60% of practices (can miss 15 practices)

Trainer
Must attend at least 60% of all practices (can miss 15 practices)

Event Coordinator
Must attend at least 60% of all practices (can miss 15 practices).

NOTE: Any officer holding more than one position must comply with the highest attendance corresponding to the positions being held. Also at least 4 officers, including one safety officer, must be at any given practice. All officers should be at every practice for the first two weeks.

Members
Due paying members are not required to attend every practice but are encouraged to attend at least 1-2 practices per week in order to maintain proficiency in boxing techniques and overall physical fitness. 

Sunday Practices
Sunday practices will be reserved for “returning members”, meaning members who have been a member of UMass Boxing for a previous semester. Acceptations may be made by the coach or the president for individuals who may be competing or have previous boxing experience. These practices may be opened to all members as deemed fit by the president and other officers throughout the semester when Saturday practices are compromised, or when new members have progressed to an appropriate level.

These practices are reserved in order to allow for the continued progression of UMass boxers who have gone beyond the basics learned in one semester. Higher level conditioning and technique drills may be incorporated into these practices 



Financial Records


Financial accounts, membership fees, and other club finances will be the responsibility of the active Treasurer. This information will be logged in the treasurer’s record book for use by officers in future meetings.
Books will be kept for each year and for each semester. Treasurer is also responsible for making copies of account balances available to each member.

Meeting Records


The Secretary is responsible for recording meeting minutes, topics of discussion, and conclusions for each club meeting. 
The Secretary must also keep a record of all members and officers in attendance for each meeting.


























ARTICLE VI:
Training and Sparring 

Training



Training shall take place three times per week, and a schedule for training times and dates will be coordinated by the President with the university staff
Before any member may begin his/her full training, they must sign a UMass Boxing Club waiver releasing the University of Massachusetts Amherst and its constituents from any liability regarding injury or death. See Article VII: Safety and Liability for more information on the liability waiver.
Non Competing members are not required to attend every practice and may train at their own discretion; however they are encouraged to attend at least 1-2 practices per week in order to maintain proficiency in boxing techniques and overall physical fitness.
Typical training routines incorporate a large number of partnered and team building exercises.
There are three levels of training that are thoroughly outlined in the Trainer’s Guide; members should start their training at the level that suits their abilities. If they are unsure of their skill level, then either the club president, team captain, or the trainers will advise them where to start.
Members should include a weightlifting program into their schedules at least twice a week.

Special Accommodations

General members

Members with physical or mental differences that require additional attention at practices will be provided with one on one time with a trainer. The trainer will review the individual’s physical capacity by observing range of motion, joint strength, flexibility, balance and completion of three repetitions of the following basic light calisthenics: pushup, sit-up, squat, jumping jack. The trainer will then inquire about any challenges the individual believes they will face during practice. The trainer will then assess their ability to perform the different exercises involved with practice and identify areas that will prove challenging. The trainer will then work with the individual to make adjustments or offer assistance in the challenge areas they identified. This will ensure the individual will be able to integrate into the workout and be fully included throughout the practice. 
If the member’s difference could result in physical complications or restricts movement it is recommended that the individual informs the safety officer before practice. 

Sparring/Competing members

If the member exhibits a physical or mental disability then the member will be required to obtain documentation from their doctor stating that the individual will not be putting themselves or others at risk by participating in sparring or competition. Copies of the statement will be provided to the club’s Coach and the club’s Safety Officer. 
The doctor’s statement will also be included with the registration for USA Boxing in accordance with their rules and regulations.

Sparring


Before any member spars at any time at the Westover Air Reserve Base or at any other facilities, they MUST be a member of the UMass Boxing Club, have a signed the liability waiver and anti-hazing waiver, and be approved fit to spar by the Coach

Other Requirements and Conditions
Those who wish to compete in bouts during competitions are required to train at least three times a week, two days of which must be spent sparring in order to ensure that Coach can assess each competing member’s skill and adequacy for competition.
Those who are entered in bouts MUST include sparring sessions into their workout schedule.
Members are always required to provide their own mouth guards, wraps, clothing and shoes. Protective head gear, 16 oz gloves, and cups are all provided by the club. All equipment used for sparring must be USA Boxing approved. 
The coach must inspect the following before each sparring session:
Check the athlete for impairments
Check for proper attire:
Headgear must have the official USA Boxing Label or stamp in order to qualify as competition approved.
Mouthpiece and headgear must be secured by either trainer or coach as specified in the USA Boxing rules handbook.
Check safety equipment for rips, wear, and to ensure proper fit.
Check area for foreign objects.
Ensure that athletes are properly warmed up.
For more information on competition approved gear, please refer to Appendix A: Venegas, Brent R. “Boxer’s Attire and Equipment.” 2008 Basic Rules and Hints for Beginning Officials, (2007): 1-5. Web.
Sparring is only required if a member wishes to compete in bouts/tournaments; however any member who has passed the belt test and wishes to spar may do so.
Sparring pairs should be no more than 25 lbs apart.
All protective equipment MUST be worn (mouth guard, hand wraps, gloves, groin protector, and headgear).
No metal, straps, buckles, necklaces, jewelry, of any kind or any other object which may cause injury to either boxer shall be worn.
Coach must always be present and actively monitoring these sparring sessions.
Sparring partners will talk before sparring and agree on which level they wish to spar (light, medium, or heavy).
If one sparring partner wants to spar at a lighter level or needs to end the sparring match early, this should be done with no questions asked.
Members must spar at a light level for at least three sparring sessions before moving up to the next sparring level.

Sparring is conducted in a safe and controlled learning environment where participants can hone their skills comfortably at an appropriate pace. For this reason, having three trained safety personnel will suffice for sparring sessions. EMTs are required to be present during competitive bouts only.

Frequency
Sparing will be available once a week or as frequently as the coach can accommodate.
Each member may spar a maximum of 2 times per week with at least 24 hours rest/ recovery in between for health and safety reasons.
Only one pair may spar at any given time.

Bouts and Tournaments
Tournaments are to be organized by the coach and/or by the team captain.
Any member wishing to enter a bout must be a member of the USA Boxing Association, must have completed the Belt Test, and must have four weeks experience with advanced training skills.
EMTs must be made available on site at all tournaments and is the responsibility or the coach and team captain to provide these EMTs.
Bouts can be held monthly or bi-monthly; however, participants may not enter a bout if they competed less than 2 weeks prior to the current bout or tournament.

Training Facilities



Westover Air Reserve Military Base
The Westover Air Reserve Base is a proud partner of the UMass Boxing Club. The Westover military base allows qualified club members to train in their recreation facility with Rocky Snow; however members must be escorted onto the air force base by coach Rocky Snow and remain under his supervision until being escorted off the premises. A valid form of identification is required for entry e.g. driver’s license, FID, passport, etc.
Transportation to the Westover Air Reserve Base is coordinated through two different platforms: a social media page specifically dedicated for sparring interest and activity, and a group texting system. 
Group texts are not sent to everyone. Members must speak to the Communications Officer or Team Captain and express interest in sparring in order to be added.
Members in possession of a vehicle are highly encouraged to offer transportation and communicate availability through either medium or by contacting the Communications officer.
All trips to the Westover Air Reserve Base must be coordinated with the coach Rocky Snow.
Access to the Westover Air Reserve Base is prohibited without an escort from Coach Rocky Snow.

Emergency Procedures
Contact the fitness center hotline (413-577-3958) to speak to the health and safety coordinator.
Follow emergency protocol and assist with any paperwork if necessary. 
In the case of minor injuries, apply first aid. Call 911 immediately if the injury is severe.

Recreation Center
General Medical Emergency Protocol
If a participant is fully conscious and experiencing symptoms of low or high blood sugar, you may offer 1) glucose tablets or 2) peanut butter crackers and apple juice. It is advised to ask if they have diabetes, when was the last time they had eaten and/or if they have any food allergies. Do not hesitate to call 911 if you suspect the incident is serious or if you are unsure.
If someone is diabetic, they will likely be okay with taking glucose tablets and are aware of the positive impact of the glucose tablets. Please ask the participant in question if he/she is diabetic.
If the participant is uncomfortable taking a glucose tablet, please inform him/her that Campus Recreation has peanut butter crackers and apple juice available and ask if they would like this. Please ask if they have any allergies limiting them to taking the peanut butter crackers or apple juice.
If the condition of the participant does not improve upon providing peanut butter crackers/apple juice/glucose tablets, please call 911 for advanced care.
Any medical issue is a potential emergency for the individual. Do not hesitate to call 911 if you suspect that the incident is serious or that you are unsure.
Symptoms of low blood sugar include: confusion, dizziness, feeling shaky, hunger, headaches, irritability, weakness and anxiety. People with or without diabetes can experience low sugar symptoms.
Essentially, symptoms for individuals with low blood sugar levels and individuals with high blood sugar levels are very similar. It has been communicated that we treat both as low blood sugar levels. Low blood sugar levels come on quick and we can fix it quick. This is the same approach used by EMTs and first responders as the application of sugar to someone with high blood sugar symptoms will not have adverse effects.

Decontamination of blood spills (Recreation Center Protocol) 
For a large spill contact Environmental Health and Safety for assistance.
Treat all human blood and human body fluids as if known to be infectious for HIV, HBV, or other blood borne pathogens. Always wear protective gloves when treating any blood spills or injuries involving blood, bodily fluids, non-intact skin & mucous membranes (i.e. nose, eyes, and mouth).
Locate the nearest blood spill kit. Blood spill kits at the recreation center can be found at the following locations: Laundry 108A, Storage 118A, Storage 121A, Storage 210B, Storage 214C, Storage 215A and Storage 310B 
All contaminated items must be placed in the red biohazard waste bag(s). The Biohazard waste bag is available within the blood spill kit.
Upon completion of the spill cleanup, the red biohazard waste bag must be disposed of properly in the 33 gallon red biohazard container located in Laundry 108. After placing the items in the biohazard container, please make sure the cover to the container is secure.
Please inform Roger Heimerman (413-577-3868) if the 33 gallon biohazard container is nearing full capacity. A service request will be placed with the EH&S to have the contents picked up and disposed of by environmental health agency.
Wash your hands immediately with soap and running water after treating any injury, including situations where gloves are worn. If running water is not available, use antiseptic wipes until you are able to wash your hands with soap and water. 
If gloves are not immediately available during an emergency, it is highly recommended to create a large barrier between the blood and your hands. A bulky cloth or towel may be used until proper medical materials arrive. DO NOT USE BARE HANDS!
Anyone with a soiled shirt or workout gear must discontinue participation. Do not force someone to remove something they don’t want to, but the participant must be informed they cannot continue to participate in soiled clothing. If they choose to remove their soiled clothing, ask them if they want to keep it. If not, dispose of it with the rest if the clean-up materials. If they want to keep it, put the clothing in a biohazard bag for them to take with them.
All open wounds must be covered.
Blood spill kits contain the following: cloth towels, paper towels, red biohazard waste bags, multi-use disinfectant spray, protective gloves, goggles, forceps, small dustpan and broom, and surgical mask.
In case of major injury,, immediately notify building supervisor,  Safety officers are to follow safety procedures explained below:
Emergency services are to be called 9-1-1, CPR/AED if unresponsive and/or a possible cardiac emergency.
If a participant receives a significant blow to the head
Gently allow participant to lie or sit on the floor
Watch for signs of concussion such as:
Slurred speech
Lack of muscle coordination 
Confusion
Headache 
If symptoms are evident direct to UHS and or the nearest hospital
Complete accident/injury report, if possible assist rec center with their accident report, verify that the CSD advisor is aware of the accident/ injury and await necessary follow up instructions or actions.
All accidents and injuries involving bodily fluids must be cleaned as soon and as safely as possible:
Spray contaminated surfaces with disinfectant 
Apply pressure
Wipe surfaces with towels
Properly dispose of contaminated towels

Boyden Gym
Contact Dan Markowski of Boyden Gym (413-545-0075) for health and safety information.
Follow emergency protocol and assist with any paperwork if necessary. 
In the case of minor injuries, apply first aid. Call 911 immediately if the injury is severe.

Have a cleared criminal background check, renewed every two years.
Re-register as a boxing official every year.
Hold necessary coach certification from USA Boxing
A minimum of ten years of experience with the sport, either as a competitor or as a boxing official.
Meets the UMass athletic department/recreation sports coaching guidelines:
The coach is only responsible for coaching and refrains from involvement in the clubs management.
Clear and evident commitment to ensuring good sportsmanship at all times.
Safety certifications:
CPR/First Aid/AED

Responsibilities
It is mandatory for the coach to attend all sparring practices, bouts, and tournaments.
Safety requirements:
Must be in communication with the director of the facility for which the activity occurs in case of an injury.
Report all incidents to USA Boxing such as knockouts and/or concussions occurring during training or sparring.
Act as a referee ensuring that:
Rules and fair play are strictly upheld.
