Equipment Manager
Must attend every practice unless an arrangement is made with another officer to transport the equipment to practice.

Communications Officer
Must attend at least 60% of practices (can miss 15 practices)

Trainer
Must attend at least 60% of all practices (can miss 15 practices)

Event Coordinator
Must attend at least 60% of all practices (can miss 15 practices).

NOTE: Any officer holding more than one position must comply with the highest attendance corresponding to the positions being held. Also at least 4 officers, including one safety officer, must be at any given practice. All officers should be at every practice for the first two weeks.

Members
Due paying members are not required to attend every practice but are encouraged to attend at least 1-2 practices per week in order to maintain proficiency in boxing techniques and overall physical fitness. 

Sunday Practices
Sunday practices will be reserved for “returning members”, meaning members who have been a member of UMass Boxing for a previous semester. Acceptations may be made by the coach or the president for individuals who may be competing or have previous boxing experience. These practices may be opened to all members as deemed fit by the president and other officers throughout the semester when Saturday practices are compromised, or when new members have progressed to an appropriate level.

These practices are reserved in order to allow for the continued progression of UMass boxers who have gone beyond the basics learned in one semester. Higher level conditioning and technique drills may be incorporated into these practices 



Financial Records

Meeting Records


The Secretary is responsible for recording meeting minutes, topics of discussion, and conclusions for each club meeting.

ARTICLE VI:
Training and Sparring 

Training



Training shall take place three times per week, and a schedule for training times and dates will be coordinated by the President with the university staff
Before any member may begin his/her full training, they must sign a UMass Boxing Club waiver releasing the University of Massachusetts Amherst and its constituents from any liability regarding injury or death. See Article VII: Safety and Liability for more information on the liability waiver.
Non Competing members are not required to attend every practice and may train at their own discretion; however they are encouraged to attend at least 1-2 practices per week in order to maintain proficiency in boxing techniques and overall physical fitness.
Typical training routines incorporate a large number of partnered and team building exercises.
There are three levels of training that are thoroughly outlined in the Trainer’s Guide; members should start their training at the level that suits their abilities. If they are unsure of their skill level, then either the club president, team captain, or the trainers will advise them where to start.
Members should include a weightlifting program into their schedules at least twice a week.

Special Accommodations

General members

Members with physical or mental differences that require additional attention at practices will be provided with one on one time with a trainer. The trainer will review the individual’s physical capacity by observing range of motion, joint strength, flexibility, balance and completion of three repetitions of the following basic light calisthenics: pushup, sit-up, squat, jumping jack. The trainer will then inquire about any challenges the individual believes they will face during practice. The trainer will then assess their ability to perform the different exercises involved with practice and identify areas that will prove challenging. The trainer will then work with the individual to make adjustments or offer assistance in the challenge areas they identified. This will ensure the individual will be able to integrate into the workout and be fully included throughout the practice. 
If the member’s difference could result in physical complications or restricts movement it is recommended that the individual informs the safety officer before practice. 

Sparring/Competing members

If the member exhibits a physical or mental disability then the member will be required to obtain documentation from their doctor stating that the individual will not be putting themselves or others at risk by participating in sparring or competition. Copies of the statement will be provided to the club’s Coach and the club’s Safety Officer. 
The doctor’s statement will also be included with the registration for USA Boxing in accordance with their rules and regulations.

Sparring


Before any member spars at any time at the Westover Air Reserve Base or at any other facilities, they MUST be a member of the UMass Boxing Club, have a signed the liability waiver and anti-hazing waiver, and be approved fit to spar by the Coach

Other Requirements and Conditions
Those who wish to compete in bouts during competitions are required to train at least three times a week, two days of which must be spent sparring in order to ensure that Coach can assess each competing member’s skill and adequacy for competition.
Those who are entered in bouts MUST include sparring sessions into their workout schedule.
Members are always required to provide their own mouth guards, wraps, clothing and shoes. Protective head gear, 16 oz gloves, and cups are all provided by the club. All equipment used for sparring must be USA Boxing approved. 
The coach must inspect the following before each sparring session:
Check the athlete for impairments
Check for proper attire:
Headgear must have the official USA Boxing Label or stamp in order to qualify as competition approved.
Mouthpiece and headgear must be secured by either trainer or coach as specified in the USA Boxing rules handbook.
Check safety equipment for rips, wear, and to ensure proper fit.
Check area for foreign objects.
Ensure that athletes are properly warmed up.
For more information on competition approved gear, please refer to Appendix A: Venegas, Brent R. “Boxer’s Attire and Equipment.” 2008 Basic Rules and Hints for Beginning Officials, (2007): 1-5. Web.
Sparring is only required if a member wishes to compete in bouts/tournaments; however any member who has passed the belt test and wishes to spar may do so.
Sparring pairs should be no more than 25 lbs apart.
All protective equipment MUST be worn (mouth guard, hand wraps, gloves, groin protector, and headgear).
No metal, straps, buckles, necklaces, jewelry, of any kind or any other object which may cause injury to either boxer shall be worn.
Coach must always be present and actively monitoring these sparring sessions.
Sparring partners will talk before sparring and agree on which level they wish to spar (light, medium, or heavy).
If one sparring partner wants to spar at a lighter level or needs to end the sparring match early, this should be done with no questions asked.
Members must spar at a light level for at least three sparring sessions before moving up to the next sparring level.

Sparring is conducted in a safe and controlled learning environment where participants can hone their skills comfortably at an appropriate pace. For this reason, having three trained safety personnel will suffice for sparring sessions. EMTs are required to be present during competitive bouts only.

Frequency
Sparing will be available once a week or as frequently as the coach can accommodate.
Each member may spar a maximum of 2 times per week with at least 24 hours rest/ recovery in between for health and safety reasons.
Only one pair may spar at any given time.

Bouts and Tournaments
Tournaments are to be organized by the coach and/or by the team captain.
Any member wishing to enter a bout must be a member of the USA Boxing Association, must have completed the Belt Test, and must have four weeks experience with advanced training skills.
EMTs must be made available on site at all tournaments and is the responsibility or the coach and team captain to provide these EMTs.
Bouts can be held monthly or bi-monthly; however, participants may not enter a bout if they competed less than 2 weeks prior to the current bout or tournament.

Training Facilities



Westover Air Reserve Military Base
The Westover Air Reserve Base is a proud partner of the UMass Boxing Club. The Westover military base allows qualified club members to train in their recreation facility with Rocky Snow; however members must be escorted onto the air force base by coach Rocky Snow and remain under his supervision until being escorted off the premises. A valid form of identification is required for entry e.g. driver’s license, FID, passport, etc.
Transportation to the Westover Air Reserve Base is coordinated through two different platforms: a social media page specifically dedicated for sparring interest and activity, and a group texting system. 
Group texts are not sent to everyone. Members must speak to the Communications Officer or Team Captain and express interest in sparring in order to be added.
Members in possession of a vehicle are highly encouraged to offer transportation and communicate availability through either medium or by contacting the Communications officer.
All trips to the Westover Air Reserve Base must be coordinated with the coach Rocky Snow.
Access to the Westover Air Reserve Base is prohibited without an escort from Coach Rocky Snow.

Emergency Procedures
Contact the fitness center hotline (413-577-3958) to speak to the health and safety coordinator.
Follow emergency protocol and assist with any paperwork if necessary. 
In the case of minor injuries, apply first aid. Call 911 immediately if the injury is severe.

Recreation Center
General Medical Emergency Protocol
If a participant is fully conscious and experiencing symptoms of low or high blood sugar, you may offer 1) glucose tablets or 2) peanut butter crackers and apple juice. It is advised to ask if they have diabetes, when was the last time they had eaten and/or if they have any food allergies. Do not hesitate to call 911 if you suspect the incident is serious or if you are unsure.
If someone is diabetic, they will likely be okay with taking glucose tablets and are aware of the positive impact of the glucose tablets. Please ask the participant in question if he/she is diabetic.
If the participant is uncomfortable taking a glucose tablet, please inform him/her that Campus Recreation has peanut butter crackers and apple juice available and ask if they would like this. Please ask if they have any allergies limiting them to taking the peanut butter crackers or apple juice.
If the condition of the participant does not improve upon providing peanut butter crackers/apple juice/glucose tablets, please call 911 for advanced care.
Any medical issue is a potential emergency for the individual. Do not hesitate to call 911 if you suspect that the incident is serious or that you are unsure.
Symptoms of low blood sugar include: confusion, dizziness, feeling shaky, hunger, headaches, irritability, weakness and anxiety. People with or without diabetes can experience low sugar symptoms.
Essentially, symptoms for individuals with low blood sugar levels and individuals with high blood sugar levels are very similar. It has been communicated that we treat both as low blood sugar levels. Low blood sugar levels come on quick and we can fix it quick. This is the same approach used by EMTs and first responders as the application of sugar to someone with high blood sugar symptoms will not have adverse effects.

Decontamination of blood spills (Recreation Center Protocol) 
For a large spill contact Environmental Health and Safety for assistance.
Treat all human blood and human body fluids as if known to be infectious for HIV, HBV, or other blood borne pathogens. Always wear protective gloves when treating any blood spills or injuries involving blood, bodily fluids, non-intact skin & mucous membranes (i.e. nose, eyes, and mouth).
Locate the nearest blood spill kit. Blood spill kits at the recreation center can be found at the following locations: Laundry 108A, Storage 118A, Storage 121A, Storage 210B, Storage 214C, Storage 215A and Storage 310B 
All contaminated items must be placed in the red biohazard waste bag(s). The Biohazard waste bag is available within the blood spill kit.
Upon completion of the spill cleanup, the red biohazard waste bag must be disposed of properly in the 33 gallon red biohazard container located in Laundry 108. After placing the items in the biohazard container, please make sure the cover to the container is secure.
Please inform Roger Heimerman (413-577-3868) if the 33 gallon biohazard container is nearing full capacity. A service request will be placed with the EH&S to have the contents picked up and disposed of by environmental health agency.
Wash your hands immediately with soap and running water after treating any injury, including situations where gloves are worn. If running water is not available, use antiseptic wipes until you are able to wash your hands with soap and water. 
If gloves are not immediately available during an emergency, it is highly recommended to create a large barrier between the blood and your hands. A bulky cloth or towel may be used until proper medical materials arrive. DO NOT USE BARE HANDS!
Anyone with a soiled shirt or workout gear must discontinue participation. Do not force someone to remove something they don’t want to, but the participant must be informed they cannot continue to participate in soiled clothing. If they choose to remove their soiled clothing, ask them if they want to keep it. If not, dispose of it with the rest if the clean-up materials. If they want to keep it, put the clothing in a biohazard bag for them to take with them.
All open wounds must be covered.
Blood spill kits contain the following: cloth towels, paper towels, red biohazard waste bags, multi-use disinfectant spray, protective gloves, goggles, forceps, small dustpan and broom, and surgical mask.
In case of major injury,, immediately notify building supervisor,  Safety officers are to follow safety procedures explained below:
Emergency services are to be called 9-1-1, CPR/AED if unresponsive and/or a possible cardiac emergency.
If a participant receives a significant blow to the head
Gently allow participant to lie or sit on the floor
Watch for signs of concussion such as:
Slurred speech
Lack of muscle coordination 
Confusion
Headache 
If symptoms are evident direct to UHS and or the nearest hospital
Complete accident/injury report, if possible assist rec center with their accident report, verify that the CSD advisor is aware of the accident/ injury and await necessary follow up instructions or actions.
All accidents and injuries involving bodily fluids must be cleaned as soon and as safely as possible:
Spray contaminated surfaces with disinfectant 
Apply pressure
Wipe surfaces with towels
Properly dispose of contaminated towels

Boyden Gym
Contact Dan Markowski of Boyden Gym (413-545-0075) for health and safety information.
Follow emergency protocol and assist with any paperwork if necessary. 
In the case of minor injuries, apply first aid. Call 911 immediately if the injury is severe.

The Coach



Candidate Criteria
Meets the USA Boxing certification stated below: 
Be a registered non-athlete for USA Boxing.
Have a cleared criminal background check, renewed every two years.
Re-register as a boxing official every year.
Hold necessary coach certification from USA Boxing
A minimum of ten years of experience with the sport, either as a competitor or as a boxing official.
Meets the UMass athletic department/recreation sports coaching guidelines:
The coach is only responsible for coaching and refrains from involvement in the clubs management.
Clear and evident commitment to ensuring good sportsmanship at all times.
Safety certifications:
CPR/First Aid/AED

Responsibilities
It is mandatory for the coach to attend all sparring practices, bouts, and tournaments.
Safety requirements:
Must be in communication with the director of the facility for which the activity occurs in case of an injury.
Report all incidents to USA Boxing such as knockouts and/or concussions occurring during training or sparring.
Act as a referee ensuring that:
Rules and fair play are strictly upheld.
Sparring is conducted in a controlled fashion by offering professional advice and controlling the pace of sparring sessions appropriately.
Both boxers do not receive unnecessary and excessive blows while sparring.
The bout is terminated in the event that the team member is showing signs of injury or confusion, or displays an inability to protect themselves.
Clear communication is expressed by using key commands:
Stop - when ordering boxers to stop boxing.
Box - when ordering them to continue.
Break - when breaking a clinch, upon which each boxer shall step back before continuing to box.

Emergency Responsibilities
In the event of an injury during a club practice at the respective practice facility, the coach must do the following:
First secure the scene while notifying the building supervisor (contact 9-1-1 if a serious or life-threatening injury has occurred, then coordinate with safety officers and the building supervisor).
Follow the procedures outlined in Article VII: Safety and Liability, Safety Guidelines; then immediately complete an accident/ injury incident report

Current Coach
Stephen “Rocky” Snow is a Vietnam veteran who has put in over 17,000 hours of volunteer work for the U.S. Veterans Administration and currently serves at the Westover Air Reserve Base. Snow is a former Golden Gloves champion and professional boxer who built and coached a Junior Olympics program training kids from the ages 8 to 15 ranking as the number one team in New England five years in a row. During his time at UMass, Snow has coached a two time national champion, Josue Lopez, ranking 5th in the nation and continues to bring success to many boxers at the university. Snow has coached other UMass boxers on to win prestigious bouts and invitationals. There have been no documented injuries from any of his fighters throughout his coaching career due to his emphasis on education and safety.

Certifications
CPR, AED, and First Aid certified.
Licensed and certified with USA Boxing




ARTICLE VII:
Safety and Liability 
Liability Documentation


Upon the start of each semester, each member is required to sign a waiver releasing the University of Massachusetts Amherst and its constituents from liability of injury or death. The following is an excerpt from the RSO Liability Waiver:

“In consideration of my participation, I hereby accept all risk to my health and of my injury or death that may result from such participation and I hereby release the University of Massachusetts, Amherst, its governing board, officers, employees and representatives from any and all liability to me, my personal representatives, estate, heirs, next of kin, and assigns for any claims and causes of action for loss of or damage to my property and for any and all illness or injury to my person, including my death, that may result from or occur during my participation, whether caused by negligence of the University of Massachusetts, Amherst, its governing board, officers, employees, or representatives, or otherwise. I further agree to indemnify and hold harmless the University of Massachusetts, Amherst and its governing board, officers, employees, and representatives from liability for the injury or death of any person(s) and damage that may result from my negligent or intentional act or omission while participating.”

For more information, the full liability waiver can be viewed in appendix A.
Apparel


All participating members must wear athletic attire in compliance with Recreation Center Policies & Procedures. (For more information on appropriate apparel, please see Appendix A: Recreation Center Policies & Procedures, page 4.)
Hand wraps are required for all members.
Sizes include 108”, 120” and 180”. If you are unsure which size to use, please ask a trainer or higher ranking officer.
16 oz. boxing gloves are required when engaging in any activity involving hitting including the following:
Punching bag, mitts, and sparring.
Sneakers or boxing/wrestling shoes.
Headgear, mouthpiece and groin protector are MANDATORY when sparing, but optional otherwise.



Safety Guidelines (Official USA Boxing Medical Guidelines) 


USA Boxing is the National governing body of Olympic-style amateur boxing, overseen by both the United States Olympic Committee and the international Boxing Association. In order to compete, each fighter has to register with USA Boxing.

Disqualifying Conditions 
Acute and chronic infections including those conditions, but not limited to fever, chest infection, untreated tuberculosis, intestinal infection with potential dehydration/malabsorption, hepatitis, open infected skin lesions (including H. Simplex, MRSA, impetigo, untreated fungal infections, etc.), mononucleosis within the past month, etc. 
Severe blood dyscrasias and clotting disorders which include therapeutic anticoagulation. 
Sickle cell disease.
History of Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C or HIV infection.
Refractive (Lasik) and intraocular surgery, cataract, retinal detachment.
Myopia of more than -­‐3.50 diopters in one or both eyes.
Recorded visual acuity in one or both eyes of: uncorrected worse than 20/200; corrected worse than 20/60.
Significant congenital or acquired cardiovascular and pulmonary abnormalities including, but not limited to, severe COPD, uncontrolled asthma with potential for hypoxemia, pulmonary hypertension, severe aortic or pulmonary stenosis, myocarditis or pericarditis, recent embolic disease, 3rd degree heart block, atrial or ventricular tachycardia, contraction of the aorta, unclosed significant patent ductus arteriosus, aortic aneurysm and any of these conditions that have undergone corrective surgery or ablation unless specifically released by a cardiothoracic physician to return to contact/combat sports. Resting BP over 160/100 is considered uncontrolled and a disqualification; however, if the resting BP is over 140/90, the boxer may participate if previous recorded blood pressures have been controlled. Any boxer with persistent BP over 135/85 should be recommended for follow-­‐up with their own personal physician.
Significant congenital or acquired musculoskeletal deficiencies including, but not limited to, spinal fractures, spondylolysis, atlantoaxial instability, and the following conditions if they inhibit the boxer’s defense, balance or ability to use the authorized headgear/gloves: loss of thumb or great toe, unstable/subluxing joints
Unresolved post-­‐concussion symptoms, which will need clearance from a qualified licensed physician 
Significant neuropsychiatric disturbances or drug abuse 
Significant congenital or acquired intracranial mass lesions or bleeding, (benign smaller CNS lesions require the clearance by a neurologist or neurosurgeon regarding participation in a contact/combat sport), history of craniotomy, cerebral palsy or hypoxic brain injuries, significant neuropathies which affect balance, sensation, and ability to provide adequate defense 
Any seizure activity within the last 3 years 
Hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, ascites
Pregnancy 
Uncontrolled diabetes mellitus or uncontrolled thyroid disease
Any implantable device which can alter any physiologic process or enhance performance
Women’s breast protector which protects anything other than the breast protuberance itself 

Conditions that are not disqualifying to box:
Deafness (but coach and trainers must be made aware and the coach and or trainer may tap the deaf boxer on the shoulder if necessary to signal “break” or “stop.”) 
Boxers with dental braces or other orthodontic appliances as long as there is permission to compete with braces or orthodontic appliances form attached to the boxer’s passbook. Note that this includes the newer permanent retainers in use. 
Boxers with non‐incarcerated hernias or absence of one testicle or an undescended testicle may participate as long as a protective cup is in use at all times (competition and training). 
Boxers with breast implants may participate as long as there is a Permission to Box with Breast Implants form attached to her passbook. 
Sex reassignment (in accordance with IOC regulations): Any “individuals undergoing sex reassignment of male to female before puberty should be regarded as girls and women” (female). This also applies to individuals undergoing female to male reassignment, who should be regarded as boys and men (male). 

Emergency Protocol
Coach and or trainer administers first aid if a boxer sustains a serious injury or loses consciousness until the boxer can be turned over to the emergency medical treatment.
Secondary safety officer is to Immediately notify recreation center staff
Detailed documentation by a trainer and provide to recreation center director.
For “down boxers”:
Exercise cervical precautions.
Make sure the boxer has an adequate airway.
Remove the mouthpiece.
Assess breathing. 
Watch for vomiting or aspiration. 
Keep the boxer down until fully reactive, then permit him to sit up. 
When stable, the boxer may be escorted to the corner.
For boxers who need to be transported to the hospital:
Signal the Emergency Personnel on site or call for an ambulance as soon as possible. Consider oxygen if appropriate
If boxer is down because of head injury or other injury, do not try to remove him from the ring yourself. Signal/call for the EMT’s and their stretcher/backboard and their rigid cervical collar and let them take over the transfer. 
If at all possible, aim for a 3 minute evaluation and a 2 minute removal from the ring and or area. As this is only a guideline, safety will not be sacrificed for speed. 
The boxer has adequate access to oxygen.
If the boxer is being transferred by a different means, communicate with them by phone or written instructions. Be sure boxer is accompanied by reliable person, such that can be in contact with the boxer and the family of the boxer.

Potential Boxing Injuries: Diagnosis and Treatment

Evaluating Concussions
A boxer temporarily stunned or knocked down and unconscious is a stricken boxer and a medical emergency. This indicates that a concussion has occurred
A concussion is a temporarily altered state of motor hypotonus, helplessness and disturbed consciousness. 
This includes:
Disorientation 
Memory deficit – antegrade and retrograde amnesia 
Altered or slow speech
Difficulty processing new information
Impaired motor function – slow, uncoordinated
Concussion questionnaire. Note speech – altered, slow or repetitive?
What is your name?
Where are you?
What day and year is it?
What is your opponent’s name? What round is it? 
Ask the boxer to repeat three words after 5 minutes.
Observe the eyes
Pupils equal, round, reactive?
Is there spontaneous nystagmus? The presence of spontaneous horizontal nystagmus indicates that the boxer is very vulnerable and should definitely not be permitted to continue. 
Look for facial weakness, hemiparesis or other focal signs. 
The match should be stopped if the boxer:
was clearly stunned
Was unconscious 
Fails to answer the questions correctly
Fails to perform the motor tests 
Shows any abnormal focal signs

Abrasions
Such injuries often occur to the face and skull and elsewhere. 
Bleeding should be halted by pressure, then cleaned and a local antiseptic applied. 

Lacerations
The basic principle of handling cuts around the eye is that, if a cut causes enough bleeding to impair vision, the bout should be stopped. Most cuts will NOT require that the bout be stopped.
Dangerous Cuts:
Cuts over the supraorbital nerve or the supratrochlear nerve, if they are deep enough, may damage the nerve. 
Cuts medially over the lacrimal duct area may extend into the naso-lacrimal duct. 
Cuts over the infraorbital nerve, if deep enough, could damage the nerve. 
Cuts on the eyelid itself could damage the tarsal plate or the globe itself may have been injured. 
Vertical cuts through the vermillion border of the lip should stop the bout because of the potential for further tearing of the lip from subsequent trauma. 
Cuts around or on the bridge of the nose must be carefully checked for evidence of a compound nasal fracture. If no fracture is present, the bout may be allowed to continue.
No dressing of cuts is allowed except for collodion or steri-­‐strips

Addressing Nosebleeds
The initial evaluation should determine the presence of a fracture. Gentle handling of a nosebleed is necessary so as not to further aggravate or compound a fracture. 
If no fracture is felt, the physician must then evaluate the character of the bleeding (i.e. venous vs. brisk arterial gushing). Bouts are stopped for arterial bleeding (rare in this situation). 
(look up how to stop a nosebleed)
Determination of posterior bleeding should also be done by tongue depression and pen light observation. If there are clots in the posterior pharynx or the boxer is spitting clots, the bout should be stopped. 
Massive venous bleeding may be cause to stop a bout. 
Nosebleeds should stop bouts for medical reasons. 

“Black eye”
Cold applications and light compression limit the extravasation of blood. 

Hand fracture
Common fractures are those of the first metacarpal. They are primarily caused by a poor punching technique, where the thumb is not correctly positioned opposite to the index and middle fingers.
Indicated by localized tenderness, bruising or swelling
All suspected hand and wrist fractures should be splinted and sent for X-­‐ray.
Suspected dislocations are handled in the same fashion

Shoulder Dislocations
Best relocated immediately before spasm sets in
A sling with swathe is of benefit, but the boxer needs referral when he returns home. 

Abdominal Injuries
Ruptures of the organs in the abdomen (spleen, liver) are uncommon.
Pancreatitis is a remote possibility.
Kidney Contusions
Contusions may lead to massive hematuria even when no anatomic defect appears. 
Pain in the abdomen and/or shoulder may signify bleeding. 

Responsibilities and Duties 
Boxers with head injuries should be transported to a facility with neurosurgery. 
Sufficient area to examine and treat boxers who would not to be transported to a medical facility 

Required Medical Equipment
Oxygen is mandatory including tubing and delivery devices. 
Stretcher/backboard when EMT on site 
No obstruction that would prevent stretcher, EMT’s or Physician from moving Boxer to ambulance. 
Rigid cervical collar when EMT on site
Penlight
Gauze
Clean, disposable gloves
Airways
Sanitizer
Blood pressure cuff
Stethoscope
Tongue depressors
Adhesive tape
Ophthalmoscope 
Otoscope

Health and Safety Officer
Responsible for administering temporary aid towards injured members during both club practices and sparring.
In close contact and with the current facilities safety coordinator in case of an emergency. Responsible for documentation in case of an injury.
Works with the secretary to keep record of injuries and monitor members with existing injuries that were medically cleared to participate.
May also hold another executive or non-executive position in the club.


ARTICLE VIII:
Non-Discriminatory and Freedom of Speech Clauses

Non-discrimination


The UMass boxing club hereby vows to never deny a person membership based on race, ethnicity, political affiliation, religious beliefs, gender, sexual orientation, marital status, income, disability, age, academic status, veteran status, mental capacity, or criminal record, unless such practices are deemed to be within the bounds of Federal and/or State law. We also vow never to exclude members from meetings, training, competitions, club events, voting rights, use of facilities, a training/sparring partner, or officer position based on the aforementioned demographics. The UMass boxing club vows to support any individual, of any demographic previously stated, in the development of their boxing career. We also vow to make reasonable accommodations to our routines and schedules for those individuals who may need it. The UMass Boxing Club shall question membership to any individual who will not adopt these vows.

Freedom of Speech


Freedom of speech will not be limited or restricted by any officer or body of the UMass Boxing Club. A members’ speech is not relevant to any proceeding conducted by the UMass boxing club. No officer or member shall use the speech of another officer or member as reason to deny or limit participation in any UMass boxing club activity.




ARTICLE IX:
Amending the Constitution

Proposal


A written proposal must be made in order for an amendment to the constitution to occur. The proposal should be sent to the president who will then schedule a meeting so that the member may defend their proposal. The proposal will be put to a vote where a two-thirds majority is required for the vote to pass. If the amendment passes then the president must add the amendment to the constitution. The amended constitution must be peer reviewed and checked for correct language before a final copy is created and made available to the club.
All officers must be present at the meeting



Bibliography

Primary Source Documents


Venegas, Brent R. “Boxer’s Attire and Equipment.” 2008 Basic Rules and Hints for Beginning Officials, (2007): 1-5. Web.
Recreation Center Policies & Procedures
School Policies
RSO Liability Waiver
USA Boxing Insurance Manual
UMass Sports Club Handbook

How to Use This Form

Recreation Club Allocation Committee - Budget Request Form

Review your entire budget breakdown and select those expenses that you would like paid for by the Univeristy of Massachusetts Amherst through an allocation of SGA funds from the Recreation Club Council Allocations Commmittee. Prioritize the items from most important (1) to least important (up to 10). All items, including individual trips 
or items of equipment, should be listed separately.

How the Recreation Club Allocation Committee Will Use This Form

The Recreation Club Council Allocation Committee will review this form and other resources for allocation.  Each club will have the opportunity to explain its priority list, provide additional information regarding budget expenses and estimated income, and clarify any items during its scheduled budget hearing before the Recreation Club 
Council Allocation Committee during the allocation process.

Allocation and Spending by Category

Clubs will be allocated money by category, with allocated funds required to be spent in that category. You may adjust expenditures within category (if you request to fund a trip to Miami and you change that to Atlanta, that is acceptable).  But, to move money between categories (such as from Travel to Equipment) will require a special 
request  to the Recreation Club Council for approval.

DocsList.Name: BUILD Constitution.pdf
DocsList.Data:
BUILD 

University of Massachusetts, Amherst 

Group Constitution 
February 2019 

  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Index: 

I. Mission 

II. Membership 

III. Group Meetings 

IV. Officer Positions 

V. Election Procedure 

VI.

Free speech 

VII. Non-Discrimination 

VIII. Amendments 

Mission: 

A. BUILD UMass aims to provide students with opportunities to use 
technology for social good and gain practical knowledge through 
pro-bono consulting engagements for non-profits, local 
businesses and other registered student organizations at the 
University of Massachusetts, Amherst. 

B. BUILD UMass will be involved in many types of activities including but 

not limited to: 

● Performing community outreach to identify and connect with 

organizations that could greatly benefit from improved 
technological infrastructure but lack the financial or technical 
means to do so. 

● Taking on projects to help non-profits organizations and local 

businesses better accomplish their mission. These projects will 
be technical in nature and may include consulting and software 
development. The length of these projects may extend for 
multiple months.  

  
 
 
 
 
 
 ● Hosting workshops for members and the broader community to 

increase knowledge of various topics in computer science, 
business, and community outreach.  

C. BUILD UMass was founded on the philosophy that UMass students 

possess valuable skills that can greatly benefit the community. By 
establishing professional relationships between the community and 
students, organizations in the community will benefit from the latest 
technologies while providing students extensive real world experience.  

D. The main goals of BUILD UMass for the next five academic years are 

● Year 1: ​Provide a venue for students of all majors to enrich their 
skills and use their knowledge to have a meaningful impact on 
the community.  

● Year 2: ​Allow students to earn credit and community service 

hours for work that will impact the lives of thousands of people. 

● Year 3: ​Boost our networking with influential companies to 

secure industry sponsors. 

● Year 4: ​Strengthen our network by securing partnerships. 
● Year 5: ​Propel BUILD UMass on a larger stage to be a nationally 

recognized organization. 

Membership: 

A.  General Body -  

1. Any student who is a full-time undergraduate student at the 

University of Massachusetts Amherst is eligible to be a 
member. General Body membership is established by 
signing up for the mailing list (newsletter) on our website. 

2. There will be 1-2 General Body Meetings every semester, and 

general body members will have access to all the 
workshops, and talks from faculty and guest speakers. 

B.  Project Teams - 

1. Students interested in being project team members of the 
group, who are able to work on client engagements, must 
apply during the Fall/Spring recruiting periods for the 

  
 
 
 
 positions of Project Manager, Project Developer, and 
Business Developer. 

2. The recruiting process will be a rolling application process 
and students will be able to apply whenever they wish to. 

3. The applicants will need to submit the application which 

will consist of some generic questions, an optional 
resume/GitHub page, and an optional writing supplement. 

4. Shortlisted applicants would then be interviewed on the 

basis of personality and a technical skills test. 

5. The applicants must receive a majority vote by the 
Executive Team to join the group as a project team 
member. 

6. When someone joins a project team, they recieve voting 
rights within the organization and can vote on decisions 
that extend except for votes restricted to just officers.  

Group Meetings: 

1. Executive Team Meetings -  

a. Will be held once a week 

b. All executive board members expected unless prior notice is 

given 

c. Will vote on the following topics 

i. New member additions 

ii.

Accepting new Projects 

  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 iii. Deciding where to spend monetary funds. 

iv.

Amendments to the constitution 

d. All the board members must be present for voting and a motion 

will be passed if it receives majority votes 

2. Full Group Meetings -  

a. Will be held once a week 

b. Topics covered will be as follows- 

i. General information and updates 

ii.

Project Work and Showcases 

iii. Development Workshops 

iv. Guest Speakers 

c. Will vote on the following topics- 

i.

Amendments to the constitution 

d. 2/3rds of the team members must be present for voting. A 

motion passes when it receives majority votes 

3. Individual Team Meetings - 

a. Will meet multiple times a week as and when required 

b. The meetings will be lead by the Project Manager 

c. Topics covered will be as follows- 

i.

ii.

Project requirements 

Task Breakdown and delegation 

iii. Use of tools and technologies 

iv.

Client requirements and timelines 

  
 
 
 
 d. Will vote on the following (if necessary)- 

i.

ii.

Choice of tools and technologies 

Timeline 

iii.

Task breakdown and delegation 

e. All the team members of the particular team must be present 
for voting. A motion passes when it receives majority votes. 

  
 
 
 
 
 
 Executive Team Description: 

1. President- 

a. Plan and execute the long term strategy of BUILD UMass and 

ensure that the club maintains proper direction. 

b. Participate in team member recruiting process 

c. Follow up on project leads and help the Secretary and Project 

Managers during initial negotiations. 

d. Maintain and build relationships with clients 

e. Assist Individual Teams as and when needed. 

f. Will have signature responsibility 

2. Vice President- 

a. Assist the President in planning and executing the long term 

strategy of BUILD UMass. 

b. Focus on maximizing member exposure and access to recruiters, 

alumni and other key people across the tech industry. 

c. Act as the liaison between BUILD and CICS and the SGA. 

d. Organize corporate events and work towards obtaining sponsors 

and building corporate partnerships. 

e. Assist Individual Teams as and when needed. 

3. Secretary- 

a. Organize the projects in the pipeline and assist the President in 

following up project leads. 

b. Review deliverables and every project team’s work and provide 

feedback consistently. 

c. Ensure projects stay on schedule, and finish in a timely fashion. 

  
 
 
 
 d. Choose standard technologies for members of the group to work 
with for consistency (eg- IDE’s, Communications platform, etc). 

e. Assist Individual Teams as and when needed. 

4. Treasurer- 

a. Organize RSO funds and communications with the student 

government on matters related to the accounts management. 

b. Submit an annual budget request to the SGA. 

c. Maintain signature responsibility. 

d. Approve proposed expenditures meant to further the mission of 

the club. 

e. Assist Individual Teams as and when needed. 

  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Annual Election Procedure: 

Annual elections for officer positions within the organization will be held 
according to the following rules.  

● Elections will occur during a regularly scheduled general body 

meeting when at least ⅔ of active members are in attendance.  

● The vote will occur before April 1st.  
● The organizations secretary, at the time of the vote, will maintain 

records of the vote. For each position the secretary will record: the 
name of every member running and the corresponding number 
of votes they receive from the combined general body and 
project teams. All of this data should be recorded in Google 
Sheets and made available in a read only capacity to all members 
of the organization. The secretary should be the only person with 
the power to edit this document.  

● For each position, the member with the most votes will fill that 

position the following academic year, starting in the fall.  

Special elections shall be held if a vacancy arises due to unexpected 
departure or removal of an official. The special election shall be held 
according to the following rules . 

● Elections will occur during a regularly scheduled general body 

meeting when at least ⅔ of active members are in attendance.  
● The organizations secretary, at the time of the vote, will maintain 
records of the vote. For each position open in this special election 
the secretary will record: the name of every member running and 
the corresponding number of votes they receive from the 
combined general body and project teams. All of this data should 
be recorded in Google Sheets and made available in a read only 
capacity to all members of the organization. The secretary should 
be the only person with the power to edit this document.  

● For each open position, the member with the most votes will fill 

that position effective immediately.  

The process for removing an officer or member is as follows: 

  
 
 
 
 ● Any member may file a complaint, in a dedicated complaint 

channel in the organizations slack, about any officers or members 
they see fit. 

● Leadership is obligated to send a response acknowledging that a 

request for removal has been filed.  

● Promptly after acknowledging the filing, leadership must notify 

the member whomst the complaint was filed against. The 
complaint in its entirety will be made available to the member it 
was filed against.  

● Ahead of the next general body meeting, the member whomst 
the complaint was filed against is entitled to having a meeting, 
mediated by members of leadership, with the initial filer of the 
complaint.  

● If the initial complaint filer chooses to proceed with seeking 
removal, the complaint will be made publicly available to all 
members and at the next general body meeting the topic of 
removal will be brought forth to the general body.  

● At this meeting, the member facing removal will be allowed to 

defend themselves in front of the general membership. Following 
this a vote will be held and if at least  ⅔ ‘s of the general 
membership vote for removal the member will be removed.  
● If the member removed is an officer, a special election will be 
held at a future meeting according to the procedure detailed 
above.   

  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Free Speech: 

All members of BUILD UMass are entitled to freedom of speech and will 

not under any circumstances be deprived of the opportunity to share their 
opinion with the group. Under no circumstances shall a member’s freedom of 
speech or expression be infringed.  

Non Discrimination: 

BUILD UMass will never discriminate against any of its members on the 

basis of race, color, national origin, religion, sex, gender identity (including 
gender expression), sexual orientation, disability, age, marital status, 
family/parental status, income derived from a public assistance program, 
political beliefs, or reprisal or retaliation for prior civil rights activity.  

Amendments to this Constitution: 

1. This Constitution can be amended by a majority vote at a General 

Meeting. 

2. A motion to amend may be made and seconded by any member at a 

meeting of the general membership.  

3. Voting on the motion shall take place at the following meeting only if 

more than 3/4th of the club is present.  

4. Prior to voting, the President shall allow for a period of debate. 

5. After being approved, the amendment itself, and an updated version of 
the Constitution shall be submitted to the Secretary of the Registry for 
final approval.

DocsList.Name: Group Constitution Submit.docx
DocsList.Data:
BUILD
University of Massachusetts, Amherst



Group Constitution
February 2019




Index:
Mission
Membership
Group Meetings
Officer Positions
Election Procedure
Free speech
Non-Discrimination
Amendments


Mission:
BUILD UMass aims to provide students with opportunities to use technology for social good and gain practical knowledge through pro-bono consulting engagements for non-profits, local businesses and other registered student organizations at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.
BUILD UMass will be involved in many types of activities including but not limited to:
Performing community outreach to identify and connect with organizations that could greatly benefit from improved technological infrastructure but lack the financial or technical means to do so.
Taking on projects to help non-profits organizations and local businesses better accomplish their mission. These projects will be technical in nature and may include consulting and software development. The length of these projects may extend for multiple months. 
Hosting workshops for members and the broader community to increase knowledge of various topics in computer science, business, and community outreach. 
BUILD UMass was founded on the philosophy that UMass students possess valuable skills that can greatly benefit the community. By establishing professional relationships between the community and students, organizations in the community will benefit from the latest technologies while providing students extensive real world experience. 
The main goals of BUILD UMass for the next five academic years are
Year 1: Provide a venue for students of all majors to enrich their skills and use their knowledge to have a meaningful impact on the community. 
Year 2: Allow students to earn credit and community service hours for work that will impact the lives of thousands of people.
Year 3: Boost our networking with influential companies to secure industry sponsors.
Year 4: Strengthen our network by securing partnerships.
Year 5: Propel BUILD UMass on a larger stage to be a nationally recognized organization.
Membership:
 General Body - 
Any student who is a full-time undergraduate student at the University of Massachusetts Amherst is eligible to be a member. General Body membership is established by signing up for the mailing list (newsletter) on our website.
There will be 1-2 General Body Meetings every semester, and general body members will have access to all the workshops, and talks from faculty and guest speakers.
 Project Teams -
Students interested in being project team members of the group, who are able to work on client engagements, must apply during the Fall/Spring recruiting periods for the positions of Project Manager, Project Developer, and Business Developer.
The recruiting process will be a rolling application process and students will be able to apply whenever they wish to.
The applicants will need to submit the application which will consist of some generic questions, an optional resume/GitHub page, and an optional writing supplement.
Shortlisted applicants would then be interviewed on the basis of personality and a technical skills test.
The applicants must receive a majority vote by the Executive Team to join the group as a project team member.
When someone joins a project team, they recieve voting rights within the organization and can vote on decisions that extend except for votes restricted to just officers. 



Group Meetings:
Executive Team Meetings - 
Will be held once a week
All executive board members expected unless prior notice is given
Will vote on the following topics
New member additions
Accepting new Projects
Deciding where to spend monetary funds.
Amendments to the constitution
All the board members must be present for voting and a motion will be passed if it receives majority votes
Full Group Meetings - 
Will be held once a week
Topics covered will be as follows-
General information and updates
Project Work and Showcases
Development Workshops
Guest Speakers
Will vote on the following topics-
Amendments to the constitution
2/3rds of the team members must be present for voting. A motion passes when it receives majority votes
Individual Team Meetings -
Will meet multiple times a week as and when required
The meetings will be lead by the Project Manager
Topics covered will be as follows-
Project requirements
Task Breakdown and delegation
Use of tools and technologies
Client requirements and timelines
Will vote on the following (if necessary)-
Choice of tools and technologies
Timeline
Task breakdown and delegation
All the team members of the particular team must be present for voting. A motion passes when it receives majority votes.

Executive Team Description:
President-
Plan and execute the long term strategy of BUILD UMass and ensure that the club maintains proper direction.
Participate in team member recruiting process
Follow up on project leads and help the Secretary and Project Managers during initial negotiations.
Maintain and build relationships with clients
Assist Individual Teams as and when needed.
Will have signature responsibility
Vice President-
Assist the President in planning and executing the long term strategy of BUILD UMass.
Focus on maximizing member exposure and access to recruiters, alumni and other key people across the tech industry.
Act as the liaison between BUILD and CICS and the SGA.
Organize corporate events and work towards obtaining sponsors and building corporate partnerships.
Assist Individual Teams as and when needed.
Secretary-
Organize the projects in the pipeline and assist the President in following up project leads.
Review deliverables and every project team’s work and provide feedback consistently.
Ensure projects stay on schedule, and finish in a timely fashion.
Choose standard technologies for members of the group to work with for consistency (eg- IDE’s, Communications platform, etc).
Assist Individual Teams as and when needed.
Treasurer-
Organize RSO funds and communications with the student government on matters related to the accounts management.
Submit an annual budget request to the SGA.
Maintain signature responsibility.
Approve proposed expenditures meant to further the mission of the club.
Assist Individual Teams as and when needed.




Annual Election Procedure:
Annual elections for officer positions within the organization will be held according to the following rules. 
Elections will occur during a regularly scheduled general body meeting when at least ⅔ of active members are in attendance. 
The vote will occur before April 1st. 
The organizations secretary, at the time of the vote, will maintain records of the vote. For each position the secretary will record: the name of every member running and the corresponding number of votes they receive from the combined general body and project teams. All of this data should be recorded in Google Sheets and made available in a read only capacity to all members of the organization. The secretary should be the only person with the power to edit this document. 
For each position, the member with the most votes will fill that position the following academic year, starting in the fall. 
Special elections shall be held if a vacancy arises due to unexpected departure or removal of an official. The special election shall be held  according to the following rules .
Elections will occur during a regularly scheduled general body meeting when at least ⅔ of active members are in attendance. 
The organizations secretary, at the time of the vote, will maintain records of the vote. For each position open in this special election the secretary will record: the name of every member running and the corresponding number of votes they receive from the combined general body and project teams. All of this data should be recorded in Google Sheets and made available in a read only capacity to all members of the organization. The secretary should be the only person with the power to edit this document. 
For each open position, the member with the most votes will fill that position effective immediately. 
The process for removing an officer or member is as follows:
Any member may file a complaint, in a dedicated complaint channel in the organizations slack, about any officers or members they see fit.
Leadership is obligated to send a response acknowledging that a request for removal has been filed. 
Promptly after acknowledging the filing, leadership must notify the member whomst the complaint was filed against. The complaint in its entirety will be made available to the member it was filed against. 
Ahead of the next general body meeting, the member whomst the complaint was filed against is entitled to having a meeting, mediated by members of leadership, with the initial filer of the complaint. 
If the initial complaint filer chooses to proceed with seeking removal, the complaint will be made publicly available to all members and at the next general body meeting the topic of removal will be brought forth to the general body. 
At this meeting, the member facing removal will be allowed to defend themselves in front of the general membership. Following this a vote will be held and if at least  ⅔ ‘s of the general membership vote for removal the member will be removed. 
If the member removed is an officer, a special election will be held at a future meeting according to the procedure detailed above.  


Free Speech:
	All members of BUILD UMass are entitled to freedom of speech and will not under any circumstances be deprived of the opportunity to share their opinion with the group. Under no circumstances shall a member’s freedom of speech or expression be infringed. 


Non Discrimination:
	BUILD UMass will never discriminate against any of its members on the basis of race, color, national origin, religion, sex, gender identity (including gender expression), sexual orientation, disability, age, marital status, family/parental status, income derived from a public assistance program, political beliefs, or reprisal or retaliation for prior civil rights activity. 

Amendments to this Constitution:
This Constitution can be amended by a majority vote at a General Meeting.
A motion to amend may be made and seconded by any member at a meeting of the general membership. 
Voting on the motion shall take place at the following meeting only if more than 3/4th of the club is present. 
Prior to voting, the President shall allow for a period of debate.
After being approved, the amendment itself, and an updated version of the Constitution shall be submitted to the Secretary of the Registry for final approval.

THE CONSTITUTION AND BY-LAWS
OF THE
STUDENT GOVERNMENT ASSOCIATION


THE UNIVERSITY OF MASSACHUSETTS AMHERST





Twenty-Sixth Edition

Constitution
Approved by the Undergraduate Student Senate March 30, 1994
Approved by the SGA membership April 26, 1994
Ratified by the University Board of Trustees
June 8, 1994 as Trustee Document T94$-060

By-Laws
Approved by the Undergraduate Senate March 30, 1994
Approved by the SGA membership April 26, 1994
Approved by the Vice Chancellor for Student Affairs June 10, 1994
Updated with Undergraduate Senate Amendments June 11, 2014




PREFACE

	Welcome to the Student Government Association’s Constitution and By-laws. This is the twenty-sixth edition of those documents, which form the structural guidelines within which we, your SGA, act to serve the student body, and the University as a whole. All members of the SGA should familiarize yourselves with these documents, so you can best serve in your respective office. I want to thank you for your interest in the SGA at the University of Massachusetts –Amherst.
	
My name is Sïonan Barrett and I have the great honor of serving as the Speaker of the Undergraduate Student Senate for the 2014-2015 academic school year. The SGA has been instrumental in helping undergraduates develop leadership skills and learn to work with others in a professional environment. The SGA has been one of the most exciting, challenging, and rewarding experiences I have had so far. Becoming a leader of smart and talented leaders is truly the greatest honor I could receive. Whether you are a senator, cabinet member, or student, I hope you can appreciate and recognize the power of the student voice and student leadership and its capabilities.

My experience within the SGA has allowed me to serve undergraduates since my freshman year within the Undergraduate Senate. From being elected as a Senator, Associate Speaker, and Speaker twice, I have grown immensely, and am continuing to grow and understand more as time goes on. Together, with our diversity of passions, backgrounds and UMass knowledge, this upcoming year looks promising. 

To the senators- listen to your constituents, use your experience, and bring fresh and productive, new ideas to the Senate. If you can do so, you will be doing what leaders should: listening, designing solutions, and being willing to forge effective compromises, while not compromising your principles! Tell people what we do, and why you’re proud to be a part of this change. Our role is not one of self-promotion, rather, it is one of selfless dedication to this proud University that is, and will always be, a part of our lives.

	The University of Massachusetts at Amherst is not simply an institution of higher learning, it is our home. Be a leader, make a difference, take risks, and dare to be great. We here in the SGA do not stand on the sidelines. We have chosen, and have been chosen, to be serve our fellow students. Let’s make a difference, together! 

Sïonan N. Barrett
Speaker of the Senate
Student Government Association
University of Massachusetts- Amherst

The Constitution of the Student Government Association of the University of Massachusetts Amherst









































PREAMBLE

We, the undergraduate students of the University of Massachusetts at Amherst, in order to establish a democratic system for undergraduate University governance, and in order to promote the general welfare of all University undergraduate students, do hereby ordain and establish this Constitution of the Student Government Association at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst.

ARTICLE I
Name

Section 1	The name of this organization shall be the Student Government Association of the University of Massachusetts at Amherst, herein denoted SGA.

ARTICLE II
Membership

Section 1	All undergraduate students of the University of Massachusetts at Amherst, herein denoted the University, meeting the qualifications for SGA membership prescribed by the General By-laws of the SGA, as approved by the Vice Chancellor for Student Affairs, shall be entitled to be members of the SGA, and shall have an equal voice and vote therein with that of their fellow members.

ARTICLE III
Authority

Section 1	This Constitution shall supersede any other previously existing system of campus-wide governance for the University undergraduate population.

Section 2	The SGA shall derive its authority from the undergraduate students of the University, in general election, and The Board of Trustees, as provided for in Section 3, Chapter 75, of the General Laws of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

Section 3	The SGA, as a governance body, shall be governed by the Board of Trustees' Statement on University Governance. [Trustee Document T73-098, as amended]

Section 4	All By-laws, Acts, procedures and all other actions of the SGA, shall be consistent with this Constitution and Trustee Document T73-098, as amended.

ARTICLE IV
Composition of the Government

Section 1	The SGA shall be composed of the Legislative, Executive and Judicial branches of government. All elected and appointed officers of the SGA shall be members of the SGA, as defined by the General By-laws of the SGA, and no SGA member shall hold elected or appointed office in more than one branch of the government, except as provided for by this Constitution or the General By-laws of the SGA. 

Section 2	The University Student Trustee as defined by the General Laws of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, shall be an ex-officio officer of the SGA.




ARTICLE V
The Legislative

Section 1	Charge - The legislative authority of the SGA, as defined in Article V, Section 4 of this Constitution, shall be vested in the University Undergraduate Senate, herein denoted the Senate, and other lesser legislative bodies recognized by this Constitution or the General By-laws of the SGA.

Section 2	Composition - The Senate membership shall be composed of representatives apportioned by the Senate to Electoral Districts, as defined by the General By-laws of the SGA.

Section 3	Election - Senators shall be elected in a manner prescribed by the General By-laws of the SGA and shall serve for a term prescribed therein.

Section 4	Powers - The Senate shall have the power to:

A. Review and make recommendations regarding the Student Activities Fee. A recommended increase in the Student Activities Fee of over 7.5% shall require a two-thirds (2/3) vote of the Senate membership in attendance at a scheduled meeting, and an affirmative vote of the SGA membership through an Action Referendum.

B. Determine and provide for its rules and procedures, elect its officers, and fix the time and place of its meetings, provided that there be a regular meeting with fixed time and place at least once every week of the University academic calendar. 

C. Require the attendance of its members by rule.

D. Expel a member of the Senate. The act of Expulsion shall require a two-thirds (2/3) vote of its membership in attendance at a scheduled meeting.

E. Enact, amend or repeal the General By-laws of the SGA, unless otherwise provided for by the General By-laws of the SGA. Such an act shall require a two-thirds (2/3) vote of its membership in attendance at a scheduled meeting, and the approval of the Vice Chancellor for Student Affairs.

F. Ratify SGA Elections within thirty (30) calendar days of the election. Such an act shall require a majority vote of its membership in attendance at a scheduled meeting.

G. Initiate a referendum as defined by Article VIII of this Constitution. Such an act shall require a two-thirds (2/3) vote of its membership in attendance at a scheduled meeting.

H. Decide tie General or Special Elections at its first meeting following the election. Such an act shall require a majority vote of its membership in attendance at a scheduled meeting.

I. Recommend the Student Activities Trust Fund Budget Request. Such an Act shall require a majority vote of its membership in attendance at a scheduled meeting, and shall be reviewed by the Vice Chancellor for Student Affairs, the Campus Budget Officers, the Chancellor, and the University President, before submission to the Board of Trustees for approval.

J. Recommend the Student Activities Trust Fund Operating Budget by enactment of the Annual SGA S-1 Budget Act. Such an Act shall require a majority vote of its membership in attendance at a scheduled meeting, and shall be submitted to the Vice Chancellor for Student Affairs for approval. Disbursements there from shall be in accordance with duly established University financial and operational policies and campus procedures.

K. Override a presidential veto. Such an act shall require a two-thirds (2/3) vote of its membership in attendance at a scheduled meeting.

L. Approve Executive Cabinet and Student Judiciary appointments. Such an act shall require a majority vote of its membership in attendance at a scheduled meeting.

M. Require reports from the President and Executive Cabinet on any matter relevant to the functioning of the SGA.

N. Impeach an elected officer of the SGA. Such an act shall require a two-thirds (2/3) vote of its membership in attendance at a scheduled meeting.

O. Provide for the succession to those elected offices of the SGA not otherwise provided for by this Constitution.  

P. Provide for the transition of the SGA to this Constitution.

Q. Promote the general welfare and interests of the undergraduate student body by making recommendations on policies and procedures consistent with Trustee Document T73-098, as amended, provided that, when an action is intended as a formal recommendation from the SGA, as a governance body, it shall be submitted in accordance with the procedures prescribed in said document.

Section 5	Prohibitions - The Senate shall not:

A. Take an action abridging any of the powers delegated it by this Constitution.

B. Deny the rights and privileges of Senate membership to any duly elected Senator, except as provided for by this Constitution or the General By-laws of the SGA.

C. Recommend the appropriation of monies for a period of more than one (1) fiscal year.

D. Recommend the increase or decrease in wage of an elected officer of the SGA, effective to the incumbent at the time of the increase or decrease.

E. Infringe the secrecy of the ballot in SGA General Elections.

F. Meet in "executive session", as defined by the General Laws of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.  

Section 6 	Procedures

A. No bill, unless otherwise provided for by this Constitution or the General By-laws of the SGA, shall become an Act of the SGA unless it shall have been introduced to the Senate, read and passed, by a majority vote of its membership in attendance at a scheduled meeting.

B. No bill, unless otherwise provided for by this Constitution or the General By-laws of the SGA, shall become an Act of the SGA without the signature of the SGA President, provided that withholding of their signature shall constitute veto, and that the President of the SGA shall notify the Speaker of the Senate within seven (7) calendar days, giving explicit reasons for the veto.

C. If a bill shall not have been vetoed within seven (7) calendar days following its passage, it shall become an Act of the SGA.

D. A vetoed bill may be enacted not withstanding the veto of the SGA President, if it shall have been read in full a second time, and passed upon a two-thirds (2/3) vote of the Senate membership in attendance at a scheduled meeting.

E. The quorum for the conduct of business at a Senate meeting, or a meeting of a Senate Committee, shall be fifty percent (50%) of the total voting membership plus one (1), unless otherwise provided for by this Constitution or the General By-laws of the SGA.

Section 7 	The Speaker & Associate Speaker of the Senate

A. The Senate shall provide for the election of, from its voting membership, a Speaker of the Senate, herein denoted the Speaker, who shall serve as the chief presiding officer of the Senate.

B. The Senate shall provide for the election of, from its voting membership, an Associate Speaker of the Senate, herein denoted the Associate Speaker, who shall serve as the chief clerk and parliamentarian of the Senate.

C. If a vacancy shall occur in the office of Speaker, the Associate Speaker shall become Speaker for the duration of the unfinished term.
	


ARTICLE VI
The Executive

Section 1	Charge - The executive authority of the SGA shall be vested in an SGA President, herein denoted the President, and other lesser executive officers recognized by this Constitution or the General By-laws of the SGA.

Section 2	Election - The President shall be popularly elected by a majority or plurality of the SGA membership voting, on or before March 25 of each calendar year and shall serve for a term of one (1) calendar year, here defined as April 20 to April 19, and said election shall be held in a manner prescribed by the General By-laws of the SGA.

Section 3	The President shall, upon taking office, be administered the following affirmation by the SGA Chief Justice before the Senate membership:

A. "I do affirm to faithfully execute the office of SGA President and support the Constitution and General By-laws of the Student Government Association."
       
Section 4	Vacancies – if a vacancy shall occur in the office of the President, the Vice President shall become President for the duration of the unfinished term. In such cases where the Vice President is unable or unwilling to assume the Presidency, the Speaker of the Senate shall become President. 

Section 5	Power-The President shall have the power to:

Act as the chief executive of the SGA.

B. Take care that all the provisions of this Constitution, the General By-laws of the SGA, and Acts of the SGA are faithfully executed.

C. Appoint, upon a majority vote of the Senate membership in attendance at a scheduled meeting, the Executive Cabinet.

D. Appoint, upon the recommendation of the Coordinating Council, and upon a majority vote of the Senate membership in attendance at a scheduled meeting, the seven (7) Justices of the Student Judiciary.

E. Appoint all lesser executive officers and external SGA committees as defined by the General By-laws of the SGA.

F. In a manner prescribed by the General By-laws of the SGA, call the Senate into Session.

G. Be an ex-officio member of the Senate, as defined by the General By-laws of the SGA,  and shall, in an address upon taking office, and at the first scheduled Senate meeting of a new Session, put forward their legislative agenda for consideration by the Senate.

H. Veto any bill except Resolutions, the Annual SGA S-1 Budget Act, and Articles of Impeachment.       

I.  Initiate a referendum as defined in Article VIII of this Constitution and the General By-laws of the SGA.

ARTICLE VII
The Judicial

Section 1	Charge – The judicial authority of the SGA shall be vested in a Student Judiciary.

Section 2	Jurisdiction – The Student Judiciary shall have original jurisdiction over any controversy arising under this Constitution, the General By-laws of the SGA, or any Act of the SGA. 

Section 3	Composition – The Student Judiciary shall be composed of seven Justices appointed and confirmed in a manner prescribed by Article VI, Section 5 Sub-section D of this Constitution, and who shall serve for the calendar period of their SGA membership.

Section 4 	Power – The Student Judiciary may hold, by declaratory judgment, any act by any agent of the Executive or Legislative Branches of the SGA, or of any agency directly associated with the SGA, or of any candidate for SGA office, to be unconstitutional, or in violation of any By-law or Act of the SGA, and therefore, invalid, provided said action is not a governance item approved by the Board of Trustees.
	
Section 5	Procedure – Any person(s), with the exception of members of the Student Judiciary, may file with the Student Judiciary a Petition for a Ruling on the constitutionality and/or validity of any act by any agent of the Executive or Legislative Branches of the SGA, or of any agency directly associated with the SGA, or of any candidate for SGA office, within ninety (90) days of said action, and the Student Judiciary shall issue a ruling on same, provided said action is not a governance item approved by the Board of Trustees .

Section 6	Quorum – The Quorum for the conduct of business for the Student Judiciary shall be five (5) Justices; one (1) of whom shall be the Chief Justice or Associate Chief Justice.

Section 7	Chief Justice & Associate Chief Justice

The Student Judiciary shall provide for the election of, from its voting membership, a Chief Justice of the Student Judiciary, herein denoted the Chief Justice, who shall serve as the chief presiding officer of the Student Judiciary.

B. The Student Judiciary shall provide for the election of, from its voting membership, an Associate Chief Justice of the Student Judiciary, herein denoted the Associate Chief Justice, who shall serve as the chief clerk of the Student Judiciary.

C. If a vacancy shall occur in the office of Chief Justice, the Associate Chief Justice shall become Chief Justice for the duration of the unfinished term.


ARTICLE VIII
Referenda

Section 1	There shall be two primary types of referenda:

Action – An Action Referendum, if approved, shall become an Act of the SGA, shall not be subject to presidential veto, and when such an action is intended as a formal recommendation from the SGA, as a governance body, it shall be submitted in accordance with the procedures prescribed in Trustee Document T73-098, as amended.

B. Advisory – An Advisory Referendum shall only be a measure of public sentiment.

Section 2	All referenda shall be clearly labeled and understood by the SGA membership to be either an Action or Advisory Referendum.

Section 3	Action or Advisory Referenda shall be initiated by any one of the following:

A. The University Student Trustee

B. The Senate

C. The SGA President

D. The signatures, on a petition, of not less than five percent (5%) of the SGA membership.

Section 4	Advisory Referenda shall be initiated by the Chancellor or the Vice Chancellor for Student Affairs. 

ARTICLE IX
Amendment

Section 1	This Constitution shall be amended through either of the processes prescribed in Article IX, Sections 2-3 of this Constitution, with the approval of the Board of Trustees.

Section 2	An amendment to this Constitution shall be passed upon a two-thirds (2/3) vote of the Senate membership in attendance at a scheduled meeting, and a majority vote of the SGA membership voting on the amendment through an Action Referendum.

Section 3	An amendment to this Constitution shall be passed upon a two-thirds (2/3) vote of the SGA membership voting on the amendment through an Action Referendum.

Section 4	If the amendment process prescribed in Article IX, Section 2, of this Constitution shall have been invoked, then, following an amendment’s passage in the Senate, the amendment shall appear as an Action Referendum before the SGA membership, no more than thirty (30) calendar days from the calendar date of the amendment’s passage in the Senate.

Section 5	No person shall formally introduce an amendment to this Constitution, who shall not have first consulted the Chief Justice and the Directing Attorney of Student Legal Services Office, or their designee.

ARTICLE X
Ratification

Section 1	This Constitution shall be ratified upon a two-thirds (2/3) vote of the Senate membership in attendance at a scheduled meeting, a majority vote of the voting SGA membership on an Action Referendum, and the approval of the Board of Trustees 






































The University of Massachusetts Student Government Association Bylaws

Mission Statement
To establish and protect the democratic system for undergraduate university governance; to promote the general welfare of all university undergraduate students. To create and maintain  strong lines of communication between students and university administrators; to work toward greater transparency in administrative decisions. To protect the accessibility and affordability of the university for all students. To work to acknowledge, appreciate, and expand the diversity of the student body, including socioeconomic, racial, religious, cultural, gender, sexual orientation, and political characteristics. To provide leadership opportunities and development for all undergraduate students and to set the standards which other schools strive to uphold when leading their students into the future.





















TITLE I
Administrative




Chapter 1
SGA Membership

Section 1 	Any person, subject to, and having paid the Student Activities Fee, shall be a member of the SGA for the period of calendar time to which their paid Student Activities Fee is applicable.

Chapter 2 
Ex-officio membership

Section 1 	Any person, defined by the Constitution of the SGA or the By-laws of the SGA as an ex-officio member of any body or agency of the SGA, shall be entitled to address that body in accordance with the rules and by-laws of the body concerned during the conduct of said body’s or agency’s business, without the prior consent of said body or agency, but shall be prohibited from making any motion, casting any vote, counting toward quorum, or exercising any authority, not otherwise provided for by the Constitution of the SGA or the By-laws of the SGA.

Chapter 3 
Cross Branch Service

Section 1 	SGA members may hold elected or appointed office in more than one (1) branch of the government provided that no more than one (1) of said offices is at or above the rank of Executive Cabinet member, Senator, Student Judiciary member, or Area Government Officer.

Chapter 4 
Equal Opportunity Policy

Section 1 	No person, having qualified for SGA membership in the manner prescribed by Title 1, Chapter 1, Section 1, of the By-laws of the SGA, shall be denied the rights and privileges of SGA membership, on the basis of age, marital status, physical ability, class, national origin, political affiliation, race, religion, sex, sexual orientation, or any other category or group of individuals protected by either federal, state, or local anti-discrimination statutes and by-laws.

Chapter 5 
SGA Code of Conduct
