Approved by the BoT 4/4/73
Amended 4/2/75
Amended 6/1/88
Amended 2/3/93
 

BOARD OF TRUSTEES STATEMENT ON UNIVERSITY GOVERNANCE
I. TRUSTEE POLICY ON UNIVERSITY GOVERNANCE
 
    A. ENDORSEMENT OF AAUP STATEMENTS ON GOVERNANCE
1. The Board of Trustees has all authority, responsibility, rights, privileges, powers and duties of organization and government of the University of Massachusetts as provided in Chapter 75 of the General Laws of the Commonwealth. Nothing in the following statement shall be taken as contravening that authority or any applicable federal or state law or regulation; anything contravening such authority, law or regulation is void. 
2. Nevertheless, as an established university discharges its obligations and responsibilities to society by the advancement and dissemination of knowledge, the variety and complexity of its tasks require and ensure the interdependence of the governing board, the administration, the faculty, and the students, as well as other groups. The Board of Trustees has long recognized this interdependence, both among campuses within the system and among the various components within a campus, and now formally adopts the principle of joint effort in governing the University.
3. Join effort in University governance will take a variety of forms depending on the issue and the situation. The administrative officers or the Board may in some instances propose recommendations for the consideration of the faculty and/or students before taking final action. The faculty and/or students may in other instances propose recommendations subject only to the endorsement of the administration and the Board. In all instances, however, the principle of joint effort requires that components within the University remain sensitive to the interests of other components.
4. The Board of Trustees therefore endorses in principle the 1996 Statement on Government of Colleges and Universities adopted by the American Association of University Professors, the American Council of Education, and the Association of Governing Boards of Universities and Colleges and the 1970 statement on Student Participation in College and University Government formulated by the three aforementioned organizations, insofar as both are consistent with this Trustees’ Statement on University Governance. In endorsing these two statements, the Board, while retaining its ultimate legal authority in governing the University, recognizes that the faculty, the students, and other groups within the University have the right, the responsibility, and the privilege of advising on policies affecting the University. The Board will ensure these rights, responsibilities, and privileges through the various governing bodies—both representative bodies such as senates and assemblies, and administrative bodies such as departments, school, and colleges—established by its bylaws and other actions.
B. PRIMARY RESPONSIBILITIES IN GOVERNANCE

The Board of Trustees recognizes that while it must exercise general authority over the University, certain components of the University, such as the President’s Office, the campus administrations, and the representative and administrative governing bodies of the faculty and the students have, by virtue of interest, training, and experience, a special concern and competence in certain areas. Subject to precedents established by components on each campus and/or the restraints and procedures specified in their constitutions, these components shall have primary responsibility in their areas of special competence and concern. Whenever the phrase "primary responsibility" appears in this statement, it shall mean the capacity to initiate recommendations, after appropriate consultation, in accordance with the procedures specified in section II. D below. Such recommendations will be overruled only by written reasons stated in detail. While it in no way is intended to contravene the authority and participation of the Board of Trustees in governance, the following is a general statement of primary responsibility in the major areas of University life. 
ACADEMIC MATTERS: By virtue of its professional preparation and its central concern with learning and teaching the faculty will exercise primary responsibility in such academic matters as curriculum, subject matter and methods of instruction, research, admissions, libraries, and other aspects of University life which directly relate to the educational process. Students share this concern and they will be assured the opportunity of participating in developing academic policies and in evaluating degrees, programs, and courses.  
FACULTY STATUS: The faculty will have primary responsibility for matters of faculty status, such as appointments, reappointments, promotions, tenure, and salary adjustments. Students will also be assured the opportunity of participating in the evaluation of a faculty member’s effectiveness. 
STUDENT AFFAIRS: Students will have primary responsibility for services and activities which are designed primarily to serve students or those which are financed primarily by students, managing student political affairs and organizational matters, and setting standards for student behavior, conduct, and discipline. 
PLANNING, DEVELOPMENT AND BUDGET: The President is responsible for exerting educational leadership in the planning and development of the University, both before the Board of Trustees and on the various campuses. He/she shall coordinate the planning and development on the separate campuses, keep current a University master plan, and ensure that all appropriate components of the University have the opportunity to make recommendations before planning and development decisions are rendered. The President is also responsible for coordinating, preparing, and presenting to the Board of Trustees the University’s annual budget request. He/she shall represent the budget request approved by the Board to the Governor and the General court. The Chancellors are responsible for coordinating, preparing, and presenting to the President budget requests from the campuses. The President is responsible for continually improving the budget process and developing a calendar which allows adequate time for consultation and study by all interested components of the University.
II. RESPONSIBILITIES, DUTIES, FUNCTIONS, AND PROCEDURES OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES, THE PRESIDENT, THE CAMPUS ADMINISTRATORS, AND THE CAMPUS GOVERNING BODIES IN UNIVERSITY GOVERNANCE
Consistent with Chapter 15A and pursuant to Chapter 75 of the General Laws of the Commonwealth, the Board of Trustees may establish general policies governing the University. The authority of the Board shall include, but is not limited to, the following specific powers:
A. BOARD OF TRUSTEES
1. The Trustees will consider, upon the recommendation of the appropriate faculty and student governing bodies and/or other appropriate groups, the academic plans, personnel policies, and admissions policies of each campus and of the University as a whole; plans for the establishment of new campuses, schools, institutes, and colleges, and plans for the closing of already established units and programs.
2. The Trustees will consider, upon the recommendation of the appropriate governing body(s), the establishment of degrees.


3. The Trustees will consider the budget requests of the University and the capital outlay budget requests and major amendments thereto. In addition, they will consider new student housing and other loan construction programs, accept gifts, and approve service agreements, rental agreements, and leases. Further, they will consider policies governing the solicitation of grants and research contracts. 
4. The Trustees will appoint the President, the Chancellors, the Treasurer, and the Secretary of the University, set their salaries, and periodically evaluate their performance. When appointing the President, the Board will seek nominations from a broadly representative search committee appointed by the Board. The Board will determine the charge to and composition of the search committee after seeking the recommendations of the appropriate campus governing body(s) and, when appropriate, other components of the University. The Board will appoint faculty and student representatives to the search committee upon nomination by the appropriate governing body(s). When appointing a Chancellor, the Board will seek nominations from a broadly representative search committee appointed by the Chair of the Trustees in consultation with the President. The Chair will determine the charge to and composition of the search committee after seeking the recommendations of the appropriate campus governing body(s) and, when appropriate, other components of the University. The Board will appoint faculty and student representatives to the search committee upon nomination by the appropriate governing body(s). The President will recommend two or more candidates to the Board.
5. The Trustees will consider long-range development and design plans for each campus in relation to long-range academic plans and any major amendments to these plans. They will approve consulting architects, landscape architects, executive architects, and the designs for major campuses, consistent with the authority vested in the Department of Capital Planning and Operations.
6. The Trustees will consider all policies concerning the University’s relationship with local, state, and federal governments and all policies concerning public information. In this regard the Board will consider policies concerning the University relationship with other segments of higher education.
7. The Trustees will make the final selection of all honorary degree recipients and will name all buildings and facilities.
B. PRESIDENT OF THE UNIVERSITY
1. The President is the principal academic and executive officer of the University. He/she will exercise executive authority over the campuses comprising the University subject to the direction of the Board of Trustees. He/she will serve as chief spokesman and interpreter of the University and represent it to the general public and its representatives.
2. The President will be responsible for presenting policy recommendations to the Board of Trustees and ensuring that the campuses develop ways of implementing Trustees’ policy. He/she will develop, coordinate, and keep current a master plan of the University. He/she will be responsible for the coordination and preparation of the annual budget request and its presentation to the Board of Trustees and to the Governor and the General Court. He/she will also be responsible for the allocation of the appropriated budget and all other funds. 
3. The President will appoint, promote and grant salary adjustments to personnel in the President’s office. He/she will supervise the operations of the officers and staff in the President’s office.
4. The President will appoint the Vice Presidents with the concurrence of the Board of Trustees.
5. The President will appoint members of the faculty to tenure with the concurrence of the Board of Trustees.
6. The President will coordinate the work of all campuses of the University and promote the general welfare of the University as a whole and in its several parts. He/she will ensure as much campus autonomy as possible commensurate with achieving the central purposes of the University or fulfilling their duties as specified herein. The President will establish and maintain an effective communications system within the University that allows for the prompt identification of needs and problems and their analysis. In particular, the President, in concert with the Chancellors, will ensure that all appropriate components of the University have the opportunity to make recommendations prior to the establishment of policy.
7. The President may refer for investigation and report any matter of institutional concern to administrative staff, governing bodies, faculty, or students. The channel for official communications between the President and the various campus groups in such matter will be through the Chancellor.
C. CAMPUS CHANCELLOR
1. The Chancellor is the chief academic and executive officer of the campus. He/she will exercise executive authority over the campus subject to the direction of the President. He/she will be responsible to the President for administering the various schools, colleges, divisions, departments, and other units on the campus.
2. In the formulation of policy the Chancellor will represent their campus to the President and the Board of Trustees, and upon the adoption of policy he/she will ensure its implementation on campus. He/she will develop, coordinate, and present to the President immediate and long-range plans for the campus. The Chancellor will also coordinate, prepare, and present to the President the annual budget request of the campus and oversee campus expenditures.
3. The Chancellor will appoint the Vice Chancellors, the Provosts, and the Deans of the campus upon delegation by the President, set their salaries, and periodically evaluate their performance. When appointing a Vice Chancellor with line responsibilities, a Provost, or a Dean, the Chancellor will seek nominations from a broadly representative search committee. The Chancellor and the appropriate governing body(s), representative and/or administrative, will mutually agree upon the composition and the charge of the search committee. The Chancellor will appoint faculty and student representatives to the search committee upon nomination by the appropriate governing body(s).
4. The Chancellor will appoint, promote, and grant salary adjustments to professional and nonprofessional personnel on campus.
5. The Chancellor will coordinate the work of the various units of the campus and promote the general welfare of the campus as a whole and in its several parts. He/she will ensure as much autonomy as possible to the various units of the campus commensurate with achieving the central purposes of the campus and the University as a whole or fulfilling their duties as specified herein. He/she will assist the President in maintaining an effective communications system within the campus that allows for the prompt identification of needs and problems and their analysis. In particular, the Chancellor will assist the President in ensuring that all appropriate components of the campus have the opportunity to make recommendations prior to the establishment of policy.
6. The Chancellor may refer for investigation and report any matter of institutional concern to administrative staff, governing bodies, faculty and students.
D. CAMPUS GOVERNING BODIES
1. Faculty and students may be organized into governing bodies, such as senates and assemblies, departments, schools, and colleges. The constitutions of the major governing bodies must be approved by the Board of Trustees.
2. When appropriate, governing bodies shall have the privilege of recommending policies and procedures affecting the campus and the University as a whole, including, among other matters, academic matters, matters of faculty status, and student affairs. Also when appropriate, governing bodies will have the privilege of contributing to long-range planning, the preparation of the annual budget request, and the allocation of available resources.
3. The Chancellor, the President, and the Board of Trustees may approve recommendations from the campus representative governing bodies at any time. Subject to precedents established by components of each campus and/or the restraints and procedures specified in their constitutions, and in accordance with the preceding statements of primary responsibility (Section I.B of this statement), recommendations adopted by the campus representative governing bodies will become policy unless
(1) disapproved or sent back for reconsideration by the Chancellor within twenty working days of receipt of notification from the governing body; (2) disapproved, sent back for reconsideration, or deferred by the President within twenty working days of receipt of notification of the Chancellor’s approval or within twenty working days following the expiration of the twenty working-day period for the Chancellor’s consideration; (3) disapproved by the President during a special thirty-working-deferral period (if the President chooses to defer their decision he/she will notify the governing body; the deferral period will begin at the end of the President’s initial twenty-working-day period of consideration); (4) disapproved by the Board of Trustees within these specified time limitations. The governing bodies will notify the Chancellor, the President, and the Board of Trustees of their actions as soon as possible after their adoption. Any matter not acted upon within seventy-working-days of receipt of notification by the Chancellor of an action by a governing body will be taken as approved by the Board of Trustees. When a recommendation is disapproved, the governing body will receive written reasons in detail for the adverse decision.
III. IMPLEMENTATION
Provision for implementing the foregoing policies and procedures of University governance shall be subject to the approval of the Board of Trustees.
IV. APPROVAL AND EVALUATION
The Board of Trustees reserves the right to alter, amend or revoke the foregoing Statement on University Governance, in part or whole, at any time. The Board of Trustees will review the foregoing policies and procedures every five years.

DocsList.Data:
Campus Design
& Copy
Handbook












Introduction to the CD&C book
This handbook has been created and continuously revised in an effort to inform and remind the student-managers of Campus Design and Copy of processes involved in running this business. Though the handbook is primarily designed as an introduction for first-semester employees, it also serves as the only written record of all store policies and procedures. Therefore, copies of the handbook may be given to returning co-managers each semester as a reference for company policies and individual responsibilities. A copy of the handbook should also be present at every all-staff for the same reasons.  Finally, this handbook is the only official history of CD&C and is a vital means of passing on information from one generation of co-managers to the next.  The book is a “living” document, altered in accordance with formal changes in the business.

The CD&C handbook is organized into six distinct sections designed according to the requirements of the Center for Student Business and for your reading pleasure: HISTORY AND IDEY provides the story of our business from its conception through the present.  A discussion of cooperative ideologies is vital in order to understand the CD&C management style.  Additionally, the role of the Center for Student Businesses and its staff is explained. The ALL-STAFF section details the format and content of weekly business meetings, including the decision-making process and policies on attendance.  COMMITTEES explain how the tasks of running the business are divided and assigned to individual and groups of co-managers.  In addition to listing the descriptions and responsibilities of each committee, this section lays out committee election processes.  PERSONNEL encompasses human resource particulars: hiring and firing, attendance policies, the stars-n-dots system of accountability, and co-worker evaluations. Lastly,  BUSINESS AND FINANCE presents an overview of the financial philosophies of CD&C. This section has been designed to give non-business majors basic knowledge of the not-for-profit system and outlines the UMass purchase order system.
















PART I
HISTORY AND IDEOLOGY

MISSION STATEMENT
Campus Design and Copy is an undergraduate student-initiated and managed business at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst. Its purpose is three-fold: 

To provide undergraduate students with experience and training in collective management; to serve the University community with copying, design, binding, faxing, computer and finishing services; and to promote the co-operative and collective movements. It aims to foster ideals of equality and diversity in the workplace. CD&C is a not-for-profit organization and operates under the model “students working for students.”

IN THE BEGINNING…
Campus Design and Copy was born on January 10, 1990, when a decision was made by representatives of the SGA and the Center for Student Businesses to merge SGA Communications with the Student Notes and Printing Services (SNPS) to create a student business. Both SNPS and SGA Communications were failing and needed assistance.  The SGA could no longer afford to support such an expensive graphics service, and SNPS was not getting enough business to keep it alive. To the Univeristy, the decision to merge these two organizations seemed like a gamble, but the folks involved believed the new business would thrive with a little hard work from dedicated students. A collectively-run student business serving the University community and providing a “working classroom” for its co-managers was established.

The kinds of services offered by CD&C have significantly evolved since its inception. Initially, co-managers were paid to sit in lectures and take notes, which were then reproduced and sold to students. This service was discontinued soon after the merger, as the business began to focus on the more lucrative product of academic packets. Class notes are still a CD&C service, but in the form of “course packets,” notes/hand-outs provided by professors or teaching assistants. CD&C has increasingly emphasized working directly with RSO’s (Registered Student Organizations) and presently relies on RSO revenue for a significant part of its income. In addition to copying, many RSO’s take advantage of the business' graphic design services to create invitations, pamphlets, flyers, etc.  With advances in technology, CD&C has continually updated its computer and networking systems and expanded its design services. In addition to CD&C designed graphics, personal computer use is offered to student groups and individual students. The addition of the store’s fax machine in 2006 and new printers and computers acquired in 2010 are examples of CD&C’s commitment to expanding its services to meet the changing needs of the UMass community.

CD&C has also experienced a number of structure and policy changes over the years. Many of the initial changes occurred during fall semester of 1994, a time which marked a major turning point for the business and which accounts for the significance of this very handbook. The business was unprecedentedly unprepared for a new semester. Without a foundation to run on, the returning staff – consisting primarily of inexperienced second semester comanagers and nine new hires – were forced to restructure the business from scratch. These forefathers conceived new committees, procedures, and policies that led us to where we are today.
In early 1996, the business experienced three important changes.  First was a restructuring and beautification of the business’ office space. Second was acquisition of a new and updated Xerox copying machine.  And finally, after months of leg-work by CD&C employees, the business received a $5,000.00 grant from the Xerox Corporation in order to fund two new computers and a laser printer.  In February of that year, a grand re-opening was held to publicize this grant and to draw attention to CD&C’s status as a student-run business (see accompanying Collegian article).  

In the spring of 2002 CD&C went through another major change when the process of updating the major copying equipment was raised and research began. By the closing of winter 2002 CD&C decided to renegotiate and extend their current contract with IKON; the result was the arrival of two new Canon copiers at a fraction of the cost. The new copiers enabled CD&C to expand its networking capabilities, decreasing the cost of computer printouts with copiers replacing the use of the laser printers. Shortly after, in fall of 2003, the vision of CD&C being a major color copy provider realized with the purchase of a new color copier. This purchase opened up new possibilities for the expansion of CD&C graphic and design services. CD&C has since negotiated the conversion of the color copier rental agreement over to a more beneficial leasing agreement and also researching the possible updating of CD&C self-serve copier. 

The year 2006 has brought forth numerous valuable changes in CD&C. As a result in the fall of 2006, due to substantial decreasing change in revenue, we saw fit to permanently reduce the number of co-managers in our business.  Other changes included the addition of a public bulletin board and the transition from RSO IAR cards to computer spreadsheets. CD&C updated and pioneered numerous sources of profitable revenue to our business with these innovative  changes.

(Somewhere in here, OCE happened.)

CD&C experienced many major changes during the 2010-2011 academic year. Technologically speaking, we gained a bureaucratically enforced lease agreement with XEROX and two new printers. Against all odds, CD&C also bought two new computers. On the business side of matters, we concluded that our dot policy required restructuring. After consulting other student-run businesses with effective dot policies, a new dot policy was voted into existence in January of 2011. 


WHAT IS A CO-OP? 
CD&C is considered a “co-operative” business (“co-op”) in the sense that we manage the business according to co-operative ideologies. Although we control our own capital, UMass ultimately owns CD&C and so we are technically a collectively-run business. However, CD&C is strongly based principles of a co-operative and we generally use words like “cooperative” and “collective” interchangeably to describe ourselves.

The first cooperative was formed in  in 1844 by one woman and 27 men, who would become known as the “Rochdale Pioneers.”  This group of people put together a set of principles that all co-ops use.  The Rochdale Principles are as follows:

1.	Open Membership: Membership to the co-op is voluntary and there is no discrimination on the basis of race, sex, or religious or political affiliation. 
2.	Democratic Control: One member, one vote.  This principle guards 	 against control by the few for the benefit of the few.
3.	Limited Return on Equity Capital: Money made is re-invested in the business.
4. Net-Surplus Belongs to User-Owners: The net savings of a co-op may be distributed equitably among the membership, or used in some other agreed upon manner, either for the benefit of the group or for the local community as a whole.
5.	Continuous Education: Co-ops act to educate their members and the local community about the principles, methods, problems and goals of the organization.
6.	Cooperation among Cooperatives: To strengthen themselves and to serve members and the community better, co-ops need to work together at the local, regional, national and international levels.
Political Non-Partisanship: Adhering to the goals of a particular political party or agenda would limit membership, thus violating the open membership principle. This does not mean that co-ops must be politically inactive, but it does mean that co-ops have usually chosen to limit their political activity to those issues directly effecting the co-op movement and the industries they are a part of.

WHAT IS A ECTIVE?
As previously stated, UMass ultimately owns CD&C, and this prevents the business from being a true co-operative.  Philosophically we operate under the principles of a co-op, and operate as worker-run collective. A collective is very much like a co-op; while Co-ops often operate on the basis of majority rule, collectives are characterized by collective decision-making and commitment to empowering the people who do the work. Nearly all of the co-operative Rochdale Principles apply to CD&C despite the fact that we only own our business in spirit.  For example, every member can exercise decision making power equal to any other member and profits are reinvested into the business.  Additionally, we attempt to educate our members and customers about the ideas of collectives and cooperatives.  We enforce policies of non-discrimination and membership is open to all UMass undergrads. However, CD&C does not have completely open membership because potential members must apply and be selected by the Hiring Committee.  

WHAT IS PCIPATORY MANAGEMENT?
WHAT IS CNSUS DECISION MAKING?
A collective can have a number of different management structures; in the case of CD&C, the business is run under what is called “participatory management.”  Participatory management is as a management style in which all members have an equal say in business decisions; one member, one vote.  There is no hierarchical structure.  The tasks of running the business are broken down and delegated to different committees.  This promotes an emphasis on group development and team building.  All decisions are made by consensus.  This means that before a decision can be implemented all members of the collective must consent to the decision.  Consensus decision making is an alternative to the usual “majority rules” model of most groups and is based on the idea of unity.  Instead of a minimum of 51% of the group agreeing, consensus requires that no member object to the decision.  In effect, there is a lot of give and pull and compromise until everyone is satisfied with the decision made.  This type of decision making prevents a majority from ruling over a minority and ensures that every individual has the opportunity to contribute.  However, it should be understood that not everyone will be totally satisfied with the final outcome; this is rare; for this reason, abstentions are allowed.  The consensus process is often frustrating and time-consuming, but it can also be extremely rewarding as it requires tolerance and respect for the opinions of others. For further explanation of CD&C’s decision-making process, see “Decision-Making at All-Staff”

THE CENTER FOR STUDENT BUSINESS
	The Center For Student Business (CSB) provides guidance, training, and oversight for the University’s eight student-run businesses.  The CSB is the primary link between businesses like CD&C and the University administration.  The office assists CD&C with budgets, income statements and other financial matters.  The CSB provides a consultant for each student business, an undergraduate SOM major, who attends the All-Staff meetings and educates the group about the fiscal side of the business. 

INFRA-STRUCTURE
• Head Coordinator – Rosemary Schmidt 
	Rosemary is the head of the CSB. She oversees all student controlled businesses. Look to her for information on collective history, business advice, problem-solving consultation, and CD&C history. She can be contacted in her office at the CSB, 409 Student Union, or called at 545-2166.
• Assistant Coordinator- Amy Helstowski
	This individual plays an enormous role at CD&C. He/she deals with our financial transactions, working with the consultant to create a sound, workable budget. The Assistant Coordinator will also attend and participate in All-staff and Steering committee meetings. This person also plays a large role in educating CD&C on more effective ways of streamlining inefficiencies and productive team management. 	
• CSB Consultant
The CSB Consultant is an ISOM student working for us in the CSB. He/she is responsible for creating a sound and workable budget for each semester. Once it is completed he/she presents it to the group at an All-Staff meeting. This person also provides us with monthly income statement reviews, consultation advice, and directs the activities for the individual members of CD&C’s business committee.






PART II:
ALL-STAFF MEETINGS

What is All-Staff?
Communication is the essence of CD&C. During weekly All-Staff meetings, all co-managers and the CSB consultant meet to communicate about various issues and ideas and to make collective decisions; individuals and committees exchange information with the rest of the business (usually through committee reports) and progress on certain tasks is reported.  Meetings can also turn into mini-brainstorming sessions in which co-managers can respectfully discuss ideas for improving the business.  Occasionally there are special speakers and/or workshops held during All-Staff. For obvious reasons, All-Staff meetings are mandatory.  If an employee has a class conflict, this matter must be brought to the attention of the All-Staff as soon as possible.  

Each co-manager has 2 free/missed meetings per semester - no questions asked.  However, it is advisable that these 2 misses be saved for dire academic or health circumstances.  If an employee is going to miss a meeting, he/she is responsible for putting their name on the agenda under “Members Absent” before the agenda is copied. After the 2nd free miss, any subsequent absences are inexcusable (illness, unless serious, is not an excuse if the employee has already missed 2 meetings - see the section entitled “If you missed the meeting...”).  Anyone missing a meeting forfeits his/her right to vote on any matter decided upon in that All-Staff.  Ideally, meetings take place on Monday evenings and usually last about two hours, but can stretch longer for special discussions including committee elections or workshops. 

If school is cancelled on a Monday and the next day is a Tuesday schedule, then All-Staff will still be held that Monday. If school is cancelled but the next day is a Monday schedule, then CD&C follows a Monday schedule and Tuesday is when All-Staff will be held. This also applies with shift hours and other committee meetings that would fall on a Monday. When school is cancelled the whole day of after a certain time due to inclement weather, scheduled holidays, or other types of emergency closing CD&C will be closed as well. The same applies for late opening of the campus; CD&C will follow the late-closing schedule.


All-Staff s
(All roles are assigned on the critical info center at the beginning of each semester on a rotating schedule.)
FACILITATOR
The facilitator is responsible for guiding the All-Staff meeting: starting the meeting on time, assigning roles, and organizing the agenda. Additionally, the facilitator assists the group in determining what it is they want to accomplish and helps to carry it out by initiating discussion and carrying out votes to test for consensus. The facilitator should attempt to summarize and convey confusing or controversial ideas expressed by employees. It is also the responsibility of the facilitator to objectively diffuse emotional tension between co-mangers. The facilitator should be informed of the issues to be discussed, provide copies of the agenda and all-staff materials to all employees, and is responsible for starting the meeting promptly. The facilitator should also be aware of follow-through assignments from the previous meeting. In order to have an objective perspective, he or she should have little emotional involvement and/or investment in the meeting and remain professional at all times. Lastly, the facilitator is responsible for encouraging discussion amongst all employees to better insure the quality of the decision made. (Material adapted from Katja Hahn D’Errico’s How To Facilitate a Meeting, 1994.) The facilitator is also responsible for putting the agenda and any proposals/trainings in the all-staff binder. 

NOTETAKER
The notetaker in the All-Staff meeting records what is said and done at each meeting. Because these notes are the only record of what is currently going on at CD&C and serve as a written history, the notetaker must type up the notes and file them (along with all corresponding all-staff materials) in the appropriate folders on the critical information board.

TIMEKEEPER
The timekeeper position serves to keep the meeting functioning at an efficient pace. He/she makes sure the meeting follows the estimated times for each agenda item closely, allowing more time for important items and reminding co-managers of the time already spent on less important items. 

STACKER
The stacker keeps the flow of the meeting at a continuous pace by discreetly ‘stacking’ speakers in order when there is more than one co-manager who would like contribute. For the sake of equality, stackers have the option to tally the amount of times each co-manager speaks and verbalize the numbers.

How Meetings Are Run
Before All-Staff it is the responsibility of each co-manager to mark on the master Agenda whether they have any topics to discuss during the meeting, whether they will be absent, late, etc. If you cannot do it yourself, tell someone who will be able to mark it before copies of the agenda are made. It is the role of a steering committee member to mark who is the facilitator, note taker, stacker, and timekeeper. 

The All-Staff meeting is run according to the following format:

	I.  BEGINNING GO-AROUND
During this time each co-manager has a few moments to express how their week has been going, what they did that weekend, announce any personal news, etc. Co-managers also answer a question, provided by Steering, which allows co-managers to express their personalities. The first fifteen minutes of each all-staff is reserved for this function, allowing co-managers to get to know each other in a personal level.

	II. FOLLOW-THROUGH
	This is a list of tasks, read out loud, that was assigned at the previous meeting. Large Follow through items (Designing a banner for the store, performing a profit analysis) should be written down and put on the corkboard board in the store with its desired completion date. It can also be written in the logbook, and the communications co-manager can send a reminder email depending on the urgency and size of the job. Smaller tasks should be completed during the week either by the co-manager or committee it was assigned to (Did register get fixed?  Are the new payroll forms ready?).  If the task was not completed, the person and/or committee can be given dots by the Steering Committee. Its purpose is to allow All-Staff to hold people and committees accountable for jobs to be done.

	III. DO’S AND ’TS, S AND DOTS, EMPLOYEE OF THE WEEK.
The system of “Do’s and Don’ts” encourages co-managers to formally remind each other of various store-related conventions. Its purpose is to prevent sloppiness and attention to relevant procedures and policies. Co-managers can use Do’s and Don’ts to address issues that arise during day to day store operations. Do’s and Don’ts consist of slips of paper (respectively labeled either “Do” or “Don’t”) upon which any co-manager may write a pertinent reminder to be vocalized at the following All-Staff. At this time, Do’s and Don’ts may also be verbally added. 
 If you notice some protocol in the store was neglected or identify a policy that you feel needs to be reiterated, the Do’s and Don’ts system enables you to do so anonymously. At any point during the week you may simply record a “Do” or a “Don’t” and deposit it in the “Do’s and Don’ts” box. (e.g. DO: clean up scraps of paper after chopping; DON’T: forget to mark an email as unread if you opened it but did not respond)
	“Stars and Dots” characterize our system of accountability. Stars are given to co-managers when they go above and beyond basic duties or when they exhibit exemplary qualities which benefit the business. Any co-manager can give any other co-manager a Star at any point in time; the limit of Stars bestowed upon a given co-manager is infinity. If you feel as though a co-manager deserves a Star, fill out a “Star” slip and deposit the slip into the Star/Dot box with your name, the name of the co-manager receiving the Star, the date the Star was given, and, you guessed it, the reason for giving the Star. In the event that a co-manager earns multiple Stars for the same reason, only one of the Stars shall be counted. Stars are read at All-Staff and immediately posted by steering on the “Star chart” (located on the Critical Info board). 
	Dots are given to co-managers when they fail to carry out a designated duty. Dots can be given to any co-manager by any co-manager at any point in time. Unlike stars, a list of specific “dottable offenses” (located on the Critical Info board) serves as a guideline by which to determine what shortcomings deserve recognition. If a co-manager has committed an offense worthy of a dot that also complies with the established dottable offenses, then they should receive a Dot (or give themselves a Dot). However, Dot-worthy transgressions are not limited to the formal list of “dottable offenses” and a co-manager can give another co-manager a Dot when they feel it is appropriate. To dot a co-manager, fill out a “Dot” slip with the appropriate information (your name, name of recipient, incident of importance, date) and deposit the slip into the “Star and Dot” box. In order for a Dot to be considered official, the Dot-giver MUST discuss the situation and Dot with the Dot-recipient before it is read at the next All-Staff. Dots may be formally disputed; if a co-manager believes themselves undeserving of a particular Dot - for any reason – they should address the Steering Committee with concerns and the issue will be dealt with. All dots are recorded immediately after All staff and can be viewed on the “Dot” chart located on the “Critical Info” wall. 
	An “Employee of the Week” is voted on silently at each all-staff and announced at the end of all-staff. Being elected employee of the week is a great honor and the winner receives a star for their exemplary performance. 	

IV. COMMITTEE GO-AROUND
	Committee go-arounds provide an opportunity for the members of each committee to update the business on prevalent happenings. Committees report in accordance with the order they are written in on the agenda.  

	V. AGENDA 
	At this point in the meeting all discussions, proposals, elections and special presentations take place. Any sensitive or controversial proposals should be brought to the attention of the Steering Committee and facilitator beforehand.  The contents of the agenda are decided on before the meeting starts. Employees have the opportunity to add to the agenda during the week as new or old issues arise. Each agenda item should include the employee’s name, subject matter and estimated duration of discussion (see “All-Staff Roles” section titled “Timekeeper”).  Any issue that does not come to a definite resolution is placed on the Follow-Through list and on next week’s agenda for further evaluation.

	VI. CLOSING REMARKS AND FOLLOW THROUGH
	This is where any formerly forgotten items are stated and a summary of the meeting is read by the Notetaker.

Decision-Making at All-Staff
PROPOSALS
	Any co-manager or committee can submit a proposal for the business to adopt. There are two types of proposals: 

1.  Proposals entailing a specific change in CD&C policy (i.e. an amendment to the Dot policy, the expansion of a committee, etc.).  If passed, this type of proposal immediately becomes official policy and is added to the handbook.
2. 	Proposals that do not directly affect business policy. Examples include: purchasing new equipment or spending money on an expensive advertising campaign. 
(Please note that effective proposals are generally proportionate in length  and scope to the importance and/or cost of the point up for discussion).     

		The first step in the “proposal process” is to put the proposal on the agenda. At the beginning of the All-Staff meeting typed copies of the proposal should be given to each employee. The written proposal must include a title, name(s) of the proposer(s), and the date, specific reasons for the proposal, expected impact(s) on the business, expected costs (if applicable), and should name all areas of the business that would be effected.  
		*Please make sure to include a copy of the proposal in the proposal binder regardless of whether the proposal passes or fails. The proposal binder is useful for co-managers at the beginning of the proposal-writing process to reference to see what types of proposals have been introduced in the past, what passed, and what didn't fly. Much can be learned from former proposals!
DISCUSSION
	When time comes to discuss the proposal in question, the proposer(s) read the proposal aloud. The floor is then opened so that all members can ask clarifying questions or state opinions and reasons supporting those opinions. All those who want to speak should raise their hands and wait for the Stacker to call on them.  Employees should try not to be redundant, and should use the phrase “piggyback” of “second” when possible (e.g. “I piggyback what Alexa said”). The facilitator is indispensable during this discussion period. The facilitator must make sure everyone’s voice is heard, but he/she must also prevent the discussion from becoming a free-for-all, or from going around in circles.  When the facilitator feels that all points of view have been aired, he/she cuts off the discussion and should take a poll to see if the group appears ready to make a decision; if so, the facilitator calls for a vote (see below).  If, on the other hand, the group is still unsure of the proposal and/or there are some issues which still need to be cleared up, the facilitator either takes a vote to continue the discussion or puts the proposal on next week’s agenda and/or follow through list.
DECISIONS / TEST FOR CONSENSUS
	CD&C prides itself on consensus decision making. Every co-manager has an equal say in every decision. The facilitator begins the voting process by asking for those opposed to the proposal to raise their hands, followed by those who want to abstain, and those in support of a decision. In the interest of providing training and maintaining stability at CD&C, new hires are not allowed to vote for their first four All-Staffs. 
	
There are three ways to vote for a proposal using the model of consensus-based decision-making:
1. A YEA (pronounced “YAY”) is appropriate if you support the proposal in question. 
2. An abstain provides the option to abstain from voting if you do not directly oppose the proposal in question but do not feel comfortable endorsing the proposal either. Situations appropriate for an abstain include: you wrote the proposal and feel you are biased; the proposal applies to a semester in which you will no longer be a co-manager at CD&C; you feel ambivalent and cannot decide.
3. A NAY stops the proposal from moving along any further. If even one co-manager votes this way the proposal is immediately stopped and will not pass during that meeting. Once a 'nay' vote is made the co-managers discuss and decide whether the person(s) voting this way will be held accountable for preparing a counter-proposal or not. Please be aware that there is an expectation that if you vote 'nay' you are thusly prepared to write a counter-proposal, or can provide a substantial alternative. A counter-proposal is not a distinct requirement of the 'nay' vote because with this there could be the possibility of major filibustering. The point of a 'nay' vote is not to stall progress but to truly express your opinion concerning proposals. 

During a meeting the first step is to test for consensus. This entails the facilitator saying "Any opposed to the proposal as it stands?"-this is the time for 'nay' votes to raise their hands. If there are no objections then the call for abstaining votes is given, at which point abstinent co-managers raise their hands. Finally, those in favor of the proposal as it stands raise their hands. 

After the votes are counted, 'abstain' and 'nay' voters are given time to explain their reasoning. Comments should be concise. If one half or more of the co-op abstains from voting on a proposal then the co-managers will decide whether to let the proposal pass, table it, or have co-managers volunteer to write a counter-proposal to be ready by next all-staff.

If You Miss The Meeting...
Because All-Staff meetings are essential to the daily operations of our business, attendance is mandatory. However, there are certain instances in which employees are not able to make meetings for various reasons whether they are related to academics or to illnesses. Therefore, CD&C adopted the policy which allows for two absences per semester. If an employee misses more than two meetings, he or she must give specific reasons to validate the absence and may be given dots and/or called before the Steering Committee. If an employee does miss a meeting, he/she is not only responsible for reading all of the notes of the meeting, but also to confer with other employees regarding issues discussed at the meeting. If an employee is going to miss a meeting, he/she is responsible for putting their name on the agenda under “Members Absent” before the agenda is copied. This is kept track of in the Steering binder, and will also be recorded on the agenda for the meeting, which is also saved in the same binder. It is advisable that co-managers keep a record of the all-staff agendas for their personal records to refer back to from time to time as well. 

FIRST ALL STAFF MANDATORY ATTENDANCE POLICY
It is critical to CD&C that all co-managers attend the first All Staff of each semester. This meeting is mandatory, so there is a strict discipline policy for excessive tardiness for this meeting. If someone is tardy without excise, it warrants one dot for every thirty minutes late.

PART III:
COMMITTEES: THE HEART OF CD&C
Committees are integral to carrying out the various responsibilities to operate Campus Design
and Copy.  It is in committee work where employees can contribute the most to the success of
CD&C.  This is not to downplay the importance of shift work, but most employees put in more
hours doing committee work than shifts. The responsibilities of committee members include
meeting deadlines, taking on different duties, following up and reporting on these duties at all
staff, and most importantly, maintaining strong lines of communication with the customers and
the CD&C staff members.  All full-time committees must meet weekly at a designated time,
preferably outside of CD&C if the meeting time is during business hours (this is mandatory for the
steering committee). They report back their progress, ideas, decisions, proposals, etc. at each all
staff meeting during “Committee Go-Around.” During the first meeting of the semester, each
committee must create a list of long and short term goals that the committee wants to accomplish.
This list is given to Steering, who then tries to assist the different committees in fulfilling these
goals. Committee hours are paid like shift hours, and for financial reasons, membership is limited
to a certain number for each committee. Non-members may sit-in on meetings and contribute
their ideas. However, they will not be paid for this time. Committee membership is a great deal of
responsibility and should be taken seriously. For this reason, committee membership is voted on
near the end of each semester generally at an all-staff.  

COMMITTEE ELECTIONS
Elections are held at the end of each semester during an all-staff for the coming semester. The election process is run by members of the Steering Committee. Anyone can run for any committee, yet the idea of “committee continuity” is extremely important to the success of committees and CD&C as a whole.  That is, it is essential that committee membership from semester to semester overlap so that there is a smooth transfer of knowledge from older co-managers to new committee members.  Co-managers are voted onto committees for one semester at a time, with the exception of the bookkeeper, the and also the Steering, Academic and Hiring Committees, which are two semester commitments. Elections should be done at least two weeks before the end of the semester so that there is ample time to prepare, make timelines etc. for next semester. In accordance with the 1/15 policy (as it was named when 15 people were in the co-op), all first semester employees are required to be on one full-time committee, while all employees with one semester’s experience are required to serve on two committees, one of which must be designated full-time. Either Steering or the whole store will discuss the appropriate number of co-managers needed per committee and business designation if it becomes an issue. The election process is outlined on the following page.

ELECTION PROCESS
1.  Each committee is written on the board with the number of positions open listed. When the name of the committee is announced by Steering, nominations are taken. 
2.  Each employee running for a spot on the committee takes a little time to state why they are running. 
3.  If an election is contested (meaning that there are more people running than slots available), employees running for the committee must leave the room, and an open discussion on the candidates take place. When discussion is over, silent votes are taken on paper and the results are read immediately after each committee election.  This provides those people who did not make it onto a committee the opportunity to run for another committee.
4.  Committee slots that are not filled during the election process are reopened during the beginning of the coming semester and this process is repeated on a smaller scale.  Empty positions are usually filled by new employees.
	
Again, no one will be banned from a committee. If an employee does not make it by election and stills want to participate, they should feel free to attend meetings. However, they will not be paid for that time because they are not officially on the committee. 
	
Certain committees have a two semester commitment; those are BOSB and Steering. After two semesters of committee work have been completed an employee may be reelected onto the committee but must be reelected for each semester following. New hires are limited to certain committees.  

ACADEMIC COMMITTEE
4/5 ELECTED MEMBERS (IDEALLY WITH 2 RETURNING MEMBERS)
 The main goal of the Academic committee is to orchestrate the production of academic packets. It all starts with talking to professors and getting their copies of what they would like the packets to be. If their packets have material that is copyrighted, it is the duty of a lovely member or two of the committee to procure the needed rights from Copyright.com. The professor then signs off on a proof of the packet, and the packet is printed and priced using the CD&C packet pricing template. This committee requires co-managers with good communication skills, willingness to talk on the phone, through, email, and in person with (oftentimes) persnickety professors, and an interest in copyright procedure. People on academic must also be prepared to deal with unjamming machines and willing to spend a substantial amount of time in the store making packets during that infamous period of time at the start of each semester called “Rush”. There is a fair amount of academic packet work done over the summer and winter as well, so someone with an open schedule and availability to come into the store during break would be ideal for a position within this committee. 

For the future academic hopes to evolve, and include printed course notes and professor powerpoint print-outs for sale to students in large lecture classes.

BOARD OF STUDENT BUSINESSES

1.	Attendance is crucial at BOSB meetings and each member is required to attend every meeting.

BUSINESS COMMITTEE

Each co-manager must have a hand in the Business committee in some way, shape, or form. There are specific "Business" roles designated to individual co-managers and passed on like committee roles (but require more wisdom and training from generation to generation). They are as follows:

Bookkeeper
	Bookkeepers keep financial records that track Campus Design and Copy’s expenditures, profit and loss, and cash flow-in sum, the numerous financial activities of the business. The bookkeeper. Usually works in conjunction with the Business’ Consultant for the accounting departments of their companies. Bookkeepers employ database (in our case named the “Vendor Ledger” and spreadsheet computer programs (in our case, “QuickBooks” to do their record keeping.)
	There exists one bookkeeper at CD&C, also called the “full-chargeaweseomelybubbly” bookkeeper. The bookkeeper verifies and enters in the ledgers the details of the Business’ financial transactions. In addition, he or she has the task of summarizing these details in a general ledger. Periodically, the bookkeeper balances the books. When the books are balanced, it is possible to tell ata  glance how much cash has been spent and how much has been received, what the company owes and what is owed to the company, and whether the company has made a profit or suffered a loss. This facilitates monthly reconciliation, and budget analysis presented monthly to the Business by the Consultant. In addition to keeping records, the bookkeeper may issue monthly invoice statements. 
	Bookkeepers perform general accounting duties. They maintain complete sets of financial records, keep track of accounts and verify the accuracy of procedures used for recording financial transactions. They are employed by private businesses, governments, and virtually every other type of institution. As a bookkeeper, you perform a variety of duties. You prepare, control, balance, and check various accounts using standard bookkeeping methods. You enter daily financial transactions in a journal either manually or by computer. You also maintain general ledgers recording the status of various accounts and make sure that all the accounts balance. You also balance the ledgers and prepare financial statements. In order to verify the accuracy of computerized and manual accounting and record-keeping systems you may be asked to perform an audit. In addition you may be expected to prepare statistical, financial, accounting, or auditing reports. There is considerable job mobility in this field since many different types of establishments have need of bookkeeping services. In addition, the need for a focused and accurate bookkeeper at CD&C is key to keeping our business running efficiently and in a sustainable manner. 

Bulletin Boards
	After the constant need for someone to keep the boards updated and clean, the bulletin board manager position was assign in the spring of 2008. Responsibilities of this position are to keep an up to date record of who is renting space and how much space was purchased. Keeping the board attractive and neat is an ongoing job also. 
	While keeping students as a target market, the bulletin board manager should also be exploring the various options for advertisers that are off-campus. 

Cash-Out
Cash-out is an important role in the business. It is necessary for the understanding of how the business is doing financially. 
Requirements/Duties:
1. Update the Quickbook ledger, Daily Sales Report, and Discrepancy ledgers weekly.
2. Meet weekly with the CSB consultant to work out any problems regarding the ledger, and anything regarding cash-out. 
3. Report daily deposit amounts to the group as wella s significant cash-out discrepancies when needed at All-Staff. 
4. Ensire that deposits are madder on a daily basis by instructing other employees on the procedure for cash-out, deposit drop-off, and bag pick-up. 
5. Enter deposits, sales tracking, and discrepancies in the CSB’s Excel cash-out spreadsheet. This is due by the 7th of each month, or CD&C will incur a $50.00 fine. 

Departmental Billing
The Department Biller is responsible for facilitating payment for work done for departments on campus. (Note: The Departmental Biller cannot concurrently be a member of the flyering committee.) The first most important step in the whole process in Departmental Billing is getting Recharge Authorization Forms filled out. These files allow CD+C’s biller to bill a department at the end of each month. We cannot do anything without these forms, or with them filled out incompletely. First and foremost, we need the department’s name and the date. The speed key, department ID and fund code are also necessary for the procedure. The account # is typically 734300, unless they specify otherwise. This is a code referencing work within the university that is photocopy related. Also we need to know the authorized name, printed and in signiture form, along with their email and a phone number for contact purposes. Also on this form, you will see a section for CD+C’s information (name, sk, ID, etc.) which should be filled out already. ‘Payment To’ and ‘Payment From’ distinguish these sections. 

Unlike the RSO Billing process, these transactions authorize us to bill up to a certain amount (specified on the Recharge Authorization Form), so they still have a ‘debit account’. Every transaction goes into the “Departmental Cash Out” spread sheet on the computer, as well as in the miniwedge, as a ‘DEPT SALE’. It is important to do these for each and every transaction, even a recharge received (though this isn’t in the miniwedge). 

Weekly, the Biller should ideally split the main spreadsheet into the individual tabs that are allocated on another excel file in the ‘departmental billing’ folder.

Monthly, it is up to the Biller to bring the information into the CSB office. Log into the computers and find the ‘’Billing Log’’ as well as the actual billing spreadsheet, which Donna sends out to be processed. The log should have rows for each department, along with columns for their information and monthly spending and Recharge balances. It will also total monthly and annually what we receive or a department spends, respectively. For each speed key received one should add a line to the billing log, even if the department repeats their name.

The main file cannot be altered by anyone but someone who knows what they’re doing. i.e. the Biller shouldn’t edit the file, only should enter information into it. Each column is assigned specific numbers of characters that one cannot exceed or go under without their being an error. For instance, the column for speed key is 6 characters, because the university speed keys are 6 digits. Makes sense. Do not alter any of the formatting or order of columns on this spreadsheet. It may get a little hairy to understand, but it is sometimes helpful to look back at a past-month’s completed sheet for a reference. Some hints: the line that says “CD+C” includes also the department being billed’s information (sk, ID, acct), whereas the complementary line with the department’s name has all of CD+C’s information. Be sure not to save over the blank spreadsheet, each time you start a new one, SAVE AS something different such as “MM YY Billing”

Send the billing log and the monthly billing spreadsheet to Amy.

Betterment of the Biller’s Role: A Former Departmental Biller’s Manifesto
Although the computer system developed in 2006 is much better than the older style which no one reading this will remember, it does have it’s flaws. For instance, the individual department tabs do not account for recharges where it shows a balance. To account for this, I’ve been crediting Recharges as a positive transaction, and the work done, or jobs sold as negative transactions. This keeps the balance accurate. This poses a problem for the Daily Reconciliation however, because when a job is performed and deducted as a negative, and perhaps a Recharge was credited on the same date, the daily transaction totals will not match those on the Sales Report off the Miniwedge. This is because what are entered in the Miniwedge is only the jobs performed. This doesn’t occur for RSO tabs because of how Recharges are entered. 
Many Departments are clueless as to the paperwork behind having copies made and billed to their account. Some know and will have their forms ready when they want to start their account. This is Public Health, Center for Public Policy and Admin and others. It is important we receive the Recharge forms on time because otherwise it will be difficult to get the money we deserve. It is important to educate the departments on the process. I like to emphasize when presenting and introducing a Recharge Authorization Form two important fundamental things. First, the amount they Authorize is simply permission to be billed up to that amount. For instance, Public Health makes their tests with us frequently. I like to get an initial recharge for a large sum, so as to avoid having to get more Forms filled out later in the Fiscal Year. It is important to say this is not deducted from their account, but it simply authorizes us to do the necessary monthly billing. They will see the transaction on a statement of their account. Secondly, the amount transfers from fall to spring semesters, ie. over a fiscal year. This is important because it is beneficial to open a large amount to avoid paperwork for the entire year! I always ask, “Is this a one-time job, or do you foresee coming for more copies this year?” This is a good lead into getting a large balance to start a year off. It wouldn’t hurt to e-mail departments in the summer about this way to have access to our services over the course of the coming academic year. The Athletic Department, for instance has student-athlete receive course packets on their account. They should be notified that if this is the case they should open an account in September to work off of the next two semesters. Ideally, the Biller should have to get Recharge Authorization Forms in September only. That would be nice. 
In Spring 2008, I was told that it might be the case that the Biller will enter monthly transactions into Quick Books as well. This is a very good idea because the amount in Quick Books, which our CSB Consultant presents montly in reports is seldom what is actually received for the month. This has to do with the discrepancies in the Daily Recon as well as work being done which isn’t entered in the Miniwedge for whatever reasons. The numbers on the consultant’s reports are currently entered into QB by either the Cashout or Bookkeeping Co-Manager, but having the Biller enter this would make the numbers in reports consistent to actual money making. 
In sum, the role of the Biller is a monthly job which could take less than 2 hours when everything through the month is done correctly, ie. getting Recharge forms filled in completely and promptly. Educating departments and Co-Managers is crucial towards success! The spreadsheets are scary, but easy to get used to and when one is familiar enough it becomes simpler and friendlier

Maintenance
The goal of the maintenance co-manager is keep a constant eye on how clean the store is. It is also their job to get rid of toner boxes that pile up, cartridges that must be recycled specially, and figuring out how to get rid of old eqipment that cannot simply be put in the trash. Ideally once every month or so the maintenance co-manager would come into the store on a weekend and do a major clean-up of the store-this includes dusting, washing windows, sweeping, etc. This can be a big job, and they definitely don’t need to do it alone! But it is this co-manager’s responsibility to organize and spearhead a major store clean-up day if one is needed, which includes bringing it up at All-Staff. 
Payroll
Payroll is an integral part of the Business Committee. The Payroll supervisor must monitor and track all weekly payroll expenditures by Campus Design & Copy. He/she must attempt to keep payroll at an appropriate and consistent level, and communicate this information to the All-Staff. 


REQUIREMENTS & DUTIES
The payroll supervisor must consistently stock the pay sheets. Additionally, a record with all the employees’ names and pay period must be prepared each week, and can be filled out in the payroll binder. 
Payroll must be completed by Friday afternoon. The payroll supervisor must make sure all employees of CD&C have filled out the pay sheet for the week. Those who have not will forfeit their pay until the next pay period. Names, hours worked, and the dates must be recorded. Also the hours must be added up and compared to a breakdown of hours. Make sure all numbers match and if they do not, fix them. If all parts of the payslip are not filled out or not filled out correctly, the employee forfeits their pay until the next pay period. Be sure to check the dates, account numbers, and all other aspects of the pay slips for accuracy. 
When hours are incomplete or un-submitted the payroll supervisor is responsible for submitting “late pay”. The week in which the hours were actually worked must be updated in the excel payroll spreadsheet and an adjustment transaction must be entered into Quickbooks for that week. 
It is the payroll Supervisor’s responsibility to sign-off on the current pay sheet and to have another member from the Business Committee to sign-off on their spot on the pay sheet. Also, an up to date copy of the week’s pay sheet should be kept in the payroll binder. 
Record all information on the CSB excel payroll spreadsheet. Print two copies, put one in the payroll binder on the bookeeper’s desk and place one copy in the CD&C folder at CSB for the accountant.

Purchaser
The person holding this position is responsible for providing Campus Design and Copy with the necessary amounts of supplies in order for the business to run smoothly and without delays.  The supplies include all paper, design, office, and binding supplies. The purchaser must maintain appropriate levels of all supplies and paper; the business should not have too much money invested in inventory. The purchaser for CD&C is also responsible for taking inventory of all the supplies each month. 

REQUIREMENTS & DUTIES 
	• The purchaser is responsible for the store’s Procard. The Procard is a Mastercard with a $5000.00 monthly/$500.00 daily limit, used for all supply and minor equipment purchases. Every month the purchaser must pick up the pro-card statement from Donna Vanasse’s desk in the CSB. ONLY THE HASER IS AUTHORIZED TO USE THE PROCARD UNDER ANY CIRCUMSTANCES!

		The Procard is our primary method of ordering supplies. If the Procard is unavailable or otherwise not usable for a particular vendor, a Purchase Order must be opened with the vendor. 
	
CD&C currently has purchase orders (P.O.’s) with these two companies for supplies in case the Procard cannot be used:
			       
Océ - copy supplies, service on the copiers. (Supplies should be ordered in bulk to save money - usually once per semester.)
	
	WB MN - office supplies
* Note: When ordering all supplies, be open to new companies with lower prices/bulk order discounts. This involves doing a little checking around for prices. 

	NOTES FOR THE PURCHASER
	• After getting the new list of P.O.’s and account numbers for each business, a list should be made and copies are kept in the purchaser’s desk and on the wall next to the phone.
	• At the beginning of every semester it is very important that we keep an over abundance of paper in the store. At least 10 cases of white paper should be order by the end of the first week of classes. This will ensure that all academic packets can be produced without running out of paper. 
	• When ordering from any company, be sure to have the Procard or CD&C’s account number and P.O. number ready.
	• Have a list ready in front of you (the Purchasing LOG) with all of the order numbers, or descriptions, and quantities of what you want to buy. 

	RE-ORDERING PAPER
	• You will know when to re-order paper after you get a feel for what paper is popular and what does not sell.  Always try to sell old stock whenever it is appropriate, for example: in big jobs where the people do not care too much about which color is used. The danger of ordering paper that does not sell well is that it goes bad by drying out, discoloring, and rippling. Here is rough guide of when to reorder paper.

Regular white paper - Always order in large quantities for bulk discount. (Usually when the supply runs down to about 5 cases you can re-order anywhere between 10-12 cases except during rush where a larger store of paper will be needed. 
c
Colored text - This paper is purchased from WB Mason and can be ordered by the box.  Order when less than 4 reams remain, or a large job with a certain color of paper must be done/has just been completed. 

Colored cover - Same as above (Additional reams of cover paper will be needed during rush for academic packets)

Bond paper - This is ordered from WB Mason and can be purchased by the ream or box. It can be popular for large orders due to the fact that it costs less than text overall.  

11x17 paper – This paper has a low inventory turnover; one ream may last the entire semester. 
		
	• When re-ordering paper, make sure to specify the manufacturer, the name of the paper, the poundage (lb.), the size of the paper, the color, and the quantity (of cases, not reams).

	INVENTORY
The purchaser must take inventory on the last day of each month. Inventory sheets can be found in the Inventory log book on the Purchaser’s desk. Take last month’s computer print-out inventory form and make a photocopy of it. Use this photocopy as a check list for inventory. This way you can see how much paper we went through color by color, type by type glance.
Go through and fill out the sheets checking all the supplies in CD&C carefully.  This is important in finding out if you are spending too much and keeping us too stocked up. Usually, you can also ignore doing inventory on the small office supplies such as staples, pens, paper clips, etc.
Go to the Center for Student Businesses and enter the inventory onto CD&C’s file marked “inventory in Excel. Be sure to update changes within inventory (i.e. price changes, new paper used, paper no longer used, etc.).
After the inventory has been entered onto our disk, print out two copies. Give one copy to the CSB consultant and place the second in the inventory log book. This must be done by the 7th of each month or CD&C will incur a $50 fine.

As of 2008 a new system is in an attempted implementation period in which the inventory is taken and kept track of electronically. This is a good-system-in-the-making because items in the inventory will be kept more relevant as items in the store change, the sheet will be easily edited/adjusted/transferred, and accounting for objects in-store will be easier and more powerfully done with a spreadsheet. 

The hopes for this new system will be that it happens (the recording process) as orders are received or within the same week, so that these benefits are multiplied by their time-relevance. Also, by keeping account of how often we order certain things each month, we can trim the number of orders we make, making the process more efficient.

RSO Billing
