STEERING COMMITTEE
4-5 ELECTED MEMBERS  The Steering committee steers the business. This includes the formerly separate committees of Stars and Dots, Hiring and Training, and DVals. Steering meets once a week (usually after all-staff) to go over their own goals and deal with issues of dot disputes, scheduling, and the like. 

REQUIREMENTS & DUTIES
Chart a course for the group. This is done by discussing long-term and short-term goals among members and then proposing with the groups.  Such goals may lie within the domain of other Committees (such as getting X number of packets for the next semester), or may pertain to the entire group. 
Guide other committees in their semester goals. This involves being in communication with all committees and being aware of their semester goals and making sure committees follow through with these goals.  Steering should provide avenues for conflict resolution within and between the other committees.  It should also play a role in evaluating each Committee's performance. Therefore, if the members of Steering feel that a particular committee is unorganized and inefficient, they have the responsibility to help in the re-organization and restructuring of the committee in question.  One way to guide committees in reaching their goals is to have steering members visit committees. 
Inform the group of upcoming events.  Steering members should be aware of important events and dates (i.e. Facilitation Workshop, next semester’s first All-Staff, University schedules, etc.) throughout the semester and communicate them to the All-Staff.
Be aware of events and University actions that affect CD&C. This includes anything having to do with space allocation, SGA issues, the CSB, etc...Steering members should either attend the relevant meetings or ensure that another CD&Cer attends and reports back to the group.  Steering must be in constant communication with the CSB and CD&C’s representatives on the Board of Student Businesses.
Give dots to employees. The Committee must also read through the Discrepancy Book for any occurrences during the week that need to be discussed or may deserve dots. Steering keeps track of each employee’s dots in the Star/Dot notebook. 
Dot challenges. Employees can challenge their dots at the Steering committee meeting.  There is a strong recommendation to put a time restriction of two weeks after the dots are given for dot challenges.  If a decision made by the Steering committee is refuted by an employee, the issue will be brought to All-Staff.
Contracts.  Once any employee has received three dots, he/she will be called to Steering committee to be placed on contract.  All-Staff will be notified when an employee is put on contract. 
Enforce the Dot Policy, including contracts, performance evaluations and firing.  (See sections on Dots, Probation and Firing for specifics.) 
Stars. The Star system should be analogous to the Dot system.  There should be a Star log that employees can write in when they feel another employee has done a job well or is deserving of recognition.  The Steering committee should take these recommendations and award Stars as it sees fit.
Employee of the Week. Ballots should be distributed after weekly stars have been announced so that employees will know who went above and beyond that week and can let that inform their voting.  Ballots will be collected and tallied by Steering and the outcomes announced each week. 
Making All-Staff aware of employees Star/Dot tally. In a collective environment it is important that every manager has free and easy access to their fellow employees’ (as well as their own) performance records.  Steering should announce Stars and Dots accrued each week on the black board.  A board should be put up in the store so that all the employees will know how they and their co-managers are performing.  
Scheduling Evaluations and Diversity events. Every semester CD&C has a night where each co-manager is evaluated. It is the job of Steering to inform the co-op when that night will be so the co-managers are able to fill out the Evals binder in time for the Evaluation night. Diversity events are a time when the co-managers are able to get out of the store and have fun together. The co-managers can decide what they want to do, but Steering should be the committee to be looking ahead at when that event can take place.

In the spring of 1997, a Star/Dot Committee was created to take over Steering’s responsibility to dot employees and to enforce the dot policy.  In addition to this it was Star/Dot’s responsibility to establish an incentive program to go along with employee of the week.  However, the committee was soon abolished because it was deemed extraneous.  If at some point, however, if Steering’s responsibilities become too great, the Star/Dot committee may be re-instated. 

HIRING 
To recruit, select, and hire qualified, enthusiastic, and dedicated individuals that suit the needs of CD&C in each hiring cycle.  To train employees on all aspects of the business and to help them better their manual, teamwork, and customer service skills.

“Hiring shapes the future of CD&C.” The importance of this committee can not be underestimated because its members single-handedly determine the direction the business will take in the future. The Hiring Committee is responsible for the hiring of all new CD&C employees at the beginning of each semester. If the committee does a poor job and does not hire qualified individuals, the business will suffer in the long run.  Next to interviewing and selecting applicants, the most important responsibility of the Hiring members is to recruit as many applicants as possible (the more applicants we have, the more choice we have in selecting the best employees).  This recruiting is done primarily through flyering all over campus, posting a listing on UMass’ “Job & Careers” website under “Student Employment,” and passing out applications to RSO groups. The committee should reflect the make-up of the collective. 

REQUIREMENTS & DUTIES 
	The hiring process should resemble the following:	
1.	The committee should evaluate the need for new employees at the end of every semester.   The committee must know who is coming back to work at CD&C, and who will not be returning. From this evaluation, an outline of the ideal employee(s) should be developed (i.e. a need for designers, business oriented persons, sophomores preferred, etc.). A proposal should be presented to All-Staff encompassing the Hiring Committee’s plan, detailing how many and what type of employees to hire.
2.	Review last semester’s application and make any applicable changes (the dates on the timeline must be changed) before making a master copy. Set an interview date and reserve a  room for interview dates and times. Make copies of the application packet and display them on the front counter and also outside the CSB. Keep track of how many copies of the application are made.
3.	During the designated hiring time, in coordination with the Design Committee, flyers should be posted advertising that “CD&C is hiring for ...” stating that applications can be picked up at CD&C.  These colorful flyers should be posted all over campus. This flyering is extremely important to the success of Hiring; if the campus is not blanketed with flyers, the number of applicants won’t be as high. 
4.  A strong effort needs to be made to recruit applicants from diverse backgrounds. This is where the Hiring Committee must work in conjunction with members of the Diversity Committee. This recruiting is done predominantly by advertising our employment openings to specifics groups (i.e. New Africa House, the Native American floor in Chadbourne Hall, AASA, etc.), but any new methods should certainly be attempted.
5.	Put all returned applications in one spot and ask other employees to comment on their employability on the back of each application. This gives non-committee members a chance to participate in the hiring of their future co-workers.
6.	Review and grade each application, perhaps using an application rating sheet.  The committee should plan to interview approximately 3 times the number of employee being hired. So, if the committee determines that CD&C needs 3 new employees, 9 applicants should be interviewed.
7.	After deciding who to interview, these applicants should be called and scheduled for interview times at around 20 minute intervals.
8.   Call references for selected applicants if more information is needed. 
9.	Interview selected applicants and rate perhaps using an interview rating sheet.
10.	Make the decision of who to hire. Make sure to refer back to the description of the “ideal employee(s)” for that semester. It is helpful to keep in mind what you will be losing with graduating co-managers, and what you think the business needs in order to sustain itself.
11. Call all those who were interviewed, and state whether or not they were hired. Remind the new employees of the training session and the first All-Staff.  Select two or three alternates in case those you want to hire change their mind.
12. Schedule appropriate times to train the new employees while on-shift. These are called star shifts, and will be marked by a star on the new schedule that should be posted for the whole store to see. The new employees will attend their first All-Staff on the following Monday, even if their first star-shift isn’t until later.  	
13.  Meet with new employees roughly 4 weeks after they have been hired to discuss the hiring process and their assimilation into the business.  This should hopefully lead to some new insight on how the process can be improved.

Rules for Acquaintance Hiring
•	You may read through the application.
•	You may be involved in the interview process.
•	You can give necessary data relating to commitment, another job, or something related to work relations based on factual information.  The information must be pertinent.
•	You may not give purely personal, biased opinions.
•	Before the interview process you may only say that you know the person. Do not give any opinions at this time.

Co-Manager Equity Policy
	When making schedules Steering tries to balance hours by working with the existing school schedules of each co-manager. If there is a problem with too many/too little hours, that co-manager should talk to Steering, and it will be worked out in the easiest way possible. Rush schedule will be different from the actual solid semester schedule, and typically it takes a few weeks to work out the kinks. This is different in practice from the original 1/15 policy, but in spirit it is the same. 
	In the beginning of the semester each co-manager is expected to attend the first All-Staff and help with Night Copy. This is a big job due to beginning of the year fliers and academic packets galore, and it is a less scary job if everyone helps out. If there is a problem with a co-manager getting to the first All-Staff the co-managers should be notified a week prior. The store has an email and a phone, and each co-manager has email and a phone as well-there is no excuse for not letting people know in a timely manner that you will be unable to attend. Failure to give proper notification will result in that person having to talk to Steering and possibly being put on contract. Of course, it is always on a case-by-case basis, and emergencies happen.

DOTS, PROBATION AND FIRING
CD&C’s Dot System is the business’ means of tracking employee problems with lateness, missed meetings and follow-through.  When Steering gives an employee a dot, they are representing the entire collective in this decision. Co-managers are not accountable to the Steering Committee; they are accountable to each other. This is why dots are announced at each All-Staff, so that everyone is aware of any personnel problems occurring in the business. Hence, if and when an employee is put on contract or brought up for firing, the entire group will have been aware of the employee’s situation beforehand. When an employee is late to, or misses, a shift, an All-Staff meeting or a committee meeting, he/she has the responsibility to fill out the Dot Log sheet listed under their name. Company etiquette and honesty dictates that employees write down any such occurrences immediately.  They should be as descriptive as possible when writing reasons for their offense so that the Steering Committee can determine if it should be excused. If the employee does not note their offense, it is the responsibility of others to remind the CD&Cer to fill out the log or do so themselves.

OBTAINING DOTS
The Steering Committee has the final say over whether or not an employee will receive a dot(s).  At each Steering meeting, the members look through the “Dot Book,” and the “Discrepancy Book.”  If the members feel that an employee deserves to be “dotted” for something that he/she did, or did not do, during the week, the committee will give the employee the specified number of dots for the offense. By specifying the number of dots per offense (i.e. lateness, skipping shift, etc.), the policy treats each employee fairly. In other words, members of Steering will not receive special treatment since the number of dots for each offense is spelled out. However, the Steering Committee reserves the right to increase or decrease the number of dots when the committee members feel that there are special circumstances involved.  Please note that an employee is given a dot only when the Steering Committee feels that there is no valid excuse for the offense. For example, sleeping past your shift is not a valid excuse; having a death in the family is a valid excuse.  In any event, if an employee is going to miss a shift, he/she must call all co-workers and try to get the shift covered as early as possible.  If an employee obtains a dot and feels that he/she has a valid excuse, he/she may petition the committee to remove the dot. In order to petition, the “dotted” employee must contact a member of the Steering Committee within 1 week of the All-Staff meeting in which the dot was announced and then come before the committee.

On the next two pages you will find CD&C’s current Dot Policy.  Here each dottable offense is outlined clearly so that each member receives the same consequence.  This policy is reviewed and revised every semester by Steering so that it always pertains to the way that CD&C operates.  
Campus Design and Copy Dot Policy
This policy's purpose is to ensure that each co-manager fulfills his/her objectives and responsibilities while remaining focused on the cooperative ideals of our beloved CD&C. The giving of a dot for any infraction listed below is necessary in order to improve our competence as a business.  Steering will be available and plans to cooperatively assist all co-managers who choose to contest any dot. Discretion is allowed if a co-manager feels that a dot is deserved for an infraction not listed below.  This list will be amended as necessary throughout the semester.


1. Late over 10 minutes without a call 						1 dot 
2. Late over 10 minutes with a call							½ dot

4. No show for shift with a call							1 dot
5. Incomplete or no order form							1 dot
6. Mishandling Jobs (i.e.: user error resulting in sub-par job)			1-2 dots

9. Messing up cash out								½ dot
10.  No deposit							          	 1 do to openers
11. Not adding increases								1 dot

PROBATION
	Once an employee obtains 5 dots, he/she will be called before the next Steering meeting (usually held Friday afternoons). When an employee is “called before Steering,” it is announced at All-Staff and a written notice is placed in the employee’s mailbox stating the date and time of the meeting.  At the meeting between the CD&Cer and Steering, the employee will have an opportunity to address the reasons for their dots. At this time, the Steering Committee can decide whether or not to put the employee on probation. If the employee is not put on probation, he/she will be given a warning. If the problem persists, the employee will be called before Steering again and put on probation and a contract will be drawn up. If the committee decides that the employee should be placed on probation, he/she will be notified immediately. This probationary period lasts 3 weeks. The employee promises to address their behavior in this period and attempt to improve.

Performance Review
	If an employee obtains 5 dots in a single semester, they are brought before the co-op for review. Steering will review the dots accrued by the co-manager in question, and the co-manager will have a chance to explain the reasons for their dots. The group will then discuss the co-manager’s performance while they step outside of the meeting. Their offenses should be carefully weighed against the co-manager’s assets to the business. A vote will be held to fire the employee after all discussion. A simple majority in favor of termination is all that is required to terminate the employee. Should the employee’s job be spared, they go back to 3 dots, the “warning” margin for performance. 

	If and when an employee is fired, the Steering Committee is responsible for deciding whether or not a replacement should be hired.  If the committee determines that it is not necessary, then the terminated employee’s shifts are covered by the rest of the group (This also applies if an employee quits mid-semester).

Post firing policy
In the event a Co-manager is brought up for firing under the dot policy but is not fired, the following procedure should be followed:
The co-manager in question is still considered to be under contract, but of a more serious nature.
They go back to 3 dots, the “warning” margin for performance. Any further dots accrued mandate an immediate meeting between the co-manager in question and the steering committee.
At this meeting, steering will determine if the is significant enough to initiate a new firing procedure for this co-manager at the next possible All-Staff.

EVALUATIONS
Evaluations, commonly referred to as “Evals,” are an event held after all-staff mid-way through each semester. Evals are a chance for every CD&Cer to evaluate themselves, their co-workers, and even the collective as a whole. Evals are an extremely important part of the group’s development and all employees are required to attend.  Often times, many new ideas come from Evals and the group becomes re-energized for the second half of the semester. Evals is purposely held half-way through the semester so that employees may see their weak spots and have a chance to improve on them before the end of the term. This time should be seen as a chance to give feedback to co-workers in addition to (not instead of) the day to day feedback that is sweetly given.  That is, if a CD&Cer has a problem with a co-worker, he/she should not keep their gripes bottled-up until Evals; the employees should work out their personal differences beforehand.  Many first semester employees do not know what to expect, nor do they understand the significance and seriousness of Evals until that very day. Therefore, such employees should review this section of the handbook before filling out the Evals binder. The following is a description of the Evals process:

Steering proposes a date for the event within the few weeks of the start of each semester. This is so that everyone may clear their calendars and not have any conflicts on the selected date. 
Before this date it is each co-manager's responsibility to go to the Evals binder and fill out information for their own self-evaluation and for each co-manager that they have direct contact with on a regular basis. Each co-manager has one self evaluation page with an attached page for positive comments and one page for constructive criticism, separated by tabs. There is also a page to comment on the collective as a whole. Please fill this binder out in a quiet place where you can reflect honestly about what you write. 
At the designated Evals day after All-Staff each co-manager gets handed their positive and constructive comment sheets. Co-managers have the option to directly respond to their received comments. This is also the time where co-managers raise their hands to say things directly to this co-manager. 
Co-manager discuss the comments about the collective as a whole, pat each other on the back about the good onse and come up with ideas to deal with problems.

GUIDELINES FOR USEFUL FEEDBACK
Please keep the following guidelines in mind as you fill out your written evals and when you give verbal feedback to co-workers throughout the semester.

1. Describe behavior that you observe, rather than stating interpretations or conclusions you draw from the other’s behavior. E.g. “When I come to talk to you about customer complaints, you sigh loudly and roll your eyes,” rather than, “You have a bad attitude towards the customers.”
2. Be specific rather than general. To be told that “You are sexist,” is probably not as useful as to be told “At All-Staff you frequently interrupt me and other women in the room and you reject proposals from me and other women until a man speaks in favor of them.”
3. Take into account the needs of the receiver of your feedback. It could be destructive if it serves only your own needs, (e.g. to vent frustration). Let the other person keep their self-esteem as intact as possible.
4. Don’t overwhelm the other person with data.  The receiver of your feedback needs time to absorb it. The longer you go on, the less the other person will hear, and the more defensive he/she will become.
5. Check your timing. In general, feedback is most useful at the earliest opportunity after a particular event or behavior, (depending, of course, on the other person’s readiness to hear it and support from others).
6. Check to ensure clear communication. Ask the receiver for her understanding of your feedback.
7. Use the formula for constructive criticism:
When you _________, I feel ________, because ________ .
(Carolee Cloture, Community Consulting Group, 1987)


PERSONNEL/BUSINESS POLICIES
EMPLOYMENT POLICY
Campus Design and Copy is an Equal Opportunity Employer. The business aims to have its employees represent the diverse backgrounds and lifestyles that exist in the Umass community. All full-time Umass undergraduates are eligible for employment.
RETURN POLICY
CD&C employees are required to attend the first All Staff of each semester or make contact with the group prior to it. Failure to do so will is grounds for firing for any employee not meeting this requirement.  See Co-manager Equity Policy for early semester requirements.
QUITTING POLICY
In the event that a co-manager decides that he/she wants to quit the business, he/she is obligated to submit a formal memo informing the collective of his/her impending departure and present it at All-Staff. It is then required that the co-manager retain their duties and responsibilities to the collective for at least two weeks following the official declaration of departure. This policy is applicable primarily to those co-managers wishing to quit after the hiring period but before the very end of the semester. 

Please note, this is not a substitute for a co-manager fulfilling his/her two semester commitment to the collective; it should not be viewed as a “loophole” to offer an easy out of a commitment to CD&C that was explicitly outlined and agreed upon by the co-manager prior to employment.

RE-HIRING FORMER EMPLOYEES	
At times, employees leave the business only to return after a semester or two.  This is most common when students study abroad or take time off from the University.  Those employees who left the business in good standing (“good standing” = not on probation, not being fired) and have been gone from CD&C for only one semester are automatically re-hired.  Those employees who are gone from CD&C for more than one semester must file an application, but they are automatically interviewed during the regular hiring period (i.e. first 3 weeks of the semester).  In the process of re-hiring former employees, members of the Hiring Committee should feel free to consult with co-workers who have worked with the employee in question to get further information.  It is the Hiring Committee’s responsibility to re-acquaint re-hired employees with the business (i.e. new policies, new employees, etc.).  Whenever possible, those employees who are leaving the business should indicate whether or not they intend to return.  
EMPLOYEES AND MONEY AT CD&C
Employees have liberty over everything they do at CD&C, yet with this liberty come a great deal of responsibility.  This is especially true when it comes to employees and money.  We must all rely on the honor system when dealing with the finances of the business - cashing out the register, filling out pay slips, making purchases, etc.
Discounts:  Co-managers receive discounts on copies; they may purchase copies at cost.   Co-managers may use the company’s computers free of charge, but this privilege should not be abused (i.e. letting friends use the computers, excessive use, doing outside jobs, etc.).  However, CD&C work is the priority.
Employee credit:  There is no employee credit; co-managers cannot borrow money from the business.
Employee pay rates:  As of January 2008 the state-wide minimum wage was set to $8.00/hour. Pay raises will not be disregarded all together; the current solution has the sole purpose of  allowing enough time so that CD&C can proficiently, and effectively adapt to this weighty change in finances.  
How to get paid:  CD&C employees are paid bi-monthly through the University with money from the business’ account.  In order to get paid, each employee must fill out their hours for the week on a timesheet. This slip must be filled out completely by Friday at a time selected at the Payroll person’s discretion. The total hours cannot exceed 40 hours per week and no more than 8 hours per day. It is the responsibility of each employee (and not the Payroll person) to fill out the slip properly and on time, or else he/she won’t get paid until the next pay period. Not filling out a weekly slip throws off the financial books and makes it inconvenient for the payroll person as well as Donna, who processes payroll for the student business. 

NEW EMPLOYEES POLICY (THREE WEEK GRACE PERIOD)
New employees often feel a little lost or confused in their first two months at CD&C. This is ok! And it gets better, we promise. Not only do they have to learn how to run the copiers, the cash register, the computers, the fax machine, etc., but they must also learn how the business is run.  Very few new employees are familiar with the idea of collective management, and it is often difficult for them to find their niche in the business.  In an effort to facilitate this transition into CD&C, the “New Employees Policy” was created in the fall of 1995.  It dictates that all new employees must visit one Steering Committee meeting and one meeting of another committee of their choosing (a committee of which they are not a member) within a month of being hired.  The new employees are paid for the length of each meeting.  Furthermore in the fall of 2006, the co-managers at CD&C decided upon a “Three Week Grace Period” as an illustration of a co-op trial period.  This trial phase includes two weeks consisting of star shifts, during which new hires observe and learn as much possible of the business from existing co-managers.  The third week is dedicated to the personal improvement of each new hires.  Members of the Steering Committee also use this last week to meet with each new hire to get a sense of their acclimatization to the store.  The three week grace period also allows any new hire to leave the business if he/she fells any signs of discomfort (whether in the particulars, commitment of a co-op, or the overall milieu of the business).  “If existing co-managers feel that a new hire is not right for the store then it needs to be brought up first with steering, and steering will bring it to all staff formally.  At all staff the store will be informed of the events and feelings in this matter and the termination of the new-hire will be out to a vote” (Hiring and Training Proposal, fall 2006).      

Training
Everyone will be training new co-managers in order to make sure that each person in the store is fully knowledgeable of the responsibilities pertaining to their respective jobs.  When a problem or question arises, they should assist the employee in obtaining a proper re-training. Employees must be aware of their responsibilities so that they know what is expected of them.  CD&C employees must be trained efficiently and thoroughly in all aspects of daily procedure including the following: opening, closing, night copy, night design, policy and other various procedures. 


To provide a full-scale training to new employees immediately after they have been hired. This training should include all store procedures, with particular focus on the cash register, computers, pricing policy and the copiers. Part V:
BUSINESS AND FINANCE

If We Are Not-For-Profit, 
Why Do We  To Make A Profit?
CD&C is a “not-for-profit” organization.  Unlike most other business, we are not in business to make a profit.  Yet, we must still budget (meaning set prices and wages) to make a profit.  The primary reasons for this are outlined below.
TO COVER THE COSTS OF OPENING.  Each semester when CD&C opens, we must open up purchase orders with all of our vendors.  In order to do this, we get loans from Student Activities which must be repaid at the end of the fiscal year; there must be enough money in our account to cover these costs.
TO COVER UNEXPECTED LOSSES. Machinery breakdowns or other emergencies can cause unexpected losses during a semester.  For this reason there must be enough money to cover opening costs and any unexpected financial losses.
TO REINVEST IN THE BUSINESS.  Ours is a business which is constantly growing and changing with technology.  All money made beyond what is needed to cover costs and plan for unexpected losses should be reinvested into the business.  Specifically, this money is used to buy new capital purchases, upgrading old equipment, buying new equipment, and updating the store. 

CD&C Vendors

The  of a hase Order
Purchase Orders (more commonly known as P.O.s) are how CD&C makes all of its purchases.  Everything from pens to paper to copier toner is paid for through the Student Activities Office via P.O.s.  Just like Ross must open up 's to do business with CD&C, we must open 's with our vendors.  The process for opening a P.O. is outlined below.

DECISION TO PURCH - CD&C employees decide to make a purchase. The purchase must be budgeted for and a proposal must be passed. 
OPEN A PURCHASE ORDER - The bookkeeper fills out a purchase order worksheet and has it signed off by one of the coordinators at CSB.
THE P.O. GOES TO STUDENT VITIES - The P.O. worksheet is delivered to the Student Activities Office for their review.  It is then typed and signed by the office manager Allen Brainard.  
COPIES OF THE P.O. DISPERSED - A running copy of the P.O. is kept on file at Student Activities.  CD&C receives the original and a vendor copy which must be mailed or delivered to the specific vendor (i.e. Unisource, etc.).  
CD&C MAKES PURCHASES - Once the vendor receives its copy, CD&C can make its purchase.  The money is deducted from the Purchase Order by Justine at Campus Activities and is also tracked by the CD&C bookkeeper.
INCREASE THE P.O. - As purchases are still being made during the semester, the P.O. will run low.  Eventually an increase must be made by the CD&C bookkeeper.  The same procedure is used for a P.O. increase.

THE  OF A CAPITAL PURCHASE
Capital purchases are large purchases (this refers mainly to the purchase of a new copier). Everything from pens to paper to copier toner is paid for through the Student Activities Office. Because capital purchases have a substantially higher cost than operating inventory the purchase must be approved by Student Activities. To process of obtaining approval is outlined below:
DECISION TO PURCH - CD&C employees decide to make a purchase.
PROFIT ANALYSIS - A spreadsheet must be created detailing the revenue that CD&C expects to earn from the purchase or the amount that CD&C expects to save by switching vendors.
ADVERTISING INITIATIVE - An advertising plan must be developed and outlined with any related expenses that will be incurred at implementation.
PROPOSAL - A proposal must be organized with the profit analysis, advertising initiative, and documentation of any additional costs related to the purchase (maintenance, set-up, logistical, technical requirements, training, etc.) 
PRESENTATION - The proposal must be presented at All-Staff and passed by all members. If they proposal is approved it is brought to the  and Student Activities for approval. 

THE LIFE OF A BILL
1.  THE OR IS DELIVERED TO CD&C - Most of our orders are delivered to the CD&C office, but some may be delivered to the Student Activities Office, which then notifies us. 
2.  VENDOR GIVES CD&Cer THE GOODS AND AN IICE - The employee on shift should check the contents of the package, ensuring that the receipt and contents match up.  He/she must then sign for the order.  Our copy of the receipt should be given to the Purchaser, who must verify the order and file the receipt.
3.  CD&C REVES IICE - The vendor sends an invoice, or bill, to CD&C via Student Activities. 
4.  BOOKEEPER ENTERS INVOICE INTO THE WEEKLY GENE LEDGER - The bookkeeper gives the invoice to Sue in SAO and gives a copy to the CSB consultant and files it in their notebook.

FINANCIAL TERMS MADE EASY
BUDGET:  CD&C’s budget, which is prepared by the CSB consultant, is a projection of activity expected to occur during a particular semester.  It is a breakdown of monthly sales and expenses, and is necessary as a guideline for us to recognize our expectations and limitations.
NET SALES:  The total sales is the total cash, credit card, Ucard, monthly RSO charges, monthly academic billing, and sales tax received deposited into our account.
 OF GOODS SOLD:  This is the amount that we pay for the goods that we have sold for a particular period of time. It is calculated by taking the dollar amount of inventory at the beginning of the month, adding the purchase amounts of goods for resale and then subtracting the dollar value of the end of month inventory.  Inventory is taken by the Purchaser.  
GROSS MARGIN:  The gross margin is the amount of money we have left over to pay our expenses after we deduct the cost of goods sold.  The gross margins should be between 35% and 40%.
TOTAL EXPENSES:  Total expenses comprise the total amount of money spent on services and items such as copyright clearance expense, leases, maintenance expense, phone & fax charges, etc. needed to run the store, as well as other miscellaneous expenditures.
NET INCOME:  Net income is calculated by subtracting total expenses from the gross margin. This may be a positive (gain) or a negative (loss) number and represents the amount of money left after all expenses have been deducted.  Negative figures are placed in parentheses, positive figures are left normal.
 COSTING:  This tax is 8.3% of purchases, payroll, and expenses.  This amount goes to the Student Activities Office in return for their services. Other taxes and dues are:
CSB TAX - 1% of net sales given for services
BOB DUES - $50 per semester in support of the Board of Student Businesses
NASCO DUES - $35 per semester to belong to NASCO
SALES TAX - Quarterly sales tax paid to commonwealth for taxable services



Goooooo CD&C!

Constitution of the Cannabis Education Coalition

Name & Purpose: The name of this Registered Student Organization (RSO) is

I.
the University of Massachusetts at Amherst Cannabis Education Coalition, hereafter
referred to as the “CEC.” CEC is a pro-choice organization founded in 1991 and is the
oldest student-run organization devoted to ending the prohibition and stigmatization of
cannabis both locally and nationally and advocating for its industrial, medicinal, and
recreational use for moral, environmental, and economic reasons. UMACEC will work
toward this goal through a program of nonviolent political action and community
organization, in an effort to educate and expand the consciousness of UMass students in
regards to cannabis and its many uses.  As an RSO, CEC is required to fulfill all
University and SGA requirements.  CEC is not affiliated with any other organization,
however its membership, from time to time may vote to work in coordination with the
activities of other groups with similar goals.
II.

Membership:

a. All interested individuals are eligible to become members.
b. There are three forms of membership:

i.

ii.

iii.

Active dues paying:  An active member has paid dues, is a SATF-paying
undergraduate at UMASS/Amherst, and is on record as a member of
UMACEC.They can vote on Executive Board elections and  at general
business meetings where votes are taken.
Active non-dues paying member: An active non-dues paying member is a
SATF-paying undergraduate at UMASS/Amherst, and is on record as a
member of UMACEC.  They cannot vote on Executive Board elections,
but can vote at general business meetings where votes are taken.
Associate member:  An associate member has paid dues, however an
associate member is not a SATF-paying undergraduate at
UMASS/Amherst, or for reasons of privacy does not have their name on
official records. They cannot vote on Executive Board elections, but can
vote at general business meetings where votes are taken.

c. Requirements for membership are set forth in UMACEC’s by-laws
d. The rights of all members are:

i.

ii.
iii.

iv.

v.
vi.
vii.

To speak at all meetings except Executive Board meetings which have
been declared closed.
To vote at all meetings (excluding executive board meetings).
To examine and receive copies of the constitution and by-laws of the
UMACEC.
To receive a copy of UMACEC’s newsletter, “Smoke Signals” which will
be published several times a semester.
To receive food before weekly meetings (excluding non dues paying)
To have a CEC Membership Card (excluding non dues paying)
All members are strongly encouraged to be registered to vote (in the real
world) if they are eligible.  Members are also encouraged to attend rallies,
write letters, and become active in the community outside of UMACEC.

III.

Executive Board Officers:

 A. The President, Vice-President, Secretary, Treasurer and Public relations specialist

shall comprise the Executive Board.

B. All officers shall be elected to their positions at an annual election and shall serve
until replaced by a successor who shall assume the responsibilities of their elected
position at the 2nd to last meeting Fall Semester to last meeting of the semester in
which their election occurred.

C. There must at all times be 2 board members, one of which must be the Treasurer
and the other either the President of the Vice-President who have signature
responsibility.

D. Annual elections will be held in the last two weeks of the fall semester at the

University of Massachusetts.  It is the duty of the Secretary to issue a news brief,
which gives the date, time, and location of the election, at least two weeks before
the election occurs.

E. Only active members who fulfill all RSO requirements can be Executive Board

officers.

F. Voting shall be by secret ballot, with separate ballots for each office.
G. The Executive Board shall be the governing body of UMACEC—it shall plan

policies, activities, and elections.

H. Duties:

a. The President shall chair all meetings, be the liaison to all other

organizations, and negotiate for UMACEC with other offices and
organizations.  The President shall ensure compliance by UMACEC with
all provisions of the constitution and by-laws.  The President, with the
consent of the executive Board, shall also be in charge of appointing all
liaisons, committee heads, and other temporary officers as necessary.
Oversees all CEC activities and ensures all tasks are delegated equally
between officers.

b. The Vice-President shall assist the President and substitute for the

president in the event of the President's absence. They are also responsible
for any duties delegated by the President. They must gain the approval and
financial support of the membership of UMACEC. Oversee the running of
events.

c. The Secretary shall be responsible for the taking of minutes at all

UMACEC meetings.  A newsletter, “Smoke Signals,” containing articles
pertinent to cannabis legalization or of interest to the CEC members. They
are also responsible for any duties delegated by the President.

d. The Treasurer shall be responsible for maintaining all financial assets of

the UMACEC.  The treasurer is also responsible for depositing all monies
and dues and paying all debts.  The Treasurer shall have signature
responsibility.  The Treasurer is responsible for creating a budget at the
end of  the year. They are also responsible for any duties delegated by the
President.

e. The Public Relations specialist shall be in charge of contacting

organizations outside of the UMass Amherst community. They are also
responsible for any duties delegated by the President.

 f. The Executive Board may provide for the continuity of     UMACEC

during any period of absence and may, for that purpose, create temporary
officers to delegate their individual and collective powers to, who must
qualify according to RSO standards.

g. All Executive Board members of UMACEC are strongly encouraged to

take the Nuts and Bolts training.

h. A majority vote of the quorum of a general meeting is required to overturn

a decision of the Executive Board.

i. The decision of a single officer may be overturned by a majority vote of

the Executive Board.

IV.

Non Officer Positions

a. Webmaster;
i.

The master is appointed by the previous webmaster; if the previous
Webmaster is not available the President may appoint the new Webmaster.
The Webmaster's duties are to maintain the CEC website,  facebook page,
Instagram, Twitter page and any technical issues that their abilities allow
them to do.
Qualifications to be the Webmaster will be listed in the By-Laws.

ii.

iii.

V.

Meetings:

a. There are three types of meetings:.

i.

ii.

iii.

Executive board meetings will be held every week; we decide on dates for
club meetings, events, demonstrations, to fine tune ideas for activities
discussed in general meetings, and to decide on any relevant
organizational matter that can not be decided by a general vote, and
delegate tasks.
General business meetings will be held twice per month, and will focus on
organizational matters such as news from other legalization groups,
upcoming events, and suggestions from the membership for activities.
General meetings will provide a forum for member participation in the
running of the organization.
Informational meetings occur on dates set by the executive board.  The
purpose of these meetings is to raise student awareness about cannabis and
the reasons for its re-legalization.

b. Meeting types 2 and 3 are to be open to the public and are to be publicized.
c. Meetings may be called by officers in the executive board, or by a petition of 15

active members.

d. A minimum quorum will consist of 10 members.  No business may be conducted
at a meeting unless quorum is present.  Any police officers at the meetings shall
count toward quorum.
Financial Policy:

VI.

a. The amount of dues to be paid by members to UMACEC shall be fixed in the

by-laws.

b. All UMACEC expenditures of up to $150 must have the prior approval of an

officer.

 c. All UMACEC expenditure over $150 must have the prior approval of the

executive board.

d. All UMACEC expenditures exceeding $150 dollars must also be approved in

advance at a general business meeting.

i.

ii.

If, during periods of time in which the University of Massachusetts is not
in session or if a general business meeting cannot reach quorum. Then the
executive board is allowed to exceed their normal spending limit of $200.
If the expenditure has not been precedent or is controversial the executive
board cannot spend money without a vote at general business meetings.

VII.

By-Laws:

a. The purpose of the By-Laws is to establish UMACEC policy and aid in the

interpretation of the constitution and conduct of daily affairs.

b. Amendments to the by-laws shall be brought before a meeting at least one week
prior to the vote.  A majority vote of a meeting in which 20 active members are
present is required to amend the by-laws.

c. The webmaster should be able to manage the website effectively, manage google
documents, manage the mailing list, manage the CECumass@gmail.com email.

VII. Amendments: Amendments to the constitution shall be
meeting at least one week prior to the vote.  A majority vote of a business meeting with a
quorum is 20 members are required to amend the constitution.
VIII. Ratification: This constitution and by-Laws must be ratified
every three
years in accordance with RSO regulations by a 2/3 majority vote at a business meeting
called for
IX. Statement of Beliefs Concerning Cannabis:

this purpose, which quorum consists of 20 members.

brought before a

a.

Industrial Cannabis Products:  UMACEC believes that the benefits to the
environment and to the consumer of the widespread utilization of industrial
cannabis products, such as paper, textile, oil, and animal feed, far outweigh the
benefits that the prohibition of cannabis brings to certain elements of big business,
therefore UMACEC believe that industrial cannabis products should be allowed
to freely enter the market.

b. Cannabis Medicines:  UMACEC believe that certain cannabis medicines have
been proven very effective in treating certain ailments, such as glaucoma, and
nausea from cancer chemotherapy, and AIDS, and have also shown to have very
few side effects, and therefore, UMACEC believe it is cruel to deny patients
access to potentially life-saving cannabis medicines.

c. Recreational Cannabis:  UMACEC supports the removal of all criminal and civil
penalties for the possession and consumption of cannabis.  UMACEC believes
that this is a civil rights issue.

d. Regulation: UMACEC advocates a system of cannabis regulation that would

include age restrictions, public health and agricultural controls, and taxation of
cannabis for profit.  A well planned system of cannabis regulation would
discourage abuse, protect public health and safety, reduce crime associated with
illicit distribution, and raise large sums of new tax revenues.  Regulation is the
inevitable replacement of prohibition.

e. Personal cultivation:  UMACEC believes the right to possess cannabis also

 includes the right to grow substantial amounts for personal use, transport, and to
make casual, non-profit gifts of small amounts of cannabis.

f. Drug abuse:  UMACEC believes that drug addiction is an illness which is best
treated by doctors rather than by prison guards.  UMACEC is opposed to drug
abuse, whether illegal or illegal drugs are involved.

g. Destruction of Criminal Records:  UMACEC urges the enactment of legislation to
provide for the destruction of criminal records of persons arrested for or convicted
of cannabis offenses prior to the enactment of legislation repealing criminal
penalties for such offenses.

h. Public Use: UMACEC recognizes the individual rights of non-smokers not to be
subjected to discomfort, or whatever health risks may arise from the smoking of
any substance in designated non-smoking areas, however UMACEC is opposed to
criminal law being used to regulate such activity.

i. Driving While Intoxicated:  UMACEC strongly discourages driving motor

vehicles while under the influence of any drug, and recognizes the legitimate
public interest in the prohibition of such activity.

j. Role of the Military in Law Enforcement:  UMACEC opposes any use of the

military in civilian, domestic law enforcement.

k. Cannabis Eradication:  UMACEC is opposed to the use of Paraquat and all other
chemical or biological agents intended to destroy or identify cannabis under
cultivation in this or any other country.  UMACEC supports the prohibition of
herbicides, fungicides or any other chemicals used to spray cannabis as consistent
with the protection of public health and the environment.

l. Cannabis Research and Women:  UMACEC urges revisions of current FDA

policies which severely limit cannabis research on women of child-bearing age.
UMACEC believes that such restrictions are unwarranted, and that studies on the
effects of cannabis on women and men of all ages are necessary, important, and
should be encouraged by the NIDA and other similar agencies.

BY-Laws of the Cannabis Education Coalition

I. Membership Duration:

a. Membership lasts for one full year, beginning when dues are received by

the UMACEC.

b. Membership of an individual in the group may be revoked by a majority
of dues-paying members at a general business meeting or a majority of
officers on the board.  This does not include executive board members.

II.  The Executive Board:

 a. Nominations:  Annual nominations shall be opened at the 3rd to last

meeting of the fall semester of the University of Amherst.

b. A person may nominate themselves by informing a member of the
executive board who will post a list of nominations at the earliest
opportunity, or announce their nomination at the election meeting.

c. A person may nominate themselves for more than one office.
d. Elections:
i.
ii.

The election of new officers shall occur at a business meeting.
Elections shall be the first order of business after determining
quorum.
The elections shall be held without any discussion except for
candidate speeches.  Each candidate can make a speech that can
last up to two minutes.  A question and answer period will follow
that will last no longer than 5 minutes.
Any person who is nominated to more than one office shall
withdraw their nomination upon being elected to any office.
Only one person may hold an office at a time.
The elections shall be decided on the first ballot except in the case
of a tie, in which case there shall be a run-off election.

iii.

iv.

v.
vi.

e. Special Election:

i.

ii.
iii.

iv.

Special elections shall be held when an officer resigns or is
otherwise unable to act in the capacity of that office.
The special election date shall be set at a business meeting.
The date set for special elections must be one week after the
meeting to set the date.
Nominations shall be taken from the floor.

f. Temporary Vacancies:  The order of succession after the Vice-President

shall be as follows: Secretary, Treasurer.

g. Provisions for dismissal of officers:

i.

ii.

Any member can bring forth a case for dismissal against an officer
at a general business meeting.  At that meeting a vote will be held,
if ten people support the measure to dismiss an officer then at the
next general business meeting a vote will take place.
At the special meeting any member may make a case against the
officer for dismissal, this section will take no more than 10
minutes.  The officer then has 10 minutes with which to defend
themselves. Following this discussion a vote will take place, a 2/3
majority is necessary to dismiss the officer.  Dismissals may only
happen if a quorum is present.

III.    Conduct of a business Meeting:

a. The sole subject of a business meeting that is called by a member petition is the

subject set forth in the petition.

b. Questions of procedure shall be decided by the chair, subject to appeal.  A 2/3

majority

c. Motions shall be passed upon receiving the votes of a majority of the members

 present and voting, unless specifically stated otherwise in the constitution,
by-laws, or other rules of order.

d. Proxies and absentee Ballots:
Proxies:

i.

1. Proxies shall not be counted toward a quorum at a business

meeting.

2. Proxies do not specify specific votes on specific issues.
3. Proxies are not valid for elections other than special elections.
4. Proxies may have a list of names for people to whom they will be

directed.  An order of preference must be given for this list.

5. Proxies are not transferable.
6. No person shall hold more than two proxies.

ii.

Absentee ballots:

1. Absentee ballots shall not be counted toward quorum at a business

meeting.

2. Absentee ballots specify votes on specific issues.
3. Absentee ballots are the property of UMACEC, and shall be

tabulated by the secretary.

IV. Dues:

a. Dues are $0.00 for one calendar year.
b. Dues entitle a member to a CEC wristband, food before meetings, and any other

benefit achieved by the CEC.

CHARTER for The UMass Card Game Club

Adopted 1 December, 2015 in Amherst MA

Revised 23 April, 2019 in Amherst MA by John Kraemer

Pronouns and formatting revised 11 April 2021 by Ryan Fletcher

 Mission Statement

The mission of the University of Massachusetts – Amherst Card Game Club is to

unite people who play all sorts of card games together including, but not limited to,

trading card games such as YuGiOh!, Magic: The Gathering, Weiss Schwarz. We

believe that card game players should have an easy access community where

members can improve and connect with other players. We plan to host several

non-profit tournaments in order to train members for high-level competitive play at

regional events. Also, there will be mentors to teach and play with the more casual

players. There will be pizza parties, viewing sessions on YouTube of several of the

card games, and member-prepared presentations of future card games.

 I. Membership

A.

All students at the University of Massachusetts – Amherst and the

general public will be eligible to be members of the UMass Card

Game Club (CGC).

1.

Only University of Massachusetts students are eligible to vote

in elections.

B. Membership shall be established after a prospective member attends

one meeting and notifies the Secretary that they wish to be a member.

II. Meetings

A. Members of the UMass CGC will have meetings on a weekly basis

unless stated otherwise.

B. Meetings will be chaired by the President.

C.

The purpose of the meetings shall be:

1.

2.

Group Bonding

Planning events

3. Watching videos dedicated to card games.

4.

Other topics deemed necessary.

D.

Topics of the meetings will be decided by the officers.

 III. The Executive Board

A.

The officers of the UMass CGC shall be:

1. President

2. Vice President

3. Secretary

4. Treasurer

B.

Officers besides the president to serve a term of one year, starting the

day after the last day of classes in the spring semester.

C.

A new president shall only be elected during the current president’s

final semester in the club at UMass Amherst.

Officers can be re-elected multiple times.

The President

D.

E.

1.

The President shall be the chief executive officer of the RSO.

They shall be responsible for all aspects of the functioning of

the group.

2.

The President shall have signature responsibility.

F.

The Vice President

1.

The Vice President shall take over the President’s place in the

event that they are absent. (Including signature responsibility)

2.

The Vice President shall aid the President in preparing for

meetings and shall be responsible for discussing future events

with the President.

 G.

The Secretary

1.

The Secretary shall be responsible for the maintaining a list of

current members.

2.

They shall assist the president in maintaining social media

pages and campus pulse pages.

3.

They shall be in charge of communicating with the members by

email.

H.

The Treasurer

1.

The Treasurer shall be responsible for keeping track of how

money is spent within the club.

2.

They shall work together with other members of the board to

determine how money shall be spent.

IV. Officer Elections

A.

B.

Officer elections shall be held during the month of March.

The election shall be a 2-week process – the nomination meeting and

the election meeting

C.

During the nomination meeting, the president will first deal with

non-election matters. Then once the president says nominations are

open, members can choose to nominate candidates including

themselves along with their positions.

D.

Each nominee can only be selected for one position

1.

Nominees must receive the approval of the president in to

proceed through with elections.

2.

Nominations shall close during the same meeting when a

unanimous decision is made to do so.

 3.

Upon approval of the president, members shall be given a week

to prepare a speech for the following week’s election.

E.

During the meeting of the second week of elections, each candidate

will provide a short speech on why they deserve their respective

position. Then, members shall put their votes inside of a box for the

current secretary to tally up. The winners by majority vote will be

announced on the same evening.

F.

In an event of a tie, the current officer of the respective position the

candidates are running for shall decide the new officer.

G.

The previous officers will train the new officers with their duties.

1.

Newly elected officers shall take power during the final meeting

for that semester.

2.

If any issue arises or a student wishes to appeal the results, it

must be addressed to the president who will then consult with

the other current officers to deal with the issue.

 V. Officer Removal

A.

In the event an officer fails to fulfill their duties, they may be asked to

be impeached by the president.

B.

The president may only be granted this power when

1.

There are four or more members who agree on the

impeachment.

2.

The president feels that the actions of the officer impending

impeachment are detrimental to the UMass CGC as a whole.

C.

Upon being asked to be impeached, the respective officer will have to

present their case to the other officers only.

1.

If all of the officers agree on the impeachment, the officer will

lose their position and a special election will be held which will

run similarly to article IV of this constitution.

2.

Else, the case will be presented to the members during one of

the meetings and members will vote on the officer’s

impeachment. If a high majority (70%) of the vote goes towards

the officer being impeached, the officer will lose their position

and a special election will be held which will run similarly to

article IV of this constitution.

D.

All officers can resign on their own which will then run a special

election.

E.

The president can be impeached if a very high majority (80%) of the

members agree on it. Then a special election will be run.

 VI. Resolving Disputes

A.

Disputes arising between members on matters of RSO policy shall be

dealt with through majority votes of the general membership.

B.

Disputes arising between members on other matters shall be dealt with

through mediation.

1.

Mediation consists of a meeting involving both parties and a

mediator with the purpose of coming to a solution and putting

the issue to rest.

2.

3.

The President shall mediate disputes between members.

Should the President be involved in the dispute, or should either

party not be satisfied by the result of the mediation, any party

may request that the Secretary of the Registry mediate. The

results of mediation with the Secretary of the Registry shall be

final.

VII. Free Speech

A.

All members of the UMass CGC are entitled to freedom of speech and

will not under any circumstances be deprived of the opportunity to

share their opinion with the group.

 VIII. Amendment

A.

This charter may be amended by a 2/3 vote of the general membership

at a regularly scheduled meeting.

1.

A motion to amend may be made and seconded by any member

at a meeting of the general membership. The motion shall be

presented at the meeting in which the motion is made. Voting

on the motion shall take place at the following meeting. Prior to

voting, the President shall allow for a period of debate.

B.

After being approved by the membership, the amendment itself, and

an updated version of the Charter, shall be submitted to the Secretary

of the Registry for final approval.

IX. Amendment List

A.

Non-discrimination Clause - The UMass CGC prohibits

discrimination under Federal and State law, based on race, color,

national origin, religion, sex, gender identity (including gender

expression), sexual orientation, disability, age, marital status,

family/parental status, income derived from a public assistance

program, political beliefs, or reprisal or retaliation for prior civil rights

activity. This list is not exhaustive, and groups can add more protected

classes to this statement. For further compliance, please refer to the

SGA policy.

B.

Gender neutral pronouns Clause - The UMass CGC must refer to

members/officers using they/them/their pronouns.

CHARTER for The UMass Card Game Club

Adopted 1 December, 2015 in Amherst MA
Revised 23 April, 2019 in Amherst MA by John Kraemer




























Mission Statement
The mission of the University of Massachusetts – Amherst Card Game Club is to unite people who play all sorts of card games together including, but not limited to, trading card games such as YuGiOh!, Magic: The Gathering, Weiss Schwarz. We believe that card game players should have an easy access community where members can improve and connect with other players. We plan to host several non-profit tournaments in order to train members for high-level competitive play at regional events. Also, there will be mentors to teach and play with the more casual players. There will be pizza parties, viewing sessions on YouTube of several of the card games, and member-prepared presentations of future card games.
















I. Membership
All students at the University of Massachusetts – Amherst and the general public will be eligible to be members of the UMass Card Game Club (CGC).
Only University of Massachusetts students are eligible to vote in elections.
Membership shall be established after a prospective member attends one meeting and notifies the Secretary that they wish to be a member.

II. Meetings
Members of the UMass CGC will have meetings on a weekly basis unless stated otherwise.
Meetings will be chaired by the President.
The purpose of the meetings shall be:
Group Bonding
Planning events
Watching videos dedicated to card games.
Other topics deemed necessary.
Topics of the meetings will be decided by the officers.
III. The Executive Board
The officers of the UMass CGC shall be:
1. President
2. Vice President
3. Secretary
4. Treasurer
Officers besides the president to serve a term of one year, starting the day after the last day of classes in the spring semester.
A new president shall only be elected during the current president’s final semester in the club at UMass Amherst.
Officers can be re-elected multiple times.
The President
1. The President shall be the chief executive officer of the RSO. He or she shall be responsible for all aspects of the functioning of the group.
2. The President shall have signature responsibility.
The Vice President
1. The Vice President shall take over the President’s place in the event he or she is absent. 
2. The Vice President shall aid the President in preparing for meetings and shall be responsible for discussing future events with the President.
The Secretary
1. The Secretary shall be responsible for the maintaining a list of current members.
2. He or she shall assist the president in maintaining social media pages and campus pulse pages.
3. He or she shall be in charge of communicating with the members by email.
The Treasurer
1. The Treasurer shall be responsible for keeping track of how money is spent within the club.
2. He or she shall work together with other members of the board to determine how money shall be spent.



IV. Officer Elections
Officer elections shall be held during the month of March.
The election shall be a 2-week process – the nomination meeting and the      election meeting
During the nomination meeting, the president will first deal with non-election matters. Then once the president says nominations are open, members can choose to nominate candidates including themselves along with their positions.
Each nominee can only be selected for one position
1. Nominees must receive the approval of the president in to proceed through with elections.
2. Nominations shall close during the same meeting when a unanimous decision is made to do so.
3. Upon approval of the president, members shall be given a week to prepare a speech for the following week’s election.
During the meeting of the second week of elections, each candidate will provide a short speech on why they deserve their respective position. Then, members shall put their votes inside of a box for the current secretary to tally up. The winners by majority vote will be announced on the same evening.
In an event of a tie, the current officer of the respective position the candidates are running for shall decide the new officer.
The previous officers will train the new officers with their duties.
1. Newly elected officers shall take power during the final meeting for that semester.
2. If any issue arises or a student wishes to appeal the results, it must be addressed to the president who will then consult with the other current officers to deal with the issue.
V. Officer Removal
In the event an officer fails to fulfill their duties, he or she may be asked to be impeached by the president.
The president may only be granted this power when
1. There are four or more members who agree on the impeachment.
2. The president feels that the actions of the officer impending impeachment are detrimental to the UMass CGC as a whole.
Upon being asked to be impeached, the respective officer will have to present their case to the other officers only.
1. If all of the officers agree on the impeachment, the officer will lose his or her position and a special election will be held which will run similarly to article IV of this constitution.
2. Else, the case will be presented to the members during one of the meetings and members will vote on the officer’s impeachment. If a high majority (70%) of the vote goes towards the officer being impeached, the officer will lose his or her position and a special election will be held which will run similarly to article IV of this constitution.
All officers can resign on their own which will then run a special election.
The president can be impeached if a very high majority (80%) of the members agree on it. Then a special election will be run.
VI. Resolving Disputes
Disputes arising between members on matters of RSO policy shall be dealt with through majority votes of the general membership.
Disputes arising between members on other matters shall be dealt with through mediation.
1. Mediation consists of a meeting involving both parties and a mediator with the purpose of coming to a solution and putting the issue to rest.
2. The President shall mediate disputes between members.
3. Should the President be involved in the dispute, or should either party not be satisfied by the result of the mediation, any party may request that the Secretary of the Registry mediate. The results of mediation with the Secretary of the Registry shall be final.
VII. Free Speech
All members of the UMass CGC are entitled to freedom of speech and will not under any circumstances be deprived of the opportunity to share their opinion with the group.
VIII. Amendment
This charter may be amended by a 2/3 vote of the general membership at a regularly scheduled meeting.
1. A motion to amend may be made and seconded by any member at a meeting of the general membership. The motion shall be presented at the meeting in which the motion is made. Voting on the motion shall take place at the following meeting. Prior to voting, the President shall allow for a period of debate.
After being approved by the membership, the amendment itself, and an updated version of the Charter, shall be submitted to the Secretary of the Registry for final approval.


IX. Amendment List 
 Non-discrimination Clause - The UMass CGC prohibits discrimination under Federal and State law, based on race, color, national origin, religion, sex, gender identity (including gender expression), sexual orientation, disability, age, marital status, family/parental status, income derived from a public assistance program, political beliefs, or reprisal or retaliation for prior civil rights activity. This list is not exhaustive, and groups can add more protected classes to this statement. For further compliance, please refer to the SGA policy.
Gender neutral pronouns Clause - The UMass CGC must refer to members/officers using they/them/their pronouns.

How to Use This Form

Recreation Club Allocation Committee - Budget Request Form

Review your entire budget breakdown and select those expenses that you would like paid for by the Univeristy of Massachusetts Amherst through an allocation of SGA funds from the Recreation Club Council Allocations Commmittee. Prioritize the items from most important (1) to least important (up to 10). All items, including individual trips 
or items of equipment, should be listed separately.

How the Recreation Club Allocation Committee Will Use This Form

The Recreation Club Council Allocation Committee will review this form and other resources for allocation.  Each club will have the opportunity to explain its priority list, provide additional information regarding budget expenses and estimated income, and clarify any items during its scheduled budget hearing before the Recreation Club 
Council Allocation Committee during the allocation process.

Allocation and Spending by Category

Clubs will be allocated money by category, with allocated funds required to be spent in that category. You may adjust expenditures within category (if you request to fund a trip to Miami and you change that to Atlanta, that is acceptable).  But, to move money between categories (such as from Travel to Equipment) will require a special 
request  to the Recreation Club Council for approval.

DocsList.Name: 行政部门招新介绍.pdf
DocsList.Data:
行政部门招新介绍 

专业化的高效率行政团队。体验忙碌而充实的文书和管理工
作。在工作中培养责任感，团队意识等个人能力。 

❖ 为CMA为演艺类专业化社团，主要培养专业行政人员和汇聚演出人才。 
❖ 行政类人员采用培养制度。入团者需具备良好的社团意识，具备良好的个人素养。
一般任期按学年分，社团将承担培养人才的任务，让个人能力成分得到锻炼和发
挥。入团时可选择行政部门，但入团后可以根据实际情况调动部门。 

开放部门 

❖ 秘书处 
❖ 日常团内事务 

➢ 记录并整理会议上的重要信息。 
➢ 整理社团资料，及时上传到 Google   Drive 。 
➢ 通过邮件、微信等方式发布会议消息与宣布社团决策。 
➢ 记录各项活动的考勤、请假与纪律。 

❖ 宣传部 
❖ 文字与影像资料处理 

➢ 搜集日常活动及表演的文字、图像、视频信息。 
➢ 后期处理文字与图片视频信息，视频制作。 
➢ 管理社团对外平台，如 Facebook、 微信公众号 、Campus   pulse 等。 
➢ 将活动照片和视频及时上传到 Google   Drive 。 

❖ 策划部 
❖ 活动以及事务策划 

➢ 针对社团内部提出的问题或者合作方提出的问题做方案策划。 
➢ 与活动方取得沟通，落实项目细节，协调团员诉求。 
➢ 提出活动方案，并构想应急预案。 
➢ 现场进行人员调配，落实每项任务的跟进，并与主席团相互配合，随时准备

应对突发情况。 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 ❖ 财务处 
❖ 财务流动以及资金申请 

➢ 负责记录社团资金流动情况，及时处理每一笔款项。 
➢ 向学校申请资金。 
➢ 研究学校资金使用的相关政策，确保资金使用的合法性及合理性。 
➢ 收集以及处理社团内部对自己的使用诉求。 

❖ 外联部 
❖ 外事联络与沟通 

➢ 负责联络校内主管部门，与其他校级组织进行互动。 
➢ 与校外友好组织和机构进行互相沟通，收发联络邮件。 
➢ 处理突发公关紧急情况。 
➢ 主动寻找外部合作机会与赞助商 
➢ 处理与赞助商的联系和沟通。 

招新方法 

春季招新：行政人员统一时间招新，报名后等待具体通知。需要经过部门
面试后录用。 

滚动招新：每周五下午5：30分。相应职位空缺时招新，若无空缺，则不会
滚动招收行政人员。

DocsList.Name: 演出部招新介绍.pdf
DocsList.Data:
演出部招新介绍 

宽广的平台，丰富的演出机会乐贯中西，演艺类人才的聚集
地。在CMA遇见志同道合的知音，唱个小曲，玩玩音乐。 

❖ 演出人员采取季度签约录用制度。即入团者须至少具备一项演出技能，（分技术，
舞蹈，器乐和声乐方向）一经录用，须参加至少一场本季度演出。技术类须提供相
应的技术服务。每学期为一个季度。 

开放席位 

❖ 技术方向(音乐理论，舞蹈，声乐) 
❖ 对乐理，作曲编曲有较好的功底者。对声乐理论，和声等有较好基础者。舞蹈编

排，舞蹈理论等突出者。 

❖ 器乐方向（中乐，西乐，电子音乐） 
❖ 不分中西乐器。须有较好的音乐功底，可以独奏或者合奏曲目。风格不限。 

❖ 舞蹈方向  
❖ 对中国舞，古典舞，现代舞感兴趣，身体素质等视具体面试情况决定。 

❖ 声乐方向 
❖ 较好的掌握发声方法。能够自如的演唱独唱或者合唱曲目。风格视具体面试决

定。 

招新方法 

滚动招新：每周五下午5：30分。录用时需考虑本季度演出任务等情况，若
无法满足演出任务则不予录用。（舞蹈方向除外） 
舞蹈方向招新为培养制，由舞团筛选，培养，和安排相关演出。

DocsList.Name: 活动小组招新介绍.pdf
DocsList.Data:
活动小组招新介绍 

丰富的活动参与机会，体验忙碌和有成就感的场务经历。与
外校进行深度交流合作的机会，增长经验和见识。 

❖ 活动小组人员大部分在行政部门里抽调，也可以单独加入，季度签约录用制度。加
入活动队伍的同学须具备良好的团队意识，有相关后台经验者为佳。参与者原则上
去参与每一季度内的演出。 

开放席位 

❖ 器材场控 
❖ 对音响线材有较好的了解，富有责任感，具备现场应对突发事件的能力。 

❖ 舞台美术 
❖ 对舞台灯光等有较好的基本功。熟悉各类表演的走台与流程。 

❖ 节目调度  
❖ 责任心强，对团队合作有较强的主观能动性。负责催场，节目调度的总指挥。 

❖ 流动场务 
❖ 流动性的场务人员服从上述三种调度员的指挥，负责搬运，播放等等现场工作。 
❖ 场务应具备高度的责任感。 
❖ 具备良好的沟通技能。 

招新方法 

滚动招新：每周五下午5：30分。相应职位空缺时招新，若无空缺，则不会
滚动招收活动专员。
