DocsList.Name: 麻省大学CMA国乐社官方章程（中文版）.pdf
2016-2017年度春季换届选举的有关通知（主席2号文件）.pdf
DocsList.Data:
2016-2017 年度春季换届选举的有关通知 

(主席 2 号文件) 

各位团员，为落实 CMA 国乐社“小步快跑”的发展思路，现正式发布春季换届通知。 

2016-2017 年度春季，以下职位可以申请竞选 

主席团：  主席    副主席 

活动指挥小组：  活动总监      器材场控专员    舞台美术专员    项目负责专员 

行政部门：  外联部长  策划部长  宣传部长  财务部长  秘书处长 

演出部：  演出总监   

级别说明 

主席级（主席  副主席） 

部长级（外联部长  策划部长  宣传部长  财务部长  秘书处长  演出总监） 

小队指挥级  (活动总监  器材场控专员    舞台美术专员    项目负责专员  音乐指导  舞蹈指导) 

社员级  (即所有 2016-2017 年度未经取消资格的社员) 

竞选条件： 

1.  竞选主席职位的，需有副主席工作经历一年以上。（特殊情况可放宽至部长级）通过决策

小组答辩面试后，由主席提名竞选。 

2.  竞选副主席职位的，需有部长级工作一年工作经验。通过决策小组答辩面试后，由主席

提名竞选。 

3.  竞选部长级职位的，需有一学期以上工作经验（小队指挥经验更加），由现部门主管提名

 
 
 竞选。 

4.  竞选小队指挥级的职位，需有一学期以上工作经验，可主动向各自部门主管直接提出申

请。 

5.  需跨部门竞选部长的，由部门主管提出申请，决策小组进行提名。 

6.  竞选各级部门职位者，若有警告或违纪行为，一律取消竞选资格。 

7.  所有提名的名单请各部门主管汇总到秘书处霍雨佳，选举将在 campus pulse  学校官方

系统进行。 

选举时间：2016/12/11  零时开始  2016/12/14 21：00 结束 

选举办法： 

1.  主席级别的选举，由主席发起提名，决策小组成员具有投票资格。主席具有一票否决权。

社员具有质疑权和申诉权。 

2.  部长级的选举，由部门主管提名。决策小组成员具有投票资格，。主席副主席具有一票否

决权。社员具有监督权。可以向主席或副主席提出质疑。 

3.  小队指挥级干部，有各部门主管各自提名，全体成员具有投票权，若出现相同票数则由

决策小组商定。 

4.  换届选举全称在 Campus pulse  系统进行。决策小组成员有执行权，顾问团队行使最高

监督权。 

5.  竞选结果在 2016/12/15 自动生效。 

注：  决策小组成员实行内阁制，从部长级干部中抽调，由主席全权任免。 

麻省大学 CMA 国乐社 

主席              梁得康

DocsList.Name: Chinese Music Association Consititution, First Edition (WMQ), 2015.pdf
DocsList.Data:
Constitution of Chinese Music Association at the University of 
Massachusetts Amherst 

First Edition 

ARTICLE I - Name and Purpose 

Section 1 Name of the Organization: The organization shall be named Chinese Music 
Association 

Section 2 Purpose: The purpose of the Chinese Music Association is to facilitate and 
support activities that meet the academic, social, cultural, and professional needs of 
Chinese Music Association students at the University of Massachusetts Amherst. 

ARTICLE II - Membership, Membership Fees, Non-Discrimination Policy 

Section 1 General Definition of Membership: Membership shall be open to 
undergraduate students, graduate students and faculties at the University of 
Massachusetts Amherst. 

Section 2 Active Membership: Active members are those who pay annual membership 
fees which are set by the executive committee each year as they determine necessary.  

Section 3 Non-Discrimination Policy: The Chinese Music Association does not 
discriminate for any purpose on the basis of race, ethnicity, linguistic abilities, religion, 
sexual identity, political affiliation, disability status, or marital status. 

 
 ARTICLE III - Officers, Duties, and Terms  

Executive committee 

Title 

President 

Vice 
President 

Secretary 

Treasurer 

Responsibilities 

•   Representing the organization in outreaching and fund raising 
•   Production director of the shows, concerts and other events 

•   Organizing meetings 
•   Execute director of shows, events and fund raising. 
•   Personnel Representative 

•   Coordinating social media on behalf of the organization 
•   Election Committee Chair 

•   Funding and Finance 
•   Serve as GSS Representative 

ARTICLE IV - Election and Appointment Procedures  

Section 1 Election Schedule: The election for the president and vice president positions 
shall be held at the end of April of each year. The election day shall be announced in the 
immediately prior general meeting. 

Members are appointed to committees by the president of the Association. The date of 
appointment expiration is given after each name. The Constitution provides that the 
president shall be ex officio a member of all committees except the Nominating 
Committee, the Election Committee.  

Section 2 Nomination Schedule: 10 days before the election, a notice shall be thoroughly 
distributed by the secretary to announce the election and to invite nominations for each 
position. 

Section 3 Nomination Eligibility: Any active member may be nominated for any position. 
Any active member may nominate any active member including her/himself. 

Section 4 Nomination Acceptance: 8 days before the election, each nominee shall be 
given one day to accept or decline the nomination of her/his name. Each nominee shall be 
only permitted to accept a nomination for one full position only. 

Section 5 Campaigning Period: Beginning 7 days before the election, each nominee shall 
be permitted to forward a statement to the secretary to be posted on a webpage devoted to 

 
 
 nominees’ statements. 

Section 6 Election Period: On days and times decided in the prior general meeting, a vote 
collection box shall be left in a neutral and secure area. A method for votes in absentia 
shall be determined in a general meeting. 

Section 7 Votes Counting: Votes shall be counted by a suitable, impartial third person. 

Section 8 Determinations: A winner shall receive a majority of votes. In the event of a tie, 
the leading candidates sharing the tie shall participate in a runoff election following the 
general procedures in sections 5 through 7. 

Section 9 Appointment Procedures: In the event of a sudden or continued vacancy in an 
executive position, the Chair may choose to appoint an active member to the position in a 
temporary manner until an election can be held for the position. 

ARTICLE V - Meetings 

Section 1 General Meetings: The meeting will be held in the first week of every month.  

Section 2 Special Meetings: Special meetings may be held in person, by conference call, 
or by other electronic means. Every officers on the executive board can call for a special 
meeting. 
Section 3 Rules of Conduct and Speech: Follow the Roberts Rules but may also allow 
some flexibility. 

Section 4: Voting. 50% is required to pass a measure, 20% members are required to 
attend a meeting in order for a vote to happen. 

ARTICLE VI - Rights and Privileges of Members  

Section 1 General Rights of Members 

•   To receive notice of general meetings and of proposed special resolutions; 
•   To submit items of business for consideration at a general meeting; 
•   To attend and be heard at general meetings; 
•   To have access to the minutes of general meetings and other documents of 

the association. 

The rights of a member are not transferable and end when membership ceases. 

 
 Section 2 Voting Rights of Active Members 

•   To vote at a general meeting; 
•   To elect and nominate executive committee members. 

Section 3 Other Rights of Active Members 

•   To inspect the register of members; 
•   To participate in the practices and rehearsals; 
•   To play the instruments from the association; 
•   To have the access to the notes and records of the pieces shared within the 

association; 

•   To perform and advocate on behalf of the organization. 

ARTICLE VII – Committees  

Standing Committee members: 

Minqi Wang, President, Food Science PhD, 2016 

Anthony Tracia, Vice-President, Music Education, MA, 2016 

Qianzhi Jiang, Secretary, Nutrition, PhD, 2016 

Mengxuan Zhang, Treasure, MA, 2016 

•   Committees necessary officers (President, Vice president secretary, etc) at first 

meeting 

•   Committee shall maintain minutes and attendance for every meeting 
•   Each Committee shall present a annual summary of their work and achievements 

to the Council on Standing Committees 

•   All committees shall operate on a year from September 1 – May 31 

ARTICLE VIII - Amendments to the Constitution (how are amendments to the 
constitution proposed and approved?) 

Section 1 Proposal: A member may propose an amendment by distributing it in written 
format and reading it aloud in a meeting. Voting of a proposal may not take place in the 
same meeting as that in which the proposal was made. Following the meeting, the 
proposal shall be made known to all members of the CGSA. 

 
 
 
 Section 2 Approval: During the next general meeting, and only after a thorough 
discussion to the satisfaction of all members present for the voting of a proposal, a vote 
shall be taken on its approval provided that quorum is available. The amendment must 
secure two thirds of the votes available during the meeting. 

Section 3 Recording: Any successful amendment shall be recorded and copies of the new 
constitution shall be presented on the CGSA website and made available in paper format. 
Two paper copies shall be stored for record-keeping purposes.

DocsList.Name: Constitution of Choral Dilemma.pdf
DocsList.Data:
CONSTITUTION 

Preamble: We, the students and musicians at the University of Massachusetts (UMass) 
Amherst, hereby establish the co-ed a cappella performance group known as Choral 
Dilemma. 

Article I. Mission Statement: To provide the UMass community with enriching, meaningful 
entertainment while expanding the spectrum of musical diversity by performing renditions of 
various genres of music. 

Article II. Association with other a cappella groups: With the cooperation of other a cappella 
groups on campus, we will collaborate with said groups in arrangements and performances. 
Other groups will be notified at least one month in advance to a collaboration request. 

Article III. Membership criteria: Members of this group will audition with the knowledge that: 

a) They must be enrolled and attending full-time at UMass. Select exceptions can be 
made given the following circumstances: 

i) The individual is a graduate student with an occupation either on or outside 
University premises, but still studies at the University. 

ii) The individual chooses to participate in a study-abroad program, in which case 
the individual’s membership will be temporarily suspended until they return to 
study at the University. 

iii) The individual provides officers with otherwise sufficient reason to make an 
exception. 

b) They must agree and comply with the mission statement of the group. 

c) They must attend rehearsals, performances and other group activities which are 
integral to the betterment of the group as a whole (select exceptions can be made 
following administrative approval). 

Article IV. Auditioning new members. Auditions are held invariably at the beginning of each 
academic year, no more than two weeks into the semester. Auditions will be open to all who 
meet/respect the criteria outlined in Article III, and those with the most appropriate voice part (a 
good personality is also an enormous boost for chance of selection) will be selected as members 
of Choral Dilemma. Size of the group may vary based on various factors (number of individuals 
auditioning, graduating members, suspensions/expulsions, etc.). 

Article V. Duties, responsibilities, and privileges entailing Choral Dilemma membership: 
Membership with Choral Dilemma allows an individual to rehearse, perform, and 
socialize/consort with other members of the group. 

 
 
 Section I. Necessary and indispensable responsibilities of all members are as follows: 

a) Arriving on time to/attend all rehearsals, performances, and events (unless 
officers are provided with a legitimate excuse for otherwise). 

b) To the best of their ability, keeping their voice in the best possible shape for 
singing (with consideration of cold seasons/flu seasons, allergies, etc.). 

c) Learning music during their own time so as to practice, fine-tune, and perfect it 
during rehearsal. Music scores will be uploaded to Noteflight or other similar 
databases, or otherwise made accessible for members to learn. 

d) Offering feedback and constructive criticism on rehearsals, performances, and 
arrangements, as this will: 

i. Increase our functionality as a unit. 

ii. Contribute to the improvement and cohesion of the group as a whole. 

Section II. Various privileges of members include, but are not limited to: 

a) Voting. 

b) Group activities outside of rehearsals and/or performances, such as food 
arrangements, hang-outs, or other social gatherings. 

c) Membership on social media (i.e. group chats, Facebook pages, etc.). 

These privileges can be permanently revoked in the case of repeated truancy, misconduct, 
or any other action that violates the statutes outlined in this Constitution. 

Article VI. Absence and Tardiness Policies: Absence from and tardiness to rehearsals, 
performances, and other group activities will not be tolerated without a valid, verifiable excuse. 
In the event that repeated unexcused absences or tardiness occur(s), disciplinary action will 
follow, in addition to serious consideration by the officers so as to see whether or not the 
individual is qualified to remain a member of Choral Dilemma. Full commitment on the part of 
every member is required (with consideration to academics, jobs, and other mandatory duties), 
and all responsibilities should be taken seriously. 

Article VII. Non-Discrimination Clause: Choral Dilemma agrees to adhere to all policies and 
procedures outlined by UMass Amherst and any/all local, state, and federal laws and legislations. 
Members of the group can familiarize themselves with these policies in the UMass Code of 
Student Conduct. This organization is a functioning organization of UMass Amherst composed 
of at least ten people and will in no way discriminate based on race, creed, religion, color, 
gender, age, ethnicity, handicap, sexual orientation, or other diverse factors. 

Article VIII. Officers: The six officers of Choral Dilemma and their election criteria will be 
discussed in this article. 

Section 1: Titles. The six different officers will have the following titles: 

 
 
 
 Sub-section I: President. The President of Choral Dilemma will fulfill the 
following duties: 

a) Organizing and planning all rehearsals and rehearsal times. 

b) Initial contact with other a cappella groups for potential collaborations. 

c) Registry of the group as a Resident Student Organization (RSO) 

d) Handling of all the required paperwork for the continuation of the 
organization. 

e) Receiving of all information from the office of Student Activities and 
Involvement office. 

The President holds the authority to make the final decision in group 
discussions, with the knowledge that the decisions that they make will 
always be made for the best interest of the group. 

Sub-section II: Vice President. The Vice President of Choral Dilemma will take 
the place of the President in the event that the President is absent, unable to 
perform their respective tasks, or offers their resignation as President. The Vice 
President will also fulfill the following duties: 

a) Acting as a resource for the President and the group when it comes to 
finding out needed information. 

b) Organizing, analyze, and present information received from other RSOs 
on campus. 

The Vice President will also have a substantial influence in group 
decisions. 

Sub-section III: Secretary. The Secretary will fulfill the following duties: 

a) Keeping organized records of all group activities  

b) Keeping track of attendance at all group meetings (rehearsals, 
performances, etc.) 

c) Serving as group historian by being able to produce and replicate 
accurate records of everything that has happened in the group thus far – 
from inception to present day – including, but not limited to: 

i) Performances. 

ii) Collaborations. 

iii) Conflicts regarding the group. 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 iv) Interactions involving any exchange of money (records to be 
obtained from the Treasurer). 

d) Maintaining group membership list and email database. 

Sub-section IV: Treasurer. The Treasurer will fulfill the following duties: 

a) Responsibly and efficiently handling all group expenditures and 
revenues. 

b) Writing all necessary checks and have them signed by the office of 
Student Activities and Involvement. 

c) Requesting necessary funds from the University’s allocation committee. 

d) Maintaining all group ledgers and account records. 

Sub-section V: Public Relations Chair. The Public Relations (PR) Chair will 
fulfill the following duties: 

a) Promoting the group. 

b) Printing flyers, posters, brochures, etc. 

c) Making sure that the group’s voice is heard through the persistent use of 
social media (Facebook, Twitter, e-mail, etc.) 

d) Entering information onto University webpages and submitting 
appropriate press releases to the appropriate media sources. 

Sub-section VI: Music Director. The Music Director will fulfill the following 
duties: 

a) Arranging and finalizing all scores. It should be noted that arranging 
music is not a responsibility that falls solely on the shoulders of the music 
director – anybody who wishes to propose or submit an arrangement of 
any suggested song should feel free to do so. 

b) Conducting rehearsals in a way such that rehearsal time is used in the 
most efficient and productive manner. The Music Director should make 
sure that members are using their rehearsal time to practice their music (in 
part sectionals, as a group, etc.) and hone their sound. Going off-task 
should not be a regular occurrence. 

c) Making sure that everybody can obtain access to all available scores, 
whether via hard copy or electronically. 

d) Making sure that the group’s morale doesn’t sink. 

Section II: Qualifications of Officers. All officers must meet the criteria outlined in 
Article III and must be able to remain an officer for a full academic year. Officers must 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 also be regarded as responsible, driven, and fitting for their position by other members of 
the group. 

Section III: Election Process. Towards the end of the spring semester, there will be a 
portion of rehearsal dedicated to nomination of members for Board positions. The 
following rehearsal, nominees should come prepared with a brief and concise explanation 
of their qualifications and potentiality for this position. At the end of this rehearsal, group 
members will vote using a secret ballot (Google Forms, physical paper, or otherwise). 
Each individual will be afforded one vote per position. At the end of the process, the 
president will count the votes, and those voted will assume their official positions the 
following fall semester, using the summer to prepare to hold office. In the event of a tie, a 
revote will occur, using the names of those individuals whose were tied. 

Section IV: Number of Titles. With the exception of a President-Vice-President 
combination, any one individual is allowed to hold more than one title, given that a 
proportionate amount of dutifulness, responsibility and good judgment is seen to be 
exhibited by this individual. 

Section V: Disciplining of Officers/Officer Removal Process. In the unfortunate event 
that an officer needs to be rebuked, disciplined, or removed from the group, action will be 
taken by the President and Vice President (unless it is one of these two officers which 
needs to be disciplined; in which case, disciplinary action will be taken by the Secretary 
and all following ranks). These officers will try to keep the situation under control and 
confer privately with the problematic officer. This private conference should be 
considered a warning to the officer. However, if problems persist, they will receive one 
final warning before any titles will be revoked. A meeting will be organized to discuss 
the following with the officer in question: 

a) Potential disciplinary action should the improper behavior not subside. 

b) Any misunderstandings that may have led to this conflict. 

c) What the officer should begin to do in order to avoid disciplinary action. 

At this meeting, the questioning officers will present the problematic officer with 
verifiable, specific examples of repeated misconduct. The officer under investigation will 
be given a fair, unbiased, and legitimate chance to explain their behavior/defend 
themselves. By the time the end of this meeting is reached, everybody present should be 
on the same page as to current and future expectations. If, in spite of this meeting, 
problems yet persist and no ability to improve is exhibited by this officer, then all titles 
will be revoked with no further chance to appeal. 

Section VI: Resignation of an Officer. At the request of the group, any officer wishing to 
resign (from either their post as an officer or their membership in Choral Dilemma) must 
submit a proper notice of at least two weeks in order to allow the group time to appoint a 
new officer that could assume the forgone position immediately after the incumbent 
officer resigns. In the event that an officer unexpectedly resigns, the President and/or 

 
 
 
 Vice President will assume all necessary responsibilities of this position until the group 
has had sufficient time to nominate and elect a new officer. 

Article IX. Conflicts: Conflicts in the group will be handled in the following manner: 

Section I: Conflicts related to the well-being and progress of the group – that is, intra-group 
conflicts  –  will  be  addressed  by  the  affected  parties  and  brought  to  the  attention  of  the 
President and Vice President. These officers will act in such a fashion that doesn’t disturb 
the  focus  of  the  rest  of  the  group,  and  will  take  necessary  and  appropriate  disciplinary 
action (similar to that outlined in Article VIII, Section V). 

Section II: Conflicts unrelated to the well-being and progress of the group – that is, inter-
personal conflicts within the group – will be addressed by the affected parties and will be 
either: 

a)  Handled  by  the  affected  parties  in  a  manner  that  solves  the  issue  while  not 
contributing to the loss of group focus, 

or 

b) Brought to the attention of the appropriate offices of the University (i.e. Dean of 
Students Office, UMass Police Department, or any other related offices). 

Conflicts that are unrelated to the well-being and progress of the group will not be brought 
to the attention of the group (they can be discussed with the President and Vice President 
if necessary) so as not to hinder group performance and/or lower morale. Any individual(s) 
found in violation this law will be subject to disciplinary action by the officers and potential 
expulsion from the group. 

Article X. Probation, Suspensions, and Expulsions: In the event that misconduct is shown by any 
individual, that individual will be given a warning. If the warning goes unheeded, the individual 
will be given another warning and will be subject to a probation period. During this period, if the 
individual continues to exhibit poor behavior, the individual will be issued one final warning and 
a threat of potential suspension if the behavior continues. A meeting similar to the one outlined in 
Article  VIII,  Section  V  will  be  set  up,  in  which  the  individual  under  investigation  will  have  a 
chance to  explain their  behavior/defend themselves.  If further misconduct  should continue, the 
individual will have their membership suspended for a period of no less than one month (further 
time may vary based on severity of misconduct and fair discretion of officers). At the end of this 
suspension period, when the individual returns, if the misconduct continues, the individual will be 
expelled from the group with no further chance to appeal. 

Examples of misconduct that could lead to any of the aforementioned consequences are: 

a) Persistently negative attitudes that harm the morale of the group. 

b) Harassment of any kind from any individual. 

c) Neglect of responsibilities. 

 
 d) Failure to treat all members with respect, fairness, and good-naturedness. 

e) Failure to abide by the rules and statutes established by this Constitution. 

Any member who feels like another individual meets any of the criteria above should promptly 
notify the President and/or Vice President, and these officers will take appropriate action. 

Article XI. Rehearsals and Group Meetings: Depending on members’ schedules and availabilities, 
the group will meet between 2 and 3 times a week, which is the estimated amount of time necessary 
to  accomplish  the  tasks  fundamental  to  group  advancement,  with  consideration  to  schoolwork, 
jobs, and other aspects of members’ lives. The days, times, and locations of these meetings will be 
decided accordingly by group members. Amount of meetings may vary depending on: 

a) Impending performances. 

b) Exams. 

c) Other obligations. 

It should be noted that all meetings are mandatory and are to be promptly attended on time by all 
members, unless given a prior legitimate excuse for otherwise. 

Article XII. By-laws: A 2/3 or simple majority vote of the organization is required to establish, 
approve, and enforce any proposed by-laws or changes in existing by-laws. 

Article  XIII.  Disbursal  of  Organizational  Assets  in  the  event  that  Choral  Dilemma  becomes 
defunct:  The  University  of  Massachusetts  Amherst  will  inherit  the  assets  of  Choral  Dilemma 
should said group become defunct for any reason. 

Article XV. Group Quorum: A minimum of 60% of all members must be present at any given 
meeting in order for business to be conducted legally. 

Article  XVI. Amending  this Constitution:  A 2/3  or simple majority  vote  of the organization is 
required  to  establish,  approve,  and  enforce  any  proposed  amendments  to  this  Constitution. 
Members must be notified of an amendment no less than one week prior to its ratification. 

Article  XVII.  Ratifying  this Constitution:  A 2/3  or simple majority vote  of the organization is 
required to ratify this Constitution, in addition to the approval of the office of Student Activities 
and Involvement. 

Choral Dilemma President: _______________________________________________________ 

Choral Dilemma Vice President: ___________________________________________________ 

Student Activities Staff Member: __________________________________________________ 

This Constitution is effective ____________________________.

DocsList.Data:
CIRCLE K INTERNATIONAL
Standard Form for Club Bylaws

ARTICLE I - Name

Section 1:
The name of this organization shall be, “The Circle K International Club of the University of Massachusetts Amherst”.

ARTICLE II - Sponsorship

Section 1:
Its form of organization, its ideals, and its purpose shall be similar to those of the Kiwanis Club of Northampton.

Section 2:
It shall be sponsored by, work with, but not be a part of the Kiwanis Club of Northampton.

Section 3:
The Kiwanis Club of Northampton shall assume full responsibility for all chartering costs.
a.   The Kiwanis Club of Northampton is not responsible for the fiscal responsibility of the CKI Club of the University of
Massachusetts Amherst but should be able to help in the role of advising the club regarding financial matters.
b.   The Kiwanis Club of Northampton may make a monetary donation if it is helpful to the CKI club and with the approval of the
Kiwanis Club of Northampton and the CKI Club of the University of Massachusetts Amherst.

ARTICLE III - Objects and Vision

Section 1:
The objects of this club shall be:

●
●
●
●
●
●
●
●
●
●
●
●
●
●
●

●

To develop college and university students into responsible citizens and leaders with a lifelong commitment to service;
To collaborate with all members of the Kiwanis family to achieve our common objectives;
To develop positive role models;
To enhance intercultural understanding and cooperation;
To increase our service potential;
To provide opportunities for fellowship, personal growth, professional development, and leadership skills;
To work towards greater public recognition of the organization;
To emphasize the advantages of the democratic way of life;
To serve on the campus and in the community;
To encourage participation in group activities;
To develop aggressive citizenship and the spirit of service for the improvement of all human relationships;
To give primacy to the human and spiritual rather than to the material values of life;
To promote the adoption and the application of high social, business, and professional standards;
To develop, by precept and example, more intelligent, aggressive, and serviceable citizenship;
To provide through CKI clubs a practical means to form enduring friendships, render altruistic service, and to build
better communities;
To cooperate in creating and maintaining that sound public opinion and high idealism which makes possible the
increase in righteousness, justice, patriotism, and goodwill.

Section 2:
The vision of this club shall be:
To be the leading global community-service organization on college and university campuses that enriches the world one
member, one child, and one community at a time.







































































































 Section 3:
The mission of this club shall be:
CKI develops college and university students into a global network of responsible citizens and leaders with a lifelong
commitment to service. To provide student’s with volunteer opportunities on and off campus such as helping to clean up local
neighborhoods in Amherst, helping nonprofit organizations by hosting fun fundraisers, and engaging in the thirst and unicef
project affiliated with local key clubs and circle k organizations around the New England district.

Section 4:
The Circle K member pledge shall be:
“I pledge to uphold the Objects of Circle K International, to foster compassion and goodwill toward others through service and
leadership, to develop my abilities and the abilities of all people, and to dedicate myself to the realization of humanity’s
potential”.

ARTICLE IV - Motto

Section 1:
The motto of this club and of Circle K shall be “Live to Serve, Love to Serve.”

ARTICLE V - Membership

Section 1:
Membership of this club shall be in accordance with the following:

● Any student officially enrolled for at least part-time status, as defined by the University of Massachusetts Amherst, may

be granted active membership in said club.

●

The Circle K Club of University Massachusetts Amherst prohibits discrimination under Federal and State law, based on

race, color, national origin, religion, sex, gender identity (including gender expression), sexual orientation, disability,

age, marital status, family/parental status, income derived from a public assistance program, veteran status, citizenship,

genetic information, political beliefs, or reprisal or retaliation for prior civil rights activity.

●

If a member has not graduated, they have thirty (30) days to meet enrollment, academic or minimum membership

requirements before his or her membership will cease. Upon a member’s graduation, membership will cease on

September 30 of the same CKI administrative year.

● Any person, who holds membership (other than honorary) in any other CKI club, or other Kiwanis-family

organizations, shall not be eligible for active membership in this club.

Section 2:
Hazing in any form is strictly prohibited. Hazing is considered an interference with personal liberty, and includes, any act of
domination by any student over others that may lead to physical or emotional injury and discomfort. Hazing involving forced
consumption of alcohol or drugs for the purpose of initiation or affiliation with any organization is specifically prohibited.

Section 3:
A member in good standing shall be in accordance with the following:

Payment of the district per-member fee and international fees.

●
● At least a part-time student at a college or university.
●
●

Part of a club that is considered “active.”
Part of a district that is considered “active.”







































































































 ARTICLE VI – Officers

Section 1:
The elected officers of this club shall be a president, one or more vice president(s), either a secretary-treasurer or a secretary, a
treasurer, and a bulletin editor. All officers shall be active members in good standing with this club. They shall serve for one (1)
year or until their successors are elected and are qualified.

Section 2:
The duties of the officers shall be as follows:

a.

b.

c.

d.

e.

The president shall be the executive officer of this club and shall preside over all meetings of the club and the Board of
Officers. The president shall appoint committee members with the board officers. The president shall be an ex-officio
member of all standing and special committees. The president shall present the views of the club to the district in
relation to the club. As the official representative of the club, the president shall promote the growth of CKI on campus
and within the community. The president shall cooperate with their sponsoring Kiwanis club and promote
Kiwanis-family relations. They shall act as one of the delegates of the club at the district convention, and it shall be this
person’s responsibility to have this club represented at both the district and international convention by two voting
delegates. The outgoing president, in conjunction with the Kiwanis and faculty advisors, shall make provisions for the
training of the new Board of Officers prior to their installation. The president shall perform such other duties as usually
pertain to the office of the president or may be assigned by the Board of Officers. The president shall have signature
responsibility.
The vice president, in the absence of the president, shall preside at all meetings of this club and of the Board of
Officers, and shall be directly responsible to the president for all committee activities The vice-president shall also
perform such other duties as usually pertaining to the office, or as may be assigned by the president or the Board of
Officers. The vice president shall have signature responsibility.
The secretary shall record accurate minutes of the meeting; shall maintain the club’s permanent records; shall update
all addresses; shall publish the club bulletin, and shall perform such other duties as pertaining to this office or as may
be assigned by the club president or the Board of Officers.
The treasurer shall collect and disburse member dues; shall prepare and adhere to an approved budget; shall maintain
accurate records; shall transact business through a bank or school account; shall keep the Board of Officers informed of
the financial strengths and weaknesses of the club; shall order club supplies; shall have the books audited; shall
communicate with the district officers; shall file appropriate forms with the IRS if necessary; shall inform the
sponsoring Kiwanis club of this club’s financial status, and shall perform such other duties as pertains to this office or
as may be assigned by the club president or the Board of Officers.
The bulletin editor shall maintain the social media accounts, newsletter, and website (if applicable) of the club; shall
promote and advertise the initiatives and events of the club to recruit new members and highlight club and membership
achievements.

Section 3:
Any member may recommend the removal of a club officer to the Board of Officers. The officer who has received the formal
complaint shall be notified via email of the scheduling of a meeting to discuss their removal. The officer who has received the
formal complaint has five business days to respond to the complaint and work with the board to schedule a hearing. The Board of
Officers shall hold the hearing at which the officer in question shall be present their case to the membership. The Board of
Officers will then present their findings to the club at which time a vote by 2/3 of the quorum is required to remove the officer in
question. In the event any officer should be removed from office, the officer shall be notified in writing by the secretary.

Section 4:
In the event of a vacancy in the president's office, the vice president shall succeed. If two or more vice presidents hold office in
this club, one of them shall be elected to fill the vacancy by a majority vote of the entire active club membership of this club at
the next regularly scheduled meeting. In the event of a vacancy in any other office, a majority vote of the active membership of
this club present and voting at the next regularly scheduled meeting shall elect a member in good standing to serve for the
remainder of the unexpired term.







































































































 Section 5:
No elected club officer may hold an elected district or international office in addition to their club office.

ARTICLE VII - Board of Officers

The elected officers, in addition to the faculty advisor, the Kiwanis advisor, and if applicable the immediate past club president
shall constitute the Board of Officers (Executive Board) for this club. The faculty advisor and the Kiwanis advisor shall be
non-voting, ex-officio members of the Board of Officers.

Section 1:
The Board of Officers of this club shall consist of the elected officers, the faculty advisor, the Kiwanis advisor,  and if applicable
the immediate past club president. The faculty advisor and the Kiwanis advisor shall be nonvoting, ex-officio members of the
Board of Officers.

Section 2:
The Board of Officers shall approve the budget, approve all bills, take counsel with committees, discipline members, review and
report to Kiwanis the performance of the club officers, set membership requirements, and perform such other duties as shall be
referred to it by the club, in compliance with these Bylaws and the requirements of CKI.

Section 3:
The Board of Officers shall meet at least once per month during the school year, and at least once during the summer term, at a
time and place that it shall determine, and at such other times as the president or a majority of its voting members deem
necessary.

ARTICLE VIII - Election of Club Officers

Section 1:
Election of officers shall be held at a regularly scheduled meeting at least two (2) weeks prior to the district convention and
before April 1st of the academic year. All elected officers shall assume their official duties on April 1st following their election.
They shall serve for one (1) year or until their successors are duly elected and installed.

Section 2:
All officers who are members in good standing are eligible for re-election.

Section 3:
Officers shall be nominated by any member of the club at least one week prior to the election date. Elections must be held during
a regularly scheduled general body meeting with two-thirds (2/3rd) of the active SGA members in the RSO in attendance.

Section 4:
The election of officers shall be conducted by physical or electronic ballot. A member shall be voted in when a majority of the
quorum present is obtained. Once a candidate has been elected and announced, there shall be a vote to destroy (or delete) the
ballots.

Section 5:
In the event of a tie for any of the offices, the remaining candidates will be removed from the ballot and the two candidates shall
be voted on again.

a.

In the event that only two candidates are running for an office and the vote results in a tie then each candidate will be
given one and a half (1.5) minutes to speak to the membership and another vote will be taken. In the event of another
tie, the club president shall cast a tie-breaking vote.

ARTICLE IX - Club Meetings







































































































 Section 1:
During the school year, the club shall hold monthly meetings on such days and at such places as shall be determined by the club
officers and the club members. It may hold such other meetings as the officers or the membership may desire. In the event that
unusual conditions prevent a weekly meeting, this club may hold a minimum of two meetings per month, with the officers
meeting on all other weeks.

Section 2:
The quorum at a club meeting shall be considered a majority (50 percent plus one) of the active club membership and is required
for business to be legally transacted.

Section 3:
Club meetings shall be chaired by the club president (or vice president where the president is unavailable) and present the
business of the club which could include but is not limited to upcoming service opportunities, upcoming events, or leadership
opportunities. Club meetings may host workshops, guest speakers, or service projects at the discretion of the Board of Officers.

Section 4:
Decisions shall be made in accordance with Parliamentary Procedure and Roberts Rules.

ARTICLE X - Committees

Section 1:
The president and vice president(s) shall appoint committee chairs and members to the recommended committees below if
deemed appropriate:

a. Membership Experience
b. Kiwanis Family Relations
Service & Fundraising
c.
Public Relations
d.
Events
e.

Section 2:
The duties of the standing committees shall be as follows:

a.

b.

c.

d.

e.

The Membership Experience Committee shall devise effective plans to obtain new members on a regular basis and
educate members about the organization.
The Kiwanis Family Relations Committee shall educate the membership about the other branches of the Kiwanis
family and plan projects and activities that involve the CKI club with other branches of the Kiwanis family.
The Service & Fundraising Committee shall plan projects and activities promoting and supporting the club’s service
initiatives and/or CKI’s Preferred Charities and Service Partners.
The Public Relations Committee shall be responsible for informing the campus and local community of the CKI’s
activities and goals through various forms of communication.
The Event Committee shall plan activities that will promote fellowship and strengthen friendships within the club and
throughout the entire Kiwanis Family.

Section 3:
The club president has the right to form any special committee deemed necessary for normal club function.

ARTICLE XI - Kiwanis and Faculty Advisor

Section 1:
This club shall have one (1) faculty or staff advisor which the club shall turn to when in need of advising from the college or
faculty level.  A faculty/staff advisor to the Circle K club will be appointed by the unanimous decision of the officers of the club
and with the consent of the nominee. The faculty/staff advisor shall be invited and encouraged to attend all meetings.

(Please complete Section 2 if you have a Kiwanis sponsor)







































































































 Section 2:
This club shall have one (1) Kiwanis advisor which the club shall turn to when in need of advising from the local Kiwanis level.
The Kiwanis advisor should be from the sponsoring Kiwanis Club. The Kiwanis advisor shall be invited and encouraged to attend
all meetings.
a.
b. Kiwanis Advisor: Mark Robinson

The Kiwanis advisor shall be appointed by the sponsoring Kiwanis club.

ARTICLE XII - Fees and Dues

Section 1:
The district per-member fee shall be $6 per member as dictated by the district bylaws, $24 per member for International fees, and
$12 for individual club dues.

Section 1:
Under no circumstances shall a member’s freedom of speech or expression be infringed.

ARTICLE XIII - Statement of Free Speech

ARTICLE XIV - Amendments

Section 1:
Proposed amendments to this constitution may be formulated by any active member in good standing of the general organization.

Section 2:
Amendments to these bylaws shall be adopted by a two-thirds (2/3) vote of the membership at any regular meeting and with
approval of The Undergraduate Registry Oversight Committee. Amendments must be submitted to the executive board at least
two weeks prior to when a vote shall take place.

DocsList.Data:
UMass Club Management Association of America Constitution  

Mission Statement 
The Club Management Association of America (CMAA) is the professional Association for 
managers of membership clubs. With close to 6,500 members across all classifications, our 
manager members run more than 2,500 country, golf, city, athletic, faculty, yacht, town and 
military clubs. The objectives of the Association are to promote and advance friendly relations 
among persons connected with the management of clubs and other associations of similar 
character; to encourage the education and advancement of its members; and to assist club 
officers and members, to secure the utmost in efficient and successful operations. As students, 
UMass CMAA members are encouraged to attend education meetings, club tours, hands-on 
education externships, club management education sessions, and the annual World Conference.  

Core Values and Guiding Principles: 

1. Professional Development: To provide a wide variety of educational programs and 

materials to meet the diverse educational needs of our members.  

2. Networking: Opportunities to network with other club management students and 
professionals in the industry through educational meetings and conferences. 

3. Education: Student and professional run education sessions about the different aspects of 

clubs, leadership, and student specific topics.  

4. Off-Campus Experiential Learning: Hands-on opportunities to learn about clubs through 

off campus club tours, educational externships, and conferences.  

National CMAA Industry Analysis for Students 

1. Seek to create best-in-class student internship/apprentice programs for engaging student’s 

interest and exposure to clubs.  

2. Aspire to have universities, university administrators, and faculty understand 

contemporary club management practices and club dynamics and are representing the 
same to students within the core curriculum.  

3. Evaluate and consider overarching National and Chapter strategies to recruit college 

students to work in club management. 

 Our club is primarily a hospitality based club but country clubs are so 

Vision For the Future:
diverse that they have opportunities for more than just hospitality students at UMass. The 
Hospitality and Tourism Department at UMass is losing students so we have to be more diverse 
in recruiting. We hope to expand to more majors such as turfgrass, marketing, and sports 
management. We also plan on explaining to our current hospitality students how clubs offer 
many different aspects of the industry such as food and beverage, event planning, sales, and 

 
 
 
 
​
 much more. We hope to become stronger as a club by participating in more club tours, 
fundraising events, and working with the senior chapters.  

Five Year Goals:  

Year 1: Grow membership by marketing ourselves to other majors at UMass 

● Go into the classrooms for different majors to promote our club 
● Don’t promote ourselves as just a hospitality focused club 
● Expand our education topics to be more inclusive of other majors 

Year 2: Reach a membership of 30 students 

● Go into every HTM class at the beginning of the fall semester to discuss the 

opportunities of being in CMAA 

● Do more tours and bonding activities in order to get people more involved 
● Retain upperclassmen  

Year 3:Fully fund all of our students to attend World Conference for the fifth year in a row 

● Work the GreatHorse member-guest tournament and other work opportunities if 

possible 

● Create a strong budget for the SGA  
● Apply for scholarships through the HTM Department  

Year 4:  Have a 75% internship and post-grad job acceptance within our club 

● Find out where members live and research clubs in the area 
● Try to bring more students to World Conference 
● Bring more students to the New England Club Management Association Dinner 

to network with managers in the area 

Year 5: Attend more education sessions 

● Try to create a club management panel that UMass, UNH, and Johnson and Wales 

club management students can all attend 

● Work with NECMA to make monthly education sessions more accessible to 

students 

● Have at least 5 students attend Student Conference and 10 students attend World 

Conference  

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 New Members 
Determining Eligibility for Student Membership 
Any individual who is enrolled at an accredited, college, university or school for undergraduate 
or graduate students is eligible to apply for student membership. Applications for membership 
are to be supported by the Faculty Advisor or the dean of the school. Such membership does not 
entitle the holder to vote, hold elective office in the Association or transfer to any other category 
of membership. Student members who are no longer enrolled at a college/university, upon 
attaining a full time manager/assistant manager position and within two years of graduating, 
must apply for Professional membership. 

Submitting an Application to National Headquarters 
Once the chapter has approved the applicant for membership in the chapter, the Chapter Secre- 
tary should submit a completed application signed by the Chapter Liaison Manager, Chapter 
President, and Faculty Advisor to the National Headquarters along with the proper fees. Please 
keep the yellow copy for the chapter’s records. Annual student dues are currently $50. Students 
will also be required to pay a chapter fee for the UMass Chapter which varies according to the 
Executive Board each year.  

For memberships that become effective between April 1 and August 31 in any year, 50 percent 
of these dues will be applied to the following fiscal year. Memberships that become effective on 
or after September 1 in any year shall be exempt from dues for the remainder of that fiscal year 
and the entire amount shall be applied to the ensuing year’s dues. The Association’s fiscal year is 
November 1 – October 31. 

Chapter Criteria 
National Requirements 
The first step to successful chapter management is to make sure that your chapter is meeting the 
criteria necessary for a student chapter to exist. A chapter must meet the following criteria to 
maintain its charter: 

 Student chapters must have a minimum of 10 student members at all times. 

1.
2. Each chapter is to hold a minimum of seven meetings during the school year, four of 
which must be educational. Reports of ALL meetings must be sent to the National 
Headquarters within 15 days following the meeting. 

3. Each student chapter must include a minimum of one club tour each year. This may be 
considered one of the four educational meetings and minutes should be sent to the 
National Headquarters. 

4. Within three years of being granted a chapter charter, the university/college must have a 

club management course as part of its curriculum. 

 
 
 
 
 5. The chapter President must submit an annual report to CMAA’s Chief Executive Officer 

by May 1 of each year or 15 days after the last chapter meeting, whichever is first. 
Further explanation and forms are available online at 
www.cmaa.org/studentchapterofficers.aspx

. 
6. At the end of each school year, each chapter is reviewed by the Chapter/Member Services 

Committee to determine if chapter requirements have been met. Failure to meet the 
criteria may result in the chapter’s loss of its charter. 

UMass Requirements 

1. Have at least 10 undergraduate students at all times 
2. Ensure all RSO trainings are completed  
3. Submit a budget each year to the SGA 
4. Attend all SGA required meetings 
5. Update Campus Pulse and all UMass CMAA social media sites (Instagram, Facebook, 

LinkedIn, Weebly) each semester 

Meetings and Officer Positions 
UMass CMAA meets on a Weekly basis unless there is an HTM event, club tour, bonding event, 
or University Sanctioned Holiday on the meeting date. The meeting day, time, and location is 
decided each semester by the the Executive Board and promoted through emails and social 
media sites. Once the meeting time is decided, the president is responsible for submitting a room 
request through Isenberg for a classroom meeting space for the semester.  

Meetings will range from different education topics about clubs, professional development, and 
guest speakers. Each meeting begins with housekeeping topics to let members know what future 
events are coming up and then goes into the educational topic of the meeting. Past topics have 
included cover letters, resumes, Linkedin workshops, how to make the most of your 
internship/job, applying for internships/jobs, and careers in club management.  

President 

● Organize eboard and club to be the most successful that it can be for the duration of the 

academic year and future 

● Work with faculty advisor and past president to learn ins and outs of chapter and CMAA 

leadership 

● Be the leader in networking with club and industry professionals as the face of CMAA – 

contacting and updating NECMA chapter with Jeff Isbel as liaison 

● Schedule meeting times and reserve meeting room 

​
 
 
 
 
 ● Apply for Jake Hoffman Scholarship in March, complete Chapter of the Year Application 
and submit in January, submit Presidents report in May, NECMA presence in October, 
and David Meador presence in October, 

● Find work experience opportunities for the chapter to use as fundraisers and for 

experience (GreatHorse and Westmoor) 

● Plan externship 

○ Help faculty advisor with application process 
○ Detailed planning on student end including transportation, contact information, 

education sessions, accommodation, activities, interviewing, host clubs 

○ Be in contact with managers for any information they need and you need from 

them 

○ Attend and be a student leader during the week 

● Plan world conference and student conference 
○ Research and make hotel reservations 
○ Make agenda with required student education for the week 
○ Gather all travel, contact info and other details from members 
○ Network with managers to introduce students and find opportunities for them 
○ Attend a be a student leader during the week 

● Chair weekly eboard meetings and chapter meetings – create agendas for each 
● Expose members to network and benefits of a CMAA membership, the club industry by 

running weekly education topics at meetings 

● Attend all weekly eboard and chapter meeting, attend and participate in ALL CMAA 

events 

Vice President 

● Take Signature Response (SR) training for RSO’s through SAI office RSO Financial 
● Training and RSO Event Planning and Organizational Development on moodle as an SR 
● Work with president to create weekly powerpoints with topics decided by eboard, 

delegate different slides to make and present to executive board members 

● Work with Fundraising and Events Chair to plan guest speakers – either in person or by 

skype to give education and presentations to chapter meetings 
● Oversee club of the future projects working towards conference 
● ALL responsibilities listed under president are also that of VP, your responsibility to take 

tasks on and work directly with President to be successful 

● Attend all weekly eboard and chapter meeting, attend and participate in ALL CMAA 

events 

 
 
 
 
 Secretary 

● Manage CMAA email account including updating contacts list, answering all 

correspondence, sending weekly updates/meeting minutes, etc. 
● Keep track of member attendance at weekly meetings via attendance 
● Submit meeting minutes and meeting attendance to cmaa.org each week 
● Keep all member information and club records needed 
● Attend all weekly eboard and chapter meetings, attend and participate in ALL CMAA 

events 

Treasurer 

● Collect all dues and any payments to Club for any purpose and deposit them into account 
● Take Signature Response (SR) training for RSO’s through SAI office 
● RSO Financial Training and RSO Event Planning and Organizational Development on 

moodle as an SR 

● Responsible for keeping track of funds within account and purchasing materials/items for 

Club  

● Complete budget and submit to SAI office through Campus Pulse 
● Attend Academic Council Meetings to represent CMAA, usually monthly 
● Attend all weekly eboard and chapter meeting, attend and participate in ALL CMAA 

events 

Public and Member Relations 

● Set up and run tabling at all-school club fair and Isenberg club fair in September 
● Run social media outlets and update OFTEN with content: Instagram, Facebook, 

LinkedIn, website, campus pulse website 

● Post and send out job positions for members to see, on Facebook and via email 
● Save all photos to a file from the year from all CMAA events and members club activities 
● Publish a minimum of 1 newsletter per semester: Fall and Spring 
● Email newsletter to Jeff Isbel for NECMA website and post on all social media 
● Plasma boards in Isenberg 
● Attend all weekly eboard and chapter meeting, attend and participate in ALL CMAA 

events 

Fundraising and Events Coordinator 

● Plan events for members and eboard including events such as the GreatHorse 

Member-Guest Tournament fundraiser weekend, Nantucket work weekend, NECMA 
Dinner 

○ Includes contacting clubs and professionals to tour, setting up details, arranging 

transportation for members 

 
 
 
 ● Plan club tours minimum of once per semester: Fall and Spring 
● Plan a fundraiser or volunteer event a minimum of once per semester: Fall and Spring 
● Work with the President, VP and rest of eboard to plan for World Conference. Including 

specifically: 

○ Hotel and lodging for members during conference 
○ Transportation for members to and during conference 
○ Round-tables with managers and professionals during conference 
○ Other activities for members during the week 

● Attend all weekly eboard and chapter meeting, attend and participate in ALL CMAA 

events 

Election Process 

1. Each year at the beginning of March, executive board position descriptions and 
applications are sent out via email for all club members to see and fill out  

2. Elections are to be held at the last meeting date before April 1st  
3. Elections must be held during a regularly scheduled general body meeting with two-third 

of the active members in the club in attendance  

4. Students who gain the majority of votes win 

a.

If a vote results in a tie, the outgoing president will break the tie 

Special Elections or Filling Vacancies 
If an executive board member or member is to be removed for any reason, these are the steps that 
should be taken: 

1. The officer/member in question must be notified of their removal 
2. The officer/member will have an opportunity to address the membership 
3. At least a two-thirds vote of the general membership shall be required to remove the 

officer/member  

Free Speech  
Under no circumstances shall a member’s freedom of speech or expression be infringed in any 
way through UMass CMAA. 

Non-Discrimination 
UMass CMAA prohibits discrimination under Federal and State law, based on race, color, 
national origin, religion, sex, gender identity (including gender expression), sexual orientation, 
disability, age, marital status, family/parental status, income derived from a public assistance 
program, political beliefs, or reprisal or retaliation for prior civil rights activity. No one shall be 
excluded from the group.  

 
 
 
 
 
 Amendments to the Constitution 
To make an amendment to the UMass CMAA constitution at any time, a simple majority vote of 
two-thirds of the general membership is required, as well as the approval of the Secretary of the 
 to inform them 
Registry. Whenever an amendment is to be made, email 
of the changes that are being made.  

sgaregistry@umass.edu

​

DocsList.Name: Spring 2021 Constitution UMass Club Water Polo.pdf
DocsList.Data:
UMass Water Polo Constitution

Last Amended: 3/21/21

Article I: Mission Statement

The University of Massachusetts Amherst Club Water Polo’s mission is to provide the University
and its students an opportunity to learn and play the sport of water polo at the national collegiate
club level by competing in the Collegiate Water Polo Association’s (CWPA) Club Colonial and
New England Divisions.  At all practices and events the club will teach its members teamwork,
responsibility, dedication, and sportsmanship both in and out of the water. The club will provide
fair playing time at all water polo events to all players who attend all practices and show a
dedication to the club.

Article II: Goals and Objectives

The UMass Club Water Polo goals and objectives are the following:

Section 1:
Teach the sport of water polo to all University students or faculty interested in the sport. The club
will be co-ed.

Section 2:
Provide a safe and judgment free environment for all participants

Section 3:
Allow any University student or faculty despite ethnic, racial, or economic status to be able to
participate at all UMass Water Polo practices and events.

Section 4:
Hold practice four nights each week during the semester, where members practice fundamental

water polo techniques, skills, and rules while working together as a team.

Section 5:
Attend and compete in the CWPA Colonial Club Men’s division tournaments in the fall and the
CWPA New England Women’s division tournaments in the spring.

 Section 6:

Host a Spring Invitational Fundraiser Tournament to help to promote the sport and encourage

friendly competition with the visiting teams participating in the tournament.

Article III: Membership

In order to join the UMass Club Water Polo:

Section 1:
At the beginning of each semester, the President and Student Coaches will decide which
prospective members are capable of meeting the club requirements and can limit the number of
members based on pool space.

Section 2:
There will be a club membership due at the beginning of each semester. Dues may vary
depending on the estimated cost of club activities for the semester. Dues will supplement the
allocated budget in paying for tournament fees, travel, and hotel fees. Club dues are
nonrefundable. The President and Treasurer will decide the amount the membership dues will
cost after a budget is determined at the beginning of each semester. Any member of the club will
be able to have access to a report of all club expenses upon request.

Section 3:
If a prospective member cannot afford the membership dues due to economic constraints, then
the amount can be reduced or waived. The President and Treasurer will make this decision. If an
agreement cannot be made between the President, Treasurer, and the prospective member, or the
prospective member feels as though they have not been treated fairly, the prospective member
has a right to consult the Center for Student Development and the club’s advisor for help.

Section 4:
The President has the right to deny any participant access to UMass Water Polo practices and
events for any of the following reasons: participant has not paid dues, participant is not in good
standing with the university, participant does not attend practices regularly, participant does not
meet the necessary athletic qualifications.

 Article IV: Maintaining Participation

Section 1:
Participants who have paid membership dues are expected to attend all practices and events.
Valid excused absences include illness, family commitments, and academic reasons (exams,
meetings, University functions). If absent, the participant is expected to notify the Secretary
immediately, giving a valid reason.

Section 2:
The President and Student Coaches have the right to limit or deny playing time at water polo
events if participant has been absent to multiple practices, regardless if the absences are excused
or unexcused in order to incentivize and reward participation.

Section 3:
In accordance with university requirements, each member must participate in at least two hours
of community service to remain an active member on the team.

Article V: Conduct and Non-Discrimination

Section 1:
All participants must abide by all University rules and regulations on and off campus.

Section 2:
Any harassment, including but not limited to verbal, physical, racial, and sexual harassment, as
well as mistreatment of other club participants, officials, coaches, or other collegiate clubs will
result in automatic suspension from the club.

Section 3:
Misconduct outside club functions will not result in suspension from the club. Only misconduct
during club practices, events, travel, or lodging can result in suspension.

Section 4:
UMass Club Water Polo prohibits discrimination under Federal and State law, based on race,
color, national origin, religion, creed, sex, gender identity (including gender expression), sexual
orientation, mental or physical disability, veteran status,  genetic information age, marital status,
family/parental status, income derived from a public assistance program, political beliefs,
reprisal or retaliation for prior civil rights activity, or any other class of individuals protected
from discrimination under state or federal law in any aspect of access to or membership to the

 organization. The requirements to become and remain a member of UMass Club Water Polo are
laid out in Articles III, IV, and V.  Retaliation for filing complaints of discrimination will be
prohibited.

Section 5:
Members who violate these policies shall be subject to expulsion from the RSO.

Article VI: Free Speech

Section 1:
All members of UMass Club Water Polo are entitled to freedom of speech and will not under any
circumstances be deprived of the opportunity to share their opinion with the group.

Article VII: Holding Office

Section 1:
Club Office Positions are as follows: President, Vice President, Treasurer, Secretary, Student
Coach, and Captain. The classification of the officers are as follows: The President, Vice
President, Treasurer, and Secretary are classified as Administrative Officers. Both Student
Coaches and the four Captains are classified as Pool-Deck Officers. The Executive board
(E-Board) will be made up of the President, Vice President, Treasurer, Secretary, and both
Student Coaches. A member may serve as one of the Administrative officers and one of the
Pool-Deck officers simultaneously.

Section 2:
The President is responsible for all activity of the club. Ensures all SGA/CSC requirements are
met (including community service, lifeguard presence at all practices etc…). Acts as liaison
between the club and the UMass administration. Oversees all equipment maintenance, purchase
requests, and other budgetary activities. Along with the Treasurer, holds Summit access and
signature responsibility to club funds (must complete OWL training). Monthly attendance at
mandatory Club Sports Council meetings. Assists all other club officers with their respective
duties. Appropriately delegates tasks to officers in accordance with their job description in this
constitution.

Section 3:
The Vice President is responsible for planning and coordinating all events and fundraisers with
the help of the Treasurer. Organizes and designs all team apparel including but not limited to
swim suits, water polo caps, and clothing.

 Section 4:
The Treasurer is responsible for managing team finances and fee/revenue accounts. Monthly
attendance at mandatory Club Sports Council meetings. In the spring, they complete a budget
request for next year. Collects and deposits dues. Along with the President, holds Summit access
and signature responsibility  to club funds (must complete OWL training). Ensures all bills paid
(league dues, lifeguard etc…).

Section 5:
The Secretary is responsible for maintaining Club Water Polo’s campus pulse page and other
social media accounts. Takes minutes from officer meetings and distributes minutes to team
members upon request. Manages club google account. Records attendance at meetings and
events. Coordinates community service events and ensures  all participants fulfill community
service needs. Plans team bonding activities.

Section 6:
The Student Coaches will consist of one male and one female club member. Responsible for
attending and running all practices. Organizes and runs tryouts and with the help of the President,
makes cuts. Creates tournament rosters and runs frequent captain meetings. Because there are
two student coaches, the head coach in the fall is the men’s coach and the head coach in the
spring is the women’s coach to correspond with the CWPA seasons. The assistant coach position
will be whichever of the two coaches is currently not the head coach.

Section 7:
The Captains will consist of two men and two women. Responsible for acting as liaisons
between CWPA and the team during tournaments. Ensures all team members are included.
Facilitates activities and helps Student Coaches run practice. Acts as role models for club
members. A captain cannot be one of the coaches. Attendance will be taken by the captains and
reported to the Secretary.

Section 8:
Club Officers will be chosen by vote by all club members at the midpoint of every spring
semester. Once elected, the current club officers will train new club officers. Club offices will be
held for one school year (Fall through Spring Semester), unless re-elected.

Section 9:

E-Board members will meet about once a month to discuss club activities, make decisions,

provide updates to everyone, and ensure that the club’s goals are being met. The President will

 chair the meetings and will delegate responsibilities to Officers as outlined in this constitution.

Decisions will be preceded by discussion where all E-Board members will have the opportunity

to voice their opinion. If a general consensus can not be reached then a vote will take place and a

simple majority vote will determine the course of action. In the event of a tie the President will

make the decision.

Article VIII: Elections

Section 1:
Club Officers will be elected by the club members every spring semester before the April 1st
SGA deadline. Two-thirds of the club members must be present to conduct an election.

Section 2:
Any club member is eligible to run for an officer position, no time requirement is required.

Section 3:
Club members will be given the chance to nominate themselves via electronic survey in the
weeks leading up to the election. Club members may choose to run for multiple positions but can
only serve in one Administrative Officer role and one Pool-Deck Officer role.

Section 4:
The President will be elected first, followed by the Vice President, Treasurer, Secretary, Student
Coaches, then Captains.The election will begin with brief speeches from the candidates for
President. After the speech the candidates will leave the room and club members will enter a
brief discussion where they can speak on behalf of their preferred candidate. Following the
discussion each member will be able to cast one anonymous vote. Then the votes will be counted
by an Officer who is not running, the candidates will be called back into the room, and the
winner will be announced. This procedure will then be replicated for each position in the
specified order. All relevant record keeping in regards elections will take place in the team’s
google drive account. The total amount of votes cast per person should remain known just to
officers counting.

Section 5:
All present club members are eligible to vote for all ten positions, regardless of gender.

Section 6:
In the event of a tie, only the candidates that received equal votes will be given another
opportunity to speak to the team. Then, the candidates who tied will exit the room, a second

 round of voting will occur to settle the tie. If the tie is not resolved by a second round of voting,
seniority will play a factor and the winner will be the person who is graduating earliest. If
seniority does not apply then the tie will be settled by a coin flip.

Section 7:
During the election, both newly elected, current, and departing E-Board members are encouraged
to refrain from endorsing other candidates during the discussion period. This provision is written
in the interest of fairness and civility, but the E-Board is not required to remain silent in
accordance with their First Amendment rights.

Section 8:
Once elected, the current club officers will train new club officers. The process of transferring
administration powers to new officers over group chats and webpages should be complete before
the end of the semester.

Article IX: Special Elections on Office Vacancies

Section 1:
In the event of an Office vacancy, the remaining E-Board members will decide whether a special
election will occur, or whether the responsibilities of the vacant office will be fulfilled by the
remaining officers until the next regularly scheduled election. Non-officers will not be appointed
to serve in interim positions.

Section 2:
In the event of a special election to fill vacancies, any member can choose to run for the vacancy.
Current officers can choose to run for the vacant position, but they must declare their intentions
before the nomination survey is made to allow people to nominate themselves to run for the
position they will be leaving. The nomination process will take place during the weeks leading
up to the election, but will only include the elections that are taking place or possibly taking
place.

Section 3:
The order of the elections of each position will be the same as a normal election unless a change
in election order is necessary to complete the election.

Section 4:
In the event of a special election to fill an Office vacancy, no officer will have to win an election
to remain in the office they currently serve in. If a current officer wins the election for another

 office, there will be an election for the office they are leaving. If they lose the election for
another office, there will not be an election for the office they were originally serving in.

Section 5:
An officer elected through a special election will only serve the remainder of their predecessor’s
term, and to serve in that position for longer they must win the next regularly scheduled election.

Article X: Special Elections on Removal

Section 1:
Special elections that decide whether a member will be removed from the team, whether an
officer will be removed from their position, and whether an officer will be removed from the
team will all follow the same procedure.

Section 2:
A petition with one-third of the team’s signatures will need to be presented to an E-Board
member to initiate one of these types of special elections. A two-thirds vote of the general
membership shall be required to remove the Officer/member. If the person in question is an
officer, whether they are removed from their position or removed from the team will have to be
clarified on the petition to hold the election. Once the E-Board is made aware of the petition,
planning for the election and the member/Officer in question will be notified.

Section 3:
The team will gather for the election and the member/officer in question will have the
opportunity to address the membership. Members/officers will have the opportunity to ask
questions and discuss with the person in question present and then in a separate room. After
discussion, anonymous voting will occur to decide. All relevant record keeping in regards
elections will take place in the team’s google drive account.

Article XI: Amendments

In order for existing Articles and Sections to be amended, or for Amendments to be added to this

document, changes must be approved by a simple majority vote of the general membership as

well as approval from the Secretary of Registry.

DocsList.Data:
UMass Club Water Polo 
Activities Expo
 Spring 2021

Please share your Name, graduation year, and 
UMass email address with us using the chat

 Water Polo Basics

■

■

■

There are 6 main ‘field’ players and 1 goalie on each team to start a 
game
Field players must pass, catch, and shoot with only 1 hand.  Goalies may 
use 2 hands.
The official playing field is at least 25 yards long, 20 yards wide, and 7 feet 
deep. Meaning no standing!

There is a 30 second shot clock per possession.

■ Games consist of 4 quarters and typically last 45 minutes to 1 hour.
■
■ Players may not touch the bottom or hang on the wall.
■
Taking the ball under water when guarded is a turnover.
■ Minor fouls occur frequently and result in a free pass.                                                                   

There is no limit to minor fouls.

■ After 3 major fouls (ejections), a player may not return to the game.

 UMass Club Water Polo

● We are a Co-Ed team that practices 4 times a week (during a normal 

semester). 

● Men compete during the fall semester while the woman compete during the 

spring semester. 

● We run ourselves and coach ourselves through our elected e-board and 

our elected coaches. 

● We have a mix of skill levels from having players from high school play to 

people who have never played the sport before. So we are willing to teach 
if you are willing to learn!

○ We have tryouts in the beginning of each semester to 

recruit new members. 

 Joining Our Team:

● Normally, two day tryout period at the start of every semester
● We are unable to hold tryouts without pool time, so we are unable to add 

new members at this time

● Join our mailing list by providing your name, graduation year, and UMass 

email address 

● We will keep you updated on tryouts and any other opportunities 
● Next tryouts are probably going to be at the start of Fall 2021 semester
