UMass Water Polo Constitution
Last Amended: 1/26/19
 
Article I: Mission Statement
 
The University of Massachusetts Amherst Club Water Polo’s mission is to provide the University and its students an opportunity to learn and play the sport of water polo at the national collegiate club level by competing in the Collegiate Water Polo Association’s (CWPA) Club Colonial and New England Divisions.  At all practices and events the club will teach its members teamwork, responsibility, dedication, and sportsmanship both in and out of the water. The club will provide fair playing time at all water polo events to all players who attend all practices and show a dedication to the club. 
 
 
Article II: Goals and Objectives
 
The UMass Club Water Polo goals and objectives are the following:
 
Section 1:
Teach the sport of water polo to all University students or faculty interested in the sport. The club will be co-ed.
 
Section 2:
Provide a safe and judgment free environment for all participants.
 
Section 3:
Allow any University student or faculty despite ethnic, racial, or economic status to be able to participate at all UMass Water Polo practices and events.
 
Section 4:
Attend and compete in the CWPA Colonial Club Men’s division in the fall and the CWPA New England Women’s division in the spring.
 
 
Article III: Membership
 
In order to join the UMass Club Water Polo:
 
Section 1:
There will be a club membership due at the beginning of each semester. Dues may vary depending on the estimated cost of club activities for the semester. Dues will supplement the allocated budget in paying for tournament fees, travel, and hotel fees. Club dues are nonrefundable.
 
Section 2:
The President and Treasurer will decide the amount the membership dues will cost after a budget is determined at the beginning of each semester. Any member of the club will be able to have access to a report of all club expenses.
 
Section 3:
If a prospective member cannot afford the membership dues due to economic constraints, then the amount can be reduced or waived. The President and Treasurer will make this decision. If an agreement cannot be made between the President, Treasurer, and the prospective member, or the prospective member feels as though they have not been treated fairly, the prospective member has a right to consult the Center for Student Development and the club’s advisor for help.
 
Section 4:
The President has the right to deny any participant access to UMass Water Polo practices and events for any of the following reasons: participant has not paid dues, participant is not in good standing with the university, participant has frequent unexcused missed practices, participant does not meet the necessary athletic qualifications (swimming ability and stamina). At the beginning of each semester, the President and Coaches will decide which prospective members are capable of meeting the club requirements and can limit number of members based on pool space. 
 
 
Article IV: Maintaining Participation
 
Section 1:
Participants who have paid membership dues must attend all practices and events. Valid excused absences include illness, family commitments, and academic reasons (exams, meetings, University functions). If absent, participant must notify the President immediately, giving a valid reason.
 
Section 2:
The President and Coaches have the right to limit or deny playing time at water polo events on the basis of attendance, regardless if the absences are excused or unexcused. The reason is to provide participants who have been at practices to be rewarded with playing time.
 
 
Article V: Conduct
 
Section 1:
All participants must abide by all University rules and regulations on and off campus.
 
Section 2:
Any harassment (both verbally or physically) or mistreatment of other club participants, officials, coaches, or other collegiate clubs will result in automatic suspension from the club.
 
Section 3:
Misconduct outside club functions will not result in suspension from club. Only misconduct during club practices, events, travel, or lodging can result in suspension.
 
 
Article VI: Holding Office
 
Section 1:
Club Office Positions are as followed: President, Vice President, Treasurer, Secretary, Coach, and Captain.
 
Section 2:
The President is responsible for all activity of the club. Ensures all SGA/CSC requirements are met (including community service, lifeguard presence at all practices etc…). Acts as liaison between the club and the UMass administration. Oversees all equipment maintenance, purchase requests, and other budgetary activities. Along with the Treasurer, holds Summit access and signing rights to club funds (must complete OWL training). Monthly attendance at mandatory Club Sports Council meetings. Assists all other club officers with their respective duties.

Section 3:
The Vice President is responsible for planning and coordinating all events and fundraisers with the help of the Treasurer. Organizes and designs all team apparel including but not limited to swim suits, water polo caps, and clothing.

Section 4:
The Treasurer is responsible for managing team finances and fee/revenue accounts. Monthly attendance at mandatory Club Sports Council meetings. In spring, completes budget workbook requesting budget for next year. Collects and deposits dues. Along with the President, holds Summit access and signing rights to club funds (must complete OWL training). Ensures all bills paid (league dues, lifeguard etc…).

Section 5:
The Secretary is responsible for maintaining Club Water Polo’s campus pulse page and other social media accounts. Takes and distributes minutes from officer meetings. Manages club email account. Records attendance at meetings and events. Coordinates community service events and ensuring all participants fulfill community service needs. Plans team bonding activities.

Section 6:
The Coaches will consist of one male and one female club member. Responsible for attending and running all practices. Organizes and runs tryouts and with the help of the President, makes cuts. Creates tournament rosters and runs frequent captain meetings. Because there are two coaches, the head coach in the fall is the men’s coach and the head coach in the spring is the women’s coach to correspond with the CWPA seasons. The assistant coach position will be whichever of the two coaches is currently not the head coach.

Section 7:
The Captains will consist of two men and two women. Responsible for acting as liaisons between CWPA and the team during tournaments. Makes sure all team members are included. Facilitates activities and helps coaches run practice. Acts as role models for club members. A captain cannot be one of the coaches.

Section 8:
Club Officers will be chosen by vote by all club members at the midpoint of every spring semester. Once elected, the current club officers will train new club officers.
 
Section 9:
Club offices will be held for one school year (Fall through Spring Semester), unless re-elected.  
 

Article VII: Amendments
 
Amendments can be added to this document at any time by the club President with approval from the Vice President, Treasurer, and Secretary.

 
Article VIII: Non-Discrimination

Section 1:
Club Water Polo prohibits discrimination on the basis of race, color, religion, creed, sex, age, marital status, national origin, mental or physical disability, political belief or affiliation, veteran status, sexual orientation, gender identity and expression, genetic information and any other class of individuals protected from discrimination under state or federal law in any aspect of access to or membership to the organization.

Section 2:
Club Water Polo prohibits harassment of members, i.e., racial harassment, sexual harassment, and retaliation for filing complaints of discrimination.

Section 3:
Members who violate these policies shall be subject to expulsion from the RSO.


Article IX: Free Speech

Section 1:
All members of UMass Club Water Polo are entitled to freedom of speech and will not under any circumstances be deprived of the opportunity to share their opinion with the group.

UMass Water Polo Constitution
Last Amended: 1/25/18
 
Article I: Mission Statement
 
The University of Massachusetts Amherst Club Water Polo’s mission is to provide the University and its students an opportunity to learn and play the sport of water polo at the national collegiate club level by competing in the Collegiate Water Polo Association’s (CWPA) Club Colonial and New England Divisions.  At all practices and events the club will teach its members teamwork, responsibility, dedication, and sportsmanship both in and out of the water. The club will provide fair playing time at all water polo events to all players who attend all practices and show a dedication to the club. 
 
 
Article II: Goals and Objectives
 
The UMass Club Water Polo goals and objectives are the following:
 
Section 1:
Teach the sport of water polo to all University students or faculty interested in the sport.  The club will be co-ed.
 
Section 2:
Provide a safe and judgment free environment for all participants.
 
Section 3:
Allow any University student or faculty despite ethnic, racial, or economic status to be able to participate at all UMass Water Polo practices and events.
 
Section 4:
Attend and compete in the CWPA Colonial Club Men’s division in the fall and the CWPA New England Women’s division in the spring.
 
 
Article III: Membership
 
In order to join the UMass Club Water Polo:
 
Section 1:
There will be a club membership due at the beginning of each semester. Dues may vary depending on the estimated cost of club activities for the semester. Dues will supplement the allocated budget in paying for tournament fees, travel, and hotel fees. Club dues are nonrefundable.
 
Section 2:
The President and Treasurer will decide the amount the membership dues will cost after a budget is determined at the beginning of each semester. Any member of the club will be able to have access to a report of all club expenses.
 
Section 3:
If a prospective member cannot afford the membership dues due to economic constraints, then the amount can be reduced or waived. The President and Treasurer will make this decision. If an agreement cannot be made between the President, Treasurer, and the prospective member, or the prospective member feels as though they have not been treated fairly, the prospective member has a right to consult the Center for Student Development and the club’s advisor for help.
 
Section 4:
The President has the right to deny any participant access to UMass Water Polo practices and events for any of the following reasons: participant has not paid dues, participant is not in good standing with the university, participant does not attend practices regularly, participant does not meet the necessary athletic qualifications. At the beginning of each semester, the President and Coaches will decide which prospective members are capable of meeting the club requirements and can limit number of members based on pool space. 
 
 
Article IV: Maintaining Participation
 
Section 1:
Participants who have paid membership dues must attend all practices and events. Valid excused absences include illness, family commitments, and academic reasons (exams, meetings, University functions). If absent, participant must notify the President immediately, giving a valid reason.
 
Section 2:
The President and Coaches have the right to limit or deny playing time at water polo events if participant has been absent to multiple practices, regardless if the absences are excused or unexcused. The reason is to provide participants who have been at practices to be rewarded with playing time.
 
 
Article V: Conduct
 
Section 1:
All participants must abide by all University rules and regulations on and off campus.
 
Section 2:
Any harassment (both verbally or physically) or mistreatment of other club participants, officials, coaches, or other collegiate clubs will result in automatic suspension from the club.
 
Section 3:
Misconduct outside club functions will not result in suspension from club. Only misconduct during club practices, events, travel, or lodging can result in suspension.
 
 
Article VI: Holding Office
 
Section 1:
Club Office Positions are as followed: President, Vice President, Treasurer, Secretary, Coach, and Captain.
 
Section 2:
The President is responsible for all activity of the club. Ensures all SGA/CSC requirements are met (including community service, lifeguard presence at all practices etc…). Acts as liaison between the club and the UMass administration. Oversees all equipment maintenance, purchase requests, and other budgetary activities. Along with the Treasurer, holds Summit access and signing rights to club funds (must complete OWL training). Monthly attendance at mandatory Club Sports Council meetings. Assists all other club officers with their respective duties.

Section 3:
The Vice President is responsible for planning and coordinating all events and fundraisers with the help of the Treasurer. Coordinates community service events and ensuring all participants fulfill community service needs. Organizes and designing team apparel.

Section 4:
The Treasurer is responsible for managing both fees and revenues accounts. Monthly attendance at mandatory Club Sports Council meetings. In spring, completes budget workbook requesting budget for next year. Collects and deposits dues. Along with the President, holds Summit access and signing rights to club funds (must complete OWL training). Ensures all bills paid (league dues, lifeguard etc…).

Section 5:
The Secretary is responsible for maintaining Club Water Polo’s campus pulse page and other social media accounts. Takes and distributes minutes from officer meetings. Manages club email account. Records attendance at meetings and events.

Section 6:
The Coaches will consist of one male and one female club member. Responsible for attending and running all practices. Organizes and runs tryouts and with the help of the President, makes cuts. Creates tournament rosters and runs frequent captain meetings. Because there are two coaches, the head coach in the fall is the men’s coach and the head coach in the spring is the women’s coach to correspond with the CWPA seasons. The assistant coach position will be whichever of the two coaches is currently not the head coach.

Section 7:
The Captains will consist of two men and two women. Responsible for acting as liaisons between CWPA and the team during tournaments. Makes sure all team members are included. Facilitates activities and helps coaches run practice. Acts as role models for club members. A captain cannot be one of the coaches.

Section 8:
Club Officers will be chosen by vote by all club members at the midpoint of every spring semester. Once elected, the current club officers will train new club officers.
 
Section 9:
Club offices will be held for one school year (Fall through Spring Semester), unless re-elected.  
 

Article VII: Amendments
 
Amendments can be added to this document at any time by the club President with approval from the Vice President, Treasurer, and Secretary.

UMass Water Polo Constitution
Last Amended: 2/7/16

Article I: Mission Statement

The University of Massachusetts Amherst Water Polo Club’s mission is to provide the University and its students an opportunity to learn and play the sport of water polo at the national collegiate club level.  At all practices and events the club will teach its members teamwork, responsibility, dedication, and sportsmanship both in and out of the water.  The club will provide fair playing time at all water polo events to all players who attend all practices and show a dedication to the club.  


Article II: Goals and Objectives

The UMass Water Polo Club goals and objectives are the following:

Section 1:
Teach the sport of water polo to all University students or faculty interested in the sport.  The club will be co-ed. 

Section 2:
Provide a safe and judgment free environment for all participants. 

Section 3:
Allow any University student or faculty despite ethnic, racial, or economic status to be able to participate at all UMass Water Polo practices and events.


Article III: Membership

In order to join the UMass Water Polo Club: 

Section 1:

There will be a club membership due at the beginning of each semester. The amount due will vary depending the estimated cost of club activities. Dues will supplement the allocated budget in paying for coaching, tournament fees, travel, and hotel fees. Club dues are nonrefundable. 

Section 2:
Club President and Treasurer will decide the amount the membership due will cost after a budget is determined at the beginning of each semester. Any member of the club will be able to have access to a report of all club expenses.


Section 3:

If a prospective member cannot afford the dues due to economic constraints, then the amount can be reduced or waived. The club president will make this decision. If agreement cannot be meet between the club president and the prospective member, or the prospective member feels as though they have not been treated fairly the prospective member has a right to consult the Center for Student Development and the clubs advisor for help. 

Section 4:

Club President has the right to deny any participant access to UMass Water Polo practices and events for any of the following reasons: participant has not paid dues, participant is not in good standing with the university, participant does not attend practices regularly, participant does not meet the necessary athletic qualifications. At the beginning of each semester, the President and Coach will decide which prospective members are capable of meeting the club requirements and can limit number of members based on pool space.  

Article IV: Maintaining Participation 

Section 1: 
Participants who have paid membership dues must attend all practices and events. Valid excused absences include illness, family commitments, and academic reasons (exams, meetings, University functions). If absent, participant must notify club President immediately, giving a valid reason.

Section 2: 
Club President has the right to limit or deny playing time at water polo events if participant has been absent to multiple practices, regardless if the absences are excused or unexcused. The reason is to provide participants who have been at practices to be rewarded with playing time.

Article V: Conduct 

Section 1: 
All participants must abide by all University rules and regulations on or off campus.

Section 2: 
Any harassment (both verbally or physically) or mistreatment of other club participants, officials, coaches, or other collegiate clubs will result in automatic suspension from the club. 

Section 3: 
Misconduct outside club functions will not result in suspension from club. Only misconduct during club practices, events, travel, or lodging can result in suspension.


Article VI: Holding Office 

Section 1: 
Club Office Positions are as followed: Club President, Vice President, Treasurer, Secretary, Club Coach, and Club Captain.

Section 2: 
The Club President is responsible for activity of the club. Planning and coordinating events and fundraisers. Ensures all SGA/CSC requirements are met (including community service, lifeguard presence at all practices etc…). Acts as liaison between UMWP and UMASS administration. Oversee equipment maintenance, purchase requests, and other budgetary activities.

Section 3: 
Club Vice President will assist the Club President in making decisions regarding discipline, club expenses, and assisting in organizing all club practices and events. Vice President is responsible for coordinating community service events and ensuring all participants fulfill community service needs. He or she will help coordinate fundraisers (along with treasurer).

Section 4:

The Club Treasurer is responsible for managing both fees and revenues accounts. Monthly attendance at mandatory Club Sports Council meetings. In spring, completes budget workbook requesting budget for next year and presents to SGA allocations committee. Collects and deposits dues. Holds Summit access and signing rights to club funds (must complete OWL training). Ensures all bills paid (league dues, lifeguard etc…).


Section 5:

Club Secretary is responsible for coordinating events and planning all travel. Makes hotel reservations, organizes transportation for tournaments, coordinates travel plans, and helps run home tournaments/events.

Section 6: 
Club Captain will provide the leadership both in and out of the pool, represent the club at all events (i.e. captains meetings), and be a mentor and provide guidance for all club members.

Section 7: 
Club Officers will be chosen by vote by all club members at the mid-point of every spring semester.  Once elected, the current club officers will train new club officers.

Section 8:
Club offices will be help for one school year (Fall through Spring Semester), unless re-elected.  

Article VII: Coaching

Section 1: 
All club officers will interview anyone interested in being the club coach.  Once selected the club coach will adhere to all University regulations, rules, and policies. 

Section 2:
The club coach will be paid the specified rate set by the University. 

Article VIII: Amendments 

Amendments can be added to this document at any time by the club president with approval from all other club officers

Communities Against Cancer Constitution 

Article I: Organization Name 

The name of the organization shall be Communities Against Cancer.  

Article II: Purpose Statement 

Communities Against Cancer is an organization at UMass that supports various 

we have all been touched by cancer in 

non-profits fight back against Cancer. Unfortunately, 
some shape or form. Our group raises money and supports varying foundations so that no one 
has to hear the words “You have cancer” ever again. Our hope is that no one ever has to go 
through the pain and the suffering that this terrible disease causes. We not only partner with 
national foundations such as the American Cancer Society, but we also partner with local 
non-profits such as the Cancer House of Hope in West Springfield, MA. Recently we have 
joined forces with DKMS, an international organization that gives so many people second 
chances by matching them with a bone marrow donor, and Each Moment We’re Alive
non-profit that supports breast cancer survivors through various programs. This club is designed 
to allow students to work through many channels to eliminate cancer, whether that is through 
advocacy, fundraising, or education.  

, a local 

Article III: Membership and Eligibility Criteria 

Section 1: 

Qualifications 

Voting member status is open to all undergraduate students at UMass Amherst. Anyone 

else who would like to contribute such as faculty, graduate students, and alumni may attend 
meetings and will be allowed to address the group, but will not have voting status or be able to 
hold an official leadership position within the committee.  

Section 2: 

Qualifications for Voting Member Status 

In order for a member to achieve voting status, he or she must attend three full meetings 

or events as a non-voting member. Should a voting member be unable to attend a meeting, it’s 
their responsibility to communicate the absence to an executive board member. Decisions are 
made as a group, and the issue being voted upon that receives the highest percentage of votes 
will be considered a winning vote. In the case of an even tie, the President and Vice President 
will make the final call.  

Section 3: 

Dues and collection procedures 

There will be no dues for this organization. It is expected that the members will 

participate in fundraising efforts for all events. 
Section 4: 

A member may be removed for: 

 
 
​
​
 
 
​
 
​
 
​
​
 The organization and its members agree to adhere to city, state, and national laws, to the 

Student Code of Conduct, and the RSO Handbook. Any member found violating this may be 
removed from the organization. 

Section 5: 

Removal of membership procedures 

Any member may have their membership revoked by a two-thirds vote of the Executive 

Board. Any member removed may appeal to the general membership. Said member shall be 
considered reinstated with two-thirds approval of the members.  

Article IV: Voting 

Section 1: 

No business, such as executive board elections, amendments to the constitution, or an 

RSO name change, can be officially decided without a vote. Said vote may be done by Campus 
Pulse, Google Forms, or something else mutually decided by the executive board. As stated in 
SGA by-laws, ⅔ of the active members should be participating in the election process. A 
majority vote will decide the final outcome.  

Section 2:  

Each member that is considered of voting status may vote. Please refer to Article III, 

Sections 1 and 2 for further explanation.  

Article V: Officers 

Section 1: 

Officers 

 Colleges Against Cancer shall have seven officers, occupying the positions of President, 
Vice President, Treasurer, Entertainment and Events Coordinator, Media/Marketing and Health 
Promotions Chair, Fundraising/ Sponsorship Chair, and Logistics Chair to fulfill the roles 
described in Article VI, Section 8.  

 If the current executive board feels the need to add, remove, or change another position, 

Add:
they must discuss first, but are able to.  

Section 2: 

Officer Qualifications 

All candidates for officer positions must be a member of Colleges Against Cancer and in 

good standing with voting status as defined in Article III, Sections 1 and 2.  

 
​
 
 
 
 
 
​
 
​
 
​
 
 
 
 Section 3: 

Date for Officer Elections 

New officer elections will be held during the last week in March every spring semester. 
Newly elected officers obtain their full status on the day following the last day of finals, and are 
to retain their status for a term of one year.  

Section 4: 

Nomination Process and Notification 

Two weeks prior to new officer elections, all members of voting status are to be notified 
of the upcoming elections during the standard meeting, and invited to nominate a candidate for 
any one of the previously enumerated positions. Current officers may nominate themselves, and 
any non-officer may nominate themselves. A single candidate may apply for multiple positions, 
though they may not serve in two concurrent offices.  

Section 5: 

Election Process 

Officers shall be elected by a majority vote of all present voting members. The Election 
process will be carried out as stated in Article IV Section 1. Should it result in a tie, there must 
be a new vote by all of the present voting members between the candidates for which there was a 
tie.  

Section 6: 

Impeachment 

Impeachment of any officer may occur under majority vote of those present for a 
meeting. If an impeachment vote is to take place, it must be announced at an official meeting the 
week before. A reasonable opportunity for discussion of the issues at hand must be presented 
prior to the undertaking of any vote. Should an officer be impeached, any member present at the 
meeting may nominate himself or herself, as replacement, and a vote shall be held immediately.  

Section 7: 

Resignation 

Any officer may resign at any time. In the event of an officer resignation, members will 

be notified of the resignation at the next scheduled meeting time, and any member may nominate 
himself or herself as replacement. The election for the replacement officer will be held the 
following week.  

Section 8: 

Officer Responsibilities 

The President shall be the organization’s spokesperson in the community, and also serve 

as chair in all meetings. Should the President be unable to attend a meeting, it is the Vice 
President’s responsibility to serve as chair. The President also:  

● Oversees all aspects of Colleges Against Cancer and other mini fundraisers 
● Prepares and leads all meetings 
● Delegates responsibilities 

 
​
 
​
 
​
 
​
 
​
 
​
 ● Sends out emails regarding meetings and events 
● Regular check-ins with subcommittee chairs 
● Recruits new members  
● Lead the committee and event towards new improvements and goals 
● Communicates with ACS staff partner 
● Work with Events Coordinator on speeches  
● Provides ongoing encouragement and support to all committee members 
● Serves as a community spokesperson for CAC 

The Vice President must help support the President and act as the chair if the President 

cannot be in attendance at a meeting. The Vice President is responsible for coordinating 
activities, including but not limited to:  
● Assists President with duties 
● Responsible for contact with Athletics and Greek Life to increase their involvement 
● Reaching out to underclassmen for recruiting 
● Records and sends out meeting minutes  
● Creates templates for mass emails to professors, other RSOs and possible fundraising 
messages for committee members to send out to family, friends, and coworkers 

● Holds signature responsibility 

The Treasurer shall maintain all the organization’s accounts, bills and fees, as well as 
serving as an advisor to the organization as a whole with regards to the financial status of the 
club and how upcoming events will affect the club’s finances. Their responsibilities will also 
include:  

● Maintaining the budget for the year 
● Submitting budget requests 
● Requests to use the SASP card and taking money out of account 
● In charge of any cash from mini fundraisers including updating budget spreadsheets on 

the club Drive 

● Working closely with the SORC 
● Holds signature responsibility 

The Entertainment and Events Coordinator organizes all performances, speeches, and 

other event logistics. The Coordinator is also the main contact person for all outside performers 
and groups for event days. They will also be responsible for:  

● Contacting and confirms musical performances, bands, and dance groups 
● Organizing raffle baskets for events that require them 
● Developing full event schedule 
● Creating games and activities for the entire night 

 
 
 
 ● Ceremony duties - establishing speakers for ceremonies, scripts for speeches, detailed 

plans of opening and closing ceremonies, in charge of luminaria bags.  

● Setting up and running trivia nights.  

The Fundraising and Sponsorship Chair will be the main contact for outside vendors. 

They will also be in charge of creating a sponsorship committee to ask for donations and raffle 
items. The Fundraising and Sponsorship Chair has responsibilities that include, but are not 
limited to:  

● Creating a list of potential donors and sponsors 
● Contacting businesses about donations 
● Developing a sponsorship packet with levels based on donation 
● Providing adequate promotion of sponsor at the event, online, and on the t-shirt 
● Sending out follow up emails to donors after the event 
● Assisting Entertainment Chair, as well as any potential committees, in securing and 

organizing donations for raffle baskets 

The Media/Marketing and Health Promotions Chair is in charge of updating the 

Instagram and Facebook pages with event promotions and progress, fundraising goals, and health 
initiatives that go along with the clubs mission. This chair has responsibilities that include, but 
are not limited to:  

● Creates publicity/marketing materials 
● Promotes events via social media and flyers/posters 
● Determines media action plan 
● Recruit new members 
● Makes announcements about events to UMass students through the UMass weekend 

email, Student Affairs and Campus Life, Alumni Association, Campus Pulse, and any 
other potential avenues 

● Look up facts for marketing and flyers 

The main task of the Logistics coordinator is booking event and meeting spaces as well 

as coordinating with campus partners to make sure we are following campus protocol. The 
logistics coordinator has responsibilities that include, but are not limited to:  
● Coordinating with UMPD, physical plant, and other UMass services 
● Acquiring permits 
● Booking venues, locations for mini fundraisers, and meeting space 
● Ensuring security of the event 

Section 9: 

Signature Responsibility 

 
 
 
 
​
 Two officers must hold Signature Responsibility, one of which is required to be the 

Treasurer. Except in cases where he or she is, for whatever reason, unable, the Vice President 
shall also hold signature responsibility.  

Article VI: 

Amendments 

Amendments may be made to this constitution whenever it is deemed necessary. All 

amendments must be proposed a week before voting, and proper time must be given for 
members to discuss the changes. The amendments are to be implemented according to their own 
specifications. 

Article VII: 

Ratification 

All members with voting status will be given an opportunity to vote upon ratification of 

the constitution and a majority vote shall be required for approval. The Secretary of Registry 
must make final approval of this constitution, and a copy must be made available for all 
members. 

 
​
 
​

RSO Constitution for UMass Costume and Cosplay Club

Article I: Name of Organization

The recognized and official name of this organization will be “UMass Costume and Cosplay
Club” or “UMass Cosplay Club.”

Article II: Mission Statement

The primary purpose of the UMass Cosplay Club is to give interested persons the opportunity to
interact and collaborate with others interested in cosplay, the performance art of dressing as a

character from pop culture, especially ones from the genres of manga and anime.

The club will encourage the sharing of costume making techniques, having civilized discussion
on cosplay culture, and creating an atmosphere where members feel they can express their
creativity.

The secondary goal is to connect with both the school and cosplay communities.

This will be done by having social gatherings to bring in cosplayers (people who participate in
cosplay) and hosting costume making workshops and info sessions to educate the community
as to what cosplay is.

Article III: Membership

Section 1: Qualifications

Members are undergraduate students of the University of Massachusetts, Amherst who are
generally on our mailing list.

Anyone else who would like to contribute their votes, such as faculty, graduate students, alumni
and any member of the five-college community, may attend our regular meetings and will be
allowed to address the group, but will not have voting status.

Section 2: Qualifications for Voting Member Status

A student that has attended at least three full meetings may become eligible to vote.

If a voting member is unable to be present at a voting meeting, they may cast absentee ballots for

 all issues except for officer elections.

A vote of fifty percent of all present members plus one will be considered a winning vote.

If a member runs without opposition, they only require one vote excluding their own.

Article IV: Statement of Non-Discrimination

This organization will not tolerate discrimination based on race, gender, sexual orientation,
religion, creed, or political views. As membership is open and non-competitive, no student shall
be hazed or forced to participate in any activity against his/her will.

The RSO will do its best to encourage a safe and accepting environment that promotes  the
sharing of ideas. Discrimination based on interests will not be tolerated.

Article V: Meetings

Section 1: Frequency and Procedure for General Meetings

General meetings may be considered open workshops where members can work on their current
project and collaborate and shall be held at least once a week. Meetings can be attended by all
members and non-members.

The secretary will make note of attendance, which are to be kept on file. These notes will dictate
voter status of members in accordance with Article III, Section 2.

Meetings will take place during the academic year only. General meetings will be a time for
members to collaborate and work on their individual projects. Officers will be expected to give
guidance and constructive feedback to the best of their ability in addition to working on their
own projects.

The club will host workshops and discussions during scheduled meeting times.

Section 2: Frequency and Procedure for Administrative Meetings

A minimum of three administrative meetings will be held per semester to review policy, finances
and goals.

 Attendance will be limited to elected officers and any individuals who all five officers
unanimously decide should be present. This may include students from the other five colleges.

The time and date of this meeting can be decided by those planning to attend.

Section 3: Quorum

No business can be officially decided by vote with a number of members less than 25% of the
club’s total membership.

If the total number of members exceeds 40, business may be decided by vote if at least 10
members are present.

Article VI: Statement of Free Speech and Expression

Any member of any status may address the group at any meeting. Proposals will be accepted
from all members and those not in attendance are to be prevented from contributing to
discussions and decisions.

Article VII: Officers and Elections

Section 1: Officers

The UMass Cosplay Club shall have a minimum of four officers, occupying the positions of
President, Vice President, Secretary and Treasurer.

Additional positions may be added, as long as the majority of the original administrative officers
approve of this decision.

Section 2: Officer Qualifications

All candidates for officer positions must be a voting member of the UMass Cosplay Club in good
standing with voting status as defined in Article III, Section 2, and must have at the time of
election a cumulative GPA of 2.5 or greater.

Prospective officers must have been a member of UMass Cosplay Club in good standing for a
full academic semester prior to the term in which said officer is being elected.

 Section 3: Date for Officer Elections

When officers retire, new officer elections will be held within the last few meetings of the Spring
semester of an academic year, or in some cases, the first meeting of the Fall semester of a new
academic year. Current officers will converse with each other to make this decision.

After elections, newly elected officers will obtain their full status on the following day, and will
retain their status for a term of one year.

Section 4: Nomination Process and Notification

Nominations for officers may be made at the last few meetings of the spring semester of an
academic year, or the first meeting of the Fall semester of a new academic year, where a vote
will be submitted for each respective position. All members shall be notified about the election
process and positions prior to the actual election date.

Any member may nominate any eligible member, themselves included, for any of the
enumerated positions. A single candidate may be nominated for multiple positions, though he or
she may not serve in two offices concurrently. After nomination, a member must declare
acceptance of their candidacy for each given position to which they are nominated.

Section 5: Election Process

Officers shall be elected by a majority vote of all present voting members. The elections are to
take place in the following order:

President first, followed by Vice President, followed by Secretary, followed by Treasurer,
followed by added positions.

Should no one candidate receive a majority vote, a second run-off vote shall be held to
determine the winner among the two candidates who received the greatest number of
votes.

Section 6: Process for Member/Officer Removal

Resolving Disputes:

A dispute is defined as a mutual impasse between two or more cosplay club members, either
physical or verbal. The process for handling member disputes is as such:

● A dispute should be reported to the president and the vice president.

 ● A meeting can be called, if necessary, to vote on the issue.

● Ultimately, if a decision cannot be reached and a vote cannot be taken, the President will have
final say in the matter using his/her/their best unbiased judgment by considering the interests of
all  parties involved, being true to the club values, and keeping integrity of the Cosplay Club
and UMass recreation in mind.

Membership Termination:

All issues regarding the removal of members and officers shall be brought to the attention of the
President who will then decide to issue a warning to the member in question or to leave the issue
to a vote among club members.

Section 8: Officer Responsibilities

President

● Responsible for meeting agendas, establishing meeting dates and places, running

meetings, and overseeing the general flow of meetings.

● In case of voting conflicts (ties, etc.) or a meeting impasse, the President has final say

in making decisions and resolving conflicts.

● President is required to attend all meetings or find a substitute to take on meeting

responsibilities for that evening.

● President is required to complete signature responsibility training.

Vice President

● Works in tandem with the president.

● Responsible for all presidential duties in the event which the president cannot fulfill

said duties.

Treasurer

● Responsible for handling all of the club financials such as: collecting income from fundraising

events, material purchases, and travel expenses.

● Organizing and recording a budget report for the club’s financials. A copy must also be given

 to the secretary bisemesterly. A copy of the budget will be available to all officers (read
only).

● Responsible for organizing travel schedule with club’s financial advisor.

● Treasurer is required to complete Signature Responsibility training.

Secretary

● Record Keeping

● Recording meeting minutes and topics of discussion during club meetings along with any

resolutions.

● Coordinating with executive staff and other officers to keep official records of

member activity including:

● Meetings attended.

● Event participation.

● Secretary is required to attend all meetings

Event Coordinator (position as needed)

● Organizing and coordinating club events such as fundraising opportunities, charity, and club

socials (within the club, with other clubs, and events open to the public).

● Will work closely with the Treasurer for reporting and recording income and expenses relating

to fundraising events.

● Documenting attendance, funds raised, and other information pertaining to club events.

● Liaison to other clubs and organizations.

Article VIII: Amendments

Amendments may be made to this constitution whenever it is deemed necessary. All amendments
must be proposed a week before voting, and proper time must be given for members to discuss
the changes. Any voting member may cast an absentee ballot on this matter if they are unable to
attend the appropriate meeting. The amendments are to be implemented according to their own

 specifications.

All amendments pertaining to the current constitution and its ability to function are ratified two
weeks after it has been voted in, with a general body meeting and email informing the general
membership in the interim.

Article IX: Ratification

All members with voting status will be given an opportunity to vote upon the ratification of the
constitution and a majority vote shall be required for approval. The Secretary of Registry must
make final approval of this constitution.

STUDENT UNION CRAFT CENTER MEMBERSHIP POLICIES 

 Craft Center membership is limited to: 
•  Current UMass and Continuing Education students, faculty, staff, and administration with a valid school I.D. 

who have signed the policy acknowledgement sheet. 

•  Fee-paying Five College students, faculty, staff, and administration with a valid school I.D. that have signed 

the policy acknowledgement sheet. Price for 5-College students is $15/semester, or $25/year.  

*Failure to adhere to Craft Center policies and procedures may result in the revocation of one’s membership. 

EACH MEMBER AGREES TO ADHERE TO THE FOLLOWING: 

1.  TIE HAIR BACK when using the buffing wheels, the glass grinder, and the acetylene torches. Remove any 
necklaces, scarves, bracelets, sweatshirt strings, or accessories that could get caught by the machinery. 

2.  WEAR GOGGLES when operating: buffing wheels, acetylene torches, glass cutters and grinders, and drills. Wear 

goggles when cutting metal and soldering glass.  

3.  EXERCISE CAUTION WHEN SOLDERING with acetylene torches. Use the provided striker to light the torch. 

Never use matches or a lighter. Beware of clothing, hair, and other flammables. TURN OFF VALVE ON 
TORCH WHEN NOT SOLDERING. QUENCH HOT METALS before putting into the pickle. Use copper tongs 
for moving metals in and out of the pickle and baking soda.  

4.  EXERCISE CAUTION WITH STAINED GLASS SOLDERING IRON. Wear goggles. Never touch any part of 

the iron except the handle. Iron remains hot when unplugged. When not in use, turn iron off and replace in holder.  

5.  EXERCISE CAUTION WHEN USING THE DARKROOM and/or other chemicals. Avoid eye contact and 
ingestion of all chemicals. Avoid spills; however in the event of a spill, promptly consult a staff person. 

6.  Carefully monitor steamer and irons. Do not leave them unattended and TURN THEM OFF when not in use. 

NEVER leave irons FACE DOWN. 

7.  When using blades, cut AWAY from fingers. Keep fingers AWAY from the needle of the sewing machines, and 

when hand sewing with the leather needles. 

8.  Report ALL injuries to a staff member. 

9.  Tools must be signed out with a Craft Center membership card and returned to the front desk. Members’ guests 

may sign out tools through accompanying host. Both hosts and guests must sign a liability form.  

10.  Pay for all materials before starting projects. 

11.  Seek instruction on how to properly use tools and practice proper tool use.  

12.  NO FOOD OR BARE FEET are allowed in the Craft Center work areas. 

13.  NO INDIVIDUAL UNDER THE INFLUENCE OF ANY SUBSTANCE will be permitted in the Craft Center. 

14.  NO PETS OR BICYCLES are allowed in the Craft Center. 

15.  CLEAN UP AFTER YOURSELF and allow sufficient time before closing to do so. All members must vacate the 

premises by closing time; this applies to “drop-in” hours and workshops.  

16.  Pick up finished and/or unfinished work within a one-month period. The Craft Center is not responsible for 
personal belongings or work left behind. Please protect your valuables. Projects left behind at the end of the 
semester will be recycled or discarded. Please see the director if you are unable to remove your project. 

17.  Respect others and their property.

DocsList.Data:
CONSTITUTION  
UNIVERSITY OF MASSACHUSETTS CREW  

ARTICLE I NAME  
The name of this organization shall be the University of Massachusetts Crew Club.  

ARTICLE II PURPOSE  
The Massachusetts Men’s Rowing strives to teach and implement core values such as cohesion, 
leadership, humility, and purpose that are necessary for a successful and fulfilling life. We 
believe these values are developed and reaffirmed through dedicated hard work, and the 
recognition of the importance of teamwork. Most importantly, we, as representatives of our 
university, insist upon maintaining and expanding our reputation as a highly competitive, 
nationally recognized, rowing team. We must compete at a varsity level.  

ARTICLE III MEMBERSHIP   

Section 1 This organization shall be open to any student of the University of 

Massachusetts.  

Section 2 Any student who  

A.) Is not in default of their dues as defined in Article VIII  
B.) Is academically eligible as defined by the University Athletic   

Department  

C.) Performs team service at the request of the Executive Board  

Section 3 Probationary membership may be defined as placed there by Article III, 

Section 2. The Executive Board as defined in Article IV reserves the   

right to place a member on probationary membership until a majority of   
the board votes to re-admit the member. No probationary member may   

hold office, run for office, vote, or compete for the Crew Club.  

ARTICLE IV OFFICE  

Section 1 The officers of this organization shall be President, Vice President, 

Treasurer, Secretary, Media Manager, and Fundraising Coordinator.  

Section 2 The duties of the officers shall be as described:  

President: 
The President will be responsible for seeing that the diverse   
administrative needs of the club are acted upon. He/she will act as the   
presiding officer at all business meetings, as spokesperson for the   

organization, and otherwise act in good faith for the better interests of the 
members of the organization.  

Vice President: 
assume all Presidential duties in the event that the office is vacated and   

The Vice President shall facilitate the banquet and   

any other duties the club may assign.  

Treasurer: 
The Treasurer shall be responsible for all the financial affairs   
of the club in accordance with SGA and RSO policy and any other duties   

the club may assign. 

​
​
​
 The Secretary shall be responsible for the minutes of all   

Secretary: 
business meetings, shall conduct correspondence for the club. He/she is   
also the direct contact for all Alumni and will perform any other duties   

the club may assign.  

Media Manager: 
The Media Manager will update and maintain the team   
website. He/she shall be responsible for the team’s social media accounts  
and any other duties the club may assign.  

Fundraising Coordinator: 
facilitate all fundraising for the club and will perform any other duties   

The Fundraising Coordinator will organize and   

the club may assign.   

Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion Officer (DEI): 
spearhead new sustainable practices that ensure Men’s Rowing is an accessible 
program to athletes of all backgrounds and cultures. Functions include, but are 
not limited to: 

The DEI Officer will 

● Foster new diversity and inclusion policies that can be implemented within the program 
● Work with UMass NAACP chapter and multicultural groups to help with fundraisers, setup educational 

workshops, and ensure accessibility to each groups members 

● Take charge of the high school recruiting process by connecting and building rapport with various high 

school and community programs 

● Work with the Media Manager to make sure that social channels and website reflect an accessible team 

environment 

● Organize sustainable community service activities for the program to partake in 
● Work with head coach and captains to create a more accepting and inclusive team culture 

Section 3 Nominations for all offices shall be made from the floor by an active 

member. Officers will be chosen from the list of nominations by a   

majority vote of all active members as defined in Article III. Elections   
will be conducted and affirmed by a graduating officer chosen by the   

Executive Board.  

Section 4 If at any time the Executive Board as defined in Article IV finds by a 

two-thirds vote that an officer is not fulfilling their duties, that officer   

may be dismissed and secondary elections may be held. The Executive   
Board also may appoint a member to hold the office until such an   

election can be held.  

Section 5 Secondary elections are optional for a vacated office but if employed  must be 

held as soon as possible after the outgoing officer’s dismissal or   
resignation.  

Section 6 All new officers will assume office on June 1 of the election year and  hold 
office until May 31 of the following year.  

​
​
​
 
​
 
​
 
 
 ARTICLE IV EXECUTIVE BOARD  

Section 1 The Executive Board shall consist of all officers, team captains, and the  entire 

coaching staff.  

Section 2 The Board’s responsibilities include the decision making responsibilities  for day 
to day operation of the club.  

Section 3 The Board shall meet bimonthly to facilitate this process. These 

meetings are for the executive board. Details for the general team   

members will be given to them after the meetings.   

Section 4 General club meetings may be called by any member of the Executive  Board 
as deemed necessary.  

ARTICLE V MEETINGS  

Section 1 Meetings for the purpose of the club organization shall be called at the 
discretion of the members. 

Section 2 Members shall be notified of all formal business meetings at least 24  hours 

in advance.  

Section 3 Quorums shall consist of at least two-thirds of all active members.  

ARTICLE VI COACHES  

Section 1 Head Coach: A head coach shall be hired by the club in association with  an 

established Alumni Body. Their dismissal shall also be decided by   
the club in association with an Alumni Body.  

Section 2 Head coaching responsibilities include the coaching and training of 

Varsity men and women, Head of the Executive Board, overseeing   
administrative tasks, and the hiring and firing of assistant coaches.  

Section 3 Salaries for the coaching staff shall be set and provided by the club in 
association with an Alumni Body.  

Section 4 In the event of the dismissal of the Head Coach, all assistant coaches  may 

be retained or dismissed at the end of a contract year at the   

discretion of the new Head Coach. A contract year shall be defined as   

the period form June 1 to May 31.  

ARTICLE VII ADVISOR  

Section 1 The duties of the Advisor are to act as a liaison with the University 

Administration, to check on the academic eligibility of all Club   
members, and to provide general guidance to the Club.  

Section 2 The Advisor shall be appointed by the University or elected by a  majority of 

Club members. If elected, the Advisor holds office for one   
year and may retain their post by re-election of a majority.  

Section 3 The Advisor shall have no power to vote.  

 ARTICLE VIII DUES  

Section 1 Dues shall be determined by a majority vote of the Executive Board  based 

on projected expenses for the year. Additional fees may be   

assessed by the Executive Board for just case at any time during the year   

by a two-thirds vote.  

Section 2 Dues for the varsity team members will be collected after the first week  of the 
academic year. They must be paid in full at this time.  

Section 3 Dues for the novice team will be collected one week before the mid semester 

date of the fall semester. They may be paid in half at this time.   

The second half of their dues will be collected one week before the mid  

semester date of the spring semester.  

Section 4 Any member of the novice team who quits after their first race,  traditionally 

two weeks after the mid-semester, will not be reimbursed   

their due money. If they quit before their first race after paying dues,   

ARTICLE IX BY-LAWS  

they will be reimbursed. 

The Executive Board shall have the power to make by-laws to help   
administer the day to day running of the Club. Such power is quite   
broad, due to the large variety of decisions that must be made on a daily   
basis. Under no circumstances shall these by-laws contradict this   

Constitution, except by Amendment as defined in Article X.  

ARTICLE X AMENDMENTS  

This Constitution may be amended at any meeting of the Club   
membership following the meeting of the Club membership at which the   
amendment was presented. For any article to be amended it must be   

done on a two-thirds vote by a quorum of active members.
