DocsList.Name: Cru Constitution 5-14-15.docx
DocsList.Data:
The Constitution of Cru
At the University of Massachusetts-Amherst

ARTICLE I—NAME
The name of this student group is Cru.
This student group is a student chapter (hereafter Chapter) recognized by Cru, a California nonprofit corporation with its principal offices in Orlando, Florida.
This student group has applied for and been granted Chartered status as a Chapter of Cru.  As long as the student group fulfills the mission set forth in the Charter, and otherwise remains in compliance with its obligations under the Charter, the student group has the right to use the name and materials of Cru that are designated for the use of Chapters within the Campus Ministry. The student group has agreed that it will carry out the mission and present the messages of Cru.

ARTICLE II—PURPOSE
The purpose of the Chapter, as articulated in the Charter, is to build movements of people who are transformed by Jesus Christ.  The student-led movement seeks to introduce students to Jesus Christ, help them to grow in their faith, encourage them to live life passionately under the lordship of Christ, and inspire commitment to advancing the purposes of God in the world.

ARTICLE III—STATEMENT OF FAITH
The Statement of Faith is the doctrinal foundation of this organization.
The Statement of Faith for this organization can be found at http://www.cru.org/about-us/statement-of-faith/index.htm.

ARTICLE IV-STATEMENT OF MISSION AND VALUES
Our mission is to be a spiritual family that helps students grow in their faith in the Lord Jesus Christ and encourages others to explore and investigate the person of Jesus Christ.  In short, “we want to be a spiritual family that knows Christ and makes Christ known.”

We also want to encourage all students to attend various local churches that agree with the statement of faith in Article III.

We want to help others consider the person and deity of Jesus because we believe that there is no question in life more important than the “God question,” and college should be a time to wrestle with the biggest questions of life.  We always want to do this in a manner that is both respectful and intelligent. 

ARTICLE V—MEMBERSHIP
Section 1.
Membership will consist of at least 10 students and shall be open to all duly enrolled University of Massachusetts-Amherst students. Membership and activities are open to all currently enrolled students.
Voting membership shall consist of those members who regularly attend large group meetings, or a member of a small group Bible study for the previous six months, and have attended a Cru retreat or conference.
This Chapter may have associated members who are students from local colleges or non-students, such as faculty and staff, community members, alumni and Cru staff members. Associated members shall have all membership privileges except the right to vote or hold office.

Section 2.
A member may lose the privileges of membership, including the right to attend meetings and events sponsored by Cru, under the following circumstances:
1.  If the individual is causing disruption to the group or is engaged in disorderly conduct or threats.
2.  If the individual poses a danger to other students.
3. If the individual’s conduct rises to the level of harassment of another member of the group.
Under such circumstances, two or more members of the leadership team will meet with the individual, share the concerns, and ask him or her to leave the group.  The accused member may then request a hearing before the full leadership team.  The President, or another officer, will then call a special leadership meeting. They will hear from the accused member as well as other witnesses, confer, and make a decision regarding the accused member’s membership rights. 

Section 3: All members have the right to express their opinions and speak freely on any matter regarding the organization and can address the leadership team as well as the members of Cru.

ARTICLE VI – OFFICERS AND LEADERSHIP
Section 1: Officers
The officers of this organization will serve as liaisons with the University.  The officers of this organization shall be the following:
1.      President
2.      Vice President
3.      Secretary (Communication Director)
4.      Treasurer
Term of office: An officer shall serve for one year from the start of his term or until his/her successor is selected.
Leadership team: The leadership team shall consist of the officers and additional selected leaders, who also meet the qualifications spelled out in section 2, that will provide direction for various aspects of the Chapter’s purpose.

Section 2: Qualifications
In order to be eligible for office, members must demonstrate that they are qualified to serve as representatives of the Chapter and the organization of Cru. 
A.    Attendance requirement: Officers must have been involved for at least one full semester, having attended 75% of weekly large group and/or small group meetings (unless they were not in residence because they participated in an off campus study abroad program, an internship, or were involved in a Cru Chapter on a different campus).
B.     Knowledge requirement: Officers must complete the Chapter’s leadership application which shall determine the applicant’s experience and skill in providing spiritual leadership for the Chapter, knowledge of the Chapter’s core messages, and understanding of how to model the Chapter’s messages in their behavior.
C.     Alignment requirement: Officers must commit to lead the Chapter in a way which is consistent with the mission and faithful to the messages of Cru. Officers should follow Jesus’ example of leadership in word and deed. This will involve: 
1.      Guiding the Cru Chapter to serve the University community by seeking to care for student’s emotional, physical and spiritual needs.
2.      Leading ministry teams, teaching the Bible and using Cru materials in a manner that helps believers to grow in their Christian faith. This involves leading small group Bible studies, helping facilitate Christ-centered weekly meetings, or training members how they can communicate the messages that are central to the Chapter’s identity and mission.
3.      Demonstrating by example how to live in a manner that is consistent with the Biblical teachings Cru communicates.  In order to communicate the Chapter’s message clearly and with integrity, officers must not only speak the Chapter’s messages, but also live in a manner consistent with those messages. This requirement recognizes that communication is a multifaceted reality, requiring alignment between the words and behavior of the communicator. Failure to live consistently with the messages communicated results in hypocrisy and lack of credibility. 
4.      Presenting the Gospel of Jesus Christ in a manner designed to lead other students to examine, consider and accept the Christian faith as their own. Willingness and ability to clearly and respectfully present the Gospel of Jesus with an opportunity for people respond personally.
D.    Additional Eligibility Requirements: Officers must meet the school’s eligibility requirements for leaders of registered student organizations as required by the Student Government Association.

Section 3: Selection Process
A.    Officers of this Chapter will be chosen either through election by voting membership or nomination by the previous year’s leadership team which then is confirmed through election by the voting membership.  See Article VI. Additional leaders will be selected from the general membership. They will be chosen based on their ability to meet the same qualifications as the officers, and their willingness to serve.
B. 	Applicants who meet the qualifications outlined above shall be eligible for a leadership position.
C.     Applicants may be asked about their willingness to model the Chapter’s core messages through their behavior so that the messages are communicated with integrity.
D.    The staff members of Cru serve an advisory role in the selection process, working with the current leadership team to consider and evaluate potential new leaders. The leadership team will then select individuals, inviting them to take the new leadership roles.

Section 4: Removal of a Leader
Leaders may be removed from their positions by a majority of the Leadership Team.  Any member of the Chapter may make a complaint against any leader in the Chapter, including a member of the Leadership Team.  Following the complaint, the Leadership Team (or members of the Leadership Team) shall meet to confer with the Chapter’s Cru staff for advice and counsel. They will also meet with both the complaining individual and the accused leader. No leader may be removed without first receiving a full and fair hearing from the Leadership Team. A leader complained against may only be removed by at least a simple majority agreement of the remaining members of the Leadership team. 
Any misrepresentation on the leadership application or a change in the leader’s commitment to lead the Chapter to fulfill its purpose as stated in Art. II, shall be grounds for the immediate review of the leader’s position by the Leadership Team.

ARTICLE VII--ELECTIONS
Section 1.
Types of Elections: Elections will occur at the end of each term to select the following term’s officers.  Special elections may be held when an office is vacated in mid-term.

Section 2.
Nomination of Candidates: Candidates for an upcoming election can be nominated through the voting members or by the leadership team.  Any member may raise a question or concern to the leadership team regarding a present or proposed leader.  The candidate must meet the qualifications for office listed in Article VI, Section 2, in order to be placed on the ballot (or selected for any leadership position in a given term). 

Section 3.
Form of Vote: Voting members shall vote under this article by secret ballot.

ARTICLE VIII—MEETINGS
Section 1.
Types of meetings:
A.    Membership Meetings: Formal meetings of the voting membership to conduct a vote.
B.     Large and Small Group Meetings: Regularly scheduled meetings for all members to attend.
C.     Additional Meetings: Gatherings, in addition to regularly scheduled meetings, which are open to all members.

Section 2.
Quorum for Membership meetings: In order to conduct a vote of the voting members, at least half of the voting membership must be present at the meeting. 

Section 3.
Meetings shall be held to further the purposes of the Chapter.  The leadership team, in consultation with Cru staff, shall determine the frequency, time and place, and agenda of the various meetings.
Large group meetings typically occur weekly during the school year, breaking when instruction ends and during school vacation periods.  Small group meetings (Bible Studies, Discussion Groups) also meet weekly within the same parameters.  Other meetings necessary to advance the purposes of the Chapter will be held as occasion warrants.

ARTICLE IX—FINANCES
The Chapter may raise revenues through contributions, fundraising activities or by applying for school funds available to student groups.  Paying dues is not a mandatory requirement to be considered a member of this organization.  Students, however, may be asked to contribute for such events as special social gatherings, retreats and conferences in order to attend. 
The Chapter will hold to high standards of financial integrity.  A member or several members of the leadership team will be responsible to carefully administer any school funds granted to the Chapter.
ARTICLE X—ADVISORS
The officers will work with the Campus for Student Development advisor as assigned.

ARTICLE XI—CONSTITUTIONAL AMENDMENTS
Section 1.
The leadership team may seek to amend this constitution by general consensus.

Section 2.
Articles II and III may not be amended without express written permission of Cru.

Section 3.
All amendments, additions or deletions must be filed as is required with the office of Student Government Association at the University of Massachusetts-Amherst.

Created: 3/25/2015
Amended: 5/14/15

DocsList.Name: UMass Dance Company Guide (constitution_bylaws).pdf
DocsList.Data:
UMass Dance Company Guide

Account Info – Department ID: A714646000
Account Info – Fee Account Speedkey: 148303
Account Info – Revenue Account Speedkey: 148304

Deposits
" You are required to deposit both cash and checks into your RSO's account the
next business day. If you collect cash/check on the weekend the office will be
open on Monday.
" You should give a written receipt to anyone from whom you accept cash, and
keep a record of all receipts. Receipt books are available for free from the Center
for Student Development Office. Checks should be made out to the University of
Massachusetts Dance Company.
" To deposit checks go to room 416 of the Student Union (if you were coming
up from the campus center, you go up to the staircase left, take a right at the end
of the hall, and left at the end of the other hallway). You will deposit the money
into your revenue account (the speedkey is listed above; however, if you look
forget it they can look it up for you, or you can look it up on the computers there).
They will give you a deposit slip. Bring the deposit slips the Cashier's Office at the
bottom floor of the Campus Center. The Campus Center Cashier's Office will not
count your deposit immediately (maybe within 2 days) so make sure you keep the
receipt. Report any discrepancies to Krista Wilson, CSD Accounting Manager in
Room 416, immediately. If you require an immediate receipt, make your deposit
at the Bursar's Office in Whitmore (they will give you one upon deposit).
" In the case of a bounced check (where there are insufficient funds to cover the
check) a chargeback will be placed on your account and you will need to get a
replacement in the form of a certified check, money order, or cash.

Accessing the Bank Account
You can go to the SORC (basement of the Campus Center) to find out how much
money is in your revenue and fee accounts.

Booking Showcase
Showcases occur biannually; one per semester. You want to book them as late
in the semester as possible, as to give choreographers and dancers enough
time to prepare. For the fall showcase, the latest weekend you can book the
showcase is generally the weekend before Thanksgiving. For the spring
showcase, the latest weekend you can book the showcase is generally the
weekend before finals (this gives approximately two to three extra weeks of
preparation for the spring showcase). The university will not book any events
during the reading period or final examination period which excludes

 approximately the last two weeks that students are in school to book the
showcase.

-

Fill out the event request form located on Campus Pulse. This can be located

under UMass Dance Company -> Events -> Create Event. You can copy and
paste the description for the past showcase events instead of typing a new one
(UMass Dance Company -> Events -> Past Events). Make sure you mention
the amount of guests, the supplies we will need, and the acapella group
performance. You can fill in three dates and times when you fill out the event
request form. Your first choice should go through, because you went ahead
and talked to Melinda beforehand, but still make sure you fill in two other
possible dates and times, because things can always go wrong.

" After about two weeks past the mid-semester date, you should receive a
confirmation regarding the showcase. If you have not, contact Melinda.”

" You will then be receiving an AFS form in the gmail account. You must
thoroughly read this over and make sure everything is requested correctly.
There are always errors. Do this immediately, because the showcase’s
timeslot can be taken over by other groups until all of the details are
Solidified.”

" After the AFS is confirmed, you will receive an Event Order Form, which you
must repeat the same process for.”

" You then must go in to see an ECO in the SORC. You will confirm everything
you requested with them. You will also go over the layout of the room.”

In the CCA, we put the stage on the first wall perpendicular to the actual
stage. You will put a long curtain in the back, with two wings on each side.
The 300 chairs will be facing the stage with an isle in the middle. The
acapella group will be on the stage with just enough chairs for them
facing the stage. There will be two spotlights in the back of the room
shining onto the stage. The two treelights will be right in front of the stage
on each corner facing inwards. There will be one or two tables right when
you walk in on the left for the donations box, programs, snacks, drinks,
and whatever else you want to put out.

What you Need to Request
" 300 chairs – free
" 2 wireless microphones - $30
" 1 set of treelights (this is 2 treelights) - $50

 " 2 Spotlights (this is all the University owns) – free
Coat racks
" Room 168c at least 1-2 hours before the showcase for a cappella rehearsal
" 3 tables ( 1 table for donation box and UMDC poster, 1 table for baked goods)
" AV speaker to play music – free
" Request room from 10am to 5pm (for set up, rehearsal, and clean up)
No catered food
No security needed
No tickets

What you Need to Provide

Curtains- UPC form needs to be filled out at least a month before the show

Programs – Make sure you have these made at least a week before the showcase,
because there are always problems trying to print them, so you are better off
having it done earlier.

o The best option for printing is the copy and print center in the student
union. This is the cheapest option, and they can print the programs on all
different colors of paper. They have weird hours though, so you want to
look into that.

" Two table clothes for the tables with the food and programs, etc.
" A donations box.
" Pastries and food (these always go rapidly, so make as many as you can!)
" At least four signs pointing people in the right direction (one for either entrance
of the CCA, one pointing down the escalator, and one pointing into the CCA)
" Gifts for the seniors, if you chose to do so.
" Bagels for the dancers and helpers.
" An ipod to play the music on – THIS IS CRUCIAL.
o Make different playlists for each song, so they don’t automatically play, or
separate each song by a lag of 10 seconds or so, so they don’t play straight
after, and the sound people have time to pause it.

People the day of the showcase
-hosts (preferably 2 people) - or entire UMDC
-someone to play the music
-acapella group
-videographer

Campus Pulse description:
“The UMass Dance Company will perform a number of originally

 choreographed dances. The UMass Dance Company will also be joined by an on
campus acapella group. The show will last between 1.5 and 2 hours, with a 10
minute intermission. The dancers will work during the semester choreographing,
rehearsing, and perfecting their pieces in order to produce a professional level
dance showcase performance.”

Photo shoot
Group shoot once new members are picked

Everyone wears black
Meet at the back of the FAC stairs

Individual shoot

Can wear anything
Pick a weekend and give time slots for people to sign up for

Post new photos on Facebook and Campus pulse pages

Activities Expo
Attend both fall and spring expos if possible
Need to register online at campus pulse when re-registering RSO for a new academic year
UMDC poster
100-200 mini flyers with audition info
Laptop for people to write down email and personal info

Auditions
.
You need to have the date for auditions figured out before the Activities Expo,
because you need to tell people when it is!
You should have auditions before all of the other dance teams! A lot of people
don’t know the difference, and you don’t want to lose anyone to Stage Crew or
Dance Team just because they had their auditions first. Find out when they are
and make sure you have yours before.
All of the members should be wearing UMDC apparel so everyone auditioning
knows who is on the team.

" We have found that the best time to have auditions is between 7:30-9:30. Some
classes get out at 7:15, so you don’t want to exclude these people from
auditioning. 7:30 still isn’t too late though, so it’s not unreasonable to ask people
to come at this time.

 What you need:
Stickers for everyone to wear a number.
o An information sheets:
Half sheets for everyone to fill out full name, dance experience, year in school
o Everyone should have notebooks to make notes about those auditioning.
Format:
o In the past we have had across the floor turns, leaps, and tricks.
o Jazz/contemporary combo (make sure this is representative of the type of
dancing that we do)
o It generally takes about 2 hours – you should try not to go over this
because people may have homework already
" How to judge:
o In the past we have each held notebooks. We have sections for each part
of the audition (i.e. across the floor, combo, etc)
o Write people’s numbers that you want underneath each section
o At the end each person should have a list of everyone’s numbers that they
want on the team, but it’s also helpful to have it divided into sections,
because even if a member doesn’t vote for a person to be on the team
initially, if another person brings up their number you can look back and
see if you’ve marked them for something.

Choosing new members:
Discuss new members at the end of the audition
Make a finalized list and email people the next day

Role of the Board
" The role of the board is only to facilitate what needs to be done. It is a democratic
team in which everything that can be voted on must be voted on. The board
should be able to identify what needs to be done and provide several options
about how things can be accomplished. They then present the options to the
team for a vote.
" Currently there are 5 board members. If this needs to be changed there must be a
vote on it.
o Odd numbers tend to work the best, because it allows for tie breakers.
" Board members should be there all year! It has not worked out in the past having
to vote in new board members every semester. Reasons for this:
o Only the people that were there in the fall will have any authority on
campus pulse.
o You will need help from the board members abroad to get things
accomplished, because technically they are still board members on campus
pulse.

 o The new board members will not have access to Campus Pulse, and thus,
cannot fulfill many of the responsibilities of being a board member. This
puts more pressure on the other board members.
o There is no time for the new board members to shadow, because they can’t
shadow people who are in their first semester of being a board member;
this is not helpful.
" Every board member is a co-director. Everyone has the same role in the eyes of
the team.
o On campus pulse someone must be registered as the President and
someone must be registered as the Treasurer; however, this does not mean
that they should be seen differently or have more power than the other
board members.
o Everyone, in fact, must have a role on campus pulse, but other than
President and Treasurer, it doesn’t matter what the other titles are.
" Signature Responsibility:
o Two of the board members must have signature responsibility.
o To hold SR you must fill out forms online and in the SORC at the end of
the year or beginning of the new year.
o Without 2 of the members holding SR you will be unable to book any
events.
o SR lasts for the entire year, so it is even more crucial that these two board
members are present for the entire year.
" Training:
o There is a day in the fall that all RSO board members must go to training.
If you miss this day, you cannot be a board member. It lasts all day and
food is provided.
o Make sure you attend the budget and bank workshops that are offered on
this day, as they will give you a lot of guidance.
o There is online training that all board members must complete as well. It
is in the form of an OWL type quiz.
o The person registered as treasurer on campus pulse must do additional
training on OWL – so consideration should be given to who is going to be
treasurer. (The treasurer may also need to be present when dealing with
the bank account depending on how strict the employees of the bank and
the transfer station are.)

Timeline
" End of August - The first thing you need to do when you get to school is contact
Roger, the space coordinator at the Rec Center. He will tell you what the tentative
schedule looks like and when to come in again to finalize things. His email is
rheimerm@admin.umass.edu
" End of August – NSO performance

 " Beginning of September – Activities Expo will be the first week of classes
" Beginning of September – Once you have figured out Rec Center space
" Beginning of September – Auditions should be first or second week of school
" Beginning of September – Rehearsals and classes should start the second or third
week of school
" Beginning of September – About the third week of classes you should place the
clothing order
" End of September/Beginning of October – Photoshoot
" Mid Semester – you must request the CCA for the next semester’s showcase
halfway through the semester
" Fall Showcase – As late as possible. Usually the weekend after or before
Thanksgiving
End of January – Need to go to Roger the first day you are back on campus to
arrange practice space again
Mid Semester – Book fall showcase
End January – Vote in new board. This will not take effect until the new year,
but this will give them time to shadow your positions.
End of April – Budget will be due
End of Semester – re-register as an RSO on campus pulse
August – Finalize details about Fall NSO

DocsList.Name: Constitution/Bylaws 13-14.pdf
DocsList.Data:
Constitution of the University of Massachusetts 2013-2014 
Dance Company 

Article 1. 

MISSION STATEMENT 

UMass Dance Company is a pre-professional dance company.  We specialize in 
choreographing productions with highly developed concepts and story lines, to 
combine movement with the emotion that fuels it. The Company choreographs 
and performs dances in ballet, tap, jazz, hip hop, modern and contemporary 
mediums. The Company will hold classes, choreograph original dance pieces, and 
rehearse multiple times a week.  Each semester the Company will produce at least 
one show on-campus, participate in an on-campus dance showcase and/or 
compete at one local dance competition.  The UMass Dance Company strives to 
build a safe and creative environment for dancers to practice and perform, as well 
as build new and lasting friendships.   

Article 2. 

MEMBERSHIP 

Section 1.  Membership will be comprised of 15-25 currently registered 

undergraduate students of the University of Massachusetts. 

Section 2.  Members are selected through auditions. Auditions will be held at 
the beginning of the fall semester and/or the end of each semester. 

Section 3.  

During auditions, all Company members will have the opportunity 
to observe the dancers auditioning.  Dancers will be observed for 
technique, style, and emotional performance.  If a Company 
member feels the dancer will be a good fit they will award the 
dancer a point.  After the audition points will be tallied for each 
dancer.  The dancers will the highest tallied points will fill the 
open spots.  Any ties will be determined by the Creative Board.  
The Director will then inform the auditioned dancers the results of 
the audition.   

Section 3.  Members are required to attend all classes, rehearsals, and shows. 
If a member misses 4 rehearsals they will be choreographed out of 
the remainder of the piece, or as the choreographer so chooses.  
Attendance at classes will be more flexible, but members are 
encouraged to attend as many as possible to continue improving 
their dancing abilities. 

Article 3. 

OFFICERS 

Section 1. 

The UMass Dance Company is governed by a Creative Board that 
includes a Director, Assistant Director, Secretary, and Treasurer.  

Section 2. 

The Director is the head person in the Creative Board and is 
responsible for directing and delegating the Company.  Main 

Page 1 of 7 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 components of the positions include organizing and producing 
practices, board and member meetings, auditions, shows, 
competitions, and social events.  The Director will oversee all 
operations of the Company and delegate tasks when necessary to 
the appropriate people.   

Section 3. 

The Assistant Director is responsible for marketing, fundraising 
and maintaining RSO status.   

Section 4.  

The Secretary is responsible for record keeping, meeting minutes, 
developing the team calendar, newsletters and information 
distribution, and managing the Facebook and email account.   

Section 5.  

The Treasurer is responsible for all finances involved with the 
Company.  This includes developing the budget, managing the 
bank account, all purchasing and payment transactions, and billing 
and organizing money from Company members. 

Section 6.  

The Assistant Director, Secretary, and Treasurer are also 
responsible for supporting and assisting the Director as necessary.   

Section 7.  

The Director and the Treasurer will have signature responsibilities.  

Section 8.  

The Creative Board will meet for a short period of time once a 
week. 

Section 9.    During Creative Board and/or Company voting procedures, if the 
vote comes to a tie, the Director will cast the tie-breaking vote.   

Article 4. 

ELECTION OF OFFICERS 

Section 1.   Members of the Creative Board will hold office for increments of 

one school year.  Officers may be reelected for additional terms. 

Section 2. 

Section 3.  

Two weeks before Spring Break, the Company will nominate 
members to elect to the Creative Board for the following year via 
written ballot.  Members may nominate themselves or other 
members of the company.  Current Creative Board members can 
be nominated.  Members may be nominated for more than one 
position, however, if the nominee accepts and is elected for more 
than one position they will be assigned the position they receive 
the most votes for.  No person can hold more than one position per 
year.     

Once a member is nominated for a position, the member has an 
option to accept or deny the nomination.  Following nominations, 
the nominee will have a chance to campaign for the position.  The 
Company will allow each nominee to speak to all the members in 
their favor.  The week before Spring Break the Company will vote 
on each position.  Votes will be counted by the Creative Board 

Page 2 of 7 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 excluding the nominee for that position.  Announcement of new 
Creative Board members will be done before the University breaks 
for Spring Break.  

Section 3.  

Election procedures will be done by a secret written ballot. 

Section 4.  

Following the election of members to the Creative Board, new 
members will be asked to shadow their position for the remained 
of the semester to learn of their roles in their elected positions.  
However, elected members will not be able to vote or act as 
governing members until they assume their duties following the 
end of Finals Week in the Spring Semester.   

Article 5. 

REMOVAL OF OFFICERS & MEMBERS 

Section 1. 

Section 2. 

Section 3. 

If the Assistant Director, Secretary, or Treasurer steps down during 
tenure, an emergency voting process will take place to fill the 
position by all Company members.  If the Director steps down 
during tenure the Assistant Direction will take over the Director 
position.  Replacement for the missing Assistant Director member 
will then be resolved by an emergency voting process.   

An officer only may be removed from tenure for dereliction of 
duty or an egregious act that affects the rest of the RSO.  If any 
officer believes there to be grounds for removal, the first step is the 
remaining to discuss the issue with the Director.  If the Director 
feels the cause is just, the Director will then speak with the officer 
in question about the issue(s).  If the issue(s) continues, the other 
three Creative Board members will meet to determine cause. 

Once cause has been established, the Creative Board will present 
the member the list of cause(s) in writing privately by the Director 
before the next Creative Board meeting or at least one week in 
advance.  The officer may be then given the opportunity to step 
down.  A unanimous vote of the remaining officers is required to 
bring the impeachment to a vote before the rest of the club.   

Section 4. 

On voting night a vote of 75 percent of the members present is 
required to satisfy impeachment. 

Section 5. 

Only for reasons that affect the atmosphere, operations, or well-
being of the club may a member be asked not to attend.  This 
includes but is not limited to substance abuse (alcohol or drugs), 
physical or mental abuse to another Company member, negative 
attitude towards the group or individual, etc. If inappropriate 
behavior becomes apparent, the member will be given a verbal 
warning by one member of the Creative Board.  If the behavior 
persists may receive a 2nd verbal warning or asked to leave the 
group depending on the offense.  If the behavior still persists the 
Creative Board will ask the member to leave the group.  

Page 3 of 7 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Section 6. 

All Creative Board members must vote unanimously before an 
Company member is asked to leave the group. The Director will be 
responsible for delivering the decision to the individual.  

Article 6.  

DISPUTES AMONG MEMBERS 

Section 1.   When a dispute is noticed between two or more members of the  

Company that needs to be reported to the Creative Board, the  
Director or the Assistant Director will first speak with both parties  
separately to discuss the issue.  If the issue continues to  
be a problem for the overall company, the Director or Assistant  
Director will schedule a meeting with parties involved in order to  
discuss the issue further and develop a solution that benefits the  
Company.  After a solution is agreed upon, if the issue continues to 
harm the Company the procedures in Article 5 Section 5 will  
be followed. 

Article 7. 

FINANCES 

Section 1.   Modest dues are required for membership.  All monetary fees 

required from Company members will be billed to the members in 
writing at least two weeks before the bill is due. Members will 
receive a receipt of payment and all financial transactions will be 
recorded by the Treasurer. Any monies received shall be handled 
according to the regulations of and under the supervision of the 
Center for Student Development. 

Article 8.        CHOREOGRAPHY 

                        Section 1.        Large Group Choreography: Large group choreography includes 

all Company members. The Company will produce 1-2 large group 
performance per semester. All team members are encouraged to 
submit ideas for large group choreography in the previous 
semester. If the member wants to choreograph that piece they will 
include their name of the submission, however, if they do not want 
to choreograph that piece they should submit the idea without a 
name and a choreographer will be found if the idea is 
chosen.  Before the end of the semester, the Creative Board will 
review all submissions and chose the finalists ideas depending on 
the number entries. From there, the finalists will be revisited and 
expanded upon to include storyline, music, costume and other 
ideas to explain the idea. The finalists will also choreography one 
minute of their potential dance to teach to the team. The finalists 
will then be reviewed by the entire team and a vote will be held. 
The top one or two dances will be performed by the Company. 

Section 2. 

Small Group Choreography: Small group choreography is an 
opportunity for multiple Company members to choreograph.  
Company members will self nominate themselves to choreograph a 

Page 4 of 7 

 
 
    
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 small group for the following semester.  The Creative Board will 
then select the small group choreographers before the University 
breaks for the summer or winter breaks.  Company members can 
choose to participate in 2-3 small groups per year.  Small group 
choreographers and the Creative Board will decide the number of 
dancers and the roster for each dance based on dancer interest.  To 
determine dancer interest all Company members will participate in 
a survey.  This survey will ask Company members the number of 
small groups they would like to participate in and their preference 
of genre in order based on offerings.  Once the rosters are set all 
dancers will be notified.  Small group schedules will be determined 
by the choreographer of each piece 

Section 3. 

Choosing Special Roles in Choreography: If a piece of 
choreography has a special role(s) members participating in that 
piece will audition for that role. The choreographer will hold the 
mini audition and will assign the role.  No dancer will be allowed 
to hold more than one special role in a semester and the 
choreographer may not have a special role in their own dance. 

Article 9.  

CLASSES AND REHEARSALS 

Section 1.  

The UMass Dance Company will hold two classes and one 
rehearsal day per week.   

Section 2.    Company classes will be run by a different team member each 
class.  At the beginning of each semester, the Director will pass 
around a signup sheet for members to volunteer for dates.  Each 
Company member is required to run at least one class per semester.  
The member running class may choose to genre for that day and 
will state this when on the signup sheet at the beginning of each 
semester.  Once signups are completed and all class slots have 
been filled, the Director will give each Company member a 
schedule of classes with genres, allowing each member to prepare 
for each class appropriately.   

Section 3.  

If a Company member is scheduled to run class and cannot fulfill 
that task, that individual member is responsible for switching 
classes with another member.  When that occurs, the member 
responsible for the switch must inform the Director with at least 24 
hours notice in order for the Director to inform the rest of the 
company about any necessary changes.  If an emergency occurs 
the day of a members scheduled class, the Director will be 
responsible for either running the class or finding someone else to 
run the class.   

Section 4.  

Large group rehearsal schedule will be determined by the Creative 
Board and will be held on a separate day from classes.  Large 
group rehearsals with begin with a warm up before moving into the 
rehearsal. All members must attend the warm up before rehearsal.    

Page 5 of 7 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Section 5.  

If a large group rehearsal is cancelled due to holidays the next 
appropriate class will be replaced with rehearsals.  This should be 
determined in the Company schedule created at the beginning of 
the semester. 

Article 10.    DRESS CODE 

Section 1.  

Although the Company does not have a specific uniform, we do 
ask each member to dress respectfully for each class and rehearsal.  
It is suggested each member dresses as if they were a part of a 
professional company and recommends having a leotard as the 
base of Company attire.  Tight fitting clothes are essential to 
performance and hair must be tied back when dancing.  
Appropriate shoes are also recommended when necessary.   

Article 11. 

PERFORMANCES AND EVENTS 

Section 1. 

Section 2. 

Section 3. 

The UMass Dance Company strives to participate in at least two 
performances per school year (Fall and Spring semester)- a self-
run performance, an organized on-campus dance showcase, or a 
local dance competition. 

Photo Shoot: Each semester the team will participate in a photo 
shoot. Photos will be used for advertising for team, fundraising, 
fun and personal use. 

Social Events: The Company will hold multiple social events for 
members during the semester.  A couple times per semester, the 
members will hold a Company Night that includes a get-together at 
a member’s home, restaurant, or other event.  At the end of the fall 
semester, the Company will throw a Christmas Party and towards 
the end of each spring semester, the Company will put together a 
Cast Party- a fancier themed party for members and their guests.  

Article 12.  

STATEMENT OF FREE SPEECH AND EXPRESSION 

Section 1.  

All Company Members have the right to freedom of speech and  
expression.  All members are encouraged to voice their ideas and  
opinions as they please and each idea and opinion will be given  
fair consideration.  This right cannot be limited by the Creative  
Board or other Company members.   

Article 13. 

AMENDING AND RATIFACTION OF THE CONSTITUTION 

Section 1. 

Any members may request or submit an amendment to the 
Constitution.  The proposed amendment should be given to the 
Creative Board. 

Page 6 of 7 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Section 2. 

Section 3. 

The Creative Board will the determine stipulations and language of 
the amendment.  A unanimous vote by the Creative Board is 
required to finalize the amendment. 

Once approved by the Creative Board, it is submitted to the 
Company members at the next available meeting date.  If 
necessary, discussion is allowed.  A vote 50 percent plus 1 of the 
Company members present is required to pass the amendment. 

Section 4. 

Amendments must be submitted to the Secretary of Registry for 
final approval.

Article&2.&PURPOSE&AND&GOALS&
(
(

Section(2.1(Purpose(
(A) 

Delta!Kappa!Delta!Sorority,!Inc.!commits!itself!to!the!fostering!of!a!
united!sisterhood,!the!development!of!indomitable!spirit,!the!
betterment!of!the!community!through!humanitarian!services,!and!the!
education!of!ourselves!and!others!about!the!Indian!subKcontinental!
culture.!Furthermore,!we!dedicate!ourselves!to!personal,!cultural!
enrichment!through!the!awareness!and!preservation!of!our!traditions!
and!morals.!

!
Section(2.2(Goals&
&
(A) 

In!carrying!out!this!purpose,!this!organization!shall!strive!to!meet!the!
following!major!goals:!
To!serve!the!community!locally!and!globally!through!charitably!acts!of!
service!and!fundraising!money.!
To!reach!out!to!children!through!our!service!focus!by!helping!them!
succeed!in!school!and!enhancing!their!education.!
To!donate!money!to!unfortunate!and!abused!children!locally!and!in!
the!Indian!Subcontinent.!
To!uphold!the!prestige!and!image!of!Delta!Kappa!Delta!Sorority,!Inc.!
To!encourage!unity!among!the!other!chapters!within!Delta!Kappa!
Delta!and!develop!a!strong!sense!of!sisterhood,!culture,!and!morality.!
To!strive!for!unity!among!other!Greek!organizations!around!the!
nation.!

(A) 

Purpose!
(i) 

The!Executive!Board!of!a!chapter/colony!exists!to!lead!
an!entity!of!Delta!Kappa!Delta!Sorority,!Inc.!The!
Executive!Board!of!each!chapter/colony!will!be!
responsible!for!staying!in!constant!communication!
with!the!active!members!of!their!chapter/colony,!
other!chapters/colonies,!Board!of!Directors,!and!the!
National!Board.!The!following!section!contains!a!list!
of!officers!for!each!chapter/colony.!Each!
chapter/colony!should!at!least!have!the!following!
officers,!but!other!chair!positions!may!be!added!
according!to!the!needs!of!the!chapter/colony.!

Titles!

President!

Terms!of!office!
(i) 

Each!officer!will!hold!their!position!for!one!academic!or!

calendar!year.!

(ii) 

For!the!academic!term,!the!term!will!start!at!the!end!of!
May!and!go!through!the!following!May!for!that!
respective!school!year.!

(iii) 

For!the!calendar!term,!the!term!will!start!at!the!

beginning!of!January!and!go!through!the!following!
December!for!that!respective!calendar!year.!

(iv)  A!member!has!no!restrictions!on!the!number!of!years!
she!serves!on!the!executive!committee;!however,!a!
member!cannot!be!elected!to!hold!the!same!position!
of!office!for!more!than!two!consecutive!academic!or!
calendar!years.!

(v) 

If!there!are!not!enough!members!running!for!office!then!

one!person!can!hold!up!to!two!positions.!!

eligible!candidates.!!

Section(8.2(Associate(Membership(

(B)

All!ladies!interested!in!joining!Delta!Kappa!Delta!Sorority,!Inc.!
must!first!participate!in!2/3!of!the!Recruitment!process,!which!
is!detailed!in!Article!II.!Section!2.01!of!the!Bylaws.!
Once!a!lady!has!gone!through!the!recruitment!process,!the!
sisters!of!the!chapter/colony,!which!she!is!interested!in!joining,!
will!decide!if!she!can!participate!in!the!new!member!intake!
process!known!as!Association.!The!following!criteria!will!be!
involved!in!the!decision:!
(i) 

Lady!must!have!a!2.7000/4.0000!GPA!Term!and!

Cumulative!in!order!to!be!considered.!

(ii) 

Lady!must!have!attended!2/3!of!the!recruitment!

activities.!

(iii)

which!they!are!a!part!of.!

(iv) 

Lady!must!complete!an!interview,!which!will!describe!

her!intentions!for!joining!the!organization.!

If!all!criteria!are!appropriately!met,!then!the!respective!
chapter/colony!will!extend!a!bid!to!the!lady!to!participate!in!
the!new!member!intake!process.!
The!Association!process!will!take!a!minimum!of!eight!weeks!to!
complete!where!each!associate!member!will!be!given!a!set!of!
requirements!to!complete,!which!are!detailed!in!the!bylaws.!

Section(9.1(Purpose(

(A) Affiliate!organizations!are!established!service!or!philanthropic!

organizations,!which!share!a!common!purpose!with!Delta!Kappa!
Delta!Sorority,!Inc.!

(B) The!purpose!of!having!an!affiliate!organization!is!to!work!hand!

and!hand!with!the!community!to!spread!the!goals!and!purpose!of!
both!organizations.!By!affiliating!Delta!Kappa!Delta!Sorority,!Inc.!
with!other!service!organization!that!share!a!common!purpose,!we!
can!make!a!bigger!difference!in!the!community.!
!

Section(9.2(Monetary(Donations(
(

(A) Affiliate!organizations!shall!receive!monetary!donations!at!the!end!
of!the!school!year!annually!from!the!National!Board.!Amounts!may!
vary!yearKtoKyear!depending!on!the!available!funds.!

(B) Affiliate!organizations!shall!receive!monetary!donations!at!the!end!
of!the!school!year,!annually!from!each!respective!Chapter!and!
Colony.!A!minimum!of!$50!shall!be!donated!to!at!least!one!affiliate!
organization!listed!in!the!constitution.!Ideally,!chapter!or!colony!
should!budget!at!least!40%!of!their!money!of!which!to!be!donated!
for!donation!to!an!affiliate!organization.!!
!

Section(9.3(Current(Affiliate(Organizations(
(

(A) Delta!Kappa!Delta!Sorority,!Inc.!recognized!the!following!

organizations!as!official!affiliates:!!
(i) Children’s!Relief!and!You!(CRY!of!America)!for!the!common!

purpose!of!philanthropy!and!service!focus.!

(ii) United!Children’s!Fund!(UNICEF)!for!the!purpose!of!service!

focus.!
!
Section(9.4(Establishing(an(Affiliate(
(

(A) In!order!for!an!organization!to!be!considered!an!affiliate,!research!
must!be!done!on!the!organization!and!presented!to!the!National!
Board,!National!Service!Director,!and!the!Sisterhood.!It!must!
outline!the!following:!
(i) What!is!the!purpose!of!the!organization?!
(ii) Details!of!the!organization,!who!are!its!target!clients,!stats,!etc.!
(iii)  Why!is!the!organization!a!good!affiliation!for!Delta!Kappa!

Delta!Sorority,!Inc.?!!

(iv)  Does!the!organization!have!American!Affiliations?!
(v) Does!the!organization!have!501c(3)!nonKprofit!status?!

21!

 (vi)  Define!a!contact!in!the!organization,!contact!them!and!ask!if!

they!are!interested!on!affiliation!with!Delta!Kappa!Delta!
Sorority!Inc.!

(B) The!organization!will!be!voted!on!by!the!sisterhood,!National!

Board,!Directors,!and!Alumnae!and!must!pass!by!2/3s!majority.!

(C) Thereafter,!a!letter!must!be!drafted!by!the!National!Board!and!
sent!to!the!contact!person!of!the!organization!for!approval.!
(D) Once!the!letter!has!been!approved,!the!organization!can!officially!
be!considered!an!affiliate!of!Delta!Kappa!Delta!Sorority,!Inc.!

!
Section(9.5(Requirements(
(

(A) We!will!support!and!promote!each!other’s!events!by!having!

representatives!from!each!respective!organization!attend!the!
other!organization’s!events.!

(B) We!will!be!including!each!other’s!logos!and!links!on!our!respective!
websites,!which!will!help!both!organizations’!goals,!reach!more!
people.!We!request!that!the!organization!send!their!logo!so!that!
we!can!place!it!on!our!national!website!as!a!link!to!their!website.!

(C) Delta!Kappa!Delta!Sorority,!Inc.!will!provide!their!organization!
with!a!financial!contribution!at!the!end!of!each!school!year.!The!
amount!will!differ!yearKtoKyear!depending!on!the!amount!of!funds!
we!have!available.!The!only!things!the!organization!will!need!to!do!
in!exchange!is!list!Delta!Kappa!Delta!Sorority,!Inc.!as!one!of!their!
sponsors!on!their!pamphlets,!banners,!and!flyers.!

(D) A!representative!from!the!organization!will!be!requested!to!be!in!
attendance!at!events!that!we!put!on!that!will!specifically!benefit!
that!organization.!

(E) We!request!the!organization!to!provide!us!with!pamphlets,!flyers,!

posters,!etc.!so!that!we!can!promote!the!work!that!they!do.!

Section(11.1(Frequency(

(A) Chapter/colony!meetings!will!be!held!once!a!week!for!an!average!
of!an!hour!and!half,!but!can!be!longer!or!shorter!according!to!the!
amount!of!material!that!is!on!the!predetermined!agenda.!

specified.!

(C) National!Board!meetings!will!occur!at!least!twice!a!month.!
(D) National!Director!meetings!will!occur!twice!a!month!as!the!first!

part!of!the!National!Board!meeting.!

at!any!time.!

DocsList.Data:
Delta Kappa Delta Sorority, Incorporated
University of Massachusetts, Amherst | Est. December 4th, 2016

Article I.   Name

The name of this organization shall be known as Delta Kappa Delta Sorority, Inc. –
University of Massachusetts Amherst  Chapter (hereby referred to as Delta Kappa Delta) as
of December 4th, 2016.

Article II.  Purpose and Goals

Section I.  Purpose

A. Delta Kappa Delta Sorority, Inc. commits itself to the fostering of a united sisterhood,
the development of indomitable spirit, the betterment of the community through
humanitarian services, and the education of ourselves and others about the Indian
sub-continental culture. Furthermore, we dedicate ourselves to personal, cultural
enrichment through the awareness and preservation of our traditions and morals.

Section II.  Goals

A.

In carrying out this purpose, this organization shall strive to meet the following
major goals:

a. To serve the community locally and globally through charitable acts of

service and fundraising money.

b. To reach out to children through our service focus by helping them succeed in

school and enhancing their education.

c. To donate money to unfortunate and abused children locally and in the

Indian Subcontinent.

d. To uphold the prestige and image of Delta Kappa Delta Sorority, Incorporated.
e. To encourage unity among the other chapters within Delta Kappa Delta and

develop a strong sense of sisterhood, culture, and morality.

f. To strive for unity among other Greek and non-Greek organizations around

the nation and at UMass Amherst.

g. To encourage cultural diversity among the community by organizing cultural

events on and off campus.

1

 Article III. Crest, Colors, Symbol, Mascot, Flower, and Motto

Section I. Crest
See attached Document 1.

Section II. Colors
The colors of Delta Kappa Delta Sorority, Inc. are violet, black and silver.

Section III. Symbol
The symbol for Delta Kappa Delta Sorority, Inc. is the diya.

Section IV. Mascot
The mascot for Delta Kappa Delta Sorority, Inc. is the peacock.

Section V. Flower
The flower for Delta Kappa Delta Sorority, Inc. is the lotus.

Section VI. Motto

A. The Motto for Delta Kappa Delta Sorority, Inc. is:

“I slept and dreamt that life was joy,
I awoke and saw that life was service,
I acted, and behold, service was joy.”
- Rabindranath Tagore

B. Whenever the motto is communicated written or orally, credit must be given to

Rabindranath Tagore for writing it.

Article IV. Philanthropy, Service Focus, & Country Focus

Section I. The philanthropy of Delta Kappa Delta Sorority, Inc. is the prevention and
awareness of child abuse. At least 25% of the money raised by this organization must be
donated to organizations relating to our philanthropy.

Section II. The service focus of Delta Kappa Delta Sorority, Inc. is the education of children.
A portion of service hours must serve this focus.

2

 Section III.  Country Focus

A. Delta Kappa Delta Sorority, Inc. a country focus each year.  The purpose of this focus

is to learn about the culture and customs of the country as well as donate the
majority of their global donations to charitable organizations within that country.

B. The country focus list is as follows:

a. Bangladesh
b. Bhutan
India
c.
d. Nepal
e. Pakistan
f. Sri Lanka

C. The country focus will rotate to the next alphabetical country in the cycle with the

beginning of each new school year.

Article V.   Membership

Section I.  Associate Requirements

A. An associate must be in good standing with the University, have at least a 2.700 GPA
cumulative, and maintain at least a 2.700 GPA for the term concurrent to the term of
association.

Section II.  Officer and Member Requirements

A. Members and officers must have at least and maintain a 2.700 GPA cumulative and

for the concurrent term of membership.

B. To maintain membership, members and officers must pay stated amount of dues for

the term.

C. To maintain membership, members and officers must participate in Delta Kappa

Delta community service events and complete the required number of service hours
each term.

D. To maintain membership, members and officers must complete the designated 8
individual, 8 philanthropy, 5 service, and 9 sister community service hours.

a.

If a member does not complete the required community service hours during
a given semester, the member will be put on Service Probation.
b. A sister on Service Probation is considered active and must fulfill the

membership requirements.  Any hours that a sister does not complete must
be doubled and completed during the next active semester as well as the
concurrent terms service hours. Thereafter, if the sister does not finish all the

3

 hours (probationary plus required), the member will be expelled from the
sorority.  If a sister is on service probation once, and does not complete the
service hours during any semester thereafter, the member will be expelled
from the sorority.

c. The affected sister may appeal if there are extenuating circumstances, to be
passed by a 2/3 majority of remaining active sisters.  Whenever possible,
only the Community Service Chair and President should know that a sister is
on Service Probation.

E. To maintain membership, all active members and officers must attend social events

each month, but have two excused absences per semester to use whenever
necessary.

Section III.  Inactive Requirements

A.

B.

In order to obtain a state of inactivity the member must present a letter that states
the need for becoming an inactive at the last meeting of the  semester before, which
must be approved by all actives with a 2/3 majority vote.
Inactive must pay half of the membership dues for the term of inactivity.  Inactive
members will not be permitted to join the active class again until they have paid
their previous inactive dues.

C. After an inactive term, one must become active to maintain membership in Delta

D.

Kappa Delta.
Inactive members may participate in chapter activities given that they provide 48
hours notice to the respective officer/chairperson, unless 2/3 active member
majority votes otherwise.

a.

b.

Inactive Sisters are allowed to attend service events but are not allowed to
attend monthly socials, fundraising events, or vote, unless specifically invited.
However, for special annual events, they may attend if voted on by 2/3
majority.
Inactive Sisters may wear sorority letters and associate with the sorority.
Assuming inactive status does not exempt a sister from outstanding fines or
service hours.  If an inactive sister did not complete the required hours in
their last active semester, the member will be put on service probation
during the next active semester.

Section IV.  Fundraising Requirements

A. Any event designated as fundraising cannot be counted as community service hours.

4

 B. Events where Delta Kappa Delta members or associates raise money specifically for

another organization and ONLY for that organization should be considered a
community service event up to two hours per term.

C. Fundraising requirements, passed by a 2/3 majority of active sisters, is set by the

Fundraising Chair at the beginning of each semester.  These requirements are hourly
or by event.  If this requirement is not fulfilled, a fine will be assigned to the sister.
D. With a minimum of 25%, the percentage of the monies fundraised by Delta Kappa

Delta will be either donated to charity or reserved for Delta Kappa Delta sponsored
community service events, as deemed by the active members.  The remainder
should cover various sorority expenses.  (Exceptions apply where money is raised
for a specific organization, in which all is donated to the specific organization.)

Article VI.  Recruitment Process

Section I.  Recruitment Procedures

A. Recruitment procedures will be set each term by the Recruitment/Association chair

with a 2/3 approval of all active sisters.

Article VII. Election Process

Section I. Election

A. Elections will be held at the end of each semester pending grade check for the

following semester. Members must receive a 2/3 majority vote to become an officer.
E-Board positions are to be held for one year beginning at the end of the Spring
semester after elections. Chair positions are to be held for one semester.
If an E-Board officer graduates in the fall term, elections will be held accordingly to
fill that position for the Spring term. This does not include the President and Vice
President positions.
If an executive officer, officer, or committee chair decides to leave Delta Kappa Delta
or resign their position, elections should be held at the next meeting to replace the
aforementioned person.
If an officer graduates in the fall term, elections will be held accordingly to fill that
position for the spring term.
If a member is a first term active then they are not allowed to hold any Executive
Board positions unless it is absolutely necessary, but other non-Executive Board
positions are available.

B.

C.

D.

E.

5

 F. Actives, other than first term members, may run for any officer position, executive,

or committee chairs.

Section II. Election Procedure

A. Executive positions can be given by nomination only.
B. The election will be done by the Nomination/Discussion/Pro-Con-Pro method. All

nominees for that position must step out of the room when Discussion/Pro-Con-Pro
is being applied.

C. During Discussion, all nominees step out of the room. All other Sisters in the room
will discuss all of candidates and formulate questions. Nominees come in one at a
time for questioning. The Sister who held the chair the semester before is allowed to
ask the first question. After all nominees have been asked questions, they must all
step out of the room for Pro-Con-Pro.

D. The Executive positions will be the first to be nominated and elected.
E. All positions must be passed with a 2/3 majority vote. If a 2/3 majority is not

obtained for the first three times, a simple majority vote is accepted.

Section III. Voting Privileges

A. Members that have just finished a term of association and are now actives can only

vote in general meetings and for all chair and executive positions. These new actives
cannot vote in impeachment, suspension, or expulsion issues.

B. Actives have full voting privileges.
C. The executive officers have the ability to veto any item passed by the members of

Delta Kappa Delta by a 3/4 majority vote.

D. Sisters must physically attend the meeting in order to vote. If unable to attend, they

forfeit the right to vote.

Article VIII.  Probation, Suspension, Impeachment, and Expulsion

Section I.  Probation

A. Criterion for probation is the incompletion of service hours during a semester or

failure to maintain our academic standards, stated below.

a. Active members are allowed one term in which their term and cumulative
GPA is between 2.500 and 2.700. In their consecutive term, the active
members must have and maintain a 2.700 term GPA and a 2.600 cumulative
GPA. If these standards are not satisfied, the individual will be on probation.

6

 b.

c.

If an active member holds a term and cumulative GPA between 2.500 and
2.700, that individual should not maintain a position on the Executive Board
or the Chair Board- pending a review of academics.
If an active member is in danger of an academic probation, that individual
must maintain interactions with the Academic Chair. It is up to the
individual’s and the Academic Chair’s discretion if that individual is between
2.500 and 2.700 term and cumulative GPA for the first semester is active.

Section II.  Suspension

A. Criterion for suspension includes a GPA below 2.700 and incomplete community

service hours.  Members will appear before officers and suspension will be decided
by a majority officer vote.

B. While on suspension, members will pay half of the dues to the organization for the

term.

Section III.  Impeachment out of Delta Kappa Delta

A. A member will be impeached out of office by not completing their officer duties
efficiently and successfully.  Reasons for impeachment can be brought before the
executive committee and the Parliamentarian will preside over the meeting.
Impeachment of the officer will be decided by a ¾ majority of the active members.

Section IV.  Expulsion out of Delta Kappa Delta

A. A member will be expelled from this organization based on a majority decision by

the active members.  A member to be expelled will appear before the active
members and reasons for expulsion will be stated by the executive committee.

Article IX.  Meetings

Section I.  Meetings, Dates, and Attendance

A. General meetings will be held at least two times a month in which all active sisters

must be in attendance during each active term.

a. Officers must meet weekly.
b. Not being present within five minutes from the start of a meeting or event
counts as a lateness.  Arriving after fifteen minutes from the start of a
meeting or event counts as a tardy, thereby resulting in a fine and revoked
voting privileges for that meeting, unless there has been prior notification.  In

7

 addition, for every ten minutes past the fifteen minute tardy, there is an
additional fine.

i.
ii.

Arriving more than 5 minutes late to a meeting will result in a $2 fine.
Arriving more than 15 minutes late to a meeting will result in a $5
fine.

c. Secretary shall determine valid excuses for meetings and shall be notified 24

d.

hours in advance of event to avoid fines in a formally written format.
In case of events, the respective chair must be notified 48 hours in advance of
event to avoid fines.

e. Sisters are allowed to miss 2 meetings a semester but the Secretary must be
notified 48 hours in advance, unless it is an emergency situation.  It is highly
encouraged that Sisters attend every meeting though.

i.

The third one is unexcused, it is up to the executive board’s discretion
about whether or not to fine that sister. If the reasoning behind the
absence is valid, the sister will be excused. If the reasoning is not valid,
the sister will be fined the regular amount of $20.00 for an unexcused
absence to a chapter meeting. This fine can be appealed at the end of
the semester if the sister deems it unfair.

f.

g.

If a member misses a meeting and is unexcused, the member shall be fined
$20.00.  If a member is more than late to a meeting, the member shall be
fined $2.00.  If a member is fifteen minutes late to a meeting, the member
shall be fined $5.00 tardy fee.  For every additional ten minutes after the
tardy fine you will pay an additional $2.00.
If a member does not wear DKD attire (shirt, sweatshirt, jacket) to the
meeting, they will be fined $2.

Article X: Fines

Section 1:  General fines

A.

If a member is late to an event, the member shall be fined.  If a member misses an
event and is unexcused, the member shall be fined.

a. The first time a member is tardy to an event, they will be issued a warning

however the chair should notify the secretary.

B.
C.

If a member sends in updates less than 48 hours in advance, they will be fined $2.
If a member misses a MGC mandatory event, that member shall pay the full fine
given by MGC.

8

 a.

If a member is late to a mandatory event, the fines set for colony meeting
fines apply.

D.

E.

F.

If a cell phone or laptop makes any noise during a meeting there will be a $1 fine for
every disruption.
If a member fails to meet a deadline there will be a fine set by the discretion of the
officer of that position that it affects.
If a sister feels that the fine is inappropriate, the sister may appeal to the Executive
Board.  E-board must have a ¾ majority vote.

Article XI.  List of Officers and Duties

Section I.  Officer Positions and Responsibilities

A. President: Shall preside over the regular and executive meetings, oversee group
activities, and communicate with the officers and advisors on all matters.  Shall
oversee and routinely check the Delta Kappa Delta email account.  Must attend
monthly UGC President Council meeting.

B. Vice President: Shall assist President and preside over the committees and meetings
in the absence of the President.  Shall be responsible for heading all activities and
duties related to the United Greek Council, and must be one of the delegates for UGC
General Assembly meetings.

C. Treasurer: Shall collect dues, pay bills, and oversee other monetary transactions
including fundraising and social activities, and prepare and maintain the annual
budget.  Shall be an alternate for a United Greek Council General Assembly meeting
when a delegate cannot make it.

D. Secretary: Shall record minutes at all official meetings, record attendance at

meetings, approve excused absences for meetings, and record meeting excuses. Book
the rooms for meetings.

E. Parliamentarian: Shall keep track of records not listed and maintain a calm and

orderly environment within meetings.

F. Social Chair: Shall organize social events and cultural events, along with other
activities within the organization and among other organizations.  Shall keep
communications with the graduated members and inform them on events within the
organization.  Shall work hand in hand with the Public Relations Chair.

G. Sisterhood Chair: Shall work hand in hand with the Social Chair.  Shall organize

monthly socials/ mixers for the sisters only. Create bonding event and activities for
sisters to participate in each month. May also help the social chair in organizing and
overseeing events.

9

 H. Community Service Chair: Shall organize all community service events for the

organization, record attendance at service events, and record the community service
hours for the organization.

I. Historian: Shall keep record of activities and events through photography and shall

compile a scrapbook at the end of the spring term.

J. Fundraising Chair: Shall organize all fundraising events for the organization.
K. Recruitment Association Chair: Shall oversee all events for Recruitment Week and

will organize events for the associates.

L. Web Tech Administrator: Shall maintain and update the Delta Kappa Delta webpage.
Shall maintain and update the United Greek Council webpage.  Shall monitor Delphi.

Section II.  Combinations

A. The positions of Historian and Web Tech Admin, as well as treasurer and fundraiser

may be combined with a 2/3 votes of all active sisters

B. There may be two co- recruitment association with 2/3 vote of all the active sisters.

Section III.  Committees

A. Committees that will be formed at the beginning of the term will be the following,

each headed by the respective officers:

a. Service/Philanthropy Committee
b. Social/Alumni Committee
c. Fundraising Committee
d. Recruitment Committee
e. Public Relations Committee

Article XII.  Finances

Section I.  Dues

A. Amount of dues shall be determined by officers per term and will be due at the
second meeting of each term in full unless an installment plan is chosen, which
would be organized by the Treasurer.  Follow national bylaw procedure.

B. Each Sister will be required to pay the $50 dues by the third official meeting of the

semester.

Section II.  Financial Transactions

10

 A. All monies belonging to the organization shall be deposited and dispersed through a
bank account established for the organization.  All funds must be deposited within
one week after collection.

Article XIII.  Alcohol

Section I. Alcohol Stipulations

A. This organization will be in full compliance with University of Massachusetts’

alcohol policies and the state laws concerning alcohol.  It is understood that drinking
or having possession of an alcoholic or intoxicating beverage in public areas or
campus is prohibited.

B. Members are prohibited from drinking at any events sponsored by the organization.
Members and officers, active or inactive, are prohibited from consuming or having in
possession alcohol and/or illegal drugs while officially representing Delta Kappa
Delta.  Representation of Delta Kappa Delta includes wearing any type of Delta
Kappa Delta paraphernalia.  Any member or officer attending a Delta Kappa Delta
event partially or completely intoxicated and/or under the influence of an illegal
substance is subject to a one semester suspension period based on a ¾ vote of the
executive officers.  Any service hours remaining at the completion of the term will be
made up the following term.  If the service hours are not completed in the time
allotted, the member is subject to expulsion.

Article XIV.  Hazing

Section I.  Hazing Consequences

A. This organization will be held in full compliance with University of Massachusetts’
hazing policy.  Any member or associate that suffers from hazing shall report the
incident to the executive committee and National Board and punishment shall ensue.

B. Hazing allegations will be brought immediately to the knowledge of the National
Board.  After carefully considering all aspects of the situation and getting the
opinions of all of the sisters, chapters, and colonies, the National Board will make a
recommendation to all the chapters and colonies regarding the future of the accused
sister(s) and/or chapter(s) or colony/colonies.

C. The chapters and colonies will then vote to accept the recommendation. A 2/3
majority will be required to pass the recommendation, which will go into effect
immediately.

D. The chapter/colony, which is being voted on, will not be allowed to vote.

11

 E.

If a majority is not reached, voting will continue along the guidelines set in the
constitution of Delta Kappa Delta Sorority, Incorporated.

F. The consequences for hazing can range from suspension for one semester to
expulsion from Delta Kappa Delta Sorority, Incorporated and revocation of a
chapter/colony. There can be no lesser consequence than a one semester suspension
and no greater consequence than expulsion or chapter/colony revocation.

G. The National Board will decide which consequence seems fit for their

recommendation to the chapters/colonies. If the hazing allegations are found to be
true, the National Board must inform the university or college of the chapter/colony
of the hazing violations and work with them to resolve the issue.

H. If the National Board decides that the hazing allegations are unfounded, it will issue
a recommendation to drop the allegations against the accused sister(s) and/or
chapter(s) or colony/colonies which must be passed by a 2/3 majority of the
chapters and colonies.

a.

b.

If passed, the accused sister(s) and/or chapter(s) or colony/colonies will be
cleared of all hazing allegations immediately.
If a 2/3 majority is not reached, voting will continue along the guidelines set
in the constitution of Delta Kappa Delta Sorority, Incorporated.

Section II.  Definition

A. Hazing is defined as any action taken or situation created to produce mental

discomfort, embarrassment, harassment, or ridicule. Such activities and situations
include (but are not limited to):

a. Paddling in any form, pushing, hitting, or physical threats
b. Creation of excessive fatigue, or forced or coerced participation in

calisthenics

c. Physical or psychological shocks
d. Quests, treasure hunts, scavenger hunts, road trips, or any such activities not
directly related to the purpose of Delta Kappa Delta Sorority, Incorporated.

e. Publicly wearing apparel which is conspicuous and not normally in good

taste

f. Requiring shaved hair
g. Public nudity
h. Engaging in public stunts or buffoonery
i. Morally degrading or humiliating games and activities

12

 j. Late work sessions or activities that interfere with scholastic activities,

including exhausting and time consuming projects that are disruptive to
normal study patterns.
k. Tasks of personal servitude.
l. Physical disfigurements including tattooing and branding (temporary or

real).

m. Deprivation of normal sleep (less than 6 hours).
n. Memorization of information not directly related to Delta Kappa Delta

Sorority, Incorporated.

o. Forced, required, or coerced consumption of any food, liquid, or other

substance.

p. Any dangerous activity including, but not limited to, long swims, jumps from
high places, binding, and blindfolding (except as may be REQUIRED by the
national ritual).

q. Requiring the carrying of large and/or heavy objects such as bricks, buckets,

or large wooden crates.

r. Required participation in public acts, skits, or songs, for the purpose of

humiliation or embarrassment.

s. Any activity considered morally offensive by the participating individual
t. Making a recruit, associate, or sister feel "less than" they are worth or

potential.
Intentionally creating clean-up work.

u.
v. Confining participants to rooms or areas that are uncomfortable due to
temperature, noise, size, or air quality for the purpose of harassment.

w. Any activity without constructive aspect or reasonable purpose, including but
not limited to "line ups", "rat courts", mock trials, interrogations, yelling of
obscenities, or votes of continuance not consistent with the national
constitution or, or sanctioned by Delta Kappa Delta Sorority, Incorporated.

x. Any activity not consistent with the laws and rituals of Delta Kappa Delta

Sorority, Incorporated.

y. Any activity not consistent with the policies and regulations of University of

Massachusetts at Amherst.

Article XV.  Amendments and Revisions

Section I.  Amendments

13

 A. This constitution may be amended at any time by a 3/4 majority vote of the active

members.  The amendments must be in compliance with the goals and standards set
forth by Delta Kappa Delta Sorority, Incorporated  and University of Massachusetts
at Amherst.

Section II.  Revisions

A. This document must be reviewed every year and resubmitted to Campus Activities.

Article XVI.  Conduct Probation Policy

Section I.

A. See the National Constitution Article VIII, Section 5 & 6.

Last Revised
Neha Potturu, Founding Line, President | 09/16/18
Deepti Kamma, Founding Line, Marketing/PR Chair | 05/16/19

14
