Designated USFA events.  UMass fencing will organize transportation to these meets.
Other USFA events. Listed for your information.

DocsList.Name: 00 Filipino Student Association Constitution.pdf
DocsList.Data:
I.

I.

FILIPINO STUDENT ASSOCIATION CONSTITUTION/CHARTER
University of Massachusetts Amherst

ARTICLE I: ORGANIZATION TITLE

The title of this organization is the “Filipino Student Association”, and will be noted as
“FSA” throughout this document.

ARTICLE II: MISSION STATEMENT

The mission of the Filipino Student Association at the University of Massachusetts
Amherst is to

A. Create a platform for and amplify the voices of Filipino and Filipino-American

students at the university, and surrounding Five College institutions.

B. Introduce Filipino heritage to students in the Five Colleges through education and

community involvement.

C. Raise awareness of the Philippines’ rich history and traditions through native

cuisine, language learning, traditional folk dances, and other activities of interest.

D. To promote the discussion of Filipino culture around campus through social
events—including but not limited to karaoke nights, talent shows, cultural
showcases, and feasts.

E. Uphold Filipino familial values by creating an inclusive, welcoming environment

within our organization and encouraging all interested students to join us,
regardless of their background.

II.

The group’s goals for the next five academic years are to

A. Expand our following through active efforts to recruit and engage general body

members.

B. Establish a long-lasting community of leaders who will foster teamwork,

collaboration, peer support, and mentorship.

C. Build relationships and connections by networking and collaborating with other
Filipino Student organizations and Asian American organizations locally and
nationally.

ARTICLE III: MEMBERSHIP

I.

II.

III.

All students at the undergraduate and graduate level at the University of Massachusetts
Amherst and within the Five College Consortium shall be eligible to be members of the
Filipino Student Association.
FSA will have one General Body membership to promote inclusivity for all people in the
UMass Amherst and Five College community.
This membership shall be known as the General Body and defined as such:

 A. General Body Membership are those who display an active interest in our

organization’s mission and events. Active interest is displayed by:

1. Attending at least 3 of the total number of meetings or events per semester

a) Attendance may be in-person or virtual, should the need arise.

(1) Example: With 5 meetings and 5 events each semester, a

2.

General Body Member could attend 1 meeting and 2 events
to be acknowledged as an official member
Individuals may join the General Body of the FSA by attending any FSA
activities or events, signing up for the FSA emailing list, or by reaching
out to any of the Executive Board members expressing interest.

IV.

The personal information of General Body Members shall not be disclosed to anyone
outside of the FSA Executive Board, without the prior consent of the involved
member(s). The right to privacy shall be observed.

A. Personal information includes, but is not limited to, the following: names,

addresses, phone numbers, and email addresses.

V. Within the General Body, members of FSA have the ability to participate in committees

A. A committee is defined as a smaller subsection of the General body, appointed by
the Executive Board for the completion of a specific task, especially in event
planning.

B. Membership of a committee is voluntary, and based solely on the willingness of a

general body member to participate in that committee.

1. Appointment to a committee requires:

a) The individual participating in the committee to be an active

General Body member.

b) An executive board member to assign that person to a committee.

(1) Assignments are not elected positions, as they are not

permanent.

C. Committees will be created and led by Executive Board members as the need

arises for a specific committee.

ARTICLE IV: THE EXECUTIVE BOARD

I.

The Officers of the Executive Board may consist of a President, a Vice President, a
Treasurer, a Secretary, an Event Coordinator, and a Publicist-- though other positions may
be created or terminated depending on the needs of the association. While these are the
primarily available positions, more than one General Body member may be elected for
certain positions. (i.e. Co-Presidents, Co-Event Coordinators, Co-Publicists). In these
cases, the distribution of responsibilities will be determined at the discretion of the

 current Executive Board. Descriptions of the positions are outlined below, including a
non-exhaustive list of each position’s responsibilities:

A. President(s)

1. The President(s) shall act as the Chief Executive Officer of the Filipino

Student Association.

2. The President(s) must be a student at the University of Massachusetts

3.

Amherst.
In the event of an emergency, the following are the protocols for presiding
over the organization:

a)

b)

In the event that one Co-President is absent for whatever reason,
the other Co-President will assume full Presidential authority and
facilitate all meetings or events until the absent Co-President
returns or the meetings/events have concluded.
In the event that both Co-Presidents are absent for whatever reason
or the only President for that given term is absent for whatever
reason, the Vice President will assume full Presidential authority
and facilitate all meetings or events until the President(s) returns or
the meetings/events have concluded.

4. The President(s) shall ensure that all Officer duties are being completed

efficiently and on-time, provided there is a given deadline.

5. The President(s) shall have final decision making authority relating to the

organization, after consultation with the Executive Board.

a) Consultation with the Executive Board is defined as

communication of the decision and outcomes, with opportunity to
make suggestions and revisions.

6. The President(s) shall serve as the main representative(s) and speaker(s)
for the association and must maintain a high level of conduct that reflects
the values of the University and the organization’s mission.

7. The President(s) shall Have 2 Officers obtain Signature of Responsibility,
whom will be responsible for receiving and responding to communications
from the SGA and Student Engagement and Leadership office

B. Vice President

1. The Vice President shall act as the Chief Administrative Executive Officer

of the Filipino Student Association

2. The Vice President must be a student at the University of Massachusetts

Amherst.

3. The Vice President shall work closely with the President(s) and Event

Coordinator(s) to plan and coordinate all activities.

 4. The Vice President shall work closely with the Secretary of the association

to oversee administrative procedures within the organization and
Executive Board.

5. The Vice President shall have signature responsibility.

C. Treasurer

1. The Treasurer shall be the Chief Financial Officer of the Filipino Student

Association.

2. The Treasurer must be a student at the University of Massachusetts

Amherst.

3. The Treasurer shall handle all association finances and financial

transactions and create a working budget, as requested by the Executive
Board.

4. The Treasurer is responsible for keeping record of all financial activities of

the association.

5. The Treasurer shall provide updated budget reports for every Executive

Board meeting.

6. The Treasurer shall be responsible for the official RSO Budget Proposal

for the following fiscal year.

7. The Treasurer shall be responsible for the approval of internal budget

proposals submitted by Event Coordinator(s) for any and all activities of
the association.

8. The Treasurer shall have signature responsibility.

D. Secretary

1. The Secretary shall be the Chief Archivist Officer of the Filipino Student

Association.

2. Must be a student at the University of Massachusetts Amherst
3. The Secretary is responsible for tracking attendance and recording detailed

meeting minutes for all Executive Board meetings.

4. The Secretary is responsible for the timely organization and storage of
minutes via the shared Google Drive folder for the association for the
respective academic year.

5. The Secretary shall build an archive of the organization’s history and
organize and compile any previous records to build a complete set of
archives.

6. The Secretary shall be responsible for all interactions with the

organization’s email.

a) This includes, but is not limited to, responding to emails in a

timely manner, sending out email reminders and notices regarding

 the association, communicating with SEL leaders and SGA
leadership.

7. The Secretary shall work closely with the Vice President to ensure an

organized, efficient Executive Board and association.

E. Event Coordinator(s)

1. The Event Coordinator(s) shall be responsible for planning successful and

engaging events with the assistance of the Executive Board, when
necessary.

2. The Event Coordinator(s) shall work closely with the Vice President to

plan the activities of the association.

3. The Event Coordinator(s) are responsible for submitting budget proposals

for organized events and activities to the Treasurer for approval.

4. The Event Coordinator(s) are responsible for the following non-exhaustive

list of activities,

a) Making venue reservations
b) Scheduling activities and/or events
c) Booking guest speakers/performers
d) Purchasing and setting up decorations
e) Updating FSA calendar for E-board as soon as events/meetings are

discussed and finalized

F. Publicist(s)

1. The Publicist(s) shall be responsible for maintaining the organization’s
social media representation amongst all of the association’s platforms,
with input from Executive Board and general body members

2. The Publicist shall assist the Events Coordinator with advertising planned

events and activities.

3. The Publicist’s social media duties include, but are not limited to:

a) Running promotional campaigns
b) Designing fun and engaging content
c) Making Instagram announcements
d) Creating Facebook events

II.

Standards of Behavior:

A. The officers of the Executive Board shall fulfill their respective duties as defined

by this constitution and by the discretion of the President.

B. Each officer must read the distributed minutes and seek updates from members of

the Executive Board, in the event that they miss a meeting.

C. Strikes are given to officers who fail to perform their respective duties, at the

discretion of the President(s) and Vice President:

 1. Strikes are defined as a warning communicated to the officer, alerting

them of their transgression.

a) One strike upon an officer results in a warning of position

termination.

b) Two strikes upon an officer places them in a probationary period,

where they will not be able to participate in Executive Board duties
for a duration of time, as decided by the President.

c) Three strikes upon an officer make them ineligible to run for an

Executive Board position the following year.
D. Specific organizational duties of the Executive Board are contingent upon the

specified roles hereby described in this Constitution.

E. The Executive Board shall determine the amount of association dues, currently

$0.

F. All members of the Executive Board are required to attend all FSA events,

meetings, and activities, unless otherwise excused.

1. Executive Board members are required to volunteer for at least one shift of

facilitating an event or activity.

2. 3 unexcused absences from organization related activities will result in a

strike.

a) Unexcused absences include, but are not limited to:

(1) Uncommunicated or lack of reasoning for absence
(2) Invalid excuse provided for reason of absence

(a) Validity of an excuse is at the discretion of the Vice

President.

(i)

If the Vice President is absent, then the
President has the responsibility of
determining invalidity.

3. Excused absences include, but are not limited to:

a) Health-related, family-related, or other organizational related

obligations.

b) Any academic obligations, such as an exam or a review session.
c) Mental health reasons.

(1) The validity of any other reasons for excused absences that

are not listed above will be determined by the Vice
President.

G. The Executive Board will hold weekly meetings throughout the academic year as

determined by the Executive Board.

1. The first meeting will consist of at least exchanging contact information,
scheduling a weekly meeting time, and reading through the Constitution.

 2. Special meetings may be called by the President of the Executive Board

with a minimum of 24 hours notice.

3. All members of the Executive Board are required to attend all Executive

Board Meetings.

a)

If unable to attend a meeting, prior notice must be given to either
the President or Vice President within 24 hours before the meeting,
unless otherwise excused.

(1) An exposed lie is considered to be an unexcused absence.
b) Each Executive Board member should give the speaker their full
attention and respect, including no side conversations, no cell
phone activity, and laptops should be closed unless given
authorization by the President/board.

c) Each Executive Board member is responsible for arriving on time

to the weekly meetings.

d) The Secretary is responsible for recording attendance of Executive

Board Officers for events and meetings.

H. The Secretary will establish the agenda for all general meetings of this
association. The President will preside over each of these meetings.
In order for a motion to proceed, the Executive Board must approve it.

I.

1. Approval by the Executive Board shall be described as a two-thirds vote

of the entire board.

2. Approval by the Executive Board may also be described as two-thirds vote

of board members present at valid Executive Board meetings.

a) Quorum needs to be established to validate Executive Board

meetings.

b) Quorum shall be described as half plus one of the Executive Board.

J. Only the Treasurer, Vice President, and President may have Signature

Responsibility.

1. The number of officers with active Signature Responsibility shall follow
in accordance with the limits cited by the Center of Student Development
(C.S.D.).
a)

In the event that the C.S.D. changes its name/title, Article IV
Section 5-A shall be observed and remain in effect with the new
name/title of the C.S.D.

2. The Executive Board shall decide which other officer is to hold Signature

Responsibility.

 ARTICLE V: MEETINGS

I.

Executive Board Meeting Process

A. Each Executive Board meeting and any emergency meetings will be facilitated by

the President(s).

1.

2.

In the event of absence of the President(s) for any reason, refer to Section
1, Subsection A, Clause 3 for protocols for presiding over the association.
In the event that one Co-President is absent from a meeting, the other
Co-President will facilitate the meeting or event until the absent
Co-President returns or the meeting has concluded. In the event that both
Co-Presidents are absent or the only President for that given term is
absent, the Vice President will assume authority for the duration of the
meeting or event until the President(s) return(s).

B. The Secretary is responsible for recording minutes of meetings via Google Doc in

a shared Google Folder with the association.

1. The Secretary is also responsible for the timely organization and minutes

of meetings in the Google Drive shared folder.

C. Each Executive Board member will be required to provide weekly updates and
address what they are looking to or need to accomplish for the following week.

D. The President(s) will adjourn each meeting.

II.

General Body Meeting Process

A. The Executive Board shall facilitate all meetings, except in the case of an
informational meeting, where an event coordinator shall lead the meeting.

1. The Publicist will post informational graphics on social media prior to

each meeting.

B. Regular General Body meetings shall occur once per week, not including

additional meetings as determined by the Executive Board, unless there are
extenuating circumstances that require for the cancellation of a General Body
meetings.

1. Any meeting cancellations shall be at the discretion of the Executive

Board.

C. The Secretary is responsible for recording minutes of meetings in a shared Google

Doc.

1. The Secretary is also responsible for the timely organization of the

minutes in the Google Drive shared folder.

D. General Body Meetings following the first introductory meeting of each semester

will follow a written agenda, as determined by the Executive Board.

1. All ideas presented by General Body members for future events shall be

recorded, reviewed and compiled by the Secretary.

 E. General Body Meetings shall consist of the following, though the addition or

removal of any activities are at the discretion of the Executive Board.

1. A beginning ritual or an icebreaker
2. A set topic about Filipino culture or traditions
3. A social activity
4. An ending ritual

III.

Decision Making Process

A. When the Executive Board wishes to consult the General Body on a decision, the
Executive Board shall present the topic of interest to the general members at the
current or following General Body Meeting

1. The Executive Board must present the decision with explanation of the

implications of either outcomes of the decision and the context of the topic
of interest.

B. An outcome shall be decided upon by a ⅔ majority vote of the general body

members present.

C. A vote will be conducted by raise of hands, and counting the raised hands.

1.

If in-person voting during a General Body meeting is not possible, votes
shall be taken through a timed Google survey.

ARTICLE VI: ELECTION PROCEDURE

I.

The officers of the Executive Board shall be elected by members of the General Body.

A. Membership of the general body shall grant voting membership.

II.

III.

All General Body Members are eligible to run for a position on the Executive Board,
excluding the positions of President and Vice President.
Only current officers of the Executive Board of FSA or active General Body members
who have previously served on the Executive Board shall be eligible to run for the
positions of President and Vice President.

A. In the event that there are no current or past officers of the Executive Board
willing or able to run for the positions of President and Vice President, those
positions will be made available to the General Body.

IV.

Records of election results will be saved in the shared Google Drive of the association.

1. NOMINATIONS

a.

In order to be considered for an executive board position, a member must be
nominated by themselves or by another member of the association.

i.

If a member who was nominated does not wish to be considered for the
position, they have the ability to decline nomination.

 ii.

Acceptance of a nomination will put that member’s name on the ballot
only for the position that they were nominated for.

b. A member may be nominated or nominate themselves for a maximum of 2

positions.

i.

A member may not be nominated or nominate themselves for 2 positions
within the four primary roles of the Executive Board.

1. The four primary roles of the Executive Board are defined as the

President, Vice President, Secretary, and Treasurer.
A member may be nominated or nominate themselves for 1 primary
position and 1 non-primary Executive Board position.
A member may be nominated or nominate themselves for 2 non-primary
Executive Board positions.

ii.

iii.

c. The Official Nominations shall be completed at the end of the academic year in

the month of April.

i.

Nominations of General Body members for positions on the Executive
Board will be completed anonymously through Google Form and only
disclosed to the President(s)

d. The candidates for President and Vice President must be current Executive Board
members or be active General Body members who have served on the Executive
Board in the past, unless extenuating circumstances occur in which the positions
must be filled by non-Executive Board members.

e. The candidates for President must have one year of experience on the Executive

f.

Board of FSA.
In the event that there are no active members from the past or present Executive
Board eligible or willing to run for the positions of President and/or Vice
President, active members of FSA are eligible to run for the available positions.
g. All positions shall be nominated and voted for separately on the nomination form,

beginning with the President and continuing as listed by this Constitution.

h. The following nomination procedure shall be observed:

i.

An Executive Board officer or Active Member may submit a nomination
for eligible members or themselves through a Google form.
If the nominee accepts the nomination, they are officially a candidate for
the position and will be listed on the ballot for that position.
i. A candidate has the right to withdraw from the election at any time.

ii.

2. ELECTIONS

a. An Official Election Meeting must be announced at least two meetings prior and
the elected officers list must be submitted to the SA&I Culture Council Advisor
by the given deadline.

 b. The elections for all Executive Board positions will be referred to as the General
Elections, while elections for only specific positions will be referred to as Special
Elections.

i.

ii.

iii.

iv.

Official Election Meeting for the new Executive Board should occur
during the 3rd week of March, with a deadline of March 31st.
All candidates must be present at the time the Official Elections are held.
1. An Official Election includes both General and Special elections.
Elections will take place at a General Body meeting, with at least ⅔ of the
General Body members present.
If there are positions still unfilled at the end of the General Elections,
those positions shall be open to active members to apply in the Fall
semester of the following academic year as a Special Election.

1.

In the event that positions are left unfilled, all members of the
Executive Board will collaborate to complete the work of that
position.

2. All processes for a General Election shall be followed during a

Special Election.

c. Voting for a candidate shall be done anonymously, conducted through a Google
Form, that will be open for the duration of the Official Election meeting, and:

i.

ii.

All positions shall be voted upon separately, beginning with the President
and continuing as listed by this Constitution.
All candidates running for an Executive Board position shall be elected to
office by a simple majority.

d. Votes shall be privately counted by the President of the Executive Board, and

verified by the Vice President.

i.

ii.

Numbers of votes shall not be disclosed unless permission is granted by all
candidates for that position.
If numbers are to be disclosed, they must be made public to the entire
Filipino Student Association.

e.

In the event that voting cannot be conducted via Google Form for any reason,
voting shall proceed during the Official Election meeting by written vote.

i.

A vote for each position will be conducted separately, and the following
process will be followed for each position:

1. The current Executive Board will display the names of the
nominees and the position in which they are running for.

2. Voters may write the name of the nominee they choose to vote for
on a blank piece of paper and fold it so that the name may not be
seen.

a. Voters may not write their name on the piece of paper.

 3. The voters may drop the piece of paper into a bin.
4. An Executive Board member of any position not being voted for
will count the votes, and another Executive Board member will
verify the count.

5. The winner of the vote with a simple majority will be recorded.
6. The process continues for each of the open positions.
7. Only after all voting has occurred for each of the positions will the

winners of each election be announced.

f. The candidate with a simple majority of the votes will be elected to the position

they ran for.

g. The results of the Official Election will be announced via email to all members of

the association and posted onto the social media of the association.

3. RESIGNATIONS

a. All resignations have to be completed before an officer's term ends, must be in

writing, and brought before the President and Vice President.

i.

The President and Vice President must then notify and discuss the
resignation with the rest of the Executive Board.

4. RECALL

a.

Impeachment of a member of the Executive Board may be presented to the
President by any member of the association and shall mandate an investigation by
the President.

b. All Executive Board members must be present during an Impeachment.
c. The Officer shall present the Impeachment to the President with a detailed

i.

explanation of the accused Officer's violation of the Constitution. In turn, that
Officer shall remain anonymous until the actual impeachment process has begun.
The President shall proceed with an investigation and shall meet with the
accused Officer to alert them of the charge of the impeachment, to discuss
the issue, and to ask for a resignation only if the President feels that there
has been a violation of the Constitution.
The accused officer has the opportunity to address the violation to the
Executive Board as a whole, following the meeting with the President, and
has an opportunity to resign if they feel the need to or if they no longer
wish to proceed with the rest of the impeachment.
The accused Officer has the option to refuse to resign and may ask for a
full hearing, including the General Body.

iii.

ii.

d. The following guidelines shall be observed:

i.

Any communications regarding potential impeachment should remain
between the relevant board members until an official resignation or
hearing has occurred.

 1. The President shall present the statement of impeachment before

the Executive Board during the meeting.

2. The member of the association who presented the cause for

impeachment has the opportunity to provide context, explain the
cause of impeachment, and take questions.

3. The accused Officer shall be allowed to defend their position and

take questions.

4. The Executive Board shall debate and vote on the issue of whether
a recall of the accused officer should take place and a full hearing
should occur.

5. The simple majority vote shall rule. The President shall abstain

from voting.

6. Should the majority of the executive board vote in favor of moving
forward with a full hearing, the above procedure shall be followed
including the General Body.

7. The General Body shall vote on whether the officer should be

removed from office.

a. At least a ⅔ vote is required to remove an officer from

office.

8. Should the majority of the General Body vote in favor of removal,
the officer shall be removed from office and the responsibilities of
that officer shall fall upon the entire Executive Board until the
position can be filled.
Impeachment of the President shall be brought forward to the Vice
President, and the Vice President shall follow the above guidelines
as the President.

9.

10. Removal of a general body member from the association shall

follow the above guidelines.

ii.

The safety of the Executive Board and Active Members comes first. Any
accusations of physical, sexual assault or racist, discriminatory behavior
perpetrated by a member of the Executive Board will result in immediate
suspension/termination.

5. REFERENDA

a. Referendums may be initiated through two-thirds vote from any officer of the

Executive Board of the Filipino Student Association.

i.

ii.

Referendums may be initiated by the President with the consultation of the
Executive Board.
Refrenda may be initiated by a petition of no less than ten percent of the
Filipino Student Association.

 iii.

Once a Referendum is initiated, its wording cannot be changed.

b. A majority vote shall be sufficient to make a Referendum bringing upon the

Filipino Student Association.

ARTICLE VII: STATEMENT OF FREE SPEECH AND EXPRESSION

I.

Under no circumstances shall a member’s freedom of speech or expression be infringed
upon.

A. While the Filipino Student Association fully acknowledges and encourages free
speech, membership may be revoked if any slur, or discriminatory language is
used by a member against the organization, specific individuals, or the
community at large.

I.

I.

ARTICLE VIII: STATEMENT OF NON-DISCRIMINATION

The Filipino Student Association prohibits discrimination under Federal and State law,
based on race, ethnicity, color, national origin, religion, sex, gender identity (including
gender expression), sexual orientation, disability, age, marital status, family/parental
status, income derived from a public assistance program, political beliefs, immigration
status, citizenship status, or reprisal or retaliation for prior civil rights activity.

ARTICLE IX: AMENDMENT PROCEDURE

In the event that amendments to the FSA Constitution are proposed and considered, an
FSA Executive Board Member(s) shall present their amendment proposal to the FSA
General Body via Google Document.

A. Proposals must include: which specific part of the constitution is to be amended,
explanation of why the amendments are necessary, and the proposed wording of
the amendment.

II.

The General Body must have quorum in order to hear and vote for any proposed
amendments to the FSA Constitution.

A. A quorum is defined as one more than half the number of members of the General

Body.

III.

Upon receiving a majority vote by all present FSA General Body Members, the
amendment(s) will be presented to the Secretary of the Registry for approval.

A. A majority vote is defined as a ⅔ Vote of the present members of the General

Body.

DocsList.Name: Movie_Club_Constitution_%281%29.pdf
DocsList.Data:
Constitution/Organizational Charter for University of Massachusetts Film
Discussion and Critique Organization 

Otherwise referred to as UMass Film Discussion Club.  

Mission Statement: 

Encourage exposure to and exploration of multiple eras and genres of film and engage in
thoughtful, respectful discussion and critique through a variety of cinematic lenses. Our group
include discussion, screenings, and occasional outings to Amherst Cinema,
activities will
Cinemark, and other such places. We plan on exploring the Golden Era, Hitchcockian, German
Expressionist, Experimental, Foreign, as well as contemporary films and blockbusters. We will
additionally discuss historical context of the films we view, as well as issues facing the modern
film industry, and our society as a whole. We are enthusiastic about making this organization
accessible to people with all levels of film knowledge and expertise: the films and discussion
points we chose will be directly influenced by the non-officer members in the organization as
well as the officers. We hope to build a stable foundation for the club, to continue to foster an
appreciation for film and respectful discourse on campus, in a manner accessible to all students,
regardless of major or area of study.  

Our five year plan is as follows (2020 - 2025): 

YEAR ONE 

Establish UMass Film Discussion and Critique Organization as a stable resource and destination 
for group critique of cinema in its many eras and genres. Layout a consistent syllabus to touch on 
major film eras. Foster a healthy environment for critique and communication.  

YEAR TWO 

Expand excursions to local theaters (Amherst Cinema). Create a relationship with Amherst 
Cinemas for possible benefits such as private screenings or previews.  

YEAR THREE 

Expand social activities (trivia nights, film debate tournaments, outdoor movies). 

YEAR FOUR 

Possibly expand excursions to local film festivals. Contact COMM department for information 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 regarding local festivals. 

YEAR FIVE 

Plan and carry out excursion to Toronto International Film Festival. Fundraise to lower travel 
costs 

Membership:  

This organization is accessible to all undergraduate students, except that those applicants
with policies of exclusivity, which are deemed to be within the bounds of Federal and/or State
law, are exempt. 

All applicants will register by filling out a Google Form maintained by the officers, used
to notify them of official information regarding meetings and other activities. This will include
their email, phone number, year, and a space for optional feedback. Members will be notified of
their acceptance by an email from the Secretary that informs the member of their acceptance into
the club and that they have signed up for the email list. All members are expected to attend
weekly film screenings, and inform the Vice President if they cannot attend a certain week. All
members are expected to be involved in the weekly film selection process. This process is
organized by the Secretary, who sends two Google Forms weekly in the email and GroupMe to
members, one for movie submissions, and one for choosing from those submissions. They are
also expected to attend discussions after the film screenings. Information about meetings and
events will be relayed through email, GroupMe, and Instagram, maintained by the President and
Secretary. All members that are accepted are voting members and can vote in elections and other
club decisions that require a vote.  

Meeting Process:  

We will meet once weekly, not including theatre excursions (possibly twice a month,
organized in response to interest). The meetings will be planned, organized, and led by the
officers, who will guide discussion and activities regarding designated topics. The officers will
listen to feedback and offer opportunities for club members to vote on certain decisions. Whether
that be online polls for film choice, or other miscellaneous group decisions. Meetings will consist
of a film screening, with the film having been determined by the club members, and a discussion
of the film afterwards. The President will chair meetings by guiding discussions and initiating
the beginning of the screening and discussion.  

The President will also be in charge of organizing discussions about any decisions that
need to be made with the club membership, that are not subject to voting. The President will

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
   
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 outline the situation, and will moderate discussion and input from club members. At the end of
the discussion, the President will reiterate what the club had discussed, and outline the decision
made by the club. 

Executive Board/Officer Positions: 

The President will lead discussion among officers and at general meetings. They will be
the point person for general concerns regarding the organization and big picture responsibilities.
They will be primarily responsible for administrative tasks, such as re-registering on Campus
Pulse and being a representative for the organization in discussions with outside parties. They
will assist the Treasurer with the budget. They will hold signature responsibility.  

The Vice President will assist the President where they are delegated. They will primarily
in
take Presidential

manage day-to-day responsibilities pertaining to the organization. They will assist
communication between officers and members. The Vice President will
responsibility in times of Presidential absence (upon request).  

The Secretary will be responsible for social media and online presence. They will be the
main source of communication and distribution of information between officers and the general
body. They will take note of discussion and private concerns and complaints taken to them. They
will be responsible for monitoring the membership sign-up document and updating the mail lists.
They will be responsible for maintaining the storage of important administrative documents.  

The Treasurer will maintain detailed financial records, and will consistently monitor the
financial status of the organization. They will be responsible for keeping other officers up to date
with the organization’s financial situation, and act as a financial advisor for certain situations.
They would be in charge of fundraising and fund collecting pursuits. They hold signature
responsibility. 

The Librarian will be responsible for consolidating physical and digital copies of the

films that are property of the organization.  

If another position is determined by the board and the general body, elections will be held
to determine who holds this position, and there will be a meeting discussing responsibilities and
requirements for this new position.  

All other

responsibilities delegated to individual and collective Officers in this

Constitution will also apply.  

Every position will be up for re-election yearly.  

Elections: 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Elections will be held yearly. There will be information in one of the last meetings of the
year as to how to apply to run for a position, and information spread about the details of each
position. There will be a meeting wherein the candidates will state briefly their qualifications and
reasons for wanting to run to the general body. An anonymous, electronic vote will be held (on
StrawPoll, Google Forms, etc.) Two thirds of the members will be required to be present for the
speeches. These will take place sometime in March. Specific dates will be suggested by Officers,
and a Google Form will be sent out to determine a specific March date. All elections will be held
during regularly scheduled general body meetings. All elections will be completed before April
1st.  

The Secretary will organize the results (assuming no conflict of interest), and alongside
the other officers, will spread this information to the general body. When incumbents are
replaced, they are responsible for giving their successor all relevant information to the job in a
specially designated officer meeting.  

The results will be collected in a Google Form, and will be processed by the Secretary in
a Google Sheet. This Google Sheet will be available for all Officers to view but not edit. The
Sheet and Form will be in the Google Drive for the club. Physical copies will be made, and kept
by the Secretary at all times.  

In the event of an officer vacancy, an immediate announcement will be made for a special
election. The process of the election will be similar to that of a regularly scheduled election, in
the sense that every candidate would have the chance to state their qualifications and reason for
interest. If a member of the general body or the executive board has received complaints about
behavior deemed serious and harmful by the board that threatens the organization’s philosophy
and goals, a special meeting will be conducted to determine that member’s future in the
organization. They will have a chance to discuss the issues privately with the executive board,
and then the general body. An electronic vote will be held in person or over Zoom without the
member in question present. The Secretary (assuming they are not the member in question) will
collect and organize the results of the vote. If two-thirds of the general body votes to remove the
member or officer, the member or officer will no longer be welcome to attend meetings and
activities held by the organization. This member or officer will be notified verbally by all other
Officers, and will be sent an email by the President (if they are not the officer in question: if they
are, the Vice President will do this) informing them that they are no longer welcome to attend
meetings and activities held by the organization. If they are an officer, they are required to
relinquish their duties and any access they have to Executive Board information.  

Statement of Free Speech: 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
   
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
   
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
   
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Communication will be open and encouraged, but if there is an issue of disrespectful
behavior, a meeting with an officer may be scheduled. Communication is recommended to be
respectful and in line with group standards, but if not, it will only become an issue if the threat of
violence is caused by the member’s statements. Freedom of expression and freedom of speech
will not be suppressed or infringed on by the executive board members or anyone else.  

Anti-Discrimination Policy: 

This group prohibits discrimination under Federal and State law, based on race, color,
national origin, religion, sex, gender identity (including gender expression), sexual orientation,
disability, age, marital status, family/parental status, income derived from a public assistance
program, political beliefs, or reprisal or retaliation for prior civil rights activity. Members will
refer to one another in respectful terms, using desired pronouns.  

Amendments: 

Any member of the general body may propose an amendment to the group’s constitution
in a meeting. At least a simple majority vote, as well as the approval of the Secretary of Registry,
is required for this amendment to be enacted.

DocsList.Name: General Kitchen and Food Safety Checklist.pdf
DocsList.Data:
www.facebook.com/foodrecoverynetwork

www.foodrecoverynetwork.org

@foodrecovery

KITCHEN AND FOOD SAFETY 
CHECKLIST FOR STUDENTS

PERSONAL HYGIENE

•  If sick, do NOT participate.
•  Wash hands up to your elbows with warm water and soap and put on gloves before handling food.
•  Wear long pants, clean clothes, closed-toe non-slip shoes and no jewelry.
•  Wear a bandage if you have a cut.
•  Pull hair back off shoulders and wear a hat/hairnet.
•  Wash hands again and replace gloves after you do any of the following: use the restroom, sneeze, touch your 
hair, face, clothes or body, handle raw meat or eggs, bus dirty dishes, eat or drink or use cleaning chemicals.

•  Do not eat, drink, smoke or chew gum near prep or service areas.
•  Protect food from contaminating items.

KITCHEN SAFETY

•  Stop and knock twice before opening any door to ensure no one gets hit.
•  Wear slip resistant shoes if possible, be careful not to slip and fall on wet floors.
•  Communicate: when turning corners or walking behind a person make sure to yell “corner” or “behind.”
•  Be aware of hot pans, burners, ovens, and surfaces that might burn you.
•  Never run in the kitchen.

CONTROLLING TIME AND TEMPERATURE

•  Make sure food is not between 41°F and 135°F for more than 2 hours.
•  Food from hot line -- Receive and hold at 135°F or above.
•  Food from cold storage -- Receive and hold at 41°F or below.
•  Check temperature when receiving using a clean and sanitized thermometer. If food is just barely inside Food 

Temperature Danger Zone (between 41°F and 135°F, ask a dining services representative to verify that food has 
not been in Danger Zone for longer than a few minutes.

•  Label food containers with the date, temperature and contents, taking note of any potential allergens.

TRANSPORTATION

•  Use safe, non-absorbent, leak proof pans or reusable containers.
•  Never put pans full of food on the ground.
•  Use thermal bags to maintain hot or cold temperature of food; do not mix hot and cold food in the same bag.
•  Use a clean transport vehicle; food should be isolated and nowhere near cleaning supplies, other 

chemicals, dirty clothes, trash, etc.
If ever in doubt about whether these procedures were followed, do not donate the food.

•

DocsList.Name: Constitution and Bylaws of the Beta Chi Chapter of Gamma Iota Sigma.pdf
DocsList.Data:
GAMMA IOTA SIGMA – BETA CHI CHAPTER 
CONSTITUTION AND BYLAWS 

Table of Contents 

Identity and Scope 
ARTICLE I – NAME 
ARTICLE II – MISSION STATEMENT 
ARTICLE III – MEMBERSHIP AND ROSTER 

Organization Leaders 

ARTICLE IV – FACULTY ADVISOR 
ARTICLE V – ELECTION OF CHAPTER OFFICERS 
ARTICLE VI – OFFICER TRANSITIONS 
ARTICLE VII – RECALL OF OFFICERS 

Member Rights and Obligations 

ARTICLE VIII – NON-DISCRIMINATION AND MEMBER EXCEPTIONS POLICY 
ARTICLE IX – AMENDMENTS 
ARTICLE X – DISPUTE RESOLUTION 

Statements 

ARTICLE XI – STATEMENT OF FREE SPEECH 
ARTICLE XII – STATEMENT OF NON-HAZING 
ARTICLE XIII – NOT-FOR-PROFIT STATEMENT 
ARTICLE XIV – STATEMENT OF COMPLIANCE WITH CAMPUS REGULATIONS 
ARTICLE XV – STATEMENT OF JUSTIFICATION AND FUTURE GOALS 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 Identity and Scope 

ARTICLE I – NAME 

The name of this organization shall be the Beta Chi Chapter of Gamma Iota Sigma.  

ARTICLE II – MISSION STATEMENT 

The purpose of this Chapter shall be to promote, encourage, and sustain student interest in 
insurance, risk management, and actuarial science as professions; to encourage the high moral 
and scholastic attainments of its members; and to facilitate interaction of educational institutions 
and industry through networking and by fostering research activities, scholarship, and improved 
public relations. 

The Beta Chi Chapter shall accomplish this mission by building a close-knit community of 
students, faculty, and alumni who share similar academic and career interests. By combining 
University resources with industry and inter-chapter support, the Beta Chi Chapter will provide 
its members with tools and resources that will help them prepare for high-quality employment 
opportunities. 

Members of the Beta Chi Chapter shall engage in a wide array of exciting activities—both social 
and professional—to expand their networks and to distinguish themselves in today’s highly 
competitive talent market. The Chapter welcomes any interested party and promotes a friendly 
and positive environment for personal and professional growth. 

ARTICLE III – MEMBERSHIP AND ROSTER 

All students at the University of Massachusetts Amherst are eligible to become members of 
Gamma Iota Sigma by joining through Campus Pulse AND submitting a membership application 
form. Any student registered in this manner shall be referred to as a “Prospective Member” and 
will have full participation rights, including an equal vote in Chapter affairs and the ability to 
hold officer positions. 

A student can become an “Official Member” of Gamma Iota Sigma by satisfying the Chapter’s 
membership requirements. Upon completion, the Beta Chi Chapter shall subsidize the student’s 
annual membership dues to the Grand Chapter. “Official Members” have a number of additional 
benefits, including exclusive opportunities to be included in the Chapter’s resume book, to be 
eligible for Chapter prizes/awards, to attend international conferences, and to receive free student 
memberships in several professional societies. 

Chapter officers shall keep an up-to-date roster of past and present members at all times. 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Organization Leaders 

ARTICLE IV – FACULTY ADVISOR 

Faculty Advisors shall attend Chapter meetings, aid and advise the Chapter, serve as contacts for 
the Chapter, and facilitate the continuity of Chapter records and property. Faculty Advisors shall 
not be entitled to vote, to hold office, to penalize, or to veto, and shall not be liable for actions 
taken by the Chapter. 

ARTICLE V – ELECTION OF CHAPTER OFFICERS 

The executive officers of this organization, ordered by line of succession, are as follows:  

1.  President* 
2.  Vice President 
3.  Director of Operations 
4.  Director of Finance 
5.  Director of Communications 
6.  Director of Management Information Systems 
7.  Director of Actuarial Science Career Development 
8.  Director of Risk Management & Insurance Career Development  
9.  Director of Industry Affairs 
10. Director of Alumni Affairs 
11. Director of Community Affairs 
12. International Student Chair 

*One of either the President or Vice President must be concentrating in Actuarial Science. 
Additional details for officer roles and responsibilities can be found here. 

Elections shall take place by electronic ballot via Campus Pulse on the day of the first April 
meeting each year. Candidates are restricted to running for one officer position at a time and are 
required to write a brief summary of their qualifications at least TWO DAYS in advance to be 
included in the ballot. They will also have an opportunity to represent themselves before the 
Chapter during the election meeting. 

All members are required to vote in the poll, which will open at the end of the meeting, and a 
majority of votes in each category shall constitute a victory. In the event of a tie, the current 
officers who are not involved in the contested position shall interview the candidates and select 
the most qualified individual. 

Elected officers will assume their positions for the following SCHOOL YEAR and may serve for 
a maximum of TWO YEARS in the same position. Should an officer position become vacant 
during the middle of a term, there shall be a new election by the membership to fill that vacancy 
within TWO WEEKS. If the vacancy is the presidency, the line of succession shall determine the 
temporary successor. 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 ARTICLE VI – OFFICER TRANSITIONS 

All new and current officers are required to participate in a transition consisting of the following 
three components:  

1.  Shadowing and Training 
2.  Attending an Officer Retreat 
3.  Consultation Availability 

1. Shadowing and Training 
Once new officers are elected in April, current officers are required to thoroughly train their 
successors for the remaining weeks of the semester. The current President and Vice President 
shall meet with each pairing to first outline and then check in with training progress. 

2. Officer Retreat 
The newly-elected President and Vice President shall plan and facilitate an officer retreat for the 
new officers to get to know each other, to set goals for the following school year, and to have 
fun. Whenever possible, alumni are encouraged to help run the retreat. 

3. Consultation Availability 
All former officers are required to be reasonably available to answer their successors’ questions 
and to give advice when requested. This could range from a few text messages to an email or a 
quick phone conversation. 

Providing officers with this resource helps aid them with the anxiety of stepping into a new role 
by having that ongoing support available. It also helps them deal with novel problems or 
anything not covered in their training. That is, something that might take a new officer an hour to 
figure out alone could be explained in a few minutes. 

ARTICLE VII – RECALL OF OFFICERS 

Officers are subject to recall for failing to meet the obligations of their positions. Officers may 
only be removed on the basis of a reasonable complaint addressed respectfully at a Chapter 
meeting. A panel consisting of at least two Chapter officers and the Faculty Advisor shall 
determine the reasonableness of the complaint. 

Before removal, there must first be an attempt to remedy the situation, and no vote to remove an 
officer may occur sooner than TWO WEEKS after the initial complaint. There must be a 
majority vote of the Chapter membership in favor of removal in order for an officer to be 
stripped of his or her title. Removal from an officer position is permanent, but the former officer 
may remain a member of GIS. Following an officer’s removal, the position shall be treated as a 
vacancy and will follow the procedure mentioned previously in Article V. 

 
 
  
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 Member Rights and Obligations 

ARTICLE VIII – NON-DISCRIMINATION AND MEMBER EXCEPTIONS POLICY 

This organization shall not discriminate on the basis of age, color, ethnicity, gender, national 
origin, disability, handicap, race, religion, sexual orientation, or veteran status. 

This policy includes—but is not limited to—the following areas: recruiting, membership, 
activities, and opportunities to hold office. 

ARTICLE IX – AMENDMENTS 

All proposed amendments by Chapter members must be presented at the second meeting of each 
semester. Potential amendments should be specific and include a statement indicating the need 
for that particular amendment. A majority vote at the following meeting is required to pass an 
amendment, and the Director of Operations is responsible for submitting the revised Constitution 
to the Secretary of the Registry for approval. The President has the authority to call for a mid-
semester vote on a critical amendment. 

ARTICLE X – DISPUTE RESOLUTION 

Any club-related dispute between members may be respectfully brought to the attention of the 
Vice President. The Vice President shall then present the issue to the President, who will decide 
whether the issue can be handled at the next club meeting or whether an emergency officer 
meeting needs to be called. The disputing members must all be present in order for the situation 
to be discussed or resolved. If the issue is with the President or Vice President, members may 
bring it to the attention of a Faculty Advisor, who will then determine the urgency and handle the 
situation with the same responsibility that would otherwise be left to the President. 

  
 
 
 
  
 
  
 
 
 Statements 

ARTICLE XI – STATEMENT OF FREE SPEECH 

All participants of this organization may and are encouraged to address the Chapter during 
meetings. Proposals will be accepted from all members, and no one who attends shall be 
prevented from contributing to discussions and decisions. 

ARTICLE XII – STATEMENT OF NON-HAZING 

This organization shall not engage in hazing, participate in hazing, or commit any act that causes 
or is likely to cause bodily danger, physical harm, or personal degradation or disgrace resulting 
in physical or mental harm to any fellow student or person attending the institution. If anyone 
has any concerns or fears whatsoever about hazing, he or she should contact the Chapter 
President. The Beta Chi Chapter holds a zero-tolerance policy toward hazing. 

ARTICLE XIII – NOT-FOR-PROFIT STATEMENT 

This is a not-for-profit organization. 

ARTICLE XIV – STATEMENT OF COMPLIANCE WITH CAMPUS REGULATIONS 

This organization shall comply with all University and campus policies and regulations and 
local, state, and federal laws. 

ARTICLE XV – STATEMENT OF JUSTIFICATION AND FUTURE GOALS 

Please refer to our Startup Manual (2015) for a comprehensive justification and outline of future 
goals.

How to Use This Form

Recreation Club Allocation Committee - Budget Request Form

Review your entire budget breakdown and select those expenses that you would like paid for by the Univeristy of Massachusetts Amherst through an allocation of SGA funds from the Recreation Club Council Allocations Commmittee. Prioritize the items from most important (1) to least important (up to 10). All items, including individual trips 
or items of equipment, should be listed separately.

How the Recreation Club Allocation Committee Will Use This Form

The Recreation Club Council Allocation Committee will review this form and other resources for allocation.  Each club will have the opportunity to explain its priority list, provide additional information regarding budget expenses and estimated income, and clarify any items during its scheduled budget hearing before the Recreation Club 
Council Allocation Committee during the allocation process.

Allocation and Spending by Category

Clubs will be allocated money by category, with allocated funds required to be spent in that category. You may adjust expenditures within category (if you request to fund a trip to Miami and you change that to Atlanta, that is acceptable).  But, to move money between categories (such as from Travel to Equipment) will require a special 
request  to the Recreation Club Council for approval.

DocsList.Name: GGSO_Bylaws.docx
DocsList.Data:
Geoscience Graduate Student Organization (GGSO)
Bylaws

A.  ORGANIZATION

How to join:  Any UMass Department of Geoscience graduate student can join. To be a member students must join the listserve and/or slack channel.

Eligibility to run for office:  New officers are elected in the spring semester each year. Members must have attended at least three meetings to run for officer positions. Officers are elected for one-year terms. Members can nominate themselves, or nominate someone else with their permission. Nominations will be collected no later than the meeting prior to the election. 

GGSO Officers:

President:  The President shall oversee the responsibilities of all officers, act as a liaison to the Department head and GSO/GSS, and assist other members in fulfilling their duties.

Vice President:  The Vice President shall assist the president in communication and organization of meetings and events. Additionally, the vice president will run meetings in the absence of the president, and coordinate efforts with the president. 

Treasurer:  The Treasurer will be responsible for maintaining an accurate record of any and all money in the graduate caucus account and presenting a signed report of all transactions at the end of the academic year. 

Secretary:  The Secretary shall take notes and keep time at meetings, and maintain a record of agenda items and results of votes taken. In addition, the secretary shall maintain the charter and bylaw documents.   

Additional committees and committee chairs may be added according to need, to be added to the agenda and voted on during regular meetings (see Section B).

The GGSO will meet weekly, according to a schedule determined at the beginning of each semester during the department-wide meeting to select seminar times (the first meeting of GEO 701 – Professional Seminar).
    

B.    PROCEDURES

1.     Meeting Items
    
Announcements
Reports from representatives
Unfinished business
New business
Proposals for the agenda of the next meeting
    
2.     Voting

General Principles
    
Votable issues:  The only votable issues are those listed on the agenda. Voting on issues will take place by a show of hands by members present in the meeting, or otherwise specified by committee chairs.

Quorum:  When proper notification has been carried out, and at least five members are in attendance at the meeting, those members present will constitute a quorum. Without a quorum discussion may go forward but no binding decisions will be made.

Secret Ballot:  When any member attending the meeting requests it, votes will be cast by secret ballot.
    
Elections
    
Timing:  Nominations and elections for President, Vice President, Treasurer and Secretary, or other positions deemed necessary by the GGSO will be voted on at the last caucus meeting of the spring semester. Elections for other GGSO offices will be held yearly, and will be voted on as early as possible during the fall semester. When an officer or representative resigns, the position will be filled by election as soon as possible.

Voting privileges:  Members will be given no less than 24 hours to vote via an online form.

Candidates:  Eligibility for positions is defined above (Section A). Nominees or those elected may decline the position, committee or other duty.

Uncontested elections:  When only one candidate is nominated per position, election may be accomplished by a show of hands.

Contested elections:  Any time the number of nominees exceeds the number of positions for a single office or committee, election will be accomplished by secret ballot. Someone who is not one of the candidates for the position will tally ballots. When there are two or more positions on the same committee to be filled, the appropriate number of nominees receiving the highest total votes will be elected.
    
    
C.    BYLAW AMENDMENT, PUBLICATION AND REVIEW

Amendment:  The bylaws may be amended according to the following procedures:

Notification:  Any proposed amendments will be written and posted at the meeting prior to the scheduled vote.

Approval:  A simple majority vote is required for passage of any amendments.
    
Publication:  The bylaws will be made available at the first graduate caucus meeting of the academic year, and will be kept posted so that anyone may refer to them at any time.

Review:  The bylaws will be reviewed every year in graduate caucus. If updates or revisions are needed, the secretary or a committee selected by the members will draft these changes, which will then be subject to formal notification and approval as described above.

DocsList.Name: Club Golf Constitution 2_28_24.pdf
DocsList.Data:
1

Constitution of the University of Massachusetts Club Golf

Effective February 28, 2024

ARTICLE I: Name of Organization

1. The official title of this student organization is “University of Massachusetts Club Golf”
which may be acceptably shortened to, “UMass Amherst Club Golf” “UMass Club Golf”
or “Club Golf Team.”

ARTICLE II: Mission Statement

1. Whereas the purpose of the University of Massachusetts Club Golf is to provide a

competitive golfing environment for the most skilled golfers in the UMass Amherst
community.

a. Team Practice

i. Whereas we provide practice for all our team members twice weekly at

local golf courses. Practices are of significant importance to the success of
our team as players use practice time to work on aspects of their game that
need improvement in order to be best prepared for tournament play.
Practice is also where our members engage with each other, pushing one
another to improve while building overall team camaraderie. Our strong
relations with golf professionals at the local courses we practice at
embodies the high standard we hold our members to in representing the
UMass community in a positive light on and off campus.

ii. Whereas team practices are used as team meetings chaired by the

President. During meetings we discuss pertinent information regarding
upcoming team events as well as address the membership to answer any
questions they may have. If new initiatives are brought up during
meetings, the process of decision making will be: a majority vote needed
from Executive Board members, then a majority vote needed by
competitive and general members.

b. Tournaments

i. Whereas through our practices we determine the best 8 golfers out of our
14 members by scoring average in order to field a single team. The team
renews its membership with the NCCGA (National Collegiate Club Golf
Association) twice yearly (once each semester) and competes in three
regional intercollegiate tournaments per semester. The tournaments are

 2

two-day, 36 hole stroke play events. In Fall 2023 we placed 6th nationally
in a field of the country's 30 best club golf teams.

ii. Whereas in the event a player declines an invitation to compete in a

tournament, the player with the next lowest score is invited to compete.

iii. Whereas special circumstances may persist where qualifiers cannot be

held, the plan of action will be decided by the officers and publicized to
prospective competitors.

ARTICLE III: Membership

1. Full membership to the competitive team is attained by qualifying for the team through

yearly tryouts, joining the Club’s Campus Pulse page, joining the team’s IMLeagues page
and fulfilling pertinent waivers, and paying Club dues. All UMass Amherst
undergraduate students have the ability to become members and non-competitive team
members can still vote at annual elections.

a. Tryouts
i.

Tryouts will be held every fall before the first tournament of the semester
for 10 open spots. The four executive board members will not participate
in tryouts but rather watch athletes to evaluate skill and uphold the
integrity of the rules to ensure a fair competition is held. In order to
qualify for the team, a players’ scoring average must fall within the top 10.
Final team selection is up to the discretion of Executive Board members.
In the case of ties, players in question will be invited to the first team
practice of the year which will act as another qualifying round, in which
the lowest score(s) is awarded the vacant spot(s).

ii.

ARTICLE IV: Inclusion

1. Whereas UMass Club Golf prohibits discrimination under Federal and State law, based

on race, color, national origin, religion, sex, gender identity (including gender
expression), sexual orientation, disability, age, marital status, family/parental status,
income derived from a public assistance program, veteran status, citizenship, genetic
information, political beliefs, or reprisal or retaliation for prior civil rights activity.

a. Discrimination

i. Whereas violators of any of the aforementioned grounds will be punished

with a permanent ban from the Club and will be reported to our advisor for
further action.

b. Freedom of Speech

i.

Under no circumstances shall a member’s freedom of speech or expression
be infringed.

ARTICLE V: Executive Board

 1. There will be numerous positions for running UMass Club Golf, these positions are:

3

a. President
i.

The President is responsible for all communication and coordination with
the NCCGA, the governing body for the tournaments we participate in.
They are the only point of contact with the NCCGA so it is vitally
important that they maintain that relationship and keep the team informed
accordingly. It is his/her responsibility to make sure the team is properly
enrolled in each tournament and the payments and lineups are submitted
on time. The president is also responsible for overseeing executive board
meetings and collaborating with the university Advisor. They must also
delegate tasks, assist the treasurer in the budgeting process and re-register
the organization yearly on Campus Pulse. The president is required to take
advantage of collaborative opportunities with other teams/universities as
well as represent the organization in “big picture” meetings.

b. Vice President

i.

The Vice President is responsible for creating, updating and maintaining
the team scoring sheet for practice and tournament round scores. This
sheet must be made available to the rest of the executive board. The duties
of this position also include organizing team community service events, as
well as coordinating social events to help build team camaraderie. This
individual is also responsible for assisting the president in leading team
meetings. Furthermore, the Vice President is responsible for equitably
contributing to executive board meetings and providing input in budgeting
decisions.

c. Secretary
i.

The Secretary is responsible for making club tee times. This individual
outreach to local course Pros to schedule weekly practice time slots as
well as negotiate course rate discounts. The secretary assists in the
financial budgeting process and provides support where needed and
advises/provides input during executive board meetings. The secretary is
responsible for running and maintaining the official social media accounts
for the Club.

d. Treasurer
i.

The Treasurer is responsible for handling the finances of the Club. This
includes writing the team’s yearly budget, submitting purchase requests
prior to events in a timely manner, and maintaining financial records.
Other responsibilities of the Treasurer include representing the Club at
hearings, giving balance updates at meetings, and overseeing fundraising
efforts. Furthermore, the Treasurer is responsible for equitably

 4

contributing to executive board meetings and providing input on team
related matters.

e. Exofficio E-Board Members
Club Sports Advisor

i.

1. Our Club Sports Advisor is a non-student member of our E-Board.

As advisor they are responsible for settling any disputes the
E-Board members may have when voting including disagreements
and ties.

ii.

DEI (Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion) Advisor

1. Our DEI Advisor is responsible for handling any feedback on
behavior that is in violation of diversity, equity, and inclusion
initiatives.

2. Whereas other positions can be created on a need basis.
3. Public elections must be held for all E-Board positions if requested by 5 or more

members of the club. The results of that election are effective the pursuant semester.
4. Succession upon sudden resignation, forfeiture of position, or inability to hold presidency

will follow this order:
a. Vice President
b. Treasurer
c. Secretary

5. Officers with signature responsibility are

a. President
b. Treasurer

6. Whereas a situation arises in which an officer or member is in question of being removed

the person must be notified ahead of time, given an opportunity to address the
membership, and only to be voted out with at least a two-thirds vote of the general
membership.

Article VI: Requirements for Voting on Group Issues

1. Executive board members will meet on an at need basis to discuss the issue at hand

chaired by the President. When discussion ends, and all thoughts are heard,
answers/solutions will be written out. Once written out, the voting process will begin
where each E-Board member will choose what outcome they have judged to be the best
for the club, always keeping the club's best interest in mind. After each E-Board member
has casted their vote, the votes will be tallied and the majority vote will now proceed to
the general body, if and only if there is a majority. The voting process continues with the
general body now voting alongside the E-Board members. A majority vote will pass and
the issue will be addressed. If there is no majority vote with either the initial E-Board
vote or general body vote, the issue will not be passed.

 5

Article VII: The Structure and Timing for Officer Elections

1. Officer elections will be held annually on March 31st during a scheduled general body
meeting with at least two-thirds of the active SGA members in the RSO in attendance.
The term of service will run until the next election is held the following year. Any current
member of the club can run for any E-Board position. Once all members have declared
whether or not they want to run for a given E-Board position, an election will be tested
through a google form. The majority vote received for each position will be initiated into
the new position. Each club member is allowed to vote only once for each position. If
there is a tie, the current E-Board members will vote to which new member to be elected
where the majority passes. Voting results and meeting minutes will be recorded by the
incumbent Secretary and stored in the team’s google drive.

a. Special Elections

i. Whereas a situation arises in which an officer is voted to be removed from
the Club, a special election will be held through google form with the
member with the majority of general membership votes being elected.

Article VIII: Requirements for Amending the Constitution

1. Whereas any member of the UMass Club Golf team can propose an amendment to the

team constitution. The E-Board must then vote on whether or not to approve the proposed
amendment to a general body vote. If the proposed amendment is approved, the E-Board
is responsible for writing the amendment and presenting it to the general body. After the
amendment is presented to the general body, it can only be implemented by a simple
majority vote of the general membership as well as the approval of The Undergraduate
Registry Oversight Committee.

Article IX: Ratification

1. The constitution shall be offered to the Executive Board for ratification by majority vote
at the start of each fall semester, and thereupon submitted to the Undergraduate Registry
Oversight Committee for final approval.

University of Massachusetts Club Golf amended this constitution with 10 (of 14) participating
members voting unanimously in favor of passing at 2:00 PM on February 28, 2024.

DocsList.Data:
Constitution of the University of Massachusetts Golf Club
Effective February 1, 2018

ARTICLE 1: Purpose/Mission statement

The primary goal of the University of Massachusetts Golf Club is to provide a welcoming environment for players of all skill levels to play with their peers. Players, of all backgrounds, race, gender, religion, and sexual orientation are welcomed equally. Discrimination of any sort will not be tolerated.
The Club also allows players to pursue competitive golf while working towards an education at a top public university.
The Club represents the flagship campus at the highest level of competitive golf offered by the university in the National Collegiate Club Golf Association (NCCGA) against other top universities in the New England region.

ARTICLE 2:Membership

Full membership is attained by joining the Club’s Campus Pulse page and paying club the dues, which will vary, but be set prior to the start of the coming fiscal year.
Membership on a competing team will be offered to players after the completion of a qualifier. The lowest scores will be awarded a spot on the team. In the event a player declines an invitation, the player with next lowest score is invited to compete.
Special circumstances may persist where a full complement of qualifiers may not be able to be held. In such events, the plan of action will be decided by the officers and publicized to prospective competitors.

ARTICLE 3: Inclusion

Discrimination of any sorts outline in Article 1(a) will be punished with a permanent ban from the club and reported to our advisor.
Any reports of hazing will be reported to the advisor.

ARTICLE 4: Executive Board

There will be numerous positions for running the Club Golf Team, of which some are essential. These positions are:
President
Vice President
Secretary
Treasurer
Additionally there are non-essential positions that can be held which for special purposes. These positions are:
Event Coordinator
Talent Recruiter
Fundraising Strategist
Other positions can be created on a need basis.
Presidents are typically appointed by a graduating incumbent president.
The incoming president will appoint their cabinet with club members interested in an E-Board positions.
A graduating president may open public elections if desired by themselves.
Public elections must be held for all E-Board positions if requested by 5 or more members of the club. The results of that election are effective the pursuant semester.
Succession upon sudden resignation, forfeiture of position, or inability to hold presidency will follow this order:
Vice President
Secretary
Treasurer
