DocsList.Name: GBA_Charter_2019.docx
DocsList.Data:
Charter 
of the 
Graduate Business Association


Preamble
Founded in 1983, the Graduate Business Association (GBA) has been the cornerstone of the student life for full-time Master of Business Administration (MBA) and Master of Business Administration Dual Degree (MBA/MS) candidates at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst.  The GBA has led to an impressive history of enhancing the academic experience, meeting professional development needs, and providing social opportunities for all MBAs/MSAs, as well as contributing back to the community.  this charter seeks to capture the spirit of the GBA and provide a framework for future students to carry on its proud traditions.
Article I - Vision
Our Vision has been crafted to succinctly capture the essence of the Graduate Business Association.  It is meant to be a brief and powerful statement that encompasses the basic purpose of our group.

GBA Vision:  Empowering tomorrow’s top business leaders...today.

Article II - Mission Statement
Our Mission Statement outlines our areas of activity as we carry out our Vision.

GBA Mission Statement:  To continually invest for the overall interest, growth, and benefit of our stakeholders (students, prospective students, and alumni) through the following.
Academics - by enhancing and supporting the overall academic excellence of the Isenberg MBA/MBA/MS program.
Professional Development - by providing hands-on, real world professional development experiences.
Community Investment - by offering resources and services that support and add value to the Isenberg community, and to the larger community in which we live, work, and play.
Social Enterprise - by fostering opportunities to develop strong interpersonal ties within the Isenberg community; past, present, and future.
Article III - Membership, Responsibilities, and Authority
Membership is voluntary and is open to all currently enrolled full-time students in the Master of Business Association program or the MBA Dual Sports Management Program at the Isenberg School of Management University of Massachusetts Amherst.
Membership Responsibilities - To become a member and maintain membership, the interested student must:
Completely fill out and sign any membership forms or activity waiver forms that are required under current GBA Policy (described in Article VI).
Be current on all dues payments that are required under current GBA Policy (described in Article VI).
Remain a full-time student in the MBA or MBA/MS Dual program at the Isenberg School.
Fulfill any other duties as required under current GBA Policy (described in Article VI).
Membership Authority - The membership of the GBA has the following authority:
Any member may propose new activity initiatives, new GBA Policy, changes in current GBA Policy, or amendments to the GBA Charter.  Proposals must be made at a full membership meeting by the proponent or a designee, in order to lead a group discussion on the proposal.
The membership may vote on proposals for new activity initiatives, new GBA Policy, changes in current GBA Policy, or amendments to the GBA Charter.  Proposals are ratified pursuant to the provisions for each type of vote, as outlined in Article V - Voting and Elections.  A membership vote supersedes a vote by the GBA Board.
Any authority not clearly assigned under Article IV - Officers, Responsibility and Authority, shall remain the responsibility and authority of the membership as a whole.  Such points of responsibility and authority may be ratified and enacted by a majority vote of the membership.
Article IV – Officers, Responsibility and Authority
Officers are GBA members that are elected by the electorate, as outlined under Article V - Voting and Elections.  All officers are charged with seeking to fulfill the GBA Vision, and for acting as ambassadors for the MBA/MS programs at the Isenberg School of Management.  All officers are responsible for carrying out the GBA Mission within their areas of authority.
GBA Board - Th GBA Board consists of all current officers of the GBA.
Responsibilities: The GBA Board as a whole is responsible for:
Fulfilling the GBA Vision and carrying out the GBA Mission.
Seeing that the needs and desires of the membership are met.
Seeing that the needs of the student body are met.
Planning and carrying out activities that are of interest to the membership, as indicated by popular vote.
Authority:  The GBA Board as a whole has the authority to:
Propose new GBA Policy or propose changes to current GBA Policy.
Set GBA Policy via a GBA Board vote.  Proposals are ratified pursuant to the provisions for a GBA Board vote, as outlined in Article V - Voting and Elections.  A membership vote supersedes a vote by the GBA Board.
Carry out the policies of the GBA.
President
Responsibilities:  The President is responsible for:
Coordinating the activities and efforts of the GBA Board and any miscellaneous member volunteers.
Representing the MBA/MS student body both within the Isenberg community and to the community-at-large.
Assuring that the provisions of this Charter are carried out.
Protecting and promoting the interests of the GBA.
Maintaining a responsible fiscal policy for the GBA, including oversight of the treasury.
Addressing any membership issues that may arise.
Holding GBA Board meetings in order to conduct GBA business.
Holding full-membership meetings in order to conduct GBA business.
Holding elections and special elections as outlined in Article V - Voting and Elections.
Any responsibility and authority normally associated with any other GBA Officer position, except for the office of Treasury, should that position be vacant.  Treasurer responsibilities and authorities must be assigned to another GBA Officer if the officer of Treasurer is vacant.
As this elected position is a paid graduate assistantship within the Isenberg School, the President must fulfill any and all expectations and obligations as agreed to with the Assistant Program Director for the MBA/MS programs.
Authority:  The President has the authority to:
Over-rule on any point of order that runs counter to this Charter.
Enforcing GBA Policy
Enforce fiscal policy as outlined in the GBA Policy (described in Article VI).  This may include, among other actions, the collection of dues, the approval or denial of non-budgeted items, or the denial of reimbursements for non-budgeted items, as outlined in GBA Policy.
Spend GBA funds as appropriate and as authorized under GBA Policy.
Carry out duties and obligations as required under the graduate assistantship.
Call meetings, elections, and special elections in order to carry out GBA business.
Assign to other board members the responsibilities and associated authority normally associated with another office, should that office be vacant.
Treasurer
Responsibilities:  The Treasurer is responsible for:
Maintaining a responsible fiscal policy for the GBA.
Maintaining all treasury records.
Maintaining membership records.
Maintaining membership dues records, if dues are collected under GBA Policy.
Oversight for the fiscal actions of the President.
Maintaining GBA memberships and subscriptions, as outlined in GBA Policy (described in Article VI).
Authority:  The Treasurer has the authority to:
Enforce fiscal policy as outlined in GBA Policy (described in Article VI).  This may include, among other actions, the collections of dues, the approval or denial of non-budgeted items, or the denial of reimbursements for non-budgeted items, as outlined in GBA Policy.
Manage funds for the interest of the GBA.
Social Events Chairperson
Responsibilities:  The Social Events Chairperson is responsible for:
Event planning and coordination for all activities of the GBA.
Verifying that nay membership or waiver forms that are required under GBA Policy (described in Article VI) are filled out by members and nonmembers prior to their participation in an event.
Assuring adequate liability coverage for GBA events.
Authority:  The Social Events Chairperson has the authority to:
Enforce all membership policies of the GBA (described in Article VI).
Spend GBA funds on social events as appropriate and as authorized under GBA Policy.
Cancel events due to lack of interest or lack of adequate liability coverage.
Deny event participation to individuals that have not submitted adequate membership or waiver forms, as outlined in current GBA Policy.
Fundraising Chairperson: Optional Position
Responsibilities:  Th Fundraising Chairperson is responsible for:
Planning and coordinating all fundraising efforts of the GBA.
Recruiting membership for volunteering in GBA fundraising efforts.
Cancel GBA fundraising efforts or events due to lack of adequate participation, or due to monetary losses.
Article V - Voting and Elections

Proposals by the Membership

Members or their designee must be present at a full membership meeting in order to propose an item (activity initiative, new or changed GBA policy, or an amendment to the GBA Charter) for a membership vote, in order to facilitate discussion on the proposal.

Votes on New Activity Initiatives by the Membership

The membership may vote on proposals for new activity initiatives.  Proposals are ratified and accepted by a majority vote of those present.

For votes on proposals for new activity initiatives made at a membership meeting, proposals are ratified and accepted by a majority vote of those present.
b. For votes on proposals are ratified and accepted by a majority vote of all those participating in the voting. 

Votes on GBA Policy by the Membership

The membership may vote on proposals for new GBA Policy (described in Article VI) or changes in current GBA policy.  Proposals are ratified and accepted as GBA Policy by a majority vote of the entire membership.  Membership votes supersede GBA Board votes on GBA Policy.

For votes on proposals made at the same meeting, members must be present to vote.  Therefore, a quorum of at least a majority of the membership is required for a vote.
For votes on proposals made at a previous meeting, members must either be present to vote, or have written and signed their votes before the vote, and hand delivered the vote to the GBA President prior to the vote.

Votes on Amendments to GBA Charter by the Membership

The membership may vote on proposed amendments to the GBA Charter.  Proposed amendments are ratified and accepted by a two-thirds (2/3) majority of the entire membership.  Proposed amendments may not be voted on at the same meeting in which they are proposed. Votes on proposed amendments may only be voted on at a membership meeting, and such a meeting must be no less than one week and no more than three weeks after the proposed amendment was made, and members must be present to vote.

Proposals by the GBA Board

The GBA Board may propose new or propose a change to GBA Policy.  Board members must be present at a GBA Board meeting to make a proposal in order to facilitate discussion on the proposal.

Votes on GBA Policy by the GBA Board

The GBA Board may vote on proposals for new GBA Policy (described in Article VI) or changes in current GBA policy.  Proposals are ratified and accepted as GBA Policy by a majority vote of the GBA Board.  Membership votes supersede GBA Board votes on GBA Policy.

Elections

The entire GBA Board is nominated and elected by the electorate during the fall semester and hold office for the following calendar year (from January 1 to December 31).

The electorate shall consist of all full-time students of the MBA/MS program at the Isenberg School of Management, University of Massachusetts at Amherst.
Nominations for all positions must be made at a single, open GBA membership meeting or Google Poll to which all MBA/MS students are invited to attend.  Potential candidates that are nominated may accept or decline at the meeting, or at any time thereafter.  The number of candidates nominated for the various positions are not limited.  Co-chairs may be nominated for various positions, as outlined below:
President - one person only
Treasurer - one person only
Social Events - one person or co-chairs
Fundraising - one person or co-chairs (optional)
All Board member candidates shall be GBA members that have met all membership requirements as outlined under current GBA Policy (described in Article VI).
Voting shall take place through a link to the Campus Pulse site. MBA/MS are all are invited to attend. This meeting shall be no less than one week and no more than three weeks after the nomination meeting.
Voting shall be by secret ballot only.
1st year MBA/MS Students Vote for new GBA Board
ONLY 2nd Year GBA Board Votes in the 
All those wishing to vote must be present to vote or have submitted their signed and sealed absentee ballot to the current GBA President prior to the vote.  Unsigned or illegible absentee ballots cannot be counted.
Ballots for all positions are to be counted by at least two current GBA members, one of which must be a current GBA Board member.
Candidates shall be voted into office by a simple majority of all votes cast.
In the case of a tie vote for a position, one candidate may defer to the other, GBA may break the tie, or a second vote may be taken.











Article VI - GBA Policy
GBA Policy is a further set of guidelines that outline and capture what the GBA does.  GBA Policy is set by either the GBA Board or the membership, as described in Article V.  GBA Policy is meant to be the working set of guidelines that the GBA operates under, and as such, are meant to be updated with the changing needs of the GBA and the MBA/MS program.  GBA Policy may not run counter to the provisions of this Charter.
Article VII - Ratification of This Charter
This Charter must be ratified by a two-thirds (2/3) majority of the current GBA membership, following the requirements of Article V, Section 4 of this Charter.

This Charter of the Graduate Business Association, at the Eugene M. School of Management, University of Massachusetts at Amherst is hereby ratified by a two-thirds (2/3) majority of the current GBA membership.

____________________________________        _______12/12/2019_________________
Alexis J. Ditomassi				                        Date
PRESIDENT, 2019
Graduate Business Association

1st year MBA/MS Students Vote for new GBA Board
ONLY 2nd Year GBA Board Votes in the 
All those wishing to vote must be present to vote or have submitted their signed and sealed absentee ballot to the current GBA President prior to the vote.  Unsigned or illegible absentee ballots cannot be counted.
Ballots for all positions are to be counted by at least two current GBA members, one of which must be a current GBA Board member.
Candidates shall be voted into office by a simple majority of all votes cast.
In the case of a tie vote for a position, one candidate may defer to the other, GBA may break the tie, or a second vote may be taken.











Article VI - GBA Policy
GBA Policy is a further set of guidelines that outline and capture what the GBA does.  GBA Policy is set by either the GBA Board or the membership, as described in Article V.  GBA Policy is meant to be the working set of guidelines that the GBA operates under, and as such, are meant to be updated with the changing needs of the GBA and the MBA/MS program.  GBA Policy may not run counter to the provisions of this Charter.
Article VII - Ratification of This Charter
This Charter must be ratified by a two-thirds (2/3) majority of the current GBA membership, following the requirements of Article V, Section 4 of this Charter.

This Charter of the Graduate Business Association, at the Eugene M. School of Management, University of Massachusetts at Amherst is hereby ratified by a two-thirds (2/3) majority of the current GBA membership.

____________________________________        _______12/12/2019_________________
Alexis J. Ditomassi				                        Date
PRESIDENT, 2019
Graduate Business Association

DocsList.Name: Guide for Muslim Graduate Students-2021_October.docx
DocsList.Data:
Guide for Muslim Graduate Students

Transportation
Getting to UMass from the airport
From Bradley Airport (Hartford): (45 miles/80 km from UMass Amherst)
Bradley airport is the nearest airport to UMass. However, relatively few international flights fly into Bradley. You may connect to Bradley through Boston Logan International Airport or New York John F. Kennedy Airport.
The best way to reach UMass from Bradley airport is by hiring a shuttle:
Valley Transporter: 800-872-8752
This is most likely the cheapest option, but they were closed during the pandemic. Check out their Facebook page for when their services will resume.  
Seemo Shuttle: 413-586-1120
Bluebird Transportation: 413-221-4512
Michael’s Limousine & Transportation Service: 800-533-8470
If you’d like to use any of these services, one of the current UMass students can help you make a reservation (they need a credit card number to make a reservation). 
There is no direct bus or train service between Bradley airport and UMass. 

From Logan Airport (Boston): (95 miles/160 km from Umass Amherst)
Logan Airport in Boston is the nearest major international airport from UMass. It is about ~2 hrs from Amherst by car.
The best way to reach UMass from Logan is through the ‘Peter Pan’ (https://peterpanbus.com/) bus service. It costs about $35-40 for a one-way bus ticket. 
At the Logan Airport, you will have to take public transportation the Silver Line (SL1) to Boston South Station. This can take up to 30 minutes, but it is free. You can also Uber to the South Station from the airport for approximately $14. 
Please note that Peter Pan’s schedule has been impacted by the pandemic. Currently, there is only one bus coming from Boston South Station to UMass Amherst, which leaves at 4:15pm daily. Please check company website for updates and changes.
Shuttle Service: Most of the shuttle services listed above provide transport from Boston Logan to UMass. 
UMass Rideshare: This is a Facebook group run by UMass students for UMass students. You may be able to find a ride with a student from Boston to Amherst in as low as $20 or as high as $160. Please read and respect the rules of the group.

From JFK Airport (New York): (145 miles/240 km from UMass Amherst)
Located in Queens, NY, JFK is ~3.5 hrs from Amherst by car.
Refer to the following website on how to reach UMass from JFK: https://www.cics.umass.edu/grads/arriving-amherst
Transportation within the Five-College area
Most buses operated by PVTA are free year-round for students. 
Exceptions include B43 and R29 which charge a fare. A valid UMass student ID is an acceptable fare payment during the months that the university is in session. Meaning just show your student ID and you are good to go. However, during summer and winter reduced service periods, 5 college students are required to pay a fare (around $1.5 per ride). 
Uber and Lyft are also available in the area. 

Accommodation
Most graduate students live in off-campus housing where they pay a monthly rent. Amherst is a relatively expensive place to stay, with a high demand for housing. Rents typically range from $700-$1100 a month (for a single person). For a family, the rents may range from $1200 - $1600. 
The best place to start looking for housing is on the UMass off campus housing website (https://offcampushousing.umass.edu/). It has a nice layout that is easy to understand. If you find a place that you like, one of us will be happy to check it out and give advice. Some tips as you search for places to rent:
For your first year, look for housing that is in Amherst, Belchertown and Sunderland. They all lie on the bus route. Pelham is also an option, but you need a car because it is not on the bus route. While many students live in surrounding towns of Northampton, it can be a little isolating to live there during your first year. 
Craigslist- while this is a useful option for finding good rental places, avoid it during your first year. Once you arrive and have a better idea of your options, you can make use of Craigslist to find places to rent.
University of Massachusetts Amherst (UMASS) Housing, Sublets & Roommates: This is an off-campus housing Facebook group that connects
Buy Nothing Amherst MA: As the name suggests, this is a Facebook group that offers free items to receive, borrow, lend or share. 
Contact person - We will try our best to accommodate people for one or two nights while you move into your new place when you arrive. You can contact   Sadaf Latafat (slatafat@umass.edu) if you need help finding a place to stay the day you arrive in Amherst. We will do our best to help but no guarantees as spaces do tend to fill up fast.

Prayer Spaces 
Hampshire Mosque (451 Russell Street, Hadley): This is the closest mosque from UMass. It can be reached by bus (route 33, B43) in about 10 minutes. There are daily prayer services here along with Friday prayers at 1 pm all year round. Also, a great way to connect with the Muslim families and community in the area.
UMass Muslim Student Association (MSA). The Prayer Room is located in the Student Union Building, Room 355. Many students use this space for daily prayers and to meet other Muslims. This room is open for all graduate and undergraduate students, faculty and staff, and guests. Lavation rooms are also available for making wudu/ablutions nearby: Room 352 for the sisters, and Room 354 for the brothers.
Islamic Society Western Massachusetts (ISWM): This is the biggest mosque in the area located in West Springfield (~35 minutes from Amherst by car). There is also a Sunday School at the mosque for young kids. https://www.iswmonline.com/

Halal Meat/Groceries
Halal meat is easily accessible in Amherst. There are also dining locations at the UMass Amherst campus that serve Halal food, along with several restaurants in Amherst and Northampton. Below is a list of stores that sell Halal food/international groceries and the bus route that you can take to get there:
Amherst/Hadley
Maple Farms, (B43 from campus)
Stop and Shop, (33, B43)
Mom’s house, (30)/Neighbor food mart (30)
West Springfield (easily accessible via car)
El-Safi
Al-Nassir International Market
Parus
Yara Market

Halal Restaurants
Halal restaurants in Amherst/Northampton
The Halal Cart (New York style street food)
Pita pocket (Syrian)
Bombay Royale (Indian)
Amanouz Café (Moroccan)
Halal Food on UMass campus (green, labelled H)
Worcester Dining Common (UMass Amherst’s Halal Kitchen is located here so quite a number of Halal options)
Franklin Dining Common (Kosher meal option) 
Harvest in campus center 


Weather gear
	It is advisable to have waterproof shoes or boots, a waterproof jacket, and a scarf, hat and gloves. During the fall, Amherst temperatures range between 50-80F (10-27C), with some rainy days. The winter months are significantly colder, with temperatures as low as -20F (-29C) . During the winter season, there is potential for at least mild snow(1-6 inches, 0-15cm), and occasionally more significant snowfall (12-36 inches, 30-90cm). There are many locations to purchase these items in Amherst in the right season. Just be prepared!

Grad student contacts in different departments
Electrical & Computer Engineering- Noman (nbashir@umass.edu)
Civil and Environmental Engineering- Kiron (mshakhawat@umass.edu)
Computer Science: Walid (waabdelrahma@umass.edu)
Isenberg SOM - Amro El-Adle (aeladle@umass.edu) 
College of Education – Sadaf (slatafat@umass.edu)

DocsList.Data:
Constitution of the College of Nursing Graduate Student Organization at the University of Massachusetts Amherst
First Edition
ARTICLE I - Name and Purpose
Section 1 Name of the Organization: The organization shall be named Graduate Resource OrgAnization of Nursing (GROAN).
Section 2 Purpose: The purpose of GROAN  is to facilitate and support activities that meet the academic, social, cultural, and professional needs of graduate students in the College of Nursing at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.
ARTICLE II - Membership, Membership Fees, Non-Discrimination Policy
Section 1 General Definition of Membership: Membership shall be open to all graduate students in the College of Nursing at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.
Section 2 Active Membership: Active members are graduate students who are enrolled in courses or otherwise actively working toward their degree and who attend at least two meetings per academic semester (in person or via online technology). In addition, an active member is expected to take part in at least one service event per academic year. 
Section 3 Non-Discrimination Policy: GROAN does not discriminate for any purpose on the basis of age, race, gender, ethnicity, linguistic abilities, religion, sexual identity, political affiliation, disability status, or marital status.
Section 4 Faculty Involvement: Staff and Faculty at the CON are welcome to attend the monthly meetings and provide input on matters to be discussed by GROAN. Faculty may be invited to facilitate specific conversations or provide mentorship in a certain area of expertise. Staff and Faculty who are not currently enrolled in graduate study in the Umass Amherst College of Nursing shall not be voting members.
ARTICLE III - Officers, Duties, and Terms 
Executive Committee
President: The role of the president is to prepare materials and handouts for scheduled meetings, provide the agenda for the upcoming meeting at least 72 hours in advance of the meeting, co-facilitate discussion during the meeting, and work with other executive committee members on matters related to GROAN The president will, along with the Treasurer, have check signing power. The President will also collaborate with the Vice President on providing updates about the activities of the organization through the CONversations newsletter. 
Vice President: The role of the vice president is to collaborate with the President to develop an agenda for meetings, co-facilitate discussion during the meeting, and work with other executive committee members related to GROAN. In the event that the President is unable to attend a meeting, the Vice President will distribute the agenda in advance of the upcoming meeting. The Vice-President will also collaborate with the President on providing updates about the activities of the organization through the CONversations newsletter.
Treasurer: The treasurer will be in charge of maintaining and keeping track of funds related to GROAN. This may include speaking to Graduate Student Senate (GSS) Finance Committee or other on-campus entities to help secure funding for GROAN as relevant. The treasurer, in collaboration with the President, will be able to sign checks. 
In addition to attending the general meeting, Executive Committee members are expected to meet once a month (or more as needed) to help move activities related to GROAN forward. 
Terms: All terms will last for one academic year. Executive Committee work may take place during winter or summer breaks to prepare as needed for the next round of committee members. Executive Committee members will maintain responsibility for their duties until a subsequent Executive Committee is convened. Executive Committee members may also be asked to serve as mentors for the individuals who will fill their roles after the position is vacated. 
Additional Positions
Secretary: The secretary is responsible for taking notes during the general meeting and special meetings and to provide a written summary of the meeting to all those involved within one week following the meeting. 
Graduate Student Senate Representative: The GSS representative for the College of Nursing will represent the interest of graduate students within the College of Nursing at monthly GSS meetings. The GSS representative will serve as a liaison between the GSS, graduate students, and GROAN. Currently, the College of Nursing is allowed to have two GSS representatives. (May be held by a member of the Executive Committee)
Graduate Employee Organization Steward: The GEO steward is responsible for understanding workers’ rights, the grievance process, and encouraging departmental participation within the union. Stewards also represent the needs of graduate students in the College of Nursing at GEO meetings (held twice a semester). In their role as steward, the individual will act as a liaison between graduate students in the CON, GEO staff, and the GROAN. (May be held by a member of the Executive Committee). 
Social Coordinator: The role of the social coordinator is to assist in coordination of events that are held on campus or in the community. The social coordinator will distribute information about upcoming events for graduate students. (May be held by a member of the Executive Committee).
Other Committee Memberships as needed: When asked to do so by the College of Nursing, the GSO name will be responsible for nominating and electing individuals to serve on department-level and university-level committees and represent the needs and interests of the graduate students in the CON. (May be held by a member of the Executive Committee)
Terms: All terms will last for one academic year. Individuals in individual positions will maintain responsibility for their duties until another individual is appointed; they may also be asked to serve as mentors for the individuals who will fill their roles after the position is vacated. 
ARTICLE IV - Election and Appointment Procedures 
Section 1 Election Schedule: The election for all executive committee positions shall be held at the end of April of each year. The election day shall be announced in the immediately prior general meeting.
Section 2 Nomination Schedule: 10 days before the election, a notice shall be thoroughly distributed by the secretary to announce the election and to invite nominations for each position.
Section 3 Nomination Eligibility: Any active member may be nominated for any position. Any active member may nominate any active member including her/himself.
Section 4 Nomination Acceptance: 8 days before the election, each nominee shall be given one day to accept or decline the nomination of her/his name. In the event that an individual is nominated for more than one Executive Committee position, the individual will choose which position they would like to be considered for.
Section 5 Campaigning Period: Beginning 7 days before the election, each nominee shall be permitted to forward a statement to the secretary to be posted on a webpage devoted to nominees’ statements. The secretary may also choose to send the statements of interest via e-mail list serve for graduate students as a means of reaching the greatest number of graduate students possible.
Section 6 Election Period: On days and times decided in the prior general meeting, a secure online survey will be made available to all graduate students for the purpose of voting. 
Section 7 Votes Counting: Votes shall be counted by a suitable, impartial third person.
Section 8 Determinations: A winner shall receive a majority of votes. In the event of a tie, the leading candidates sharing the tie shall participate in a runoff election following the general procedures in sections 5 through 7.
Section 9 Appointment Procedures: 
In the event of a sudden or continued vacancy in an executive position, the President may choose to appoint an active member to the position in a temporary manner until an election can be held for the position.
ARTICLE V - Meetings
Section 1 General Meetings: General meetings will be held twice a month, on the 2nd and 4th Tuesdays from 11:45 a.m.-12:45 p.m. 
Section 2 Special Meetings: Special meetings may be called as needed by communicating with the President and Vice President either verbally or in writing. Depending on the goal of the special meeting and the urgency of the matter, the Executive Committee will establish a special meeting time as soon as reasonably possible. Members will be made aware of special meetings at least 48 hours in advance whenever possible. 
Section 3 Rules of Conduct and Speech: Conduct and speech will be monitored using newly revised Robert’s Rules of Order (2011). Discussion on Robert’s Rules will be presented at the beginning of the first meeting, and a handout will be provided with basic information on Robert’s Rules at the beginning of each general meeting. 
Section 4: Voting. Voting will occur after an item has been discussed thoroughly and voting members do not have further questions or concerns about the item moving forward. One member shall move to vote on the item and another member shall second the motion prior to a vote being taken. Members will be provided the opportunity to vote (in favor, opposed, abstain) and a count will be taken. Members who are not able to attend the meeting in person may provide the President and/or Vice President with their thoughts or concerns about the item which will be shared with members during the meeting. Individuals may vote in writing provided that the vote is received at least two hours in advance of the scheduled meeting. 
A minimum of four active members (not including the Executive Committee) are required to attend a meeting in order for a vote to take place (quorum). In the event that a quorum is not met, voting on the item in question will be tabled until the next meeting. If voting is needed prior to the next general meeting, a special meeting may be called. 
ARTICLE VI - Rights and Privileges of Members 
Section 1 General Rights of Members: Members have the right to attend meetings, express questions and concerns regarding topics at hand, raise topics to be discussed, initiate projects, form sub-committees, and participate in networking activities. Members may also collaborate with members of other school-wide and campus-wide committees on projects and topics of interest. 
Section 2 Voting Rights of Active Members: Active members have the right to vote on any item up for discussion. In the event that an active member is unable to attend the meeting in person or via technology, the member may submit their thoughts, concerns, questions, and/or vote toward a scheduled topic in advance of the meeting to a member of the Executive Committee; electronic votes should be received 2 hours in advance of the scheduled meeting. 
Section 3 Other Rights of Active Members: In addition to general rights listed above, active members also have the right to take on leadership roles within the organization either through elected positions or volunteer positions. Members have the right to move to amend the Constitution of GROAN.
ARTICLE VII – Committees 
Service Committee: The goal of the service committee is to identify members’ ideas for volunteer service either on campus or in the community. The service committee members will collaborate with university or community organizations to establish the service project, announce and recruit members for the project, and report on the project at the meeting following the project. The service committee shall also prepare a brief summary of the project rationale and outcomes to the editor of CONversations. The service committee will organize at least one project per academic semester. Collaboration with the undergraduate Student Nurses’ Organization will also be sought in the service projects.  
Scholarship Committee: The goal of the scholarship committee is to identify members’ needs and ideas related to advancing scholarship among graduate students in the CON. The scholarship committee members will be responsible for organizing the graduate student journal club, sharing information about upcoming conferences of interest, and funding of interest. Members of the scholarship committee may also provide mentoring and feedback to graduate students with regard to constructing abstracts, designing posters for presentation, conference presentations, and other pursuits as time allows. 
Additional permanent committees may be established if active members identify an ongoing need that can be filled by a committee, identify the mission of the committee, and present the information at a general meeting. Any additional ongoing committees will be posted on the GROAN web page. 
Ad hoc Committees: Ad hoc committees may be formed to work on short term projects as needed. 
ARTICLE VIII - Amendments to the Constitution 
Section 1 Proposal: A member may propose an amendment by distributing it in written format ahead of the meeting and reading it aloud in a meeting. Voting of a proposal may not take place in the same meeting as that in which the proposal was made. Following the meeting, the proposal shall be made known to all members of GROAN.
Section 2 Approval: During the next general meeting, and only after a thorough discussion to the satisfaction of all members present for the voting of a proposal, a vote shall be taken on its approval provided that quorum is available. The amendment must secure two thirds of the votes available during the meeting.
Section 3 Recording: Any successful amendment shall be recorded and copies of the new constitution shall be presented on the GROAN web page and made available in paper format. Two paper copies shall be stored for record-keeping purposes.

DocsList.Name: new_gsg_constitution_2024.pdf
DocsList.Data:
Whereas, the Graduate Student Senate has recognized a need to amend its   
Constitution as outlined here: Appendix 1a: WHY Constitution Amendments (Attached as 
Appendix 1a) and;    

Whereas, the proposed changes to the structure of the governing body of graduate students requires 
a new name for the organization to accurately reflect its role;    

Be it therefore enacted, the Graduate Student Senate (GSS) at the University of  
Massachusetts Amherst hereby changes its name to the Graduate Student Government (GSG) 
of the University of Massachusetts Amherst and;    

Be it further enacted, all current members, officers, senators, or any individuals with 
any  position  in  any  form  connected  with  the  GSS,  elected,  appointed,  or  associated 
under the name of GSS, shall continue under the name of GSG and;    

Be it further enacted, the effective date of the updated and amended   
Constitution shall be the date of ratification by the Board of Trustees and,    

Be it further enacted, the Constitution, also known as Trustee Document T12-001 (Attached as 
Appendix 1b), be updated and amended to the following:   

 
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
    
 THE CONSTITUTION OF THE GRADUATE STUDENT GOVERNMENT OF THE  
UNIVERSITY OF MASSACHUSETTS AMHERST   

HISTORY:    
Approved by the Graduate Student Senate April 9th, 2024    
Approved by the Graduate Students May 6th, 2024   
Ratified by the Board of Trustees September 19, 2024    

PREAMBLE   
We, the Graduate Students of the University of Massachusetts Amherst, in order to establish 
a  democratic  system  for  Graduate  Students  in  University  governance,  and  recognizing  the 
necessity of organizing in order to attain a just, cooperative society which serves the interests 
of graduate students, and further recognizing the necessity for immediate and ongoing action 
to effectuate cooperation and participation among graduate students, and ultimately to ensure 
the  representation  of  all  degree-seeking  graduate  student  members,  do  hereby  ordain  and  
establish  this  Constitution  of  the  Graduate  Student  Government  at  the  University  of  
Massachusetts Amherst.    

ARTICLE I   
Name   

Section 1 The name of this organization shall be the Graduate Student Government of the University of 

Massachusetts Amherst, herein referred to as the GSG.    

 
   
   
   
   
   
   
 Section 1  

ARTICLE II    
Authority   

This constitution shall supersede any other previously existing system of campus wide 

governance for the University graduate student population.    

Section 2 The GSG derives its authority from the graduate students of the University, through 

election,  and  by  actions  of  the  Board  of  Trustees  approving  this  Constitution,  as 

provided  in  Section  3,  Chapter  75  of  the  General  Laws  of  the  Commonwealth  of 

Massachusetts.    

Section 3 The GSG, in its responsibilities and relationships with other governing components 

of the University, shall be governed by the Board of Trustees’ Statement on University 

Governance (Trustee Document T73-098, as amended).    

Section 4 All bylaws, acts, procedures and all other actions of the GSG, shall be consistent with this 

Constitution and Trustee Document T73-098, as amended.    

ARTICLE III    
Purpose   

Section 1 The purpose of the GSG shall be:    

A. To  ensure  the  representation  of  all  degree  seeking  graduate  students,  herein  referred  to  as 

graduate students, of the University of Massachusetts Amherst;    

B. To discuss and recommend policies affecting the campus and the University as a whole;    

C. To promote graduate student participation in the development of policies and procedures within 

all aspects of the University of Massachusetts Amherst;    

D. To serve as a resource and advocate for graduate students;   

E.  To  represent  the  goals,  interests,  concerns,  and  professional  development  of  the  graduate 

student population;    

F.  To facilitate community and communication among graduate students in different  

Colleges, Schools, and Departments;    

 Section 1  

ARTICLE IV    
Membership   

All graduate students of the University of Massachusetts Amherst, herein denoted 
the University, that meet the qualifications for GSG membership as defined in Article 
IV Section 2 shall be entitled to be members of the GSG, and shall have an equal voice 
and vote therein with that of their fellow members.    

Section 2 “Graduate Student Government member”, shall hereby be defined as any graduate 
student of the University of Massachusetts Amherst who is subject to and has paid, the 
Graduate Student Government Fee for the calendar time to which it is applicable.    

Section 3 “Graduate Student Government membership”, shall hereby be defined as all GSG 

members.    

Section 4 “Graduate Student Government officer”, shall hereby be defined as any GSG 
member who holds an elected or appointed position within the Graduate Student 
Government.    

Section 5 “Membership in attendance”, shall hereby be defined as the total count of the votes 
in the affirmative and in the negative but excluding any abstentions. Abstentions shall 
not be counted towards the overall vote count.    

Section 6 Any GSG member receiving any form of compensation for services carried out in 
the  name  of,  and  for  the  express  purpose  of  furthering  the  mission  of  the  Graduate 
Student  Government,  shall  be  treated  as  an  Officer  of  the  Graduate  Student 
Government.    

Article V    
Composition of Government   

Section  1  The  GSG  shall  be  composed  of  three  branches  of  Government:  the  Legislative, 
Executive, and Judicial branches. All elected and appointed officers of the GSG shall 
be members of the GSG, as defined in Article IV of this Constitution. No GSG member 
shall hold elected or appointed office in more than one branch of the government, except 
as provided for by the General Bylaws of the GSG. No GSG member shall hold more 
than one office, in any branch, that receives monetary compensation.   

Section  2  The  University  Student  Trustee  as  defined  by  the  General  Laws  of  the 
Commonwealth of Massachusetts, shall be an ex-officio officer of the GSG.    

 Section 1  

Article VI    
The Graduate Student Government Fee   

The  GSG  shall  levy  a  fee  to  fund  the  operations  of  governmental  procedure  and 
disperse its funds in the interest of graduate students and as prescribed in the General 
Bylaws of the GSG.    

Section 2 Any recommended increase in the GSG Fee of over 7.5% shall require a two-thirds 
(2/3)  vote  of  the  Senate  membership  in  attendance  at  a  scheduled  meeting,  and  an 
affirmative vote of the GSG membership through an Action Referendum.    

Article VII    
The Legislative   

Section 1 The legislative authority of the GSG shall be vested in the Senate.    

Section 2 The membership of the Senate shall be composed of representatives, herein denoted 
as Senators, apportioned by the Senate to Electoral Districts, as defined by the General 
Bylaws of the GSG.    

Section 3 Senators shall be elected in a manner prescribed by the General Bylaws of the GSG 

and shall serve for a term prescribed therein.    

Section 4 The Speaker of the Senate:    

A. The Senate shall provide for the election of, from its voting membership, a Speaker 
of  the  Senate,  herein  denoted  the  Speaker,  who  shall  serve  as  the  chief  presiding 
officer and the chief clerk and parliamentarian of the Senate. The Speaker may only 
be  a  sworn-in  Senator,  in  good  standing,  according  to  the  General  Bylaws  of  the 
GSG.    

i. The  Speaker  shall  be  responsible  for  the  business  and  management  of  the 

Senate.    

B. If a vacancy shall occur in the office of Speaker, a new Speaker shall be elected at 
the next regularly scheduled meeting of the Senate, unless otherwise provided within 
the General Bylaws of the GSG. The President shall chair Senate meetings during 
the time of the election of a Speaker.   

i. The Associate  Speaker  shall  be  responsible  for  the  duties  of  the  Speaker, 
except for the chairing of Senate meetings in which the election of the Speaker 
shall take place, until the position is filled.    

Section 5 The Associate Speaker of the Senate:    

 A. The  Senate  shall  provide  for  the  election  of,  from  its  voting  membership,  an Associate 
Speaker of the Senate, herein denoted the Associate Speaker, who shall serve as the chief 
historian and chief coordination officer of the Senate. The Associate Speaker may only be a 
sworn-in Senator, in good standing, according to the General Bylaws of the GSG.    

B. If a vacancy shall occur in the office of Associate Speaker, a new Associate Speaker   

shall  be  elected  at  the  next  regularly  scheduled  meeting  of  the  Senate,  unless 
otherwise provided within the General Bylaws of the GSG.    

i. The Speaker shall be responsible for completion or delegation of the duties of 

the Associate Speaker until the position is filled.    

Section 6 The Senate shall have the power to:    

A.  Review and make recommendations regarding the Graduate Student Government  

Fee.    

B.  Determine and provide for its rules and procedures, elect its officers, and fix the time 
and place of its meetings, provided that there be a regular meeting with fixed time 
and    place  at  least  once  every  month  of  the  regular  academic  calendar  of  the 
University.  This  shall  not  preclude  meetings  outside  of  the  regular  academic 
calendar,  provided  that  appropriate  steps  are  taken  to  advertise  the  meeting  to 
Senators.   

C.  Require the attendance of its members by rule, as delineated in the General Bylaws 

of the GSG.    

D.  Expel a member of the Senate. The act of Expulsion shall require a two-thirds (2/3) 

vote of its membership in attendance at a scheduled meeting.    

E.  Enact, amend or repeal the General Bylaws of the GSG. Such an act shall require a 
two thirds (2/3) vote of its membership in attendance at a scheduled meeting, and 
any other such provision as outlined in the General Bylaws of the GSG.    

F.  Ratify GSG Elections within thirty (30) calendar days of the election. Such an act 

shall require a majority vote of its membership in attendance at a scheduled meeting.   

G.  Initiate a referendum as defined by this Constitution. Such an act shall require a two 

thirds (2/3) vote of its membership in attendance at a scheduled meeting.    

H.  Decide tied General or Special Elections at its first meeting following the election. 
Such  an  act  shall  require  a  majority  vote  of  its  membership  in  attendance  at  a 
scheduled meeting.    

 
 Section 1  

I.  Approve the GSG Budget Request. Such an Act shall require a majority vote of its 

membership in attendance at a scheduled meeting.    

 J.  Override a presidential veto. Such an act shall require a two-thirds (2/3) vote of its 

membership in attendance at a scheduled meeting.    

K.  Approve Executive Cabinet and Judiciary Appointments. Such an act shall require 

a majority vote of its membership in attendance at a scheduled meeting.    

L.  Require reports from the President, Vice President, Executive Cabinet, and Standing 
Committee Chairs on any matter relevant to the functioning of the GSG Senate.    

M. Impeach an elected or appointed officer of the GSG. Such an act shall proceed only 
after  a  legal  review,  followed  by  a  two-thirds  (2/3)  vote  of  its  membership  in 
attendance at a scheduled meeting.    

N.  Make  recommendations,  as  a  governance  body,  on  University  policies  and 

procedures consistent with Trustee Document T73-098, as amended.    

Section 7 The Senate shall not:    

A. Take an action abridging any of the powers delegated to it by this Constitution.    

B. Deny  the  rights  and  privileges  of  Senate  membership  to  any  duly  elected  or 
appointed Senator, except as provided for by this Constitution or the General Bylaws 
of the GSG.    

C. Recommend the appropriation  of monies for  a period of more than one (1) fiscal 

year.    

D. Recommend the increase or decrease in wage of any elected or appointed officer of 

the GSG, effective to the incumbent at the time of the increase or decrease.    

E.  Infringe the secrecy of the ballot in any GSG Elections.   

F.  Meet in "executive session", as defined by the General Laws of the Commonwealth 

of Massachusetts.   

i.  Exception:  The  Senate  may  only  enter  executive  session  in  matters  of 
Impeachment  if  the  Senate  needs  to  discuss  the  reputation,  character, 
physical condition, or mental health, rather than professional competence, 
of  an  individual,  by  a  two-thirds  (⅔)  vote  of  the  Senate  membership  in 
attendance at a scheduled meeting.   

Section 8 The procedures of the Senate shall be as follows:    

 
 A. No  bill,  unless  otherwise  provided  for  by  the  General  Bylaws  of  the  GSG,  shall 
become an Act of the GSG unless it shall have been introduced to the Senate, read, 
and  passed  by  a  majority  vote  of  its  membership  in  attendance  at  a  scheduled 
meeting.    

B. No bill, unless otherwise provided for by this Constitution or the General Bylaws of   

the  GSG,  shall  become  an  Act  of  the  GSG  without  the  signature  of  the  GSG 
President. The President of the GSG may veto  the bill  within seven (7) calendar 
days of its passage, providing explicit reasons for the veto in writing to the Speaker 
of the Senate. If the President vetoes a bill, the Speaker of the Senate shall send the 
vetoed bill, along with the President's written reasons for the veto, back to the Senate 
within three (3) calendar days of receiving the veto. The Senate shall consider the 
vetoed bill at the next regular or special meeting of the Senate.   

C. If a bill is neither signed nor vetoed by the GSG President within seven (7) calendar 
days following its passage, it shall automatically become an act of the GSG unless 
two-thirds (2/3) of the Senate membership in attendance at a scheduled meeting vote 
to extend the review period for an additional seven (7) days.   

D. A vetoed bill or a bill not signed by the GSG President within the specified period 
may be enacted notwithstanding the veto or failure of signature of the GSG President 
if it shall have been read in full a second time and passed upon a twothirds (2/3) vote 
of the Senate membership in attendance at a scheduled meeting.   

E.  The quorum for the conduct of official business at a Senate meeting, or a meeting of 
any  Senate  Committee  or  entity,  shall  be  fifty  percent  (50%)  of  the  total  voting 
membership  of  the  body,  plus  one  (1),  unless  otherwise  provided  for  by  this 
Constitution. Voting membership shall be defined as the total number of active GSG 
Senate officers eligible to vote in the body.   

F.  Should  the  Senate  be  equally  divided  on  a  matter,  the  pending  matter  shall  be 

considered to have failed.   

Section 9 Special Senate Meetings may be called by:   

A. The Speaker of the Senate, at the request of any member of the graduate student body 
or  any  representative  of  the  University  Administration.  The  Speaker  shall  be 
empowered to deny this request.    

B. Twenty-five percent (25%) of the Senate, by petition to the Steering Committee. The 
petition shall be verified and approved for accuracy by the Steering Committee, as 
delineated in the General Bylaws of the GSG. The Speaker shall not have the power 
to deny this request.    

 
 C. Five  percent  (5%)  of  fee  paying  graduate  students,  by  petition  to  the  Steering 
Committee. The petition shall be verified and approved for accuracy by the Steering 
Committee, as delineated in the General Bylaws of the GSG. The Speaker shall not 
have the power to deny this request.    

D. The President, through a request to the Steering Committee, at which the Steering   

Committee shall require a majority of its membership to approve the President's   

request.    The  President  shall  not  vote  upon  this  request,  unless  the  vote  of  the 
committee is equal. The Speaker shall not be empowered to deny the chosen action 
of the Steering Committee.    

Article VIII    
The Executive   

Section 1  The executive authority of the GSG shall be vested in the GSG President, herein 
denoted  the  President,  and  other  lesser  executive  officers  recognized  by  this 
Constitution or the General Bylaws of the GSG.    

Section 2 The President and Vice President shall run on a joint-ticket and the Treasurer on a 
separate ticket. The aforementioned positions shall be popularly elected by a majority 
or plurality of the GSG membership voting, on or before March 31st of each calendar 
year and shall serve for a term of one (1) year, here defined as June 1st to May 31st.  
Elections shall be held in a manner prescribed by the General Bylaws of the GSG.    

Section  3  In  the  event  of  the  vacancy  of  the  President,  the Vice  President  shall  assume  the 
Office of the President. The vacancy of the Vice President shall be filled by appointment 
from  the  President  in  accordance  with  the  General  Bylaws  of  the  GSG.  Should  the 
Office of President and Vice President become vacant at the same time, the Treasurer 
shall assume the Office of the President. The vacancy of the Treasurer shall be filled by 
appointment  by  the  Steering  Committee  in  accordance  with  General  Bylaws  of  the 
GSG. All vacancies shall be filled for the unexpired term of office.   

Section 4 The President shall have the power to:   A.  

Act as the chief executive of the GSG.    

B. Take care that all the provisions of this Constitution, the General Bylaws of the GSG, 

and Acts of the GSG are faithfully executed.    

C. Appoint, upon a majority vote of the Senate membership in attendance at a scheduled 

meeting, the Executive Cabinet.    

D. Appoint, upon a majority vote of the Senate membership in attendance at a scheduled 

meeting, the five (5) Justices of the Judiciary.    

E.  Appoint all lesser executive officers and membership to all external committees.    

 
 F.  In a manner prescribed by the General Bylaws of the GSG, call the Senate into   

Session.    

G. Add any bill to the agenda of a regularly scheduled meeting of the Senate.    

H. Veto any bill except the Annual Budget Act and any Articles of Impeachment.    

I.  Be the President of the Senate, but shall have no vote.    

J.  Initiate a referendum as defined in Article XI of this Constitution.    

Section 5 The Vice President shall have the power to:    

A. Act as the head of the Executive Branch when the President is not in attendance.    

B. Act  for  the  President  as  their  official  representative  in  all  capacities  with  the 
exception of signing or vetoing legislation, so long as the President has given prior 
consent to their actions.    

C. At  such  times  as  the  President  deems  necessary,  become Acting  President  and  to 
exercise all the powers of the Presidency, including, but not limited to, hiring and 
firing staff and signing and vetoing legislation. The President shall inform the Senate 
of this transfer of power.   

D. Act, in conjunction and consultation with the Directing Attorney of Student Legal 
Services Office or their designee, as the chief legal counsel to the GSG in matters 
pending before the GSG Judiciary.    

i. Be directly responsible for the official judicial records of the GSG including, 

but not limited to Judiciary Rulings.    

Section 6 The Treasurer shall have the power to:    

A. Act as the chief financial officer of the GSG.    

B. Take care that all the financial provisions of this Constitution, the General Bylaws 

of the GSG, and Acts of the GSG are faithfully executed.    

C. Manage the Graduate Student Government Trust Fund in conjunction with the   

Senate, as prescribed in the General Bylaws of the Graduate Student Government. 

D. Control purchasing and expenditure of GSG funds.    

D. Oversee distribution of Line Item and Ad Hoc funding.    

E.  Audit recipients of GSG monies.    

 
 F.  Create,  modify,  or  alter  the  Graduate  Student  Organization  (GSO)  funding 
guidelines, in conjunction with the Senate, as prescribed in the General Bylaws of 
the Graduate Student Government.    

G. Be directly responsible for the official GSO records of the GSG.    

H. Approve or deny the applications of new GSOs, and manage all registrations or re 

registrations of GSOs.    

I.  Freeze graduate student group financial accounts for violation of University Policy, 
or violation of any Bylaw, Act, or resolution of the GSG via the process enumerated 
in the General Bylaws of the Graduate Student Government.    

Article IX    
The Judicial   

Section 1 The Judicial authority of the GSG shall be vested in a Judiciary.   

Section 2 The Judiciary shall have original jurisdiction over any controversy arising under this 

Constitution, the General Bylaws of the GSG, or any Act of the GSG.    

Section 3 The Judiciary shall be composed of five (5) Justices appointed by the GSG President 
and confirmed by a majority vote of the Senate membership in attendance at a scheduled 
meeting. The Justices shall serve from the date of their swearing-in until they resign or 
graduate  from  the University. The Chief Justice  and Associate Chief Justice shall be 
elected at the start of every academic year, as provided in Article IX Section 7 of this 
Constitution. Should the Judiciary lack the ability to produce quorum, due to a lack of 
action by the President to appoint Justices, for a period of ninety (90) calendar days 
from the date on which quorum could no longer be met, the President shall defer their 
right to appoint the number of Justices that would facilitate  the Judiciary’s ability to 
produce quorum. The Steering Committee, via a majority vote of its membership, shall 
be empowered to appoint, upon a majority vote of the Senate membership in attendance 
at a scheduled meeting, the number of Justices necessary to facilitate a quorum.    

Section  4  The  Judiciary  may  hold,  by  declaratory  judgment,  any  act  by  any  agent  of  the  
Executive or Legislative Branches of the GSG, or of any agency directly associated with 
the  GSG, or of any candidate for GSG office, to be unconstitutional, or in violation of 
any  Bylaw    or Act  of  the  GSG,  and  therefore,  invalid,  provided  said  action  is  not  a 
governance item  approved by the Board of Trustees.    

Section 5 Any person(s), with the exception of serving Justices of the Judiciary, may file with 
the Judiciary a Petition for a Ruling on the constitutionality or validity of any act by any 
agent of the Executive or Legislative Branches of the GSG, or of any agency directly 
associated with the GSG, or of any candidate for GSG office, within sixty (60) calendar 
days of said action.  The Judiciary shall issue a ruling on the same, provided said action 
is not a governance item approved by the Board of Trustees.    

 
 Section 6 The Quorum for the conduct of business for the Judiciary shall be four (4) Justices.   

No business shall be conducted by the Judiciary without quorum.    

Section 7 Chief Justice & Associate Chief Justice    

A. The Judiciary shall provide for the election of, from its voting membership, a Chief 
Justice of the Judiciary, herein denoted the Chief Justice, who shall serve as the chief 
presiding officer of the Judiciary.   

B. The  Judiciary  shall  provide  for  the  election  of,  from  its  voting  membership,  an 
Associate Chief Justice of the Judiciary, herein denoted the Associate Chief Justice, 
who shall serve as the chief clerk of the Judiciary.    

C. If a vacancy shall occur in the office of Chief Justice, the Associate Chief Justice 

shall become Chief Justice for the duration of the unfinished term.    

Article X    
The Steering Committee   

Section  1  The  Steering  Committee  shall  serve  as  an  intermediary  body,  consisting  of  GSG 
leadership, in order to promote and strategize a plan for, and the direction of, the GSG. 
The  purpose  of  the  Steering  Committee  is  to  ensure  cooperation  and  coordination 
between  the  branches  of  the  GSG  Government,  and  ensure  necessary  functions  of 
government  are  carried  out. The  task  and  charges  of  the  committee  shall  follow  the 
parameters set forth in the General Bylaws of the GSG.    

Section 2 The President shall be the Chair of the Steering Committee, with the Speaker as the 

Vice Chair. The membership of the Steering Committee in its entirety is as follows:    

A. President    

B. Vice President    

C. Treasurer   

D. Chief Justice    

E.  Speaker    

F.  Two (2) Chairs of a GSG Standing Committee, as provided in the General Bylaws 
of the GSG, with appointment to the Steering Committee via a majority vote of the 
Senate.    

Article XI   
Referenda   

Section 1 There shall be two primary types of referenda:    

 
 A. Action - An Action Referendum, if approved, shall become an Act of the GSG, shall 
not be subject to presidential veto, and when such an action is intended as a formal 
recommendation  from  the  GSG,  as  a  governance  body,  it  shall  be  submitted  in 
accordance  with  the  procedures  prescribed  in  Trustee  Document  T73-098,  as 
amended.   

B. Advisory - An Advisory Referendum shall only be a measure of public sentiment.    

Section 2 All referenda shall be clearly labeled and understood by the GSG membership to be 

either an Action or Advisory Referendum.    

Section 3 Referenda shall be initiated by any one of the following:    

A. The Senate    

B. The GSG President    

C. The  signatures,  on  a  petition,  of  not  less  than  five  percent  (5%)  of  the  GSG 

membership.    

Section 4 No referenda shall be considered valid unless approved by no less than five percent 

(5%) of the GSG membership.    

Article XII    
Amendments to the General Bylaws of the GSG   

Section 1 The General Bylaws of the GSG may be amended in accordance with the General 
Bylaws  of  the  GSG  and  by  a  two-thirds  (2/3)  vote  of  the  Senate  membership  in 
attendance at a scheduled meeting.    

Article XIII    
Amendments to the Constitution of the GSG   

Section 1 An amendment to this Constitution shall be passed upon a two-thirds (2/3) vote of 
the  Senate  membership  in  attendance  at  a  Regular  or  Special  meeting  of  the  GSG, 
provided that the proposed change shall have been presented at a previous Regular or 
Special Meeting of the GSG, and with a majority vote of the GSG membership voting 
on the amendment through an Action Referendum.    

Section 2 Amendments to this Constitution shall be effective only after approval by the Board 

of Trustees.    

Section  3  If  the  amendment  process  of  this  Constitution  shall  have  been  invoked,  then, 

following an amendment's passage in the Senate, the amendment shall appear as an   

Action Referendum before the GSG membership, no more than thirty (30) calendar days 
from the calendar date of the amendment's passage in the Senate.   

 
 Article XIV   
Ratification   

Section  1  This  Constitution  shall  be  ratified  upon  a  two-thirds  (2/3)  vote  of  the  Senate 
membership in attendance at a scheduled meeting, a majority vote of the voting GSG 
membership on an Action Referendum, and the approval of the Board of Trustees.

DocsList.Data:
Graduate Student Senate 
University of Massachusetts Amherst 

Constitution 

PREAMBLE 

Recognizing the necessity of organizing in order to attain the just, cooperative society which 
alone can be in the absolute interests of graduate students, and further recognizing the 
necessity for immediate and ongoing action to effectuate cooperation and participation among 
graduate students, the graduate students of this campus hereby establish a Graduate Student 
Senate for the University of Massachusetts Amherst (hereinafter referred to as the GSS). 

ARTICLE I. Authority 
ARTICLE II. Purpose 
ARTICLE III. Graduate Student Senate Tax 
ARTICLE IV. Composition 
ARTICLE V.  Procedures 
ARTICLE VI. General Meetings of Graduate Students 
ARTICLE VII. Amending procedure 
ARTICLE VIII. Bylaws Amendment Procedures 
ARTICLE IX. Ratification 

ARTICLE I. Authority 

A. This constitution shall supersede any other previously existing system of campus wide 

governance for the University graduate population. 

B. The GSS derives its authority from actions by the Board of Trustees approving this 

Constitution, as provided in Section 3, Chapter 75 of the General Laws of the 
Commonwealth. 

C. The GSS, in its responsibilities and relationships with other governing components of the 
University, shall be governed by the Board of Trustees’ Statement on University 
Governance (Trustee Document T73-098, as amended). 

D. All bylaws, acts, procedures and all other actions of the GSS, shall be consistent with this 

Constitution and Trustee Document T73-098. 

ARTICLE II. Purpose 

A. To ensure the representation of all degree-seeking graduate student members of the 

campus community in the governance of the Amherst campus and the University as a 
whole; 

B. To discuss and recommend policies affecting the campus and the University as a whole; 

  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
   
 
 C. To promote graduate student participation in the development of policies and procedures 
within the various colleges, schools, faculties, and departments of the University of 
Massachusetts Amherst; 

D. To review and make recommendations regarding the Graduate Student Senate Tax. 
E. To enact, amend and repeal Bylaws for its internal functioning. 

ARTICLE III. Graduate Student Senate Tax 

A. All degree-seeking graduate students paying curriculum fee shall pay full GSS tax. 
B. All degree-seeking graduate students not paying curriculum fee shall pay 50% tax. 
C. A recommended increase in the Senate Tax of over 7.5% shall require a two-thirds (2/3) 

vote of the Senate membership in attendance at a scheduled meeting, and an affirmative 
vote of the GSS membership through an Action Referendum. 

ARTICLE IV. Composition 

A. The GSS consists of the elected senators from the departments or programs laid out in the 
Bylaws. Representation shall be proportional to the number of graduate students in each 
department or program. The proportion of senators to graduate students shall be 
determined by the Bylaws. 

B. The officers of GSS shall consist of the President, the Vice President and the Treasurer, 

who shall be elected according to the GSS Bylaws. The GSS officers shall perform such 
duties as are specified in the bylaws. An officer may be recalled according to the 
provisions set forth in the GSS Bylaws. 

C. The Executive Committee of the GSS shall consist of the President, the Vice President, the 

Treasurer, and two representatives elected from the Senate. 

D. The GSS shall also establish other standing and ad hoc committees in accordance with the 
Bylaws. The GSS shall require regular reports from the standing committees and special 
reports from its ad hoc committees. 

ARTICLE V. Senate Meeting 

A. The GSS shall hold at least one regular meeting each month while in session during the 

academic year. 

B. A special meeting may be called by: 

i.  the GSS President, at the request of any member of the graduate student body or 

any representative of the University Administration; 

ii.  twenty percent of the Senate by petition to the Executive Committee; 
iii. ten percent of fee paying graduate students, by petition to the Executive Committee. 

C. Agendas for regular meetings shall be developed by the President under the advice of the 
Executive Committee, and shall be made available to the membership twenty-four hours 
in advance of the meeting. 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 D. A quorum of the Senate for the purposes of a regular meeting shall consist of twenty-five 

percent of the Senators in good standing as defined in the Bylaws. 

ARTICLE VI. General Meetings of Graduate Students 

A. General Meetings of the Graduate Students may be called in one of the following ways: 
i.  The GSS President, at the request of any member of the graduate student body; 
ii.  The Senate may call a meeting by a motion duly passed; or 
iii. The Executive Committee, upon receiving a written petition signed by one hundred 

and fifty fee paying graduate students, shall call a general meeting within two 
weeks. 

B. A quorum of the graduate students for the purposes of a general meeting shall consist of ten 

percent of fee paying graduate students including Senators. 

C. Any action of the GSS may be overruled by a majority vote of those present and voting at a 
General Meeting of Graduate Students. Rules for voting at such a meeting shall be 
outlined in the Bylaws. 

D. Agendas for general meetings shall be developed by the President under the advice of the 
Executive Committee, and shall be made available to the membership twenty-four hours 
in advance of the meeting. Any matters mentioned in the petition shall appear on the 
provisional agenda for the meeting, as also shall any motion for recall of a Senate officer. 
The finalized agenda for each meeting shall include (a) those items mentioned in the 
provisional agenda and (b) further items added by petition of twenty graduate students 
received at least five days before the general meeting. 

ARTICLE VII. Amendment Procedures 

A. Amendment to this Constitution may be proposed: 

i.  By a three-fifths (3/5) vote of those present and voting at a Regular or Special 

Meeting of the GSS provided that the proposed change shall have been 
presented at a previous Regular or Special Meeting. The vote shall be by written 
ballot, unless the Senate rules otherwise by a two-thirds (2/3) majority; or 

ii.  By petition of ten percent or more graduate students provided that it contains at least 

five signatories drawn from each of the colleges or schools. 

B. Ratification of amendments to this Constitution shall be by the general graduate student 
members and shall be by a majority of those voting by written or electric ballot. Voting 
eligibility shall be as specified in the Bylaws. The ballot shall be prepared and distributed 
by the President, under the supervision of the Executive Committee, setting out the 
proposed amendment in full. Accompanying the written or electric ballot shall be excerpts 
from the Senate Minutes containing the debate by the Senate on the proposed 
amendment and the exact vote by which it carried. The ballot shall also include the date, 
providing for a voting period of at least 14 but not more than 21 days, by which time votes 
must be received by the GSS Office. Votes shall be counted by the Executive Committee. 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
   
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 C. Amendments to this Constitution shall be effective only after approval by the Board of 

Trustees. 

ARTICLE VIII. Bylaws Amendment Procedures 

The Bylaws of the GSS may be adopted, amended, or repealed in accordance with the 
Bylaws by a two-thirds (2/3) vote of those present and voting at a Regular or Special 
Senate Meeting of the GSS; or by a majority vote of the fee paying members present and 
voting at a General Meeting of Graduate Students. The procedures for such acts shall be 
specified in the Bylaws. 

ARTICLE IX. Ratification 

This Constitution shall be ratified upon approval of the Board of Trustees and shall be 
effective as of that date.
