outlined in the Bylaws. 

D. Agendas for general meetings shall be developed by the President under the advice of the 
Executive Committee, and shall be made available to the membership twenty-four hours 
in advance of the meeting. Any matters mentioned in the petition shall appear on the 
provisional agenda for the meeting, as also shall any motion for recall of a Senate officer. 
The finalized agenda for each meeting shall include (a) those items mentioned in the 
provisional agenda and (b) further items added by petition of twenty graduate students 
received at least five days before the general meeting. 

ARTICLE VII. Amendment Procedures 

A. Amendment to this Constitution may be proposed: 

i.  By a three-fifths (3/5) vote of those present and voting at a Regular or Special 

Meeting of the GSS provided that the proposed change shall have been 
presented at a previous Regular or Special Meeting. The vote shall be by written 
ballot, unless the Senate rules otherwise by a two-thirds (2/3) majority; or 

ii.  By petition of ten percent or more graduate students provided that it contains at least 

five signatories drawn from each of the colleges or schools. 

B. Ratification of amendments to this Constitution shall be by the general graduate student 
members and shall be by a majority of those voting by written or electric ballot. Voting 
eligibility shall be as specified in the Bylaws. The ballot shall be prepared and distributed 
by the President, under the supervision of the Executive Committee, setting out the 
proposed amendment in full. Accompanying the written or electric ballot shall be excerpts 
from the Senate Minutes containing the debate by the Senate on the proposed 
amendment and the exact vote by which it carried. The ballot shall also include the date, 
providing for a voting period of at least 14 but not more than 21 days, by which time votes 
must be received by the GSS Office. Votes shall be counted by the Executive Committee. 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
   
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 C. Amendments to this Constitution shall be effective only after approval by the Board of 

Trustees. 

ARTICLE VIII. Bylaws Amendment Procedures 

The Bylaws of the GSS may be adopted, amended, or repealed in accordance with the 
Bylaws by a two-thirds (2/3) vote of those present and voting at a Regular or Special 
Senate Meeting of the GSS; or by a majority vote of the fee paying members present and 
voting at a General Meeting of Graduate Students. The procedures for such acts shall be 
specified in the Bylaws. 

ARTICLE IX. Ratification 

This Constitution shall be ratified upon approval of the Board of Trustees and shall be 
effective as of that date.

DocsList.Name: CONSTITUTION 2020.docx
DocsList.Data:
Constitution of the History Club


Mission Statement:


The name of this Registered Student Organization (RSO) is the “History Club.” The History Club seeks to bring together history enthusiasts from across the campus and Five College community to pursue activities reflecting our common interest. The Club is also a location for History majors to network with their peers and professors. The History Club acknowledges its special relationship with the History Department at UMass, and seeks to more fully integrate students into the Department and encourage them to take advantage of all the opportunities there. It also prioritizes bringing its members to historically significant locations to help further understanding of history.


Article I. Member Rights and Responsibilities
1.   A member shall be defined as any person who has attended two or more History Club meetings (not including election meetings) and belongs to one of the Five Colleges.
Each member shall have the right:
2.   To propose an amendment to the Constitution
3.   To run for a position on the Executive Council
4.   To request to job shadow an Executive Council member
5.   To submit a formal complaint against another member for failing in their responsibilities or a different offense.
6.   To submit articles of impeachment to the Executive Council, initiating impeachment proceedings.
7.   To attend meetings without fear of harassment in any form.
8.   To vote in all club elections through an anonymous paper ballot.
9.   To be informed promptly of club activities.
10. To have the opportunity to sign up for club activities.
a.   In cases of activities that only allow for a limited number of participants, it is the responsibility of each member to register promptly to obtain a spot.
11. To be consulted on the direction of the club and club activities during the first meeting of every month.
Every member shall have the responsibility:
12. To treat everyone at a club meeting with respect.
13. To not harass any club member or other meeting attendee by any means including, but not limited to, verbal, physical, written, electronic, or sexual.
14. To adhere to all of the University of Massachusetts Amherst Code of Conduct rules and refrain from any form of harassment as defined by Article II, Clause B of the University of Massachusetts Amherst Code of Conduct.
15. To attend at least one meeting every semester if they wish to vote in club elections
16. To exercise good sportsmanship (e.g. not cheating, not harassing other members/teams)
during club activities.
17. To follow the History Club Constitution in its entirety at History Club events outside of regular meetings, such as the Haunted History Tour and field trips.


Article II. The Executive Council
1.   The executive powers and responsibilities shall be vested in an elected Executive
Council.
2.   The Executive Council will be composed of a President, a Vice-President, a Treasurer, a
Secretary, and a Public Relations Officer.
3.   Every member of the Executive Council must be a member of the History Club.
4.   If the President is unable to perform their duties, the line of temporary succession will be as follows: Vice-President, Treasurer, Secretary, Public Relations Officer


Article III. Executive Powers and Responsibilities
1.   The Executive Council shall have the following responsibilities and powers, making decisions by majority vote of the Executive Council.
a.   Every Council member shall have access to all club social media pages and email resources.
b.   The responsibility to follow up on requests, complaints, or concerns raised by members and non-members in a timely manner.
c.   The responsibility to assign a Council member to look after club resources such as board games or promotional materials.
d.   The responsibility to promote cooperation across the University of Massachusetts
Amherst and the Five College Consortium.
e.   The responsibility to organize weekly meetings. f.    The power to confer and/or revoke membership. g.   The power to determine food orders.
h.   The power to set the agenda.
i.    The power to select field trip time and destination. j.    The power to determine type of meeting.
k.   The power to eject a meeting attendee. l.    The power to select speakers.
m.  The power to select movies.
n.   The power to oversee amendments to the Constitution.
o.   The power to preside over appeals of expulsion.
p.   The power to direct how Club funds will be spent. q.   The power to oversee impeachment proceedings.
r.    The power to name members to shadow Executive Council positions.
2.   The President shall have the following responsibilities and powers.
a.   The responsibility to serve as main liaison between the Council members, members, and the History Department.
b.   The responsibility to keep the History Department updated on the activities and state of the club.
c.   The responsibility to ensure that all responsibilities are being carried out. d.   The responsibility to have SGA signatory responsibilities.
e.   The responsibility to complete SGA Event Planner Training.
f.    The responsibility to get the key to Herter 601 every Monday.
g.   The responsibility to get the History Department provided board games on Game
Nights.
h.   The power to delegate responsibilities.
i.    The power to preside over all meetings and set the agenda.
3.   The Vice-President shall have the following responsibilities and powers. a.   The responsibility to acquire equipment needed for club activities. b.   The responsibility to complete Travel Planner Training.
c.   The responsibility to be available to assist other Council members d.   The responsibility to serve as the main inter-college liaison.
e.   The power to declare a meeting over at the end of the weekly activity.
4.   The Treasurer shall have the following responsibilities and powers.
a.   The responsibility to sign for food deliveries and bring the receipt to the History
Department.
b.   The responsibility to take any and all dietary restrictions into account when ordering food.
c.   The responsibility to account for club expenses.
d.   The responsibility to coordinate fundraisers and events with the Public Relations
Officer.
e.   The responsibility to have SGA signatory responsibilities.
f.    The responsibility to complete SGA Travel Planner Training.
5.   The Secretary shall have the following responsibilities and powers. a.   The responsibility to compose the Trivia Night slideshow,
b.   The responsibility to take minutes of Executive Council meetings.
c.   The responsibility to communicate with club members and inform them of club activities.
d.   The power to run Trivia Night.
6.   The Public Relations Officer shall have the following responsibilities and powers. a.   The responsibility to coordinate fundraisers and events with the Treasurer.
b.   The responsibility to promote the club and its events to the general public and the
Five Colleges.
c.   The responsibility to compose the “Today in History” post everyday for the club’s
Facebook Page.
d.   The responsibility to take pictures of club events. e.   The responsibility to design promotional posters.
f.    The responsibility to be familiar with History Department. printing procedures. g.   The power to run the Facebook Page.


Article IV. Election and Voting Procedures
1.   Elections will take place no later than 6th to last meeting of the History Club in the
Spring Semester.
2.   In the event of a position becoming vacant, the Executive Council must organize a special election to fill that position within four weeks of the vacancy occurring. If a vacancy occurs outside of the Fall or Spring Semester, the Executive Council must organize a special election within four weeks of the beginning of the next semester, be it Fall or Spring. Members must be given at least two weeks notice of this special election.
3.   All persons wishing to run for an Executive Council position must submit their candidacy in writing or electronically to the Secretary at least one week before the election. Write-in candidates will not be considered.
4.   The President will preside over election proceedings, allowing each candidate ten minutes to give a speech to the Club and distributing and then collecting anonymous paper ballots. The President may designate others to help with ballot distribution and collection. In cases where the President is one of the parties the vote concerns, the Vice-President will assume the President’s duties regarding election proceedings.
5.   Anonymous paper ballots will be tallied by the Secretary and then re-counted by the Vice-President. In cases where the Secretary or the Vice-President is one of the parties the election concerns, the Treasurer will assume the duties of whichever officer is involved in the election as a candidate.
6.   If there is disagreement between the Secretary and Vice-President on the correct vote tally, members will anonymously submit their votes again according to the same process and the Secretary and Vice-President will tally the votes again, this time supervised by the President who will work to mediate and resolve any further disagreement or confusion.
7.   The result of the vote will be announced by the officers who tallied it.
8.   In cases where a member is running for a position unopposed, the President or presiding officer may call for a vote by acclamation rather than an anonymous paper tally.
9.   Newly elected members will assume their positions the following semester, be it Spring or Fall. In cases of special elections they will assume their positions immediately.


Article V. Impeachment
1.   Plausible causes for impeachment of an Officer
a.   Violation of the rights of another member
b.   Failure to carry one or more of their responsibilities
c.   Violation of University of Massachusetts Amherst Student Code of Conduct
2.   The Executive Council must hold impeachment proceedings within two meetings of receiving Articles of Impeachment.
3.   The President shall preside over impeachment proceedings. If the President is the subject of the impeachment proceedings, then the Vice-President will preside over impeachment proceedings.
4.   Impeachment proceedings will take place during a Club meeting with the officer who is the subject of the proceedings and the members who submitted Articles of Impeachment present, as well as any other members who wish to vote on impeachment.
5.   The presiding officer will provide ample time for the submitting members and the officer who is the subject of the proceedings to present arguments and evidence.
6.   When all parties have presented evidence to the satisfaction of the presiding officer, the presiding officer will call for a vote. All members of the Club who are present will vote on a secret ballot that will then be counted by the presiding officer.
7.   If a majority of those present vote for impeachment, the officer in question will immediately leave their position.


Article VI. Expulsion and Appeal
1.   The Executive Council may at any time, by majority vote, expel a member from the club and prohibit them from attending meetings.
2.   An expelled member must be told the reasons for their expulsion. Reasons for expulsion
are:
a.   Violation of the rights of another member
b.   Failure to carry one or more of their responsibilities
c.   Violation of University of Massachusetts Amherst Student Code of Conduct
3.   The Executive Council has the right to lift an expulsion at any time by a majority vote.
4.   An expulsion may be appealed.
5.   An expelled member may submit a request for an appeal of their expulsion in writing to an Executive Council member.
6.   The Executive Council must organize an appeal, to take place within three meetings of receiving the request. The appeal will take place during a History Club meeting.
7.   The appeal will be presided over by a party agreed upon by the Executive Council and the member appealing their expulsion. This party can be a member of the Executive Council, another member of the History Club, an employee of one of the Five Colleges, or any other member of the Five College community.
8.   During the appeal the presiding member will allow ample time for the Executive Council and the appealing member to submit arguments and evidence for the expulsion.
9.   After arguments and evidence has been presented, the presiding member will collect anonymous paper ballots from all members present and tally them. Members will write “Approve” to grant the appeal or “Deny” to reject the appeal.
10. If the appeal is granted, the appealing member’s membership is reinstated. They cannot be expelled again by the Executive Council unless it is for a separate incident or violation.


Article VII. Amendments
1.   Any member can submit a proposed amendment to the History Club Constitution the
Executive Council at any time.
2.   The Executive Council must organize a vote on the proposed amendment within two meetings of receiving the proposal.
3.   The vote shall take place during a History Club meeting.
4.   The Executive Council shall preside over the amendment proceedings.
5.   Up to two proponents and two opponents of the amendment shall each receive ten minutes to speak in support of their position.
6.   After speeches are concluded all present club members shall vote by anonymous paper ballot.
7.   Anonymous paper ballots will be tallied by the Secretary and then re-counted by the
Vice-President.
8.   If there is disagreement between the Secretary and Vice-President on the correct vote tally, members will anonymously submit their votes again according to the same process and the Secretary and Vice-President will tally the votes again, this time supervised by the President who will work to mediate and resolve any further disagreement or confusion.
9.   The result of the vote will be announced by the officers who tallied it.
10. If a majority of the club members present vote to adopt the amendment, the Executive
Council will begin proceedings with the SGA to add it to the History Club Constitution.

m.  The power to select movies.
n.   The power to oversee amendments to the Constitution.
o.   The power to preside over appeals of expulsion.
p.   The power to direct how Club funds will be spent. q.   The power to oversee impeachment proceedings.
r.    The power to name members to shadow Executive Council positions.
2.   The President shall have the following responsibilities and powers.
a.   The responsibility to serve as main liaison between the Council members, members, and the History Department.
b.   The responsibility to keep the History Department updated on the activities and state of the club.
c.   The responsibility to ensure that all responsibilities are being carried out. d.   The responsibility to have SGA signatory responsibilities.
e.   The responsibility to complete SGA Event Planner Training.
f.    The responsibility to get the key to Herter 601 every Monday.
g.   The responsibility to get the History Department provided board games on Game
Nights.
h.   The power to delegate responsibilities.
i.    The power to preside over all meetings and set the agenda.
3.   The Vice-President shall have the following responsibilities and powers. a.   The responsibility to acquire equipment needed for club activities. b.   The responsibility to complete Travel Planner Training.
c.   The responsibility to be available to assist other Council members d.   The responsibility to serve as the main inter-college liaison.
e.   The power to declare a meeting over at the end of the weekly activity.
4.   The Treasurer shall have the following responsibilities and powers.
a.   The responsibility to sign for food deliveries and bring the receipt to the History
Department.
b.   The responsibility to take any and all dietary restrictions into account when ordering food.
c.   The responsibility to account for club expenses.
d.   The responsibility to coordinate fundraisers and events with the Public Relations
Officer.
e.   The responsibility to have SGA signatory responsibilities.
f.    The responsibility to complete SGA Travel Planner Training.
5.   The Secretary shall have the following responsibilities and powers. a.   The responsibility to compose the Trivia Night slideshow,
b.   The responsibility to take minutes of Executive Council meetings.
c.   The responsibility to communicate with club members and inform them of club activities.
d.   The power to run Trivia Night.
6.   The Public Relations Officer shall have the following responsibilities and powers. a.   The responsibility to coordinate fundraisers and events with the Treasurer.
b.   The responsibility to promote the club and its events to the general public and the
Five Colleges.
c.   The responsibility to compose the “Today in History” post everyday for the club’s
Facebook Page.
d.   The responsibility to take pictures of club events. e.   The responsibility to design promotional posters.
f.    The responsibility to be familiar with History Department. printing procedures. g.   The power to run the Facebook Page.


Article IV. Election and Voting Procedures
1.   Elections will take place no later than 6th to last meeting of the History Club in the
Spring Semester.
2.   In the event of a position becoming vacant, the Executive Council must organize a special election to fill that position within four weeks of the vacancy occurring. If a vacancy occurs outside of the Fall or Spring Semester, the Executive Council must organize a special election within four weeks of the beginning of the next semester, be it Fall or Spring. Members must be given at least two weeks notice of this special election.
3.   All persons wishing to run for an Executive Council position must submit their candidacy in writing or electronically to the Secretary at least one week before the election. Write-in candidates will not be considered.
4.   The President will preside over election proceedings, allowing each candidate ten minutes to give a speech to the Club and distributing and then collecting anonymous paper ballots. The President may designate others to help with ballot distribution and collection. In cases where the President is one of the parties the vote concerns, the Vice-President will assume the President’s duties regarding election proceedings.
5.   Anonymous paper ballots will be tallied by the Secretary and then re-counted by the Vice-President. In cases where the Secretary or the Vice-President is one of the parties the election concerns, the Treasurer will assume the duties of whichever officer is involved in the election as a candidate.
6.   If there is disagreement between the Secretary and Vice-President on the correct vote tally, members will anonymously submit their votes again according to the same process and the Secretary and Vice-President will tally the votes again, this time supervised by the President who will work to mediate and resolve any further disagreement or confusion.
7.   The result of the vote will be announced by the officers who tallied it.
8.   In cases where a member is running for a position unopposed, the President or presiding officer may call for a vote by acclamation rather than an anonymous paper tally.
9.   Newly elected members will assume their positions the following semester, be it Spring or Fall. In cases of special elections they will assume their positions immediately.


Article V. Impeachment
1.   Plausible causes for impeachment of an Officer
a.   Violation of the rights of another member
b.   Failure to carry one or more of their responsibilities
c.   Violation of University of Massachusetts Amherst Student Code of Conduct
2.   The Executive Council must hold impeachment proceedings within two meetings of receiving Articles of Impeachment.
3.   The President shall preside over impeachment proceedings. If the President is the subject of the impeachment proceedings, then the Vice-President will preside over impeachment proceedings.
4.   Impeachment proceedings will take place during a Club meeting with the officer who is the subject of the proceedings and the members who submitted Articles of Impeachment present, as well as any other members who wish to vote on impeachment.
5.   The presiding officer will provide ample time for the submitting members and the officer who is the subject of the proceedings to present arguments and evidence.
6.   When all parties have presented evidence to the satisfaction of the presiding officer, the presiding officer will call for a vote. All members of the Club who are present will vote on a secret ballot that will then be counted by the presiding officer.
7.   If a majority of those present vote for impeachment, the officer in question will immediately leave their position.


Article VI. Expulsion and Appeal
1.   The Executive Council may at any time, by majority vote, expel a member from the club and prohibit them from attending meetings.
2.   An expelled member must be told the reasons for their expulsion. Reasons for expulsion
are:
a.   Violation of the rights of another member
b.   Failure to carry one or more of their responsibilities
c.   Violation of University of Massachusetts Amherst Student Code of Conduct
3.   The Executive Council has the right to lift an expulsion at any time by a majority vote.
4.   An expulsion may be appealed.
5.   An expelled member may submit a request for an appeal of their expulsion in writing to an Executive Council member.
6.   The Executive Council must organize an appeal, to take place within three meetings of receiving the request. The appeal will take place during a History Club meeting.
7.   The appeal will be presided over by a party agreed upon by the Executive Council and the member appealing their expulsion. This party can be a member of the Executive Council, another member of the History Club, an employee of one of the Five Colleges, or any other member of the Five College community.
8.   During the appeal the presiding member will allow ample time for the Executive Council and the appealing member to submit arguments and evidence for the expulsion.
9.   After arguments and evidence has been presented, the presiding member will collect anonymous paper ballots from all members present and tally them. Members will write “Approve” to grant the appeal or “Deny” to reject the appeal.
10. If the appeal is granted, the appealing member’s membership is reinstated. They cannot be expelled again by the Executive Council unless it is for a separate incident or violation.


Article VII. Amendments
1.   Any member can submit a proposed amendment to the History Club Constitution the
Executive Council at any time.
2.   The Executive Council must organize a vote on the proposed amendment within two meetings of receiving the proposal.
3.   The vote shall take place during a History Club meeting.
4.   The Executive Council shall preside over the amendment proceedings.
5.   Up to two proponents and two opponents of the amendment shall each receive ten minutes to speak in support of their position.
6.   After speeches are concluded all present club members shall vote by anonymous paper ballot.
7.   Anonymous paper ballots will be tallied by the Secretary and then re-counted by the
Vice-President.
8.   If there is disagreement between the Secretary and Vice-President on the correct vote tally, members will anonymously submit their votes again according to the same process and the Secretary and Vice-President will tally the votes again, this time supervised by the President who will work to mediate and resolve any further disagreement or confusion.
9.   The result of the vote will be announced by the officers who tallied it.
10. If a majority of the club members present vote to adopt the amendment, the Executive
Council will begin proceedings with the SGA to add it to the History Club Constitution.

Name: Humanities and Fine Arts Student Leadership Board

DocsList.Name: HFA SLG Constitution as of Fall 2023.docx
DocsList.Data:
Humanities & Fine Arts Student Leadership Group Constitution
Updated Fall 2023

Mission Statement
We hope to be a collective voice as well as a resource for all undergraduate students at the University of Massachusetts Amherst, particularly for students of the College of Humanities & Fine Arts. 
We sponsor events that bring students together and celebrate the Humanities and Fine Arts outside the classroom. We hope to engage students not enrolled in the College of HFA and include the whole campus in our promotion of the Humanities and Fine Arts.
We believe that all undergraduate students at the University of Massachusetts Amherst deserve a voice and the ability to be heard. We believe that a student organization is the best way to prioritize student voices. 

Process for Establishing Voting Membership
To obtain voting membership, one must be an undergraduate student at UMass Amherst, but not necessarily in the College of Humanities & Fine Arts.
UMass faculty, graduate students, alumni, and members of the Five College community are welcome to attend our meetings but cannot vote or hold an official position. Anyone is more than welcome to attend our events.

Procedures for Conducting Meetings and Planning Activities
Meetings will be held once weekly on Tuesday evenings from 8-9pm. 
At each meeting, no less than 50% of the meeting time will be spent in committees, with the exception of any Celebrations, voting meetings, or other predetermined extenuating circumstances. The Special Events Committee will use their meeting time to plan the next week’s meeting.
At the beginning of each semester, the Executive Board will meet with the Advisor to determine a general schedule for the semester’s meetings. At the end of each semester, the Executive Board will meet with the Advisor to reflect on the general success of the semester and begin planning for the upcoming semester. Meetings between the Board and the Advisor will last no longer than two hours.
The first and last meetings of each semester will be Celebrations rather than standard meetings. Additionally, at least one but no more than two meetings midway through the semester will be Celebrations, as planned by the Special Events Committee. Celebrations will not have time for committee work.
The President or Special Events Committee Chair will open each meeting with announcements.
The Executive Board will meet after each General Body meeting to discuss future plans and ensure all Board members are caught up with each other. These Executive Board meetings will last no longer than a half hour after the conclusion of the General Body meeting.

Governance 
The Executive Board will be composed of a President, a Special Events Committee Chair, an Editor-in-Chief of The Scribe, two Showcase Committee Co-Chairs, and two Field Trip Committee Co-Chairs.
The President presides over both Executive Board and General Body meetings. All other members of the Executive Board have equal governing power.
The President and at least one other member of the Executive Board will have Signature Responsibility, as determined during the end-of-spring-semester Executive Board meeting. The decision to have Signature Responsibility is voluntary for all Board members other than the President. If no member volunteers, the Special Events Committee Chair will have Signature Responsibility.
All Board members serve one-year terms. Board members are permitted to run for their office again provided they anticipate being able to serve the full term.

Officer Duties and Responsibilities
The President will supervise and run all General Body and Executive Board meetings, including sending weekly emails to the General Body reminding them about meetings, checking in on committees throughout meetings, keeping track of time, and creating agendas for Executive Board meetings. 
The Special Events Committee Chair will chair the Special Events Committee, including managing agendas for General Body meetings, planning and executing Celebrations, and coordinating games for the end of each General Body meeting.
The Editor-in-Chief of The Scribe will oversee and facilitate the production of Fall and Spring editions of The Scribe, including planning weekly meeting agendas, delegating tasks to members, creating a semester schedule including submission deadlines, voting deadlines, and drop dates, and uploading and designing the respective editions before publication. 
The Showcase Committee Co-Chairs will oversee and facilitate the organization and execution of the annual showcase in the spring semester. This includes sending weekly updates to the showcase committee members as to what the committee is currently working on, delegating tasks to committee members, creating an annual schedule and submission deadlines, voting on award winners, organizing and executing all sectors of the showcase, setting up/running/cleaning up the showcase, and reflecting on what the committee can do better in the future.  
The Field Trip Committee Co-Chairs will share responsibilities in chairing the Field Trip Committee, including planning weekly meeting topics, coordinating field trip location (both city and museum), planning tabling and additional advertising for the field trip, and planning the logistics of the field trip including busing, contact persons, and any other pertinent details.

Process for Elections, Nominations, and Voting by Membership
In the case of an election, any active member may run for an Executive Board Position.
Elections for one of the Showcase Committee Co-Chairs and one of the Field Trip Committee Co-Chairs take place at the end of fall semester. Elections for all other positions take place in March. In extraordinary circumstances, elections may take place at other times, but they must take place before April 1. 
Upcoming elections will be announced verbally in preceding General Body meetings as well as by email and social media announcements. Members must declare their intent to run before the election officially begins. A final call for candidates will be made just before each election.
Elections will take place during a standard General Body meeting where a quorum of the active members are in attendance. Quorum is defined as half of the General Body membership plus one member. Each candidate will give a 30-60 second oral presentation on why they should be elected to the Position. The Special Events Committee Chair will take all candidates out of the room.
Active members may then vote anonymously. The candidate with the most votes will be elected to the Position.
In the event of a tie, the Showcase Committee Co-Chairs, Field Trip Committee Co-Chairs, and Editor-in-Chief of The Scribe will send their votes to the President. The candidate with the most Board votes will be elected to the Position.
This process will occur as needed when previously-elected Board members go abroad, fill their term as defined in Article IV, or become otherwise unable to continue serving in their Position.
The President will be responsible for maintaining a record of candidates and the results of each election. These records must be located somewhere easily accessible by all Board members.

Process for Removal of an Executive Board Member
If the Executive Board determines that a Board member is in violation of this constitution or performing sub-optimally in their work or conduct, they must notify the Board member in question.
Such determinations may arise from a concern or complaint noted by a General Body or Executive Board member. Any concern or complaint must be directed to the Executive Board or a member thereof.
Once a Board member has been notified and has not sufficiently improved, their removal will be put to vote before the General Body. They will have an opportunity to address the membership and explain their case before the vote. If two-thirds of members vote to remove them, they shall be stripped of their office.
If a Board member is removed, a special election will be planned and announced to fill the vacancy in the Board.

Process for Removal of a General Body Member
If a General Body member is found to be in violation of this constitution or otherwise performing sub-optimally in work or conduct, an Executive Board member will notify the member in question.
Once a member has been notified and has not sufficiently improved, their removal will be put to vote before the General Body. They will have an opportunity to address the membership and explain their case before the vote. If two-thirds of members vote to remove them, they shall be stripped of their membership.

Procedure for Dissolving Disputes among Members
1.   In the case of a dispute among members, the opposing sides will present their views to the members of the Board. The Board will consider the disagreement, discuss any alternate solutions, and then vote. Whichever solution gets the most votes will be the path the organization will take.

Statement of Free Speech / Expression
Under no circumstances shall a member’s freedom of speech or expression be infringed.

Statement of Non-Discrimination
1.   The Humanities and Fine Arts Student Leadership Group prohibits discrimination under Federal and State law, based on race, color, national origin, religion, sex, gender identity including gender expression, sexual orientation, disability, age, marital status, family/parental status, income derived from a public assistance program, veteran status, citizenship, genetic information, political beliefs, major, academic interest, or reprisal or retaliation for prior civil rights activity. We will be open and accepting to anyone who is willing to help our organization.

Amendments and Ratification
Amendments to this Constitution may be proposed at any time. Amendments must be proposed by an active member. Amendments will be accepted by a majority vote of active members.
Ratification of this Constitution will be approved with the majority of the Board’s votes and approval of the Undergraduate Registry Oversight Committee.

CONSTITUTION

Interfraternity Council of the University of Massachusetts at Amherst

PREAMBLE

We, the undergraduate members of the Interfraternity Council of the University of Massachusetts at Amherst, set forth this Constitution and By-Laws in order to promote and encourage the personal development of all the member Fraternities- intellectually, morally, physically, and socially- and to foster closer friendships, set standards, and develop a stronger sense of community among the member Fraternities and the University.

ARTICLE I – NAME

This organization shall be known as the Interfraternity Council (IFC) of the University of Massachusetts at Amherst

ARTICLE II – PURPOSE

The purpose of this organization shall be to:

Foster the growth morally and socially.
Promote favorable interaction between the Fraternities and Sororities, the University, and the University Community at-large.
Encourage the implementation of our Ideals: brotherhood, personal character, and scholarship.
Act as the voice of the Fraternities regarding policy and public relations.

ARTICLE III – MEMBERSHIP

Section I.	Membership in the IFC shall be composed of all colonized and chartered Fraternities, which are recognized as student organizations by the University of Massachusetts at Amherst.

Section II.	Each member Fraternity shall be represented by two (2) voting members:

An IFC Representative, selected by the member Fraternity.
The Chapter President.
Or a duly designated representative in the absence of the President or the representative.
The individuals cannot be an officer on the IFC.

Section III.	Each Fraternity shall be entitled to two (2) votes, one (1) to be cast by the Chapter President and one (1) by the Representative.

a.	The Chapter President and the Representative, or their stand-in, must be present to vote.
b.	Under no circumstance shall the President or the Representative cast the other's vote, nor vote twice.

Section IV.	Each Fraternity is responsible for a proportionate share of all financial burdens assumed by the IFC. Dues are accessed at eight dollars and zero cents ($8.00) per member. A maximum of 50 members being accounted for in the assessment, such that the maximum amount a chapter or colony will be responsible for is four hundred dollars and zero cents ($400.00). 

Section V.	Any IFC member may request a reassessment of dues allocation by filing a written complaint with the Vice-President of Finance. The process for review shall be outlined accordingly:

a.	A written petition must be signed by three-fourths (3/4) of a recognized Chapter's membership.
b.	Upon receipt of written complaint, and within fifteen (15) calendar days, the Executive Officers shall investigate the complaint in a manner prescribed by a majority vote of its membership in attendance at a scheduled meeting.
c.	Within fifteen (15) calendar days of its investigation, upon a majority vote of its membership in attendance at a scheduled meeting, the Executive Officers will report to the IFC Membership as to their recommendation.
d.	If the Executive Officers shall have recommended to change the monetary amount of the dues, a motion will be brought before the IFC membership at the next regularly scheduled IFC meeting and would require two-thirds (2/3) vote of the IFC membership in attendance for the change to take effect.

Section VI.	Dues must be paid by the third official IFC meeting or within three (3) weeks of receipt of the bill from the Vice-President of Finance. The Vice-President of Finance is empowered to set fines or establish an adequate policy for delinquent bills.

ARTICLE IV – EXECUTIVE OFFICERS

Section I.	The officers of the Council shall be: President, Vice-President of Communications, Vice-President of Finance, Vice-President of Recruitment, and Vice- President of Activities, Vice-President of Community Service, and Vice-President of Standards.

Section II.	All officers shall serve for a one (1) year term as non-voting members and shall not serve as representatives from their respective Fraternities.

ARTICLE V – MEETINGS

Section I.	Business meetings of the Council shall take place every week.

Section II.	Special meetings may be called by the President of the Council at any time, and must be called by the President at the request of any two (2) member Fraternities with a notice of no less than twenty-four (24) hours.

Section III.	Notification of regularly scheduled meetings shall be done at the beginning of the current semester utilizing communication addressed to the president of each member fraternity.

Section IV.	Notification of special meetings shall be done in writing and hand-delivered to the highest ranking officer of the member fraternity who can be located.

ARTICLE VI – AMENDMENTS

Section I.	The IFC alone shall have the power to amend the Constitution and Bylaws. The IFC shall institute, administrate, and execute the goals and ideals of the Fraternity system.

Section II.	This Constitution and Bylaws may be amended by a two-thirds (2/3) vote of representatives of the member Fraternities. The amendment must be submitted in writing to the Council and to the Presidents of the member Fraternities at least two weeks prior to the business meeting at which the vote is taken.






























BYLAWS

Interfraternity Council of the University of Massachusetts at Amherst

ARTICLE I – QUORUM

Section I.	Quorum shall be defined as two-thirds (2/3) of the voting membership in attendance.

ARTICLE II – PLACE OF MEETING

Section I.	The council President will designate the meeting location

ARTICLE III – DUTIES OF THE MEMBER FRATERNITIES

Section I.	It shall be the duty of the member Fraternities to uphold and abide by the Constitution, Bylaws, and rules and regulations of the Council.

Section II.	It shall be the duty of the member Fraternities to have two (2) representatives present at every regular and every special meeting of the Council.

ARTICLE IV – RULES OF ORDER

Section I.	Robert’s Rules of Order shall be used to run all business meetings.

ARTICLE V – MEMBER FRATERNITY POLICIES

Section I.	Each member Fraternity will support open expansion by NIC Fraternities onto the University of Massachusetts at Amherst campus.

Section II.	Admission into the IFC shall require a written petition to be submitted to the IFC Executive Board for review. After a two week period, the Petitioner shall offer a presentation to the IFC membership. Following the presentation, a closed hearing shall ensue. A vote on the candidate’s suitability will be taken after the hearing. Should a motion to table pass, the period for further review shall not be less than two (2) weeks, not exceed three (3) weeks. A previously tabled petition for membership may not again be tabled.

Section III.	The criteria for Chapter admission shall be defined accordingly:

a.	A two-thirds (2/3) majority vote of the IFC membership in attendance at a regularly scheduled meeting.
b.	The colony must be officially recognized as a Chapter in good standing with their respective National organization. In the case of Local Fraternities, the period of colony status shall be not less than three (3) years.
c.	After two (2) years of colony status in a nationally recognized Fraternity, a petition may be initiated and presented to the IFC Executive Board for recognition as a Chapter.
Section IV.	Each member Fraternity’s associate/new member program shall last no longer than twelve weeks.

Section V.	Each member Fraternity will not have a women’s auxiliary group, such as “little sisters.”

Section VI.	Each member Fraternity will have risk management policies that address alcohol use, fire safety, hazing, and sexual assault/abuse.

Section VII.	Each member Fraternity will be alcohol free at all recruitment activities including formal, informal and summer break recruitment activities.

Section VIII.	Each member Fraternity will have alcohol free associate/new member program.

Section IX.	Each member Fraternity must abide by the rules and regulations set forth by IFC as pertains to recruitment.

ARTICLE VI – EXECUTIVE BOARD

Section I.	The Executive Board shall consist of the Executive officers of the IFC, as defined in Article IV, Section I of the Constitution.

Section II.	The Executive Board shall have, but it is not limited to, the following powers:

a.	To state the IFC policy position on any question.
b.	To serve as the Fraternity consulting body on relevant Greek issues.
c.	To advise the University Administration on matters pertaining to the Fraternity system.
d.	To initiate policy and procedure.
e.	To regulate all IFC elections and/or referenda.
f.	To act for the IFC if it is unable to meet or if quorum cannot be attained.
g.	To undertake any act deemed necessary and proper to enable the execution of the powers vested by this Constitution.
h.  	To sanction member Fraternities that break the rules and regulations of recruitment to the degree stated by the recruitment document.




Section III.	Any action taken by the Executive Board can be rescinded by a majority vote of the IFC membership in attendance at a regularly scheduled meeting.

Section IV.	The IFC shall monitor the submission, documentation, and the administration of all IFC papers by the Office of Fraternities and Sororities. These papers are to be made public for inspection by recognized IFC members at all times. These papers shall be required to be kept in good order and shall be filed in a conspicuous place.

Section V.	The rules and procedures outlined in this Constitution and Bylaws shall take precedence over all other governing documents of the Inter-Fraternity Council.

Section VI.	No member of a Colony Chapter recognized by the IFC shall be permitted to run for an IFC Executive Officer position.

Section VII.	No member of a Fraternity recognized by the IFC may run or hold an Executive Office position without a minimum cumulative grade point average of at least a 2.75.

Section VIII.	To be eligible for the IFC Executive Board, a member must be a Sophomore and have served one full semester as an active brother within their chapter.

Section IX.	The Executive Board will meet once (1) every week for the duration of the fall and spring semesters.

Section X. 	The IFC Executive Board will set forth a document stating the rules and regulations of recruitment twice (2) annually. The document is valid only after a majority favorable vote by member fraternities.


ARTICLE VII - ELECTIONS

Section I.	A two-thirds (2/3) majority of the general membership, as defined by Article I, Section I of these Bylaws, is needed for quorum. A quorum of the member Fraternities shall be present for elections to take place.

Section II.	Nominations for IFC Officers shall be two (2) meetings prior to the elections

Section III.	Elections shall be conducted as follows:

At the election meeting, the candidates are escorted out of the room. Two questions are then determined by the IFC. The questions apply to all candidates for said position and must be asked in the same order after each candidate’s speech.
Each candidate then presents a speech, no longer than five (5) minutes in duration.
c.	After each candidate’s speech, the candidate will leave the room and the floor will be open for discussion. There will be two (2) pros and two (2) cons for each candidate.
d.	After all candidates have gone, they will remain outside the room and the IFC Presidents and Representatives (equaling two votes per house) shall vote by means of secret ballot.
e.	The IFC Officers shall be elected by a majority vote. In the case of more than two (2) candidates running for the same position, the candidate with the lower number of votes will be eliminated. The election proceedings will be continued until one (1) of the candidates receives a majority vote.

Section IV.	Should a vacancy occur during the natural term of the Executive Board, an announcement shall be made at the next regularly scheduled meeting, and a call for nominations will be issued. At the next meeting, elections shall be conducted for said office, as prescribed in Article VII, Section 3 of these Bylaws.

Section V.	Officers may be impeached by a three-fourths (3/4) vote of the IFC membership. The Officer in question must be notified in writing two (2) weeks prior to any such action being voted upon.

ARTICLE VIII – ATTENDANCE

Section I.	Attendance by two (2) Representatives of each Fraternity at all IFC and Fraternity/Sorority Leadership meetings shall be mandatory.


Section II.	An excused absence will only be permitted if an excuse is presented to the President and/or the Vice-President of Communications at least twelve (12) hours prior to the meeting.

Section III.	In the event of an excused absence, a chapter will be permitted to send a duly designated representative, who shall have voting privileges as defined by Article II, Sections 2 & 3 of the Constitution.

Section IV.	Absences may be excused for any one (1) of the reasons prescribed herein:

1.	Personal Illness
2.	Family Obligation
3.	Exam or other scholastic commitment scheduled during meeting time
4.	Religious Observance

Section V.	Upon accumulation of three (3) unexcused absences by a chapter during the semester, the IFC shall administer a $50.00 fine to be levied by the Vice President of Finances.

Section VI.	Any appeal of this fine shall only be in order during the new business period of the meeting immediately following the levying of the fine.

ARTICLE IX – HAZING POLICY

Section I.	Every member fraternity must have an anti-hazing policy statement on file at the IFC Office and the Office of Fraternities and Sororities, and must state the support of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts’ position against hazing. The IFC and its members support will enforce adherence to the dry rush policies that all National and Local Organizations have developed.

DocsList.Data:
Isenberg Marketing Club Mission Statement
Fall 2024
The mission of Isenberg Marketing Club is to provide students interested in the marketing field with
hands-on and resume worthy experiences. Our club is separated into three committees that members can
join (Fundraising, Public Relations, and Community Service) and an executive board in order to find
opportunities for our members to gain marketing experience. Each February we host a networking event
(Marketing Career Networking Night), intended to provide marketing majors and those interested in
marketing with opportunities for jobs, internships, and co-ops. We host weekly meetings that will offer
marketing-focused students the skills they need to develop a career in the marketing world.

Club Philosophy
The Isenberg Marketing Club fosters a safe environment for students to learn and engage in
marketing-related and career preparation activities, such as networking events, marketing workshops, and
participation in specialized committees (Fundraising, Public Relations, and Community Service).
Participation in the Isenberg Marketing Club prepares students to enter the workforce through developing
both technical and soft skills relevant to the modern business world.

Article I - Membership
All students at the University of Massachusetts Amherst and the 5 College Area shall be eligible to be
members of the Isenberg Marketing Club.
Membership shall be established after a prospective member attends one meeting and informs the
Secretary that they wish to be a member, by requesting to be added to the mailing list.
In order to be an active member, each registered member must attend a minimum of 50% of the scheduled
meetings for that semester.
Each semester, it is up to the discretion of the Co-Presidents and Treasurer to determine if they will
collect dues of $5.

Article II - Meetings
The Isenberg Marketing Club shall have general body meetings on a weekly basis.
Committee Meetings shall be held twice a semester and will replace a general body meeting.
General Body Meetings shall be chaired by the Presidents. The agenda of each General Body Meeting
shall be determined ahead of time by the Presidents. Decisions and suggestions for upcoming meetings
shall be made by the Eboard and general body one week before the scheduled General Body Meeting.
Committee Meetings shall be chaired by their appropriate committee heads.
The purpose of the meetings shall be:

● To develop marketing skills
● Update members about opportunities the club is offering

 ● Meet with recruiters and guest speakers from the marketing world
● Any other topics deemed necessary

During meetings, agenda items are openly discussed and finalized with a majority vote (⅔ of General
Body in attendance). Decisions are documented by the Secretary and shared with active members in a
timely manner.

Article III - The Executive Board
Co-Presidents terms shall last no longer than 2 semesters
Should a Co-President wish to stay on longer than 2 semesters, they can petition to the Eboard and with a
⅔ majority vote to stay, may be reinstated.

Committee Co-Chairs, Vice President, Treasurer, and Secretary are able to maintain their positions if they
wish to do so. After 2 semesters in a role, ⅔ majority of the Eboard must vote to re-elect members in
order for them to remain in the same role for future semesters.
Should one of the above officers choose to not return to their position, the Co-Presidents may hold a
selection for that position prior to the start of the next semester

The executive board of The Isenberg Marketing Club shall be made up of the following positions:
Co-Presidents, Vice President, Treasurer, Secretary, Public Relations Committee Co-Chairs (2-3),
Community Service Committee Co-Chairs (2-3), Fundraising Committee Co-Chairs (2-3), DEIA+
Co-Chairs (2-3)

The Co-Presidents reserve the right to create new EBoard positions as they see fit. If a new position is
created, the position parameters shall be defined by the Co-Presidents and submitted as an Amendment to
the Constitution.

Article IV - Duties of The Executive Board Officers

1. The Co-Presidents

● The Co-Presidents shall share Co-President Responsibilities.
● One of the Co-Presidents of IMC shall possess signature responsibility for the

organization.

● The Co-Presidents, along with the Treasurer, must approve all financial expenditures of

the organization.

● The Co-Presidents shall serve as the chairs and facilitate general body and Eboard

meetings.

● The Co-Presidents are to speak on behalf of the general body but will not make policy

decisions for the organization on his/her own.

● The Co-Presidents shall be ex-official members of the general body.
● The Co-Presidents have the right to delegate tasks and oversee projects.
● The Co-Presidents will oversee all committee chairs.
● The Co-Presidents will act as a liaison between IMC and the Marketing

Department/Isenberg.

 ● The Co-Presidents will make sure someone attends all “Club Leaders Meetings” for

Isenberg and RSO meetings.

● The Co-Presidents shall send reminders of Eboard meeting times to the members of the

Eboard.

2. The Vice President*

● The Vice President shall assist in the duties and responsibilities of the Co-Presidents.
● The Vice President shall assume the duties and powers of one of the Co-Presidents in

his/her absence.

● The Vice President shall be eligible for Signature Responsibility.
● The Vice President shall form and manage the Constitution Review Meeting

○ The Constitution Review Meeting shall review and confirm the Constitution of

IMC and make any changes as the Eboard sees fit.

○ This meeting shall take place during the first EBoard meeting of the fall semester.
○ The Constitution Review Meeting shall answer any questions that arise

pertaining to the Constitution.

3. The Treasurer

● The Treasurer shall be the Chief Financial Officer of the RSO.
● The Treasurer shall be responsible for maintaining the group’s finances.
● The Treasurer shall be responsible for submitting an annual budget request to the SGA, if

necessary.

● The Treasurer is eligible for Signature Responsibility if the Vice President does not take

Signature Responsibility.

4. The Secretary*

● The Secretary shall maintain up to date membership lists via the Google Groups email

list.

● The Secretary will draft and publish weekly club emails to IMC members.

5. Public Relations Committee Co-Chairs (2-3)

● The two-three Public Relations Committee Co-Chairs shall share responsibilities.
● The PR Co-Chairs are responsible for maintaining and posting to the club’s social media

accounts, including Instagram, Twitter, Facebook, and Linkedin.

● The PR Co-Chairs are responsible for holding committee meetings (20 minutes in length)

in lieu of a general body meeting twice a semester.

○ The topic of the meetings are at the discretion of the Co-Chairs.

● Any IMC content created by the PR Co-Chairs is considered to be club property and may

not be repurposed for personal use.

● PR Co-Chairs may not block any social media user from the club account, unless

approved by the Co-Presidents.

● The club social media accounts are not to be used for personal communications under any

circumstance.

● Any violation of these social media parameters are to be subject to review by the EBoard.

6. Community Service Committee Co-Chairs (2-3)

● The two Community Service Committee Co-Chairs shall share responsibilities.

 ● The Co-Chairs are responsible for organizing community service initiatives within the

club.

● The Co-Chairs are responsible for holding committee meetings (20 minutes in length) in

lieu of a general body meeting twice a semester

○ The topic of the meetings are at the discretion of the Co-Chairs

7. Fundraising Committee Co-Chairs (2-3)

● The two Fundraising Committee Co-Chairs shall share responsibilities.
● The Co-Chairs are responsible for organizing fundraising initiatives within the club.
● The Co-Chairs are responsible for holding committee meetings (20 minutes in length) in

lieu of a general body meeting twice a semester

○ The topic of the meetings are at the discretion of the Co-Chairs

8. DEIA+ Committee Co-Chairs (2-3)

● The Co-Chairs are responsible for hosting 1 DEIA+ workshop during a general body

meeting per semester (2x per year, 1 per semester).

● The Co-Chairs are responsible for coordinating a DEIA+ training for the executive board

during the beginning of the semester (2x per year; 1 per semester).

● The Co-Chairs will be responsible to find weekly events from UMass and other cultural

centers on campus and send to the Secretary to be included in weekly emails in
‘Additional Announcements’.

*The Co-Presidents reserve the right to combine the Vice President and Secretary positions into one
position as deemed fit and necessary.

Article V - Officer Selections
Officer Selections for Committee Co-Chairs, Secretary, and Treasurer

1. Officer selections shall take place through an application and interview process.

a.
Interviews shall take place the semester prior to the term they will be served in.
b. For fall semester, an election will be held before April 1 of the previous semester.
c. For spring semester, an election will be held before December 1 of the previous semester.

2. At the end of each semester, open positions shall be posted and advertised via club social media

accounts and emails.

3. Prospective candidates must send their resume and a personal statement via email to the club

email account to be considered.

4. All applicants shall receive an interview.
5. The Co-Presidents are in charge of the interview process. An election is to be held during a

general body meeting to determine the new Eboard members, with ⅔ of the active IMC members
in attendance.

6. Upon completion of the interview process, the Co-Presidents reserve the right to choose who they

see as the best candidate to fill the position.

a.

If the Co-Presidents cannot come to an agreement on which candidate shall be picked, the
tie vote goes to the VP.

7. Once a candidate is chosen, they are to be informed via email to be extended the offer.

 8. Written acceptance of the offer must be given by the candidate before they can assume the

position.

9. The Secretary is responsible for keeping records about the election process including who applied

for which roles and who was selected for each Eboard position.

Officer Selections for Co-Presidents and Vice President

1. The Co-Presidents shall appoint existing EBoard members to the positions of VP and

2.

Co-President based on qualifications.
In the event that no Eboard members want to be appointed to the positions of Co-President or VP,
the Co-President may defer to the Selection process to fill the position.

Article VI - Removal of Executive Board Members
Any officer may be impeached from office for failure to perform the duties of their office or for conduct
that is detrimental to the group.
The following procedure must be followed in order for an officer to be impeached:

1. A motion must be made and seconded during an official and regularly scheduled general body

meeting to impeach an officer.

2. The officer who is being impeached must be notified by email of their potential removal from

office.

3. At the general body meeting, the member making the motion of impeachment shall have 15

minutes to present their case against the officer. This shall be the time to present any evidence
and/or witnesses relevant to the impeachment. These 15 minutes shall not be interrupted for any
reason, other than if the petitioner decides to take questions from the membership.

4. Following the presentation of evidence from the petitioner, the accused officer will have 15

minutes to present their defense and any evidence or witnesses they wish. These 15 minutes shall
not be interrupted for any reason, other than if the officer decides to take questions from the
general membership.

6.
7.

5. Following the presentations from the petitioner and the accused officer, a vote shall be taken. 2/3
of the general body must vote in favor of impeachment in order for an officer to be removed.
If the voting results in impeachment, the officer shall immediately surrender his or her office.
If the officer in question is the President, the meeting in which the impeachment is considered
shall be chaired by the Vice President.
If any issues arise during this process, or if either party wishes to appeal the results, the question
may be taken by any member or officer to the Student Judiciary.

8.

Article VII - Officer Vacancies
If a Co-President resigns or is impeached, the Vice President shall immediately take over as Co-President.
If the Vice President resigns or is impeached, the Co-Presidents may appoint an existing EBoard member
to the position, or defer to the selection process.
If the Treasurer, Secretary, or a Committee Co-Chair resigns or is impeached, a selection process shall be
held for that position by the executive board.

 Article VIII - Resolving Disputes
Disputes arising between members on matters of RSO policy shall be dealt with by the executive board as
a whole.
Disputes arising between members on other matters shall be dealt with by mediation.
Mediation consists of a meeting involving both parties and a mediator with the purpose of coming to a
solution and putting the issue to rest.
The President shall mediate disputes between members.
Should the President be involved in the dispute or a conflict of interest shall recuse themself from
mediation and the responsibility will defer to the VP.
Should either party not be satisfied by the result of the mediation, any party may request that the RSO
advisor shall mediate. The results of mediation with the advisor shall be final.

Article IX - Free Speech and Statement of Non-Discrimination
“Under no circumstances shall a member’s freedom of speech or expression be infringed.”
All members of IMC are entitled to freedom of speech and will not under any circumstances be deprived
of the opportunity to share their opinion with the group.

“Isenberg Marketing Club prohibits discrimination under Federal and State law, based on race, color,
national origin, religion, sex, gender identity (including gender expression), sexual orientation, disability,
age, marital status, family/parental status, income derived from a public assistance program, veteran
status, citizenship, genetic information, political beliefs, or reprisal or retaliation for prior civil rights
activity,” This list is not exhaustive, and groups can add more protected classes to this statement.

Article X - Amendment
This charter may be amended by a 2/3 vote of the general body at a regularly scheduled general body
meeting.

- A motion to amend may be made and seconded by any member at a meeting of the general body
or at the Constituion Review Meeting. The motion shall be presented at the meeting in which the
motion is made. Voting on the motion shall take place at the following meeting. Prior to voting,
the Co-Presidents shall allow for a period of debate.

After being approved by the membership, the amendment itself, and an updated version of the Charter,
shall be submitted to the Secretary of the Registry for final approval.

DocsList.Name: Strategic Plan Fall 2024.pdf
DocsList.Data:
Isenberg Marketing Club Strategic Plan Fall 2024

Mission Statement

The mission of Isenberg Marketing Club is to provide students interested in the marketing field with
hands-on and resume worthy experiences. Our club is separated into three committees that members can
join (Fundraising, Public Relations, and Community Service) and an executive board in order to find
opportunities for our members to gain marketing experience. Each February we host a networking event
(Marketing Career Networking Night), intended to provide marketing majors and those interested in
marketing with opportunities for jobs, internships, and co-ops. We host weekly meetings that will offer
marketing-focused students the skills they need to develop a career in the marketing world.

Vision

Our vision is to create an engaging learning community where students can grow their marketing skills,
explore career paths, and network with peers and industry professionals. We aim to be a resource for
students interested in marketing, known for providing enriching experiences and opportunities that
support career development.

Values

1. Practical Experience

We prioritize hands-on learning to prepare members for real-world challenges in the marketing
field.

2. Community and Networking

We believe in the power of connections and seek to foster a supportive network within the club
and beyond.
Integrity and Professionalism
We commit to high standards of ethics and professionalism in all club activities.

3.

 4.

Inclusivity and Diversity
We value diverse perspectives and aim to create an inclusive environment where every member
feels welcome and supported.

Five-Year Goals for Isenberg Marketing Club

Year 1: Enhance Member Skills and Career Readiness
Deadline: 2025

● Develop a series of workshops and seminars focused on digital marketing, branding, analytics,

and other relevant marketing sectors.

● Partner with companies to provide internship and project-based learning opportunities for

members.

Year 2: Strengthen Community and Industry Connections
Deadline: 2026

● Expand the annual Marketing Career Networking Night to include more companies, alumni, and

industry leaders.

● Create a mentorship program that connects upperclassmen with incoming members and alumni.

Year 3: Increase Member Engagement and Career Development
Deadline: 2027

● Connect members with career opportunities and certificate programs to enhance their resumes

and career preparedness.

● Organize social events, team-building activities, and cross-committee projects to enhance club

cohesion and involvement.

Year 4: Boost Club Visibility and Campus Presence
Deadline: 2028

● Implement a strategic social media plan to increase our online presence and share club highlights,

achievements, and upcoming events.

● Table regularly on campus and participate in campus-wide events to attract new members and

build awareness.

Year 5: Cultivate a Sustainable Funding Model
Deadline: 2029

● Develop and execute annual fundraising events, such as merchandise sales, bake sales, and

ticketed events.

● Apply for grants and sponsorships from local businesses and university programs to support club

activities and future events.

 Annual Estimated Expenses and Fundraising Strategy

Estimated Expenses

1. Travel Expenses: $2,500
2. Club Supplies: $500
3. Spring Networking Event: $4,500

Total Estimated Annual Expenses: $7,500

Fundraising Strategy

Fall

● Organize a bake sale on campus – $300
● Sell hand-made jewelry – $200
● Plan activities for members and guests with a small entry fee – $200

Spring

● Host a networking event with different level sponsors - $4,500
● Partner with local businesses to raise money through buy-to-donate or restaurant give-back

programs – $300

Total Fundraising Goal: $5,500 annually

Marketing and Recruitment Strategy

The Isenberg Marketing Club will form a Public Relations committee by electing 2-3 PR leaders. The PR
leaders will focus on promoting the club through campus events, social media, and print flyers. The
Public Relations committee will actively engage with students, attend campus fairs, and host club
informational sessions to attract new members. Together, they will maintain a strong club presence on
campus and ensure membership growth.

By staying active on social media, regularly hosting events, and engaging with the campus community,
we aim to keep our membership strong and continue to build a network of dedicated marketing
professionals at UMass Amherst.
