DocsList.Name: Japanese_Students'_Association_Constitution_18-19SY.docx
DocsList.Data:
Japanese Students Association Constitution and Bylaws
 
Article I: Name of Organization
The name of the organization is Japanese Students Association (JSA).

Article II: Purpose of Organization
The Japanese Students Association (JSA) is open to all 5 College Consortium undergraduate and graduate students who are interested in deepening their knowledge of Japanese culture. The club encourages interaction between those who are interested in Japanese culture by providing a respectful, inclusive environment. Further, it creates a community outreach through guided discussions, presentations, movies, socializations, fundraisers, and cultural events to broaden general knowledge and awareness of Japanese culture throughout campus.

Article III: General Executive Board Responsibilities (By Order of Importance)
All Board members shall promote a supportive, friendly, encouraging, and interactive environment within the club.
All Board members must represent the JSA effectively at public and collaborative events (involving other RSOs). 
All Board members are expected to openly communicate concerns at Executive Board meetings in a productive, inclusive manner. 
If there is a personal or safety issue, members are advised to speak with the President or Vice President as soon as possible. 
All Board members are expected to attend JSA group and Executive Board meetings. 
If a Board member plans to miss a meeting, he or she must report to the President or Vice President no later than 24 hours before it starts (excluding emergencies). Prior obligations, family commitment, health issues, exams, etc. are acceptable reasons for absence. Board members are expected to read over a detailed summary of any missed meetings.
All Board members must keep up to date with meeting documents
All Board members must be familiar with the constitution.

 >Make posters
        	>Hand out and post Flyers
        	>Recruit club and Board members

Article IV: Executive Board Positions 
The Executive Board consists of four main positions listed hierarchically: President, Vice President, Treasurer, and Secretary. Board members can only do one main position and fill in for a secondary position, but never do two main positions.
  President
The president shall be the primary representative of the JSA, and is expected to familiarize themselves with club members, students, RSOs, faculty, and the community.
The president shall be the primary contact for the club.
The president shall ensure that the JSA and its members follow UMASS Amherst policies and the JSA constitution.
The president shall oversee all activity within the Board and the club.
The president shall prepare and present an agenda for each Board meeting.
The president shall oversee the smooth progression of all Board meetings. 
The president shall arrange and delegate weekly assignments for all Board members that includes due dates.
The president shall be secondarily responsible for SR (Signature Responsibility)
The president shall oversee the larger events and most tea tables.
In the chance case the president cannot make an event or tea table, all responsibility gets delegated to the vice president.
Only the president, with one year’s worth of experience, can be appointed the Senior Adviser.
It is possible to have two people as Co-Presidents as long as both can work out how to divide the responsibilities of the President position among themselves. 
One fair manner of doing so would be to delegate one person in charge of one semester, and the other person in charge of the remaining one in the school year. 
In the absence of a Senior Adviser, the President shall train the next President.
The president shall be responsible for looking over the constitution along with the vice president and the secretary. The president has the final say on what changes to the Constitution should be made.
   Vice President
The vice-president shall facilitate Board meetings and ensure the focus remains on the agenda.
The vice-president shall assist the president to oversee club activities such as tea tables and large events. In the case of the president’s absence, the vice president shall take over and lead tea tables and large events. 
The vice-president shall be responsible for ensuring that each assignment is completed.
24-hr check in for each assignment
If a Board member has trouble or is unable to complete an assignment, he or she must report to the Vice President AS SOON AS POSSIBLE.
The vice-president shall be the secondary contact for the club.
The vice president shall be in charge of mediating between club and board, resolving conflicts within board through compromising.
The vice president shall be responsible for looking over the constitution along with the president and the secretary.
In the absence of a Senior Adviser, the vice president shall train the next vice president.
   Secretary
The secretary shall record and summarize activities at board meetings and post onto Google Docs.
The secretary shall be responsible for sign-up sheets for the e-mail list. 
The secretary shall keep an official email list of club members up to date.
The secretary shall email reminders of meetings and events to club members.
The secretary shall be the primary responder to all club emails as well as the person that reaches out to other organizations for events, advertising needs, etc.
The secretary shall be responsible for keeping in contact with important university officials for RSO related matters such as storage space.
The secretary should keep the Constitution up to date, referring to the vice president and the president for a final check.
Treasurer
The treasurer shall keep records of finances and funds of the club on the Google Drive, updating them regularly.
The treasurer shall advise the club on what to do with the money and how it should be raised or funded.
The treasurer shall be primarily responsible for SR (Signature Responsibility).
The treasurer shall be responsible for seeking out grants for events.
The treasurer shall fill out and hand in all purchase requests / SASP card requests. 
The treasurer shall keep up to date with the current campus design/copy - fliers account and make sure the account has sufficient funds to print out necessary items. 
 The treasurer shall keep a record of all receipts of purchases.
The treasurer should alert the Board as soon as possible as to when to purchase items for events or tea tables. 
The Executive Board consists of four secondary positions listed randomly: Event Coordinator, Cultural Ambassador, Creative IT, Senior Adviser, Public Relations Officer, and Historian.
Event Coordinator(s) 
The event coordinator shall book rooms for events and club meetings and confirm the approval of projector use (if necessary) 
The event coordinator shall oversee and lead the event creation process of large events and tea tables by helping to generate ideas for such gatherings and by presenting cultural points during said events and tea tables.
The event coordinator will work together with the Cultural Ambassador to create events.
The event coordinator will work together with the Treasurer to make SASP requests.
Ideally, the event coordinator has some knowledge to the Japanese culture to provide seamless creation of events, but this is not a requirement.
The event coordinator shall be in charge of recruiting and managing volunteers during large scale events.
The event coordinator shall train event coordinators in training in how to create events on Campus Pulse.
The event coordinator shall keep in contact with the Cultural Advisor of SORC to ensure the smoothest manner of event creation.
Cultural Ambassador(s)
The cultural ambassador shall ensure that the Japanese culture is being accurately represented.
The cultural ambassador shall work with the event coordinator to generate ideas for tea tables and events as well as helping them present important cultural points that sparked the tea table or event. 
The cultural ambassador shall be in charge of recruiting people interested in the Japanese culture to come to events and tea tables.
The cultural ambassador must possess extensive knowledge of the Japanese culture. 
Creative IT
The creative IT shall design graphics and images for events such as posters and pictures. This person shall also be the main person in creating short PowerPoints for tea tables and large events.
The creative IT shall print flyers after confirming approval of the draft from the rest of the Board.
The creative IT shall distribute flyers to board members to post around campus.
The creative IT is responsible for updating the flyers on the presentation used for advertising during club fairs.
Senior Adviser
The senior adviser can only be a Board member who has had at minimum two years’ worth of experience on the Board, and who has held President or Co-President position for at least one year. They must be generally competent with the jobs that the main four Board positions entail. 
The senior adviser shall train the next generation of Vice President and President in order to provide a smooth transition of power onto the next generation. Besides training the next president and vice president, the senior adviser can also train new Board members as they see fit.
The senior adviser should advise the president and vice president on the general oversight of the club, including event creation, leading tea tables, planning for the club’s future, etc.
The appointment of a senior adviser can only be accomplished with the above first point. Because of that, there may be years were there is no senior adviser appointed. 
Historian
The historian is in charge of taking picture and videos of club events and tea tables.
The historian is in charge of uploading said pictures and videos onto the club’s Instagram, Facebook page, and Campus Pulse page.
The historian is also responsible for updating the pictures on the presentation used for advertising during club fairs.
Public Relations Officer
The public relations officer shall be in charge of the club’s social media sites, including but not exhaustive: LINE and the Facebook Page. They will be the one to create events on Facebook up to a month before the event, but no less than a week to it and updating the general members about club events and tea tables. 
The public relations officer will be the one in charge of responding to questions on the club’s social media platforms. In the chance case of there not being enough time for the public relations officer to respond, another available Board member shall do so.

ADVISORS 
TALK TO THE ADVISORS AND FIGURE OUT WHAT THEY DO!

Article IV: Electing Board Members


Article V: Membership
The Japanese Students’ Association (JSA) will welcome any full-time undergraduate students from the 5 College Consortium to join the club. 
The JSA will not discriminate the membership on the basis of ethnicity, race, culture, religion, sexual orientation, gender identity, color, political affiliations, or any physical/mental disabilities.
The JSA will not restrict anyone from leaving the club. The club will allow anyone who wishes to leave the club to talk to the president or vice president for the procedures of discontinuation. 
The JSA encourages anyone who is a Japanese major, minor, or taking any other Japanese courses to join the club.
The JSA will recognize a member only in relatively regular attendance to the meetings and through the JSA Campus Pulse roster. 

Article VI: Voting membership (Elections)
Anyone is eligible for nominations for the elections. Elections happen during both Fall and Spring semester. The elections will start during the General Interest Meeting in Fall semester and before Spring break of Spring semester.  The date of the election will be announced weeks prior to the election interviews.
There needs to be 2/3 majority vote to be elected as a member of the Executive Board. 
The candidates are to be members of the JSA club. Candidates can be nominated, or they can nominate themselves. The candidates must notify its nomination to the current Board by one week before the election date.
The results to the election will be sent through e-mail.
The elected Executive Board members shall have a one year term.
To impeach an officer, at lease 2/3 majority of the members should present a report stating their reason to remove an officer from the Executive Board. Any Executive Board officer will be removed if the officer violates the UMASS Amherst campus policies or the JSA constitution by presenting poor performance of their role consistently. To impeach an officer, the current Board members must cast a 2/3 majority vote. An immediate election will be called the following week of the impeachment if the president sees needed.

Article VII: Meetings
Japanese Students’ Association general meetings shall be open to all undergraduate students of the 5 College Consortium and will be held weekly at a specific time and location. The meetings will consist of members participating in an activity or discussion pertaining to Japanese culture. Each meeting will have its purpose in relating to the different aspects of Japanese culture, whether it would be music, history, traditional theatre, games, fashion, books, manga, or films. The agendas will be decided in the Executive Board’s meetings which will consider the thoughts and comments of general members.
If something at a meeting goes wrong the Vice President and the Event Coordinator(s) are to leave the room and solve the problem.
All Board members will NOT be involved.
Executive Board Meetings:
The Executive Board meetings shall have attendance of the President, Vice-President, Secretary, and the Treasurer. The purpose of this meeting is to set up agendas for the JSA concerning the rest of the academic semester. The Executive Board members will bring up concerns, comments, and questions about the JSA activities.
 Activities:
Cooking traditional Japanese cuisine
Participating in traditional Japanese games
Celebrating Japanese holidays, traditions. 
Watching Japanese films
Discussion on modern Japanese Culture
Talking to Japanese study abroad students
Presenting specific Japanese geography
Presenting major topics of Japanese pop culture

Article VIII:  Finance
There are no fees to join the membership of the JSA. There is to be fundraising to obtain necessary resources to conduct activities, unless the SGA funds JSA, within the club of which the treasurer will be held responsible to keep records.

Article IX: Amendments and Dismissals
Amendments shall be approved from 2/3 of the majority of votes casted by the Board members and approved by the Sec. of the Registry.
If the President or Vice President notices a Board member’s (including President, Vice President)  repeated negligence of any of the aforementioned responsibilities of their position or by their continued absence during events and tea tables, the entire Executive Board will discuss relevant issues and possible solutions. After this initial warning, if the member continues to neglect his/her essential responsibilities, the Board will vote on his/her continuation as a Board member. If a 2/3 majority votes that the member is NOT upholding responsibilities, he/she will be asked to step down. The member is still invited to attend meetings, events, etc. 
If a JSA group member interferes with other members’ comfort or safety at ANY meeting or event, the member will be given a warning by the President or Vice President. 
If this behavior continues, he/she will be asked to stop attending meetings or events. 
If this behavior is a serious concern for a students’ sense of comfort or safety, Board members will assist the student as much as possible and take necessary action. If we observe any students breaking the Umass Code of Student Conduct at our meetings or events, we will report the incident to the Dean of Students Office. 

Article X: Advisor
The Advisor for this club shall be a full time Umass faculty. The Advisor is expected to guide the club in the procedures to change the constitution (if desired), to find location for events, to find financial aid, and to advise on being an effective and active UMASS campus club.
 
Article XI: Ratification
The JSA constitution will be ratified by 3/4th majority vote by the Student Government Association House of Representatives.

The president shall prepare and present an agenda for each Board meeting.
The president shall arrange weekly assignments for all Board members that includes due dates.
The president shall be secondarily responsible for SR (Signature Responsibility)
   Vice President
The vice-president shall facilitate Board meetings, and ensure the focus remains on the agenda.
The vice-president shall assist the president to oversee club activities.
The vice-president shall be responsible for ensuring that each assignment is completed.
24-hr check in for each assignment
If a Board member has trouble or is unable to complete an assignment, he or she must report to the Vice President AS SOON AS POSSIBLE.
The vice-president shall be the secondary contact for the club.
Mediating between club and board; resolving conflicts within board (compromising)
   Secretary
The secretary shall record and summarize activities at board meetings, and post onto Google Docs.
The secretary shall be responsible for attendance sheets for each meeting/event and sign-up sheets for the e-mail list. 
The secretary shall keep an official email list of club members up to date
The secretary shall email reminders of meetings and events to club members
Treasurer
The treasurer shall keep records of finance and funds of the club.
The treasurer shall advise the club on what to do with the money, and how it should be raised or funded.
The treasurer shall be primarily responsible for SR (Signature Responsibility).
The treasurer shall be responsible for seeking out grants for events.
The treasurer shall fill out and hand in all purchase requests / SASP card requests 
The treasurer shall keep up to date with the current (campus design/copy - fliers) account and make sure the account has sufficient funds to print out necessary items. 
 The treasurer shall keep a record of all receipts of purchases.
Event Coordinator(s)
The event coordinator shall create agendas for club events 
The event coordinator shall present this agenda to the E-board before any event to ensure organization
The event coordinator shall make sure events are running according to the agenda
The event coordinator shall book rooms for Board and club meetings and confirm the approval of projector use (if necessary)
The event coordinator shall create events on FB. 
 
The Executive Board consists of four secondary positions listed hierarchically: Secretary, Creative IT, Undergrad Liaison, and Historian.
Creative IT
The creative IT shall design flyers and posters for events.
The creative IT shall print flyers after confirming approval of the draft from the rest of the Board.
The creative IT shall distribute flyers to board members.
Undergrad Liaisons
The undergrad liaison shall be responsible for recruiting. 
The undergrad liaisons shall fill any responsibility in case of a Board member being unable to complete a task. 
The undergrad liaison shall be responsible for the posting of flyers in the following locations: 	
YKCC
Herter
Limered Teahouse
Resource Room
The undergrad liaison shall update the E-board on current events of fellow RSO’s at each meeting. 
The undergrad liasion shall also be responsible for adding members to campus pulse, encouraging members. 
The undergrad liaison shall hand flyers to fellow RSO’s to help advertisement. 
 The undergrad liaison shall take pictures at all club events.
 The undergrad liaison  shall collect and summarize Board members’ critiques of how events turn out and post it on Google Drive. 
The undergrad liaison shall check campus pulse consistently, and add members. 

ADVISORS 
TALK TO THE ADVISORS AND FIGURE OUT WHAT THEY DO!

POSITIONS: People can do a primary and secondary position (filling in), but never TWO primary positions.

Article IV: Electing Board Members


Article V: Membership
The Japanese Students’ Association (JSA) will welcome any full-time undergraduate students from UMASS Amherst to join the club. 
The JSA will not discriminate the membership on the basis of ethnicity, race, culture, religion, sexual orientation, gender identity, color, political affiliations, or any physical/mental disabilities.
The JSA will not restrict anyone from leaving the club. The club will allow anyone who wishes to leave the club to talk to the secretary for the procedures of discontinuation. 
The JSA encourages anyone who is a Japanese major, minor, or taking any other Japanese courses to join the club.
The JSA will recognize a member only in relatively regular attendance to the meetings. 

Article VI: Voting membership (Elections)
Previous club members of the JSA are eligible for nominations for the elections. The elections will start three weeks before the end of an academic year. The date of the election will be e-mailed one week prior to the election.
There needs to be 2/3 majority vote to be elected as a member of the Executive Board. The Executive Board has four candidate positions to which the members can be elected.
The candidates are to be members of the JSA club. Candidates can be nominated, or they can nominate themselves. The candidates must notify its nomination to the secretary by one week before the election date.
The results to the election will be sent through e-mail.
The elected Executive Board members shall have a one year term.
To impeach an officer, at lease 2/3 majority of the members should present a report stating their reason to remove an officer from the Executive Board. Any Executive Board officer will be removed if the officer violates the UMASS Amherst campus policies or the JSA constitution. To impeach an officer, the general club members must cast a 2/3 majority vote. An immediate election will be called the following week of the impeachment.

Article VII: Meetings
Japanese Students’ Association general meetings shall be open to all undergraduate students of UMASS Amherst, and will be held weekly at a specific time and location. The meetings will consist of members participating in an activity or discussion pertaining to Japanese culture. Each meeting will have its purpose in relating to the different aspects of Japanese culture, whether it would be music, history, traditional theatre, games, fashion, books, manga, or films. The agendas will be decided in the Executive Board’s meetings which will consider the thoughts and comments of general members.
If something at a meetings goes wrong the Vice President, and the Event Coordinator(s) are to leave the room and solve the problem.
All board members will NOT be involved.
Executive Board Meetings:
The Executive Board meetings shall have attendance of the President, Vice-President, Secretary, and the Treasurer. The purpose of this meeting is to set up agendas for the JSA concerning the rest of the academic semester. The four Executive Board members shall be required to cooperate and work together as a team to come up with agendas. The Executive Board members will bring up concerns, comments, and questions about the JSA activities.
 Activities:
Cooking traditional Japanese cuisine
Participating in traditional Japanese games
Celebrating Japanese holidays, traditions. 
Watching Japanese films
Discussion on modern Japanese Culture
Talking to Japanese study abroad students
Presenting specific Japanese geography
Presenting major topics of Japanese pop culture

Article VIII:  Finance
There are no fees to join the membership of the JSA. There is to be fundraising to obtain necessary resources to conduct activities, unless the SGA funds JSA, within the club of which the treasurer will be held responsible to keep records.

Article IX: Amendments and Dismissals
Amendments shall be approved from 2/3 of the majority of votes casted by the members and approved by the Sec. of the Registry.
If the President or Vice President notices a Board member’s (including President, Vice President)  repeated negligence of any of the 5 aforementioned responsibilities, the entire Executive Board will discuss relevant issues and possible solutions. After this initial warning, if the member continues to neglect his/her essential responsibilities, the Board will vote on his/her continuation as a Board member. If a ¾ majority votes that the member is NOT upholding responsibilities, he/she will be asked to step down. The member is still invited to attend meetings, events, etc. 
If a JSA group member interferes with other members’ comfort or safety at ANY meeting or event, the member will be given a warning by the President or Vice President. 
If this behavior continues, he/she will be asked to stop attending our meetings or events. 
If this behavior is a serious concern for a students’ sense of comfort or safety, Board members will assist the student as much as possible and take necessary action. If we observe any students breaking the Umass Code of Student Conduct at our meetings or events, we will report the incident to the Dean of Students Office. 

Article X: Advisor
The Advisor for this club shall be a full time Umass faculty. The Advisor is expected to guide the club in the procedures to change the constitution (if desired), to find location for events, to find financial aid, and to advise on being an effective and active UMASS campus club.
 
Article XI: Ratification
The JSA constitution will be ratified by 3/4th majority vote by the Student Government Association House of Representatives.

DocsList.Name: Constitution 2020.pdf
DocsList.Data:
Constitution of the University of Massachusetts-Amherst
Jazba Bollywood-Bhangra Dance Team

This Registered Student Organization will be known as the University of Massachusetts Jazba
Bollywood-Bhangra Dance Team.

Article I: Name

Article II: Mission Statement

Section 1: The Purpose
Jazba Bollywood-Bhangra Dance Team is a group of students dedicated to the art of dance and the
promotion of culture and diversity.  Our team incorporates various dance styles, focusing on elements in
Bollywood and Bhangra. We strive to create an environment where individuals can express themselves
and find community through dance.

Section 2: Engagement on Campus
We aim to bring cultural awareness throughout the Massachusetts community in addition to representing
the University of Massachusetts Amherst in dance performances across the country. We hope to utilize
our skills and passion for the benefit of the community by participating in outreach events and performing
at fundraisers in the surrounding Amherst area.

Section 3: Our Philosophy
Jazba Bollywood-Bhangra Dance Team strives to understand and learn more about the different forms of
dance styles by which we can contribute to society and enhance cultural awareness.

Section 4: Goals for the Next 5 Academic Years
Year 1: Establish Jazba Bollywood-Bhangra Dance Team as a diverse and culturally-focused dance team
on the University of Massachusetts Amherst campus.

●

●

Submit an RSO application to SGA and get approved for recognition and funding through the
university

Recruit members to be a part of Jazba Bollywood-Bhangra Dance Team

Year 2: Establish and strengthen fundraising efforts

●
●

●

Create sustainable fundraisers
Identify opportunities for growth and enhancement by including more dance styles from different
parts of the world

Perform at showcases and participate in competitions on campus and other universities around the
New England Area

Year 3: Establish Jazba Bollywood-Bhangra Dance Team as a mechanism through which individuals can
creatively express themselves

●
●
●

Grow relationships with the student body and other organizations through social media
Table at Campus Center concourse to gain recognition, spread awareness, and fundraise

Engage with other student organizations to create more opportunities for cultural awareness in

 and around campus

●

Try out different techniques to incorporate choreography and storylines

Year 4: Promote community inclusivity and involvement

●

●

●

Organize dance workshops focusing on different dance styles like Bollywood, Bhangra, Hip Hop
etc.
Coordinate and collaborate with other dance teams and cultural groups on campus to create more
opportunities for students to come to open practices and team events

Focus and work on our skillset to prepare ourselves for upcoming competitions in the dance
circuit

Year 5: Gain regional and national recognition in the Bollywood fusion dance circuit

●
●
●

Apply to and perform in national conferences and showcases
Broaden social media audience and extend reach into various diverse demographics

Participate in different dance competitions across the country

Article III: Group’s Membership
All undergraduate students are welcome to join our RSO if interested. Members are allowed to be a part
of the RSO if they are interested in our objective, without having to be an active dancer. These types of
roles consist of aiding in fundraising efforts, costume design, attending general body meetings, and all
other tasks that the Executive Board deems feasible.

The ability to dance at competitions and performances with the team is granted through auditions only.
Auditions will be held within the first two weeks of the beginning of each semester.

Practices will be held three times a week. Practice schedules will be made specifically with all members’
schedules and obligations in mind; attendance is mandatory unless excused by the Executive Board.
Excused absences require a doctor’s note, screenshot of exam schedule on Spire or Moodle, or other
official documentation. An email should always be sent to the Executive Board regarding any issue of
absence or tardiness. The Executive Board reserves the right to determine what constitutes as proof for an
excused absence.

In the event of four consecutive unexcused absences, the member’s right to participate in the team and
associated membership will be frozen for the semester.

A two-week notice is mandatory before leaving the team.

Dues of $50 will be collected at the beginning of each semester. This fee helps cover costs associated with
travel, costume, booking, etc. but does not eliminate out-of-pocket spending. Any potential expense for
travel and/or food will not be included in the team member fee. The Executive Board will do its best to
eliminate any extraneous spending, but it is important to note that dues will not cover all costs associated
with the team.

 Every undergraduate member of Jazba Bollywood-Bhangra Dance Team has the right to vote and under
no circumstance shall their right to vote be infringed. Every undergraduate team member has the right to
vote on items including, but not limited to; auditions, Executive Board elections, or any other decisions
regarding membership of a team member.

Article IV: Group Meeting’s Process

Section 1: Executive Board Meetings
Executive Board Meetings are to be held weekly throughout the school year at the times decided by the
Executive Board members. Additional meetings/team practices may be held each month if the Executive
Board deems it necessary. Every Executive Board member must be present at these meetings unless there
is an official excuse or discussion with the President and Secretary 48 hours before the meeting. All team
meetings will be chaired and managed by the President with the help of the rest of the Executive Board.
In case of the President’s absence, the Vice President will chair and manage all team meetings and
practices.

Section 2: Procedure for an Executive Board Meeting
Procedures are as follows:

● Secretary will read the minutes aloud and inform the Executive Board of any new updates

regarding performances, finances, etc. They will then verify that each Executive Board member
has fulfilled their task for the given week

● Treasurer will update the Executive Board on the account balance and on any new information

from the previous meeting

● All members of the Executive Board will be able to share and discuss any topic that involves the

Jazba Bollywood-Bhangra Dance Team.

● The President and Vice President will assign tasks and open a new topic of discussion relating to

the Jazba Bollywood-Bhangra Dance Team.

● The Secretary will then adjourn the meeting after everything is discussed
● Every member has the right to vote in meetings and practices and a majority of votes is required

to make a final decision.

Section 3: General Body Meetings/Team Practices
General Body Meetings will be held 3 times a week, consisting of team practices to teach choreography,
improve dancing skills, and make team decisions. The General Body will be able to decide team practice
timings, methods of transportation to events, costume selection, and competition/performance choices.
These decisions will be made with a two-thirds majority vote by the general body. All practices are
closed, meaning that only RSO members are allowed to come to the practices, at the discretion of the
Executive Board. The President will be chairing these meetings with assistance from the other Executive
Board Members. In case of the President’s absence, the remaining Executive Board members will chair
and manage all team meetings and practices.

 Section 4: Events
Team performances can take place both on-campus and off-campus. Events shall be planned and executed
by the entire Executive Board. In order to compete in any competition or perform in any performance
each team member is required to be at all practices one week prior to the event and participate in efforts to
fundraise for the event.

Article V: Executive Board

Section 1: Executive Board Overview
The Executive Board for Jazba Bollywood-Bhangra Dance Team will consist of President,
Vice-President, Treasurer, Secretary, and Public Relations Officer. The Board Members’ duties and
positions will be outlined throughout this article. Each Board Member is required to attend all meetings,
practices, and performances unless absences are officially excused or have discussed and been approved
by the Executive Board.

Section 2: Position Descriptions
President
The duties of the President include the following:

● Position is held from the day following the election to the date of the next election (one full year)
● Co-captain of Jazba Bollywood-Bhangra Dance Team
● Engage actively as choreographer to create new content along with the rest of the team
● Oversee Executive Board, general body meetings and choreography meetings
● Delegate tasks for each board member when appropriate
● Organize and file appropriate documents for all team-sponsored activities with the help of the

Treasurer

● Find venues on campus to help hold practices alone with the Vice President
● Organize all practices along with the Vice President
● Help prepare Jazba Bollywood-Bhangra Dance Team for competitions and performances with the

rest of the Executive Board

● Promote and encourage new members to participate
● Plan team bonding events
● Keep the Advisor updated on all matters concerning the Jazba Bollywood-Bhangra Dance Team
● Re-register Jazba Bollywood-Bhangra Dance Team on an annual basis via Campus Pulse
● Contact other organizations for collaborative opportunities
● Hold Signature Responsibility

Vice President
The duties of the Vice President include the following:

● Position is held from the day following the election to the date of the next election (one full year)
● Assist the President to oversee the Executive Board and general body meetings
● Manage day-to-day responsibilities of the Jazba Bollywood-Bhangra Dance Team
● Act as a liaison for the members of the Jazba Bollywood-Bhangra Dance Team
● Coordinate with the Treasurer to assist in the budgeting process

 ● Act as mediator in every meeting concerning Jazba Bollywood-Bhangra Dance Team
● Assist each board member with their respective tasks
● Collaborate with other organizations’ Executive Boards for opportunities
● Assist board members who are not able to finish their tasks
● Help prepare Jazba Bollywood-Bhangra Dance Team for competitions and performances
● Regulate the proceedings of Jazba Bollywood-Bhangra Dance Team in order to maintain
accordance with the rules and regulations of the University of Massachusetts, Amherst

Secretary
The duties of the Secretary include the following:

● Position is held from the day following the election to the date of the next election (one full year)
● Actively maintain and update the Jazba Bollywood-Bhangra Dance Team RSO Campus Pulse

Profile page

● Update the President and Vice President on issues involving Jazba Bollywood-Bhangra Dance

Team

● Note and distribute minutes at meetings and events
● Record the attendance at every meeting and event
● Create and use the email for Jazba Bollywood-Bhangra Dance Team to update the general body

and other interested individuals/ organizations

● Preserve and organize the documents that hold important policies and procedures for future

Executive Board members

● Preserve and organize the documents pertaining to any information concerning annual events and

communications with other organizations

● Organize and preserve all records of auditions, elections and other decisions made by the general

body or Executive Board.

Treasurer
The duties of the Treasurer include the following:

● Position is held from the day following the election to the date of the next election (one full year)
● Maintain and update the President and Vice President on the monthly account balances with the

Business Center Staff

● Monitor Summit for any expenses
● Maintain a financial record for Jazba Bollywood-Bhangra Dance Team
● Submit all the requests for funding from SGA and represent the organization at hearings
● Give monthly balance updates at Executive Board meetings
● Oversee every fundraising effort
● Hold Signature Responsibility
● Write grant proposals and have them approved with CSD Advisor

Public Relations
The duties of the Public Relations officer include the following:

● Position is held from the day following the election to the date of the next election (one full year)

 ● Publicize Jazba Bollywood-Bhangra Dance Team and promote the organization in efforts to

recruit new members

● Raise awareness of Jazba Bollywood-Bhangra Dance Team to the Five College Area and

surrounding community members

● Create flyers, advertisements, and table promotions in Campus Center Concourse
● Update and maintain all social media pages affiliated with Jazba Bollywood-Bhangra Dance

Team

● Contact other organizations for collaborative opportunities

Section 2: Voting
Every decision made by the Executive Board will be determined by a majority vote within the Executive
Board members.

Section 3: Meetings
Any one of the Executive Board members have the right to call for a meeting if at least three Executive
Board members can attend. Must have a quorum of 3 Executive Board members. One of these three
Executive Board members must be either the President or Vice President.

Section 4: Attendance of Meetings
All the Executive Board Members are required to attend all meetings, practices, and performances unless
they are officially excused or have discussed and made arrangements with the rest of the Executive Board.

Section 5: New Officer Requirements
The General Body will elect new officers annually. Newly elected officers’ terms will begin the day
following the election and will end on the date of the next election. The newly elected officers must have
prior experience as a member of the team for at least one semester, and the newly elected President and
Vice President must have at least one semester of experience on the Executive Board and as a
choreographer for the team.

Section 6: New Officer Orientation
There will be a mandatory orientation and shadowing for newly elected officers (excluding President or
VP positions). New officers will then be informed of and presented with the future duties and
responsibilities associated with their given position.

Section 7: Resignation of an Officer
In the case of excusing a member of the Executive Board from their position due to personal or academic
reasons, elections for a new officer will take place as soon as possible after notifying the general body of
Jazba Bollywood-Bhangra Dance Team, following the procedures for a special election. If an Executive
Board member wishes to quit their position as an officer, they will need to let the Executive Board know
of their decision two weeks prior to quitting in order to ensure that the Executive Board has enough time
to notify the general body and elect a new Executive member to fill the role.

 Article VI: Election Procedures

Section 1: Records
During the time of elections, all records will be kept by the Secretary. They will record all details
including the team members running and the consensus of the election procedure. All active RSO
members are eligible to vote. New team members will be decided by a vote carried out by current team
members after an affirmative consensus is reached. All these records will be stored by the Secretary on
the team’s google drive. In case of the Secretary’s absence, the Vice President shall take over the
Secretary’s responsibilities.

Section 2: Election Timings
Officer elections will be held before April 1st each year, during a regularly scheduled general body
meeting. Elections shall be placed on the agenda of a regular General Body Meeting at least three weeks
in advance, with notification of the general body. A quorum of two-thirds of the active SGA members in
the RSO is required for elections to occur.

Section 3: Election Procedure for Officer Positions
A google form will be sent out to the team fifteen days prior to elections and/or before March 12th. Every
team member that fulfills the requirements stated above (Article V, Section 5) will have the right to run
for the available positions on the Executive Board. After all the forms are received from the team
members, elections will be held before April 1st for the upcoming academic year. During elections, all the
candidates for the new Executive Board positions will receive a chance to address the general
membership. Every general body member will have the right to vote for every officer position. Two-thirds
of the active SGA members in the RSO (general body) constitute a quorum to hold elections.

Section 4: Removal of An Officer/Member
If an Executive Board officer or team member fails to perform their duties and/or their actions are
negatively affecting team morale and disrupting team operations, they then may elect to follow the
process of removal. The process of removal begins with any general body team member questioning the
actions of a current Executive Board member/general body member. This issue should be discussed with
the President and Vice President, who will then take action and give notice to the questioned
officer/member. The President and Vice President will give three warnings to the member failing their
duties, which include but are not limited to, missing more than three unexcused team meetings every
semester without discussing it with the Executive Board or attending practices unprepared. If the
questioned officer/member continues to fail to perform their duty and/or their actions are still negatively
affecting team morale and disrupting team operations, the President and Vice President will bring this
issue to the attention of the general body during a general body meeting/team practice.

At least two-thirds of the general body must be in agreement to put up any officer position/member for
potential removal. Once two-thirds of the general body has agreed, the member/officer in question will
have a meeting with the President and Vice President to discuss the relevant concerns. The
officer/member in question will also be given an opportunity to address the general body for ten
uninterrupted minutes during a scheduled team meeting; the general body and officer/member in question
will be notified at least 48 hours in advance of the date of the removal hearing. There will be a vote held

 by the entire general body whereby a two-thirds vote is required to remove the officer/member in
question.

Section 5: Filling Officer Vacancies/Special Elections
Newly elected officers will start their roles the day following elections. In the event that there is a vacancy
in the Executive Board less than a month before a regularly scheduled election, a special election is not
necessary. The remaining Executive Board members will assume the responsibilities of the removed
officer until the upcoming election date. In the event that a vacancy in the Executive Board occurs more
than a month before a regularly scheduled election, a special election is necessary in order to fill the
empty officer position. The general body members will be notified of the open Executive Board position
and this special election will occur at the next scheduled general body meeting/team practice. It will
consist of the same procedures as a regular election, except only one position will be voted on. In order
for the member to be elected, a majority vote of the general body is required.

Article VII: Statement of Free Speech and Expression

Every team member of Jazba Bollywood-Bhangra Dance Team will have the right to free speech and
expression. Every team member has the right to free speech, which includes but is not limited to, voicing
their views, opinions, or ideas in front of the team. Under no circumstances shall a team member’s
freedom of speech or expression be infringed.

Every team member has the right to voice their opinion on any matter including but not limited to team
dynamics, artistic direction, etc.

Article VIII: Statement of Non-Discrimination

Jazba Bollywood-Bhangra Dance Team is a non-exclusive organization. The team prohibits
discrimination under Federal and State law, based on race, color, national origin, religion, sex, gender
identity (including gender expression), sexual orientation, disability, age, marital status, family/parental
status, income derived from a public assistance program, political beliefs, or reprisal or retaliation for
prior civil rights activity.

Every member has the ability to speak their mind and raise any questions or concerns they have regarding
Jazba Bollywood-Bhangra Dance Team without facing any consequences. This team is a safe, open and
accepting space, and we dedicate ourselves to promoting and maintaining a secure and warm
environment.

Article IX: Amendments to the Charter/Constitution

Amendments to this Charter/Constitution must be decided by a simple majority vote of the general
membership as well as the approval of the Secretary of the Registry. All members of the RSO are eligible
to vote. The amendment must be approved by the Secretary of the Registry before changes can be made.

DocsList.Name: KGSO Constitution_third_edition.pdf
DocsList.Data:
Constitution of the Kinesiology Graduate Student Organization 
(KGSO) at the University of Massachusetts Amherst 

Third Edition 
Updated: May 1st, 2020 

ARTICLE I - Name and Purpose 

Section  1  Name  of  the  Organization:  The  organization  shall  be  named  the  Kinesiology 
Graduate Student Organization (KGSO). 

Section 2 Purpose: The purpose of the KGSO is to facilitate and support activities that meet 
the academic, social, cultural, and professional needs of Kinesiology Graduate students and 
to act as a voice for graduate students in the Department of Kinesiology at the University 
of Massachusetts Amherst.  

ARTICLE II - Membership, Membership Fees, Non-Discrimination Policy 

Section 1 General  Definition of Membership: Membership shall be open to all enrolled 
graduate  students  in  the  Department  of  Kinesiology  at  the  University  of  Massachusetts 
Amherst. 

Section 2 Active Membership: Active members are all those who are currently enrolled as 
graduate students within the Department of Kinesiology at the University of Massachusetts 
Amherst. Active participation and attendance of events and meetings is expected, but not 
mandatory. Any graduate student can opt out of active membership by sending a letter to 
the KGSO committee at any time.  

Section 3 Non-Discrimination Policy: The KGSO does not discriminate for any purpose 
on  the  basis  of  race,  ethnicity,  linguistic  abilities,  religion,  sexual  identity,  political 
affiliation, disability status, or marital status. 

ARTICLE III – The Representative Committee 

Section 1 General Description: The Representative Committee (RC) will consist of four 
members,  with  one  representative  from  each  area  of  the  Department  of  Kinesiology 
(Biomechanics,  Movement  Neuroscience,  Physical  Activity,  and  Physiology).  Students 
will be eligible to be a member of the RC if they have completed at least one semester of 
graduate study in the department and will not be graduating for two years. If there are no 
eligible candidates, faculty recommendations will be utilized for nominations.  

Section 2 Term Length: Each RC member will serve a two-year term starting September 
1, with a one term limit. Terms will run from September 1 to August 31 of the following 
year. The committee will be composed of two first-year RC members (one member from 
two areas) and two second-year RC members (one from each of the remaining two areas) 
to ensure some continuity between years. Each spring, elections will be held to elect one 

 
 new RC member from the two areas whose representatives have finished their two-year 
term.  

Section 3 Roles: Formal chair positions will not be assigned. Work will be divided equally 
amongst all four members and/or to those who are best suited to address an issue.  Roles 
of the RC include serving as a link between the graduate student body and the graduate 
program  director  (GPD),  as  well  as  setting  up  professional  development  and  social 
opportunities for Kinesiology graduate students.  

Section 4 Meetings: The RC will meet biweekly or as needed to determine the needs of the 
graduate students and organize necessary events.   

ARTICLE IV - Election and Appointment Procedures  

Section 1 Election Schedule: Each spring semester, two new members from two different 
areas will be elected for a two-year term. The election to replace outgoing RC positions 
shall be held through an online portal during the spring semester. The election portal will 
be open for at least a week to allow all Active Members to cast their votes in their own area 
(e.g. Physiology students vote for one new Physiology RC member).  

Section 2 Nomination Schedule: At least 10 days before the election begins, a notice shall 
be  distributed  by  the  RC  to  announce  the  election  and  to  invite  nominations  for  each 
position.  Nominations  will  be  made  online  via  email  to  the  KGSO  email  account 
(umass.kgso@gmail.com).  Active  members  can  nominate  one  individual  for  the  RC  in 
their  specific  area  (Biomechanics,  Movement  Neuroscience,  Physical  Activity,  and 
Physiology).  

Section 3 Nomination Eligibility: Active members are eligible for nomination if they have 
completed  one  semester  of  graduate  study  within  the  Department  of  Kinesiology  at  the 
University of Massachusetts Amherst or if they have received a faculty nomination. Any 
active member may nominate any active member in his/her area including his/herself. 

Section  4  Nomination  Acceptance:  Approximately  seven  days  before  the  election,  each 
nominee shall be given two days to accept or decline the nomination of her/his name. If no 
response  is  given  within  the  two-day  time  period,  a  declination  of  nomination  will  be 
assumed. 

Section 5 Campaigning Period: Beginning three days before the election, each nominee 
shall be permitted to forward a statement (no more than 250 words) or curriculum vitae to 
the RC to be distributed to the active members pertaining to the merits of the nominee.  

Section 6 Election Period: Beginning on the first day of the election, active members will 
be given a link to an anonymous online survey to vote. Active members will have one week 
to complete their vote. 

Section 7 Votes Counting: Votes shall be tabulated via the online survey. 

 Section 8 Determinations: A winner shall be declared based on receiving a plurality of the 
votes in their area. In the event of a tie, a winner will be determined by an anonymous vote 
by the current RC members.  

Section 9 Appointment Procedures I: In the event of a sudden or continued vacancy in an 
executive  position,  the  RC  may  choose  to  appoint  an  active  member  to  a  position  in  a 
temporary manner until an election can be held for the position. In the event of a special 
election to fill the vacancy, the voting procedures will follow sections 2-8 above.  

Section 10 Appointment Procedures II: In the event that an RC member from a given area 
leaves the program, has served two-years, or no longer wishes to continue being an RC 
member, a normal two-year or a special one-year term RC position will be made available 
at the next election.       

Section 11 Removal from Office: An individual may be removed from the RC if they are 
not fulfilling the requirements set forth by the Constitution. In the event of the need for 
removal from a RC position, the individual will be given a verbal warning from the RC at 
the next meeting. In the case of a second occurrence, a written warning will be given. In 
the case of a third occurrence, a vote will be held amongst the RC to remove the individual.  

ARTICLE V - Meetings 

Section 1 General Meetings: General meetings of active KGSO members will be held at a 
minimum of once per academic year, and as necessary. Meeting times and dates will be 
announced at least two weeks prior to the meeting. 

Section  2  RC  Meetings:  The  RC  will  meet  approximately  biweekly  or  as  needed  to 
determine  the  needs  of  the  graduate  students  and  organize  necessary  events.  Meeting 
minutes will be kept and made available to active members upon request.   

Section  3  Special  Meetings:  Any  member  of  the  RC,  an  active  KGSO  member,  or 
Kinesiology faculty can call a special meeting. 

Section 4 Rules of Conduct and Speech: The RC will follow a flexible version of Robert's 
Rules.  

Section 5 Voting. For RC and general body meetings, 2/3 of the voting body (including 
one  member  from  each  area)  must  be  present  to  establish  quorum.  A  majority  vote  is 
needed to pass a measure.  

ARTICLE VI - Rights and Privileges of Members 

Section 1 General Rights of Members: Active members have the right to bring forth any 
issues or concerns in anonymity and to request professional development or social events.  

Section 2 Voting Rights of Active Members: Every active member has the right to vote as 
long as they are in good standing with the department. 

 ARTICLE VII – Committees 

The only permanent committee is the  RC.  Ad hoc committees (i.e. social, professional 
development) will be formed and utilized as needed.  

ARTICLE VIII - Amendments to the Constitution  

Section  1  Proposal:  An  active  member  may  propose  an  amendment  by  submitting  the 
amendment in written format to the RC. Voting on the amendment may not take place in 
the  same  meeting  as  that  in  which  the  proposal  was  made.  Following  the  meeting,  the 
proposal shall be made known to all active members. 

Section 2 Approval: At the next general meeting, a vote shall be taken on the proposed 
amendment after a discussion as to the merits of the amendment (See Article V, Section 
5). The amendment must secure the majority of the votes available during the meeting. 

Section 3 Recording: Any successful amendment(s) shall be recorded and copies of the 
new  constitution  shall  be  made  available  digitally  on  the  KGSO  UMass  Campus  Pulse 
website, and made available in paper format upon request. Two paper copies shall be stored 
for record-keeping purposes. 

Section 4 University Closure:  In the event that the university is closed for an extended 
period of time, KGSO RC member voting may be conducted online.  All other nonessential 
KGSO activities can be dealt with at an ad hoc basis.   

ARTICLE IX – Presenting Concerns to the Representative Committee 

Section 1 Written submission of a/an issue/concern: Any student who wishes to voice a 
concern about the role of graduate students in the Department of Kinesiology may submit 
an anonymous online form. The student may provide their name if they feel comfortable 
doing so. 

Section 2 Review of Issue: All concerns received will be reviewed by the RC at the next 
RC meeting.  

Section 3 Action: If the issue is deemed to be significant and cannot be solved by the RC, 
it  will  be  presented  to  the  either  the  GPD,  department  chair,  or  dean  depending  on  the 
nature of the issue. If a name is provided in the claim, the RC will respond with an update 
on the status on their claim.

Constitution of the Kinesiology Graduate Student Organization 
(KGSO) at the University of Massachusetts Amherst 

Second Edition 
Updated: 03/18/19 

ARTICLE I - Name and Purpose 

Section 1 Name of the Organization: The organization shall be named the Kinesiology 
Graduate Student Organization (KGSO). 

Section 2 Purpose: The purpose of the KGSO is to facilitate and support activities that 
meet the academic, social, cultural, and professional needs of Kinesiology Graduate 
students and to act as a voice for graduate students in the Department of Kinesiology at 
the University of Massachusetts Amherst.  

ARTICLE II - Membership, Membership Fees, Non-Discrimination Policy 

Section 1 General Definition of Membership: Membership shall be open to all enrolled 
graduate students in the Department of Kinesiology at the University of Massachusetts 
Amherst. 

Section 2 Active Membership: Active members are all those who are currently enrolled 
as graduate students within the Department of Kinesiology at the University of 
Massachusetts Amherst. Active participation and attendance of events and meetings is 
expected, but not mandatory. Any graduate student can opt out of active membership by 
sending a letter to the KGSO committee at any time.  

Section 3 Non-Discrimination Policy: The KGSO does not discriminate for any purpose 
on the basis of race, ethnicity, linguistic abilities, religion, sexual identity, political 
affiliation, disability status, or marital status. 

ARTICLE III – The Representative Committee 

Section 1 General Description: The Representative Committee (RC) will consist of six 
members, with two representatives from each area of the Department of Kinesiology 
(Motor Systems, Physical Activity, and Physiology). Students will be eligible to be a 
member of the RC if they have completed two years of graduate study in the department. 
If there are no eligible candidates, faculty recommendations will be utilized for 
nominations.  

Section 2 Term Length: Each RC member will serve a two-year term starting September 
1, with a one term limit. Terms will run from September 1 to August 31 of the following 
year. Each spring, elections will be held to elect one new RC member from each area. 
The committee will be composed of three first-year RC members (one from each area) 
and three second-year RC members (one from each area) to ensure some continuity 
between years.  

 
 Section 3 Roles: Formal chair positions will not be assigned. Work will be divided 
equally amongst all six members and/or to those who are best suited to address an issue.  
Roles of the RC include serving as a link between the graduate student body and the 
graduate program director (GPD), as well as setting up professional development and 
social opportunities for Kinesiology graduate students.  

Section 4 Meetings: The RC will meet biweekly or as needed to determine the needs of 
the graduate students and organize necessary events.   

ARTICLE IV - Election and Appointment Procedures  

Section 1 Election Schedule: Each spring semester, one new member from each area will 
be elected for a two-year term. The election to replace outgoing RC positions shall be 
held through an online portal during the spring semester. The election portal will be open 
for at least a week to allow all Active Members to cast their votes in their own area (e.g. 
Physiology students vote for one new Physiology RC member).  

Section 2 Nomination Schedule: At least 10 days before the election begins, a notice shall 
be distributed by the RC to announce the election and to invite nominations for each 
position. Nominations will be made online via email to the KGSO email account 
(umass.kgso@gmail.com). Active members can nominate one individual for the RC in 
their specific area (i.e. physiology, motor systems, physical activity).  

Section 3 Nomination Eligibility: Active members are eligible for nomination if they 
have completed two years of graduate study or if they have received a faculty 
nomination. Any active member may nominate any active member in his/her area 
including his/herself. 

Section 4 Nomination Acceptance: Approximately seven days before the election, each 
nominee shall be given two days to accept or decline the nomination of her/his name. If 
no response is given within the two-day time period, a declination of nomination will be 
assumed. 

Section 5 Campaigning Period: Beginning three days before the election, each nominee 
shall be permitted to forward a statement (no more than 250 words) or curriculum vitae to 
the RC to be distributed to the active members pertaining to the merits of the nominee.  

Section 6 Election Period: Beginning on the first day of the election, active members will 
be given a link to an anonymous online survey to vote. Active members will have one 
week to complete their vote. 

Section 7 Votes Counting: Votes shall be tabulated via the online survey. 

Section 8 Determinations: A winner shall be declared based on receiving a plurality of 
the votes in their area. In the event of a tie, a winner will be determined by an anonymous 
vote by the three returning RC members.  

 Section 9 Appointment Procedures I: In the event of a sudden or continued vacancy in an 
executive position, the RC may choose to appoint an active member to a position in a 
temporary manner until an election can be held for the position. In the event of a special 
election to fill the vacancy, the voting procedures will follow sections 2-8 above.  

Section 10 Appointment Procedures II: In the event that both RC members from a given 
area are leaving the program, have served two-years, or no longer wish to continue being 
an RC member, a normal two-year and a special one-year term RC position will be made 
available at the next election.       

Section 11 Removal from Office: An individual may be removed from the RC if they are 
not fulfilling the requirements set forth by the Constitution. In the event of the need for 
removal from a RC position, the individual will be given a verbal warning from the RC at 
the next meeting. In the case of a second occurrence, a written warning will be given. In 
the case of a third occurrence, a vote will be held amongst the RC to remove the 
individual.  

ARTICLE V - Meetings 

Section 1 General Meetings: General meetings of active KGSO members will be held at a 
minimum of once per academic year, and as necessary. Meeting times and dates will be 
announced at least two weeks prior to the meeting. 

Section 2 RC Meetings: The RC will meet approximately biweekly or as needed to 
determine the needs of the graduate students and organize necessary events. Meeting 
minutes will be kept and made available to active members upon request.   

Section 3 Special Meetings: Any member of the RC, an active KGSO member, or 
Kinesiology faculty can call a special meeting. 

Section 4 Rules of Conduct and Speech: The RC will follow a flexible version of Robert's 
Rules.  

Section 5 Voting. For RC and general body meetings, 2/3 of the voting body (including 
one member from each area) must be present to establish quorum. A majority vote is 
needed to pass a measure.  

ARTICLE VI - Rights and Privileges of Members 

Section 1 General Rights of Members: Active members have the right to bring forth any 
issues or concerns in anonymity and to request professional development or social events.  

Section 2 Voting Rights of Active Members: Every active member has the right to vote 
as long as they are in good standing with the department. 

ARTICLE VII – Committees 

 The only permanent committee is the RC.  Ad hoc committees (i.e. social, professional 
development) will be formed and utilized as needed.  

ARTICLE VIII - Amendments to the Constitution  

Section 1 Proposal: An active member may propose an amendment by submitting the 
amendment in written format to the RC. Voting on the amendment may not take place in 
the same meeting as that in which the proposal was made. Following the meeting, the 
proposal shall be made known to all active members. 

Section 2 Approval: At the next general meeting, a vote shall be taken on the proposed 
amendment after a discussion as to the merits of the amendment (See Article V, Section 
5). The amendment must secure the majority of the votes available during the meeting. 

Section 3 Recording: Any successful amendment(s) shall be recorded and copies of the 
new constitution shall be made available digitally on the KGSO UMass Campus Pulse 
website, and made available in paper format upon request. Two paper copies shall be 
stored for record-keeping purposes. 

ARTICLE IX – Presenting Concerns to the Representative Committee 

Section 1 Written submission of a/an issue/concern: Any student who wishes to voice a 
concern about the role of graduate students in the Department of Kinesiology may submit 
an anonymous online form. The student may provide their name if they feel comfortable 
doing so. 

Section 2 Review of Issue: All concerns received will be reviewed by the RC at the next 
RC meeting.  

Section 3 Action: If the issue is deemed to be significant and cannot be solved by the RC, 
it will be presented to the either the GPD, department chair, or dean depending on the 
nature of the issue. If a name is provided in the claim, the RC will respond with an update 
on the status on their claim.
