Latinos Unidos Constitution 

“Latinos Unidos was established at the University of Massachusetts Amherst in the Spring of 
2011 by members of the previous existing LatinX/Hispanic groups, Boricuas Unidos and CASA 
Dominicana, because of the need to serve the larger LatinX/Hispanic community within the 
student body. Its purpose is to provide a student organization for all students interested in 
Latin

é
/Hispanic heritage”. 
​

Section 1: The name of this organization shall be (Latinos Unidos). 

ARTICLE I 
NAME 

ARTICLE II 
PURPOSE 

Section 1: To, to the best of its ability, preserve and promote all LatinX/Hispanic cultures, 
through programming that reflects such cultures, and address its cultural, political, economic, 
and social realities. 

Section 2: To, through self-empowerment and with a strong voice, create unity within the 
é
Latin
/Hispanic community at the University of Massachusetts Amherst, and establish 
​
connections with other such organizations in the Five College area as well as other registered 
student organizations and campus agencies in order to carry out its activities. 

Section 3: To celebrate cultural diversity through intellectual and social activities; such as dance, 
music, and food. 

Section 4: To advocate on behalf of the Latin
Latin
Latin

é
/Hispanic descent, at the University of Massachusetts Amherst, and on behalf of the 
​
é
/Hispanic community in general when required. 
​

é
/Hispanic students’ interests, be native born or of 
​

Section 5: To create and run programs to address the elimination of discriminatory practices in 
areas such as educational outreach, student recruitment, admissions, financial support, retention, 
student/community relations, and legal issues. 

Section 6: To assist and support other organizations, institutions, agencies, corporations, 
associations, etc., organized around the same goals as Latinos Unidos. 

Section 7: To maintain the tradition of annual events such as HASA CASA, Noche Latina, Mr. 
& Miss Latinos Unidos and other smaller events such as bachata & dominos, and chips and salsa, 
etc. As well as the initiation of our own individualized RSO events. 

  
​
  
                                                                    
 
                                                        
 
​
                                                                    
 
                                                                    
 
​
​
​
                                                                    
 
                                                                    
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 ARTICLE III 
STATEMENT OF FREE SPEECH and NON- DISCRIMINATION 

Section 1: Under no circumstances shall a member’s freedom of speech or expression be 
infringed.   

Section 2: Membership will be open to any students or faculty members from UMass Amherst or 
the five-college consortium regardless of race, color, national origin, religion, sex, gender 
identity (including gender expression), sexual orientation, disability, age, marital status, 
family/parental status, income derived from a public assistance program, political beliefs, or 
reprisal or retaliation for prior civil rights activity. 

Latinos Unidos at the University of Massachusetts Amherst

 prohibits discrimination 
Section 3: 
under Federal and State law, based on race, color, national origin, religion, sex, gender identity 
(including gender expression), sexual orientation, disability, age, marital status, family/parental 
status, income derived from a public assistance program, political beliefs, or reprisal or 
retaliation for prior civil rights activity.  

ARTICLE IV 
MEMBERSHIP 

Section 1: Membership is open to all students who are interested in learning about 
LatinX/Hispanic culture. Membership will be open to those who agree with the purpose of this 
organization, abide by its regulations, and demonstrate their commitment to its goals. 

Section 2: An active member as defined by ARTICLE IV, Section 1, shall attend at least four 
meetings per semester and participate actively in the organization’s activities. 

Section 3: Eligible voting members shall be defined as University of Massachusetts Amherst fee 
paying students who have abided by the rules set forth in ARTICLE IV, Sections 1 & 2. 

Section 4: There shall be no discrimination under any circumstances on the basis of race, 
nationality, creed, gender, sexual preference, or age. 

Section 5: The executive board is responsible to sharing this information with their general body 
twice per semester. 

Section 1: Elections shall be held during a general body meeting by April 1
​ , every year, and 
every top 4 titles shall run for a one-year period; non-top 4 titles shall run on a semester basis. 

st

ARTICLE V 
ELECTIONS 

 
 
 
​
​
 
                                                                    
 
 
                                                        
 
  
  
  
                                                                    
 
​
 Section 2: Elections shall be by secret ballot. 

Section 3: A candidate running for a top 4 position (President, Vice President, Treasurer, Event 
Coordinator), is required to have prior executive board experience. 

Section 4: Only “active” members as defined by ARTICLE IV, Section 2 shall vote. This 
includes executive board members. 

Section 5: In the result of a tie, the top 4 executive members (President, Vice President, 
Treasurer, Event Coordinator), will vote individually by a secret ballot to break the tie. 

Section 6: The secretary shall record the minutes and results of the election, then inform the 
executive board and the general body members.  

Section 7: Executive board members terms shall last from the date of their election until the 
following election. 

Section 1: 

ARTICLE VI 
THE EXECUTIVE BOARD  

a) The organization will be headed by an Executive Board composed of nine to eleven 
members, but no less than four student members. 

b) All Executive Board positions will be open to general elections as prescribed herein. 

c) All Executive Board members will be responsible for all policies and administrative 
decision making for the organization. 

d) The Executive Board is responsible to the general body and should make decisions 
with them in mind. 

Section 2:                            
​The Executive Board shall consist of: 
(a)
​   
​President 
1.
​     
​Vice-President 
2.
​     
3.
​Treasurer 
​     
​Event Coordinator (2 available chairs) 
4.
​     
​Secretary 
5.
​     
​Public Relations (2 available chairs) 
6.
​     
​RSO Liaison  
7.
​     
​La Raza Co-Chairs  
8.
​     
​Cayena Co-Coordinators (2 available chairs) 
9.
​     

                                                                    
 
 
  
 
  
 
                                                                    
 
  
  
  
  
  
                                                                    
 
 
 (b)  Any person shall be allowed to run for all positions excluding President, 
Vice-president, Event Coordinator and Treasurer. Top 4 titles. 

(c) For President, Vice-president, Event Coordinator and Treasurer, previous Latinos Unidos 
executive board experience is required. 

(d) Dance Coordinators are appointed to their position by the previous dance 
coordinators. 

(e) Exceptions can be made when no previous executive board member wishes to run for 
the positions described above.  

(g) In the event of a known absence, the President and Vice-President must be informed. 

(h) Two Executive board members should plan to attend the bi-weekly cultural council 
Meetings. Typically, the President or Vice President and the Secretary or Event 
Coordinator should be attending. 

Section 3: The President & Vice-President 

(a) The President shall preside over and call all meetings to order. 

(b) They shall be one of the persons authorized to deal with all administrative and 
financial matters of the organization. 

(c) The President’s main responsibility is to speak on behalf of the Executive Board and 
will not make policy decisions for the organization on they own without consultation of the 
executive board. They are the Primary contact of the organization on Campus Pulse. 

(d) Both the President and Vice-President should have been an official member of the 
previous Executive Board or have been an experienced, active group member. 

(e) The President and Vice-President shall overlook all subcommittees and Executive 
Boards in the organization. 

(f) The President and Vice-President should be in contact regularly with everyone who 
has an outstanding task assigned. They should make sure that tasks are being completed 
and help out when necessary. 

(g) The Vice-President should seek out potential fundraising activities and help the 
President as needed. These fundraising activities should be brought to the E-board meetings at 
least once a month at the beginning of every month. 

(h) The Vice-President will oversee the Public Relations Officers. Making sure Public 

  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
 Relations maintains relationships and connections with 5-College, Amherst community 
and other nearby organizations, to accomplish our goals under ARTICLE II. 

Section 4: In the event of either the President or Vice-President’s absences: by their request, the 
Secretary shall preside over and call the meetings to order. If they are not present, the Event 
Coordinator presides over and calls the meetings to order. 

Section 5: The Treasurer 

(a) The Treasurer is responsible for the books, financial records and administration of any 
of the organization’s money, according to the decision of the general body and Executive 
Board. 

(b) The Treasurer is to have signature responsibility and works closely with the President 
to determine how much an event will cost and if it is in the organization’s best interest. At least 
two members will have signature responsibility; typically the Treasurer and Event Coordinator, 
unless deemed otherwise due to extreme circumstances. If the Treasurer and Event Coordinator 
are not able to have signature responsibility, than it is at the discretion of the board which two 
members of the board have signature responsibility. 

(c) The Treasurer must also write grants/proposals and fill out purchase orders. 

(d) The Treasurer must know and report the updated balance of both accounts when 
asked, this can be found through their access to Summit Administrative Systems and 
meetings with the advisor. 

(e) The Treasurer is to fill out the Budget Request form for the following year by the set 
deadline, determined by the SGA. 

(f) The treasurer is also responsible for filling out SASP and purchase requests as 
necessary. The treasurer shall also coordinate the person to pick up the SASP card based 
on who is most knowledgeable about the purchase. 

(g) The treasurer shall also be stationed at the ticket counter during events to assist the 
SORC and or judge outfits in the case of any pricing distinctions based on attire. 

(h) The treasurer shall also be responsible to creating any spreadsheets detailing budgets 
of any collaboration events and will be responsible for transferring or ensuring that 
Latinos Unidos gets money transferred in the event of a money exchange. 

Section 6: The Event Coordinator 

​The Events Coordinator or Co-Coordinators (if deemed necessary) shall book space by 
(a)
​   
creating events through Campus Pulse as soon as three possible dates and locations are chosen. 
At least two members will have signature responsibility; typically the Event Coordinator and 

                                
 
                                                                    
 
  
  
 
  
  
  
  
  
              
  
 Treasurer, unless deemed otherwise due to extreme circumstances. If the Event Coordinator and 
Treasurer are not able to have signature responsibility, than it is at the discretion of the board 
which two members of the board have signature responsibility. 

​The Event Coordinator shall be responsible for creating and maintaining all records of all the 
​  

(b)
events including the examples of itinerary, logistical plan, food waiver, AFS, acquiring ticket 
services through the SORC, Room diagram, Menu creation, updating flyers on campus pulse, 
and creating lanyard for events as necessary etc. 

​The event coordinator shall also book rehearsal/audition space and run rehearsals/auditions 
​   

(c)
prior to showcases excluding Cayena, which will be the responsibility of the Dance 
Coordinators. 

Section 7: The Secretary 

​The Secretary is responsible for conducting executive board meetings. All executive board 
​   

(a)
members must email the secretary with concerns/ suggestions/ topics to be discussed at the 
meeting at least 24 hours in advance.  They shall also be responsible for recording the minutes 
during executive board and general board meetings when needed. The minutes must be emailed 
out to the Eboard within 24 hours of the meeting. 

​The Secretary shall check UMass Gmail daily, keep the contacts updated, and actively inform 
​  

(b)
the executive board of any important correspondence or opportunities. 

​The Secretary shall be responsible to renewing our office space with SGA at the end of each 
(c)
​   
year. 

Section 8: The Public Relations Officers 

​The Public Relations Officers shall preside over the public affairs of Latinos Unidos 
​   

(a)
including social media. 

​They shall serve as liaison between Latinos Unidos and various organizations on campus/off 
​  

(b)
campus.       

​They will create and maintain good communication with the Registered Student 
(c)
​   
Organizations (RSOs) from the Five Colleges. This includes keeping our Executive Board 
updated on their events and notifying them of our events. 

​They shall coordinate all publicity for Latinos Unidos. This means taking photos at events, 
​  

(d)
posting and printing flyers, making Facebook events, Tweeting, etc. 

​They shall maintain adequate public relations with the Executive Board, the general 
​   

(e)
body, and the public.  

 
  
                                                       
 
  
  
  
                                                                                
                                                                    
 
  
  
 
  
  
  
  
 (f) They shall be responsible for communicating and networking with cultural 
organizations, fraternities, and sororities. 

Section 9: The La Raza Coordinator  

(a) La Raza Coordinator shall preside over the fundraising affairs of Latinos Unidos 
. 
(b) They shall serve as liaison between Latinos Unidos and the Student Government 
Association as a point person to the Secretary and the Undersecretary of Diversity, and 
other organizations, to provide updates and inform the community about upcoming events.  

(c) The RSO Liaison shall host at least 2 social justice related events per semester. 

(d) They are responsible for developing and reviewing fundraising strategies.   

(e) They shall have a fundraising goal, keep track of all collected funds, while overseeing 
all fundraising activity. 

(f) They are responsible for writing and presenting proposals to solicit necessary funds. 

Section 10: The RSO Liaison 

(h) They shall be continuously networking with other organizations and communities to 
search for fundraising and community service opportunities. 

(i) They will keep the executive board informed of happenings on campus such as 
Defined Residential Community (DRC) initiatives, marches, plays or other events 
pertaining to or embracing the latinX/hispanic culture. 

(j) They shall also be responsible for setting up community service initiatives in the 
Community and tabling in the campus center when necessary. 

(k) Serves as the representative for Latinos Unidos by attending other RSO meetings/ events. 
Keeps the executive board informed and up to date with events and programming put on by other 
campus organizations 

Section 10: The Cayena Dance Troupe Co-Directors 

(a) The Co-Directors of Cayena are responsible for managing the affairs of the “Cayena” 
dance group, as they see fit along with the input from the Executive Board. This includes 
the creation of original dances to be performed for the public. 

(b) They will be committed to promoting LatinX/Hispanic Culture through the art of 
Dance. 

 
  
      
 
                                                                    
 
 
                                                                    
 
  
  
  
  
 
  
  
  
  
 (c) They are responsible for handling all bookings and performances, directing practices 
and organizing biannual auditions (or as seen fit). 

(d) They shall not make any final booking and/or performance decisions without the 
group’s consent. 

(e) They will be responsible for ordering the uniforms for dancers and collecting them at 
the end of each performance 

(f) They shall also be responsible for booking practice space, typically sought out at the 
recreation center on campus.  

Section 12: Officer Absence Requirement and Vacancy Filling 

​No member of the Executive Board shall be allowed more than six unexcused absences 
​   

(a)
(three per semester) or shall be absent for more than three consecutive Executive Board 
meetings. 

(b)
​If ARTICLE VI, Section 12(a) is overseen the officer’s position shall be voted on to keep the 
​  
board member or create a vacancy. If vacant the position in question shall be voted on in the next 
general body meeting, to fill the vacancy. 

(c)

​Excused absences shall be granted by the Executive Board’s discretion. 
​   

ARTICLE VII 

                     CAYENA 

Section 1: “The dance group Cayena was established in October 1994 by a group of members of 
Casa Dominicana interested in promoting the Dominican Republic's folk dancing. As the 
LatinX/Hispanic population grew on campus so did Cayena. Cayena, now, as part of (Latinos 
Unidos) will also perform other folkloric/traditional dances from Latin America." 

Section 2: Auditions will be held the second or third week of September, every year. Auditions 
shall be open to all who are interested in promoting LatinX/Hispanic dance. Spring auditions 
may also be held at the discretion of the dance coordinators 

Section 3: Members of Cayena are responsible for promoting folklore through the art of dance. 
There should be no discrimination on the basis of race, nationality, creed, gender, color, sexual 
preference, or age for admission to Cayena. 

Section 4: Members of Cayena shall abide by all regulations of the general membership. 

Section 5: Members of Cayena shall attend all Cayena’s practices and meetings. In the case that 
a member cannot attend they need to contact the Dance Coordinator 24 hours in advance.  

  
  
  
                                                                    
 
  
  
  
                                                                    
 
                                            
                    
 
                                                                                                        
                                            
 
                                                        
 
  
  
 Section 6: Cayena will perform for all major events of Latinos Unidos, and other campus events 
decided by the dance coordinators. 

Section 7: Cayena may charge a fee for their performances outside of Latinos Unidos, which is 
to be decided by the Executive Board and the dance group. 

Section 8: All revenue generated by Cayena shall be deposited in Latinos Unido’s revenue 
account. However monies that were generated solely by Cayena shall be allocated to them for 
costumes, trips, etc. 

Section 9: A portion of the overall Latinos Unidos budget will be allocated to Cayena at the 
beginning of the year. This amount will be decided upon by the executive board. 

ARTICLE VIII 
MEETINGS 
Section 1: General body meetings shall be held at least twice a month or as deemed necessary by 
the Executive Board. 

Section 2: During general body meetings, except for the officers’ election, the voting will be by 
raising of hands or majority vote. Quorum shall be 50% of the general membership. 

Section 3: Executive Board meetings shall be held at least twice a month or as deemed necessary 
by the Executive Board. Quorum shall be 50% + 1 of the Executive Board. 

ARTICLE IX 
BYLAWS & MEDIA RELATIONS 

Section 1: ByLaws shall be established by the general body to provide detailed procedures to 
carry out or to put in the provisions of the constitution. 

Section 2: ByLaws may be approved and/or changed by a vote of 2/3 of the membership. 

Section 3: The Executive Board shall decide whether or not to make statements to the media on a 
unanimous basis. The statements will then be approved by an advisor and sent to the media 
source if necessary. An individual member may make public statements not on behalf of Latinos 
Unidos. 

ARTICLE X 

CONSTITUTIONAL AMENDMENTS
​

Section 1: This Constitution may be amended at the last general body meeting of every semester 
by a simple majority of all members in good standing defined in ARTICLE II
altered, reformed, repealed, or added to by an affirmative vote of no less than 60% of the general 
membership at a special meeting. Stated quorum shall be reached in order to approve changes. 

Section 1 be 

, 

Section 2: An amendment to this Constitution shall be forwarded to the Student Government 
Association registrar for their action and must gain the approval of the Secretary of the Registry.  

                                                                    
 
 
  
                                                                    
 
                                                                    
 
                                                                    
 
                                                                    
 
                                                                    
 
                                                        
 
                                                        
 
        
 
​
​
                                                                    
 
 ARTICLE XI 
IMPEACHMENT OF AN OFFICER 
Section 1: Should at any point and time an elected officer fail to do their job and refuse to abide 
by the provisions of this document, they shall be entered into the process of impeachment by the 
majority decision of the executive board 

Section 2: Impeachment Process 

​If an officer fails to do their job in a first offense, they shall be given a warning by the 
​   

(a)
president/next highest holding position. 

(b)
​If they fail to abide by that warning, they would have to go to an official meeting with the 
​  
two leading officers of the organization, the President and Vice-President. They could then be 
given one more opportunity to do their job. 

​If they a third time; elections will be held by the entire Executive Board. They would then go 
​   

(c)
before the President and Vice-President in an official meeting, again. 

​At this point, a meeting with the advisor of the group will be held where the decision can be 
​  

(d)
further discussed. 

​If the majority of the group votes for removal, they will be informed of potential removal and 
​   

(e)
emergency elections. 

(f)
​Lastly, if the advisor is in agreement, in addition to the results of emergency elections, the 
​   
board member shall at that point be relieved of their duties and the results of that meeting would 
be reported to the general assembly. The student is still given the opportunity to be a member of 
the organization despite loss of an Executive Board position.

DocsList.Data:
Latinos Unidos Constitution

“Latinos Unidos was established at the University of Massachusetts Amherst in the Spring of 2011 by members of the previous existing Latino/Hispanic groups, Boricuas Unidos and CASA Dominicana, because of the need to serve the larger Latino/Hispanic community within the student body. Its purpose is to provide a student organization for all students interested in Latino/Hispanic heritage”.

ARTICLE I
NAME
Section 1: The name of this organization shall be (Latinos Unidos).
						
ARTICLE II
PURPOSE
Section 1: To, to the best of its ability, Latinos Unidos shall preserve and promote all Latino/Hispanic cultures, through programming that reflects such cultures, and address its cultural, political, economic, and social realities.
					
Section 2: To, through self­-empowerment and with a strong voice, create unity within the Latino/Hispanic community at the University of Massachusetts Amherst, and establish connections with other such organizations in the Five College area as well as other registered student organizations and campus agencies in order to carry out its activities.
						
Section 3: To celebrate cultural diversity through intellectual and social activities; such as dance, music, and food.
						
Section 4: To advocate on behalf of the Latino/Hispanic students’ interests, be native born or of Latino/Hispanic descent, at the University of Massachusetts Amherst, and on behalf of the Latino/Hispanic community in general when required.
						
Section 5: To create and run programs to address the elimination of discriminatory practices in areas such as educational outreach, student recruitment, admissions, financial support, retention, student/community relations, and legal issues.
						
Section 6: To assist and support other organizations, institutions, agencies, corporations, associations, etc., organized around the same goals as Latinos Unidos.

Section 7: To maintain the tradition of annual events such as HASA CASA, Noche Latina, Mr. & Miss Latinos Unidos and other smaller events such as bachata & dominos, and chips and salsa.
						
ARTICLE III
MEMBERSHIP
Section 1: Membership is open to all students who are interested in learning about Latino/Hispanic culture. Membership will be open to those who agree with the purpose of this organization, abide by its regulations, and demonstrate their commitment to its goals.
					
Section 2: An active member as defined by ARTICLE III, Section 1, shall attend at least four meetings per semester and participate actively in the organization’s activities.
Section 3: Eligible voting members shall be defined as University of Massachusetts Amherst fee­ paying students who have abided by rules set forth in ARTICLE III, Sections 1 & 2.

Section 4: There shall be no discrimination under any circumstances on the basis of race, nationality, creed, gender, sexual preference, or age.

Section 5: The executive board is responsible to sharing this information with their general body twice per semester. 
						
ARTICLE IV
ELECTIONS
Section 1: Elections shall be held during a general body meeting, the first week of April, every year, and positions shall run for a one­-year period.
						
Section 2: Elections shall be by secret ballot.

Section 3: Only “active” members as defined by ARTICLE III, Section 2 shall vote. This includes executive board members.

Section 4: The Secretary shall contact all members informing them of election results.
						
ARTICLE V
THE EXECUTIVE BOARD	
Section 1: 

a) The organization will be headed by an Executive Board composed of nine to eleven
members, but no less than four student members.

b) All Executive Board positions will be open to general elections as prescribed herein.

c) All Executive Board members will be responsible for all policies and administrative
decision making for the organization.

d) The Executive Board is responsible to the general body and should make decisions
with them in mind.

						
Section 2: 
The Executive Board shall consist of: 
President 
Vice­-President
Treasurer
Event Coordinator
Secretary
Public Relations (3 available chairs)
La Raza Coordinator
La Raza Co-Chairs (2 available chairs)
Dance Troupe­ - Cayena Co­-Directors (2 available chairs)

(b) Any person shall be allowed to run for all positions excluding president,
Vice-president, event coordinator and Dance Troupe Coordinators. 

(c) For president, vice-president and event coordinator, previous Latinos Unidos
executive board experience is preferred. 

(d) Dance Coordinators are appointed to their position by the previous dance
coordinators. 

(e) Exceptions can be made when no previous executive board member wishes to run for
the positions described above. 

(g) In the event of a known absence, the President and Vice-President must be informed. 

(h) Two Executive board members should plan to attend the bi-weekly cultural council
Meetings. Typically, the President or Vice President and the Secretary or Event
Coordinator should be attending. 

Section 3: The President & Vice-President

(a) The President shall preside over and call all meetings to order.

(b) They shall be one of the persons authorized to deal with all administrative and
financial matters of the organization.

(c) The President’s main responsibility is to speak on behalf of the Executive Board and
will not make policy decisions for the organization on his/her own. He/she is the Primary
Contact of the organization on Campus Pulse.

(d) Both the President and Vice-­President should have been an official member of the
previous Executive Board or have been an experienced, active group member.

(e) The President is to have signature responsibility along with the Treasurer, unless
voted against by the Executive Board, at least 6/10.

(f) The President and Vice-­President shall write up the agenda for the Executive Board
And email it to the E­board at least 24 hours prior to the next meeting.

(g) The President and Vice-­President shall overlook all subcommittees and Executive
Boards in the organization.

(h) The President and Vice­-President should be in contact regularly with everyone who
has an outstanding task assigned. They should make sure that tasks are being completed
and help out when necessary.

(i) The Vice­-President should seek out potential fundraising activities and help the
president as needed.

(j) The Vice-President will oversee the Public Relations Officers. Making sure Public
Relations maintains relationships and connections with 5­-College, Amherst community
and other nearby organizations, to accomplish our goals under ARTICLE II.
			
Section 4: In the event of either the President or Vice­-President’s absences: by their request, the Secretary shall preside over and call the meetings to order. If they are also not present, the Event Coordinator presides over and calls the meetings to order.
						
Section 5: The Treasurer

(a) The Treasurer is responsible for the books, financial records and administration of any
of the organization’s money, according to the decision of the general body and Executive
Board.

(b) The Treasurer is to have signature responsibility and works closely with the President
to determine how much an event will cost and if it is in the organization’s best interest.

(c) The Treasurer must also write grants/proposals and fill out purchase orders.

(d) The Treasurer must know and report the updated balance of both accounts when
asked, this can be found through his/her access to Summit Administrative Systems and
meetings with the advisor.

(e) The Treasurer is to fill out the Budget Request form for the following year by the set
deadline, determined by the SGA.

(f) The treasurer is also responsible for filling out SASP and purchase requests as
Necessary. The treasurer shall also coordinator the person to pick up the SASP card based
on who is most knowledgeable about the purchase. 

(g) The treasurer shall also be stationed at the ticket counter during events to assist the
SORC and or judge outfits in the case of any pricing distinctions based on attire. 

(h) The treasurer shall also be responsible to creating any spreadsheets detailing budgets
of any collaboration events and will be responsible to transferring or ensuring that
Latinos Unidos gets money transferred in the event of a money exchange. 
						
Section 6: The Secretary

The Secretary is responsible for recording the minutes during Executive Board and general Body meetings. The minutes must be emailed out to the E­board within 24 hours of the meeting.

The secretary shall check UMass Gmail daily, keep the contacts updated, and actively inform the executive board of any important correspondence or opportunities.

The secretary shall be responsible to renewing our office space with SGA at the end of each year. 
							
Section 7: The Event Coordinator

The Events Coordinator shall book space by creating events through Campus Pulse as soon as three possible dates and locations are chosen.

The Event Coordinator shall be responsible for creating and maintaining all records of all the events including the examples of itinerary, logistical plan, food waiver, AFS, acquiring ticket services through the SORC, Room diagram, Menu creation, updating flyers on campus pulse, and creating lanyard for events as necessary etc.

The event coordinator shall also book rehearsal/audition space and run rehearsals/auditions prior to showcases excluding Cayena, which will be the responsibility of the Dance Coordinators.
						
Section 8: The Public Relations Officers

The Public Relations officers shall preside over the public affairs of Latinos Unidos including social media.

They shall serve as liaison between Latinos Unidos and various organizations on campus/off campus.	

They will create and maintain good communication with the Registered Student Organizations (RSOs) from the Five Colleges. This includes keeping our Executive Board updated on their events and notifying them of our events.

They shall coordinate all publicity for Latinos Unidos. This means taking photos at events, posting and printing flyers, making Facebook events, Tweeting, etc.

They shall maintain adequate public relations with the Executive Board, the general
body, and the public.	

(f) They shall be responsible for communicating and networking with cultural
organizations, fraternities, and sororities.
				
Section 9: The La Raza Coordinator

(a) La Raza Coordinator shall preside over the fundraising affairs of Latinos Unidos.
	
(b) They are responsible for developing and reviewing fundraising strategies.
						
(c) They shall have a fundraising goal, keep track of all collected funds, while overseeing
all fundraising activity.

(d) They shall be continuously networking with other organizations and communities to
search for fundraising and community service opportunities.
						
(e) They are responsible for writing and presenting proposals to solicit necessary funds.

(f) La Raza Coordinator shall be responsible for appointing 2 co-chairs to help facilitate
events and activities.

(g) La Raza Coordinator shall host at least 2 social justice related events per semester. 

(h) They will keep the executive board informed of happenings on campus such as
Defined Residential Community (DRC) initiatives, marches, plays or other events
pertaining to or embracing the latino/hispanic culture

(i) They shall also be responsible for setting up community service initiatives in the
Community and tabling in the campus center when necessary. 

(j) They shall serve as liaison between Latinos Unidos and the Student Government
Association as a point person to the Secretary and the Undersecretary of Diversity, and
other organizations, to provide updates and inform the community on upcoming events.

Section 10: The Cayena Dance Troupe Co-Directors

(a) The Co-­Directors of Cayena are responsible for managing the affairs of the “Cayena”
dance group, as they see fit along with the input from the Executive Board. This includes
the creation of original dances to be performed for the public. 

(b) They will be committed to promoting Latino/Hispanic Culture through the art of
Dance.

(c) They are responsible for handling all bookings and performances, directing practices
and organizing bi­annual auditions (or as seen fit).

(d) They shall not make any final booking and/or performance decisions without the
group’s consent.

(e) They will be responsible for ordering the uniforms for dancers and collecting them at
the end of each performance

(f) They shall also be responsible for booking practice space, typically sought out at the
recreation center on campus.  
						
Section 12: Officer Absence Requirement and Vacancy Filling

No member of the Executive Board shall be allowed more than six unexcused absences (three per semester) or shall be absent for more than three consecutive Executive Board meetings. 

If ARTICLE V, Section 12(a) is overseen the officer’s position shall be voted on to keep the board member or create a vacancy. If vacant the position in question shall be voted on in the next general body meeting, to fill the vacancy.

Excused absences shall be granted by the Executive Board’s discretion.
						
ARTICLE VI
						CAYENA
Section 1: “The dance group Cayena was established in October 1994 by a group of members of Casa Dominicana interested in promoting the Dominican Republic's folk dancing. As the Latino/Hispanic population grew on campus so did Cayena. Cayena, now, as part of (Latinos Unidos) will also perform other folkloric/traditional dances from Latin America."
		
Section 2: Auditions will be held the second or third week of September, every year. Auditions shall be open to all who are interested in promoting Latino/Hispanic dance. Spring auditions may also be held at the discretion of the dance coordinators
													
Section 3: Members of Cayena are responsible for promoting folklore through the art of dance. There should be no discrimination on the basis of race, nationality, creed, gender, color, sexual preference, or age for admission to Cayena.
					
Section 4: Members of Cayena shall abide by all regulations of the general membership.

Section 5: Members of Cayena shall attend Cayena’s practices and meetings.

Section 6: Cayena will perform for all major events of Latinos Unidos, and other campus events decided by the dance coordinators.
						
Section 7: Cayena may charge a fee for their performances outside of Latinos Unidos, whic is to be decided by the Executive Board and the dance group.
Section 8: All revenue generated by Cayena shall be deposited in Latinos Unido’s revenue account. However monies that were generated solely by Cayena shall be allocated to them for costumes, trips, etc.

Section 9: A portion of the overall Latinos Unidos budget will be allocated to Cayena at the beginning of the year. This amount will be decided upon by the executive board. 
						
ARTICLE VII
MEETINGS
Section 1: General body meetings shall be held at least twice a month or as deemed necessary by the Executive Board.
						
Section 2: During general body meetings, except for the officers’ election, the voting will be by rising of hands or majority vote. Quorum shall be 50% of the general membership.
						
Section 3: Executive Board meetings shall be held at least twice a month or as deemed necessary by the Executive Board. Quorum shall be 50% + 1 of the Executive Board.
						
ARTICLE VII
BYLAWS & MEDIA RELATIONS
Section 1: ByLaws shall be established by the general body to provide detailed procedures to carry out or to put in the provisions of the constitution.
						
Section 2: ByLaws may be approved and/or changed by a vote of 2/3 of the membership.
					
Section 3: The Executive Board shall decide whether or not to make statements to the media on a unanimous basis. The statements will then be approved by an advisor and sent to the media source if necessary. 
					
ARTICLE VIII
CONSTITUTIONAL AMENDMENTS	
Section 1: This Constitution may be altered, reformed, repealed, or added to by an affirmative vote of no less than 3/4 of the general membership at a special meeting. Stated quorum shall be reached in order to approve changes.
						
Section 2: An amendment to this Constitution shall be forwarded to the Student Government Association registrar for their action.
						
ARTICLE XI
IMPEACHMENT OF AN OFFICER
Section 1: Should at any point and time an elected officer fail to do his or her job and refuse to abide by the provisions of this document, he or she shall be entered into the process of impeachment by the majority decision of the executive board
						
Section 2: Impeachment Process

If an officer fails to do his or her job in a first offense, he or she shall be given a warning by the president/next highest holding position.

If he or she fails to abide by that warning, he or she would have to go to an official meeting with the two leading officers of the organization, the President and Vice­-President. He or she could then be given one more opportunity to do their job.

If he or she fails a third time; elections will be held by the entire Executive Board. He or she would then go before the President and Vice-­President in an official meeting, again.

At this point, a meeting with the advisor of the group will be held where the decision can be further discussed.

If the majority of the group votes for removal, she/he will be informed of potential removal and emergency elections.

Lastly, if the advisor is in agreement, in addition to the results of emergency elections, the board member shall at that point be relieved of his/her duties and the results of that meeting would be reported to the general assembly. The student is still given the opportunity to be a member of the organization despite loss of an Executive Board position.

DocsList.Data:
LEADING WOMEN OF TOMORROW

UNIVERSITY OF MASSACHUSETTS CHAPTER

Article 1: Name

CONSTITUTION

The name of this organization shall be Leading Women of Tomorrow at the University of

Massachusetts Amherst.

Article 2: Mission Statement

The UMass Amherst chapter of Leading Women of Tomorrow is a bi-partisan
organization with the intention of addressing gender gaps in legislatures and public service.
Through education, voter enfranchisement, and community outreach, we seek to encourage
young women of all majors to become vocal advocates. We aim to become a strong activist
organization to advocate for women and minority groups through the creation of educational
opportunities for members and local public school students, professional development activities,
and community engagement. As an intersectional organization, we welcome people of all
genders and backgrounds in an effort to create a more diverse and representative generation of
leaders.

Article 3: Chapter Objectives

Section 1. This Chapter will seek to motivate the next generation of women to seek

leadership opportunities and equal representation in government.

Section 2. Through the provision of educational resources and workshops, this chapter

will seek to educate students on how to remove gender equality barriers and inspire members to
positions of leadership in public service.

Section 3. This organization will attempt to change the community perspective around

gender and gender identity in public service through facilitated conversation.

Section 4. In order to create a space for growth and acceptance, this Chapter will

welcome all people regardless of affiliation, beliefs, and background to inspire collaboration.

Section 5. This Chapter will seek to empower women to embrace who they are and take

pride in their identity.

 Article 4: Programming

Section 1. This Chapter will accomplish its objectives through a variety of activities and

events, as defined here:

Guest Lecturers
Voting Registration Events
Fundraising Events
Professional Development Workshops

I.
II.
III.
IV.
V. Mock Trial Days
VI.
VII.
VIII.

Advocacy Campaigns (i.e Social Media)
Community Service
Networking Events

Article 5: Five Year Goals

Section 1. The goal of this club is to create an activism organization for students to

utilize to advocate for women, minority groups, and issues relevant to the mission of the
National organization.

Section 2. This Chapter will educate more underclassmen on the importance of public

service and equal representation.

Section 3. Through collaboration with local public schools, this organization will
encourage students in middle and high school to develop leadership skills and give them
confidence to become vocal leaders with the use of civics lessons and programming.

Section 4. All interested students will be provided with resources for pursuing positions

in public service, such as internship opportunities, peer mentoring, and education on
scholarships.

Section 5. This organization will provide resources on proper interview behavior and

attire while holding annual drives for appropriate professional clothes.

Section 6. This Chapter will create a campus-wide conversation about gender identity in

politics and society and facilitate acceptance and tolerance.

Article 6: Membership

 Section 1. Any UMass student may become a member of LWT. The admission will not
be based on race, creed, gender, sexual preference, physical ability or any other discriminatory
criteria.

Section 2. No hazing or discrimination will be used as a condition of membership in this

organization. The Chapter prohibits dicrimination under Federal and State law, based on race,
color, national origin, religion, sex, gender identity (including gender expression), sexual
orientation, disability, age, maritial status, family/parental status, income derived from public
assistance program, political beliefs, or reprisal or retaliation for prior civil rights activity, or any
part of someone’s identity.

Section 3. All members of the UMass Amherst Chapter of LWT are entitled to freedom

of speech and through self-empowerment and with a strong voice, create unity within the
community of the University of Massachusetts Amherst, and establish connections with other
such organization in the Five College Area, as well as, other registered student organizations and
campus agencies in order to carry out its. Under no circumstances shall a member’s freedom of
speech or expression be infringed.

Sections 4. Any prospective voting members must be in compliance with National and

UMass Chapter requirements and adhere to the following procedure for becoming an
acknowledged member of the Chapter:

I.
II.

Sign up for the mailing list with the Secretary via Google Form
Pay annual chapter fee of $15 within thirty (30) days of registration

Section 5. In order to be recognized as an official member of Leading Women of
Tomorrow at the University of Massachusetts Amherst, one must have paid dues for the
semester. However, non-due paying persons are allowed to participate in events and non-voting
membership is available for any member of the 5-college community, their dependents, staff,
faculty, and alumni.

Section 6. Dues may be set by the Executive Board although such dues shall not exceed
$25 for the year or $15 for the semester. In the event that a member cannot pay dues, they must
be provided an alternative mechanism for fulfilling this requirement such as a payment plan or
executive board sanctioned service to the organization or participate in at least 5 events, not
including general body meetings, per semester (Fall/Spring only).

Section 7. Membership may be revoked without a mutual agreement for any misconduct

or violations of this Constitution. Members will be informed of their potential revocation 48

 hours prior to the vote by the executive board. To remove a member, there must be a two-thirds
vote by the general body.

Section 8. Members may appeal a revocation of membership for up to one week after

being notified of their membership revokement. To appeal, they must make their case to the
executive board and wait for the board to vote, which must result in a majority vote for
reinstatement.

Article 7: Meetings

Section 1. This club shall be active during the fall and spring academic semesters, with

limited activity during the summer.

Section 2. There shall be two general body meetings per month, with the exception of the

summer semester, with the first one occurring within the first 3 weeks of the fall semester. The
executive board will agree upon the dates for the general body meetings. Each meeting will be
run collectively and follow parliamentary procedure.

Section 3. There shall be two executive board meetings per month, taking place on

opposite weeks from the general body meetings during the fall and spring semesters. The
executive board will agree upon the dates for the general body meeting. The President of the
Chapter shall preside over each meeting and will follow parliamentary procedure.

Section 4. There shall be a minimum of 1 event or workshop per month, with the

exception of the summer semester.

Section 5. Order of Business. Each general body meeting will uphold the mission and

goals of the Chapter. Unless altered or suspended at any meeting by a majority vote of the
members present, shall follow the order of business at meetings which goes as follows:

I.
II.
III.
IV.
V.
VI.
VII.

Ascertainment of members present
Reading of minutes of previous meeting
Reports of Officers
Elections (during the Annual Meeting and Special Election Meetings)
Unfinished Business
New Business
Adjournment

Section 6. Members must attend ⅔ of the general body meetings to be in good standing.

Article 8: Elections

 Section 1. Elections for the next school year will be held between March 1st and April

1st of the spring semester during a regularly scheduled general body meeting where two-thirds of
the active members of the Chapter shall be present. No business will be conducted at the said
meeting except for elections. Any member who is in compliance with membership requirements
listed above can vote in elections.

Section 2. Any Chapter member who is in good standing with both the national and

UMass Chapter requirements is eligible to run for office.

Section 3. All voting will take place using a secret ballot. Secret ballot will be used
during all elections including decisions to remove an officer. Secret ballots must be used to
conduct a vote on any topic if at least one-third of members request their use.

Section 4. Persons running for executive board positions must receive a majority of votes

to be appointed to the position.

Section 5. In the event of a tie during an election, the election shall be resolved by a
majority vote by the executive board. If there is a tie with the executive board, the President shall
cast the deciding vote.

Section 6. Newly elected officers shall shadow former officers from time of appointment

to the end of the Spring semester.

Section 7. Special Elections. Special Elections shall be held in the case of an unexpected

vacancy in the Executive Board. The process for Special Elections shall be as follows:

I.

II.

III.

The President of the Chapter shall call a Special General Body Meeting to
hold elections giving at least a seven (7) day notice to the membership. The
notice shall include the date, location, time, and the position(s) that are open.
Any person looking to run for the open position can give notice to the
President at any point before the elections begin and will be added to the
ballot.
The membership shall convene for the meeting and vote following regular
voting rules.

Section 8. Record Keeping of Elections: The standing Secretary of the Chapter shall keep

the minutes of the electoral meeting; including but not limited to:

IV.
V.
VI.
VII.

Attendance of membership, including whether or not a quorum was met;
Names of the candidates and the positions they are running for;
Names of the newly elected officials;
The date of the next meeting

 Article 9: Officers

Section 1. This club shall elect a President, Vice-President, Secretary, Treasurer, Director

of Public Relations, Director of Political Affairs, and Director of Events.

Section 2. Regular elections for all officer positions shall be held only once per calendar

year unless otherwise called for by a majority of the General Body or in the case of a special
election. Nominations for executive board positions will be announced by the President no more
than four weeks and no less than 2 weeks prior to the election. Elections will be facilitated by the
President who may be assisted by the Vice President. Officers must be elected by a majority vote
by members.

Section 3. Past officers shall hold office until a transition meeting can be completed.

Section 4. Any officer may be removed from office for gross negligence of their duties

by a two-thirds vote by the executive board if they 1) have not been fulfilling their duties within
the first month of holding their position or 2) within the course of holding their position, the
board agrees the officer has not been fulfilling their duties. Any officer considered for removal
shall be notified and given an opportunity to address the members of the Chapter. In order to
remove an officer from the Executive Board, there must be a two-thirds vote by the general body.

Section 5. An officer may resign from office with two weeks’ notice before the next

general body meeting with a formal resignation letter given to the President.

Section 6. In the event of any vacant position due to officer removal or resignation, a

one-week application process will proceed and a special election will be held.

Section 7. No officer may incur any indebtedness on behalf of the club without prior club

approval. Any handling of funds of transactions shall be carried out with approval from the
President or Vice-President.

Section 8. Any decisions made by an officer may be overridden by a simple majority

vote at a general body meeting or executive board meeting.

Section 9. The executive board shall have the authority to create and appoint positions as
they see fit. These positions shall be filled through an application process followed by a majority
vote by the executive board. These positions will not be a part of the executive board.

 Article 10: Officer Duties

Section 1. All officers must have a minimum 2.0 GPA and working knowledge of the

club’s constitution.

Section 2. All officers are required to complete designated tasks weekly unless specified

by the executive board.

Section 3. All officers shall (a) perform their assigned duties; (b) train their successors;
(c) turn over all club material after the end of their term in office; (d) perform duties not listed
that may be necessary or as directed by the President or executive board. Any officers in
disagreement may appeal to the executive board.

Section 4. President. The President shall (a) Stand as the spokesperson for the
organization and lead meetings; (b) Delegate tasks to board members to accomplish the goals of
the organization; (c) Collect member feedback and establish the ideas of the members; (d)
approve all amendments to our constitution; (e) Organize times and settings for executive board
meetings and general body meetings; (f) Shall maintain signature responsibility.

Section 5. Vice President. The Vice President shall (a) Facilitate meetings in the absence
of the President; (b) Assist and Facilitate all board members in their duties of office; (c) Maintain
a log of all active members; (d) Creates and maintains meeting and event attendance logs; (e)
Ensure the constitution is being upheld.

Section 6. Secretary. The Secretary shall (a) Keep a record of all organization meetings

and meeting minutes; (b) Send out emails following meetings with important information
discussed; (c) Maintain all email lists for the organizations; (d) Create a comprehensive calendar
of all events and meetings of the Chapter; (e) Create Facebook rsvp lists for chapter events and
meetings.

Section 7. Treasurer. The Treasurer shall (a) Organize all fundraising activities while

abiding by University rules; (b) Keep a record of all organization spending; (c)  Make sure RSO
money is spent while following university rules; (d) Create a fundraising plan for each semester
and have approval from the board; (e) Maintain records of due and members who pay them; (f)
Shall maintain signature responsibility.

Section 8. Director of Membership Engagement. The Director of Membership

Engagement shall (a) Coordinate and implement a student recognition program focused on
making students aware of Chapter opportunities; (b) Promote Chapter opportunities to

 non-members through information and advertising; (c) Brainstorm and execute unique ideas to
increase membership.

Section 8. Director of Public Relations. The Director of Public Relations shall (a)
Manage all aspects of the chapter social media outlets and posts; (b) Respond to and interact with
members and supporters on Social Media; (c) Create graphics and other creative materials for the
Chapter; (d) Send out bi-weekly emails regarding events, meetings, and reminders; (e) Reach out
to student press on behalf of the chapter.

Section 9. Director of Political Affairs. The Director of Political Affairs shall (a)
Establish and maintain all relationships between the chapter and other entities; (b)Research and
give political updates to the board; (c) Work with President to develop the general body meeting
learning component; (d) Find and facilitate opportunities that the chapter can participate in; (e)
Research and coordinate guest speakers for chapter meetings and events.

Section 10. Director of Events. The Director of Events shall (a) Coordinate with other

on-campus organizations to facilitate joint events; (b) Coordinate and attend all Market
Wednesday, Involvement Fair, and other tabling events; (c) Coordinate all chapter events from
the planning process through the end of the event; (d) Work with the Director of Public Relations
to promote chapter events; (e) Obtain event ideas from chapter members and chapter board.

Article 11: Executive Board

Section 1. The executive board will consist of the President, Vice President, Secretary,

Treasurer, Director of Membership Engagement, Director of Public Relations, Director of
Political Affairs, and Director of Events.

Section 2. The executive board shall meet at least twice monthly at a predetermined time,

agreed upon by all executive board members.

Section 3. All members of the executive board are required to attend all executive board
meetings and chapter events unless an extenuating circumstance arises. In the event of this, the
board member must provide the President with a written explanation within 48 hours prior to the
event.

Section 4. In the event where the President is unable to chair the executive board, the
Vice-President shall take the President’s place. When the vice-president if absent, the meeting
shall be chaired by the next officer listed, and so on.

 Article 12: Ad-Hoc Committees

Section 1. Ad-Hoc Committees may be created upon a vote by the executive board.

Chairs may be appointed by a majority vote of the executive board for the specific purpose and
duration to be announced at the time of the committee’s creation. All committee meeting times
shall be set by the committee chair.

Section 2. All committee decisions must be transmitted to the executive board for

approval.

Section 3. All ad-hoc committee decisions may be overridden by a simple majority vote

at a general body or executive assembly meeting within one month of the decision.

Article 13: Advisor

Section 1. It is the duty of the current president to ensure there is an advisor for the club.

Section 2. The advisor must be a full-time faculty or staff member at the University of

Massachusetts Amherst and may not be granted voting rights in any form, including as an
ex-officio member.

Section 3. The advisor will act as a liaison between the executive board and other faculty

members and provide insight as needed and requested.

Section 4. Upon a presidency change, the departing president must facilitate

communication between the new president and the organization’s advisor.

Article 14: Finances

Section 1. At a minimum, the treasurer and president must both maintain signature

responsibility.

Section 2. Any form needing a signature from a board member with signature

responsibility must be shown to all board members before it is signed in order to ensure all board
members understand what is being signed

Section 3. No university student may be denied membership due to inability to pay dues.

If a member is not able to pay dues, other arrangements will be made as proposed by the
treasurer and agreed on in quorum by the executive board.

 Article 15: Amendments

Section 1. The constitution may be amended at any general body meeting of the club

upon a two-thirds vote, provided that the amendment was submitted at least seven days prior to
the General body meeting. The amendment of this Constitution must be passed by a simple
majority by the general body of the Chapter and have the approval of the Secretary of the
Registry.

Article 16. Publications

Section 1. All printed media must be approved by the Director of Public Relations or a

majority of the Executive Board.

Article 17. Compliance with University and State Regulations

Section 1. This club, as an official student organization of the University of

Massachusetts Amherst, shall adhere to the policy regulations in the Registered Student
Organization Handbook.

Constitution of the Minorities and Philosophy Chapter at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.docx
DocsList.Data:
Constitution of the Minorities and Philosophy Chapter at the University of Massachusetts Amherst (First Edition)
Article I. Name
The official name for this organization is the Minorities and Philosophy Chapter at UMass, or UMass MAP.

Article II. Purpose
 The purpose of UMass MAP is to facilitate and support activities that meet the academic,
 social, cultural, and professional needs of students in the philosophy department at the
 University of Massachusetts Amherst. 
 This organization aims to examine and address issues of minority participation in
 philosophy, and to foster a sense of community between minority students and faculty.
 All activities of this organization must be directed toward this purpose. 

Article III. Affiliations
 This organization is a recognized graduate student organization at the University of
 Massachusetts Amherst. As such, it agrees to follow GSS guidelines and restrictions, and
 will have its ‘Active’ GSO status renewed each school year by the Executive Board. 
 This organization is affiliated with MAP, and as such it agrees to participate in
 conversations among all MAP chapters and end-of-the-year reporting as needed. The
 President and Secretary shall be subscribed to the MAP International listserv.

Article IV. Membership
 Membership Qualifications
Membership shall be open to all graduate students in the philosophy department at the University of Massachusetts Amherst. 
Membership decisions will not discriminate on the basis of race, ethnicity, national origin, religion, sex, gender identity, sexual orientation, disability status, marital status. 
Active members are those who attend the biannual UMass MAP meetings at the beginning of each semester. 
 Member Rights
All members are eligible to attend all meetings and events of this organization. 
Active members can approach members of the Board at any time to raise concerns or make suggestions about chapter events and/or programming, and to establish an ad hoc committee or group.  
All active members have the right to vote on all proposed amendments to the constitution. 

 Article V. Officers 
 Executive Board Titles and Duties
President- The President will chair all meetings of UMass MAP and direct the planning of educational and social programming. For events that include appearances by guest speakers, the President shall head an ad hoc task force to organize the event. They will have secondary signing responsibility and will be subscribed to the MAP International listserv.
Vice President (with enough interest)- The Vice President will assist in the fulfillment of the President’s duties. 
Secretary- The Secretary will take, record, and file meeting minutes. They shall also be responsible for producing official correspondence for the organization, including emails to UMass MAP members, non-member graduate students (both from and outside the philosophy department), and website updates. They will be subscribed to the MAP International listserv.
Treasurer- The Treasurer will have signing responsibility and shall secure funding and financial support for UMass MAP. They will maintain the organization’s revenue and fee funds and keep detailed records concerning the financial transactions of the organization. 
 All graduate students that were active members of the chapter during the previous
 academic year qualify to serve as the President (and Vice President), Secretary, and
 Treasurer.  
 To ensure that the Executive Board members have adequate time to plan for the upcoming
 school year, board members will be appointed during the summer MAP meeting
 held on the last Friday in May. Executive Board members’ terms will begin June 1st and
 end on May 31st of the following year.
 Positions on the Executive Board will be filled via the following procedure:
Qualified candidates will nominate themselves for each position until the Board (including a President, Secretary, and Treasurer) is filled. With enough interest, a Vice President may be appointed to serve alongside the President. 
In the event that more than one person volunteers for a particular position on the Executive Board, preference will be given to those who identify as minorities in philosophy. After these considerations, nominees will be distributed according to their qualifications and preferences across vacant positions.
After following the procedure outlined above in subsections (a) and (b) of this section, if there are still an excess of volunteers, an impromptu election will be held. Candidates will be permitted to make a statement before voting begins. Votes in this election will be cast by a secret ballot that is given to the incumbent UMass MAP Secretary to be counted. The winner shall receive a majority of votes. 
 In the event of a vacancy on the Executive Board, the President will solicit volunteers
 from among the active members of the chapter. A volunteer will then be appointed at the
 President’s discretion to fill the vacant position for the remainder of the term. 

Article VI. Meetings
 General meetings will be held three times each year. The entire chapter shall meet on the
 Monday before the fall and spring semesters begin, and an additional chapter meeting will
 be held on the last Friday of May to appoint an Executive Board for the coming school
 year. 
 Executive and meetings may be called by any of the member(s) of the Executive Board at
 least 72 hours in advance. They will be held on an as-needed basis to discuss
 financial and administrative issues and planned events on the first Monday of every month. 
 Roberts Rules shall make up the general guidelines for conduct and speech during all
 official UMass MAP chapter meetings. 

Article VII. Committees and Groups
 The Executive Board shall authorize the creation of any standing or ad hoc committees as
 needed at their discretion. 
 All active members can establish a group (e.g., a reading group, peer group, etc.) at any time. These autonomous groups shall set their own meeting schedule but are still considered extensions of UMass MAP. 
  When such a group is created, the head of the group shall notify the Executive Board.
 The group shall update a member of the Executive Board periodically. 

Article VIII. Amendments to the Constitution
 A member may propose an amendment during any general or special meeting by
 distributing it in written form and reading it aloud in a meeting. After a thorough
 discussion to the satisfaction of all members present, a vote shall be taken. The amendment
 must secure at least two-thirds of the votes available during the meeting. 
 Any successful amendment shall be recorded, and copies of the new constitution shall be
 presented on the UMass MAP chapter website. Both an electronic and hard copy shall
 be stored for record-keeping purposes by the current Secretary.
