DocsList.Data:
University of Massachusetts Amherst Mock Trial Team Constitution

Article I: Name

Section 1:

The name of this organization shall be University of Massachusetts
Amherst Mock Trial Team, hereafter referred to as UMass Mock Trial. All usage
of these names to identify this group shall be in this form.

Article II: Purpose

Section 1:

The University of Massachusetts Amherst Mock Trial Team is organized

to promote knowledge of the law, foster excellence in speech and persuasion, and
help develop logical thinking skills. Our purpose is to open the doors to students
interested in the legal spectrum while creating a close community within the
larger UMass campus—known amongst team members as the Mock Trial Family.
University of Massachusetts Amherst Mock Trial is an American Mock Trial
Association, intercollegiate team competing in strategy and performance-based
legal education tournaments at the local, regional and national level.

Article III: Season

Section 1:

The yearly season of competition (hereafter referred to as the “season”)

begins on  June 1st and continues through May 31st of the next calendar year.

Article IV: Affiliations

Section 1:

This organization is affiliated with the University of Massachusetts
Amherst (hereafter referred to as “the University”) as a Registered Student
Organization. This organization is also affiliated with the American Mock Trial
Association (hereafter referred to as “AMTA”) as a team competing in
tournaments on the local, regional, and national level.

Article V: Membership

Section1:

UMass Mock Trial is open to any undergraduate student in the
Five-College circuit, regardless of race, sex, creed, national origin, disability, or
other status protected under international human rights law.

Section 2:

The team consists of all students on a competition roster and

non-competing, undergraduate students who regularly attend meetings and events.

 Section 3:

A competition roster consists of no more than ten undergraduate students

who are officially eligible to participate in a given competitive event, according to
the host organization’s rules. Pending the number of involved students and
budgetary limitations, UMass Mock Trial may establish multiple competition
rosters.

Section 4:

Each member must uphold their responsibilities as members of the team.
These include respecting all other team members, actively participating in team
practices and competitions, attending related activities, and others, as required.

Article VI: Officers

Section 1:

The officers of the group shall be:

President – The President shall:

Preside over all team and officer meetings

•
• Act as primary contact for all correspondence including, but not limited to,

e-mail, campus pulse, AMTA, SGA, and CSD

• Represent the team at all organization related events in the capacity of

captain including, but not limited to the tab room, captain’s meetings, and
team awards

• Represent the group at all coordinating meetings with the Student

Government Association and any official advisors

• Disseminate information received from AMTA
• Track logistical matters involving email accounts, case materials, updates
from the American Mock Trial Association and other contacts within the
collegiate mock trial circuit

• Manage team enrollment status with the University and the AMTA
• Call any additional meetings
• Coordinate training of all members during the season, with the assistance

of the Vice President and any chosen advisor(s)

• Act as Tournament Director
• Hold Signature Responsibility
• Mediate conflict, with consideration of other officers
• Work with all other officers to ensure officers’ duties are completed in an

acceptable and timely manner

• Break ties for the purpose of establishing a majority amongst the officers
• Delegate any before-mentioned duties to other officers or team members

as needed

Vice President – The Vice President shall:

• Assist the President in training members during the season

 •

Facilitate recruitment of new members through the means of the Fall and
Spring Activities Expos, New Student Orientation, introductory legal
studies courses, and other areas as the Vice President sees fit
•
Facilitate recruitment of judges for tournaments and scrimmages
• Act as Judges Coordinator for our annual tournament, the CCIT

Treasurer – The Treasurer shall:

• Keep updated records of all team expenditures
• Keep an updated budget sheet with all current balances
• Hold Signature Responsibility
•
• Request purchases through methods of Purchase Orders and SASP
• Book travel accommodations including, but not limited to, hotels, rental

Prepare the annual budget request for SGA funding

cars, parking, and tolls

• Manage all revenue collection responsibilities including, but not limited

to, collection of tournament entrance fees, membership dues and
donations.

• Deposit with the University all revenue gained through team activities

Secretary – The Secretary shall:

• Reserve space for all team events, meetings, and practices
•
•

Schedule all meetings, practices, and events throughout the season
Prepare itineraries for all events including, but not limited to, practices
and travel
Prepare minutes of all meetings and practices, if requested

•
• Manage equipment for tournaments including, but not limited to,
travelling case boxes containing the season’s materials (“Boxes of
Justice”), demonstrative aids, stands, and physical evidence

• Manage all footage that goes through the team

Director of Fundraising – The Director of Fundraising shall:

• Actively seek out additional sources of revenue throughout the year by
grants, sponsorships, fundraisers, and other means that the Director of
Fundraising sees fit

• Manage any fundraising campaigns through the University

Director of Social Engagement – The Director of Social Engagement shall:

• Maintain the organization’s public image via internet including, but not

limited to, Instagram, Facebook, Twitter, Impeachments

• Maintain aspects of the website and update with member photos, bios, and

achievements

 •

Serve as Public Relations Representative and Primary Media Contact to
mediums including, but not limited to, the Daily Collegian, local news
outlets, and official university media e.g. Political Science department
website

Section 2:

The term of each office shall be one year from June 1st to May 31st.
Officers may be re-elected each year, pursuant to standard election procedure. At
the officers’ discretion, officers may unanimously decide to end their term of
office early and allow the next term to begin. The proceeding term will last until
May 31st the following calendar year.

Section 3:

Should an officer’s position become vacant during his/her term, aside from

the process outlined in Article VI (2), the remaining officers will hold a meeting
and choose to pick an alternative officer by majority.

Section 4:

Officers will work together with fundraising, budgetary matters, travel

arrangements, communication with University organizations and AMTA,
procurement and distribution of case materials, demonstrative aids and other
materials required for competition, and communication with other collegiate and
high school mock trial programs and participants. While each officer will be
designated to his/her duties, the efforts will be collaborative.

Article VII: Advisors

Section 1:

The UMass Mock Trial organization advisor will be assigned by the

Center for Student Development.

Section 2:

UMass Mock Trial may designate one or more outside advisor(s) who is a

member of the faculty, administration, or staff of the University, or any other
member of the community as the President sees fit.

Article VII: Finances

Section 1:

All finances shall be handled in accordance with the established fiscal

procedures in effect for the school in the Center for Student Development offices
on campus.

Article VIII: Meetings

Section 1:

Regular meetings of the organization shall be held twice a week. The

Secretary will schedule time and place of all meetings called by the President.
With unanimous approval from the officers, additional or fewer regular meetings
may be held to accommodate changes in the competitive season.

 Section 2:

Special meetings of the organization shall be held at request of the
President. Members will be notified two weeks in advance of any such meeting.

Article IX: Amendments

Section 1:

This constitution shall be amended by a vote of 2/3 majority of all current

members in good standing. These members will be defined as any competing
member that participated in the competition (scrimmage, invitational tournament,
regional tournament, ORCS, or the National Championship) that the team that
they are rostered to most recently attended. If there has yet to be a competitive
event during the season, all members will be of good standing.

Section 2:

Amendments to the Constitution may only be passed during a regular or
special meeting called by the President. Three-quarters of all current members in
good standing must be in attendance to reach voting quorum.

Section 3:

Amendments to the Constitution may be proposed by any member of the

program, subject to approval by a majority vote of the officers. Provision for
advance notice of amendment shall be notification by email.

Date Ratified: May 4, 2021

University of Massachusetts Amherst Mock Trial Team Bylaws

Article I: Membership

Section 1:

The procedure for selection of membership will be a tryout held at the

beginning of each fall semester, and subsequently at the discretion of the officers.
Competition rosters will be determined at the sole discretion of a majority vote of
the officers

Section 2:

Due to the nature of the organization, the officers have the authority to

place rostered members in the position they feel most adequate. Throughout the
course of the season, officers may replace, change, or edit the extent of a
member’s rostered position at their discretion, by a majority vote.

Section 3:

Dues for this organization shall be determined at the start of the fall
semester. Dues may be waved on an individual basis in the case of financial
hardship, with permission of the Treasurer.

Section 4:

Membership responsibilities shall include respecting all other team

members, paying team dues, and actively participating in a majority of team
practice, competitions, and related activities.

Section 5:

In part with team participation, all members are required to have a form of

 dress attire to wear during competitions. This includes, but is not limited to, dress
pants, dress shirts and shoes, suit jackets, ties, and dress skirts. Attaining such
clothing is at the responsibility of the team member, and is not included in the
financial responsibilities of UMass Mock Trial.

Section 6:

Members must also conform to the requirements for competition in

AMTA. The specific criteria for acceptance onto the team include, but are not
limited to, demonstrated skill in presentation of ideas, analyzing documents,
persuasive speaking, as well as a commitment to UMass Mock Trial and
subsequent acceptance by the officers.

Section 7:

All members shall intend to participate fully for the entire season.
Members intending to study abroad, or who would otherwise knowingly miss a
competitive event, cannot be considered for membership, unless they receive
exemption from a unanimous decision of the officers.

Section 8:

Upon the first violation of a member’s responsibilities, the officers shall

give a verbal warning to the member. Upon the second violation, or if the first
violation is of such moral disregard, then the officers shall, by a majority vote, be
given the authorized discretion to terminate that member’s status on the team. If
such an act is in violation of any student policy code created by the University, the
member may face further discipline.

Article II: Election of Officers

Section 1:

Prior to any season’s end, an anonymous, general election will occur to

elect the next season’s President. Only current members in good standing, as
defined in Article IX (1) of our constitution, may be permitted to vote. The vote
will be conducted on a medium where all officers can have a live view of the
results, and members can view the official results once voting has closed. The
voting must begin two weeks after the last competitive event of the season, or by
April 1. The winner of this election will hereafter be referred to as the
President-Elect.

Section 2:

All team members in good standing will then vote to elect the remaining
officer positions, in the order of Vice President, Treasurer, Secretary, Director of
Fundraising, and Director of Social Engagement. These votes will be decided by a
majority. In the case of a member choosing to abstain, their vote will not count for
the purpose of establishing a majority. The vote will occur anonymously, through
a medium approved by the organization. Ties, if they occur in this open election,
will be broken through additional rounds of anonymous voting.

Section 3:

If the election process outlined in Article II (1) and (2) fails to occur

before the required timeframe outlined in Article II (1), the election process will
be reviewed by the UMass Mock Trial organization advisor assigned by the

 University. The election of all next season’s officers will then occur by the
popular selection of all members who were in good standing before the end of the
season.

Section 4:

If the legitimacy of the election is questioned by any incumbent officer,

during any point in the process, their concern(s) should be brought to the UMass
Mock Trial organization advisor. If the advisor finds any fraud to have occurred,
the election will proceed at their discretion.

Section 5:

If an officer is deemed unable or incapacitated in any manner to fulfill his
or her duties as an officer of the team, the respective officers shall forthwith make
a unanimous decision for the officer’s subsequent and permanent (if necessary)
removal from that position. In such cases, the respective officers shall appoint a
new officer to fulfill those duties on a temporary or permanent basis.

Article III: Amendments

Section 1:

These bylaws shall be amended by a vote of 2/3 majority of all current

members in good standing.

Section 2:

Amendments to these bylaws may only be passed during a regular or

special meeting called by the President. 3/4 of all current members in good
standing must be in attendance to reach voting quorum.

Section 3:

Amendments to these bylaws may be proposed by any member of the
program, subject to approval by a vote by the officers. Provision for advance
notice of amendment shall be notification by email.

Date Ratified: May 4, 2021

DocsList.Data:
University of Massachusetts Amherst Mock Trial Team Constitution
The University of Massachusetts Amherst Mock Trial team is organized to promote knowledge of the law, foster excellence in speech and persuasion, and help develop logical thinking skills. Our purpose is to open the doors to students interested in the legal spectrum, and to participate in academic competitions against other aspiring mock trial teams. University of Massachusetts Amherst Mock Trial is an American Mock Trial Association intercollegiate team competing in strategy and performance-based legal education tournaments at the local, regional and national level.

Article I. 
	The name of this group shall be University of Massachusetts Amherst Mock Trial Team, or UMass Mock Trial. All usage of these names to identify this group shall be in this form.


Article II.
	Section1. UMass Mock Trial is open to any undergraduate student in the five-college circuit, regardless of race, sex, creed, national origin, disability, or other status protected under international human rights law.

	Section 2. The team consists of all competing rosters and non-competing undergraduate students.

	Section 3. Each competing roster consists of no more than ten competing undergraduate students and any additional non-competing undergraduate students assigned to that team. Pending on the number of involved students, there may or may not be opportunity to have two full competing rosters. 

	Section 3a. Each member must uphold their responsibilities as members of the team, including respecting all other team members, actively participating in team practices and competitions, and related activities. If, in any situation, a member has violated these responsibilities, a penalty phase shall follow. 			3b. Upon the first violation of a member’s responsibilities, the officers shall give a verbal warming to the member. Upon the second violation, the member shall receive a final warning. Upon the third violation, or if the first/second violation is of such moral disregard, then the officers shall be given the authorized discretion to terminate that member’s status on the team. If such an act is in violation of the anti-hazing forms or any student policy code created by the university, the member may face further discipline. 

	Section 4. Potential members must also conform to the requirements for competition set forth by the American Mock Trial Association. The specific criteria for acceptance onto the team include, but are not limited to, demonstrated skill in presentation of ideas, analyzing documents, and persuasive speaking, as well as a commitment to UMass Mock Trial and subsequent acceptance by the officers. 

	Section 5. Tryouts for potential roles on the team will be conducted by the officers and structured by the officers accordingly. 

Article III.
	Section 1. The offices of the group shall be:
a. President
b. Vice-President
c. Secretary
d. Treasurer

	Section 2. The President and Vice-President for the following year will be selected by the current President and Vice-President. At least 2 of the officers must not be graduating at the end of the year. The Secretary and Treasurer will be selected by a vote from the team. First, members of the team will submit nominations for the position of Secretary. In a second vote, the position of Secretary will be filled by the nominee with the most votes. The same procedure will fill the position of Treasurer with the exception that the Secretary cannot also be the Treasurer. Officers will work in a conjoined effort to ensure the team’s presence and prominence within the collegiate mock trial circuit. 

	Section 2a. If a student elected officer is deemed unable or incapacitated in any manner to fulfill his or her duties as an officer of the team, the respective officers shall forthwith make an unanimous decision for the officer’s subsequent and permanent (if necessary) removal from that position. In such cases, the respective officers shall appoint a new officer to fulfill those duties on a temporary or permanent basis. 

	Section 3. Each member will hold office from fall semester of the regular academic year to the fall semester of the following year. New officers will be assigned captains during the spring.
 

	Section 4. In accordance with Section 2, officers will work together with fundraising, budgetary matters, travel arrangements, communication with the S.G.A. as well as with the American Mock Trial Association (AMTA), procurement and distribution of case materials, demonstratives and other materials required for competition, communication with other collegiate and high school mock trial programs and participants. While each officer will be designated to his/her duties, the efforts will be collaborative. 


Article IV.
	Section 1. The duties of the President shall be:
a. Preside over all group meetings.
b. Call any additional meetings.
c. Disseminate information received from the American Mock Trial Association. 
d. Represent the group at all coordinating meetings with the Student Government Association. 
e. Keep track of logistical matters with email accounts, case materials, updates from the         American Mock Trial Association and other contacts within the collegiate mock trial circuit.
f. Keep an updated budget sheet with the current balance.

	Section 2. The duties of the Vice-President shall be: 
a. Keep updated records of team expenditures
b. Keep a record of all financial documents and submit all financial records to the Center for Student Development when necessary. 
c. Turn in all financial records for re-issue to the new Secretary or Treasurer when required or appropriate.
d. Be the lead coordinator of team-hosted tournaments on campus.

	Section 3. The duties of the Secretary will be:
a. Facilitate team travel to competitions and tournaments.
b. Set up team reservations for hotels and other tournament related issues.
c. Plan team get-togethers, and scheduled meetings throughout the year. 

	Section 4. The duties of the Treasurer will be:
a. Act as a liaison to the campus newspaper.
b. Ensure that all group events are well publicized through campus newspapers, bulletins, announcement boards, posters, fliers, and by other means.
c. Act as liaison to businesses or groups willing to support UMass Mock Trial.
d. Be the primary developer and editor of the team website.
e. Keep an updated budget sheet with the current balance.

Article V.
	Section 1. There shall be a $20 fee required from all members of the team during the first meeting of the year (after tryouts have been held).

	Section 2. In part with team participation, all competing members on UMass Mock Trial are required to have a form of dress attire to wear during competitions. This includes, but is not limited to, dress pants, dress shirts and shoes, suit jackets, and dress skirts (women only). Attaining such clothing is at the responsibility of the team member, and is not included in the financial responsibilities of the team. 

	Section 3. All finances shall be handled in accordance with the established fiscal procedures in effect for the school in the Center for Student Development offices on campus.  

Article IX.
	Amendments to the Constitution may be proposed by any member of the program, subject to approval by the captains. Potential amendments approved by the captains must then be approved by two-thirds of the team members.

Ratified 3/27/2018 
PREAMBLE
Whereas international political issues and state-to-state relations are of paramount importance in a globalized world, we hereby establish the University of Massachusetts Model United Nations in an effort to both promote awareness of relevant topics and gain valuable experience in the art of diplomacy.  

ARTICLE I: NAME
SECTION 1
The name of this Organization shall be the University of Massachusetts Amherst Model United Nations, abbreviated “UMassMUN”.  

ARTICLE II: MEMBERSHIP 
SECTION 1

Membership in the Organization will be open to all students, staff, faculty, dependents, and alumni of the five-college community.  
SECTION 2
The Organization will not discriminate on the basis of age, gender, race, ethnicity, nationality, religion or sexual orientation.  
SECTION 3
Membership is granted through regular attendance and familiarity with the E-board. Attendance will be taken at the beginning of every General Body meeting. 

ARTICLE III: THE EXECUTIVE BOARD
SECTION 1: COMPOSITION
The executive board, herein E-board, shall consist of a President, Vice President, Finance Officer, Events Coordinator, Head Delegate(s), Director of Conference Logistics, the Parliamentarian, the Training Chair(s), and the Secretary General. Each member of the E-board must be in good academic standing with the institution. All members of the E-board are granted voting rights.
ELECTED POSITIONS
SECTION 2: THE PRESIDENT
The President shall act as the “chairman of the board” during executive board meetings, and as such, is responsible for setting the agenda and running each E-board meeting. This individual is also responsible for managing the Organization’s President’s email account for all communications. The President will serve as the organization’s primary liaison to the University, Student Government Association and to the Political Science Department. The President must receive UMASS signature responsibility. The President must also serve as the Director General for the Secondary School Model United Nations Conference.  
SECTION 3: THE VICE PRESIDENT
The Vice President shall assist the President in any and all administrative matters. The office of the Vice President should coordinate efforts between E-board members and provide logistical support for both the E-board and the organization as a whole. The office of the Vice President is also responsible for working with the Events Coordinator to ensure the quality and seamless operation of General Body meetings. Together these positions are responsible for drafting each semester’s event schedule to be submitted for approval by the whole E-board. In the event of the President’s absence from an E-board meeting, the Vice President assumes responsibility for the proper administration of the meeting. This office is also given the responsibility of overseeing the Delegation by collaborating with the Director of Conference Logistics, the Head Delegate(s), and the Training Chair(s) on collegiate conference trips. 
SECTION 4: THE FINANCE OFFICER
The Finance Officer is responsible for recording and facilitating all financial transactions of the organization. They must receive UMASS signature responsibility. The Finance Officer is responsible for fundraising, preparing the annual SGA budget and submitting end-of-semester reports and reactivation packets, and is also responsible for overseeing and recording all financial transactions of the club, particularly of MinuteMUN. It is the responsibility of the Finance Officer to make sure IRC is in good financial standing with the University. The Finance Officer must also serve as the Undersecretary General of Logistics for the MinuteMUN conference. 
SECTION 5: THE EVENTS COORDINATOR
The Events Coordinator is responsible for managing the logistics of General Body meetings for the year; including booking the rooms and ensuring that audiovisual equipment is present for the meeting if necessary. The Events Coordinator should work closely with the Parliamentarian to disseminate information about meetings in a timely and effective manner. Together with the Vice President, the Events Coordinator is responsible for drafting each semester’s event schedule which is submitted for E-board approval.  Other E-board members are expected to assist the Events Coordinator with presentations and planning of the General Body meetings. The Events Coordinator also has the responsibility in reaching out to faculty members for speaking at General Body Meetings. 

SECTION 8: THE PARLIAMENTARIAN
The Parliamentarian is responsible for publications, membership drives, and must actively recruit members throughout the year when deemed needed by the E-board. They are also responsible for managing the Organization’s Parliamentarian email account for all communications. This E-board member is responsible for creating minutes from both E-board and general club meetings. Also, they must maintain the Organization’s publicity throughout the semester through social media and through the emailing list. The Parliamentarian is also responsible for maintaining attendance and maintaining a members list at both E-board and General Body Meetings.
APPOINTED POSITIONS
SECTION 6: THE DIRECTOR OF CONFERENCE LOGISTICS
The Director of Conference Logistics (DoCL) is responsible for all matters relating to intercollegiate conferences. They are also responsible for managing the Organization’s Conference Logistics email account for secretariat, hotel, rental car, and other external communications. The DoCL shall manage all hotel reservations, travel forms, liability paperwork, conference registration and itineraries, conference registration, and all other matters herein related. The DoCL will also guide, direct, and assist the head delegates as needed.  
SECTION 7: THE HEAD DELEGATE(S)
The two Head Delegates(s) shall work alongside the DoCL and is/are responsible for the students attending all matter relating to intercollegiate conferences. They are also responsible for managing the Organization’s Head Delegate email account for all delegate communications. The Head Delegate(s) shall manage all hotel reservations, travel forms, conference itineraries, conference registration, delegate position papers, logistics meetings, delegate inquiries, publicity for conferences, delegation cohesion, and all other matters herein related, and will also decide the team to attend conferences. A minimum of one Head Delegate will be in attendance during a collegiate conference, unless the DoCL is attending instead. The Head Delegate must coordinate with the Training Chair(s) to conduct at least three training/research sessions prior to every conference.  
SECTION 7: THE TRAINING CHAIR(S)
The Training Chair(s) is responsible for planning and conducting at least two training/research sessions prior to each conference in coordination with the Head Delegate(s). The Training Chair(s) should ensure that all conference participants, particularly those new to Model UN, are practiced in parliamentary procedure prior to attending each conference. They should also be expected to attend MinuteMUN training of staffers and lead Mock Model General Meetings. This appointed position should be filled by (a) club member(s) with significant Model U.N. experience, as determined by the E-board. They should work closely with the Head Delegate(s) to ensure the delegates selected for each conference are able and willing to perform at the highest level.
SECTION 9: SECRETARY GENERAL 
The Secretary General is charged with the creation and execution of MinuteMUN, the organization’s Secondary School Model United Nations Conference. Though they have sole discretion on all matters relating to the conference, the Secretary General is prohibited from possessing signatory responsibility. This office may appoint the President as Director General. The Secretary General or the Secretariat member of his/her choosing is responsible for keeping financial books and keeping the Finance Officer apprised of what monies are encumbered by the conference. An operations manual must be created/maintained on an annual basis. Lastly, the Secretary General is responsible for holding Secretariat meetings and communicating with Secretariat on a regular basis up until the end of MinuteMUN.
SECTION 10: EXECUTIVE BOARD MEETINGS
All officers are expected to be present at all E-board and General Body meetings. Officer reports should be given verbally at the beginning each E-board meeting and recorded by the Parliamentarian. The Finance Officer must give the most accurate account balances and available funds, including conference expenditures at every meeting. E-board meetings are generally open to all members to attend, however, by the request of any officer, they can be held in executive session. Failure to attend three E-board meetings without proper excuse will result in an immediate impeachment of that E-board member, following an automatic recall election process. Notification of a known upcoming absence at E-board must be communicated to the President no less than 12 hours prior to the meeting, with the exception of genuine emergencies as to be determined by the discretion of the E-board. The President is the facilitator and moderator of each E-board meeting. In their absence, the Vice President assumes this role.  
SECTION 11: QUORUM & SUCCESSION
Quorum will consist of a majority of the members. In the event that the President is unable to attend a meeting, the Vice President will act in his/her capacity. The order of succession will be President, Vice President, Finance Officer, Events Coordinator, Parliamentarian, Head Delegate(s), Training Chair(s), Secretary General. 
SECTION 12: DECISIONS
Decisions made by the executive board are binding. The President has the power to break tied votes. Officers will be sovereign within their own spheres of influence; however, decisions deemed major decisions by the President are subject to E-board vote.
SECTION 13: EXCLUSIVITY
All E-board positions are mutually exclusive. No person may hold more than one office.  

ARTICLE IV: GENERAL CLUB MEETINGS
SECTION 1: FREQUENCY
General Club Meetings will be held on UMASS campus, at a minimum of biweekly, barring unforeseen or irregular circumstances.  
SECTION 2: AGENDA
The Executive Board shall jointly decide the agenda prior to a General Meeting under the direction of the Vice President. If a vote is deemed required, a simple majority is required to set/change the agenda.  
SECTION 3: FORMAT
The President shall open and close all meetings. First, old business should be discussed. Then the President should move into the E-board decided agenda. Discussion of international relations issues is highly encouraged.  
SECTION 4: NOTIFICATION
All E-board members are responsible for announcing meetings at least 72 hours prior whenever possible.  

ARTICLE V: VOTING
SECTION 1: ELIGIBILITY
Voting membership shall be restricted to University of Massachusetts- Amherst undergraduate students. Voting privileges shall be granted once a member has attended at least 3 formal meetings, so long as they have not missed two of the three meetings preceding the vote. Unless otherwise noted, a simple majority is needed to pass all measures. A simple majority is defined as 50% + 1 of the eligible voting members present at the time of the vote. Voting eligibility requirements can be waived by a majority of organization members.  
SECTION 2: ELECTIONS
Elections should be held in the second week of April; should this date cause a schedule conflict, the first or third week may be substituted instead. The exact date of elections must be given by the President at least two weeks prior.  
SECTION 3: OFFICES
The positions of President, Vice President, Finance Officer, Events Coordinator, and Parliamentarian shall all be voted on. After the election, the new E-board shall appoint a Director of Conference Logistics, Head Delegates, Secretary General, and Training Chair(s). The Secretary General is subject appointed by the E-board.
SECTION 4: ELECTION PROCEDURES
Every candidate is nominated, starting with the President. The Organization shall then elect a Chancellor of Elections from those members not running for office, preferably a retiring officer. This individual must remain neutral and is therefore unable to participate in debate. 
For each office, candidates will give a speech up to 5 minutes. After all candidates for office speak, they pass their secret ballots to the Chancellor of Elections and leave the room. Debate is conducted under a limited version of Robert's Rules of Order for up to 10 minutes. At any time, the Chancellor may conduct a vote to determine if debate is still needed. 
This process repeats until all officers are elected. Drop down voting is permitted.  

SECTION 5: TERMS OF OFFICERS
An officer's term begins immediately after being elected and terminates at elections the following year. The terms of the Training Chair(s) expire at elections as well. The Secretary General shall remain in office until a new Secretary General is appointed – this shall be the first task of the new Executive Board.
SECTION 6: RECALL
A recall election for any officer can be called by either 4 E-board members or by a 2/3rd majority of the Organization. If recalled, an officer must be reconfirmed by the organization.  
SECTION 7: IMPEACHMENT
An officer may be removed from office by impeachment proceedings. Charges of impeachment may only be filed if an officer has violated the Constitution or has committed other egregious misconduct against UMass that places the Organization in administrative jeopardy. After charges of impeachment are placed, a vote will be taken at the next E-board meeting that occurs within a 2-week window. A 2/3 majority vote is required to remove an officer. If an officer is impeached, they are barred from ever holding office.  
SECTION 8: QUORUM
No voting may take place unless there is quorum. Quorum shall consist of a majority of the E-board members and 50% of the General Body membership who are eligible to vote.  

ARTICLE VI: FUNCTIONS & OPERATIONS OF IRC
SECTION 1: ROBERT’S RULES OF ORDER
At the discretion of the President, General Body club meetings may be held under a limited version of Robert's Rules of Order.  
SECTION 2: DEPUTY PROGRAM
A deputy is appointed to at least one officer to assist with the duties of their office, if that officer is either (a) studying abroad in the successive semester, or (b) is graduating the following year. These persons will comprise the subcommittees for their respective offices. Officers may call meeting of their subcommittees independently of the general body. At these meetings, the respective officer has sole discretion as to what is discussed, and in what manner. These meetings can never be considered General Body meetings.  
SECTION 3: VACANCIES OF OFFICE
Should any office become vacant throughout the year, the E-Board shall appoint an interim officer in their place for the remainder of the semester as soon as possible. 
SECTION 4: VACANCY OF THE PRESIDENT
Should the office of the President be open at any time, the Vice President shall fill the office. This supersedes Article VI, Section 3.  
SECTION 5: SUCCESSION
In the event that both the President and Vice President are unable to fulfill the role of President, the order of succession is as follows: Finance Officer, Events Officer, Parliamentarian, Head Delegate(s), Training Chair(s), and Secretary General.  
SECTION 6: EXPULSION
Any regular club member may be expelled from the organization by a 2/3 vote of the general body or a unanimous vote of the Executive Board. Conditions include but are not limited to situations such that would compromise the integrity of the Organization subject to the institution’s administration and/or public standing. Expulsion is carried through for the remainder of the semester and one additional semester.  

ARTICLE VII: MINUTEMUN
SECTION 1: THE CONFERENCE
The International Relations Club shall act as an umbrella for MinuteMUN: Secondary School Model United Nations Conference, herein referred to as “the Conference.”  
SECTION 2: THE SECRETARIAT
The Secretary General shall appoint all members of the Secretariat. No Secretariat members may serve as an appointed staffer for the Conference. The Secretariat shall consist of the following offices: 
DIRECTOR GENERAL - The Director General will assist the Secretary General in all matters relating to MinuteMUN. They will coordinate with the entire Secretariat and ensure proper functioning of the conference. The Director General also has signatory powers for all financial documents.
USG LOGISTICS – USG Logistics oversees the basic arrangements of the conference, such as booking the hotel rooms for all delegates and staffers, transportation for delegates and staffers from the hotel to the Campus Center and ordering/managing all supplies and all food for the conference. 
USG STAFF – USG Staff is the liaison between the Secretariat and the staff. They make sure that all the staff is trained and present at the conference, overlooks staffer behavior and ensures that any concerns or questions raised by the staffers regarding the Conference and/or Secretariat are taken care of. USG Staff is also responsible for recruitment of staffers, updating both delegate and staff manuals, monitoring staffer behavior such as ensuring professionalism during the conference, appointing tour guides for campus tours, and assigning staffer roles to each committee. 
USG DELEGATIONS – USG Delegations is responsible for assigning committee positions to high school delegates, serves as the link between the Secretariat and the Advisors by constantly maintaining the MinuteMUN email with the Secretary General throughout conference. They are also responsible for managing invoices of the delegations for the Conference and works in par with USG Committees to make sure all committees and staff appointments are accounted for.
USG COMMITTEES - USG Committees is responsible for generating topics and content for the committees and ensures that they are running smoothly throughout the duration of the conference. This office is also responsible for handling committee feedback and ensures all background guides are submitted on time with proper editing and formatting. 
USG CRISIS - USG Crisis is responsible for all crisis committees and their functionality, information and flow of debate. They are also tasked with making sure all crisis staff teams are working smoothly and efficiently with their respective committees and can help move the crises forward on a case by case basis, if necessary. This office can also help him with committee content ahead of the conference; as such they should work closely with USG Committees, as well as Chairs and Vice Chairs before and throughout the duration of the Conference. 
USG EVENTS – The USG Events is responsible with all events pertaining to the Conference, including but not limited to; the Delegate Dance, Trivia, T-Shirt orders, and Donations. This office is to work closely with the USG Delegations on the first day of the conference with registration, aids the USG Committees with committee feedback, and is also responsible for collaborating with local businesses to promote Amherst and UMass to the delegations during the conference.

SECTION 3: SUCCESSION
Should the Secretary General be unable or unwilling to fulfill the duties of the office, the Director General shall fill the office until a replacement can be appointed by the executive board with the advice and consent of the current secretariat.  
SECTION 4: BUDGET
At the request of the President or the Finance Officer, the Secretary General and the Finance Officer is required to produce the most accurate budget and account information available.  

ARTICLE VIII: INTERCOLLEGIATE CONFERENCES
SECTION 1: THE UMASSMUN DELEGATION
The International Relations Club shall act as an umbrella for the intercollegiate Model United Nations Team, herein referred to as “the Delegation.” Delegates will be chosen based off ability, performance, and attendance in Mock Model General Body Meetings, led by the Vice President, the Director of Conference Logistics, the Head Delegate(s) and the Training Chair(s). 
SECTION 2: HEAD DELEGATE(S)
The Head Delegate(s) shall act as the delegation’s Head Delegate whenever possible. Should this not be possible, the Head Delegate can assign an acting Head Delegate or ask the DoCL to assume the head delegate role during a conference.  
SECTION 3: AUTHORITY  
When attending a conference, the Head Delegate, or acting Head Delegate(s) has ultimate authority and speaks for the executive board. They reserve the right to disaffiliate a member of the delegation if deemed absolutely necessary.

ARTICLE IX: AMENDMENTS
SECTION 1: AMENDMENTS
This document can be changed via constitutional amendment. Amendments must be proposed, in writing, two weeks prior to the end of the semester. The time requirement can be waived if the president deems the matter an “important question.” A 2/3 majority is required to pass an amendment.  

ARTICLE X: RATIFICATION
SECTION 1: RATIFICATION  
This document shall be ratified if passed by 2/3 of the voting members, as determined by the preceding constitution. If ratified, it takes effect immediately and elections will occur directly afterward.

How to Use This Form

Recreation Club Allocation Committee - Budget Request Form

Review your entire budget breakdown and select those expenses that you would like paid for by the Univeristy of Massachusetts Amherst through an allocation of SGA funds from the Recreation Club Council Allocations Commmittee. Prioritize the items from most important (1) to least important (up to 10). All items, including individual trips 
or items of equipment, should be listed separately.

How the Recreation Club Allocation Committee Will Use This Form

The Recreation Club Council Allocation Committee will review this form and other resources for allocation.  Each club will have the opportunity to explain its priority list, provide additional information regarding budget expenses and estimated income, and clarify any items during its scheduled budget hearing before the Recreation Club 
Council Allocation Committee during the allocation process.

Allocation and Spending by Category

Clubs will be allocated money by category, with allocated funds required to be spent in that category. You may adjust expenditures within category (if you request to fund a trip to Miami and you change that to Atlanta, that is acceptable).  But, to move money between categories (such as from Travel to Equipment) will require a special 
request  to the Recreation Club Council for approval.

DocsList.Data:
University of Massachusetts – Amherst
Multicultural Greek Council

Constitution & Bylaws









Edited by:
Tanmaiyee Vaddepati
President (Fall 2020 - Spring 2021)
Kappa Phi Gamma Sorority, Inc.




August 29, 2020




Article I – Name

The name of this association shall be the University of Massachusetts- Amherst Multicultural Greek Council, also referred to as the UMass Amherst MGC

Article II – Objectives and Jurisdiction

Section 1 - Objectives

The objective of the Multicultural Greek Council shall be to develop and maintain
fraternity life and interfraternity relations at a high level of accomplishment and in so doing:
Consider the goals and ideals of member groups as continually applicable to campus and personal life.
Promote superior scholarship as basic to intellectual achievement.
Cooperate with member fraternities/sororities and university administration in concern for cultural awareness and maintenance of high social and moral standards.
Act in accordance with all rules established by the University of 
Massachusetts-Amherst Multicultural Greek Council, as to not violate the 
sovereignty, rights, and privileges of member fraternities and sororities.
Be a forum for discussion of questions of interest to the university and the fraternity/sorority world.
Encourage social service and philanthropic activities for the development of members and the Amherst community.
Further leadership education and development within the Greek realm and on campus.

Section 2 – University Jurisdiction

The University of Massachusetts – Amherst Multicultural Greek Council is under the jurisdiction of the Registered Student Organization Office and therefore adheres and follows all regulations established by the school for Registered Student Organizations and fraternity/sorority organizations.

Article III – Membership

Section 1 – Council Membership
As of 08/29/2020 the membership of the University of Massachusetts- Amherst Multicultural Greek Council is composed of the members of the following organizations at the University of Massachusetts- Amherst and nationals:


La Unidad Latina, Lambda Upsilon Lambda Fraternity, Inc.
Delta Xi Phi Multicultural Sorority, Inc.
Kappa Phi Lambda Sorority, Inc.
Pi Delta Psi Fraternity, Inc.
Sigma Psi Zeta Sorority, Inc.
Beta Chi Theta National Fraternity, Inc. 
Kappa Phi Gamma Sorority, Inc.
Delta Kappa Delta Sorority, Inc. 

Chapters previously on this campus (inactive):
Sigma Lambda Beta International Fraternity, Inc.
Sigma Lambda Upsilon/Señoritas Latinas Unidas Sorority, Inc..
Sigma Lambda Gamma National Sorority, Inc.


Section 2 – Active Membership

Definition
Organization that have undergraduate members or representation on campus.
Organizations in good financial standing. 
Organizations that attend all meetings and events pertaining to the council and Office of Fraternities and Sororities
Rights of Active Members
Have full voice and voting rights.
Expectations and Responsibilities include, but are not limited to
 Each organization must have at least two delegates at all MGC general body 
    meetings and All Council (OFS) meetings
Organizations with 11 members or more must send two or more delegates.
With the exception of organizations with 10 members or less. They can send one delegate
A delegate on the executive board can count as one delegate
Pay council dues of $30 by the 2nd general body meeting
Dues will increase by $10 every week they are not turned in

Section 3 – Inactive Status

Definition
Organizations that have no undergraduate members or representation on campus.
Multicultural Greek Council organizations that have not paid all dues and fees to the Multicultural Greek Council by the end of the academic year.
Organizations who have not paid will be put on probation until dues are paid off. They will be frozen and have no voting rights until dues are paid in full. 



Procedures to become Active
Contact Office of Fraternities and Sororities
Contact the Multicultural Greek Council – Executive Board
Fulfill the following Multicultural Greek Council Program Requirements in two consecutive semesters:
1 Academic program
1 Cultural program
1 Community Service program
1 Social program
Fulfill the following Office of Fraternities and Sororities Program Requirements
1 Multiculturalism and/or diversity program
1 Substance Abuse program
1 Leadership and/or Organizational Issues program
If applicable, pay off all dues, fees, and debts of the organization within the Multicultural Greek Council. 
Once all requirements have been completed, contact the Executive Board to set up a presentation date.
Directly after the presentation, each active organization of the Multicultural 
Greek Council will have a voice, but no vote, to determine whether the 
inactive group will be recognized by the Multicultural Greek Council.
In this case, only the Executive Board will vote, considering the council’s voice.
The council president will notify the inactive group within 24 hours of the council’s decision.
If not accepted, the inactive group can send the Multicultural Greek Council – Executive Board a proposal for another presentation date.
In this case, each active organization president and executive board member of the council will have a vote directly after the presentation
If not completed within two consecutive semesters, the inactive group must send the Multicultural Greek Council – Executive Board a proposal requesting another presentation date (asking for an extension). This is will be discretion the executive board.
After the organization has been approved to be in the council, the organization will be considered under “Probation Status” the following semester
While in probation status, organizations have a voice, but no voting rights.
Organizations have at least 2 delegates at all MGC general body meetings, All Council meetings, and MGC events and community services.
Must pay council dues of $30 by the 2nd general body meeting of the semester



Section 4 - Interest Groups
 
A.	Definition
        i.  Interest groups are fraternities or sororities interested in joining the Multicultural Greek Council that have not been previously recognized by the Multicultural Greek Council.

B. 	Procedure to join the council

1.  	Contact Office of Fraternities and Sororities
2.  	Be recognized by the National Board of the fraternity/sorority they are interested in joining (an official letter from their nationals to the executive board stating they are officially an interest group).
3.  	Within one year of joining the organization, be recognized by the University of Massachusetts – Amherst as a Registered Student Organization 			
Contact the Multicultural Greek Council – Executive Board and send a proposal to set up a presentation date.
4.  	Directly after the presentation, each active organization of the Multicultural Greek Council will have one vote to determine whether the interest group will be recognized by the Multicultural Greek Council.
a.   In the case of a tie, each member of the Executive Board will vote individually.
5.  	The council president will notify the interest group within 24 hours of the council’s decision.
a.   If not accepted, the interest group can send the Multicultural Greek Council – Executive Board a proposal for another presentation date
6.  	Once the interest group has been accepted by the Multicultural Greek Council, they have two consecutive semesters to become affiliated with the organization they are interested in.
a.   If not completed within two consecutive semesters, the interest group must send the Multicultural Greek Council – Executive Board a proposal requesting another presentation date.

B. Guidelines for Admittance

Interest groups must receive 3 Y’s for the main question portion section of the guidelines. For the subsets, any questions answered no will automatically bar the group from admittance into the council. Questions 6-8 are not to be used in the vote, but can be used for special consideration in the discussion during the presentation or in the event there is a majority N for question 5. 

1. Does the population represented in the organization represent an underrepresented population on campus/not represented within any of the other 3 Greek councils? Y/N
2. Does the interest group have a sustainable model for operations, recruitment and programming? Y/N
If not, do they have the means to attend the proper trainings to do so? Y/N
3. Are they recognized by the interested organization’s national office? Y/N
4. Are they a recognized RSO? Y/N
If not, are they on course to become an RSO within the next 2 semesters? Y/N
5. Do you feel the admittance of this organization will help the council in its growth and operation? Y/N
*6. Was this organization previously established at UMass? Y/N
*7. Does this organization have any other local entities? Y/N
*8. Is this a local or national/international organization? Y/N
If local organization, what support systems does it have in place to help with operations? Y/N

Article IV – Executive Board

Section 1 – Executive Board
The officers of the University of Massachusetts- Amherst Multicultural Greek
Council shall be President, Vice President, Treasurer, Secretary, and  Events Coordinator, Public Relations.
Executive Board members shall hold their positions from April 1st to March 31st.
They shall serve as officers of the Multicultural Greek Council and shall have powers and duties as prescribed in the Constitution of the University of Massachusetts- Amherst Multicultural Greek Council.
The Executive Board shall have the power of the Council in emergencies that necessitate immediate action between meetings. A report of such actions must be made at the following general body meeting. 
Executive Board shall meet every other week in between Council meetings.
Any officer can be impeached or asked to resign by the majority (3/4) of the Council for just cause.

Duties 
President- the general duties and responsibilities of the President include, but are not limited to, the following:
Maintaining lines of communication with the Office of Fraternities and Sororities
Attend Council Board meetings, or choose designee to attend in their place
Report to the Secretary of Registry, RSOs that are in violation of SGA by-law’s and/or University of Massachusetts Amherst policies.
Function as liaison between RSOs in MGC and SGA
Schedule e-board meetings with advisor at least (1) a month during the regular period.
Encouraging each organization to take initiative in creating and implementing ideas/events
Holding officers and organizations accountable for their goals and responsibilities
Prepare general body agenda and send to secretary for revision and distribution
Call and lead MGC meetings
Carry out training to the council as recommended by the Secretary of Registry or Student Activities and Involvement Advisor
Delegating tasks to officers on the executive board
Take Signature Responsibility and Event Coordinator training
Serve as Four Council liaison with IFC, PanHellenic Council and NPHC. 
Enforce the Multicultural Greek Council regulations, constitution and policies.
Review constitution every year with the executive board

Vice President- the general duties and responsibilities of the Vice President include, but are not limited to, the following:
Assume the responsibility of the president in her/his absence
Maintaining lines of communication with the executive board and each individual organization
Attend Council Board meetings with Council President
Support the president, and perform any duties assigned by the president
Review constitution every year with the executive board

Treasurer
Maintain accurate records of expenditures and receipts of all funds
Handle all financial exchanges
Collects semester dues
Prepares/monitors budget for each year
Serve as authorized signer for the Multicultural Greek Council
In absence of president and vice president, the treasurer will be an interim 
Attend Treasurer Board meetings or choose designee to attend in their place.
Work collaboratively with the Ways and Means Representative for their council and the Secretary of Finance, to ensure RSOs in their council are following SGA by-laws and University of Massachusetts Amherst spending policies.
Report to Secretary of Finance RSOs that are in violation of SGA or UMass Amherst’s spending policies. 
Meet at least (2) twice a semester with the Secretary of Finance and the Ways and Means Representative for MGC.
Carry out financial trainings to their council as instructed by the Ways and Means Representative to MGC, the Chair of Ways and Means or the Secretary of Finance. 
Review constitution every year with the executive board

Secretary
Record all attendance and take minutes at all executive board and general body meetings
Print out and distribute agenda to the executive board and delegates
Send out general body minutes to presidents and delegates and Secretary of Registry
Maintain and distribute current contact information list of the executive board of the council, the presidents of each organizations, and delegates.
Review constitution every year with the executive board

Event Coordinator
Review constitution every year with the executive board 
Be in charge of room bookings, campus pulse event submissions, and duties affiliated with coordinating an event
Work in conjunction with the Public Relations officer.
Develop and coordinate council wide philanthropy/community service initiatives.
Maintains master calendar of events for all organizations within and affiliated with MGC (including council organizations, interest groups, graduate organizations, Student Activities events, etc). 

Public Relations
Promote the image of the Multicultural Greek Council through various social network sites.
Promote Multicultural Greek Council events and oversee creating flyers for such events
Work alongside Event Coordinator to establish branding and promotional events for the council to take part in. 
C. Impeachment

a. Impeachment charges can be brought to the general body through a petition signed by a two-third (2/3) of the RSOs of the general body or two-third (2/3) of the executive board members in that council of the officer in question.
b. The council’s Secretary of Registry, or their designee, shall chair meetings where impeachment charges are on the agenda.
c. The petition and any other documents regarding the impeachment must be also given to the Secretary of the Registry and the council’s SA&I advisor.
d. Impeachment charges that have been brought to the general body shall follow this procedure:
Impeachment charges must be on the agenda for the next regularly scheduled general body meeting.
Impeachment charges shall be the first item on the agenda.
The general body member who filed the impeachment charges shall have ten (10) minutes maximum to address the general body.
The officer in question shall then have ten (10) minutes maximum to address the general body.
The chair of the meeting shall then call a vote from the general body members.
If two-thirds (2/3) of the RSOs present are in favor of impeachment, the officer in question shall be removed from their office. 

Section 2 – Eligibility, Nomination, and Voting Process

Eligibility
The officers shall be delegated from fraternities/sororities holding active membership in the University of Massachusetts- Amherst Multicultural Greek Council. 
In order to be nominated and elected for an Executive Board position, the individual must be an enrolled undergraduate student during both semesters of his/her term and must be in good academic standing institutionally.

Nomination
Nominations will be held the second to last general body meeting of the semester.  The candidate must be nominated by him/herself or any other council member.
Nominations can be accepted or denied by the nominee at the second to last general body meeting. 
Maximum of 2 nominees per organization per position.
Elections
Elections will be done by the second week in March, with final decisions sent to SGA by March 25th. The day of elections, each candidate must come with a speech and be prepared for a possible Q&A session afterwards.
In the case if a nominee could not attend the election they forfeit their nomination.
The general body delegates will be given one pre-printed ballot per organization to cast their vote. Executive board has 1 vote per position separate from his or her organization.
If a delegate will be absent, the delegate must notify an officer of the Executive Board and designate a convenient time to cast their vote.
All ballots will be given to the executive board and the new Executive Board will be announced at the end of the last meeting.
Each candidate must win by a simple majority
In the case of a tie the executive board will make the final decision.

D. Vacancies
If a vacancy occurs for the council president, the vice president must succeed and become president, or call for a special election, to follow the same guidelines set forth in the above election protocol.
If a vacancy occurs in any position other than president, the president must appoint a willing RSO executive board member of the general body that is in good academic standing according to the university. 

Section 3 – Meeting Procedure

A. Attendance 
Each organization shall send in their respective delegate(s) to each MGC meeting. 
Inability to send delegates to meetings will result in freezing of all accounts and suspension of programming until meeting with advisor is completed.
Missing 3 or more will result in accounts being frozen time limit for tardiness, anything after the initial start time being considered tardy.
Tardiness will not be tolerated. Each tardy will result in a half absentee point.
After 6 tardies, the organization will be frozen and have all programming suspended until meeting with advisor occurs. 
Exception for academic/religious/emergency events that must be stated at least 48 hours ahead of time along with name of replacement delegate (if organization size allows), or as early as possible in the event of an extreme emergency. 
Each organization represented is allowed a single (1) vote for all things (elections, transfer of funds presentations, interest group presentations, etc).
In the event there is a tie, the executive board will vote alongside the council.
In the event there is still a tie, an individual vote will be cast among the attending delegates, within the delegate framework established in the “Active Membership” section. 
NOTE: No more than 2 votes permitted for organizations 11 members and more.
B. Meeting Procedure

Meetings shall occur bi-weekly, as often as the semester allows, and will take place within a two hour window and a selected day by the President. 
President will open meeting with roll call of all organizations. Sign in sheet will also be passed around for individual delegates to sign in.
Adviser will discuss their updates first. Assign action items if they are required. 
President, along with the rest of the executive board, will present any updates/initiatives from their respective positions. Action items to be assigned if required.
Announcements from the rest of the council regarding council related business, going down the order of roll call. Discussions/action items to be assigned at this time.
Tabled/outstanding/unfinished business from previous meeting to be discussed and closed if possible. 
Announcements to be given from each individual organization. 
President will formally close meeting. 
NOTE: In the event of a training in place of a meeting, there will only be updates from the advisor and executive board, and all other updates will need to be emailed to the Secretary to be distributed among the rest of the council after the meeting. 
NOTE: In the event of a vote to make a decision, each organization shall receive a single vote, and in the event of a tie, the executive board shall vote as individuals to break the tie. In the event there is still a tie, the entire council will vote as individuals (with only a maximum of 2 delegates per organization getting individual voting power).

University of Massachusetts – Amherst
Multicultural Greek Council

Constitution & Bylaws









Edited by:
Juan Martinez-Muñoz
President (Fall 2017 - Spring 2018)
Sigma Lambda Beta International Fraternity, Inc.




February 19, 2018




Article I – Name

The name of this association shall be the University of Massachusetts- Amherst Multicultural Greek Council, also referred to as the UMass Amherst MGC

Article II – Objectives and Jurisdiction

Section 1 - Objectives

The objective of the Multicultural Greek Council shall be to develop and maintain
fraternity life and interfraternity relations at a high level of accomplishment and in so doing:
Consider the goals and ideals of member groups as continually applicable to campus and personal life.
Promote superior scholarship as basic to intellectual achievement.
Cooperate with member fraternities/sororities and university administration in concern for cultural awareness and maintenance of high social and moral standards.
Act in accordance with all rules established by the University of 
Massachusetts-Amherst Multicultural Greek Council, as to not violate the 
sovereignty, rights, and privileges of member fraternities and sororities.
Be a forum for discussion of questions of interest to the university and the fraternity/sorority world.
Encourage social service and philanthropic activities for the development of members and the Amherst community.
Further leadership education and development within the Greek realm and on campus.

Section 2 – University Jurisdiction

The University of Massachusetts – Amherst Multicultural Greek Council is under the jurisdiction of the Registered Student Organization Office and therefore adheres and follows all regulations established by the school for Registered Student Organizations and fraternity/sorority organizations.

Article III – Membership

Section 1 – Council Membership
As of MM/DD/2018 the membership of the University of Massachusetts- Amherst Multicultural Greek Council is composed of the members of the following organizations at the University of Massachusetts- Amherst and nationals:


Delta Xi Phi Multicultural Sorority, Inc.
Kappa Phi Lambda Sorority, Inc.
Pi Delta Psi Fraternity, Inc.
Sigma Psi Zeta Sorority, Inc.
Beta Chi Theta National Fraternity, Inc. 
Sigma Lambda Beta International Fraternity, Inc.
Delta Kappa Delta Sorority, Inc. 

Chapters previously on this campus (inactive):
La Unidad Latina, Lambda Upsilon Lambda Fraternity, Inc.
Sigma Lambda Upsilon/Señoritas Latinas Unidas Sorority, Inc..
Sigma Lambda Gamma National Sorority, Inc.


Section 2 – Active Membership

Definition
Organization that have undergraduate members or representation on campus.
Organizations in good financial standing. 
Organizations that attend all meetings and events pertaining to the council and Office of Fraternities and Sororities
Rights of Active Members
Have full voice and voting rights.
Expectations and Responsibilities include, but are not limited to
 Each organization must have at least two delegates at all MGC general body 
    meetings and All Council (OFS) meetings
Organizations with 11 members or more must send two or more delegates.
With the exception of organizations with 10 members or less. They can send one delegate
A delegate on the executive board can count as one delegate
Pay council dues of $30 by the 2nd general body meeting
Dues will increase by $10 every week they are not turned in

Section 3 – Inactive Status

Definition
Organizations that have no undergraduate members or representation on campus.
Multicultural Greek Council organizations that have not paid all dues and fees to the Multicultural Greek Council by the end of the academic year.
Organizations who have not paid will be put on probation until dues are paid off. They will be frozen and have no voting rights until dues are paid in full. 



Procedures to become Active
Contact Office of Fraternities and Sororities
Contact the Multicultural Greek Council – Executive Board
Fulfill the following Multicultural Greek Council Program Requirements in two consecutive semesters:
1 Academic program
1 Cultural program
1 Community Service program
1 Social program
Fulfill the following Office of Fraternities and Sororities Program Requirements
1 Multiculturalism and/or diversity program
1 Substance Abuse program
1 Leadership and/or Organizational Issues program
If applicable, pay off all dues, fees, and debts of the organization within the Multicultural Greek Council. 
Once all requirements have been completed, contact the Executive Board to set up a presentation date.
Directly after the presentation, each active organization of the Multicultural 
Greek Council will have a voice, but no vote, to determine whether the 
inactive group will be recognized by the Multicultural Greek Council.
In this case, only the Executive Board will vote, considering the council’s voice.
The council president will notify the inactive group within 24 hours of the council’s decision.
If not accepted, the inactive group can send the Multicultural Greek Council – Executive Board a proposal for another presentation date.
In this case, each active organization president and executive board member of the council will have a vote directly after the presentation
If not completed within two consecutive semesters, the inactive group must send the Multicultural Greek Council – Executive Board a proposal requesting another presentation date (asking for an extension). This is will be discretion the executive board.
After the organization has been approved to be in the council, the organization will be considered under “Probation Status” the following semester
While in probation status, organizations have a voice, but no voting rights.
Organizations have at least 2 delegates at all MGC general body meetings, All Council meetings, and MGC events and community services.
Must pay council dues of $30 by the 2nd general body meeting of the semester



Section 4 - Interest Groups
 
A.	Definition
        i.  Interest groups are fraternities or sororities interested in joining the Multicultural Greek Council that have not been previously recognized by the Multicultural Greek Council.

B. 	Procedure to join the council

1.  	Contact Office of Fraternities and Sororities
2.  	Be recognized by the National Board of the fraternity/sorority they are interested in joining (an official letter from their nationals to the executive board stating they are officially an interest group).
3.  	Within one year of joining the organization, be recognized by the University of Massachusetts – Amherst as a Registered Student Organization 			
Contact the Multicultural Greek Council – Executive Board and send a proposal to set up a presentation date.
4.  	Directly after the presentation, each active organization of the Multicultural Greek Council will have one vote to determine whether the interest group will be recognized by the Multicultural Greek Council.
a.   In the case of a tie, each member of the Executive Board will vote individually.
5.  	The council president will notify the interest group within 24 hours of the council’s decision.
a.   If not accepted, the interest group can send the Multicultural Greek Council – Executive Board a proposal for another presentation date
6.  	Once the interest group has been accepted by the Multicultural Greek Council, they have two consecutive semesters to become affiliated with the organization they are interested in.
a.   If not completed within two consecutive semesters, the interest group must send the Multicultural Greek Council – Executive Board a proposal requesting another presentation date.

B. Guidelines for Admittance

Interest groups must receive 3 Y’s for the main question portion section of the guidelines. For the subsets, any questions answered no will automatically bar the group from admittance into the council. Questions 6-8 are not to be used in the vote, but can be used for special consideration in the discussion during the presentation or in the event there is a majority N for question 5. 

1. Does the population represented in the organization represent an underrepresented population on campus/not represented within any of the other 3 Greek councils? Y/N
2. Does the interest group have a sustainable model for operations, recruitment and programming? Y/N
If not, do they have the means to attend the proper trainings to do so? Y/N
3. Are they recognized by the interested organization’s national office? Y/N
4. Are they a recognized RSO? Y/N
If not, are they on course to become an RSO within the next 2 semesters? Y/N
5. Do you feel the admittance of this organization will help the council in its growth and operation? Y/N
*6. Was this organization previously established at UMass? Y/N
*7. Does this organization have any other local entities? Y/N
*8. Is this a local or national/international organization? Y/N
If local organization, what support systems does it have in place to help with operations? Y/N

Article IV – Executive Board

Section 1 – Executive Board
The officers of the University of Massachusetts- Amherst Multicultural Greek
Council shall be President, Vice President, Treasurer, Secretary, and  Events Coordinator, Public Relations.
Executive Board members shall hold their positions from April 1st to March 31st.
They shall serve as officers of the Multicultural Greek Council and shall have powers and duties as prescribed in the Constitution of the University of Massachusetts- Amherst Multicultural Greek Council.
The Executive Board shall have the power of the Council in emergencies that necessitate immediate action between meetings. A report of such actions must be made at the following general body meeting. 
Executive Board shall meet every other week in between Council meetings.
Any officer can be impeached or asked to resign by the majority (3/4) of the Council for just cause.

Duties 
President- the general duties and responsibilities of the President include, but are not limited to, the following:
Maintaining lines of communication with the Office of Fraternities and Sororities
Attend Council Board meetings, or choose designee to attend in their place
Report to the Secretary of Registry, RSOs that are in violation of SGA by-law’s and/or University of Massachusetts Amherst policies.
Function as liaison between RSOs in MGC and SGA
Schedule e-board meetings with advisor at least (1) a month during the regular period.
Encouraging each organization to take initiative in creating and implementing ideas/events
Holding officers and organizations accountable for their goals and responsibilities
Prepare general body agenda and send to secretary for revision and distribution
Call and lead MGC meetings
Carry out training to the council as recommended by the Secretary of Registry or Student Activities and Involvement Advisor
Delegating tasks to officers on the executive board
Take Signature Responsibility and Event Coordinator training
Serve as Four Council liaison with IFC, PanHellenic Council and NPHC. 
Enforce the Multicultural Greek Council regulations, constitution and policies.
Review constitution every year with the executive board

Vice President- the general duties and responsibilities of the Vice President include, but are not limited to, the following:
Assume the responsibility of the president in her/his absence
Maintaining lines of communication with the executive board and each individual organization
Attend Council Board meetings with Council President
Support the president, and perform any duties assigned by the president
Review constitution every year with the executive board

Treasurer
Maintain accurate records of expenditures and receipts of all funds
Handle all financial exchanges
Collects semester dues
Prepares/monitors budget for each year
Serve as authorized signer for the Multicultural Greek Council
In absence of president and vice president, the treasurer will be an interim 
Attend Treasurer Board meetings or choose designee to attend in their place.
Work collaboratively with the Ways and Means Representative for their council and the Secretary of Finance, to ensure RSOs in their council are following SGA by-laws and University of Massachusetts Amherst spending policies.
Report to Secretary of Finance RSOs that are in violation of SGA or UMass Amherst’s spending policies. 
Meet at least (2) twice a semester with the Secretary of Finance and the Ways and Means Representative for MGC.
Carry out financial trainings to their council as instructed by the Ways and Means Representative to MGC, the Chair of Ways and Means or the Secretary of Finance. 
Review constitution every year with the executive board

Secretary

Send out general body minutes to presidents and delegates and Secretary of Registry
Maintain and distribute current contact information list of the executive board of the council, the presidents of each organizations, and delegates.
Review constitution every year with the executive board

Event Coordinator
Review constitution every year with the executive board

Work in conjunction with the Public Relations officer.

a. Impeachment charges can be brought to the general body through a petition signed by a two-third (2/3) of the RSOs of the general body or two-third (2/3) of the executive board members in that council of the officer in question.
b. The council’s Secretary of Registry, or their designee, shall chair meetings where impeachment charges are on the agenda.
c. The petition and any other documents regarding the impeachment must be also given to the Secretary of the Registry and the council’s SA&I advisor.
d. Impeachment charges that have been brought to the general body shall follow this procedure:
Impeachment charges must be on the agenda for the next regularly scheduled general body meeting.
Impeachment charges shall be the first item on the agenda.
The general body member who filed the impeachment charges shall have ten (10) minutes maximum to address the general body.
The officer in question shall then have ten (10) minutes maximum to address the general body.
The chair of the meeting shall then call a vote from the general body members.
If two-thirds (2/3) of the RSOs present are in favor of impeachment, the officer in question shall be removed from their office.
