If not accepted, the interest group can send the Multicultural Greek 
Council – Executive Board a proposal for another presentation date 
7. Once the interest group has been accepted by the Multicultural Greek Council, 
they have two consecutive semesters to become affiliated with the organization 
they are interested in. 

a.

If not completed within two consecutive semesters, the interest group must 
send the Multicultural Greek Council – Executive Board a proposal 
requesting another presentation date. 

8. Once affiliated

, interest groups must fulfill the following Multicultural Greek 

Council Program Requirements in two consecutive semesters 

● 1 Academic program 
● 1 Cultural program 
● 1 Community Service program 
● 1 Social program 

* These events must be sponsored by the Multicultural Greek 
Council 

9.

Interest groups must also fulfill the following Office of Fraternities and Sororities 
Program Requirements. 

● 1 Multiculturalism and/or diversity program 
● 1 Substance Abuse program 
● 1 Leadership and/or Organizational Issues program 

10. Upon event completion, the interest group must send the Multicultural Greek 

Council – Executive Board a proposal for a follow-up presentation 

 
​
 11. Directly after the presentation, each active organization of the Multicultural Greek 

Council will have one vote to determine whether the interest group will be 
officially recognized by the Multicultural Greek Council. 

a.

In the case of a tie, the Executive Board will vote individually. 

12. The council president will notify the interest group within 24 hours of the 

council’s decision. 

a.

If not accepted, the interest group must meet with the Multicultural Greek 
Council – Executive Board to discuss a new action plan regarding their 
events. Afterwards, send a new proposal for another presentation date. 

13. Once officially recognized by the Multicultural Greek Council, the interest group 

will become an active organization under “Probation Status” 

a. While in probation status, organizations have a voice, but no voting rights. 
b. Organizations must have at least three delegates at all MGC general body 

meetings, All Council meetings, and MGC events and community 
services. 

c. Pay council dues of $30 by the 3

rd
​ week of the semester 

Article IV – Executive Board 

Section 1 – Executive Board 

A. The officers of the University of Massachusetts- Amherst Multicultural Greek 

i.

Council shall be President, Vice President, Treasurer, Secretary and 
Parliamentarian/Events Coordinator, Four Council Liaison/Publicity.  
They shall serve as officers of the Multicultural Greek Council and shall have 
powers and duties as prescribed in the Constitution of the University of 
Massachusetts- Amherst Multicultural Greek Council. 

ii. The Executive Board shall have the power of the general Council in 

emergencies that necessitate action between meetings. A report of such 
actions must be made at the following general body meeting.  

iii. Executive Board shall meet every other week in between General Body 

meetings. 

iv. Any officer can be impeached or asked to resign by the majority (3/4) of the 

Council for just cause. 

B. Duties  

a. President- 

the general duties and responsibilities of the President include, but 

are not limited to, the following: 

i. Maintaining lines of communication with the Office of Fraternities and 

Sororities 

ii. Encouraging each organization to take initiative in creating and 

implementing ideas/events 

iii. Holding officers and organizations accountable for their goals and 

responsibilities 

​
 
 
 
 
​
 iv. Prepare general body agenda and send to secretary for revision and 

distribution 

v. Delegating tasks to officers on the executive board 

b. Vice President- 

the general duties and responsibilities of the Vice President 

include, but are not limited to, the following: 

i. Assume the responsibility of the president in her/his absence 
ii. Maintaining lines of communication with the executive board and each 

individual organization 

iii. Support the president, and perform any duties assigned by the 

president 

c. Treasurer 

i. Maintain accurate records of expenditures and receipts of all funds 
ii. Handle all financial exchanges 
iii. Collects semester dues 
iv. Prepares/monitors budget for each year 
v. Serve as authorized signer for the Multicultural Greek Council 
vi.

In absence of president and vice president, the treasurer will be an 
interim  

d. Secretary 

i. Record all attendance and take minutes at all executive board and 

general body meetings 

ii. Print out and distribute agenda to the executive board and delegates 
iii. Send out general body minutes to presidents and delegates 
iv. Maintain and distribute current contact information list of the 

executive board of the council, the presidents of each organizations, 
and delegates. 

e. Parliamentarian/Event Coordinator 

i. Enforce the Multicultural Greek Council regulations, constitution and 

policies. 

ii. Review constitution every year with the executive board  
iii. Be in charge of room bookings, campus pulse event submissions, and 

duties affiliated with coordinating an event 

iv. Work in conjunction with the Four Council Liaison/Public Relations 

chair 

f. Four Council Liaison/Public Relations 

i. Maintain lines of communication amongst the rest of the councils 
ii. Compile a list of events from other councils to present to the 

Multicultural Greek Council general body 

iii. Promote the image of the Multicultural Greek Council through various 

 
 
​
 
 
 
 
 social network sites. 

iv. Promote Multicultural Greek Council events and be in charge of 

creating flyers for such events 

Section 2 – Eligibility, Nomination, and Voting Process 

A. Eligibility 

a. The officers shall be delegated from fraternities/sororities holding active 

b.

membership in the University of Massachusetts- Amherst Multicultural Greek 
Council.  
In order to be nominated and elected for an Executive Board position, the 
individual must be an enrolled undergraduate student during both semesters of 
his/her term and have at least a 2.5 cumulative GPA. The individual must also 
have been on the council previously for at least one semester.  

i. To run for 

President

, candidate must have been on the executive 

board of their organization before for at least one full term and not be 
current President of any other Registered Student Organizations. 

B. Nomination 

a. Nominations will be held the second to last general body meeting of the 
semester.  The candidate must be nominated by him/herself or any other 
council member. 

i. Nominations can be accepted or denied by the nominee at the second 

to last general body meeting.  

ii. Maximum of 2 nominees per organization per position. 

C. Elections 

a. Elections will be done last general body meeting of the fall semester 

(Jan-Dec). The day of elections, each candidate must come with a speech and 
be prepared for a possible Q&A session afterwards. 
In the case if a nominee could not attend the election they forfeit their 
nomination. 

b.

c. The general body delegates will be given one pre-printed ballot per 

organization to cast their vote. Executive board has 1 vote per position 
separate from his or her organization. 

i.

If a delegate will be absent, the delegate must notify an officer of the 
Executive Board and designate a convenient time to cast their vote. 
ii. All ballots will be given to the executive board and the new Executive 

Board will be announced at the end of the last meeting. 

iii. Each candidate must win by a simple majority 
iv.

In the case of a tie the executive board will make the final decision. 

 
 
​
​

DocsList.Data:
University of Massachusetts – Amherst
Multicultural Greek Council

Constitution & Bylaws









Edited by:
Sovanny Lim
President (Spring 2016 - Fall 2016)
Sigma Psi Zeta Sorority Inc.

Mrinal Asthana
Vice President (Spring 2016 - Fall 2016)
Beta Chi Theta National Fraternity Inc.
 
January 19, 2016
Article I – Name

The name of this association shall be the University of Massachusetts- Amherst Multicultural Greek Council, also referred to as the UMass Amherst MGC

Article II – Objectives and Jurisdiction

Section 1 - Objectives

The objective of the Multicultural Greek Council shall be to develop and maintain
fraternity life and interfraternity relations at a high level of accomplishment and in so doing to:
Consider the goals and ideals of member groups as continually applicable to campus and personal life.
Promote superior scholarship as basic to intellectual achievement.
Cooperate with member fraternities/sororities and university administration in concern for cultural awareness and maintenance of high social and moral standards.
Act in accordance with all rules established by the University of 
Massachusetts-Amherst Multicultural Greek Council, as to not violate the 
sovereignty, rights, and privileges of member fraternities and sororities.
Be a forum for discussion of questions of interest to the university and the fraternity/sorority world.
Encourage social service and philanthropic activities for the development of members and the Amherst community.
Further leadership education and development within the Greek realm and on campus.

Section 2 – University Jurisdiction

The University of Massachusetts – Amherst Multicultural Greek Council is under the jurisdiction of the Registered Student Organization Office and therefore adheres and follows all regulations established by the school for Registered Student Organizations and fraternity/sorority organizations.

Article III – Membership

Section 1 – Council Membership
As of 01/13/2016 the membership of the University of Massachusetts- Amherst Multicultural Greek Council is composed of the members of the following organizations at the University of Massachusetts- Amherst and nationals:


Delta Xi Phi Multicultural Sorority, Inc.
Kappa Phi Lambda Sorority, Inc.
Pi Delta Psi Fraternity, Inc.
Sigma Psi Zeta Sorority, Inc.
Beta Chi Theta National Fraternity, Inc. 

Chapters previously on this campus (inactive):
Gamma Phi Sigma, Hermanos Unidos Fraternity, Inc.
La Unidad Latina, Lambda Upsilon Lambda Fraternity, Inc.
Latinas Promoviendo Comunidad/ Lambda Pi Chi Sorority, Inc. 
Hermandad de Sigma Iota Alpha, Inc.
Sigma Lambda Beta International Fraternity, Inc.
Sigma Lambda Upsilon/Señoritas Latinas Unidas Sorority, Inc.
Omega Psi Delta Sorority, Inc.
Phi Iota Alpha Fraternity, Inc.
Sigma Lambda Gamma National Sorority, Inc.


Section 2 – Active Membership

Definition
Organization that have undergraduate members or representation on campus.
Organizations in good financial standing. 
Organizations that attend all meetings and events pertaining to the council and Office of Fraternities and Sororities
Rights of Active Members
Have full voice and voting rights.
Expectations and Responsibilities include, but are not limited to
 Each organization must have at least two delegates at all MGC general body 
    meetings and All Council (OFS) meetings
With the exception of organizations with 15 members or less. They can send two delegates
With the exception of organizations with 10 members or less. They can send one delegate
A delegate on the executive board can count as one delegate
Pay council dues of $30 by the 2nd general body meeting
Dues will increase by $10 every week they are not turned in

Section 3 – Inactive Status

Definition
Organizations that have no undergraduate members or representation on campus.
Multicultural Greek Council organizations that have not paid all dues and fees to the Multicultural Greek Council by the end of the academic year.


Procedures to become Active
Contact Office of Fraternities and Sororities
Contact the Multicultural Greek Council – Executive Board
Fulfill the following Multicultural Greek Council Program Requirements in two consecutive semesters:
1 Academic program
1 Cultural program
1 Community Service program
1 Social program
* These events must be sponsored by the Multicultural Greek Council
Sponsored can be defined as: providing financial and social support. Up to the discussion of the executive board.
Fulfill the following Office of Fraternities and Sororities Program Requirements
1 Multiculturalism and/or diversity program
1 Substance Abuse program
1 Leadership and/or Organizational Issues program
If applicable, pay off all dues, fees, and debts of the organization within the Multicultural Greek Council. 
Once all requirements have been completed, contact the Executive Board to set up a presentation date.
Directly after the presentation, each active organization of the Multicultural 
Greek Council will have a voice, but no vote, to determine whether the 
inactive group will be recognized by the Multicultural Greek Council.
In this case, only the Executive Board will vote, considering the council’s voice.
The council president will notify the inactive group within 24 hours of the council’s decision.
If not accepted, the inactive group can send the Multicultural Greek Council – Executive Board a proposal for another presentation date.
In this case, each active organization president and executive board member of the council will have a vote directly after the presentation
If not completed within two consecutive semesters, the inactive group must send the Multicultural Greek Council – Executive Board a proposal requesting another presentation date (asking for an extension). This is will be discretion the executive board.
After the organization has been approved to be in the council, the organization will be considered under “Probation Status” the following semester
While in probation status, organizations have a voice, but no voting rights.
Organizations have at least 2 delegates at all MGC general body meetings, All Council meetings, and MGC events and community services.
Must pay council dues of $30 by the 2nd general body meeting of the semester







Section 4 - Interest Groups

Definition
 Interest groups are fraternities or sororities interested in joining the Multicultural Greek Council that have not been previously recognized by the Multicultural Greek Council. 
Procedure to join the council
Be recognized by the National Board of the fraternity/sorority they are interested in joining (an official letter from their nationals to the executive board stating they are officially an interest group).
Contact Office of Fraternities and Sororities
Within one year of joining the council, be recognized by the University of Massachusetts – Amherst as a Registered Student Organization
Contact the Multicultural Greek Council – Executive Board and send a proposal to set up a presentation date.
Directly after the presentation, each active organization of the Multicultural Greek Council will have one vote to determine whether the interest group will be recognized by the Multicultural Greek Council.
In the case of a tie, each member of the Executive Board will vote individually.
The council president will notify the interest group within 24 hours of the council’s decision.
If not accepted, the interest group can send the Multicultural Greek Council – Executive Board a proposal for another presentation date
Once the interest group has been accepted by the Multicultural Greek Council, they have two consecutive semesters to become affiliated with the organization they are interested in.
If not completed within two consecutive semesters, the interest group must send the Multicultural Greek Council – Executive Board a proposal requesting another presentation date.
Once affiliated, interest groups must fulfill the following Multicultural Greek Council Program Requirements in two consecutive semesters
1 Academic program
1 Cultural program
1 Community Service program
1 Social program
* These events must be sponsored by the Multicultural Greek Council
Interest groups must also fulfill the following Office of Fraternities and Sororities Program Requirements.
1 Multiculturalism and/or diversity program
1 Substance Abuse program
1 Leadership and/or Organizational Issues program
Upon event completion, the interest group must send the Multicultural Greek Council – Executive Board a proposal for a follow-up presentation
Directly after the presentation, each active organization of the Multicultural Greek Council will have one vote to determine whether the interest group will be officially recognized by the Multicultural Greek Council.
In the case of a tie, the Executive Board will vote individually.
The council president will notify the interest group within 24 hours of the council’s decision.
If not accepted, the interest group must meet with the Multicultural Greek Council – Executive Board to discuss a new action plan regarding their events. Afterwards, send a new proposal for another presentation date.
Once officially recognized by the Multicultural Greek Council, the interest group will become an active organization under “Probation Status”
While in probation status, organizations have a voice, but no voting rights.
Organizations must have at least 2 delegates at all MGC general body meetings, All Council meetings, and MGC events and community services.
Pay council dues of $30 by the 3rd week of the semester


Article IV – Executive Board

Section 1 – Executive Board
The officers of the University of Massachusetts- Amherst Multicultural Greek
Council shall be President, Vice President, Treasurer, Secretary and  Parliamentarian/Events Coordinator, Four Council Liaison/Publicity,  Community Service.
They shall serve as officers of the Multicultural Greek Council and shall have powers and duties as prescribed in the Constitution of the University of Massachusetts- Amherst Multicultural Greek Council.
The Executive Board shall have the power of the general Council in emergencies that necessitate action between meetings. A report of such actions must be made at the following general body meeting. 
Executive Board shall meet every other week in between General Body meetings.
Any officer can be impeached or asked to resign by the majority (3/4) of the Council for just cause.

Duties 
President- the general duties and responsibilities of the President include, but are not limited to, the following:
Maintaining lines of communication with the Office of Fraternities and Sororities
Encouraging each organization to take initiative in creating and implementing ideas/events
Holding officers and organizations accountable for their goals and responsibilities
Prepare general body agenda and send to secretary for revision and distribution
Delegating tasks to officers on the executive board


Vice President- the general duties and responsibilities of the Vice President include, but are not limited to, the following:
Assume the responsibility of the president in her/his absence
Maintaining lines of communication with the executive board and each individual organization
Support the president, and perform any duties assigned by the president

Treasurer
Maintain accurate records of expenditures and receipts of all funds
Handle all financial exchanges
Collects semester dues
Prepares/monitors budget for each year
Serve as authorized signer for the Multicultural Greek Council
In absence of president and vice president, the treasurer will be an interim 

Secretary
Record all attendance and take minutes at all executive board and general body meetings
Print out and distribute agenda to the executive board and delegates
Send out general body minutes to presidents and delegates
Maintain and distribute current contact information list of the executive board of the council, the presidents of each organizations, and delegates.

Parliamentarian/Event Coordinator
Enforce the Multicultural Greek Council regulations, constitution and policies.
Review constitution every year with the executive board 
Be in charge of room bookings, campus pulse event submissions, and duties affiliated with coordinating an event
Work in conjunction with the Four Council Liaison/Public Relations chair

Community Service
		 i. Maintain lines of communication with local organizations from   
                                        previous semesters that provide outlets for community service
		ii. Come up with a tentative list of potential events
		iii.Must coordinate the event corresponding to the schedules of the council   
     members

Four Council Liaison/Public Relations
Maintain lines of communication amongst the rest of the councils
Compile a list of events from other councils to present to the Multicultural Greek Council general body
Promote the image of the Multicultural Greek Council through various social network sites.
Promote Multicultural Greek Council events and be in charge of creating flyers for such events


Section 2 – Eligibility, Nomination, and Voting Process
Eligibility
The officers shall be delegated from fraternities/sororities holding active membership in the University of Massachusetts- Amherst Multicultural Greek Council. 
In order to be nominated and elected for an Executive Board position, the individual must be an enrolled undergraduate student during both semesters of his/her term and have at least a 2.5 cumulative GPA. The individual must also have been on the council previously for at least one semester. 

To run for President, candidate must have been on the executive board of their organization before for at least one full term and not be current President of any other Registered Student Organizations.
Nomination
Nominations will be held the second to last general body meeting of the semester.  The candidate must be nominated by him/herself or any other council member.
Nominations can be accepted or denied by the nominee at the second to last general body meeting. 
Maximum of 2 nominees per organization per position.
Elections
Elections will be done last general body meeting of the fall semester (Jan-Dec). The day of elections, each candidate must come with a speech and be prepared for a possible Q&A session afterwards.
In the case if a nominee could not attend the election they forfeit their nomination.
The general body delegates will be given one pre-printed ballot per organization to cast their vote. Executive board has 1 vote per position separate from his or her organization.
If a delegate will be absent, the delegate must notify an officer of the Executive Board and designate a convenient time to cast their vote.
All ballots will be given to the executive board and the new Executive Board will be announced at the end of the last meeting.
Each candidate must win by a simple majority
In the case of a tie the executive board will make the final decision.

National Association for the Advancement of Colored People 2021-2022.pdf
DocsList.Data:
The National Association for the Advancement of
Colored People: Chapter at the University of
Massachusetts-Amherst

Constitution

 ARTICLE I

NAME AND JURISDICTION

(Name)

a. The name of this organization shall be the University of Massachusetts - Amherst

College Chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

(Jurisdiction)

a. Whenever a College Chapter is located in a city or country containing another unit of the
NAACP, the off-campus activity of the College Chapter shall be by mutual exchange of
information

ARTICLE II
MISSION AND OBJECTIVES

MISSION STATEMENT:

The mission of the UMass Amherst College Chapter of the National Association for the

Advancement of Colored People is to ensure the political, educational, social and economic
equality of rights of all students and to eliminate race-based discrimination on campus.

Chapter Objectives:

● To ensure the political, educational, social and economic equality of all students.

● To achieve equality of rights and eliminate race prejudice among the students of the

University of Massachusetts - Amherst

● To concern ourselves with the educational practices of our campus as well as other

campuses

● Be a center of popular education on the problems of students of color and the work of the

NAACP

● To inform students of the adverse effects of racial discrimination and to seek its

elimination

● To work for the integration of students, faculty and non-teaching personnel and the

elimination of quota systems.

Programming:

1

 The University of Massachusetts-Amherst Chapter of the NAACP shall look to promote these
objectives through the use of programming that includes but is not limited to:

● Lectures
● Panel Discussions
● Social Events (eg. Game Nights, Listening Parties, etc.)
● Fundraising Events
● Tabling Events
● Voter Registration Parties

5 Year Goals:

● Increase diversity in the student body as well as within the faculty and staff of the

University of Massachusetts-Amherst
● Expand Black culture within the University
● Strengthen pride in the Black identity
● Stay in Compliance with the National Office
● Create connections between the Association and the University

ARTICLE III
MEMBERSHIP REQUIREMENTS

(NAACP Chapter Member Requirements)

Requirements:

The National and UMass requirements for being a member shall be:

a. Any person under the age of 25 and/or currently enrolled as a student at the

University of Massachusetts Amherst

b. Any UMass student may become a member of the NAACP. The admission

will not be based on race, creed, gender, sexual preference, physical ability or
any other discriminatory criteria. A minimum of 25 members is required for
NAACP affiliation with UMass and Nationals. Non-voting membership is
available for any member of the 5-college community, their dependents, staff,
faculty, and alumni.

2

 c. Any prospective voting members must be in compliance with National and
UMass Chapter requirements and follow the following procedure for
becoming an acknowledged member of the Chapter:
a. Sign up for the mailing list with the Secretary
b. Complete the National membership application; which must be given

to the Secretary for record keeping

c. Pay annual National fee of $15 within two (2) weeks of application

submission and thirty (30) days before elections

d. The Chapter prohibits dicrimination under Federal and State law, based on
race, color, national origin, religion, sex, gender identity (including gender
expression), sexual orientation, disability, age, maritial status, family/parental
status, income derived from public assistance program, political beliefs, or
reprisal or retaliation for prior civil rights activity, or any part of someone’s
identity.

e. All members of the NAACP UMass Amherst Chapter are entitled to freedom
of speech and through self-empowerment and with a strong voice, create unity
within the community of the University of Massachusetts Amherst, and
establish connections with other such organization in the Five College Area,
as well as, other registered student organizations and campus agencies in order
to carry out its. Under no circumstances shall a member’s freedom of speech
or expression be infringed.

Chapter Governance and Procedures

(NAACP Meetings)

Meetings of Units

a. Regular Meetings. Regular General Membership meetings shall be held at least
twice a month and each General Body Meeting shall be assigned to one of the
Committee Heads. Each General Body Meeting shall be headed by the Committee
Head to which that General Body Meeting was assigned under the advisement of
the appointed executive board members who oversee that committee. Each

3

 General Body Meeting shall follow the Order of Business and respect Robert’s
Rules.

b. Executive Board Meetings. Executive Board Meetings shall be held at least once a
week and will be headed by the President of the Chapter. The President shall
follow the Order of Business to conduct the meeting and shall respect Robert’s
Rules.

c. Annual Meetings. Annual Meetings will be headed by the President of the

Chapter. Annual Meetings will also follow the Order of Business of all other
Meetings conducted by the Chapter. As instructed by the Bylaws for Units of the
NAACP, each college Chapter shall hold an Annual meeting for the election of
officers between March 1st and April 1st of each year, unless the date(s) of the
meeting is changed with the written approval of the National Office.

d. Order of Business. Each general body meeting will uphold the mission and goals
of the Chapter and Committee that is holding the General Body Meeting. Unless
altered or suspended at any meeting by a majority vote of the members present,
shall follow the order of business at meetings which goes as follows:

i.
ii.
iii.
iv.
v.
vi.
vii.

Ascertainment of members present;
Reading of minutes of previous meeting;
Reports of Officers;
Reports of Committees;
Elections (during the Annual Meeting and Special Election Meetings);
Unfinished Business; and
New Business;

e. Decision Making During Meetings. The Chapter will follow Robert’s Rules of
Order to make decisions. The elements of Robert’s Rules are as follows:

i. Motion: To introduce a new piece of business or propose a decision or

action, a motion must be made by a group member ("I move that......") A
second motion must then also be made (raise your hand and say, "I second
it.") After limited discussion the group then votes on the motion. A
majority vote is required for the motion to pass
Postpone Indefinitely: This tactic is used to kill a motion. When passed,
the motion cannot be reintroduced at that meeting. It may be brought up
again at a later date. This is made as a motion ("I move to postpone
indefinitely..."). A second is required. A majority vote is required to
postpone the motion under consideration.
Amend: This is the process used to change a motion under consideration.
Perhaps you like the idea proposed but not exactly as offered. Raise your
hand and make the following motion: "I move to amend the motion on the

ii.

iii.

4

 floor." This also requires a second. After the motion to amend is seconded,
a majority vote is needed to decide whether the amendment is accepted.
Then a vote is taken on the amended motion. In some organizations, a
"friendly amendment" is made. If the person who made the original
motion agrees with the suggested changes, the amended motion may be
voted on without a separate vote to approve the amendment.
Commit: This is used to place a motion in committee. It requires a second.
A majority vote must rule to carry it. At the next meeting the committee is
required to prepare a report on the motion committed. If an appropriate
committee exists, the motion goes to that committee. If not, a new
committee is established.
Question: To end a debate immediately, the question is called (say "I call
the question") and needs a second. A vote is held immediately (no further
discussion is allowed). A two-thirds vote is required for passage. If it is
passed, the motion on the floor is voted on immediately.
Table: To table a discussion is to lay aside the business at hand in such a
manner that it will be considered later in the meeting or at another time ("I
make a motion to table this discussion until the next meeting. In the
meantime, we will get more information so we can better discuss the
issue.") A second is needed and a majority vote required to table the item
being discussed.
Adjourn: A motion is made to end the meeting. A second motion is
required. A majority vote is then required for the meeting to be adjourned
(ended).

iv.

v.

vi.

vii.

Meetings of the State/State-Area Conference

a. Our Chapter shall attend the Annual Meeting hosted by the NAACP New England
State Conference who shall also head the meetings. At the Conference we shall
act upon Annual reports for each New England Branch and from Officers and
Standing Committees.

b. Regular meetings of the State/state area conference shall be held on days selected

by the Conference

Notice of Meetings

a. Regular Meetings & Executive Board Meetings: Written notice shall be provided
a minimum of 7 days prior to Executive and General Board meetings, notice shall
be sent by email and shared through social media for Regular Meetings.

b. Annual Meetings: Written notice shall be provided a minimum of 30 days prior to
the meeting and shall include the time and place of the Annual Meeting to each
member, and shall be shared online via email.

Quorum

5

 c. The number of members necessary to constitute a quorum at all meetings shall be
a minimum of 10 members in good standing with both Nationals and the UMass
Amherst Chapter.

(NAACP Positions and Duties)

Executive Board Compliance:

Executive board members must be:

a. Full time student at UMass Amherst

b.

In accordance with the national and UMass Amherst Chapter regulations

c. Abiding all constitutional bylaws

d. Assigned a Game Changer Committee to oversee

e. Able to fulfill all respective duties on a timely manner

i.

Any Executive Board member who is in violation of said compliance rules

may be subject to removal of responsibilities. See Removal of Executive

Board Members and Committee Heads section below.

President:

The duties of the President shall be:

a. To be present at Chapter meetings and lead the Executive Board meetings,

including having a set agenda.

b. To send out the agenda for Executive Board members so they are aware of the

topics that will be discussed during said meeting.

6

 c. Be the head of the Chapter and to exercise general executive authority on

behalf of the NAACP Chapter, subject to ratification by the Executive Board.

d. To encourage and assist all board members in the development of their

programs and the performance of their duties.

e. To write the Annual Report on the status and activities of the Chapter for the

Annual Meeting.

f. To write and submit an annual report to the Secretary of Registry detailing the
Chapter’s progress toward achieving the goals listed in the 2019 Strategic
Plan.

g. To hold Signature Responsibility.

Vice President:

The duties of the Vice President shall be:

a. To perform all the duties of the President in their absence or disability. In case
of more than one Vice President, the Vice Presidents shall be designated first,
second, third and so forth and shall perform their duties according to their
numerical rank.

b. Be a supportive role for the President and be appointed delegated duties.

c.

In the event of the resignation or removal of the President, the Vice
President(s) shall automatically ascend to the position of President, according
to their numerical rank, for the remainder of the term of the presidency. Any

other Vice President(s) shall ascend in the same manner.

Secretary:

The duties of the Secretary shall be:

a. To act as secretary of the NAACP Chapter, give members notice of regular
meetings and at least seven (7) calendar days notice of special meetings and
events.

b. To keep full and accurate records of meetings and proceedings of the Chapter
at the University of Massachusetts and record the same in meeting minutes.

7

 c. To keep a record of all Chapter members and their dues through the use of the
National online database, along with providing receipts for all membership
fees received and to transmit the fees to the Treasurer.

d. To send promptly to the treasurer lists of all membership fees received, and to
assure that the portion of membership fees that goes to the association is sent.

e. To secure the booking of rooms for Executive Board meetings, General Body

Meetings, and special events.

f. To submit to the Youth Unit at its annual meeting, an Annual Report on the

status and activities of the Chapter

g. All records will additionally be kept under a secured email database for

back-up purposes

Treasurer:

The duties of the Treasurer shall be:

a. To receive all money of the Chapter and promptly deposit the same in the
name of the NAACP Unit in a separate account in a responsible bank.

b. To maintain the bank account and make sure that it is in good standing.

c. To send out received application forms and fees to the Association, along with

keeping records of applications sent in and all fees.

d. Submit year-end financial reports to the Chapter President on or before

February 1st.

e. To remit through the secretary to the association the proportion of

membership fees to which the Association is entitled, as hereinafter provided,
within fifteen (15)  calendar days after their receipt.

f. To ensure that all assessment fees are paid to Nationals and the State/Area
Conference that may vary depending on active membership numbers.

8

 g. To ensure that the registration fee for the State/Area Conference Annual
Meeting of  four (4) officers is secured and sent in before the registration
deadline

h. To hold Signature Responsibility.

RSO Liaison:

The duties of the RSO Liaison shall be:

a. To work in collaboration with other organizations that align with the organization’s

mission and goals on campus to create programming

b. To be the main communication between other Registered Student Organizations and

the Chapter.

c. To create bonds with the executives from other organizations

Public Relations Chair(s):

The duties of the Public Relations Chair(s) shall be:

a. To seek to promote media content consistent with fundamental NAACP goals
which include the elimination of racial isolation and fear and the furtherance
of multiracial and cultural understanding

b. To monitor local and national media, especially advertising events and the

ideals of the NAACP

c. To secure publicity for the work of the Chapter and the Association in the

local press and on radio and other media.

d. To act as far as possible as an agency for the promotion of diversity. No

publicity shall be released without being approved by the President of the
Chapter

9

 e.

In the event of more than one Public Relations Chair, the Chairs shall split
these responsibilities evenly and ensure that one person is responsible for the
distribution of physical promotion, such as: flyers, handbills and promo items,
and another be responsible for social media promotions, such as managing the
Chapter’s Twitter, Instagram and Snapchat accounts.

Membership Chair:

The duties of the Membership Chair shall be

a. To work throughout the year to maintain and increase the membership of the

Chapter

b. To be responsible for planning and organizing membership campaigns and

drives, along with ensuring that the Chapter is tabling before major events and
some General Body meetings.

c. To be continuously responsible during their term for soliciting new members,

and for securing renewals.

d. To be responsible for ensuring that all new members receive their membership

cards and that the member’s preferred name is correct.

e. To initiate all possible means to obtain life members and sponsor a continuing

program towards this end.

Community Service Chair:

The duties of the Community Service Chair shall be:

a. To promote the ideals of the association through community service

opportunities.

b. To create a connection with the members of the Chapter and the residents of

the community through community service

c. To provide bi-weekly opportunities for students to become involved in the

community through volunteering.

d. To plan and coordinate with local homeless shelters, food pantries, etc. to find

where the Chapter may be able to contribute.

10

 Fundraising Chair:

The duties of the Fundraising Chair shall be:

a. To coordinate with the other members of the Executive Board to come up with

ideas for fundraising.

b. To work closely with the Treasurer to find the best ways in which to bring in

revenue and donations.

c. To plan and conduct fund-raising activities, entertainment and other projects
for local and national purposes within the scope of the association’s program.

Freshman Representative:

The duties of the Freshman Representative shall be:

a. To seek membership of incoming freshman and educate current freshman

about the existence of the Chapter.

b. To seek out freshman membership and holding freshman membership drives

at the beginning of each semester.

c. To ensure that freshman that become members pay their dues and are given

their membership cards

d. To create a welcoming environment for other freshman and reaching out to

freshman on their ideas and input.

e. To reach out to freshman-oriented organizations and programs to gain and

retain freshman membership.

Chapter Advisor:

11

 The duties of the Chapter Advisor shall be:

a. To attend a majority of Executive Board meetings

b. To help support promotion of NAACP events including promotion to students,

staff and faculty

c. To be a reliable liaison between the Chapter, the association, and the local

Amherst Chapter

d. To provide guidance to the Executive Board on programming and future

actions of the board

Standing Committees and Duties:

(Duties of the Committee Heads)

The duties of the Standing Committees shall be:

a. Economic Sustainability. The Committee shall seek ways to empower youth

economically by: (1) Encouraging the development of job readiness training and
placement programs for youth and young adults. (2) Studying levels of
unemployment and underemployment of working age youth and the causes of
each. (3) Working for improved opportunities in vocational and apprenticeship
training. (4) Working to eliminate discriminatory employment practices. (5)
Studying levels of youth and young adult credit and debit creating programs to
decrease debt. (6) Creating training programs in entrepreneurship, savings,
investment, and home ownership.

b. Education. The Committee on Education shall: (1) seek to eliminate segregation

and other discriminatory practices in public education. (2) Study local educational
conditions affecting minority groups. (3) Investigate the public school system and
school zoning. (4) Familiarize itself with textbook material there from which is
racially derogatory. (5) Seek to stimulate school attendance. (6) Keep informed of
school conditions and strive to correct abuses where found. (7) Investigate the
effects of standardized and high stakes testing practices, (8) teacher certification,
(9) promote parental involvement in education; and (10) aims to be a center of
popular education on the race question and on the work of the organization.

12

 c. Health. The Heath Committee shall: (1) work to promote, protect and maintain
the health of African Americans; (2) assess the health needs of the community;
(3) advocate for equal access to health education, care, treatment and research for
all Americans; (4) sponsor health-related activities such as health forums, fairs
and workshops highlighting issues of importance to people of color; and (5)
support health initiatives of the association.

d. Public Safety and Criminal Justice. The Committee shall: (1) Seek to eliminate
discriminatory practices in the juvenile and adult justice systems. (2) Research
and monitor local and state incarceration, sentencing, arrest and probation rates of
African- American and other youth of color. (3) Investigate disproportionate
incarceration and sentencing of African-Americans and other youth of color.  (4)
Investigate living conditions and treatment within youth detention centers, (5) and
mobilize Units to correct abuses where found.

e. Voting Rights and Representation. The Committee shall: (1) seek to increase voter
registration and voting; (2) work for the enactment of municipal, state and federal
legislation designed to improve the educational, political, and economic status of
minority groups; (3) seek the repeal of racially discriminatory legislation; (4)
work to improve the administration of justice; (5) work to secure equal
enforcement of the law, and (6) keep the National Office and the Unit informed of
all proposed legislation which affects minority groups. The Committee shall be
nonpartisan and shall not endorse candidates for public office.

f. Expanding Youth and Young Adult Engagement. The Committee shall: (1) seek to
expand the presence of youth consciousness in every aspect of the Association
through significant attention to expanding engagement with key age demographic
(1979 and after); (2) seek to expand youth and young adult involvement in the
policy research, development and advocacy at all levels; (3) encourage student
activism at all levels; (4) seek to interact with local youth and introduce them to
the mission and vision of the Association; (5) promote the National youth agenda
through programming and informationals.

Elections and Selections:

(Executive Board Elections)

a. Elections will be held annually at the Chapter’s Annual Meeting that will occur
between March 1st and April 1st. Any member who is in compliance with
membership requirements listed above can vote in elections.

b. Any Chapter member who is in good standing with both the national and UMass

Chapter requirements is eligible to run for office.

13

 c. Persons running for executive board positions must receive ⅔ of votes to be

appointed to the position.

d. Newly elected officers shall shadow former officers from time of appointment to the

end of the Spring semester.

e. Special Elections. Special Elections shall be held in the case of an unexpected
vacancy in the Executive Board. The process for Special Elections shall be as
follows:

a. The President of the Chapter shall call a Special General Body Meeting to

hold elections giving at least a seven (7) day notice to the membership. The
notice shall include the date, location, time, and the position(s) that are open.

b. Any person looking to run for the open position can give notice to the

President at any point before the elections begin and will be added to the
ballot.

c. The membership shall convene for the meeting and vote following regular

voting rules.

f. Record Keeping of Elections: The standing Secretary of the Chapter shall keep the

minutes of the electoral meeting; including but not limited to:

a. Attendance of membership, including whether or not a quorum was met;
b. Names of the candidates and the positions they are running for;
c. Names of the newly elected officials;
d. The date of the next meeting

(Procedure for Selection of Committee Heads)

a. Prospective Committee Heads will submit a written statement of no more than 400
words during the time of elections. The statement should include: (1) why they
believe they will be a good fit for the position; (2) relevant experience or interest; and
(3) plans and ambitions they have for their desired committee.

b. Upon review of received applications for Committee Heads, the Executive Board will
vote for the candidate that they feel will best fit the position. Each position will be
filled by the person that receives the majority of votes.

(Term of Office)

1. All elected members of the Executive Board, shall be elected by a majority ballot of ⅔ of
the general membership for a two semester term. Elections will be held between March
1st and April 1st annually. Term of each elected member shall begin in the fall semester
of the next academic year.

2. All appointed Committee Heads shall be appointed by a majority vote of the Executive
Board for a two semester term. Applications will be accepted between March 1st and

14

 April 1st. Term of each Committee Head shall begin in the fall semester of the next
academic year.

(Removal of Executive Board Members, Committee Heads and Members)

1. Complaints:

a. A complaint against a member of the Board or Head of Committee may be
initiated by any three (3) members of the Board and must be signed by such
members and sent to the Chapter Advisor.

b. Upon receiving the complaint, the Chapter Advisor will meet with the member

against which the complaint was filed giving them notice of the complaints. After
the meeting, the member will have five (5) calendar days to complete a written
response to the complaint.

c. The Chapter Advisor will bring the written response to the general body during a
scheduled general body meeting where the member against which the complaint
was filed will have the chance to address the membership.

d. The membership shall then vote on the removal of the officer/member, and if ⅔
are in accordance with the removal of said officer/member then, and only then
shall said officer/member be removed.

2. Compliance:

a. Any member of the Executive Board and Heads of Committee who shall be
absent from three (3) consecutive meetings (including general and executive
board meetings) without a minimum of 2 (two) day notice shall be removed by
the board and replaced.

b. Any member of the Executive Board and Heads of Committee who fails to

perform the required duties for 1 (one) consecutive months shall be removed from
the Board and replaced.

c. Any member of the Executive Board or Heads of Committee, who is absent from
50% of the regularly scheduled meetings for the Chapter without notice for a
semester shall be removed from the Board and replaced.

15

 d. Any member who fails their Periodic Evaluations, that includes performing all of
the listed duties to the best of their ability shall be removed from the Board and
replaced.

(Ratification and Amendment of the Constitution)

The Constitution for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People Chapter at
the University of Massachusetts - Amherst becomes effective _________________. The Chapter
understands that needs and positions change with time, that being the case the Constitution may
be amended after the amendment has been proposed three (3) times to the Members and
Executive Board and may then be voted in following a majoritarian system.

16

 As a member of the Executive Board of the NAACP Chapter at the University of Massachusetts
- Amherst, I have an ethical responsibility to ensure that the organization does the best work
possible in pursuit of its goals. I support the purpose and mission of the organization and commit
to assist in carrying out its work.

As an Executive Board member, I will consistently act responsibly. I understand my duties to
include those that have been listed in the Constitution, and understand I have an obligation to
fulfill those to the best of my ability.

Should I fail to fulfill my commitments to the organization, I understand that there is a
possibility of being removed from the Board. Should there come a time where I am no longer
able to fulfill my obligations to the organization, it will be my responsibility to resign my
position as a member of the Executive Board.

DocsList.Name: New NPHC Constitution 2.docx
DocsList.Data:
University Of Massachusetts Amherst
 National Pan-Hellenic Council 
Constitution and By-Laws 

2012-2013 Revisions 

Table of Contents:
Preamble
Constitution
Article I: Name & Colors
Article II: Purpose
Article III: Membership
Article IV: Officers
Article V: Executive Committee
Article VI: Standing Committees
Article VII: President’s Council
Article VIII: Duties of Officers
Article IX: Elections
Article X: Meetings
Article XI: Attendance
Article XII:  Amendments
Article XIII: Duties of Officers
Article XIV: Ratification




Preamble 
We, the representatives of Alpha Phi Alpha, Alpha Kappa Alpha, Kappa Alpha Psi, Omega Psi Phi, Delta Sigma Theta, Phi Beta Sigma, Zeta Phi Beta, Sigma Gamma Rho, and Iota Phi Theta. Recognizing the need for coordination and regulation of activities of intercollegiate Greek letter fraternities and sororities, and recognizing that there are certain areas of action and programming that can best be carried out by the joint efforts of all such organizations, do hereby establish such an organization and bind ourselves to abide by the provisions of the following Constitution and By-Laws. 
Constitution
Article I – Name and Colors 
Section 1: The name of this organization shall be The University of Massachusetts Amherst National Pan- Hellenic Council. 
Section 2: Official colors of this organization shall be black and white. 

Article II – Purpose 

Section 1: Maintain greek life and greek relationships. 
Section 2: To serve as a liaison between the University and the affiliated organizations. 
Section 3: To encourage member organizations to participate in community development programs as a council and Be actively involved in the UMASS community by supporting other orgs at events and engaging in community service

Section 4: To act as the advocate of member organizations on matter of policy and public relations and Be actively involved in the UMASS community by supporting other orgs at events and engaging in community service

Section 5: To promote and foster academic excellence among general body members and the council


Article III – Membership 

Section 1: The following sororities and fraternities are the members of the University of Massachusetts Amherst National Pan- Hellenic Council: 

Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity Incorporated
Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority Incorporated
 Kappa Alpha Psi Fraternity Incorporated
Omega Psi Phi Fraternity Incorporated
Delta Sigma Theta Sorority Incorporated
Phi Beta Sigma Fraternity Incorporated
Zeta Phi Beta Sorority Incorporated
Sigma Gamma Rho Sorority Incorporated
Iota Phi Theta Fraternity Incorporated

Section 2: Each organization shall be represented by 1 delegate, chapter presidents or an appointed delegate. 

Section 3: Each organization shall be entitled to one vote. 

Article IV- Officers 
Section 1: The officers of the University of Massachusetts Amherst National Pan- Hellenic Council shall be: 
President 
Vice- President 
Treasurer
Secretary 
Public Relations 
Event Committee Lead 

Section 2: Officers shall not serve as the representative from their organization. An exception will be granted if an organization has less than four members. 

Article V – Executive Committee 

Section 1: The executive committee shall consist of all elected officers of the University of Massachusetts Amherst National Pan- Hellenic Council. 
Section 2: The executive committee shall have the authority to conduct the affairs of the council between meetings. 

Article VI- Standing Committees 

Section 1: (NPHC Week) Create and develop the programmatic content for NPHC week. Ensure public awareness, outreach, and positive impact for our community. 
Section 2: (Public Relations Committee) Responsible for all events and informational dedicated to increasing membership within each organization; Will implement membership driven initiatives. Responsible for marketing and spreading awareness for all NPHC programs, events and competitions; Will provide promotional support for all committees.  
Section 3: (Event Committee) Responsible for all major events and competitions that have an expected attendance of 100 or more people; Will implement initiatives of the council; There will be a Four Council liaison responsible for major collaborative events.

Article VII- Presidents Council 

Section 1: The Presidents Council shall consist of the presidents or appointed delegates of each member organization. 



Article VIII- Duties of Officers 
Section 1: President 
Preside over all meetings of the Executive Committee of the University of Massachusetts Amherst National Pan- Hellenic Council. 
Ensure e-board position are filled. If an e-board position is vacant, the president may appoint someone.
Be responsible for the implications of all decisions of the University of Massachusetts Amherst National Pan- Hellenic Council. 
Approve all vouchers for expenditures of budgeted funds. 
Perform all other duties pertaining to the office of Presidents. 
Act as a Four Council liaison
Section 2: Vice President 
Shall assume the duties of the President in the absence or incapacity of the President. 
Shall perform such other duties as are assigned. 
Shall be responsible for overseeing all committees. 
Section 3: Secretary 
Shall record and distribute the minutes of all meetings. 
Maintain a directory of all organization members. 
Issue and maintain a record of all necessary correspondence.
Serve as Parliamentarian, and enforce the bylaws and Roberts Rules of Order. 

Section 4: Public Relations 
Maintain social media platforms. 
Act as outreach person to other student organizations. 
Section 5: Treasurer 
Maintain accurate account of all financial transactions. 
Co-Sign all checks. 
Deposit all funds and other valuables. 
Develop a fundraising program. 
Should hold signature responsibility. 
Receive and issue receipts for funds. 
Submit annual budget to the Student Government Association.
Section 6: Event Committee Lead 
Maintain a calendar of upcoming National Pan- Hellenic Council events. 
Complete all event submissions timely. 
Plan all events and serve as a leader for the Event committee. 
Article IX - Elections 
Section 1: A quorum (2/3 of member organizations) shall be present for elections to take place. 
Section 2: Officers shall be elected by majority vote, consisting of one vote from each organization. 
Section 3: Voting shall be secret ballot. 
Section 4: All vacancies shall be filled through appointment by the president with majority approval of the presidents Council. 
Section 5: Officers may be impeached by ¾ vote of the council. The officer in question must be notified in writing two weeks before any action is voted upon. The officer will be notified by the President or Vice President.
Article X – Meetings 

Section 1: Executive Board Meetings shall be held once every other week.. 
Section 2: A quorum shall consist of a full 2/3 of the representatives. 
Section 3: Special meeting may be called by the President anytime with a notice of no less than 24 hours. 
Section 4: An open “Meet the Greeks” meetings shall take place at least once a semester. If members of an organization would like to be present, and have no undergraduate members currently enrolled at UMASS Amherst, the current NPHC advisor must be notified. 
Section 5: Only official council delegates may voice, for each chapter. 
Section 6: Attendance to all meetings is mandatory. Members of the council are given one unexcused absence per semester. 2nd missed meeting will result in disciplinary action. The chapter will be contacted regarding their truancy and their 25 dollar deduction from their revenue account to be transferred into National Pan-Hellenic Council account. 
Section t: Robert’s Rule of Order governs meetings except for NPHC bylaws.

Article XI- Attendance
Section 1
Members shall attend all meetings of the National Pan Hellenic Council and National Pan Hellenic Council Committee to which they are assigned.  All absences and the nature thereof, shall be recorded in the minutes of the meeting. If a delegate is fifteen minutes or more late, and this is the third occurrence, then a deduction of $25 will be taken from their account and added to National Pan Hellenic Council’s budget. 

Section 2
The secretary shall take a roll call at the beginning of all meetings of the council.  And 3 unexcused tardies shall constitute one absence.

Section 3
The Chair of each National Pan Hellenic Council Committee shall take attendance at the beginning of each meeting of the Committee. An member’s unexcused absence from a Committee meeting shall constitute for one absence from the council.

Section 4
If an organization shall appeal the decision of the President after having been notified by non attendance, the organization may have one absence stricken from the record, upon a majority vote of the Council membership in attendance at a schedule meeting.
					
Article XII
Individual Organizations
Section 1
Each organization must provide their semester calendar at the beginning of the semester
Section 2
If an organization has a week and/or a founder’s week, No organization should have an event during that week.
Article XIII – Amendments 

This constitution may be amended by a 2/3 positive vote of member organizations provided that the proposed amendment be presented at least 1 week prior to a vote. Each organization has one vote.
This constitution shall be revised once every September at the start of every academic year.

Article XIV – Ratification 

This constitution, upon ratification by a 2/3 vote of the Presidents Council, shall go into effect immediately. 


















The University Of Massachusetts Amherst 

National Pan-Hellenic Council 



 



Constitution and By-Laws 

2017-2018 Revisions

DocsList.Name: NRHH 18-19 GB Meeting #11 Minutes.docx
DocsList.Data:
March 20th, 2019

NRHH 18-19 GB Meeting #11 Minutes

Food: Cookies, Fruit Platter, and Candy from Big Y

Materials 
Scrap paper, pens, small quarter sheets of all the habits, projector, laptop, coloring materials (colored pencils, paper/pictures), candy (chocolate based and nonchocolate based)

Set up
Initially overview of all the habits: each e-board member will present one 
5 smaller groups formed to practice habits 5 and 2 lead by e-board member (10-15 minutes per exercise) 
After everyone finishes, group everyone together to discuss habit 7. do habit 7 exercise for 20-30 minutes. Answer any questions about the habits/practices and offer other ways to work on the habits.

Leadership Activity: 
7 habits of success:
Be proactive, begin with the end in mind, put first things first, think win-win, seek first to understand then be understood, synergize, sharpen the saw
Habit exercises:
Exercise: (Have two people have a 30 second conversation and everyone else cover their ears and watch) Was one person more interested than the other? What emotions were conveyed that words couldn’t? Have them discuss.
Exercise: Write down what classes/clubs/activities are helping you reach your end goal and what aren’t? Share. What can you do to change what you are doing to better fit your goals? Have them share.
Exercise: We are now going to help strengthen our spiritual dimension by first doing some quiet meditation. Afterwards you will have the chance to color or talk with other students while we play some music. At that time, you may leave but we encourage you to take the extra time to sharpen your saw and begin healthy habits! We hope that you enjoyed this workshop and will see you in two weeks!

DocsList.Name: NSSLHAConstitution.docx
DocsList.Data:
National Student Speech Language and Hearing Association 

University of Massachusetts Amherst Chapter
<<Constitution>>

Mission Statement
The mission of the National Student Speech Language Hearing Association (NSSLHA) is to benefit its members by continually improving its support, promotion, and advocacy of the highest quality preparation of professionals in audiology, speech-language pathology and speech and hearing science. NSSLHA also hopes to learn about and spread awareness of communication disorders.
 

Name and Office
The name of the organization shall be ‘The National Student Speech Language and Hearing Association’ hereby referred to as NSSLHA.
The Principal office of the organization (mailbox) shall be at the Communication Disorders Building of the University of Massachusetts Amherst. The mailing address of the organization shall be 358 North Pleasant Street, Amherst, MA 01002.

Purposes 
The first aim of NSSLHA is to provide information to students about the Communication Disorders program, to be a support group for students within the major and for everyone to learn new information about the field. 
The second aim of NSSLHA is to reach out to the surrounding community and provide fun events and activities that give back and allow members to see environments within the field of study. 
The third aim of NSSLHA is to promote advocacy and awareness of communication disorders throughout the campus and community. 
Membership
All students at the University of Massachusetts Amherst and the greater Five College Community that are interested in carrying out the stated purposes of the organization shall be eligible members of NSSLHA. 
Undergraduates and graduate students of the University of Massachusetts Amherst and the greater Five College Community shall be eligible to vote.
Membership shall be established after a prospective member attends one general meeting and informs the officers that they wish to be a member.
Official membership is contingent upon two general meetings and one formal event a semester. NSSLHA members must also pay yearly dues. 
Meetings
NSSLHA shall have general meetings on a bi-weekly basis.
Meetings shall be chaired by the President
The purpose of the meetings shall be:
Learning more about the field of Communication Disorders
Planning fundraisers and outreach
Group bonding
Other topics deemed necessary

The Executive Board
The Officers of NSSLHA shall be:
President
Vice President
Treasurer
Secretary 
Social Media Chair
Officers shall serve a term of one year starting the day following the last day of classes in the Spring semester.
Officers shall be eligible for re-election to multiple terms. 
The President
The president shall be the Chief Executive Officer of the R.S.O. He or she shall be responsible for all aspects of the functioning of the group. 
The President shall lead meetings and oversee planning of events
The President shall have signature responsibility.
The Vice President 
The shall be the second in command of the R.S.O and take over for President when he or she is not present. 
The Vice President shall be the liaison between NSSLHA and the SGA, Student Activities and Involvement, and other campus offices. 
The Treasurer 
The Treasurer shall be the Chief Financial Officer of the R.S.O.
The Treasurer shall be responsible for maintaining the group’s finances. 
The Treasurer shall be responsible for submitting an annual budget request to the SGA, if necessary. 
The Secretary
The Secretary shall be responsible for maintaining all records for the R.S.O.
All minutes, advertising, and other documents relevant to the functioning of the group shall be considered records. 
These records shall, in all possible cases, be collected and shall be passed on from the current to the future Secretary during the transition period. 
The Secretary shall record minutes at all official group meetings. 
The Secretary shall maintain up to date membership lists.
The Secretary shall be responsible for routinely checking the group’s email account. 
The Social Media Chair
The Social Media Chair shall be responsible for managing all social media accounts of NSSLHA.
Social media accounts include Facebook, Instagram and Twitter.  Responsibilities include keeping pages up to date and promoting meetings/events.
The Social Media Chair shall be responsible for maintaining the group’s Campus Pulse page. 
The Faculty Sponsor
There will be a faculty sponsor from the Communication Disorders department.
The sponsor will be appointed by the faculty of the Communication Disorders department
The Faculty Sponsor will advise officers when needed.
The Faculty Sponsor will serve as a liaison between the group and the Communication Disorders department. 


Officer Elections
Officer elections shall take place during the month of March.
The Executive Board shall announce the exact date, time, and location of the election meeting no later than two weeks prior.
Officer elections shall take place at one meeting  in two stages: the nomination stage and the election stage.
The nomination phase of the election shall run according to the following procedure:
Any non-election business shall be dealt with first. 
After all other business is taken care of, the President shall announce nomination to be open. 
During the nomination period, any voting member shall nominate any voting member, including themselves to a position.
In order for the nomination to be official, it shall need to be seconded by another voting member. 
A voting member may only be nominated to one position.
The nomination period shall remain open until a motion is made, seconded and approved by unanimous consent , to close nominations.
After the nomination period is closed, the President will read from the minutes the names of the candidates who have been nominated. Each member nominated may then choose to accept or reject the nomination.
All nominees that have accepted the nomination will be given the opportunity to address the general membership for two minutes. The nominees for Social Media Chair will go first, followed by Vice President, Treasurer, and Secretary. The nominees will present first by position and then by the order in which they were nominated. 
Immediately following nominations will be the official voting and shall adhere to the following procedure:
The entire membership, Executive Board included, will be given a written ballot including all nominated members.
The membership shall have 20 minutes to cast their votes and the ballots will be collected by the Secretary who will then count the vote, with the help of the Executive Board and/or Faculty sponsor. 
Following the close of the election period, the Secretary shall prepare an election report, including the winners. This report shall be presented by the Secretary at the meeting directly following the closing of elections. 
The Secretary may seek assistance from the Student Activities and Involvement Center of the Secretary of the Registry for any Campus Pulse or election related issues.
The Executive Board shall use the time in between the election and the end of their terms to train the newly elected officers. 
The newly elected officers shall take power following the final day of classes of the Spring semester. 
If any issues arise during this process, or if any member wishes to appeal the results the question may be taken by any member or officer to the Student Judiciary. 



Removal of Officers
Any officer may be impeached from office for failure to perform the duties of their office or for conduct that is detrimental to the group.
The following procedure must be followed in order for an officer to be impeached:
A motion must be made and seconded during an official and regularly scheduled general body meeting to impeach an officer. 
At the following general body meeting, the member making the motion of impeachment shall have 5 minutes to present their case against the officer. This shall be the time to present any evidence and/or witnesses relevant to the impeachment. These 5 minutes shall not be interrupted for any reason, other than if the petitioner decides to take questions from the membership.
Following the presentation of evidence from the petitioner, the accused officer will have 5 minutes to present their defense and any evidence or witness they wish. These 5 minutes shall not be interrupted for any reason, other than if the officer decides to take questions from the general membership. 
    Following the presentations from the petitioner and the accused officer, a vote shall be taken. 2/3 of the general membership must vote in favor of impeachment in order for an officer to be removed.
If the voting results in impeachment, the officer shall immediately surrender his or her office.
If the officer in question is the President, the meeting in which the impeachment is considered shall be chaired by the Vice President.
 If any issues arise during this process, or if either party wishes to appeal the results, the question may be taken by any member or officer to the Student Judiciary.

Officer Vacancies
 If the President resigns or is impeached, the Vice President shall immediately take over as President.
  If the Vice President, Treasurer, or Secretary resigns or is impeached, a special election shall be held for that position, following the same procedures as section IV of this charter.	
The remaining members of the Executive Board shall schedule a special election at a regularly scheduled meeting between 1 and 3 weeks from the date the office become vacant. The Secretary shall inform the general membership of the date of the special election no less than 1 week prior.

Resolving Disputes
Disputes arising between members on matters of RSO policy shall be dealt with through majority votes of the general membership.
Disputes arising between members on other matters shall be dealt with through mediation. 
Mediation consists of a meeting involving both parties and a mediator with the purpose of coming to a solution and putting the issue to rest. 
The President shall mediate disputes between members
Should the President be involved in the dispute, or should either party not be satisfied by the result of the mediation, any party may request that the Secretary of the Registry mediate. The results of mediation with the Secretary of the Registry shall be final. 
	
Free Speech and Non-Discrimination 
All members of NSSLHA are entitled to freedom of speech and will not under any circumstances be deprived of the opportunity to share their opinion with the group. 
NSSLHA will not discriminate against any students for any reason such as race, gender, religion etc. 

Amendment
This charter may be amended by a ⅔ vote of the general membership at a regularly scheduled meeting. 
A motion to amend may be made and seconded by and member at a meeting of the general membership. The motion shall be presented at the meeting in which the motion is made. Voting on the motion shall take place at the following meeting. Prior to voting, the President shall allow for a period of debate.
After being approved by the membership, the amendment itself, and an updated version of the Charter, shall be submitted to the Secretary of the Registry for final approval. 

Affiliations 
The University of Massachusetts Amherst Chapter of NSSLHA is affiliated with the National Student Speech and Language Hearing Association. 
At least two members of the Umass Chapter will be national members of this association.
To be a national member, one must pay annual dues. 
NSSLHA must stay in good national standing as dictated by the national guidelines of the association
The Purpose of this affiliation is to be involved and learn more about ASHA, the association that accredits and certifies Speech Language Pathologists and Audiologists.

THE CONSTITUTION OF THE NEWMAN CATHOLIC STUDENT ASSOCIATION, UNIVERSITY OF MASSACHUSETTS – AMHERST
PREAMBLE

	As the primary organization representing the Catholic Community on the University of Massachusetts campus, the Newman Catholic Student Association (hereforth designated the NCSA) declares the following as its purpose and goals:

To promote the ideals of the Catholic faith on the University campus through both action and example.
To provide service to the University campus and community, the local community, the Newman Center and any other organization serving the common good.
To provide a diverse social program for (but not limited to) the members of the Newman Community and the NCSA for the purpose of building a strong community rooted in the Church.
To provide spiritual guidance and support for the student community to encourage spiritual growth through the Catholic faith.

MEMBERSHIP

	In order for any member of the University community to be considered a member of the NCSA, they must complete a registration form and submit it to the current NCSA Secretary. They must also request membership on Campus Pulse.  Membership is guaranteed regardless of age, race, religion, gender, or sexual orientation.

MEETINGS

The NCSA will have regularly scheduled bi-monthly meetings, to occur at 8:00pm in the Burke Lounge of the Newman Center. The first meeting of every month will hold primary importance. Meetings will occur throughout the academic year (while school is in regular session) except for holidays.
The Officers of the NCSA will have regularly scheduled weekly meetings with the designated Newman Center advisor, to plan meeting agendas and discuss policies, activities, and events.
The Programming Board will have scheduled meetings at the discretion of the Programming Board Coordinator. They will also form committees to organize events under the guidance of a designated NCSA Officer. 

EXECUTIVE BOARD

	All activities and operations of the NCSA will be supervised by the NCSA Officers and Committee Chairs. Together, these two groups and the designated NSA advisor will comprise the Executive Board.  The following structure will apply to the Executive Board (however, the following responsibilities for each office are considered a minimum standard and officers may be granted additional roles on an annual basis)

President: To oversee the successful completion of all NCSA activities and events, to supervise all administrative aspects of the Association, to serve as the primary representative of the Association and to make executive decisions for circumstances which are not explicitly described in the Constitution.
Vice President: To assist the President in any official capacity, to act in the President’s stead when necessary, to facilitate active connections between the NSA and the extended community.
Treasurer: To keep a current record of all NCSA income and expenditures, to maintain a budget, ensure the Association’s solvency and to prepare the annual Student Government Association funding petition. The Treasurer is required to attend Religious and Spiritual Council Life meetings on behalf of the NCSA.
Secretary: To keep current records of membership, to record Agendas and Minutes, to ensure the timely sending of the weekly NCSA email, and to maintain a current Constitution. To manage all correspondence to membership through email, Campus Pulse, and social networks, to liaise with Newman staff to publicize NCSA events in Newman communications with permanent community.
Community Service Coordinator: To organize and facilitate regular service opportunities, to act as a contact to outside organizations seeking volunteers, local religious communities, and to coordinate the annual Fall Food Drive. 
Event Coordinator: Coordinate large scale events such as the winter ball and the senior reception.  


ELECTIONS

	Elections will occur at a general body meeting in the second semester of each academic year to elect the above listed officers. Elections will proceed by nomination and ballot voting. Officers will be elected for the term of one academic year, to begin the semester following their election.  Two people can run as co-officers at the discretion of the current officer board. In the case of a tie for any position, a re-vote may be cast and the losing nominees are encouraged to join the programming board. It is the responsibility of the elect officers to organize a calendar of events for the following year, in cooperation with the current officers, before the cessation of the academic year. The President, Vice President, Treasurer, and Secretary Elects are required to attend all mandatory trainings organized by the Religious and Spiritual Life Council before the end of the academic year in which they are elected.
	Only currently registered members of the University of Massachusetts Amherst may vote in elections and only the current NCSA Advisor may count or see the ballots once the voting members have cast their votes.

OFFICE POLICIES

	The NCSA will maintain an office in the main corridor of the Newman Center and a mailbox at the Newman Center.
	The NCSA will have the following address:

Newman Student Association
472 North Pleasant Street
Amherst, MA 01002

	Only NCSA Officers shall have official access to NCSA mailboxes and only NCSA officers shall have keys to the NCSA office. NCSA Office Hours will be set at the discretion of the Executive Board, and may not apply each semester. Access to the office by the membership will be based solely on the discretion of the current officers.

Programming Board Coordinator: To be the official head of the Programming Board, to coordinate volunteers for events that the Executive Board wants to be planned.
