The Programming Board will be headed by the Programming Board Coordinator and will be responsible for planning and executing events under the guidance of another Executive Board officer. The President, Vice President, Treasurer, and Secretary Elects are required to attend all mandatory trainings organized by the Religious and Spiritual Life Council before the end of the academic year in which they are elected.
	Only currently registered members may vote in elections and only the current NSA Advisor may count or see the ballots once the voting members have cast their votes.

OFFICE POLICIES

	The NSA will maintain an office in the main corridor of the Newman Center and a mailbox at the Newman Center.
	The NSA will have the following address:

Newman Student Association
472 North Pleasant Street
Amherst, MA 01002

	Only NSA Officers shall have official access to NSA mailboxes and only NSA officers shall have keys to the NSA office. NSA Office Hours will be set at the discretion of the Executive Board, and may not apply each semester. Access to the office by the membership will be based solely on the discretion of the current officers.

DocsList.Name: Note-orious Constitution 12-2019.docx.pdf
DocsList.Data:
Constitution 
UMass Note-orious 
Updated: 12/2019 

Mission Statement 
The mission of UMass Note-orious, or Note-orious, is to perform a capella music 
on and off campus to people of all backgrounds and cultures. We believe that 
music has the power to bring people together. Our goal is to grow as individuals 
and musicians through learning and performing original arrangements of songs of 
all genres and tastes. 

I.

Membership 
a. All students at the University of Massachusetts Amherst shall be 

eligible to audition to be a member of Note-orious.   

b. Membership shall be established after auditioning and receiving 

acceptance into the group. No members will be admitted without an 
audition. 

II.

Auditions 
a. Auditions are open to all UMass students. 
b. Auditions will be advertised to the general public via flyers and social 

media. 

c. Auditions will be the same for all auditionees. These auditions will 

include a song sung a capella of their choice, as well as a test of their 
range and pitch-matching. 

d. Auditionees selected for callbacks shall be decided on by the group. 
e. The callback process will be decided by the Executive Board officers. 
f. Auditionees will be evaluated at callbacks based on their pitch, tone 

of voice, blending and stage presence.  

g. Auditionees will be notified whether they’ve been accepted within a 

timely manner.  

 
 
 
 
 III. Meetings 

a. Note-orious shall have rehearsals twice weekly for 1-3 hours each. 
b. Note-orious shall have sectionals once a week for 1 hour. 
c. Attendance at meetings is mandatory. Members missing meetings 

for urgent matters must alert the President of their absence as soon 
as possible. 

d. Rehearsals and sections shall be led by the Music Director and the 

appointed section leader, respectively. 

e. The purpose of rehearsals shall be: 

i. Rehearsing music 
ii. Rehearsing choreography 
iii. Group bonding 
iv. Planning activities and shows 
v. Other activities as needed 

f. Decisions regarding performance and meeting dates and times will 
be made by majority vote during meetings, with at least 2/3 of the 
group present. 

IV.

The Executive Board 
a. The officers of Note-orious and their responsibilities shall be: 

i. President  

1. The President will handle all intergroup communication. 
2. The President will mediate problems within the group. 
3. The President will ensure rehearsals are organized and 

run smoothly and efficiently. 

4. The President will keep group members focused during 

rehearsals. 

5. The President will communicate with music directors 

about rehearsal plans. 

6. The President will enforce an attendance policy.   
7. The President shall have Signature Responsibility. 

ii. Music Director 

1. The Music Director will run the music portion of the 

rehearsal. 

 
 
 2. The Music Director will arrange music and review others’ 

arrangements contributed to the group. 

3. The Music Director will help each part learn their music. 
4. The Music Director will lead vocal warm-ups. 

iii. Vice President(s) 

1. The Vice President(s) shall take over for the President 

when he or she is not present. 

2. The Vice President(s) will be in contact with outside 

entities as necessary.   

3. The Vice President(s) will deal with event coordination. 

iv. Treasure/Secretary 

1. The Treasurer shall be the Chief Financial Officer. 
2. The Treasurer will deal with reimbursement and keep 

track of the group’s finances. 

3. The Treasurer will update the Executive Board on the 

group's financial situation 

4. The Treasurer shall be responsible for maintaining the 

groups’s finances. 

5. The Treasurer shall be responsible for submitting an 
annual budget request to the SGA when necessary. 

6. The Treasurer shall have Signature Responsibility. 

v. Marketing Coordinator 

1. The Marketing Coordinator will upkeep the group’s 

social media presences (YouTube, Instagram, Facebook). 

2. The Marketing Coordinator will update the group’s 

Campus Pulse. 

3. The Marketing Coordinator shall create and distribute 

marketing materials, such as flyers, chops, and posters, 
as well as the materials posted on social media. 
b. Officers shall serve a term of one year, starting the day after 

elections, except for the positions of Marketing Coordinator and Vice 
Presidents, which shall have terms of one semester. 

c. Officers shall be responsible to set goals for themselves and the 

group. 

d. Officers shall be eligible for re-election for multiple terms. 

 e. Officers shall be responsible to meet as necessary to discuss 

Executive Board related matters. 

V.

Elections and Terms of Office 
a. Elections shall take place approximately three weeks before the end 

of each semester. In Fall, the Vice President and Marketing 
Coordinator positions shall be open for re-election. In Spring, all 
positions shall be open for re-election. 

b. The President shall announce the exact rehearsal date at which the 

election will take place. 

c. Prior to each election, the Executive Board member currently in the 
positions opening shall briefly explain their roles and responsibilities 
to the group. 

d. The election process will take place as follows: 

i. Any member may run for any position open. 
ii. The order of elections shall be: President, Vice President(s), 

Music Director, Treasurer, Marketing Coordinator 

iii. For each position, members shall announce their candidacy, 

followed by a 2-3 minute speech about why they believe they 
are best qualified for the position, with other members able to 
ask questions after for another 2-3 minutes. After all 
candidates for a position have gone, every member shall cast a 
paper vote. Candidates may vote for themselves. The majority 
vote will win the election and secure the position for the 
following term. 

e. During the last three weeks of the semester, the officers currently in 
the Executive Board shall train the newly elected officers in their 
roles. 

f. Any officer may be removed from office for failure to perform the 
duties they are entrusted with, or for conduct detrimental to the 
group. To impeach an officer, the prospect must be brought up 
during a group meeting and voted on with a 2/3 majority. In the 
event of impeachment, the impeached officer’s role will be delegated 
to another Executive Board officer. In the case of a full-year position 
being impeached in Fall, those positions will be open for reelection at 

 
 the end of Fall semester. If impeachment occurs after elections, 
there must be an emergency election to elect a new officer before 
the start of the next semester, with the logistics being determined by 
the other Executive Board officers. 

g. At the end of Fall semester, a meeting will be held to discuss and 
evaluate the performance of Executive Board officers, as well as 
review their goals. This shall be an open and honest discussion of 
what things they have achieved, and what things could be better. 
This shall be a time for constructive criticism and open 
communication, to help the officer improve their performance in the 
role. 

VI.

Free Speech and Non-Discrimination 
a. Note-orious strives to create an environment where all feel safe and 
welcome. This will be achieved by encouraging group bonding and 
acceptance of all sexualities, identities, religions, and races. No 
prospective member may be rejected based on any of these factors. 

b. Members of Note-orious are encouraged to voice their opinions 
respectfully. We want everyone to feel like their voice is heard.  
c. Any form of hate speech or discrimination will result in immediate 

dismissal from the group. 

VII. Amendment Policy 

a. Every member of Note-orious will be provided this Constitution. They 

may suggest an amendment at any time. 

b. Proposed amendments will be reviewed by the Executive Board and 

put to a vote by the group. 

c. After being approved, the amendment and the updated Constitution 
will be submitted to the Secretary of the Registry for final approval.

Membership
All students at the University of Massachusetts Amherst shall be eligible to audition to be a member of Note-orious.  
Membership shall be established after auditioning and receiving acceptance into the group. No members will be admitted without an audition.

Auditions
Auditions are open to all UMass students.
Auditions will be advertised to the general public via flyers and social media.
Auditions will be the same for all auditionees. These auditions will include a song sung a capella of their choice, as well as a test of their range and pitch-matching.
Auditionees selected for callbacks shall be decided on by the group.
The callback process will be decided by the Executive Board officers.
Auditionees will be evaluated at callbacks based on their pitch, tone of voice, blending and stage presence. 
Auditionees will be notified whether they’ve been accepted within a timely manner. 

Meetings
Note-orious shall have rehearsals twice weekly for 1-3 hours each.
Note-orious shall have sectionals once a week for 1 hour.
Attendance at meetings is mandatory. Members missing meetings for urgent matters must alert the President of their absence as soon as possible.
Rehearsals and sections shall be led by the Music Director and the appointed section leader, respectively.
The purpose of rehearsals shall be:
Rehearsing music
Rehearsing choreography
Group bonding
Planning activities and shows
Other activities as needed
Decisions regarding performance and meeting dates and times will be made by majority vote during meetings, with at least 2/3 of the group present.


The Executive Board
The officers of Note-orious and their responsibilities shall be:
President 
The President will handle all intergroup communication.
The President will mediate problems within the group.
The President will ensure rehearsals are organized and run smoothly and efficiently.
The President will keep group members focused during rehearsals.
The President will communicate with music directors about rehearsal plans.
The President will enforce an attendance policy.  
The President shall have Signature Responsibility.
Music Director
The Music Director will run the music portion of the rehearsal.
The Music Director will arrange music and review others’ arrangements contributed to the group.
The Music Director will help each part learn their music.
The Music Director will lead vocal warm-ups.
Vice President(s)
The Vice President(s) shall take over for the President when he or she is not present.
The Vice President(s) will be in contact with outside entities as necessary.  
The Vice President(s) will deal with event coordination.
Treasure/Secretary
The Treasurer shall be the Chief Financial Officer.
The Treasurer will deal with reimbursement and keep track of the group’s finances.
The Treasurer will update the Executive Board on the group's financial situation
The Treasurer shall be responsible for maintaining the groups’s finances.
The Treasurer shall be responsible for submitting an annual budget request to the SGA when necessary.
The Treasurer shall have Signature Responsibility.
Marketing Coordinator
The Marketing Coordinator will upkeep the group’s social media presences (YouTube, Instagram, Facebook).
The Marketing Coordinator will update the group’s Campus Pulse.
The Marketing Coordinator shall create and distribute marketing materials, such as flyers, chops, and posters, as well as the materials posted on social media.
Officers shall serve a term of one year, starting the day after elections, except for the positions of Marketing Coordinator and Vice Presidents, which shall have terms of one semester.
Officers shall be responsible to set goals for themselves and the group.
Officers shall be eligible for re-election for multiple terms.
Officers shall be responsible to meet as necessary to discuss Executive Board related matters.

Elections and Terms of Office
Elections shall take place approximately three weeks before the end of each semester. In Fall, the Vice President and Marketing Coordinator positions shall be open for re-election. In Spring, all positions shall be open for re-election.
The President shall announce the exact rehearsal date at which the election will take place.
Prior to each election, the Executive Board member currently in the positions opening shall briefly explain their roles and responsibilities to the group.
The election process will take place as follows:
Any member may run for any position open.
The order of elections shall be: President, Vice President(s), Music Director, Treasurer, Marketing Coordinator
For each position, members shall announce their candidacy, followed by a 2-3 minute speech about why they believe they are best qualified for the position, with other members able to ask questions after for another 2-3 minutes. After all candidates for a position have gone, every member shall cast a paper vote. Candidates may vote for themselves. The majority vote will win the election and secure the position for the following term.
During the last three weeks of the semester, the officers currently in the Executive Board shall train the newly elected officers in their roles.
Any officer may be removed from office for failure to perform the duties they are entrusted with, or for conduct detrimental to the group. To impeach an officer, the prospect must be brought up during a group meeting and voted on with a 2/3 majority. In the event of impeachment, the impeached officer’s role will be delegated to another Executive Board officer. In the case of a full-year position being impeached in Fall, those positions will be open for reelection at the end of Fall semester. If impeachment occurs after elections, there must be an emergency election to elect a new officer before the start of the next semester, with the logistics being determined by the other Executive Board officers.
At the end of Fall semester, a meeting will be held to discuss and evaluate the performance of Executive Board officers, as well as review their goals. This shall be an open and honest discussion of what things they have achieved, and what things could be better. This shall be a time for constructive criticism and open communication, to help the officer improve their performance in the role.

Free Speech and Non-Discrimination
Note-orious strives to create an environment where all feel safe and welcome. This will be achieved by encouraging group bonding and acceptance of all sexualities, identities, religions, and races. No prospective member may be rejected based on any of these factors.
Members of Note-orious are encouraged to voice their opinions respectfully. We want everyone to feel like their voice is heard. 
Any form of hate speech or discrimination will result in immediate dismissal from the group.

Amendment Policy
Every member of Note-orious will be provided this Constitution. They may suggest an amendment at any time.
Proposed amendments will be reviewed by the Executive Board and put to a vote by the group.
After being approved, the amendment and the updated Constitution will be submitted to the Secretary of the Registry for final approval.

Name: Organization of Graduate Students in Comparative Literature
Orthodox Christian Fellowship of the University of Massachusetts - Amherst

DocsList.Name: UMass Panhellenic Bylaws.pdf
DocsList.Data:
BYLAWS OF UMASS AMHERST COLLEGE PANHELLENIC ASSOCIATION
Adopted: 11/5/2020

Article I. Name

The name of this organization shall be the UMass Amherst College Panhellenic Association.

Article II. Object

The object of the College Panhellenic Association shall be to:
·        Conduct the business of the College Panhellenic only during the campus academic year.
·        Promote the growth of individual chapters and the sorority community.
·        Organize and sponsor a women’s only membership recruitment program.
·        Encourage the highest possible academic, social and moral standards.
·        Coordinate activities, establish orderly procedures and provide programming in addition to recruitment.
·        Adjudicate all matters related to the NPC Unanimous Agreements, College Panhellenic bylaws and/or other
governing documents, College Panhellenic membership recruitment rules, College Panhellenic Code of ethics and
College Panhellenic standing rules.
·        Actively support the mission of its host institution.
·        Promote good public relations.
·        Give service to the community and campus.
·        Sponsor Junior Panhellenic, if appropriate, for specialized programming efforts.
·        Promote friendship, harmony and unity among members, chapters, faculty, administrators and campus groups.

Article III. Membership

Section 1. Membership classes
There shall be three classes of membership: regular, provisional and associate.

Provisional membership. The provisional membership of the UMass Amherst College Panhellenic

A. Regular membership. The regular membership of the UMass Amherst College Panhellenic Association shall
be composed of all installed chapters of NPC sororities at UMass Amherst. Regular members of the College
Panhellenic Association shall pay dues as determined by the Panhellenic Council.
B.
Association shall be composed of all colonies of NPC sororities at UMass Amherst. Provisional members shall pay
no dues and shall have voice but no vote on all matters. A provisional member shall automatically become a regular
member upon being installed as a chapter of an NPC sorority.
C. Associate membership. The associate membership of the UMass Amherst College Panhellenic Association
shall be composed of  women’s only local sororities or inter/national or regional non-NPC member organizations.
The membership eligibility requirements and the process for submitting an application and approval of the
application shall be determined by the Panhellenic Council. Associate members shall pay dues as determined by the
Panhellenic Council. An associate member shall have voice and one vote on all matters except extension-related
matters. If they do not participate in the primary recruitment process, they shall not have a vote on recruitment rules
and the establishment or modification of Panhellenic total. An associate member may be expelled for cause by a
majority vote of the Panhellenic Council. An associate member shall not be entitled to vote on the question of its
expulsion.

 1. All associate members must abide by all NPC Unanimous Agreements and be subject to the UMass Amherst
College Panhellenic Association bylaws and governing documents and risk management policies.
2. Members of sororities holding associate membership in the Panhellenic will be eligible to serve as officers.
3. Whether associate members will:

A. Have voice and one vote in all matters except those that are extension related. If not participating in the
primary recruitment process, they will not have a vote on recruitment rules and establishment or
modification of Panhellenic total.
B. Pay full dues.
C. Be required to participate in any or all Panhellenic and fraternity/sorority programming such
as Greek Week, honoraries, awards programs, etc.
D. Be subject to judicial proceedings.
E. Be required to participate in organized recruitment..
F. May be expelled for cause by a majority vote of the Panhellenic Council. An associate member shall not
be entitled to vote on the question of its expulsion.

4. That associate membership in a College Panhellenic Association cannot and does not confer or imply any
guarantee that an associate member will be permitted to affiliate with an NPC organization, such authorization being
conveyed only on a separate extension vote of the regular members of the College Panhellenic when campus
numbers warrant a vote to open for extension.

Section 2. Privileges and responsibilities of membership
Duty of compliance. All members, without regard to membership class, shall comply with all NPC Unanimous
Agreements and policies and be subject to these UMass Amherst College Panhellenic Association bylaws, code of
ethics and any additional rules this College Panhellenic Association may adopt, unless otherwise prescribed in these
bylaws. Any rules adopted by this Association in conflict with the NPC Unanimous Agreements shall be void.

Section 3. Dues
A.     NPC College Panhellenic dues shall be paid yearly as invoiced by the NPC office.
B.     College Panhellenic Association membership dues shall be an assessment per member and new member.
•        The amount of such dues for each semester  shall be determined by the Vice President of Finance by the
second Panhellenic Council meeting of the semester
•        The dues of each College Panhellenic Association member sorority shall be payable on or before the date set
by the Vice President of Finance at the beginning of each semester

Section 4. Fines
The Panhellenic Council shall have the authority to charge and distribute fines for violations including but not
limited to infractions of recruitment rules, bylaws infractions, Panhellenic Philanthropy Event attendance and other
fines as that may be considered necessary and as passed through a vote of the council members.

A. Each chapter will have one Panhellenic Philanthropy event every semester. It is expected that 13% of every

chapter will be in attendance at other chapters’ designated Panhellenic Philanthropy event. Failure to have
13% of a chapter in attendance will result in a fee of double the cost of the event ticket price. So for
example, if it costs $5 to attend an event, the fine will be $10 per person. The fees will be collected by the
Panhellenic Council and will be split between the council and the designated chapter.

B. Failure to pay dues by the given date will result in a $50 fine per week late, unless granted a extension by

the Vice President of Finance

C. Failure of the Chapter to give correct formatting on check after two warnings will result in a $25 fine

 D. Each chapter and general chapter member must be aware of every fine in the Recruitment Rules section of
these bylaws. Should an infraction occur the President and Vice President of Standards will meet with the
Chapter President and the individual who is accused, then assign the fine to the given chapter based on
evidence.

Article IV. Officers and Duties

Section 1. Officers
The officers of the UMass Amherst College Panhellenic Association shall be President, Vice President of Standards,
Vice President of Membership, Vice President of Activities, Vice President of Philanthropy, Vice President of
External Affairs , Vice President of Finance, and Vice President Diversity and Inclusion.

Section 2. Duties of officers

A. The President shall:

•        Preside at all meetings of the Panhellenic Council.
•        Preside at all meetings of the Executive Board.
•        Serve as an ex-officio member of all College Panhellenic Association committees.
•        Communicate regularly with the Panhellenic advisor.
•        Be familiar with the NPC Manual of Information and all governing documents of this Association.
•        Ensure all NPC College Panhellenic reports are completed on time.
•        Communicate regularly with the NPC area advisor.
•        Maintain current copies of the following: UMass Amherst College Panhellenic Association bylaws and
standing rules, the College Panhellenic Association budget, contracts executed on behalf of the College Panhellenic
Association, correspondence and materials received from the NPC area advisor, all NPC College Panhellenic reports
and other pertinent materials.
•        Perform all other duties as applicable to the office as prescribed by the parliamentary authority adopted by the
Association.

B. The vice President of Standards shall:

•        Perform the duties of the president in her absence.
•        Be familiar with the NPC Manual of Information and all governing documents of this Association.
•        Oversee Judiciary procedures
•        Organize an Admin Banquet in collaboration with the President at the end of Spring semester
•        Organize Scholarship Banquet at the end of the Fall semester
•        Perform all other duties as applicable to the office as prescribed by the parliamentary authority adopted by the
Association.

C. The Vice President of Membership shall:
•        Oversee all Panhellenic recruitment activities and events.
•        Oversee all recruitment publication efforts.
•        Oversee Panhellenic recruitment registration.
•        Submit any revisions to the College Panhellenic recruitment rules to the Panhellenic Council for approval.
•        Recruit and train Panhellenic recruitment counselors.
•        Host all Panhellenic recruitment wrap-up meetings with recruitment chairs and advisors.
•        Organize all Panhellenic recruitment meetings.

 •        Keep complete and accurate records of Panhellenic recruitment information including up to date active
numbers. Chapters must report active numbers to the Vice President of Membership within 24 hours after the
continuous open bidding period ends.
•        Present a full report, including recommendations, to the Panhellenic Council based on an analysis of the
recruitment statistics and recruitment evaluations from new members, potential new members who withdrew, each
member organization and chapter advisors.
•        Perform all other duties as applicable to the office as prescribed by the parliamentary authority adopted by the
Association.

D. The Vice President of Activities shall:

•        Oversee planning of Greek Week
•        Coordinates theme, teams, events, and books rooms/fields for Greek Week events.
•        Arrange inter-panhellenic activities in the Fall semester and Spring semester
•        Communicate with chapter Sisterhood chairs, or each chapter’s equivalent of  sisterhood chair, as well as
chapter delegates
•         Coordinate with the Vice President of Diversity and Inclusion to plan programming within the  Panhellenic
community
•        Perform all other duties as applicable to the office as prescribed by the parliamentary authority adopted by the
Association.

E. The Vice President of Philanthropy shall:

•        Maintain bylaws surrounding Panhellenic Philanthropy attendance at chapter philanthropy events.
•        Track attendance and funds raised at philanthropy events.
•        Manage fines from chapters that do not adhere to 13% attendance at Panhellenic Philanthropy Events in
collaboration with the Vice President of Finance.
•        Communicate regularly with chapter Philanthropy chairs.
•        Work with campus and community partners to create philanthropy events and opportunities.
•        Perform all other duties as applicable to the office as prescribed by the parliamentary authority adopted by the
Association.

F. The Vice President of External Affairs

•        Act as liaison between chapters and the Panhellenic Executive Board.
•        Act as liaison between the UMass Panhellenic Council and the National Panhellenic Conference.
•        Take minutes at every council meeting and send them to chapters and nationals.
•        Send monthly newsletters with chapter updates to chapters and nationals.
•        Maintain the brand of panhellenic sorority life at UMass Amherst
•        Connect with those interested in collaborating with the council.
•        Manage all social media accounts
•        Create graphics and advertisements for events..
•        Perform all other duties as applicable to the office as prescribed by the parliamentary authority adopted by the
Association.

G. The Vice President of Finance shall:

•        Supervise the finances of the UMass Amherst College Panhellenic Association. In order to create an
appropriate budget, collect financial needs from every executive board member before the first day of every
semester in order to determine an appropriate budget for each semester
•        Receive all payments due to the Association, collect all dues and give receipts if chapters desire them.
•        Pay promptly the annual NPC dues and all bills of the UMass Amherst College Panhellenic Association.

 •        Be familiar with the NPC Manual of Information and all governing documents of this Association.
•         Work with the Vice President of Philanthropy to collect fines from chapters that do not adhere to 13%
attendance at Panhellenic Philanthropy Events
•        Oversee all financial fines with the Vice President of Standards and President to deem them appropriate,
including recruitment fines
•        Remain confidential regarding all fine amounts
•        Make sure to be involved in any financial matters with any outside organizations and hold signature
responsibility for the Council
•        Have two meetings per semester (one at beginning and one at end) with the finance chairs to update them on
financial information, and ask for any suggestions on financial matters for the semester
•        Perform all other duties as applicable to the office as prescribed by the parliamentary authority adopted by the
Association.

H.The Vice President of Diversity and Inclusion

Preside over all meetings of the UMass Amherst College Panhellenic Association Diversity and Inclusion

•
Committee.
•        Create a Diversity and Inclusion Survey each academic year
•
Plan and coordinate internal DEI programming for the Panhellenic Community and external programming for
any UMass students at least once a semester with mandatory attendance in collaboration with the Vice President of
Activities.
•        Create and facilitate DEI training in collaboration with the Vice President of Membership prior to Formal
Panhellenic Recruitment with mandatory attendance from all chapters and recruitment counselors.
•
Committee subcommittees and task forces.
•        Facilitate a semesterly bylaw review in collaboration with the DEI Committee and the President  to ensure that
all bylaws align with our communities DEI standards and make changes accordingly.
•        Perform all other duties as applicable to the office as prescribed by the parliamentary authority adopted by the
Association.

Serve as an ex-officio member of all UMass Amherst College Panhellenic Association Diversity and Inclusion

Section 3. Eligibility
Eligibility to serve as an officer shall depend on the class of membership:
A.     Regular membership. Members from women’s only sororities holding regular membership in the UMass
Amherst College Panhellenic Association shall be eligible to serve as any officer.
B.     Provisional membership. Members from women’s only sororities holding provisional membership in the
UMass Amherst College Panhellenic Association shall not be eligible to serve as an officer.
C.     Associate membership.
Members from women’s only sororities holding associate membership in the UMass Amherst College Panhellenic
Association shall be eligible to serve as an officer.

Section 4. Selection of Officers

The offices of President, Vice President of Standards, Vice President of Membership, Vice President of Activities,
Vice President of Philanthropy, Vice President of External Affairs, Vice President of Finance, and Vice President of
Diversity and Inclusion of the UMass Amherst College Panhellenic Association shall be elected by ballot, except if
there is only one nominee for an office that nominee shall be declared elected.

Section 5. Office-holding limitations

 No more than one member from the same women’s only sorority shall hold office during the same term.

Section 6. Nomination procedure
A Nominating Committee is formed from the current Executive Council shall consider the qualifications of all
candidates for elected officers and shall nominate at least one name for each elected officer position.

Section 7. Term
A.     The officers shall serve for a term of one year or until their successors are selected.
B.     The term of office will begin at installation at the end of the Fall semester.

Section 8. Removal
Any officer may be removed for cause by a vote of two-thirds (6/8) of the Panhellenic Council.

Section 9. Vacancies
Vacancies shall be filled in the same manner of selection as provided in Section 4 of this article.

Section 10. Biases
Any officer elected to serve on the Panhellenic Council Eboard must remain unbiased towards any chapter
preferences. When serving in this position the officer is representing the whole Panhellenic community, not just their
own chapter, thus must remain unbiased. Delegates should represent the needs of each chapter and relay information
to the chapter, not the Officer on the Panhellenic Eboard from the chapter.

Article V. The Panhellenic Council

Section 1. Authority
The governing body of the UMass Amherst College Panhellenic Association shall be the Panhellenic Council. It
shall be the duty of the Panhellenic Council to conduct all business related to the overall welfare of the UMass
Amherst College Panhellenic Association including, but not limited to: annual review of the parameters as adopted
in the recruitment rules for the automatic adjustment of total every regular academic term, annual determination of
dues, approval of the annual budget, consideration of extension, setting a calendar of events, determining
programming and establishing recruitment rules and recruitment style. The Panhellenic Council shall also have the
authority to adopt rules governing the College Panhellenic Association that do not violate the sovereignty, rights and
privileges of member women’s only sororities.

Section 2. Composition and privileges
The UMass Amherst Panhellenic Council shall be composed of one delegate and one alternate delegate from each
regular, provisional and associate women’s only member organization at Umass Amherst as identified in Article III.
The delegates shall be voting members of the Panhellenic Council except as otherwise provided in Article III of
these bylaws. The alternate delegates shall have voice but no vote. The alternate delegate shall act and vote in the
place of the delegate when the delegate is absent. If both delegate and alternate are absent, the vote may be cast by a
member of the sorority, providing her credentials have been presented to the Association president.

Section 3. Selection of delegates and alternates
Delegates and alternates to the Panhellenic Council shall be selected by their respective women’s only sorority
chapters to serve for a term of one year commencing upon selection by the chapter.

Section 4. Delegate vacancies

 When a delegate vacancy occurs, it shall be the responsibility of the sorority affected to select a replacement within
two weeks and to notify the College Panhellenic Association President of her name, email and telephone number.

Section 5. Duties and responsibilities
Panhellenic delegate duties and responsibilities
•      Must attend all Panhellenic Council meetings.
•      Must support NPC Unanimous Agreements, policies and procedures.
•      Must understand local College Panhellenic Association policies and procedures.
•      Should know when to consult her sorority’s NPC delegate for assistance and advice regarding Panhellenic
concerns.
•      Should be prepared and knowledgeable about Panhellenic concerns, the view of her member organization and
chapter, and how to voice concerns to the Council.
•      Should present regular College Panhellenic Association reports at chapter meetings
•      Ensure all committee have representation from their chapters, and fill seats as needed
•      Inform Chapter Eboards and general chapter members about all votes and events put on by the Panhellenic
Council
•      Perform all other duties as applicable to the office as prescribed by the Panhellenic Council Eboard.

Section 6. Regular meetings
Regular meetings of the Panhellenic Council shall be held at a time and place established at the beginning of each
academic term.

Section 7. Annual meeting
The annual meeting of the Panhellenic Council shall be held at the end of the Fall semester. The purpose of the
annual meeting shall be for the election of officers and any other business that may properly come before the
delegates.

Section 8. Special meetings
Special meetings of the Panhellenic Council may be called by the president when necessary and shall be called by
her upon the electronic or written request of no fewer than one-fourth of the member women’s sororities of the
UMass Amherst College Panhellenic Association. Electronic or written notice of each special meeting of the
Panhellenic Council shall be sent to each member of the Panhellenic Council at least 24 hours prior to convening the
meeting; however, such notice may be waived, and attendance at such meeting shall constitute a waiver of said
notice.

Section 9. Quorum
Two-thirds of the delegates from the member sororities of the UMass Amherst College Panhellenic Association shall
constitute a quorum for the transaction of business.

Section 10. Vote Requirements
A.     All other votes, unless specified in these bylaws, shall require a majority vote for adoption.
B.     A two-thirds vote of the Panhellenic Council shall be required to approve a recolonization plan and for all
extension-related votes.
C.     Proposed motions on issues that impact a chapter as a whole must be announced at a previous meeting to allow
opportunity for chapter input before a vote may be taken on the issue.
Voting may take place electronically. An anonymous vote can occur through a designated internet
D.
platform, to which the President will create and administer it to all delegates at the moment of voting. Provided the
meeting has Quorum, all votes conducted this way are valid.

 Article VI. The Executive Board

Section 1. Composition
The composition of the Executive Board shall be the President, Vice President of Standards, Vice President of
Membership, Vice President of Activities, Vice President of Philanthropy, Vice President of External Affairs, Vice
President of Finance, and Vice President of Diversity and Inclusion .

Section 2. Duties
The Executive Board shall administer routine business between meetings of the Panhellenic Council and such other
business as has been approved for action by Panhellenic Council vote. At the next regular meeting of the Panhellenic
Council through the Vice President of External Affairs, the Executive Board shall also report all actions it has taken
and record the action in the minutes of that meeting.

Section 3. Regular meetings
Regular meetings of the Executive Board shall be held at a time and place established at the beginning of each
academic term.

Section 4. Special meetings
Special meetings of the Executive Board may be called by the president when necessary and shall be called by her
upon the electronic or written request of three members of the Executive Board. Electronic or written notice of each
special meeting of the Executive Board shall be sent to each member of the Executive Board at least 24 hours prior
to convening the meeting; however, such notice may be waived, and attendance at such meeting shall constitute a
waiver of said notice.

Section 5. Quorum
A majority of Executive Board members shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business.

Article VII. The Panhellenic Advisor

Section 1. Appointment
The Panhellenic advisor of the UMass Amherst College Panhellenic Association shall be appointed by the UMass
Amherst administration.

Section 2. Authority
The Panhellenic advisor shall serve in an advisory capacity to the UMass Amherst College Panhellenic Association.
The Panhellenic advisor shall have voice but no vote in all meetings of the Panhellenic Council and the Executive
Board.

Article VIII. Committees

Section 1. Standing committees
A.
Board, Membership Recruitment Committee, and the Diversity and Inclusion Committee.

The standing committees of the UMass Amherst College Panhellenic Association shall be the Judicial

 B.     Term. The standing committees shall serve for a term of one year, which shall coincide with the term of the
officers.

Section 2. Appointment of committee membership
The Executive Board shall appoint members and chairwomen of all standing and special committees, except as
provided otherwise in these bylaws, and in making these appointments, recognize fair representation from all
member women’s only sororities as much as possible. The president shall be an ex-officio member of all
committees.

Section 3. Judicial Board
The Judicial Board shall consist of the vice president of standards as chairwoman and the President of the College
Panhellenic Association. The Panhellenic advisor shall serve as a nonvoting, ex-officio member. The Judicial Board
members shall participate in training to be educated about the purpose of the board, the rules and regulations the
Judicial Board will monitor, the procedures to be followed, proper questioning techniques, the rights of the charged
organizations, evaluating evidence, and deliberations and sanctioning. The Judicial Board shall educate member
sororities about the College Panhellenic judicial procedure.

In accordance with NPC Unanimous Agreement VII. College Panhellenic Association Judicial Procedure, it shall be
the Judicial Board’s duty to hold a hearing to adjudicate all alleged violations of the NPC Unanimous Agreements
and the bylaws, code of ethics, standing rules and membership recruitment regulations of the UMass Amherst
College Panhellenic Association that are not settled informally or through mediation. The hearing shall be conducted
by the entire Judicial Board unless the Panhellenic Council adopts rules for the hearing to be conducted by a
committee of the Judicial Board. The members of the Judicial Board shall maintain confidentiality throughout and
upon completion of the judicial process.

Section 4. Membership Recruitment Committee
The Membership Recruitment Committee shall consist of a chairman and one representative from each regular,
provisional and associate women’s only member (if they are participating in the primary recruitment process).
Alumnae advisors may attend meetings of the committee. The alumnae advisors shall have voice but no vote. This
committee shall review and develop membership recruitment rules and submit them for discussion and approval to
the Panhellenic Council before the end of the academic term preceding the primary membership recruitment period.
After each primary membership recruitment period, the chairman of this committee shall present a full report,
including recommendations, to the Panhellenic Council based on an analysis of the recruitment statistics and
recruitment evaluations from new members, potential new members who withdrew, each member organization and
chapter advisor.

Section 5. Diversity and Inclusion Committee
The Diversity and Inclusion Committee must consist of at least one woman per chapter who will remain on said
committee for the full calendar term. Committee meetings shall be open to all Panhellenic community members to
attend. This committee shall work with the Vice President of Diversity and Inclusion to plan at least one event in the
spring semester and at least one event in the fall semester for the Panhellenic community, and work to plan at least
one open event or fundraiser . They will also help in the creation and assessment of a diversity and inclusion survey
each year, as well as work to create training around diversity and inclusion for all members to have prior to primary
recruitment of that year.  This committee will present to the Panhellenic Council at the end of each semester. This
committee shall meet no less than four times per semester. The committee will work on and complete any other
tasks deemed necessary by the Vice President of Diversity and Inclusion.

 Section 5. Other committees
Other such committees, standing or special, shall be appointed as deemed necessary by the Panhellenic Council.

Article IX. Finances

Section 1. Fiscal Year
The fiscal year of the UMass Amherst College Panhellenic Association shall be from June, 1 to May, 31 inclusive.

Section 2. Contracts
Dual signatures of the VP finance and President or some other protective arrangement shall be required to bind the
UMass Amherst College Panhellenic Association on any contract.

Section 3. Checks
All checks and electronic payments issued on behalf of the UMass Amherst College Panhellenic Association shall
bear dual signatures. The following shall be authorized to be one of the two required signatures: VP Finance and
President

Section 4. Payments
All payments due to the UMass Amherst College Panhellenic Association shall be received by the VP Finance, who
shall record them. Checks for payments shall be made payable to the UMass Amherst Panhellenic Council.

Article X. Extension

Section 1. Extension
Extension is the process of adding an NPC women’s only sorority.

The UMass Amherst College Panhellenic Association shall follow all NPC Unanimous Agreements and NPC
extension guidelines found on the NPC website and in the NPC Manual of Information.

Section 2. Voting rights
Only regular members of the Panhellenic Council shall vote on extension matters.

Article XI. Violation Resolution

Section 1. Violation
Chapters shall be held accountable for the conduct of their individual collegiate and alumnae members. Conduct
contrary to the NPC Unanimous Agreements, these bylaws, the Panhellenic code of ethics, standing rules and/or
membership recruitment regulations of the UMass Amherst College Panhellenic Association shall be considered a
violation.

Section 2. Informal resolution
Members are encouraged to resolve alleged violations through informal discussion with the involved parties.

 Section 3. Judicial process
The UMass Amherst College Panhellenic Association shall follow all NPC Unanimous Agreements and NPC
guidelines for the judicial process found in the NPC Manual of Information.

Article XII. Hazing

Per the Unanimous Agreements, NPC supports all efforts to eliminate hazing. All forms of hazing shall be
BANNED.
Hazing can be defined as  any reckless or intentional act that produces physical, mental, or emotional pain,
discomfort, humiliation, embarrassment, or ridicule, regardless of a person’s willingness to participate, that is
required or expected of a member and that is not related to the Fraternity’s mission. Examples of this include but are
not limited to the forced consumption of alcohol, scavenger hunts, being required to wear embarrassing or
uncomfortable clothing, getting yelled or screamed at,  or any kind of personal servitude.  Should any member
witness any form of hazing, that member must report the incident to the Panhellenic Advisor.  Retaliation against
any person who reports, is a witness to, or is involved with or cooperates in the investigation and adjudication of
hazing is strictly prohibited.

Article XIII. Inclusion Statement

The UMass Amherst College Panhellenic Association does not categorically deny membership to an individual,
based on race, color, religion, age, national origin, ancestry, sexual orientation, gender identity and expression,
military or veteran status, the presence of a disability, genetic information, familial status, political affiliation or
participation in protected activities (discrimination based on sex is allowed through Title IX of the Educational
Amendments of 1972).

Article XIV. Parliamentary Authority

The rules contained in the current edition of Robert's Rules of Order Newly Revised shall govern the UMass
Amherst College Panhellenic Association when applicable and when they are not inconsistent with the NPC
Unanimous Agreements, these bylaws and any special rules of order the UMass Amherst College Panhellenic
Association may adopt.

Article XV. Amendment of Bylaws

These bylaws may be amended at any regular or special meeting of the UMass Amherst Panhellenic Council by a
two-thirds vote, provided the proposed amendment has been announced and submitted in writing at the previous
regular meeting, allowing an opportunity for chapter input.

Article XVI. Dissolution

This College Panhellenic Association shall be dissolved when only one regular member exists at UMass Amherst. In
the event of the dissolution, none of the assets of the Association shall be distributed to any members of the
Association, but after payment of all debts, its assets shall be given to NPC unless otherwise required by state law.

 CODE OF ETHICS

NOTE: For Fall 2020 the following recruitment rules were followed, however for future recruitments the
Recruitment Rules Adopted on 4/16/20 will be followed until updated by the Next Panhellenic Eboard.  The
4/16/20 Recruitment Rules are listed below the Fall 2020  Virtual Recruitment Rules that we adopted on
7/30/20.

 RECRUITMENT RULES Date adopted: 7/30/20

These rules are valid for Virtual  Primary Recruitment Fall 2020. For all future recruitments, the previous
recruitment rules adopted on 4/16/20 will still be valid until voted on by the next panhellenic board and
representatives.

1. General Rules

1. All members, advisors, and alumnae are responsible for knowing and observing the
constitution, bylaws, and recruitment rules of the UMass Amherst Panhellenic
Association. As well as the Unanimous Agreements of the National Panhellenic
Conference.

2. A Potential New Member is any full time female college student who has been

determined by Panhellenic to qualify as eligible to go through the Primary Recruitment
Process.

3. The Total will be  94 women per chapter as this was the total from Fall 2019

2. Continuous Open Bidding (COB)

1. A chapter is eligible for COB if not at campus total, or did not match quota during

primary recruitment.

2. During COB chapters may extend a bid verbally. If the bid is accepted, the new member

must report to the Office of Fraternities and Sororities to complete her acceptance card
and COB MRABA within 24hrs of accepting her bid.

3. Any full time student at UMass Amherst will be eligible for COB. (• Not be

simultaneously enrolled in high school and attending college. • Be an undergraduate
regularly matriculated according to the definition of matriculation established by that
institution.)
If a woman had previously accepted a bid and decided to terminate her membership prior
to initiation, she may go through recruitment during the next primary recruitment period.

4.

5. COB will not begin in the Fall semester until 24hrs after bid day.

3. Primary Recruitment

1. General

i.  Primary  Recruitment shall be defined as the period extending from the
beginning of the Informational Session until the end of the Bid Day celebration.

ii.   Primary  Recruitment shall be held in the Fall Semester. The dates will be
announced at the end of Fall semester in the prior academic year.

Iii. No chapter-specific information is to be distributed by any individual sorority
at any time from the start of school until Bid Day unless it is during the primary
recruitment process. The membership recruitment booklet composed by the
Panhellenic Council will be distributed to all Potential New Members prior to the
first round of recruitment events. This will include dues information.

 iv.  Any conversations that women have with Potential New Members, and any
promotional materials are given out need to be “Go Greek”, there should be no
promoting of one sorority over another. Sororities should not be advertising
“Rush XYZ” on social media posts, or social media hashtags, including but not
limited to Facebook, Twitter, Snapchat and Instagram. Any “Go XYZ” or "Rush
XYZ" chapter advertisements or promotional materials will be subject to judicial
hearing. This paraphernalia includes but is not limited to shirts, bags, house
banners, pens, etc., even if both phrases are included (i.e. "GO Greek, Go XYZ").
However, in accordance with NPC Promotion of Sorority Policy 2020,  chapters
should  actively promote the overall sorority experience and membership
opportunities in organizations through all forms of communication as much as
possible.

v.     Release Figures Methodology will be implemented by NPC Guidelines.

vi.   Should  sorority members be in the Amherst area for Fall 2020, they must
respect any rules  and town regulations when it comes to off campus and greek
housing. Should fraternities be allowed to have guests, no sorority members are
to enter any fraternity house at any time for any reason from the start of primary
recruitment until twenty-four hours after the conclusion of Bid Day events.

vii.  Provided with extenuating circumstances, timelines can be adjusted (like a
power outage, extreme weather conditions, etc.).  Such changes will be done in
consultation with the VPs of membership from the chapters.

4. Potential New Members and Sisters

i.       A Potential New Member shall be any full time college student who is capable
of going through the Primary Recruitment Process. She shall retain this status until
the end of the Recruitment Counselor reveal.

ii.     In order to respect the decision-making process of Potential New Members,
chapter members will have Normal Social Contact with Potential New Members
outside of recruitment events from the end of the Information Session on Wednesday
September 9th, through Preference Night on Sunday, September 13th  Normal Social
Contact is defined as polite, friendly conversations such as saying hello to a PNM on
your way to class, but should not include anything about recruitment.

iii.   Chapter members, including recruitment chairwomen and recruitment
counselors, may contact Potential New Members via social media prior to as long as
this promotion is done with a Go Greek attitude. These social media outlets include,
but are not limited to Facebook, Twitter, Snapchat, Instagram, etc. The Panhellenic

 Council will create a facebook group for Potential New Members, thus no other
sorority  members should be adding Potential New Members to any open or closed
Facebook groups whatsoever.

iv.   Strict Silence is the period where there shall be no conversation or contact
between Potential New Members and active members, new members, and alumnae.
Strict silence is designated as the period of time from the end of the Potential New
Members last preference party until the end of the Recruitment Counselors reveal on
Bid Day.

v.     No chapter members, including new members, alumnae and advisors, may visit
a Potential New Member in her dorm room, apartment, or place of residence during
Primary Recruitment.

vi.   No Potential New Member may visit a chapter house or facility unless it is
during a recruitment event.

vii.  No chapter member, new member, alumnae or advisor may buy anything for a
Potential New Member during Primary Recruitment. No Potential New Member may
buy anything for any chapter member, new member, alumnae or advisor during
Primary Recruitment.

viii. There will be no promising of bids either directly or indirectly by any member,
new member, alumnae or advisor of a sorority. Sorority members should not promise
any material incentives to Potential New Members, including but not limited to
apartment leases, relations with fraternities, becoming a Potential New Member’s
Big, etc.

ix.   Conversations with Potential New members during recruitment should be of the
“Go Greek” nature and should not include the topics of: alcohol, drugs, drug
paraphernalia, boys, parties, and fraternities. There should also be no direct or
indirect mention of any chapter other than a sister’s own during conversations with
PNMs. Sorority members should not speak negatively about or on behalf of other
chapters, or promote false rumors about other chapters at all.

5. Information Session and Recruitment Events

i.       All Potential New members shall attend all Primary Recruitment events she is
invited to. If a Potential New Member is unable to attend a round of events, she must
notify the Panhellenic Council by the following means:

1.    For all prior known engagements, including class, work, etc., she must
submit to her Recruitment Counselor a written explanation of why she is
unable to attend at least 24hrs in advance.

 2.   In case of illness or any other emergency, the Potential New Member
shall call her Recruitment Counselor.

3.  Panhellenic shall notify any sorority or sororities involved of a Potential
New Member’s absence.

ii.   The Information Session on the first day of Primary Recruitment: Panhellenic
Executive Board, Recruitment Counselors, Potential New Members, Chapter
Presidents and Chapter Recruitment Chairs.

iii.   Events will follow the schedule and format agreed and voted upon by the UMass
Amherst Panhellenic Council prior to the beginning of Primary Recruitment,
according to the guidelines set in the NPC Manual of Information.

iv.   No men shall be included in Primary Recruitment events, including Bid Day
except for advisors and administrators. This includes slideshows or pictures shown to
PNMs.

v.     No alcoholic beverages consumed during Primary Recruitment events, including
Bid Day.

ix.   No favors or gifts may be given to potential members by a chapter or its
individual members, alumnae or advisors at any time during Primary Membership
Recruitment.

x.     All lists must be submitted on ICS in accordance with designated times listed on
the recruitment schedule, which will be the following mornings at 1 AM after each
day of recruitment.

xi.   All materials and proposals for round one or round 2 must be submitted and
approved by the VP of Membership by date announced. Recruitment slideshows
should not contain song lyrics, photos or videography that mention/include boys,
fraternity members unless it is a greek week promoted activity, sorority members at
fraternity houses, alcohol, drugs, drug paraphernalia, and/or partying. Recruitment
slideshows should only mention positive information about their chapter, and should
not mention negative comments about materials or traditions utilized by other
chapters (for example, speaking poorly about having a chapter house or not having a
chapter house. If unhoused, having a single sorority house should not be mentioned
and the chapter should only speak of their satellite houses).

xii.  The budget for Primary Recruitment shall be capped at $3000 per chapter. This
does not include room rental fees for the unhoused chapters and does not include Bid
Day t-shirts. All receipts must be submitted to the VP of Membership by date
announced.

 Xiii. Each chapter must submit an Active Membership roster no later than the date
announced. This is the correct active membership number each sorority has submitted
to their National organization (if applicable) for Fall semester.

5. Bid Matching

a. No undergraduates will participate in bid matching.

b. All bid lists must be submitted at 8 AM the following morning after the last preference

party ends.

c. Bid matching will be completed using the ICS system and will be in compliance with the

procedures outlined in the NPC Manual of Information.

d. Snap Bidding: Chapters will be contacted by the fraternity/sorority advisor by 8:00 AM if

they qualify for snap bidding. All chapters should be prepared to issue snap bids at this time.

6. Recruitment Counselors

a.   The purpose of the Recruitment Counselor is to advise potential new members while
maintaining an unbiased and positive view of the Greek community.

B. Recruitment Counselors will be selected through an application and interview process
to take place in February.

c. Each chapter shall have at least 8 members as Recruitment Counselors,  unless a
chapter is significantly under total and permission is granted by the Panhellenic
Executive Board. No more than 10 members from a chapter will be Recruitment
Counselors. Each chapter must recommend at least 10 sorority members to apply for the
Recruitment Counselor position.

d.               Recruitment Counselors are required to attend all educational sessions
conducted by the VP of Membership.

e.               Recruitment counselors will disaffiliate from August 1st to Bid Day reveal on
September 14th. Starting August 1st, Recruitment Counselors will take letters off social
media and any social media posts regarding one’s chapter on personal accounts or chapter
social media.  Should Recruitment Counselors be going on campus, they will limit social
interaction to no more than two sisters  and none with sisters wearing letters. Recruitment
Counselors may attend any virtual chapter events

f. Recruitment Counselors should only speak to Potential New Members about topics that
promote “Going Greek.” Recruitment Counselors should not list the benefits of specific

 chapter incentives to Potential New Members, including but not limited to the benefits of
having, or not having, a chapter house, fraternity relations, etc. Recruitment Counselors
should not disclose or hint at their affiliation to Potential New Members whatsoever.

g. Recruitment Counselors are not allowed to speak to any chapter members, new
members, advisors, alumnae about any Potential New Members.

i.   Recruitment Counselors may only access the ICS system when inputting Potential
New Members’ preferences. Recruitment Counselors shall not alter or change these
preferences without the request of the Potential New Member in question, or access the
ICS system outside of recruitment events.

J. Recruitment Counselors are expected to be at every party unless a valid excuse is
shared with the panhellenic VP of Membership (class, illness, and other excuses on a case
by case basis) or will be subject to fine

K.Recruitment Counselors should not attend any recruitment event they are obligated to
go to or perform any of their duties under the influence of drugs and alcohol, violators
will be subject to fine

Judicial Procedures and Recruitment Infractions

a.  Filing of infractions must follow the guidelines set by the NPC Manual of Information.

b. Infraction mediations and all other Judicial Hearings will follow the procedures
outlined in the NPC Manual of Information. The president and relevant parties of the
reporting and infarcted  chapter shall attend the mediation. An appointed mediator will
mediate the session. The fraternity/sorority advisor can act as a mediator unless he/she is
directly involved in the infraction.

c.The Panhellenic Council Officers will be completely impartial during this time and will
model this behavior to Rho Gammas and the rest of the community. Officers will be kind,
approachable  and respectful at all times. Should a chapter have an issue with a
Panhellenic Officer, they are to report the issue to the Vice President of Standards and the
Panhellenic Advisor. Should the issue be with the Vice President of Standards report the
issue to the President and the Panhellenic Advisor.

D. Chapters should be aware of all recruitment bylaws and consequences if in violation of
any law. Chapters should abide by all bylaws.  Expectations for the Recruitment Chairs
will be discussed at the beginning of Fall semester during a meeting with the Vice
President of Membership for the Panhellenic Council.

7.     Fines

 a.   If any of the following recruitment bylaws have been violated and reported to the
Panhellenic Council, the sorority member(s) or chapter in question will be subject to
fines. The violations will be discussed through the filing of an infraction, followed by a
mediation with the Panhellenic Council in which the fine may or may not be presented.

i.     Late submission of active chapter roster, $50 fine and additional $50 for each
additional day the roster has not been submitted after the due date

ii.    Late submission of recruitment slideshow, $100 fine and an additional $100
for each additional day the slideshow has not been submitted after the due date

iii.   Late submission of recruitment receipts, $100 fine and an additional $100
for each additional day the receipts have not been submitted after the due date

iv.   Late submission of Potential New Members lists on ICS during recruitment,
$300 fine and additional $100 for each additional hour past the deadline

v.   Any “Go XYZ” or "Rush XYZ" chapter advertisements on social media or
any promotional materials, $100 fine per incident

vi.    Sorority members, including Recruitment Counselors, who have attended
any social events at fraternity houses, including satellite houses, during
recruitment $50 fine per chapter member in violation and a meeting with
Panhellenic Standards

vii.   Sorority members who have not respected Normal Social Contact with
Potential New Members outside of recruitment events from the end of the
Information Session the first day of Primary  Recruitment, through Preference
Night, $300 fine per chapter member in violation

vii.  Promising of bids or material incentives to Potential New Members either
directly or indirectly by any member, new member, alumnae or advisor of a
sorority, $100 fine per incident

ix.  Sorority members who have not respected the conversations of “Go Greek”
nature and/or direct or indirect mention of any chapter other than a sister’s own
during conversations. Sorority members who have conversed with Potential New
Members about the topics of: alcohol, drugs, drug paraphernalia, boys, parties,
and fraternities, $200 fine per chapter member in violation.

x.   Presentation of recruitment slideshow that was not approved by the
Panhellenic Vice President of Membership, $50 fine per party

 xi.  Recruitment Counselors who have disclosed their affiliation to Potential New
Members, $50 per incident

xii. Recruitment Counselors who have mentioned specific chapter benefits or
chapter biases to Potential New Members, $50 per incident

xiii.  Recruitment Counselors who have spoken to chapter members, new
members, advisors, alumnae about any Potential New Member or any other
recruitment matters, $50 per incident

xiv.  Recruitment Counselors who have accessed the ICS system outside of
recruitment events, $100 fine per incident

Xvii. Recruitment Counselors who are marked absent and unexcused  for more
than one party will have the potential to be called into Panhellenic Standards

xviii. Recruitment Counselors who are found under the influence of drugs or
alcohol during their Recruitment Counselor duties including Bid Day, $50 per
incident and  the individual will be called into Panhellenic Standards

Xix . Failure to recommend at least 10 chapter members to be recruitment
counselors, without special permission from the Panhel Executive board will
result in a $50 fine to the chapter for each member they are missing.

End of Virtual Recruitment Rules - Adopted 7/30/20

RECRUITMENT RULES Date adopted: 4/16/20

These rules are valid for  Formal Recruitment. Provided the uncertainty due to COVID-19 and discussion of what
Fall 2020 will look like the Panhellenic Council is working to formulate an alternative option for recruitment.
Should Fall 2020 look different then expected, the Panhellenic Council will inform chapters of the alternative plan
within two weeks after University notification. The alternative plan will model after the suggested findings by the
NPC Recruitment Task force, who are focusing on the best strategies for recruitment based on what is happening
with the pandemic. We will follow the recommendations of the University of Massachusetts, Amherst and be in
compliance with CDC regulations.

Panhellenic to qualify as eligible to go through the Formal Recruitment Process.

 3. The Total will be used with the total membership of each sorority being automatically adjusted to

average chapter size (rounded to the nearest whole number) or median chapter size no later than
72 hours following bid distribution.

4.

5. COB will not begin in the Fall semester until 24hrs after bid day.

that women have with Potential New Members, and any promotional materials are given
out need to be “Go Greek”, there should be no promoting of one sorority over another.
Sororities should not be advertising “Rush XYZ” on social media posts, or social media
hashtags, including but not limited to Facebook, Twitter, Snapchat and Instagram. Any
“Go XYZ” or "Rush XYZ" chapter advertisements or promotional materials will be
subject to judicial hearing. This paraphernalia includes but is not limited to shirts, bags,
house banners, pens, etc., even if both phrases are included (i.e. "GO Greek, Go XYZ").

v.     Release Figures Methodology will be implemented by NPC Guidelines.

vi.   No sorority members are to attend any social events at fraternity houses, including
satellite houses that contain four or more fraternity members, from 12 Midnight of
Sunday September 20th  through the beginning of recruitment (this includes any closed
social events). No sorority members are to enter any fraternity house at any time for any
reason from the start of formal recruitment until twenty-four hours after the conclusion of
Bid Day events.

 vii.  Provided with extenuating circumstances, timelines can be adjusted (like a power

with the vps of membership from the chapters.

4. Potential New Members and Sisters

i.       A Potential New Member shall be any full time college student who is capable of going
through the Formal Recruitment Process. She shall retain this status until the end of the
Recruitment Counselor reveal.

media outlets include, but are not limited to Facebook, Twitter, Snapchat, Instagram, etc.
Sorority members should not be adding Potential New Members to any open or closed

designated as the period of time from the end of the Potential New Members last preference
party until the end of the Recruitment Counselors reveal on Bid Day.

v.     No chapter members, including new members, alumnae and advisors, may visit a

Recruitment.

recruitment event.

New Member during Formal Recruitment. No Potential New Member may buy anything for
any chapter member, new member, alumnae or advisor during Formal Recruitment.
