member, alumnae or advisor of a sorority. Sorority members should not promise any material
incentives to Potential New Members, including but not limited to apartment leases, relations
with fraternities, becoming a Potential New Member’s Big, etc.

ix.   Conversations with Potential New members during recruitment should be of the “Go
Greek” nature and should not include the topics of: alcohol, drugs, drug paraphernalia, boys,

 parties, and fraternities. There should also be no direct or indirect mention of any chapter
other than a sister’s own during conversations with PNMs. Sorority members should not
speak negatively about or on behalf of other chapters, or promote false rumors about other
chapters at all.

5. Information Session and Recruitment Events

i.       All Potential New members shall attend all Formal Recruitment events she is invited to.
If a Potential New Member is unable to attend a round of events, she must notify the
Panhellenic Council by the following means:

1.     For all prior known engagements, including class, work, etc., she must submit
to her Recruitment Counselor a written explanation of why she is unable to attend at
least 24hrs in advance.

2.     In case of illness or any other emergency, the Potential New Member shall call
her Recruitment Counselor.

3.     Panhellenic shall notify any sorority or sororities involved of a Potential New
Member’s absence.

ii.     The Information Session on the first day of Formal Recruitment: Panhellenic Executive
Board, Recruitment Counselors, Potential New Members, and 8 members from each chapter.

iii.   Events will follow the schedule and format agreed and voted upon by the UMass
Amherst Panhellenic Council prior to the beginning of Formal Recruitment, according to the
guidelines set in the NPC Manual of Information.

iv.   No men shall be included in Formal Recruitment events, including Bid Day except for
advisors and administrators. This includes slideshows or pictures shown to PNMs.

v.     No alcoholic beverages shall be served or consumed during Formal Recruitment events,
including Bid Day.

vi.   All decorations and entertainment shall be confined to the room or house in which the
recruitment event is taking place. Items such as chapter wooden letters, banners, flowers, and
welcome mats may be allowed outside of the house’s or room’s interior. Any decorations not
listed have to be approved by the Panhellenic VPM. Any decorations not within the approved
list outside of the room or house’s interior space in which recruitment events are held without
permission shall be eliminated and chapter in violation are subject to fine. Decorations are
limited to tablecloths, sorority banners, and sorority paraphernalia on the interior. There shall
be no streamers, balloons filled with helium or other posting on the walls due to fire safety
precautions. All decorations and entertainment must be appropriate.

vii.  No food will be provided by individual chapters during the first round of recruitment.
Food will be limited to water, soda, juice, cookies, petit fours, and brownies for Rounds 2 and
3, any other foods must be submitted to the Panhellenic VPM for approval. There will be no

 limitation for food during Preference Round. Any chapter who violates this guideline is
compromising the integrity of recruitment and shall be subject to a judicial hearing.

viii.         The Panhellenic Council will provide one name tag for each Potential New Member
at the first round of recruitment. Recruitment Counselors and/or Potential New Members are
responsible for replacing any lost nametags.

ix.   No favors or gifts may be given to potential members by a chapter or its individual
members, alumnae or advisors at any time during Formal Membership Recruitment.

x.     All lists must be submitted on ICS in accordance with designated times listed on the
recruitment schedule, which will be the following mornings at 8 AM after each day of
recruitment.

xi.   All materials and proposals for round one or round 2 must be submitted and approved by
the VP of Membership by date announced. Recruitment slideshows should not contain song
lyrics, photos or videography that mention/include boys, fraternity members, sorority
members at fraternity houses, alcohol, drugs, drug paraphernalia, and/or partying.
Recruitment slideshows should only mention positive information about their chapter, and
should not mention negative comments about materials or traditions utilized by other chapters
(for example, speaking poorly about having a chapter house or not having a chapter house).

xii.  The budget for Formal Recruitment shall be capped at $3000 per chapter. This does not
include room rental fees for the unhoused chapters and does not include Bid Day t-shirts. All
receipts must be submitted to the VP of Membership by date announced.

xiii.         Each chapter must submit an Active Membership roster no later than date
announced. This is the correct active membership number each sorority has submitted to their
National organization (if applicable) for Fall semester.

5. Bid Matching

a. No undergraduates will participate in bid matching.

b. All bid lists must be submitted at 8 AM the following morning after the last preference party ends.

c. Bid matching will be completed using the ICS system and will be in compliance with the procedures

outlined in the NPC Manual of Information.

d. Snap Bidding: Chapters will be contacted by the fraternity/sorority advisor by 8:00 AM if they

qualify for snap bidding. All chapters should be prepared to issue snap bids at this time.

6. Recruitment Counselors

a.               The purpose of the Recruitment Counselor is to advise potential new members while
maintaining an unbiased and positive view of the Greek community.

 b.               Recruitment Counselors will be selected through an application and interview process
to take place in February.

c.               Each chapter shall have at least 8 members as Recruitment Counselors,  unless a
chapter is significantly under total and permission is granted by the Panhellenic Executive Board.
No more than 10 members from a chapter will be Recruitment Counselors. Each chapter must
recommend at least 10 sorority members to apply for the Recruitment Counselor position.

d.               Recruitment Counselors are required to attend all educational sessions conducted by
the VP of Membership.

e.               Recruitment counselors will disaffiliate from September 4th to Bid Day reveal on
October 6th. September 4th to September 20th disaffiliation of Recruitment Counselors will
consist of taking letters off social media, any social media posts regarding one’s chapter on
personal accounts or chapter social media, limited social interaction with sisters on campus
(chapters and sisterhood events are acceptable to attend),  From September 20th to Bid Day
October 6th all rules regarding social media will continue, there will be no social interactions with
more than two sisters in public and none with sisters wearing letters. Chapter and sisterhood
events from this point on are prohibited.

f.                Recruitment Counselors should only speak to Potential New Members about topics that
promote “Going Greek.” Recruitment Counselors should not list the benefits of specific chapter
incentives to Potential New Members, including but not limited to the benefits of having, or not
having, a chapter house, fraternity relations, etc. Recruitment Counselors should not disclose or
hint at their affiliation to Potential New Members whatsoever.

g.               Recruitment Counselors are not allowed to speak to any chapter members, new
members, advisors, alumnae about any Potential New Member or any other recruitment matters.

h.               In order to preserve the integrity of the disaffiliation, Recruitment Counselors may not
interact with more than four members of their chapter at one time.

i.             Recruitment Counselors may only access the ICS system when inputting Potential New
Members’ preferences. Recruitment Counselors shall not alter or change these preferences without
the request of the Potential New Member in question, or access the ICS system outside of
recruitment events.

Recruitment Counselors are expected to be at every party unless a valid excuse is shared

J.
with the panhellenic VP of Recruitment (class, illness, and other excuses on a case by case basis)
or will be subject to fine

K.
Recruitment Counselors should not attend any recruitment event they are obligated to go
to or perform any of their duties under the influence of drugs and alcohol, violators will be subject
to fine

Judicial Procedures and Recruitment Infractions

a.               Filing of infractions must follow the guidelines set by the NPC Manual of Information.

 b.               Infraction mediations and all other Judicial Hearings will follow the procedures
outlined in the NPC Manual of Information. The president and relevant parties of the reporting and
infracted group shall attend the mediation. An appointed mediator will mediate the session. The
fraternity/sorority advisor can act as a mediator unless he/she is directly involved in the infraction.

c.The Panhellenic Council Officers will be completely impartial during this time and will model
this behavior to Rho Gammas and the rest of the community. Officers will be kind, approachable
and respectful at all times. Should a chapter have an issue with a Panhellenic Officer, they are to
report the issue to the Vice President of Standards and the Panhellenic Advisor. Should the issue
be with the Vice President of Standards report the issue to the President and the Panhellenic
Advisor.

D. Chapters should be aware of all recruitment bylaws and consequences if in violation of any law.
Chapters should abide by all bylaws.  Expectations for the Recruitment Chairs will be discussed at
the beginning of Fall semester during a meeting with the Vice President of Membership for the
Panhellenic Council.

7.     Fines

a.      If any of the following recruitment bylaws have been violated and reported to the
Panhellenic Council, the sorority member(s) or chapter in question will be subject to fines. The
violations will be discussed through the filing of an infraction, followed by a mediation with the
Panhellenic Council in which the fine may or may not be presented.

i.       Late submission of active chapter roster, $100 fine and additional $100 for each
additional day the roster has not been submitted after the due date

ii.     Late submission of recruitment slideshow, $100 fine and an additional $100 for each
additional day the slideshow has not been submitted after the due date

iii.   Late submission of recruitment receipts, $100 fine and an additional $100 for each
additional day the receipts have not been submitted after the due date

iv.   Late submission of Potential New Members lists on ICS during recruitment, $300
fine and additional $100 for each additional hour past the deadline

v.     The violation of bylaws regarding decorations and entertainment used for
recruitment parties, $300 fine per party and the potential to be called into Panhellenic
Standards if not removed.

vi.   The violation of bylaws regarding food served during recruitment parties, $50 fine
per party

vii.  The violation of bylaws regarding alcohol served during recruitment parties, $500
fine per party

viii.  Any “Go XYZ” or "Rush XYZ" chapter advertisements on social media or any
promotional materials, $100 fine per incident

 ix.   Sorority members, including Recruitment Counselors, who have attended any social
events at fraternity houses, including satellite houses, $150 fine per chapter member in
violation and a meeting with Panhellenic Standards

x.     Sorority members who have not respected Normal Social Contact with Potential
New Members outside of recruitment events from the end of the Information Session the
first day of Formal Recruitment, through Preference Night, $300 fine per chapter member
in violation

xi.   Sorority members who are not Recruitment Counselors who have contacted Potential
New Members via social media, $300 fine per chapter member in violation

xii.  Promising of bids or material incentives to Potential New Members either directly or
indirectly by any member, new member, alumnae or advisor of a sorority, $300 fine per
incident

xiii.  Sorority members who have not respected the conversations of “Go Greek” nature
and/or direct or indirect mention of any chapter other than a sister’s own during
conversations. Sorority members who have conversed with Potential New Members
about the topics of: alcohol, drugs, drug paraphernalia, boys, parties, and fraternities,
$200 fine per chapter member in violation.

xiv.  Presentation of recruitment slideshow that was not approved by the Panhellenic Vice
President of Membership, $100 fine per party

xv.  Recruitment Counselors who have disclosed their affiliation to Potential New
Members, $100 per incident

xvi.  Recruitment Counselors who have mentioned specific chapter benefits or chapter
biases to Potential New Members, $200 per incident

Xvii.  Recruitment Counselors who have spoken to chapter members, new members,
advisors, alumnae about any Potential New Member or any other recruitment matters,
$200 per incident

xviii. Recruitment Counselors who have accessed the ICS system outside of recruitment
events, $500 fine per incident

Xix. Recruitment Counselors who are marked absent and unexcused or are found lying
about their absence for more than one party, $300 fine and the potential to be called into
Panhellenic Standards

XX.  Recruitment Counselors who are marked absent and unexcused or are found lying
about their absence for one party, $150 and the potential to be called into Panhellenic
Standards

 Xxi. Recruitment Counselors who are found under the influence of drugs or alcohol
during their Recruitment Counselor duties including Bid Day, $150 per incident and  the
individual will be called into Panhellenic Standards

Xxii. Failure to recommend at least 10 chapter members, without special permission from
the Panhel Executive board will result in a $50 fine to the chapter for each member they
are missing.

Adopted 4/16/20

DocsList.Name: UMDS Constiution 5_2_2023.pdf
DocsList.Data:
Constitution of the University of Massachusetts Debate Society
Article I: Name of the Organization

The official title of this student organization is, “University of Massachusetts Debate
Society” which may be acceptably shortened to, “UMass Amherst Debate” “UMDS” or
“UMass Debate Society.”

Article II: Mission Statement

The purpose of this organization is to advance the growth of its members in the areas of
critical analysis, argumentation and oratory through competition in intercollegiate
parliamentary debate, while providing an inclusive and supportive team environment at
no cost to its members.

Article III: Membership

All UMass Amherst students are welcome and encouraged to participate in team practices
or events. Voting member status, however, is a specific subcategory of membership open
only to undergraduates at UMass Amhersts who sign the Code of Conduct and regularly
attend practices. UMass Amherst faculty, graduate students, alumni and Five College
students are welcome to attend and address meetings, but will not be awarded voting
member status. All members are expected to follow the team Code of Conduct as well as
the University Conduct standards.

Article IV: Meetings and Practices

Section A: Team Practice

Team Practices will occur weekly, with optional practices over summer and
winter breaks. Practices will be organized in anticipation of participation in
tournaments. Members must follow the attendance policy outlined in the Code of
Conduct.

Section B: Executive Board Meetings

Executive Board meetings to discuss administrative matters will occur at dates
and times determined by unanimous consent of the Executive Board, and will
involve no fewer than two-thirds of the Executive Board at a frequency of no
fewer than twice per month during the academic year and no less than once per
month during school breaks. The President shall chair the Executive Board
Meetings. Executive Board members will be expected to notify the Board of an
anticipated absence at least two weeks in advance, barring extenuating
circumstances.

 Section C: Quorum

No substantive matters under the purview of the Executive Board may be decided
by vote without the totality of the Executive Board.

Section D: Order of Conduct

Meetings will be chaired by the President, or in their absence, another Executive
Board member, who will read the orders of business and call upon speakers to
discuss said orders. The chair will also hold all votes.

Article V: Executive Board
Section A: Members

The Executive Board shall consist of six elected positions: President, Vice
President of Internal Operations, Vice President of External Operations, Vice
President of Finance, Vice President of Education, and Vice President of Public
Relations. The term of these offices will be from the reading day of the spring
semester through the reading day of the following spring semester; newly elected
Executive Board members will be trained by the current Executive Board so they
will be prepared to transition by the reading day. If the position is to be split by
two individuals, the term of each officer will extend from the first reading day of
either the Fall or Spring semester, and end on the last day of the officer’s
respective semester.

Section B: Elections

1. Timing:

Elections to the Executive Board by majority vote shall be held during the
March of the spring semester or upon resignation of any member of the
Board. One week’s notification to all members is required.

2. Procedure:

A) The Executive Board will announce the timeline of elections to all

members no later than the first week of March and will remind members
of the timeline in the practices leading up to the election.

B) The Executive Board will distribute a Google Form by email for members
to self nominate for Executive Board positions. This self nomination
period shall be at least one week.

C) Each member wishing to run for office is entitled to a speech lasting no

more than three minutes, the distribution of a written statement in advance
of the election by the current Executive Board and participation in a
question and answer event in front of the general membership.

 D) Speeches and the question and answer period shall be held during a
regularly scheduled practice in March with no fewer than two-thirds
(2/3rd) of the active members in the RSO in attendance.

E) Following candidate speeches and the question and answer period, an
electronic ballot shall be available to members for the next 72 hours.
These 72 hours will be started so that the final results are known and able
to be communicated by March 31. The initial election process will be
started in mid-March so that in the event of a special election the March
31st deadline will be met.

F) If a given Executive Board position only has one candidate on the ballot,
the ballot should have a “No” option for that position to oppose the
unopposed candidate. If “No” receives a majority vote, the position will be
vacant and a special election will occur.

G) At least two Executive Board members, graduating seniors or people not

seeking elected office for the next academic year when needed, shall count
the votes and publish the results in a timely fashion. These individuals will
be known as The (Election) Committee. A record of results will be kept in
the Executive Board Google Drive and can be shown to members upon
request.

H) In the event of a tie, the Executive Board shall hold a runoff election

between the candidates. The candidates are entitled to a speech lasting no
more than three minutes. The distribution of a written statement in
advance of the election by the current Executive Board and participation
in a question and answer event in front of the general membership.
Speeches and questioning period shall be held no later than 7 days after
the tie. Following candidate speeches and the question and answer period,
an electronic ballot shall be available to members for the next 72 hours.
If a given Executive Board position does not have any candidates on the
ballot, a special election will occur for this position. A special election will
consist of reopening the candidate application pool and following the
Executive Board election process as outlined by Article V, Section B,
Subsection 2(C-H).
In the event that an active Executive Board member must take a leave of
absence during their term, a special election will take place in accordance
with the process outlined in Article V, Section B, Subsection 2(I) to
establish an interim member.

I)

J)

Section C: Eligibility

 All voting members of the team shall be eligible to hold any office. If a member
wishes to run for office who is unable to be present both semesters of their term
for academic reasons (i.e. graduating in the Fall semester, studying abroad, etc),
that member may run to hold the position for a single semester, provided they find
a running mate to fulfill their duties in the other semester.

Section D: Vote of No Confidence

A vote of no confidence in a member of the Executive Board may be held at a
team meeting called specifically for that purpose at the request of two-thirds of
the Executive Board. The officer shall be notified at least 48 hours prior to the
meeting and have an opportunity to address the membership in a written statement
or speech. Should the vote pass by two thirds of the general membership, that
officer shall immediately resign and the Executive Board will hold a special
election. The Executive Board shall notify the Secretary of the Registry of the
UMass Amherst Student Government Association or their undersecretary of
potential removals of officers.

Section E: Responsibilities:

1. President:
The President ensures the team is consistently pursuing its big picture goals. This is
done through leading meetings, managing the Executive Board, and communicating
with various individuals. It is important that the President is self motivated and able
to motivate others to work toward the team’s success. The President leads the
Executive Board and ensures that all tasks are assigned and executed properly.
Furthermore, the President is often the first point of contact when people are
introduced to the team, so the President needs to maintain cordial relations with all
people related to team operations, including any alumni involved in the team alumni
network.
2. Vice President of Internal Operations:
The primary role of the Vice President of Internal Operations is to support the
President and Vice President of Education in running practices on a weekly basis.
The VP of Internal Operations will take point on the resolution of conflict within
the team and serve as a mediator to any disagreements as needed. In organizing
practice and managing internal affairs of the team, the individual of this position
must be accessible to the team and strive to maintain an atmosphere of acceptance
and positive growth through weekly practices and team events. The Vice President
of Internal Operations also ensures team members are keeping up with their

 obligations to the team. Lastly, the Vice President of Internal Operations serves as
the liaison between the team Equity Officers and the Executive Board in any equity
situations that require Executive Board action.
3. Vice President of External Operations:
The VP of External Operations will have the primary responsibility of making sure
our team is prepared to enter upcoming tournaments, this VP will do so by
submitting our paperwork to tournaments on time and relaying tournament
information to the team. To facilitate this, the Vice President of External Operations
will hold Signature Responsibility. Additionally, the VP of External Operations will
be responsible for the maintenance and encouragement of American Parliamentary
Debate Association (APDA) relations. This individual will be expected to exchange
emails and messages with other APDA-affiliated teams on a weekly basis in the
better interest of growing our connection within the league. Finally, this individual
is responsible for organizing any tournaments that UMDS hosts.
4. Vice President of Finance:
The Vice President of Finance is responsible for monitoring the team’s finances and
reporting information regarding the team’s finances to the rest of the Executive
Board. This individual is the point of contact with any advisors in the SA&I office
and will hold Signature Responsibility. The Vice President of Finance fills out
travel forms for each tournament and also ensures that registration funding from
UMass is disbursed to the hosting universities of tournaments that we attend. In
addition, the VP of Finance will also be in charge of creating, editing, and
submitting the team’s annual RSO budget request at the start of the Spring semester.
Finally, the VP of Finance will lead fundraising efforts and apparel orders, as well
as any other aspect of team management that involves spending or raising money
and managing purchased team property.
5. Vice President of Education:
The primary responsibility of this position is to identify and implement areas of
improvement. This individual is charged with helping everyone get better at debate,
including first year members. More specifically, this includes helping novices learn
the ropes, figuring out what the team should be focusing on in practices, and
finding/creating educational materials. When UMDS has a coach, this individual is
responsible for working with a coach to develop lesson plans and identify areas of
improvement for the team. Finally, this individual is in charge of UMDS
institutional resources. This means developing institutional cases, updating or
creating new resources to cover common debate topics, and expanding an archive of
resources and recorded rounds for members.
6. Vice President of Public Relations:

 The Vice President of Public Relations is responsible for creating and maintaining
the public image of the team. Duties of this position include creating and posting
material for the team’s social media pages, planning and facilitating social events
and communicating messages with the team through email and other means. The
Vice President of Public Relations is also in charge of branding and apparel as well
as recruitment. The Vice President of Public Relations will also maintain the weekly
team announcements Google Slides for all practices, the team Google Calendar and
any group chats.
7. General Executive Board responsibilities:
All Executive Board members are responsible for attending Executive Board
meetings which may occur from the date of their election, in addition to attending
team practices. All Executive Board members will participate in new member
recruitment and the transition to the next Executive Board. On an as needed basis,
the Executive Board may establish Committees with an Executive Board liaison
whose position description is closest to that committee. Finally, the Executive
Board shall update and distribute a Code of Conduct for all members outlining
equitable behavior standards for all members to sign at least once per academic
year.
7. Committees:
On a need basis, committees may be established by the Executive Board with a
specific goal for one semester at a time with the possibility of renewal. All team
members are able to work on a committee. Committees may have chairs appointed
by the Executive Board by an application process.
8. Equity Officers:
Each semester, the Executive Board will appoint two Equity Officers through an
anonymous application process with a public comment period of at least one week.
Equity Officers are non-punitive and confidential resources who: educate members
on best practices of equitable conduct outlined in the Code of Conduct, and mediate
conflicts and listen to member’s problems. The Vice President of Internal
Operations will serve as the liaison between Equity Officers and the Executive
Board, but the Equity Officers are independent of the Executive Board.

Section F: Presidential Line of Succession

If there is ever a vacancy in the Presidency, the Vice President of Internal
Operations will assume the President’s constitutional responsibilities until a new
President is elected per the guidelines above. The Vice President of Internal
Operations duties will be delegated to the remaining Vice Presidents until a full
Executive Board is assembled. In the event of a vacancy in any Vice-Presidential

 Office, the President will delegate all relevant tasks to the remaining members of
the Executive Board.

Section G: Temporary Vice Presidency Vacancies

If a Vice President is ever unable to serve on a temporary basis (such as due to
illness or extended academic absence) but is unable to resign from their position,
the Executive Board has the authority to appoint a Temporary Vice President to
fill that position via an application process. The application process will last at
least 48 hours and will be open to all voting members of the team. The Temporary
Vice President will serve until the end of the Vice President’s term or when the
Vice President returns, whichever period is shorter.

Article VI: Anti-Discrimination

Section A: Free Speech

All members have the right to free speech and expression. Additionally, under no
circumstances shall a member’s freedom of speech or expression be infringed
upon.

Section B: Non-discrimination

The University of Massachusetts Debate Society prohibits any and all forms of
discrimination under Federal and State law, based on race, color, national origin,
religion, sex, gender identity (including, but not limited to, gender expression and
pronoun use), sexual orientation, disability, age, marital status, family/parental
status, income derived from a public assistance program, political beliefs, or
reprisal or retaliation for prior civil rights activity.

Article VII: Amendment

The constitution may be amended at any team meeting by a simple majority vote by
voting members.

Article VIII: Ratification

The constitution shall be offered to the Executive Board for ratification by majority vote
at the start of each fall semester, and thereupon submitted to the Undergraduate Registry
Oversight Committee for final approval.

DocsList.Name: Umass Poetry Club Constitution.docx
DocsList.Data:
Charter for Poetry Club @ UMass
Adopted 11/1/2016 in Amherst, Mass
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Mission Statement
 
Poetry Club strives to create an environment and a platform for students to share, appreciate, and discuss poetry, original or otherwise. We will hold weekly open meetings as well as host writing workshops and poetry slams. We believe that there should exist in our community a space for local poets and poetry aficionados to share and enjoy the art of words. We will navigate through the fog, and draw meaning out of the void, as it melts through our fingers and evaporates on our floors.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 



I.        Membership
A.   All students at the University of Massachusetts Amherst and the general public shall be eligible to be attend Poetry Club meetings and events.
1.     Only University of Massachusetts Amherst undergraduates shall be eligible to vote.
B.    Membership shall be established after a prospective member attends two meetings and informs the Secretary that they wish to be a member.
II.     Meetings
A.  Poetry Club shall have general meetings on a weekly basis.
B.    Meetings shall be chaired by the President.
C.    The purpose of the meetings shall be:
1.     group bonding
2.     planning activities
3.     Reading, discussing, appreciating, and writing poetry
4.     other topics deemed necessary
D.   Decisions will be made at meetings by a majority vote of the general membership.
1.     Quorum (50% +1) of the voting membership must be present in order for votes to be taken.
III.   The Executive Board
A.   The officers of Poetry Club shall be:
1.     President
2.     Vice President
3.     Treasurer
4.     Secretary
5.  Publicist
6. Delegate
B.    Officer shall serve a term of one year, starting the day after the last day of classes in the
Spring semester.
C.    Officers shall be eligible for re-election to multiple terms.
D.   The President
1.     The President shall be the Chief Executive Officer of the RSO. He or she shall be responsible for all aspects of the functioning of the group.
2.     The President shall have Signature Responsibility.
E.    The Vice President
1.     The Vice President shall be the second in command of the RSO.
2.     The Vice President shall take over for the President when he or she is not present.
3.     The Vice President shall be the liason between Poetry Club and the SGA, Student Activities and Involvement, and other campus offices.
F.    The Treasurer
1.     The Treasurer shall be the Chief Financial Officer of the RSO.
2.     The Treasurer shall be responsible for maintaining the groups’s finances.
3.     The Treasurer shall be responsible for submitting an annual budget request to the SGA, if necessary.
4.     The Treasurer shall have Signature Responsibility.
G.   The Secretary
1.     The Secretary shall be responsible for maintaining all records for the RSO.
a)     All minutes, advertising, and other documents relevant the functioning of the group shall be considered records.
b)    These records shall, in all possible cases, be collected electronically and shall be passed on from the current to the future Secretary during the transition period.
2.     The Secretary shall record minutes at all official group meetings.
3.     The Secretary shall maintain up to date membership lists.
4.     The Secretary shall be responsible for maintaining the group’s social media and Campus Pulse pages.
IV.   Officer Elections
1.     Officer elections shall take place during the month of March.
2.     Officer elections shall take place in two stages: the nomination meeting and the online election.
3.     The nomination meeting shall be the first meeting in March.
a)     The Executive Board shall announce the exact date, time, and location of the nominating meeting no later than two weeks prior.
4.     The nominating meeting will be run according to the following procedure:
a)     Any non-election business shall be dealt with first.
b)    Once all other business is taken care of, the President shall announce nomination to be open.
c)     During the nomination period, any voting member shall nominate any voting member, including themselves, to a position.
(1)     In order for the nomination to be official, it shall need to be seconded by another voting member.
(2)     A voting member may only be nominated to one position.
d)    The nomination period shall remain open until a motion is made, seconded, and approved by unanimous consent, to close nominations.
e)     After the nomination period is closed, the President will read from the minutes the names of the candidates who have been nominated. Each member nominated may then chose to accept or reject the nomination.
f)     All nominees that have accepted the nomination will be given the opportunity to address the general membership for 5 minutes, and to take questions from the membership for 5 minutes. The nominees for President will go first, followed by Vice President, Treasurer, and Secretary. The nominees will present first by position and then by the order in which they were nominated.
5.     The second phase of the election shall be the online election period, and it shall adhere to the following procedure.
a)     Directly following the nominating meeting, the Secretary shall set up an election on the group’s Campus Pulse page. He or she shall include only the names of the members that have nominated at the nomination meeting; only nominated members may be elected.
b)    The election shall be open from the day after the nominating meeting to the day prior to the next scheduled meeting.
c)     Following the close of the election period, the Secretary shall prepare an election report, including the winners and the total vote counts for each candidate. This report shall be presented by the Secretary at the meeting directly following the closing of elections. The Secretary shall also view the vote report available on Campus Pulse to ensure that only voting members have voted. If any non-member shall have voted, the election will be deemed invalid and the election period will be re-done, under the supervision of the Secretary of the Registry.
(1)     The Secretary may seek assistance from the Student Activities and Involvement Center of the Secretary of the Registry for any Campus Pulse or election related issues.
6.     The Executive Board shall use the time in between the election and the end of their terms to train the newly elected officers.
7.     The newly elected officers shall take power following the final day of classes of the Spring semester.
8.     If any issues arise during this process, or if any member wishes to appeal the results, the question may be taken by any member or officer to the Student Judiciary.
V.      Removal of Officers
A.   Any officer may be impeached from office for failure to perform the duties of their office or for conduct that is detrimental to the group.
B.    The following procedure must be followed in order for an officer to be impeached:
1.     A motion must be made and seconded during an official and regularly scheduled general body meeting to impeach an officer.
2.     At the following general body meeting, the member making the motion of impeachment shall have 15 minutes to present their case against the officer. This shall be the time to present any evidence and/or witnesses relevant to the impeachment. These 15 minutes shall not be interrupted for any reason, other than if the petitioner decides to take questions from the membership.
3.     Following the presentation of evidence from the petitioner, the accused officer will have 15 minutes to present their defense and any evidence or witnesses they wish. These 15 minutes shall not be interrupted for any reason, other than if the officer decides to take questions from the general membership.
4.     Following the presentations from the petitioner and the accused officer, a vote shall be taken. 2/3 of the general membership must vote in favor of impeachment in order for an officer to be removed.
5.     If the voting results in impeachment, the officer shall immediately surrender his or her office.
6.     If the officer in question is the President, the meeting in which the impeachment is considered shall be chaired by the Vice President.
7.     If any issues arise during this process, or if either party wishes to appeal the results, the question may be taken by any member or officer to the Student Judiciary.
VI.    Officer Vacancies
A.   If the President resigns or is impeached, the Vice President shall immediately take over as President.
B.    If the Vice President, Treasurer, or Secretary resigns or is impeached, a special election shall be held for that position, following the same procedures as section IV of this charter.
C.    The remaining members of the Executive Board shall schedule a the special election at a regularly scheduled meeting between 1 and 3 weeks from the date the office become vacant. The Secretary shall inform the general membership of the date of the special election no less than 1 week prior.
VII.  Resolving Disputes
A.   Disputes arising between members on matters of RSO policy shall be dealt with through majority votes of the general membership.
B.    Disputes arising between members on other matters shall be dealt with through mediation.
1.     Mediation consists of a meeting involving both parties and a mediator with the purpose of coming to a solution and putting the issue to rest.
2.     The President shall mediate disputes between members.
3.     Should the President be involved in the dispute, or should either party no be satisfied by the result of the mediation, any party may request that the Secretary of the Registry mediate. The results of mediation with the Secretary of the Registry shall be final.
VIII.       Free Speech
A.   All members of Poetry Club are entitled to freedom of speech and will not under any circumstances be deprived of the opportunity to share their opinion with the group.
IX.    Amendment
A.   This charter may be amended by a 2/3 vote of the general membership at a regularly scheduled meeting.
1.     A motion to amend may be made and seconded by any member at a meeting of the general membership. The motion shall be presented at the meeting in which the motion is made. Voting on the motion shall take place at the following meeting. Prior to voting, the President shall allow for a period of debate.
B.    After being approved by the membership, the amendment itself, and an updated version of the Charter, shall be submitted to the Secretary of the Registry for final approval.

Constitution – 2013/2014						               24 May 2013



Name of RSO: UMASS Pre-Dental Society

RSO Status
Benefits 
Our organization would be officially recognized by the university.
It would also legitimize our goals and allow us to make use of university rooms for holding meetings.
We would be able to take advantage of SGA resources including forming an alliance with CSD and allow our officers to benefit from leadership training.
Our RSO will be independently funded by its members through fundraising and membership fees as necessary. 

Mission Statement
The mission of this RSO is to provide a stable foundation for developing communication among pre-dental undergraduate students. It will also seek to provide exposure to the dental field and other health related fields.

Future Goals
To educate students on opportunities available in the dental field.
Expose students to different sub-fields of dentistry by giving students volunteer opportunities in dental offices in the Amherst area and having guest speakers describe current advances in dentistry. 
To bring together undergraduate students interested in pursuing a career in dentistry.
Provide an open forum for communication between students by holding bi-weekly discussions and guest speakers.
Guide students in course selection, preparation for the DAT and application to dental schools.
Membership
Eligibility
All voting members must be enrolled as fee-paying Umass Amherst undergraduate students.
Membership will be open to all men and women from the five-college area as well as alumni, faculty and staff.
Membership requirements will entail a minimum attendance of 2/3 of the meetings held during each semester.
Non-Discrimination Clause
No one will be denied membership as long as they fulfill the eligibility requirements. 
Free speech and expression is encouraged.

Voting Process
Voting on amendments and club activities will be conducted publicly (eyes open) by members based on a 50%+1 majority decision. 

Meetings
Meetings will be held bi-weekly and as deemed necessary
Attendance will be monitored through signing an attendance sheet passed around at the start of each meeting.
Prior to each meeting, a notification email will be sent out to all members by a club officer indicating place and time of meeting as well as the event details.
Meeting will begin with officer reports, followed by an open forum for members to express their opinions on past and future events along with voting on events and any necessary amendments.
A 50%+1 majority vote will constitute a decision.

Resolving disputes
Disputes regarding club activities will be resolved based on a 50%+1 majority of voting members.
In the case where club members cannot come to a majority consensus, a pro-con debate will be held and a second vote will be conducted. 
Personal disputes among members not regarding general club concerns will be privately discussed among officers with the specific members.
In certain instances where certain members cannot resolve their disagreement, their voting privileges will be revoked for the remainder of the meeting.

Record Keeping 
Records will be held by the Secretary and viewed by officers.
Attendance sheets, calendar events, and any other general documentation associated with the RSO will be included in record keeping.
The Treasurer will be responsible for holding records of dues, travel money and any other expenses.
Members who have concerns regarding records can request information from records by asking an officer.

Titles and Duties
All officers are expected to attend every meeting unless unavoidable circumstances arise (i.e. illness, exam, etc.)
President
Presides over all meetings.
Organizes structure of the meetings.
Responsible for signing documentation.
Presides over chairs.
Vice-President
Assumes responsibilities of President in absence.
Provides assistance to President.
Monitors other officer decisions and responsibilities.
Treasurer 
Keeps financial records of dues, fundraising money and other expenses.
Responsible for events involving club finances
Chair for fundraising events
Holds signature responsibility
Secretary
Sends out recorded minutes and attendance to all members after each meeting.
Holds records and attendance sheets.
Publicity 
Responsible for hanging and distributing flyers throughout university campus and community.
Fundraising
Responsible for creating events to raise money for club activities and dental causes.
Shadowing Coordinator
Responsible for contacting area dental professionals to create shadowing opportunities for general body meetings
Event Coordinator
Responsible for designing and creating social events.
Will coordinate with Fundraising, Shadowing, and Publicity Chairs to create events to raise money, bring in dental professional speakers, raise dental health awareness.


Elections
Will be held at the end of every fall semester.
All active members will participate in electing new officer positions.
Officer election will be held via secret ballot with a 50%+1 vote necessary for approval.
Officers or members will nominate candidates.
Candidates will be required to deliver a short speech outlining their future goals and contributions as an officer.
Individuals can nominate themselves or be nominated by other voting members.
Individuals nominating themselves and those nominated must be current voting members.
Process of Officer Removal
2/3 of the present voting majority will decide on whether or not an officer’s position should be revoked.
If an individual adheres to membership regulations, they will be permitted to run again for office during the next elections.

Amendments
During officer reports, any officer may propose amendments.
Voting on amendments will take place during open forum.
Approval of 50%+1 majority vote will be submitted to the Secretary of the Registry.

Ratification of the constitution
Shall be voted upon by majority vote (50%+1).
Must be approved by the Secretary of the Registry.
Copy will be made available to all members

RSO Constitution for UMass Rang
 
Article I: Name of the Organization.
The recognized and official name of this organization shall be UMass Rang.

Article II: Mission Statement.
	UMass Rang will do its best to provide a space for students at the University of Massachusetts Amherst to be able to learn about and perfect music with one another, while performing at musical and multicultural events for others’ enjoyment.

Article III: Group Description.
UMass Rang is UMass’ first co-ed Hindi-English fusion a cappella group. Founded in October 2013 by Sakshi Regmi and Shirin Hakim, Rang prides itself on its cultural diversity and South Asian ties. We strive to educate others about Desi culture and showcase the ability to not only sing a cappella styles of music, but also do so in a refreshingly new, multilingual way. In order to develop a sense of community, this club shall be open to anyone, regardless of prior Hindi language knowledge. Group outings will be made to strengthen group friendships in order to work well with one another during rehearsals and perform exceptional concerts.
We are a different group solely because of the fact that we are a cultural a cappella group. We sing not only western-styles of music, but also add Hindi and other Indian songs into the mix. The Hindi-english fusion style is a new sensation throughout the country, and we believe that it has to do with the ability to expose the audience to a very beautiful style of music. We greatly believe in our ties with our culture, and strive to produce setlists that showcase styles of music that people of all backgrounds can enjoy and connect with.
The members of UMass Rang will strive to educate themselves musically through rehearsals and performances, with special emphasis on the pronunciation and exposure of the Hindi language. We will also work towards educating general audiences about Hindi-english fusion a cappella. 

Article IV: Membership.
Section I: Auditions.
UMass Rang is open to anyone who is an undergraduate at the University of Massachusetts Amherst. Graduate students at the University—as well as members of the five-college consortium—are also welcome in the group.
The Audition process and requirements are as follows:
Initial Auditions.
The audition process begins with a general audition in which all interested students can attend.  General Auditions are held for two days during times designated by UMass Rang, and may be extended at the discretion of the Executive Board. 
All members of UMass Rang will evaluate each candidate based on a song chosen by the candidate and performed by the candidate. 
The candidate will then be asked to sing sets of scales to determine pitch accuracy, a vital entity needed for an understanding of a cappella music.
The group will determine who will be called back to a second audition through a vote. 
A two-thirds majority in that vote is needed to call back a candidate for a second audition.
Callbacks.
The candidates will learn part of a song that the group uses in performance, which will be demonstrated for them by the group. 
The candidates will perform the piece with the group, and then individually to determine blend with one another. 
The group members will then decide, based on musical ability and blend, which candidate or candidates fit the current needs of the group in a vote.
 A two-thirds majority is needed in that vote to admit new performing members into the group.
There is only one round of callbacks—only certain exceptions will be made in the case of emergencies. 
Once accepted to UMass Rang, members no longer need to audition for a spot in the group. Members who intend to take a semester off will be allowed reinstatement upon their return provided they notify the group both of their intent to leave before the onset of the semester in which they will be absent, as well as their intent to rejoin upon return upon return to the University at the onset of the semester in which they will be absent. 
Section II: Attendance.
All members are expected to attend all rehearsals and reserve enough time to actively perform with the group. 
Attendance will be taken at every rehearsal, which is to be recorded and kept up-to-date by the Secretary.
Members must keep in contact with the members of the Executive board if they know that they will be missing a rehearsal. All members are allowed 5 unexcused absences per semester without penalty (discussion with the officers regarding commitment). Arriving to rehearsal after the first fifteen minutes will be considered late. Three unexcused late arrivals will equate to one unexcused absence. Members may be asked to leave the group if they violate the attendance policy.
Excused Absences – Absences from rehearsal, meeting, and performance dates will not be counted against a member when determining voting rights under the following circumstances:
Family Emergency
Academic Conflict (test, quiz, class, project). 
Other circumstances in question will be reviewed by the Executive Board of UMass Rang to determine validity.
All performing members must attend 90% of performances during the semester in order to maintain good standing in the group. 

Article V: Establishing Meetings/Planning Activities.
Section I: Regular Rehearsal Meeting Schedule.
A regular meeting schedule will be determined at the beginning of each semester during the first meeting at the completion of the audition process.
Rehearsals will occur a minimum of twice a week, or for at least three hours a week.
The members of UMass Rang may cancel or reschedule a meeting with a two-thirds majority in a vote.
No more than five meetings per semester may be canceled to ensure group productivity and success.
Meeting Structure will be as follows:
The music director will come up with a schedule for every rehearsal in order for the group to stay on track. Usually, the first five minutes may be used for general announcements and bookkeeping in order for the entire group to be on the same page as the Executive Board. 
Ten to fifteen minutes of each rehearsal will be dedicated to warm ups, with the remainder of rehearsal time to be reserved for rehearsing and performance preparation, run by the music director/assistant music director.
Section II: Performance Schedule.
The President of UMass Rang will notify members of possible performance opportunities. The group will then decide if they will accept each performance in a majority vote.
UMass Rang will strive to host at least one performance or event each semester in which to perform for a public audience at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.

Article VI: Record Keeping.
Announcements and records from the beginning of each rehearsal will be written and kept by the Secretary for the remainder of the semester.
Regular meeting attendance will be kept by the Secretary.
The President is responsible for updating this constitution if the need for amendment arises.
The Treasurer will keep track of all financial records.
The Vice President will keep all records involving contact with organizations of the University and outside the University, except SGA and the University Administration.
The President will keep track of any and all activity with SGA and the University Administration. He/She will also aid the Vice President when contacted by various organizations for potential performance opportunities.
Any and all sheet music and organization of the Noteflight online software will be managed and organized by the Music Director.

Article VII: Leadership.
Section I: Officers.
There will be six official officer positions: President, Vice President, Secretary, Treasurer, Social Media/Public Relations Manager, and Music Director.
Section II: Qualifications Needed to Pursue Executive Office.
Candidates must be members of UMass Rang in good standing in order to run for office. All candidates must have been members of UMass Rang for at least one semester.
Section III: Process for Election of Officers.
Elections will be held once a year for all seven executive board positions, and will occur at the final meeting of the academic year.
Candidates for elected office must give a short speech to the voting members of UMass Rang at said voting meeting.
The voting members of UMass Rang will then complete the election process with a confidential vote (through secret paper ballot, Google Forms, or other anonymous voting methods). A majority vote is needed to secure a position on the Executive Board.
Officers may remain in their respective offices for a maximum of two consecutive years or four consecutive semesters.
Section IV: Position Details.
President.
He/She is to facilitate the announcement and discussion portion at the beginning of each rehearsal.
The President will be responsible for all RSO official business.
The President shall possess signature responsibility for the academic year.
The President is responsible for all financial dealings of the group in partnership with the Treasurer, including annual budget requests.
The President is responsible for managing relations or dealings with the SGA, CSD, and the University Administration.
The President is responsible for the upkeep of the official email account, and contact with other organizations in partnership with the Vice President.
The President will be responsible for keeping up group morale.
The President can and should aid all other positions as necessary.
Vice President.
The Vice President is responsible for assisting the President at any point
The Vice President shall step as President if the President is absent
The Vice President shall be in charge of contact with other organizations on or off campus in partnership with the President.
Secretary.
The Secretary will keep track of attendance at all rehearsals.
The Secretary will serve as the primary note-taker at E-board meetings and at rehearsals, informing the group of any announcements or decisions made.
Treasurer.
The Treasurer will be in charge of all financial dealings of UMass Rang.
The Treasurer keeps track of how much the group spends and what the finances are being used for.
The Treasurer will possess signature responsibility for the academic year.
The Treasurer will relay information regarding funding requirements for concerts/show bookings, mics, sound equipment, etc.
Social Media/Public Relations Manager.
The PR Manager is responsible for publicizing any UMass Rang-related event including auditions and UMass Rang hosted events.
The PR Manager is responsible for the upkeep of the official UMass Rang website, and any other social media platforms in affiliation with UMass Rang.
The PR Manager is responsible for making all arrangements for performances (room reservations, guest groups, etc.)
The PR Manager is responsible for concert decorations as well as providing directions and any other information for away performances.
Music Director.
The Music Director is responsible for facilitating rehearsal time during group meetings.
Any new arrangements that are to be introduced into the group’s repertoire must be approved by the Music Director first, and then the group as a whole.
The Music Director shall keep track of Noteflight or other forms of sheet music required for the group.
The Music Director must put every effort into attending every rehearsal, meeting, and performance involving UMass Rang.
The Music Director serves as a coordinator and advisor for all those members of the group arranging music, and should take an active role in arranging and teaching music himself/herself his/her assigned part.
The Music Director is responsible for the procurement and storage of microphones and other sound system elements.
The Music Director provides a major voice in choosing the set list for performances.
Assistant Music Director.
If necessary, the Music Director can appoint an Assistant Music Director at his/her own discretion. The Assistant Music Director will take on all the responsibilities of the Music Director if he/she is absent.
The Assistant Music Director will work with the Music Director in bettering the musicality and performance aspect of the group.
Section 5: Resignation of an Officer.
At the request of the group, any officer wishing to resign (from either their post as an officer or their membership in Rang) must submit a proper notice of at least two weeks in order to allow the group time to appoint a new officer that could assume the forgone position immediately after the incumbent officer resigns. In the event that an officer unexpectedly resigns, the President and/or Vice President will assume all necessary responsibilities of this position until the group has had sufficient time to nominate and elect a new officer.
	Section 6: Removal of an Officer.
Any executive member of UMass Rang may be removed if they fail to perform any of the duties explicitly listed in Article V, Section IV in this Constitution. 
Any executive member of UMass Rang may be removed from office if he/she has violated any portion of this Constitution.
Charges based on violation of this Constitution and duties of an officer may be addressed by any of the active members of UMass Rang at any time during the course of a semester. 
The claim or charge must be addressed to the entire group and must be justified in a hearing in which the officer in question will be allowed to speak as well. 
The voting body of the group will have a secret ballot vote to remove the officer in question. 
A two-thirds majority is needed to remove an executive, and the executive board member in question may participate in the vote, provided that they have not failed to maintain member privileges.
If an officer position is vacated mid-year or mid-semester, an election will take place following the terms of Article V, Section III, and the newly elected officer will step in for the remainder of the academic year.
If the President resigns or is impeached, the Vice President shall immediately take over as President.
If the Vice President, Treasurer, or Secretary resigns or is impeached, a special election shall be held for that position, following the same procedures as Article V, Section III of this charter.
The remaining members of the Executive Board shall schedule a the special election at a regularly scheduled meeting between 1 and 3 weeks from the date the office become vacant. The Secretary shall inform the general membership of the date of the special election no less than 1 week prior.

Article VIII: Resolving Disputes Among Members.
UMass Rang must address a dispute between any of the active members in a group setting, only in the event that the dispute disrupts normal group activity (performances and rehearsals).
A dispute must formally be brought to the Executive Board of the group if the Executive members are not already aware of the dispute.
The President will record any complaints filed and will facilitate a hearing in a meeting with the rest of the executive board of UMass Rang, in which the dispute will be settled.
The Executive Board members will address both parties involved in the dispute in this hearing.
The parties involved may elect to address the general members of UMass Rang.
The executives will reach a conclusion on the matter that allows for compromise with both parties in agreement and the general active membership will take a simple majority vote to dismiss the issue.
Necessary action will be taken by the Executive Board if it is determined that the behavior of one of the active members involved in a dispute or conflict that compromises the integrity of UMass Rang and its activities. This includes the revoking of voting rights and potential dismissal from the group based on the severity of the issue.

Article IX: Free Speech and Non-Discrimination Clauses
UMass Rang does not and will not, under any circumstances, discriminate on the basis of gender, sex, religion, class, race, or sexual orientation.
The members of UMass Rang reserve the right as individuals to free speech in all group dealings provided that the speech is not threatening or harmful to any other group member or organization affiliated with the University of Massachusetts Amherst.

Article X: Repertoire of Songs
New arrangements will be run by the Music Director. If approved, they will put up to a majority vote by the general body.
Songs that will remain in the current repertoire will be decided upon by all members of UMass Rang. In most cases, many of the songs will be remain in the current setlist for a maximum of three semesters, and then will be retired in order to expand the repertoire and increase exposure to other songs.
The choice to remove a song from a current repertoire before its retirement must be made by a two-thirds majority vote among the group.
Any member of the group may audition for a solo in a song introduced to the repertoire. During these auditions, at least a two-thirds majority vote is required for a soloist to receive the part in a song. This individual may hold the solo until their leave from the group, at which point if the song is still in the current repertoire, another round of auditions may be held to determine a new soloist. Pursuant to UMass Rang’s policy of fairness and overall equality, it will therefore try and make sure that there is an even distribution of solos, such that every member has a chance to have his/her voice heard.

Article XI: Process for Amendment.
Changes in this Constitution must be recorded and acted upon by the President of UMass Rang.
A two thirds majority decision by the members of UMass Rang is required to change this document in any way.
After an amendment is passed, it must be approved by the Secretary of the Registry of the Student Government Association before being enacted by the group.

Article XII: Bylaws.
A two-thirds or simple majority vote of the organization is required to establish, approve, and enforce any proposed by-laws or changes in existing by-laws.

Constitution  

ARTICLE I – Name and Purpose  

 Name The name of this organization shall be the Residence Hall Association of the University

meetings.

 RHA prohibits discrimination based on race, color, national origin, religion, sex, gender

Section 2

 – RHA Executive Board Eligibility,  Elections and Removal/Resignation  

1) RHA Executive Board Eligibility and Removal  

a) Eligibility  

i) To be eligible for any Executive Board position, one must meet the following

(1) Be free of judicial sanction from the Dean of Students Office and/or

Residential Life.  

(2) Must reside in a residence hall while holding the position  
(3) Maintain a minimum cumulative GPA of 2.5  
(4) Not be a member of the NRHH Executive Board  
(5) Not continue to serve as a House Council Executive member, or as an
Area Government Member and may not be a Student Staff Member (ie. Resident
Assistant or Peer Mentor)  

(6) To be eligible for the project manager position on must comply with
of the RHA Bylaws in addition to aforementioned

b) Removal  

3 

​
​
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
​
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
   
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
   
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 University of Massachusetts Amherst, Residence Hall Association 

i) If at any point in the year an officer can no longer meet these requirements, that
position will be vacated and filled by a special election as soon as possible. The RHA
president, or highest-ranking officer may appoint an interim acting officer to take fill the
vacated position.  

(1) An appeals process will be available to any officer who becomes

ineligible under the above Sections  

(2) Any officer charged after the date of their election with judicial
sanction from the Dean of Students Office and/or Residential Life who wishes to
appeal the removal from their position will be placed on suspension.  
ii) Suspended officers will keep their title, pending the result of their appeal, but

will not retain rights to act within their position.  

iii) An officer looking to appeal their ineligibility must file within seven (7) days

of notification that they are ineligible for their position 

iv) The appeal shall be presented to the RHA General Body for a hearing. The
officer may present their case in a five (5) minute speech and the General Body shall
have the right to question the officer regarding the charges and the reasons for appeal.  

(1) Questions will be limited to five (5) minutes. (2) The General Body,
following a five (5) minute discussion, shall vote on the appeal. A two thirds (⅔)
vote in favor will allow the officer to be fully reinstated to their position on the
Executive Board.  
v) The RHA President will preside over these hearings except for their own, in
which case the Vice President will preside.  

c) Impeachments  

i) Executive Board members can be impeached by the General Body after

gaining a petition signed by three-fourths (¾) of the Voting Representatives  

ii) Once a petition is filed, a hearing will be held at the next General Body

meeting and impeachment will occur with a two-thirds (⅔) majority vote. 

iii) The President will preside over these hearings except for their or own, in
which case the Vice President will preside. Any Executive Board member is allowed to
testify on their own behalf  
d) Resignation by Inaction 

i) Any member of the EBoard who misses three consecutive General Body 

meetings shall resign their office due to inactivity.  

ii) Any member of the EBoard shall have the ability to appeal the resignation to 

the General Body by the same procedure outlined above (Section 2b) 

iii) If a member resigns from their post due to inactivity, they may run for the 

open EBoard position again.  

e) EBoard Scholarship Forfeiture 

i) At any time a member of the EBoard is Impeached or removed via Resignation 

by Inaction, they will forfeit all scholarship entitled to them for their time at RHA from 
that current semester.   

4 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 University of Massachusetts Amherst, Residence Hall Association 

ii) If a member of the EBoard resigns not by inactivity, they shall receive half of 
their scholarship if they have been in their position for more than one half of the current 
semester, in which they resigned.  

2) Executive Board Elections  
a) Timeline  

i) Elections for President, Vice President, NCC, PROC, and Project Managers

will be included as a part of the regular General Body Agenda.  

ii) Elections shall take place in the Spring Semester, before inauguration, which
will take place at the Of the Year Awards ("OYAs") organized by the National Residence
Hall Honorary ("NRHH").  

(1) If it is not possible, or not feasible for elections to take place before
the OYA, the RHA E-board may vote to waive the requirement with a simple
majority.  
iii) Election must be completed at least three RHA General Body meetings before

the end of the semester.  
b) Procedure  

i) The President will call for nominations off the floor at the General Body

meeting prior to elections and the meeting at which elections will take place. 

(1) No member of the current EBoard may offer nominations for an
Eboard position regarding the next year, in which the nominations are being
taken. 
ii) For each position, the candidates will be asked to leave the room and by

random selections will be brought into the room one at a time.  
iii) Candidates will present a three (3) minute speech.  

(1) Extendable one (1) time, by up to three (3) minutes.  

iv) Followed by Five (5) minutes of question and answer from the General Body.  

(1) Extendable one (1) time, by up to (5) five minutes  
(2) Each individual may be allowed no more than two (2) questions per

candidate  
v) Once Question and Answer is completed, the candidate will leave the room

and the process repeats with the next candidate  

vi) Discussion will occur once all candidates have presented and has been

completed.  

(1) Discussion will be limited to five (5) minutes to discuss all

candidates.  

(2) Extendable (2) two times, by up to (5) minutes each extension.  
(3) Discussion will cover anything addressed during the presentation,

question and answer session, and person statements about the candidates  

(4) Members of the RHA Executive Board may not bring up points of

discussion.  
vii) When discussion has ended, each Voting Representative will be given ballots

and may vote for a candidate, no confidence, or abstain.  

5 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 University of Massachusetts Amherst, Residence Hall Association 

viii) Candidates for the office being voted on will not be allowed in the room
and, hence, cannot vote, but they may proxy their vote to another Voting Representative.  
ix) In the event that a representative cannot decide, they will submit a vote of

abstain.  

(1) Abstention votes do not count as votes toward the simple majority.  

x) An advisor and the RHA president will count all the ballot votes, unless the
President is a candidate for the position. In that case, the Vice President will assist an
advisor in the counting and so on through the officers according to rank so that no officer
is counting the ballots for which they are a candidate.  

xi) Candidates must obtain a simple majority of the votes in order to be declared

the winner.  

(1) In the event no candidate receives a simple majority, the candidate

with the lowest number of votes will be thrown out. A two  

(2) minute discussion will occur about the remaining candidates, and a

revote will be held. There will be no opportunity for extension.  
xii)The candidates will then be brought into the room and the results announced

by the current President.  

xiii) Any candidate not elected can choose to run for any remaining positions.  
xiv) The President will call for those nominations before beginning the election

process for the next position.  
c) Mid-Year Openings 1  

i) In the case of an Executive Board opening during the year, a special election
will be scheduled as soon as possible, and will follow the Procedure outlined in the
previous section.
