TITLE 2 – House Council  

Section 1

- Purpose  

1. The purpose of a House Council is to administer programming, advocacy, and community development
for a resident hall or cluster.  

Section 2 

- Powers  

1. House Council derives its powers from the Constitution and By-Laws of the Residence Hall
Association.  

Section 3 

- Structure  

1. A House Council shall be comprised of an Executive Board and a Programming Board.  
2. Order of Power  

a. President  
b. Vice President  
c. Treasurer  
d. Secretary  
e. Programming board  

3. House Council is overseen by their respective Area Government. . Every Area Government is

overseen by the Residence Hall Association.  

8 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
​
 
 
 
 
   
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
​
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
​
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
   
 
 
 
 
 University of Massachusetts Amherst, Residence Hall Association 

4. Resident Assistants and Peer Mentors may not serve as members of the House Council’s

Executive Board or Programming Board.  

5. House Councils are advised by their respective Residence Director.  
6. Members of the Programming Board are appointed by their respective House Council

President.  

Section 4 

- Elections and Eligibility  

1) Elections:  

a) Election procedures shall be outlined in the Elections policy book  

2) Eligibility:  

a) Must reside in the cluster they represent while holding the position.  
b) May not be a member of the RHA or NRHH Executive Board.  
c) Not be a Resident Assistant or Peer Mentor  
d) Maintain a MINIMUM cumulative GPA of 2.0.  
e) Be free of judicial sanction from the Dean of Students Office and/or Residential Life.  
f) If at any point in the year an officer no longer meets these requirements, they can no

longer serve as a member of the House Council Executive Board.  

i) If a house council member wishes to appeal their removal on the grounds of
ineligibility they may do so by emailing the RHA executive board vice president to
schedule a meeting with the executive board to present their case.  

ii) If the board determines with a simple majority vote that the removed person is

capable of fulfilling their duties they shall be reinstated.  

iii) The board shall not hear cases whereby a student is removed on the grounds

of 2a-c.  

Section 5 - 

Impeachments:  

1. Executive Board members can be impeached by the Executive Board after gaining a petition

signed by three-fourths (¾) of the Executive and Programming Boards.  

2. Once a petition is filed, a hearing will be held at the next House Council meeting and

impeachment will occur with a two-thirds majority vote.  

3. The President will preside over these hearings except for his/her own, in which case the Vice

President will preside.  

4. Any Executive Board member is allowed to testify on his/her own behalf.  

Section 6 - 

Duties  

1) Executive board  
a) President  

i) Responsible for overseeing House Council projects and initiatives.  
ii) Writes agendas for weekly House Council meetings.  

9 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
​
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
   
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
​
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
​
 
 University of Massachusetts Amherst, Residence Hall Association 

iii) Encourages interaction and discussion among group members by serving as a

leader at House Council meetings.  

iv) Acts as a spokesperson to other campus organizations.  
v) Attends monthly President’s Roundtables.  
vi) Appoints General Members to the Programming Board. 
vii) Shall have signature responsibility in all financial matters.   

b) Vice President  

i) Shares responsibilities negotiated with President.  
ii) Attends weekly RHA meetings and serves as the voting representation for the

cluster.  

iii) Relays information from RHA meetings to their House Council.  
iv) Receives mandatory neutrality training to vote at RHA meetings.  
v) Takes place of President in case of President's absence.  
vi) Serves as spokesperson to community.  

c) Treasurer  

i) Responsible for all money management of the House Council including proper

depositing and record keeping.  

ii) Monitors and advocates for ethical monetary allocation.  
iii) Submits funding requests to RHA.  
iv) Responsible for signing on monetary matters.  
v) Shall have signature responsibility in all financial matters.  

d) Secretary  

i) Primarily responsible for communicating with the cluster community.  
ii) Records and provides minutes to advisor(s) and House Council, and the

Residence Hall Association Executive Board.  

iii) Markets and designs publicity or activity promotions.  
iv) Maintains House Council bulletin board or posting area  

2) Programming Board (non-hierarchical)  

a) Attends periodic meetings led by the House Council Executive Board  
b) Helps plan and organize events for cluster community  
c) Performs tasks and responsibilities for events assigned by the President  
d) Provides amenities to Clusters that improve lifestyle in community  
e) Must attend at least 50% of House council meetings. If attendance threshold is not met, 

the President may remove the member.  

i) 50% attendance is defined by one half of House Council meetings where the 

secretary has recorded attendance.  

TITLE 3 – Area Government 

Section 1 - 

Purpose 

An area government’s purpose shall be to act as an elected student representative body, recognized as a 
subsidiary governmental arm of RHA, charged with the administration of programming, advocacy, and 

10 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
   
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
​
 
 University of Massachusetts Amherst, Residence Hall Association 

oversight of a residential area. The role of area government shall be to exist as the connection between 
House Councils and RHA as well as the greater campus community.  

Section 2 -

 Powers 

Area Governments derive their powers from the Constitution and By-Laws of the Residence Hall 
Association.  

Section 3 -

 Positions  

1) Governor  

a) The Governor (or Highest occupied position) may appoint members of their area to
unfilled executive positions, and may create Ad-Hoc positions as necessary, as well as appoint
members of the area to those positions.  

b) Serves as de facto presiding officer in all Area Government proceedings and may 

create subcommittees. 

c) Meet with the Area Government advisors on a regular basis.  
d) Hold weekly meetings for the Cabinet of the Area Government.  
e) The Governor shall have signature authority for any and all financial matters pertaining 

to Area Government.  
2) Lt. Governor  

a) Serves as the presiding officer in the absence of the governor. May serve as acting 

Governor when there's a vacancy in the Governorship.  

b) Is the main contact person on the Area Government Cabinet for all House Councils in 

the area.  

c) Must attend weekly RHA meetings or send a designee.  
d) Organize area wide meeting with all House Councils in the area at least once per 

semester  
3) Treasurer  

a) Keeps track of all Area Government expenditures and budgetary matters. Responsible 

for creating funding requests. 

b)  If the Area Government has a budget of any kind, weekly budget reports must be 

created outlining expenses and revenues.  

c) They shall have signature authority for any and all financial matters pertaining to Area 

Government.  
 4) Secretary  
5

a) Responsible for recording all minutes for all Area Government cabinet meetings, house 

council meetings when attended, and for any committee lead by the Area Government.  

i) Minutes shall be kept in designated space  

b) Will write up any proposals needed by the Area Government for purposes decided by 

the Area Governor.  

c) Add to the record all communications between Area Government, House Councils, and 

RHA.

d) Shall host a monthly Secretaries Roundtable between all Secretaries or designee in said 
area for the purpose of maintaining communication and cooperation between House Councils and 
Area Governments. 

e) Responsible for collecting transition reports from outgoing members of the Area 

Government and delivering them to the Area Government advisor at the end of their term for 
preceding administrations.  

Section 4

 - Elections  

1) The Area Government Timeline shall follow the RHA house council election timeline, as

determined and organized by the Assistant Director for Leadership and Engagement via Campus Pulse  

2) Nominations form for Governor, Lt. Governor, Treasurer, and Secretary require a minimum of
50 signatures to be submitted to any RSD in a timeline established by the Coordinator for Selection,
Training, and Leadership each year.  

3) Campaigns may not be financed in any way. Marketing and Marketing Materials for Area

Government elections is possible in the following way:  

a) The candidate shall prepare a campaign flyer and; Email the RHA president and
Coordinator for Selection, Training, and Leadership, so that the flyer can be distributed in each
relevant residence Hall (i.e. Residence Halls Within the Relevant Area), so that at least one flyer
is on each RA’s board and that two flyers are present in each relevant building’s lobby. If an RA
or RD does not distribute flyers appropriately this shall not be a failure of duty from the RHA
president or the Coordinator for Selection, Training, and Leadership. Furthermore, the candidate
my request 20 flyers from the RHA president and Coordinator for Selection, Training, and
Leadership which the candidate may distribute in any way which does not violate any other
policy. (e.g. trespassing into a building  

b) If a substantial evidence exists that a candidate has won an election due to improperly
marketing their campaign the RHA president is responsible for bringing forth an Impeachment
case against the candidate. In this case the RHA president is not required to collect signatures of
support to bring an impeachment to the floor. ⅔ of Eboard members must agree to bring
impeachment trial to the floor in this case.  

Section 5

 - Area Government and House Council Interactions  

1) The Role of Area Government is to increase collaboration between house councils and to

program for and represent the relevant Area’s interests.  

a) To fulfill this end the Governor may request meetings with at least one House Council

member from each cluster in the relevant Area, facilitated by the RHA executive board.  
2) Area Governments are required to hold at least one formal meeting with with all house
councils represented by at least one member per semester to discuss area wide issues. RHA has
the ability to enforce this by the freezing of funds. This meeting must take place before the mid
semester date.  
3) Secretaries of Area Governments must hold monthly meetings with all Secretaries of the 

House Councils within the area.

4) Clusters within an Area that do not have a House Council due to failing to elect officials,

house councils’ presidents.

TITLE 4 – General Body Meeting Procedures  

Section 1

 - Meeting Times:  

1) General Body Meetings shall take place on a defined day of week and time weekly where the
University of Massachusetts is in session, to be defined by the RHA governing Board before the first
meeting each semester.  

2) In extenuating circumstance regarding scheduling determined by the executive board, the 

President shall have the ability to move the meeting time to a date not previously outlined at the 
beginning of the semester, with the consent of half of the Executive Board members.  

3) The General Body shall be notified of the change no later than 48 Hours before the cancelled 

or rescheduled meetings initial time.  

Section 2

 - Order:  

General Body meetings will follow a revised version of Robert’s Rules of Order for Parliamentary
Procedure, as used by NACURH Inc.  

Section 3

 - Quorum:  

13 

 
​
 
​
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
​
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
​
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
​
 University of Massachusetts Amherst, Residence Hall Association 

Quorum shall be determined at
the beginning of each meeting based on the number of voting
representatives in the General Body, who are in good standing. Quorum will be defined as two-thirds of
the voting population who are in good standing.  

Section 4

 – Speaking Rights:  

Only House Council Officers, Area Government Officers, and RHA Executive Board Officers
("Officers"), NRHH and SGA representatives, and Relevant Advisors shall have speaking rights, provided
they have received Neutrality Training.  

Section 5

 - Funding  

1) Area Governments shall have their own budget allocated to them by RHA and shall be composed 

of funds from SGA for the sole purpose of Area Government funding.  

2) Specifics of Area funding are shall be outlined in TITLE 5 Section 8 of the RHA Constitution and 

Bylaws. 

Section 6

 - Voting Representation: 

1) Each residence cluster shall be assigned one to three votes based on cluster capacity, defined in

the below schedule.  

2) Voting Schedule:  

a) A capacity of under 400 residents: 1 Vote  
b) A capacity of 400-799 residents: 2 Votes  
c) A capacity of over 799 residents: 3 Votes  

3) Only a House Council Vice-President or his or her designee may vote.  

a) All voting representatives must receive SLSO neutrality training.  
b) Once a voting representative has received neutrality training, their name shall be
recorded in the voting representative registry by the RHA Executive Board Vice President, or his
or her designee.  

Section 7

 - Voting Attendance:  

1) Attendance will be taken at the beginning of each General Body meeting, before any official

business is conducted.  

2) Voting Representatives will be called by first and last name, their title and by the cluster they

represent, ex: Jane Doe, Vice President of James Emerson Cluster.  

a) If a Voting Representative is not in attendance, or does not answer roll call, they shall

be marked as absent.  

Section 8

 - Good and Bad Standing:  

14 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
​
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
​
 
 
​
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
​
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
​
 University of Massachusetts Amherst, Residence Hall Association 

1) Good standing is defined as having voting, discussion, and funding privileges within the

General Body.  

2) Bad standing is defined as having discussion and meeting participation privileges, but not

being permitted to access funding or vote.  

a) Not being permitted to access funding means already allocated funding will be frozen.  
3) If a cluster or Area Government has two unexcused absences in two consecutive General Body

meetings, said cluster shall be placed in bad standing.  

4) To regain good standing, the cluster or Area Government must attend two consecutive RHA

General Body meetings.  

5) The RHA Executive Board Vice President is responsible for notifying clusters or Area

Government of their standing should their standing change.  

6) Each cluster or Area Government begins the semester in good standing.   

TITLE 5 – Financial Policies  

Section 1

 - Funding for RHA  

1) RHA is funded through fundraising initiatives.  
2) Additional money may be provided by Residential Life.  
3) SGA provides money for the exclusive purpose of Area Government funding.  

Section 2

 - Criteria for General Funding Eligibility  

1) RHA will assess funding requests by the following criteria, in no specific order. If any one of
the below criteria is not met, then the author of the request will be denied or asked to revise and resubmit
a new funding request form.  

a) The organization must be a House Council, Area Government, Resident Assistant, Peer
Mentor, Defined Residential Community, a student group working with a Faculty in Residence,
or other Residence Life employed, elected, or otherwise appointed person acting in their official
capacity.  

b) No organization that is not officially affiliated with the University of Massachusetts or 

Residential life may request funding from RHA.  

c) No organization funded separately by SATF or the University of Massachusetts may 
request funding unless partnering with a House Council, Area Government, Resident Assistant, 
Peer Mentor, Defined Residential Community, or working with Residential Life.  

d) The organization must contain at least one current resident of the University of 

Massachusetts Amherst.  

e) The event or activity in which the organization is requesting funding for must involve

residential students.  

f) The organization must provide an estimated number of residential students that will be

involved.  

g) The purpose of the event or activity of requests should primarily be beneficial to the

residential areas and their residents.  

15 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
​
 
 
​
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
   
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 University of Massachusetts Amherst, Residence Hall Association 

h) Requests must include a list of items purchased for an event, or an equivalent (i.e.
travel itinerary for a trip, purchased items, etc.) in order to provide a full breakdown of their
budget for the General Body. 

i) The organization must include a clear amount of funds being requested, as well as a

breakdown of their budget with expected costs.  

j) The organization must present a clear plan of how they will effectively deliver their

services.  

k) Requests and approvals must be based off of neutral, objective criteria, and may not
discriminate on the basis of race, religion, national origin, color, sex, sexual orientation, age,
veteran status, or disability.  

l) Requests must be submitted at least two academic weeks prior to the Funding request

meeting.  

Section 3

 – Submitting a Funding Request:  

1. Funding request must be submitted via Google Forms (the form is made available on the RHA

website.)  

2. All funding requests must meet the RHA financial policies and procedures guidelines for

funding eligibility, outlined in this article (Article 5 of the RHA Bylaws).  

Section 4 - Funding requests exceeding 501.00 USD.  

1) Upon receiving the Funding request, the RHA executive board will schedule the group

requesting funds to present the submitted request to the General body, the procedure is as follows:  

a) The group may present the submitted request and supporting documents (such as, but

not limited to, a PowerPoint and cost estimates) to the RHA general body.  

i) The presentation time is five (5) minutes, extendable once, by five (5) minutes.  
b) The General Body will pose questions for five (5) minutes, extendable once, by five

(5) minutes.  

i) At the discretion of the Presiding Officer and with the consent of ⅔ of the
General Body, the question period may be ended earlier after there has been at least 3 questions
or 2.5 minutes passed.  

c) The General body will enter a period of discussion for five (5) minutes, extendable

once, by five (5) minutes.  

i) At the discretion of the Presiding Officer and with consent of ⅔ of the General

Body, the discussion period may be ended earlier after a time of 2.5 minutes has passed.  
2) The General Body reserves the right to alter the amount of the funding request, upon

submission of an amendment to the main motion, by a General Body member.  

3) The funding request will be approved upon the General Body reaching a majority consensus in

favor of allocation.  

Section 5 

- Funding requests under 501.00 USD.  

1) Upon receiving the Funding request with a value of under 501.00 USD, the RHA Executive

Board adhere to the following procedure:  

16 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
​
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
   
 
 
 
 
​
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 University of Massachusetts Amherst, Residence Hall Association 

a) The group will be scheduled to present to the RHA Executive Board, at the next

possible time.  

i) This shall not override any existing RHA commitments (such as, but not

limited to: another funding request.)  
b) The group may present the submitted request and supporting documents (such as, but

not limited to, a PowerPoint and cost estimates) to the RHA Executive Board.  
i) The presentation time is ten (10) minutes.  

c) The executive board may pose questions at anytime, however, as soon as a question is
posed the presentation timer will be stopped, so that time spent asking and answering questions is
not counted against the presentation time.  

d) The RHA Executive Board will vote on the allocation of funds at the meeting in which

the request it is presented.  

i) This vote requires a vote of ⅔ majority in order to allocate funds.  

e) If a group submits a funding request for less than $501.00 USD and is denied allocation of 
funds by the EBoard, they may appeal it to the General body for consideration.  

i) All procedures outlines in TITLE 5 Section 4 shall be followed for this request in 

addition to any other provisions outlined in the RHA Constitution or Bylaws.  

ii) All appeals to the General Body must be held no at the following meeting from when 

the funding request was initially denied.  

iii) A ⅔ majority of the General Body is required to overturn the EBoards denial and 

accept the appeal.  

iv) A member of the EBoard must deliver a statement as to the EBoards rationel as to 

why the funding request was denied to the general body before the question period.  

v) A member of the group must deliver a statement as to the reason for the appeal to the 

general body before question period.  

vi) Only House Councils or Area Governments may appeal the ruling of the EBoard to 

the General Body.  

viii) All General Body decisions pertaining to the appeal of a funding request are final.  

Section 6 

- Funding Restrictions and Procedures  

1) In funding any organization, RHA shall expressly prohibit the use of funds for any activities

prohibited by federal or state law.  

a) Funded organizations will be required by RHA to clarify that funds will not be used in

a manner that violates state or federal law.  
2) RHA prohibits the use of funds for activities that may violate any University policies. House

councils and Area Government in 'bad standing' are prohibited from applying for funds  

3) Please see Article II, Section 3 of the RHA Constitution for more details.  
4) RHA will not provide funding for any programs used to endorse political candidates or
political campaign contributions for, including, but not limited to, Area Government, SGA, municipal,
state, or federal elections.  

17 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
   
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
​
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 University of Massachusetts Amherst, Residence Hall Association 

5) No organization shall receive more than $100 per student participating and/or attending per
single program, with the exception of a student requiring long-distance travel, in which case the RHA
General Body may vote to provide excess of $100 by a ⅔ majority.  

6) RHA can co-sponsor programs with SGA. The organization requesting funding is responsible
for notifying RHA of funding coming from other sources, including fundraising, requests to the SGA,
RSO budgets, house councils, and other means.  

7) Funding requests will open on the day of the first meeting in the fall, and will close 2 weeks

before the first day of elections in the spring semester.  

8) Upon approval of funding the student organization agrees to accept any additional restrictions

that RHA has put in place, including, but not limited to the following:  

a) Events that are funded by RHA must clearly state on all advertising and promotional
items that their program is made possible in part by the Residence Hall Association, and/or
include the RHA key logo.  

b) Every organization that receives funding from RHA will submit a Post-Program
Evaluation Form, through the RHA Campus Pulse page, Google Docs, via email, or with a
printed copy submitted to the RHA Executive Board. Forms must be submitted no later than two
weeks after the funded program occurred.  

i) In the event that the funded program was a conference, the organization’s
members that attended such conference must present their experience to the General
Body.  

ii) For any other organizations that received funding from RHA for a program,
the Treasurer will announce the results of the program to the General Body based off
information provided in the Post-Program Evaluation Form.  
c) All unused funds provided by RHA to an organization will be returned to RHA within

a reasonable time, but no later than 30 days.  

d) Any organization that received funding and fails to submit either the Post-Program
Evaluation Form within the allotted time will be ineligible for any future funding University of
Massachusetts Amherst, Residence Hall Association 15 requests until the form(s) is submitted, or
until the end of the academic year, whichever is later.  
9) RHA reserves right to limit or deny requests if any of the above restrictions and/or criteria are

not met, and may deny future funding of such organization.  

Section 7

 – Further Financial Policies and Procedures  

Further policies and procedures are outlined in the Financial Policies and Procedures document, are made
available in the Financial Policies and Procedures document on the UMass RHA website.  

Section 8: Area Government Funding  

1) Area Government shall receive funding from SGA, directed through RHA, with the sole purpose 

of funding Area Government.  

2) Area Government shall have full discretion over said funding and budgets unless otherwise 

outlined in the RHA constitution and Bylaws.  

18 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
​
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 University of Massachusetts Amherst, Residence Hall Association 

a) Area Governments shall not use any monies for purposes that violate, federal law, state 

law, local law, university policies, SGA constitution and bylaws, and the RHA 
Constitution and Bylaws.  

3) Funding Breakdown 

a) Each of the 4 Area governments will receive 12.5% of the funding allocated to RHA by 

SGA for Area Government irrespective of student population.  

b) The additional 50% of funding not allocated in TITLE 5, Section 8.3a will be allocated to 
Ex: If 
Area Governments as a percentage of the Campus population that lives in that area. 
30% of the Resident Population lives in NESAG, NESAG shall receive 30% of the funding 
not used in each of the Area Governments initial 12.5% allocation.  

i)

Population will be defined as the number of residents living in that area at the 
beginning of that academic year.  

c) Area Government funding may be frozen if in bad standing (see TITLE 4 Section 7).  
d) Area Governments are eligible to apply for funding requests through the RHA Eboard 

and General body in addition to receiving a budget.  

19

DocsList.Data:
This informational handout is to explain to persons participating in Women’s Rugby at the University of Massachusetts what is expected of them and what they should expect from the team:

What the School Provides:

We are a recognized RSO (registered student organization) at UMass and come under the jurisdiction of Club Sports. We receive financial support from UMass, which accounts for a portion of our budget. The balance of our budget comes from Club dues and team sponsored fundraisers.
The school provides use of fields for practice and games which are located off of Stadium Road, next McGuirk Stadium. These fields are under the jurisdiction of the Athletic Department and cannot be used without the express permission of Mr. Dan Markowski, the Associate Athletic Director.
The school, club, and club officials DO NOT assume responsibility for any injuries which may occur, and they DO NOT provide additional insurance to any participant. All club members must provide proof of insurance to participate. In addition, we request you provide us with an emergency contact, and advise your parents/guardian that you have joined the club.

What the Team Provides:

	Rugby is a physical, contact sport which requires a certain level of athleticism and fitness. The team has organized practices Monday through Friday in the afternoons and/or evenings during the season and specified times during preseason. The purpose of these practices is to teach players game skills, condition players for rugby and to learn the team game plan. Games are traditionally held on Saturdays, but may vary according to our schedule.
	The team provides game jerseys for the players and will have rudimentary medical supplies available such as tape, water, and ice for games. If a player has specific needs to participate, such as braces or orthopedic appliances it is her responsibility to obtain those and confirm that they meet all rule requirements. In addition, players are expected to purchase a pair of game shorts and team socks which are required on the playing field. 
	The team is managed through elected officers. The officers are: President- Corinne Herlihy , Vice President- Loan Vuong, Treasurer- Gabby Moriello, Match Secretary- Molly Farber, Social Secretary- Christine McHugh, Fundraising Coordinator- Lindsey Stanton, and Public Relations- Shannon Kelly who run the administration of the club. The captains Shelby Vance (forwards) and Kayla Hourihan (backs) and are in charge during game situations.
	The officers hire the coaches who oversee practice, game plans, and selections. The current coaches for fall 2014 are Amy Cheesman (978) 870-6725 and Emily Stone (978) 886-2769.
	A large part of being on a rugby team is the social aspect. You will make friendships that will last well beyond your college years. The team holds a number of social events during the year such as team banquets and we frequently will host a visiting team after the game for a social. Both UMass and US Rugby prohibit the consumption of alcoholic beverages at any college venue and we ask that the players respect this rule.

Team Affiliations:

	We currently play in Division I in the New Enlgand Rugby Union (NERFU) which is known as our Local Area Union (LAU). NERFU is part of the Northeast Rugby Union (NRU), which is one of the seven territories which compromise the US Rugby Union (USARFU). Part of the dues paid to the club by the players goes to these organizations. Each player must be enrolled in CIPP with USARFU in order to play in an A-side game. This also provides additional insurance coverage to a player.
	The UMass Women’s Team has had a great success in league play in the last 12 years which also winning 4 NERFU Championships in six of the last twelve years. During the past twelve years we have placed numerous player on all star teams, including eight on the National Under 23 Team and we have produced fourteen All Americans.

What is Expected of the Players:

There is a club participation fee of $60.00 per season. Players need to pay this or make arrangements with the Treasurer (Gabby) prior to the first game. 
Players must commit to attending practices and being available for all games
We understand that academics should be everyone’s highest priority and players are excused from practice for school related activities such as classes, labs, and qualification exams
Some players need to hold jobs while in school and may miss practice for this reason. We ask players try to arrange their schedules so as not to conflict with practice and that the payers give a copy of their schedule to the team each season. 
If a player cannot attend at least 3 of the 5 practice in a week she must speak to the Captains and Coach to determine if she is eligible to play (for returning players).
If a player must miss a practice she is not excused from she must contact the Captains and/or Coach and inform them. 
Players must inform the Coaches if they have any conflicts during the season whereby they may miss a game 2 weeks prior to game so arrangements can be made. 
Players are expected to participate in all pre-season workouts which includes the week prior to classes in the Fall Semester and indoors in the evening during February and March in the Spring Semester. 
The team will also have arrangements for Spring Break in order to prepare for the season. Attendance is mandatory.
Selection for the A-side are based on Ability, Attitude, and Attendance. The Coaches and Captains choose the players for A and B side. If the player is unhappy about her selection she should speak to the Coaches and Captains.
Players are expected to remain at the fields supporting the team until all games are concluded. We encourage players to invite friends and family to the games, but please make sure they are aware of your commitment. Also, please advise them that the consumption of any alcoholic drinks are prohibited at the fields under both UMass and US Rugby policy.

Mission Statement:

	The UMass Women’s Rugby Team is a dedicated group of women competing against nationally recognized teams. We’ve been invited to national tournaments as both a sevens and fifteens team across New England. We also host opposing teams to come play games on our campus. We play intercollegiate games in Massachusetts and in all surrounding states. Our games are played in both spring and fall semesters.  At our core, we are women finding a community to belong in UMass. In this sense, this club gives us a place in UMass’ large campus as we give back to the UMass community as well.
 
Alcohol Policy:

	Players are expected to train and to be in game condition throughout the season. Players are expected to refrain from using alcohol after Thursday night through Saturday during the season and for the entire week prior to Championships. We request that players voluntarily extend this restriction through Wednesday evenings so as to have removed the alcohol form their system by game day. Any player violating this policy or found using illegal substances will be suspended from playing until the Captains and Coaches can meet with the player to determine the appropriate remedy. Pursuant to both University policy and Massachusetts State Law, it is unlawful for any person under the age of 21. No player on the team should be providing alcoholic beverages to any underage person.

Hazing Policy:
	Massachusetts State Law prohibits hazing and makes it a criminal offense. If a player feels she has been subjected to hazing or if she has witnessed an act which she believes to be hazing it should immediately be reported to the coaching staff. The player’s name filing the report will remain confidential. It is important to note that consent is not a defense to hazing and does not excuse the action.

Section 2. 

Any team member may nominate themselves for a position. 

Section 3. 

Officers will be elected to positions by the date designated by the Club Sports 
Council, which occurs early in the spring semester. 

Section 4. 

All officers will serve one-year terms, and are eligible for re-election. New 
officers shall communicate with the previous holder of their position as soon as 
they are elected, for a smooth transfer of responsibility. Voting for the next Fiscal 
Year’s officers happens in the beginning of the spring semester to allow plenty of 
time for current position holders to train their successors. Positions officially 
begin and end at the termination of each Spring semester. 

Section 5. 

Candidates are elected through a majority vote, in the method dictated by the Club 
Sports Council. If a candidate for a certain position does not win, they may run 
for a different office. 

Section 6. 

“Chair” positions entail all rights and responsibilities of any regular officer, with 
the exception of not having an official vote on executive matters. These positions 
may be created to fulfil changing team needs which require extra leadership.

and executed with a ⅔ majority team consensus (excluding the officer in 
question) in favor thereof. The officer in question will then be asked to withdraw 
from their respective position. This officer has the opportunity to present a case in 
their favor to the team at large prior to the vote. 

Should any officer wish to resign, they may do so by notifying the rest of the 
Executive Board and setting a date for when their term will end. The open 
position is then offered to the rest of the team or any existing Executive Board 
members. The new candidates are then elected by a majority vote in the method 
dictated by the Club Sports Council. 

Article IX.  Coaching Staff. 

Section 1. 

A coaching staff is not required for the operation of the team. However, in the 
event that the team would like to hire a coach, they may do so. It is at the 
discretion of the current team and Executive Board as to how they would like to 
seek out eligible candidates. 

Section 2. 

A coaching position for the team is a paid position. A coach’s income is to be 
determined by the current Executive Board, in discussion with the University. 

Section 2. 

The duties of a coach for the team are, at the basic level, to provide instruction 
and advice on strategy and tactics. Given the environment of Arcadia Lake, 
on-water practices may not always be effective, and thus a coach is encouraged to 
hold land practices if necessary. A coach is also not required to travel to events 
and regattas with the team. However, a coach may certainly choose to be involved 
beyond their paid duties. 

Section 3. 

A candidate for a coach will be interviewed in front of the full Executive Board 
before a decision is made. 

Section 4. 

A coach may choose to suggest one or more candidates for the Captain or 
Co-Captain positions. In the event that a coach is not present, or the coach 
chooses not to suggest a candidate, then team members can nominate themselves 
as per the policy in Article VIII. 

Section 5. 

A coach is a team leader and is welcomed to make recommendations, as well as 
contribute to the life and longevity of the team. However, as the team is a 

10 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Registered Student Organization, and a student-run team within NEISA, all 
official proceedings are at the discretion of the student governing body of the 
team, the Executive Board. 

Article X. 

Equipment. 

Section 1.

Any and all equipment owned, leased, rented, or borrowed by the team or for 
which the team is responsible may not be used by non-members. Exceptions to 
this rule are as follows: 
(i) 

Official events sanctioned by the team for the purposes of raising 
awareness of the team. 
(a) 

To qualify for an exception, the event must be brought before and 
approved by the executive board no later than a week before it is 
scheduled to occur. The event must also be properly promoted to 
reach as many students as possible. 
The event must be properly organized, with basic safety and boat 
care addressed. 
For the use of the equipment and possible damage or wear, each 
non-member will be charged $20 per day. 

Non-members wishing to join the team. 
(a) 

Any non-member wishing to join the team may attend one 
practice. 
They will be taught basic safety and boat care. 
For the use of the equipment and possible damage or wear, they 
will be charged $20, which will be deducted from their fees should 
they decide to join the team. 

(ii) 

(iii) 

Lending equipment. 
(a) 

The team may lend equipment to non-members at the discretion of 
the executive board. 
The party borrowing the equipment will sign a waiver 
indemnifying the University of Massachusetts Amherst Club 
Sailing Team and its members against any injury or death resulting 
from the use of the borrowed equipment. 
The party borrowing the equipment will be responsible for any 
loss, theft, or damage. 
For the use of the equipment, they will be charged not less than $5 
per day. The only exception to this fee will be organizations from 
which the team borrows equipment. 

(b) 

(c) 

(b) 
(c) 

(b) 

(c) 

(d) 

11 

 
 
 
 
 Section 2. 

, and subsequently signed 

All team equipment must be signed out before use
back in when returned. All gear is labeled and numbered. As such, it is expected 
that a team member who borrows gear will return the exact same gear. If gear is 
lost or damaged beyond repair, the borrower is responsible for paying the full 
price of said gear. Gear may be signed out by a team member for the duration of a 
semester for convenience, but in the event that there is a shortage of certain gear, 
this may not be allowed. 

Section 3. 

The Co-Captain holds jurisdiction over the use and organization of all gear. 

Section 4. 

For any use of equipment owned, leased, rented, or borrowed by the team or for 
which the team is responsible, except in the case of equipment being lent, at least 
two current members must be present. 

Section 5. 

Any unauthorized use of the equipment owned, leased, rented, or borrowed by the 
team or for which the team is responsible will be considered grounds for 
immediate removal from the team, at the discretion of the Executive Board. If 
loss, theft, or damage occurs during the unauthorized use, the member(s) and 
non-member(s) found responsible for the unauthorized use will be responsible for 
the cost to replace the equipment. 

Article XI.  Finances. 

Section 1. 

Section 2. 

Each team member is responsible to pay $80 in dues per semester, congruent with 
Article III Section 4. This price may be amended at any time per the regular 
amendment policy, outlined in Article XII. Dues are collected to benefit the team 
by being used to support expenses such as gear/boat maintenance and apparel. 

Any and all purchases made from team funds must first be discussed among the 
Executive Board. Upon consensus over the purchase in question, the Treasurer or 
President must then submit a Purchase Request accordingly. Per University 
policy, the team may only make purchases through the Purchase Request system. 

Section 3. 

Expenditures quoted at over $1,000 should be brought to the attention of the team 
at large before a Purchase Request is submitted. 

Article XII. Amendments. 

12 

 
​
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Section 1. 

Amendments to this constitution must be submitted in writing to the President. 
Arguments for and against these amendments will be made at a meeting organized 
by the Executive Board members. If the Executive Board agrees with the 
sentiment of the amendment, it will be passed along to the team for review. In 
order for an amendment to be approved, ⅔ of the team members must vote to 
instate the amendment. 

Section 2. 

Executive board votes must be a majority vote. In the event of a tie, a re-vote may 
occur at a later time. 

13
