ARTICLE VIII – PARLIAMENTARY AUTHORITY** 
The rules contained in the tenth edition of Robert’s Rules of Order Newly Revised shall 
govern this section in all cases to which they are applicable and in which they are not 
inconsistent with these bylaws and any special rules of order the section may adopt. 

ARTICLE IX  –  AMENDMENT** 
A.  These bylaws may be amended by a two-thirds vote of the members present and 

voting at a meeting or of the ballots received prior to the stated deadline.   

B.  Amendments may be proposed by a majority of the executive council or five voting 
members of the section.  All proposed amendments must be submitted to the 
secretary. 

C.  Written notice, delivered either by mail or electronically, must be given to all 

members of the section at least fifteen days prior to the date of the meeting or the 
specified date for voting to be completed. 

D.  Amendments adopted by the section shall be sent to the Society secretary according 
to established procedures, and shall become effective after approved by the Society 
secretary. 

E.  Sections marked with a double asterisk (**) are identical to the collegiate section 

bylaws template approved by the Society board of directors on November 13, 2006 
Changes to these sections of the collegiate section bylaws template shall become 
part of these bylaws upon approval of the Society. The section secretary shall 
incorporate such changes into the section bylaws and forward the updated bylaws to 
the Society secretary within six months of notification of the change to the section 
bylaws template.

DocsList.Name: UMass Amherst Club Softball Consitution and Bylaws Spring 2019.docx
DocsList.Data:
Constitution and Bylaws of University of Massachusetts Club Softball

Article I - Name of Organization 
The name of the organization is the University of Massachusetts Club Softball.

Article II - Mission Statement
The mission of the University of Massachusetts Amherst Club Softball team is to provide a fair and equal opportunity for any current UMass student to play competitive intercollegiate softball as a part of the National Club Softball Association, allowing students to obtain their education while staying active and involved in sports. The team provides students with another competitive option if they do not make the Division 1 team or if they want to play in addition to, or instead of, intramural sports. Our team strives to build teamwork skills, networks, and support systems within the campus community, all while having fun as we further our academic endeavors at the University.   

Article III - Membership
To become a member of the UMass Club Softball team, we hold open tryouts every fall, 
which are advertised on our social media accounts, Campus Pulse page, and at the Fall Activities Expo. These tryouts are open to all UMass students. Members must tryout for the team and then be chosen to fill a roster spot based off the skills they demonstrate. All members must be currently enrolled at the University of Massachusetts and have paid their Student Activities Fee. Once students are chosen to be a part of the team, each member must pay dues of $100.00 and complete a minimum of 2 hours of community service each semester. All financial obligations are shared equally amongst members and if any member cannot pay their dues, they will be required to fundraise or put on a payment plan. All members will receive equal playing time each tournament at their desired field position(s) (1.5 games) unless they miss two or more practices a week. There will be no discrimination based on race, religion, color, sexual orientation, national origin, age, political affiliation, or handicap in the activities, programs, and operations of the club or in the selection of members. 

Article IV - Meetings  
Once tryouts are completed and the members of the team are established, the team regularly meets three times a week during the season. These meetings act as team practices, where we practice all of the skills required to be a successful softball team, including offensive and defensive work. Meeting times are decided upon by the team captains, and if a team member cannot attend, it is expected they let a team captain know. All members must attend at least two practices a week during the season to receive equal playing time in tournaments unless there are excused circumstances determined by the team captains. In addition to team practices, meetings will also occur when our team competes in games throughout the year, there are at most six tournaments per school year. 

Article V - Executive Board 
The Executive Board is composed of a President, Vice President, Treasurer, and Secretary. Team members who hold these positions are determined by a team vote at the end of the fall semester each year. The Executive Board will meet once a week in addition to regular team meetings to ensure that the logistics behind the team are in order. These logistics include organizing team activities, budget collaboration, attending council meetings, annually updating the team handbook, and other essential tasks. In addition to these general responsibilities, each Executive Board member has specific duties, which are as follows: 
President:
Monitor team email account and contact with outside parties including but not limited to: other teams, Club Sports Council, Advisor, Umpires, field representative, alumni
Scheduling of tournaments
Schedule weekly E-Board meetings, write meeting notes beforehand each week
Umpire contracts
Weekly game submission form to NCSA during the season
Complete Financial Training to earn signature responsibility
Complete Travel Training
Manage alumni database
Organize E-Board and Team Captain voting
Annually review and re-submit this constitution
Annually review and re-submit the Club Softball Bible
Ensure all Executive Board members complete their respective duties
Vice President:
Determine safety officers
Emergency Action Plan for team trips
After Action Form for team trips
Organize lunch plan for away tournaments
Organize team apparel orders
Complete Event Management Training
Complete Student Organizational Training
Treasurer:
Maintain team funds through Summit access and SORC
Collect and deposit dues
Travel forms
Travel rosters
SASP Requests
Purchase lunch for home tournaments and pasta dinners (from SASP Requests)
Purchase request for annual league dues
Annual budget request
Complete Financial Training to earn signature responsibility
Complete Travel Training
Secretary:
Maintain team accounts (Facebook, Instagram, Campus Pulse, Team App, etc.) with frequent updates and posts
Ensure all members are on Campus Pulse, Team App, and NCSA website
Ensure all members sign necessary University and NCSA league paperwork (liability waivers, academic eligibility, etc.)
Create poster and table for Fall Student Activities Expo
Act as social chair, contact other student clubs and groups for social events
Organize community service opportunities
Organize club fundraising opportunities
Complete Event Management Training
Complete Student Organizational Training

Article VI - Team Captains
Alongside the Executive Board, there are also two team captains leading the team. These captains are chosen by a team vote, and they are in charge of the sport-specific logistics of the team. In the absence of a coach, the team captains will have more responsibilities. These responsibilities include:
Communication with the team in regards to scheduling of practices, games, and team events
Organizing and running tryouts and selecting new team members
Scheduling and running 3 practices a week when in-season and 1 practice a week during off-season based on preferences of team
Scheduling and hosting team pasta dinners
Creating and organizing line-ups for all tournaments
Organizing and running game warm-ups 
Coaching bases
Completing the scorebook during games  
Assisting Executive Board members if necessary 

Article VII - Coach/Manager
	In the event that the club votes on having a coach, the club coach can be a UMass faculty
member, undergraduate, or graduate student, or if there are no qualified applicants in these categories, an outside third-party can fill the position. The position for a coach will be posted on University job boards as well as reaching out to the Amherst community. As long as funding is provided, the club coach will be paid $500.00 a semester, $1,000.000 for the year. If there is no funding, it will be a volunteer position. The coach will be selected based on experience and knowledge of softball as well as cohesion with club members. Final selection will be determined through voting from club members. The duties of the coach include but are not limited to: meeting all requirements of club sports coaches, creating practice schedules and game line ups with team captain approval, run all practices, attend and manage all games including organizing warmups and coaching bases, provide proper supervision, set goals that are attainable, realistic, and challenging, encourage talk with the team about how performance can be improved during practices and games, and encourage team building and cohesion. 

Article VIII - Funds
All members of the team are required to pay dues. The value of the dues is established by the executive board each year, with the current amount being $100.00. These dues must be paid before the team’s first tournament. The team will be involved in various fundraising activities throughout the fiscal year. In addition to team revenue funds, the team will submit a budget for each fiscal year requesting money from the Student Activities Fees of the University. These funds will go towards team travel for conference games, league dues to the National Club Softball Association, umpire pay, field usage, new team equipment when necessary, and other qualified expenses.

Article IX - Affiliations/Rules 
The club will abide by the National Club Softball Association (NCSA) rules and regulations. 

Article X - Advisor
	The club advisor will be provided by the University. They will be responsible for but 
not limited to periodic checks with the RSO to ensure club officers are performing their duties, reviewing the club’s annual budget and all expenditures, reviewing all travel plans, assisting members and officers with organizational matters and club development, and abiding by University and Club Sports rules and regulations.

Article XI - Amendments
	Amendments to this constitution will be drafted by the executive board and presented to
the club members to review. All concerns, questions, and comments with the constitution will be discussed amongst the executive board and club members. 

Article XII - Ratification
	All members of the club will receive a copy of the constitution for review and a meeting
will be held to discuss any problems or concerns. A majority team vote and approval by the Student Government Association via Secretary of Registry must be obtained.

Article XIII - Statement of Free Speech and Non-Discrimination
All members of the University of Massachusetts Club Softball team are entitled to freedom of speech and will not under any circumstances be deprived of the opportunity to share their opinion with the group.

The University of Massachusetts Club Softball team prohibits discrimination on the basis of race, color, religion, creed, sex, age, marital status, national origin, mental or physical disability, political belief or affiliation, veteran status, sexual orientation, gender identity and expression, genetic information and any other class of individuals protected from discrimination under state or federal law in any aspect of access to or membership to the organization.

The University of Massachusetts Club Softball team prohibits harassment of members, i.e., racial harassment, sexual harassment, and retaliation for filing complaints of discrimination.

Members who violate these policies shall be subject to expulsion from the RSO.

DocsList.Name: HOW TO PEACEFULLY COEXIST WITH YOUR FRATERNITY AND SORORIT..pdf
DocsList.Data:
HOW TO PEACEFULLY COEXIST WITH YOUR FRATERNITY AND 
SORORITY NEIGHBORS 

1.  Introduce yourself to the chapter president(s).  Ask for a phone number for contact 
purposes.  Offer your phone number and/or email address.  Share with the president 
any important concerns: number of children in family, neighbors with special needs, 
and other considerations. 

2.  Introduce yourself and your family to as many of the students as possible.  Repeat 
your name several times so that the students will learn it (and do you want them to 
call you Mr./Mrs. or Ward/June?). 

3.  Learn as many names of the students as possible.  Engage them in brief conversations 

when possible.  Ask them questions.  Share with them information about the 
neighborhood. 

4.  Organize a neighborhood meeting and invite members of the fraternities/sororities to 

participate. 

5.  Organize a neighborhood activity and invite the student residents to participate. 

6.  If you are extended an invitation to attend a function at the fraternity/sorority house, 

make the effort to attend. 

7.  If you have children, let the fraternity/sorority know what your expectations are about 

interactions and activities.  Some fraternity and sorority members are seeking 
interaction with children because of their majors and career aspirations. Some 
members are seeking interaction with children because they like them.  Let the 
members know what is appropriate and inappropriate. 

8.  If you are planning an activity that might be intrusive to the neighborhood (increased 
level of noise, foot traffic, automobiles and parking concerns, etc.), please inform all 
the neighbors at least a week before the event.  Discuss any concerns and reasonable 
alternatives. 

9.  If you have concerns about a function or activity at the fraternity house, take the 

concern directly to the chapter president or a chapter officer.  Discuss your concerns 
with them and give them an opportunity to remedy the situation before asking a third 
party to intervene. 

10. Take advantage of opportunities to be pro-active with your neighbors.  Discuss 

concerns before they happen.  Make the students fell welcomed.  Be a role model for 
the students by modeling the behaviors of a good neighbor. 

11. Repeat these efforts each year, as the fraternity/sorority membership and leadership 

changes each year.   

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 HOW TO PEACEFULLY COEXIST WITH YOUR AMHERST NEIGHBORS 

1.  The chapter president and/or other officers should introduce themselves to the 

neighbors.  Provide each household with information about the chapter: a contact 
number and/or email address; a list with names of officers; name and number of 
chapter advisor. 

2.  Encourage your members to meet as many of the neighbors as possible.  Repeat your 
name several times so that the neighbors will learn it.  Engage the neighbors in brief 
conversations.  Ask them questions about the neighborhood and the families. 

3.  As you meet your neighbors, determine if they have any special needs that could be 

met by a member of the chapter.  (Examples – assistance with grocery shopping, leaf 
raking, removal of snow, yard maintenance, etc.). 

4.  Host an open house and invite area neighbors to visit and tour the chapter facility.  
Have a brief meeting and discuss mutual concerns.  Offer your facility or yard for a 
neighborhood function. 

5.  If you are extended an invitation to attend a function at a neighbor’s house, make the 

effort to attend. 

6.  Meet and know the children in the neighborhood.  Drive safely and park in only 
designated areas.  With the permission and assistance of the parents, organize an 
activity/event for the neighborhood children. The membership should discuss what 
are appropriate and inappropriate behaviors for them when in the presence of 
children.  The use/abuse of alcohol should never take place in the presence of 
children or minors. 

7.  If you are planning an activity that might be intrusive to the neighborhood (increased 
level of noise, foot traffic, automobiles and parking concerns, increased trash, etc.), 
please inform the neighbors at least a week before the event.  Give the neighbors an 
opportunity to voice their concerns and discuss any reasonable alternatives. 

8.  If you have concerns about a function or activity at a neighbor’s house, take the 

concern directly to the neighbor.  Discuss your concerns with the neighbor and give 
them an opportunity to remedy the situation before asking a third party to intervene. 

9.  Take advantage of the opportunities to be pro-active with the neighbors.  Discuss 

concerns before they happen.  Make the neighbors feel valued.  Be a role model for 
the neighbors by modeling the behaviors of a good fraternity/sorority member. 

10. Maintain a good relationship with the Amherst Police through the community 

policing effort. 

11. Maintain regular trash collection and maintenance of the property/yard.

DocsList.Name: New_Soul_TV_Constitution (1).docx
DocsList.Data:
University of Massachusetts - Amherst Registered Student Organization: Constitution of the Organization Soul TV  
Article I- Name 
	The name of this organization is Soul TV 
Article II - Mission Statement
	The purpose of this organization is to fulfill the interests of UMass students interested in all forms of creative activity as well as other outlets of entertainment which can include but are not limited to TV, Print, Radio, Music, Art, Fashion and Design. The organization’s objectives are to put on a series of events and productions that tie into the organization’s purpose and highlight student creatives and performers. To encourage, engage, and inspire all students to artistically express themselves by providing a platform to do so. 
	Throughout the next five years, Soul TV hopes to continue to provide a platform for students in the five-college area to share their talents and hard work. To do this, we will involve more general body members. We strive to do this through continuing to expand our existing programming which currently offers students the chance to become involved with or showcase their dancing, designing, modeling and much more. We also plan on creating different ways for people to get involved. Going forward, we want to give more opportunities to the musicians in the area by holding competitions where the winner would be decided by our general body. It creates a sense of investment in the organization for general body members, while allowing for a different way to get involved for those who do not want to be front and center. Regardless of who wins, these competitions give artists an opportunity to promote and practice their craft and network with other artist on campus. For those who are more interested in working behind the scenes, we plan on training general body members on becoming stagehands that can help in running some of our bigger events. This again creates a sense of investment, fosters community, and ensures we have a way for anyone to get involved. This is also a great way to start to develop potential future leaders within the RSO ensuring that we don’t have a high turnover rate in the Eboard which leads to a more stable and sustainable organization.
Article III – General Body Membership
	Soul TV shall be open to any UMass or five-college student with interest in the objectives and mission statement of the organization.  Members are generally interested in the execution of the goals and outreach and of the organization. Attendance of at least two general body meetings is required in order to be a member. All members are allowed to vote on matters concerning the organization but only UMass students can join the Eboard.  
Article IV - Executive Board Officers 
	The executive board of Soul TV consists of a President, a Vice President, a Treasurer, an Event Coordinator, a Public Relations officer, a RSO Liaison and a Creative Outreach Coordinator. Below are the roles and duties they are responsible for:
President - Responsible for the organizational activities which include: coordinating executive board meetings, council meetings, communication with RSO Advisor, distribution of all written documents to council members in the case of no event coordinator, and maintenance of any documents pertaining to organization and its affairs. Work to ensure that the lines of communication stay open between the entirety of the executive board via all forms of communication including emails, meetings etc. Holds Signature Responsibility and Event Coordinating Training.    
Vice President - Responsible for coordinating general body meetings and general body committees. Assists the President or fill in when they are absent or unable to fulfill their duties. Takes minutes at Eboard meetings and handles general body meetings/committees. Responsible for communication with the general body (esp through email).Holds Signature Responsibility and Event Coordinating Training. 
Treasurer - Handle any monetary transactions and  responsible for all financial documents. Their duties include maintaining financial records, monitoring and approving or declining organizational spending and assisting the President with drafting a budget for the next school term. In the case of collaborations with other RSOs, the treasurer is the point-person for handling all aspects of the transfers of funds. Responsible for sending and receiving W-9s and sending them to Student Engagement Business Center. Holds Signature Responsibility.     
Event Coordinator - Has Event Coordinating training and is the point person for planning events. Fills out event requests, handles food waivers, and attends meetings for the AFS and ticket details. Attends meetings with RSO adviser to confirm that holding an event is acceptable. Handles the details of an event to help it come to life. Works with President to host a successful event and in the event of no event coordinator, the President will fulfill most of these responsibilities with the help of other eboard members. 
Public Relations - Maintains positive relations with the general body by maintaining positive images on social media. Posts on social media to keep up with visibility and advertisement for events. Creates flyers and gets approval for them by the Adviser (mainly for the fashion show/parties). Constantly working on more followers for social media. Point person for advertising an event and upholding the image of the organization (although everyone has a responsibility with upholding a positive image of Soul TV)
 
Outreach Coordinator - Recruits student artists, performers, models and designers. Handles distributing contracts and collecting them (esp from models and designers). Handles communication with artists (esp designers and performers) and holds them accountable for their responsibilities. Also serves as bridge of communication between Soul TV and other organizations. The point person who speaks for the Organization with collaborations for events and logistics of those events. Calls for meetings with the other organizations to take about logistics. 

Dance Coordinator - Responsible for the creation of choreography for the Soul TV dance team (Soul Sistas) as well as workshops. Must facilitate dance practices, try outs and workshops as well as any other event associated with the dance team. This position will work in tandem with event coordinator to book spaces for try outs, practices and dance workshops. The Dance Coordinator is expected to communicate all rules and expectations pertaining Soul TV dance team members. 

Model Coordinators – Responsible for the organization and facilitation of all activities pertaining to Soul TV models. This is including but is not limited to; try outs, practices and recruitment. Model Coordinators are expected to communicate and enforce the expectations and rules pertaining to Soul TV models. 

Secretary – Responsible for keeping and maintaining minutes for Eboard meetings. Must organize all records on the RSO’s google drive to ensure ease of access to documentation for current and future Eboards. This position will also be responsible for making sure that the Campus Pulse roster is up to date. 
Article V - Eboard Expectations 
	All Eboard members are expected to attend meetings, fulfill the requirements of their positions and contribute evenly to events. All Eboard members are expected to maintain communication and be responsive in GroupMe (or any method of communication with all Eboard members) and emails. Everyone is expected to hold each other accountable for their roles and their mistakes. But members should not feel like other Eboard members are micromanaging their position; every member has each other's back. 
Article VI - Removal of an Officer 
	If an officer is not doing his/her duty in the position designated to them or is in direct violation of the constitution then removal is a feasible action. If an elected officer is not fulfilling the expectations of their role then a warning will be issued by the President. Warnings are also given when an elected official misses three Eboard meetings. If the officer is given a warning, then misses an eboard meeting then privileges will be lost. Missing two meetings after warnings are given will result in the removal of an officer. Excuses absences will only be permitted for academic and health reasons.   
Article VII - Membership 
	Soul TV membership will be open to any Umass or five-college student with an interest in the objectives and mission of the organization. Attendance of at least two general body meetings is required in order to become a member. All members are allowed to vote on matters concerning the organization and events but only UMass students can join the Eboard. No member will be denied the right to freedom of speech/expression. All members are allowed and encouragement to voice their opinion in all matters concerning the organization including the performance of Eboard members and events. No one will be denied acceptance as long as they attend meetings. 
Article VIII - Dispute Amongst Members 
	If disputes among members concerning affairs of the organization and decisions made, the problem should be mediated by the President or Vice President. Concerns should be brought to the general body and an ultimate decision through the majority vote. If the dispute is between the President and another Eboard member, the matter is to be presented to the entirety of the members which will be monitored by the Vice President or an eboard member who is not involved in the dispute. 
Article IX - Meetings
	General body meetings will be held monthly or bi-monthly and organized by the Vice President. Eboard meetings will be held weekly or biweekly depending on upcoming events. If an eboard member misses three meetings they will be given a warning and after the fifth missed meeting, they are subject for removal. 
Article X - Voting 
	Officers are elected at the 3rd to last GB meeting at the end of the Spring semester. Officers are elected upon a majority vote of Eboard members. Newly elected officers will shadow the person holding their position to familiarize themselves with their duties. In the case of a tie, the President of the person in charge of the event will have veto power. Elections will be held during a regularly scheduled general body meeting with two-thirds (2/3rd) of the active SGA members in the RSO in attendance. RSO officer elections for the following year must take place before April 1st. 

Article XI - Amendments & Ratifications  
	Amendments to the constitution and by-laws will need a ⅔ majority vote of the Eboard vote in attendance at a scheduled meeting-. The ratification of the constitution will need a ⅔ majority vote from Eboard members at a scheduled meeting. The secretary of registry of SGA must approve ratification and the updated copy must be made available to all members and the public through Campus Pulse.  

Article XII- Statement of non-discrimination
	Membership will not be denied to no students on the basis of race, color, national origin, religion, sex, gender identity (including gender expression), sexual orientation, disability, age, marital status, family/parental status, income derived from a public assistance program, political beliefs, or reprisal or retaliation for prior civil rights activity. Under no circumstances shall a member’s freedom of speech or expression be infringed.
Article XIII- Statement of free speech 
	Because Soul TV is committed to free and open inquiry in all matters, it guarantees all members of Soul TV the broadest possible latitude to speak, write, listen, challenge, and learn. 
Soul TV respects and support the freedom of all members of Soul TV engage in robust, uninhibited discussion and deliberation on any and all topics. 

 The group prohibits discrimination under federal and state law, based on race, color, national origin, religion, sex,  gender identity (including gender expression), sexual orientation, disability, age, marital status, family/parental status, income derived from a public assistance program, political beliefs, or reprisal or retaliation for prior civil rights activity.

	General body meetings will be held monthly or bi-monthly and organized by the Vice President. Eboard meetings will be held weekly or biweekly depending on upcoming events. If an eboard member misses three meetings they will be given a warning and after the fifth missed meeting, they are subject for removal. 
Article X - Voting 
	Officers are elected at the 3rd to last GB meeting at the end of the Spring semester. Officers are elected upon a majority vote of Eboard members. Newly elected officers will shadow the person holding their position to familiarize themselves with their duties. In the case of a tie, the President of the person in charge of the event will have veto power. Elections will be held during a regularly scheduled general body meeting with two-thirds (2/3rd) of the active SGA members in the RSO in attendance. RSO officer elections for the following year must take place before April 1st. 

Article XI - Amendments & Ratifications  
	Amendments to the constitution and by-laws will need a ⅔ majority vote of the Eboard vote in attendance at a scheduled meeting-. The ratification of the constitution will need a ⅔ majority vote from Eboard members at a scheduled meeting. The secretary of registry of SGA must approve ratification and the updated copy must be made available to all members and the public through Campus Pulse.  

Article XII- Statement of non-discrimination
	Membership will not be denied to no students on the basis of race, color, national origin, religion, sex, gender identity (including gender expression), sexual orientation, disability, age, marital status, family/parental status, income derived from a public assistance program, political beliefs, or reprisal or retaliation for prior civil rights activity. Under no circumstances shall a member’s freedom of speech or expression be infringed.
Article XIII- Statement of free speech 
	Because Soul TV is committed to free and open inquiry in all matters, it guarantees all members of Soul TV the broadest possible latitude to speak, write, listen, challenge, and learn. 
Soul TV respects and support the freedom of all members of Soul TV engage in robust, uninhibited discussion and deliberation on any and all topics. 

 The group prohibits discrimination under federal and state law, based on race, color, national origin, religion, sex,  gender identity (including gender expression), sexual orientation, disability, age, marital status, family/parental status, income derived from a public assistance program, political beliefs, or reprisal or retaliation for prior civil rights activity.

DocsList.Name: Spring 2018 Soul TV Constitution.docx
DocsList.Data:
University of Massachusetts - Amherst Registered Student Organization: Constitution of the Organization Soul TV  
Article I- Name 
	The name of this organization will be Soul TV 
Article II - Mission Statement
	The purpose of this organization is to fulfill the interests of UMass students interested in all forms of creative activity as well as other outlets of entertainment which can include but are not limited to TV, Print, Radio, Music, Art, Fashion and Design. The organization’s objectives are to put on a series of events and productions that tie into the organization’s purpose and highlight student creatives and performers. To encourage, engage, and inspire all students to artistically express themselves by providing a platform to do so.
Article III - Elections / Nominations
	Soul TV shall be open to any UMass or five-college student with interest in the objectives and mission statement of the organization.  Members are generally interested in the execution of the goals and outreach and of the organization. Attendance of at least two general body meetings is required in order to be a member . All members are allowed to vote on matters concerning the organization but only UMass students can join the eboard.  
Article IV - Executive Board Officers 
	The executive board of Soul TV consists of a President, a Vice President, a Treasurer, an Event Coordinator, a Public Relations officer, a RSO Liaison and a Creative Outreach Coordinator. Below are the roles and duties they are responsible for:
President - Responsible for the organizational activities which include: coordinating executive board meetings, council meetings, communication with RSO Advisor, distribution of all written documents to council members in the case of no event coordinator, and maintenance of any documents pertaining to organization and its affairs. Work to ensure that the lines of communication stay open between the entirety of the executive board via all forms of communication including emails, meetings etc. Holds Signature Responsibility and Event Coordinating Training.    
Vice President - Responsible for coordinating general body meetings and general body committees. Assists the President or fill in when she/he is absent or unable to fulfill their duties. Takes minutes at Eboard meetings and handles general body meetings/committees. Responsible for communication with the general body (esp through email).Holds Signature Responsibility and Event Coordinating Training. 
Treasurer - Handle any monetary transactions and  responsible for all financial documents. Their duties include maintaining financial records, monitoring and approving or declining organizational spending and assisting the President with drafting a budget for the next school term. In the case of collaborations with other RSOs, the treasurer is the point-person for handling all aspects of the transfers of funds. Responsible for sending and receiving W-9s and sending them to Student Engagement Business Center. Holds Signature Responsibility.     
Event Coordinator - Has Event Coordinating training and is the point person for planning events. Fills out event requests, handles food waivers, and attends meetings for the AFS and ticket details. Attends meetings with RSO adviser to confirm that holding an event is acceptable. Handles the details of an event to help it come to life. Works with President to host a successful event and in the event of no event coordinator, the President will fulfill most of these responsibilities with the help of other eboard members. 
Public Relations - Maintains positive relations with the general body by maintaining positive images on social media. Posts on social media to keep up with visibility and advertisement for events. Creates flyers and gets approval for them by the Adviser (mainly for the fashion show/parties). Constantly working on more followers for social media. Point person for advertising an event and upholding the image of the organization (although everyone has a responsibility with upholding a positive image of Soul TV)
RSO Liaison - The bridge of communication between Soul TV and other organizations. The point person who speaks for the Organization with collaborations for events and logistics of those events. Calls for meetings with the other organizations to take about logistics. 
Creative Outreach Coordinator - Recruits student artists, performers, models and designers. Handles distributing contracts and collecting them (esp from models and designers). Handles communication with artists (esp designers and performers) and holds them accountable for their responsibilities. 
Article V - Eboard Expectations 
	All Eboard members are expected to attend meetings, fulfill the requirements of their positions and contribute evenly to events. All Eboard members are expected to maintain communication and be responsive in GroupMe (or any method of communication with all Eboard members) and emails. Everyone is expected to hold each other accountable for their roles and their mistakes. But members should not feel like other Eboard members are micromanaging their position; every member has each other's back. 
Article VI - Removal of an Officer 
	If an officer is not doing his/her duty in the position designated to them or is in direct violation of the constitution then removal is a feasible action. If an elected officer is not fulfilling the expectations of their role then a warning will be issued by the President. Warnings are also given when an elected official misses three Eboard meetings. If the officer is given a warning, then misses an eboard meeting then privileges will be lost. Missing two meetings after warnings are given will result in the removal of an officer. Excuses absences will only be permitted for academic and health reasons.   
Article VII - Membership 
	Soul TV membership will be open to any Umass or five-college student with an interest in the objectives and mission of the organization. Attendance of at least two general body meetings is required in order to become a member. All members are allowed to vote on matters concerning the organization and events but only UMass students can join the Eboard. No member will be denied the right to freedom of speech/expression. All members are allowed and encouragement to voice their opinion in all matters concerning the organization including the performance of Eboard members and events. No one will be denied acceptance as long as they attend meetings. 
Article VIII - Dispute Amongst Members 
	If disputes among members concerning affairs of the organization and decisions made, the problem should be mediated by the President or Vice President. Concerns should be brought to the general body and an ultimate decision through the majority vote. If the dispute is between the President and another eboard member, the matter is to be presented to the entirety of the members which will be monitored by the Vice President or an eboard member who is not involved in the dispute. 
Article IX - Meetings
	General body meetings will be held monthly or bi-monthly and organized by the Vice President. Eboard meetings will be held weekly or biweekly depending on upcoming events. If an eboard member misses three meetings they will be given a warning and after the fifth missed meeting, they are subject for removal. 
Article X - Voting 
	Officers are elected at the 3rd to last GB meeting at the end of the Spring semester. Officers are elected upon a majority vote of Eboard members. Newly elected officers will shadow the person holding their position to familiarize themselves with their duties. In the case of a tie, the President of the person in charge of the event will have veto power.
Article XI - Amendments & Ratifications  
	Amendments to the constitution and by-laws will need a ⅔ majority vote of the Eboard vote in attendance at a scheduled meeting-. The ratification of the constitution will need a ⅔ majority vote from Eboard members at a scheduled meeting. The secretary of registry of SGA must approve ratification and the updated copy must be made available to all members and the public through Campus Pulse.

Special Olympics College at the University of Massachusetts

DocsList.Name: Special Olympics at the Universiy of Massachusetts Constitution:ByLaws.docx
DocsList.Data:
Special Olympics College at the 
University of Massachusetts (SO UMass)
Adopted 26 November, 2015 in Amherst, MA

Article I: Name

The name of this student organization is the Special Olympics College at the University of Massachusetts (SO UMass).

Article II: Mission Statement

The mission of the Special Olympics College at the University of Massachusetts (SO UMass) is to outreach to the Special Olympic athletes through on-campus sports and fitness, volunteering with the Special Olympics Organization, and spreading awareness to enhance the lives of people with intellectual disabilities. SO UMass will achieve this through student leadership, social advocacy, campus engagements in Special Olympics programs, fundraisers, and other initiatives. 

Article III: Membership

Membership to this group is open to all students in the Five College community, their dependents, staff, and faculty.
There shall be no qualifications for membership. 
No one shall be denied membership of this group due to their race, creed, color, sex, sexual orientation, or physical disabilities.
Any member may remove his/her membership from the group by contacting the Executive Board and requesting removal.
Any officer in the group may resign at any time by contacting the Executive Board and requesting removal.
Dues of $5.00 will be requested to be submitted at the beginning of the academic year to maintain membership within the club. If an individual decides to join in the middle of the academic year, their $5.00 dues will be attained at the start of their membership. 
To maintain membership, not including the Executive Board, each member must attend at least three general meetings during each academic semester.

Article IV: The Executive Board and Officers

The Executive Board of this group consists of: two Co-Presidents, Vice-President, Secretary, Treasurer, Events Coordinator, Volunteerism Chair, and a Media Relations Officer.
All members of the Executive Board must be current members of the group and in good standing within the group upon the conclusion of an academic semester. Each member should be a full time undergraduate student at the University. There shall be no other qualifications for any of the offices. 
Each officer will hold term for two consecutive academic semesters. 
Officers shall be eligible for re-election to multiple terms. 
The Executive Board will meet at least once a month. 
All group officers are elected democratically to the position during a group meeting that is announced at least two weeks prior to the election. This meeting will be held at the end of April for the following academic year. However, if an officer of the Executive Board is removed or resigns during the academic year, the club members will be notified immediately of the position that is open. Once elected, the new officer will take the place of the removed or resigned officer automatically and fulfill the rest of the resigned or removed officer’s term.
The descriptions of each officer’s positions and responsibilities within the group are as follows:
Co-Presidents: The Co-Presidents are the chief executive officers of the group and are responsible for overseeing and maintaining the Executive Board and the group as a whole. Also, they are responsible for ensuring that the group is fulfilling their mission for the organization and running of the Executive Board meetings. The first Co-President will obtain the title of “President of Administration” and be in charge of overseeing the various administrative duties. This president will hold signature responsibility. The second Co-President will obtain the title “President of Events” and be in charge of overseeing event coordination.
Vice-President: The Vice-President supports the Presidents in all of their duties and is able to fill in for one of the Presidents if he/she is unavailable. He/she is responsible for taking on activities that the President's delegate, which may include, but are not limited to, the following: organizing a volunteer event with Special Olympics, spreading awareness through school-wide initiatives, and contacting persons for the group.
Secretary: The Secretary is responsible for keeping a record of minutes for all topics discussed in both group meetings and Executive Board meetings. He/she is also responsible for holding and updating the master list of all group members and for taking attendance at each meeting. The Secretary is also the main liaison between the Executive Board and the rest of the group and, as such, must e-mail all members to remind them of the group meeting dates and events to give updates after each meeting occurs.
Treasurer: The Treasurer is responsible for the financial affairs and activities of the group. He/she is another officer holding signature responsibility and, as such, may be required to book rooms, submit Purchase Order Requests, or be present to sign off on any financial documents. The Treasurer should also work closely with the two Co-Presidents in order to incorporate the results of the fundraising activities into the group budget. Finally, the treasurer will be responsible for maintaining the budget and submitting a budget to SGA in the Spring semester.  
Events Coordinator: The Events Coordinator’s main responsibility is to work with outside groups such as the Special Olympics to run events that the Organization is holding. Falling under this responsibility is the promotion of the club and its events as well as helping to increase attendance at club meetings. 
Volunteerism Chair: This position entails working with local communities to promote and instill the values of the Special Olympics College of the University of Massachusetts and the University. The responsibility of this chair is to create and promote community events that will benefit both the student body of UMass and residents of the local towns and cities.  
Media Relations Officer: The Media Relations Officer is responsible for providing current news and events about SO UMass to members of the group, the campus, and the surrounding community. This can be through, but not limited to, the following: The Campus Pulse SO UMass page, Social Media, and on-campus video systems. 
Formed Committees: Committees may be formed in order to assist one of the officers of the board with their duties. Formed committees are re-established when needed and are open to all active members.    

Article V: Elections

Any candidate wishing to be nominated for an open officer position for the following year must write and send the Executive Board an e-mail statement of intent for the position. This candidate is then nominated and may present a statement to the group during the election meeting.
During the election meeting, each nominated member for each position will present a two to three minute statement to the entire group. If he/she can not be present at the meeting, then he/she must contact the Executive Board. In this case, the nominated member will have a statement read to the group.
During the election meeting and after all statements have been offered by the nominated members, a ballot is distributed to all members and to the Executive Board. The ballot will include all nominated members for each open position and will be private. These ballots are then collected and tallied first by the President of Administration and secondly by the Secretary. A nominated member needs a ⅔ majority to win the open position. The results are then declared to the entire group or at the following group meeting and through a group e-mail.

Article VI: Meetings

The Executive Board will decide when the meetings for the entire group should be held based on a democratic vote from the club members. This vote should occur at the beginning of every semester.
Meetings should be bi-weekly, however may vary depending on the scheduling of Special Olympics events.
The Presidents may also call special meetings involving the entire group when he/she deems it necessary. These meetings shall be called with no less than twenty-four hours notice. 
The Co-Presidents chair all meetings of the group and the Executive Board meetings, except for individual committee meetings. In the absence of a President, the Vice-President may take the place of a President for the meeting.
No meetings will occur during University holidays or during Final Exam periods.
Members of the club must attend at least three meetings during an academic semester.

Article VII: Removal of Member(s) and/or Executive Board Member(s)

The Executive Board withholds the rights to remove a member from the club if the member is not fully participating and/or causing unwarranted disturbances within the club.
A member can fall under such circumstances requiring removal by not attending three group meetings.
All other circumstances that call for group member removal will be judged on an issue-by-issue basis.
If someone feels violated by another group member, they are requested to approach someone on the Executive Board and state their problem.  The officer that receives the complaint will take the issue to the Presidents who will thereafter bring it to the attention of the Executive Board.
The Executive Board will address the group member through a formal e-mail, requesting a meeting with the Executive Board where the group member in question will be given a chance to plead their case. The member or person who filed the complaint will be e-mailed separately, asking them to file their own case but will not be asked to attend the meeting with the group member in question.
The Executive Board will listen to the case of the members, and proceed forward on a case-by-case basis. After discussing the issue without the group members present, the Executive Board will vote on whether the person will be allowed to stay in the group or not. The group member in question will be notified by e-mail no later than a week after their hearing.
If an Executive Board member fails to attend two or more consecutive meetings or events and has no valid explanation for such absences, the Executive Board retains the ability to suspend or completely remove the officer, reopening their position for election.
The Executive Board will have a private meeting to discuss this issue as well as the severity of the offense by the officer under questioning. Then, the officer who is under scrutiny will be allowed to plead their case to the Executive Board at a second meeting where the Executive Board, after hearing the plea, can decide what terms this board member will work under for the rest of their time in office.
The Executive Board will vote after discussion of the Executive Board member in question pleads their case. If the severity of the issue does not seem to be major, then the officer will be allowed to stay under his or her title with a warning and minimal authority. However, if the issue is concluded to be severe enough, the officer will be removed from their title and the club, causing an empty seat in the Executive Board. See Article IV for elections for vacant officer seats for further proceedings.

Article VIII: Free Speech

All member of SO UMass are entitled to freedom of speech and will not under any circumstances be deprived of the opportunity to share their opinion to the group.

Article IX: Resolving Disputes

Disputes arising between members on matters of the SO UMass policy shall be dealt with through majority votes of the general membership. 
Disputes arising between members on other matters shall be dealt with through mediation. 
Mediation consists of a meeting involving both parties and a mediator with the purpose of coming to a solution and putting the issue to rest.
The President of Administration shall mediate disputes between members.
Should the President of Administration be involved in the dispute, either the President of Finances or the President of Events may mediate. Should either party not be satisfied by the result of the mediation, any party may request that the Secretary of Registry mediate. The results of the mediation with the Secretary of the Registry shall be final. 

Article X: Amendements

Any group member may propose an amendment to this constitution by submitting the proposal in writing to the President of Administration or Secretary. Any proposal that is submitted will then be discussed and decided upon by the Executive Board at the next meeting through a democratic vote and a ⅔ majority of the Executive Board.
If majority is found in the Executive Board, the matter will be brought to the general membership for voting. The constitution will be amended with a ⅔ majority of the general membership.
After being approved by the membership, the amendment itself, and an updated version of the Charter, shall be submitted to the Secretary of Registry for final approval.

DocsList.Name: SAA Constitution 2017-2018.docx
DocsList.Data:
UNIVERSITY OF MASSACHUSETTS AMHERST
Student Alumni Association

CONSTITUTION

ARTICLE I
Name

SECTION 1. The name of the organization shall be the Student Alumni Association. The organization shall be popularly referred to hereinafter as the SAA. SAA shall be an organization housed under the UMass Amherst Alumni Association

ARTICLE II
Purpose

SECTION 1. 
	The mission of the SAA is to connect students and alumni to enhance the UMass community and to foster a spirit of giving back. The SAA assists the UMass Amherst Alumni Association in providing programs of direct benefit to students, alumni, parents and faculty as well as the campus in general.  We serve as viable links between the alumni of today and the alumni of the future.  The programs of the SAA are designed to promote interaction between students and alumni and increase student involvement and a sense of belonging to the UMass Amherst community, all for the betterment of the campus.
	Sponsored by the UMass Amherst Alumni Association, the SAA will foster a sense of pride and tradition in the campus and will promote an active program of recruitment and commitment among both students and alumni.

ARTICLE III
Affiliation

SECTION 1. The Student Alumni Association shall be affiliated with and responsible to the University of Massachusetts Amherst Alumni Association.

ARTICLE IV
Eligibility/Membership

SECTION 1. The organization will be open to all UMass Amherst students. The membership will not be limited.

SECTION 2. A member in good standing shall be defined by the following criteria: regular attendance at meetings, active participation in events, and attendance and participation in the mandatory events decided by the E-board. 

SECTION 3. A member in regular contact (email, phone, etc) and has more than 10 points (see Article V) is considered active. Members must confirm they are active once they have been contacted upon earning 10 points. 

SECTION 4. A member who is not in regular contact but still wants to hold a future commitment to the organization is considered inactive.
This includes those students who are off campus (i.e. studying abroad, domestic exchange, internship)

SECTION 5. Members who do not keep in contact with SAA through email, attending meetings, volunteering nor participating at mandatory events/programs is considered to have resigned and will be taken off the roster. 


ARTICLE V
Points System & Active Recording

SECTION 1. A point system will be used to keep attendance and membership recording. Members will be able to personally record their activity at every event, meeting, and volunteer occasion by signing their name in the master Attendance Book. 
The Sign-In Book will also store meeting sign-in sheets and be under the responsibility of the Administrative Coordinator. 

SECTION 2. Points will be given for attending meetings, hours dedicated to volunteering, working events, etc. 

SECTION 3. Upon receiving 10 points, the member is considered active and will receive a SAA t-shirt to acknowledge their membership.

SECTION 4. The Administrative Coordinator will keep record and update the point system and database. It is the responsibility of the Executive Board to record points for their own events/volunteer services and then pass the points to the Administrative Coordinator within a week after said service.

ARTICLE VI
Executive Board and Officers

SECTION 1. The SAA shall have the following officers: President, Vice President of Traditions, Vice President of Communications and Public Relations, Vice President of Recruitment and Engagement, Vice President of Training and Development, and Vice President of Student Ambassadors. The term of office is from May 1 until April 30. This can be changed by a majority vote of the Executive Board. Other positions may be implemented as deemed necessary by the president. 
No two offices may be held by the same person, without special consent by the advisor and Executive Board.
Executive Board Officers must plan to be on campus for the whole academic year of their term.

SECTION 2. In the event that there is a vacancy during an academic year, that officer shall be filled by nomination of the Executive Board and then appointment for that office.

SECTION 3. Executive Board: 
1. Shall consist of the officers.
2. Shall have the authority to approve or create ad hoc committees as deemed necessary. Shall be responsible for the coordination of the executive responsibilities of the SAA. 

SECTION 4. Duties of Offices:
President 
Shall be the chief presiding officer for all SAA meetings.
Shall enforce the constitution.
Shall provide leadership for the group.
Shall preside over SAA Executive Board meetings.
Shall have the power to create cabinet positions with the approval of the Executive Board.
Shall meet with the advisor on a weekly basis or as often as deemed necessary.
Shall, in consultation with the advisor, create an agenda for each Executive Board meeting and general meeting.
Shall hold one seat as a member of the UMass Amherst Alumni Association Board of Directors if appointed. 
Shall attend all general Board of Director meetings during the academic year.
Shall attend University functions as a Board member.
Shall serve the Association and subcommittees as deemed necessary.

All Vice President positions and the Director of Student Ambassadors are responsible directly to the President.  Each of these positions shall enforce the constitution and assist the President as necessary.  

Vice President of Traditions
Shall assume some duties of the president in the president’s absence.
Shall create and execute a strategic plan for implementing and maintaining traditions programs that are engaging to students.
Shall guide cabinet members with traditions strategy.
Shall be the liaison to any cabinet positions created under this title.
Shall propose committees/task forces for traditions programs to engage student leadership.

Vice President for Public Relations and Communications
Shall assume some duties of the president in the president’s absence.
Shall develop and execute a strategic public relations and communications strategy in alignment with the Alumni Association communications strategy.
Shall guide cabinet members with public relations and communications strategy
Shall be the liaison to any cabinet positions created under this title.

Vice President of Training and Development
Shall assume some duties of the president in the president’s absence.
Shall create and execute a strategic plan for training and development
Shall guide cabinet members with training and development strategy
Shall coordinate training and development efforts.
Shall be the liaison to any cabinet positions created under this title.
Shall be responsible for award nominations and applications.

Vice President of Recruitment and Engagement
Shall assume some duties of the president in the president’s absence.
Shall create and execute a strategic plan for recruitment and engagement
Shall guide cabinet members with recruitment and engagement strategy
Shall be the liaison to any cabinet positions created under this title.
Shall coordinate reactivation each fall semester.
Shall obtain Signature Responsibility.

Vice President of Student Ambassadors
Shall assume some duties of the president in the president’s absence.
Shall create and execute a strategic plan for the ambassador program and will work with Vice Presidents in their areas of expertise to grow and strengthen the program.
Shall guide cabinet members with the Ambassador strategy.
Shall be the liaison to any cabinet positions created under this title.
Shall manage application and recruitment process.
Shall manage all requests for support.

SECTION 5. If more than 3 members of the Executive Board feel that one board member is not meeting the expectations nor performing the duties of that position, the board members must submit to the President and Advisor a formal proposal of impeachment. The President and Advisor must then discuss if the proposal is justified within a week of submission. If justified, the President and Advisor must speak to the officer in question and put them on a two week re-evaluation. After the re-evaluation period, if the President and Advisor feel that to further the impeachment process, the executive board (not including the officer in question) will anonymously vote to impeach officer in question. At least 3 people must vote for the impeachment in order to implement. 
If three members of the Executive Board feel that the President has not been meeting expectations nor performing their duties, they must present a formal proposal to the advisor who will then further the process of impeachment if deemed legitimate.

ARTICLE VII
Voting Privileges

SECTION 1. Each member in good standing shall be allowed one vote on all matters, except for the President, who will serve as a tiebreaker.  If the President is running for re-election, s/he may vote while the advisor serves as a tiebreaker.

SECTION 2. The voting process will be handled on Campus Pulse in a set election time of 24 hours. All members must be on the Campus Pulse roster in order vote in the election. 

ARTICLE VIII
Meetings

SECTION 1. Meetings of the general membership of the SAA shall be held every other week during the academic year or as frequently as deemed necessary by the Executive Board.  This can be changed by majority vote of the Executive Board.

SECTION 2. The Executive Board shall meet every academic week on the same day as the general meeting, preferably, or on a day that permits all members of the Executive Board to be present. 

SECTION 3. A majority, fifty-one percent (51%), of the general membership of the SAA in attendance shall constitute a quorum.  A quorum is required for the transaction of all regular business of the SAA at all general membership meetings. Sixty percent (60%) of the Executive Board will likewise constitute a quorum for the transaction of business.

SECTION 4. In consultation with the advisor, the President shall create an agenda for each general meeting. The President will also create the agenda for each executive board meeting with input from the executive board members.

ARTICLE IX
Advisor

SECTION 1. Shall be a member of the UMass Amherst Alumni Association staff.

SECTION 2. Shall present ideas to the Executive Board for discussion before presentation to the group for approval, and shall serve as a general advisor for the organization.

ARTICLE X
Elections

SECTION 1. A person applying for the office of President, Vice President of Traditions, Vice President of Communications and Public Relations, Vice President of Recruitment and Engagement, Vice President of Training and Development, and Vice President of Student Ambassadors shall have been a member of the SAA for at least one semester or receive approval by the Advisor and the President to run. Each candidate must have a confirmed member of SAA endorse them on their application. 

SECTION 2. A senior member of the Executive Board or Cabinet will conduct the elections as Elections Chair. This person will design the online ballot on Campus Pulse, compile the biographies of candidates into a document as reference for the voters. 

SECTION 3. At least two weeks prior to the election, the Elections Chair will announce upcoming elections and describe duties of each position. 

SECTION 4. Applications for Executive Board and Cabinet positions will be accepted prior to election.  Elections should be held in during the spring semester or as decided by the Executive Board. 

SECTION 5. Those members who applied shall be able to accept or decline at any time during the election period.  

SECTION 6. Before the vote is taken, candidates for that office will be given the opportunity to speak on their own behalf.

SECTION 7. Members in good standing shall vote on the online Campus Pulse platform.  The advisor and the Elections Chair shall count the votes. The person who acquires the highest number of votes shall win that office.

ARTICLE XI
Amendments

SECTION 1. This constitution shall become effective upon approval by a majority of SAA members at a general meeting.

SECTION 2. Hereinafter, this constitution may be amended at an Executive Board meeting by a three-fourths (3/4)-majority vote of all officers. Proposed amendments must be submitted in writing to the membership one meeting prior to the vote.

SECTION 3. The effectiveness of this constitution shall be reviewed and evaluated every year.

DocsList.Name: Constitution 2016-2017.docx
DocsList.Data:
UNIVERSITY OF MASSACHUSETTS AMHERST
Student Alumni Association

CONSTITUTION

ARTICLE I
Name

SECTION 1. The name of the organization shall be the Student Alumni Association. The organization shall be popularly referred to hereinafter as the SAA. SAA shall be an organization housed under the UMass Amherst Alumni Association

ARTICLE II
Purpose

SECTION 1. “Students helping students- past, present and future”
	The purpose of the SAA is to assist the UMass Amherst Alumni Association in providing programs of direct benefit to students, alumni, parents and faculty as well as the campus in general.  We serve as viable links between the alumni of today and the alumni of the future.  The programs of the SAA are designed to promote interaction between students and alumni and increase student involvement and a sense of belonging to the UMass Amherst community, all for the betterment of the campus.
	Sponsored by the UMass Amherst Alumni Association the SAA will foster a sense of pride and tradition in the campus and will promote an active program of recruitment and commitment among both students and alumni.

ARTICLE III
Affiliation

SECTION 1. The Student Alumni Association shall be affiliated with and responsible to the University of Massachusetts Amherst Alumni Association.

ARTICLE IV
Eligibility/Membership

SECTION 1. The organization will be open to all UMass Amherst students. The membership will not be limited.

SECTION 2. A member in good standing shall be defined by the following criteria: regular attendance at meetings, active participation in events, and attendance and participation in the mandatory events decided by the E-board. 

SECTION 3. A member in regular contact (email, phone, etc) and has more than 10 points (see Article V) is considered active. Members must confirm they are active once they have been contacted upon earning 10 points. 

SECTION 4. A member who is not in regular contact but still wants to hold a future commitment to the organization is considered inactive.
This includes those students who are off campus (i.e. studying abroad, domestic exchange, internship)

SECTION 5. Members who do not keep in contact with SAA through email, attending meetings, volunteering nor participating at mandatory events/programs is considered to have resigned and will be taken off the roster. 


ARTICLE V
Points System & Active Recording

SECTION 1. A point system will be used to keep attendance and membership recording. Members will be able to personally record their activity at every event, meeting, and volunteer occasion by signing their name in the master Attendance Book. 
The Sign-In Book will also store meeting sign-in sheets and be under the responsibility of the Administrative Coordinator. 

SECTION 2. Points will be given for attending meetings, hours dedicated to volunteering, working events, etc. 

SECTION 3. Upon receiving 10 points, the member is considered active and will receive a SAA t-shirt to acknowledge their membership.

SECTION 4. The Administrative Coordinator will keep record and update the point system and database. It is the responsibility of the Executive Board to record points for their own events/volunteer services and then pass the points to the Administrative Coordinator within a week after said service.

ARTICLE VI
Executive Board and Officers

SECTION 1. The SAA shall have the following officers: President, Vice President of Traditions, Vice President of Communications and Public Relations, Vice President of Recruitment and Engagement, Vice President of Training and Development, and Vice President of Student Ambassadors. The term of office is from May 1 until April 30. This can be changed by a majority vote of the Executive Board. Other positions may be implemented as deemed necessary by the president. 
No two offices may be held by the same person, without special consent by the advisor and Executive Board.
Executive Board Officers must plan to be on campus for the whole academic year of their term.

SECTION 2. In the event that there is a vacancy during an academic year, that officer shall be filled by nomination of the Executive Board and then appointment for that office.

SECTION 3. Executive Board: 
1. Shall consist of the officers.
2. Shall have the authority to approve or create ad hoc committees as deemed necessary. Shall be responsible for the coordination of the executive responsibilities of the SAA. 

SECTION 4. Duties of Offices:
President 
Shall be the chief presiding officer for all SAA meetings.
Shall enforce the constitution.
Shall provide leadership for the group.
Shall preside over SAA Executive Board meetings.
Shall have the power to create cabinet positions with the approval of the Executive Board.
Shall meet with the advisor on a weekly basis or as often as deemed necessary.
Shall, in consultation with the advisor, create an agenda for each Executive Board meeting and general meeting.
Shall hold one seat as a member of the UMass Amherst Alumni Association Board of Directors if appointed. 
Shall attend all general Board of Director meetings during the academic year.
Shall attend University functions as a Board member.
Shall serve the Association and subcommittees as deemed necessary.

All Vice President positions and the Director of Student Ambassadors are responsible directly to the President.  Each of these positions shall enforce the constitution and assist the President as necessary.  

Vice President of Traditions
Shall assume some duties of the president in the president’s absence.
Shall create and execute a strategic plan for implementing and maintaining traditions programs that are engaging to students.
Shall guide cabinet members with traditions strategy.
Shall be the liaison to any cabinet positions created under this title.
Shall propose committees/task forces for traditions programs to engage student leadership.

Vice President for Public Relations and Communications
Shall assume some duties of the president in the president’s absence.
Shall develop and execute a strategic public relations and communications strategy in alignment with the Alumni Association communications strategy.
Shall guide cabinet members with public relations and communications strategy
Shall be the liaison to any cabinet positions created under this title.

Vice President of Training and Development
Shall assume some duties of the president in the president’s absence.
Shall create and execute a strategic plan for training and development
Shall guide cabinet members with training and development strategy
Shall coordinate training and development efforts.
Shall be the liaison to any cabinet positions created under this title.
Shall be responsible for award nominations and applications.

Vice President of Recruitment and Engagement
Shall assume some duties of the president in the president’s absence.
Shall create and execute a strategic plan for recruitment and engagement
Shall guide cabinet members with recruitment and engagement strategy
Shall be the liaison to any cabinet positions created under this title.
Shall coordinate reactivation each fall semester.
Shall obtain Signature Responsibility.

Vice President of Student Ambassadors
Shall assume some duties of the president in the president’s absence.
Shall create and execute a strategic plan for the ambassador program and will work with Vice Presidents in their areas of expertise to grow and strengthen the program.
Shall guide cabinet members with the Ambassador strategy.
Shall be the liaison to any cabinet positions created under this title.
Shall manage application and recruitment process.
Shall manage all requests for support.

SECTION 5. If more than 3 members of the Executive Board feel that one board member is not meeting the expectations nor performing the duties of that position, the board members must submit to the President and Advisor a formal proposal of impeachment. The President and Advisor must then discuss if the proposal is justified within a week of submission. If justified, the President and Advisor must speak to the officer in question and put them on a two week re-evaluation. After the re-evaluation period, if the President and Advisor feel that to further the impeachment process, the executive board (not including the officer in question) will anonymously vote to impeach officer in question. At least 3 people must vote for the impeachment in order to implement. 
If three members of the Executive Board feel that the President has not been meeting expectations nor performing their duties, they must present a formal proposal to the advisor who will then further the process of impeachment if deemed legitimate.

ARTICLE VII
Voting Privileges

SECTION 1. Each member in good standing shall be allowed one vote on all matters, except for the President, who will serve as a tiebreaker.  If the President is running for re-election, s/he may vote while the advisor serves as a tiebreaker.

SECTION 2. The voting process will be handled on Campus Pulse in a set election time of 24 hours. All members must be on the Campus Pulse roster in order vote in the election. 

ARTICLE VIII
Meetings

SECTION 1. Meetings of the general membership of the SAA shall be held every other week during the academic year or as frequently as deemed necessary by the Executive Board.  This can be changed by majority vote of the Executive Board.

SECTION 2. The Executive Board shall meet every academic week on the same day as the general meeting, preferably, or on a day that permits all members of the Executive Board to be present. 

SECTION 3. A majority, fifty-one percent (51%), of the general membership of the SAA in attendance shall constitute a quorum.  A quorum is required for the transaction of all regular business of the SAA at all general membership meetings. Sixty percent (60%) of the Executive Board will likewise constitute a quorum for the transaction of business.

SECTION 4. In consultation with the advisor, the President shall create an agenda for each general meeting. The President will also create the agenda for each executive board meeting with input from the executive board members.

ARTICLE IX
Advisor

SECTION 1. Shall be a member of the UMass Amherst Alumni Association staff.

SECTION 2. Shall present ideas to the Executive Board for discussion before presentation to the group for approval, and shall serve as a general advisor for the organization.

ARTICLE X
Elections

SECTION 1. A person applying for the office of President, Vice President of Traditions, Vice President of Communications and Public Relations, Vice President of Recruitment and Engagement, Vice President of Training and Development, and Vice President of Student Ambassadors shall have been a member of the SAA for at least one semester or receive approval by the Advisor and the President to run. Each candidate must have a confirmed member of SAA endorse them on their application. 

SECTION 2. A senior member of the Executive Board or Cabinet will conduct the elections as Elections Chair. This person will design the online ballot on Campus Pulse, compile the biographies of candidates into a document as reference for the voters. 

SECTION 3. At least two weeks prior to the election, the Elections Chair will announce upcoming elections and describe duties of each position. 

SECTION 4. Applications for Executive Board and Cabinet positions will be accepted prior to election.  Elections should be held in during the spring semester or as decided by the Executive Board. 

SECTION 5. Those members who applied shall be able to accept or decline at any time during the election period.  

SECTION 6. Before the vote is taken, candidates for that office will be given the opportunity to speak on their own behalf.

SECTION 7. Members in good standing shall vote on the online Campus Pulse platform.  The advisor and the Elections Chair shall count the votes. The person who acquires the highest number of votes shall win that office.

ARTICLE XI
Amendments

SECTION 1. This constitution shall become effective upon approval by a majority of SAA members at a general meeting.

SECTION 2. Hereinafter, this constitution may be amended at an Executive Board meeting by a three-fourths (3/4)-majority vote of all officers. Proposed amendments must be submitted in writing to the membership one meeting prior to the vote.

SECTION 3. The effectiveness of this constitution shall be reviewed and evaluated every year.

Chief of Staff Application
