After completing the application Email to Avitale@umass.edu, once received the applicant will receive an email scheduling an interview. Also all completed applications are due Wednesday April 13th at 5:00PM no late applications will be accepted. Good Luck!


Section 1: General Information

Name: 

Major(s): 
 
Minor(s): 
 
Cumulative GPA: 
 
Year of Graduation: 
 
 
UMass Email Address to contact you for an interview:  
 

Are you a member of any Registered Student Organizations, Agencies, or Student Businesses? If so, which ones, and what has your experience been like?

 
What leadership positions/roles have you had on or off campus?


 
How many credits are you plan on taking next semester?

 
Do you have any experience working in or with the Student Government Association? If you have had none, please describe how you have interacted with the SGA in the past.  

 
Do you have any plans yet for after graduation? If so, what are they?


Section 2: Mission Statement of the SGA
To establish and protect the democratic system for undergraduate university governance; to promote the general welfare of all university undergraduate students. To create and maintain strong lines of communication between students and university administrators; to work toward greater transparency in administrative decisions. To protect the accessibility and affordability of the university for all students. To work to acknowledge, appreciate, and expand the diversity of the student body, including socioeconomic, racial, religious, cultural, gender, sexual orientation, and political characteristics. To provide leadership opportunities and development for all undergraduate students and to set the standards which other schools strive to uphold when leading their students into the future.


Section 3: SGA Equal Opportunity Policy  

No person, having qualified for SGA membership in the manner prescribed by Title 1, Chapter 1, Section 1, of the By-laws of the SGA, shall be denied the rights and privileges of SGA membership, on the basis of age, marital status, physical ability, class, national origin, political affiliation, race, religion, sex, sexual orientation, or any other category or group of individuals protected by either federal, state, or local anti-discrimination statutes and by-laws.

Section 4: Responsibilities of the Cabinet

In accordance with Title III, Chapter 9 Section 1 the responsibilities of the Cabinet are as follows;

1.   S/he shall be directly responsible for the effective implementation and execution of Acts of the SGA relevant to their administrative area.

2.   S/he shall be responsible for representing the President’s sentiments on matters relevant to their administrative area.

3.   S/he shall be directly responsible for the execution of all tasks prescribed for their administrative area by the Constitution of the SGA, the By-laws of the SGA, Acts of the SGA, or the President.

4.   S/he shall be responsible for submitting to the President and Senate, a written or verbal report on the activities and functions of their administrative area no less than once (1) every calendar month. In addition, any Senator may request a written or verbal report at any time.

5.   S/he shall serve as an ex-officio member of the Senate

Section 5: By-Laws of the Chief of Staff

Section 1	The Chief of Staff shall:

Act as the head of the Executive Branch when the President and the Vice President is not in attendance. 
In addition to the Vice President, the Chief of Staff shall be empowered to act for the President as their official representative in all capacities with the exception of signing or vetoing legislation, so long as the President has given prior consent to their actions. The Chief of Staff shall also be empowered to delegate this responsibility to any member of the Executive Cabinet.
Coordinate all Presidential appointments including creating a full list of any committees, councils, and advisory boards that the President has the authority to appoint student representation.
Serve as the chief adviser and receive instruction and direction from the President and Vice President. 
Be responsible for hiring and giving directions to the SGA Office Manager.   
The office manager will be responsible for day-to-day operations of the SGA office.
Signing bikes in and out of the SGA office
Checking out keys for RSO lockers.
Assisting students in reserving meeting spaces, event spaces, and conference rooms.
Ensuring that the needs of day-to-day office functions are satisfied.
Managing the office phone.
Managing a calendar to keep an up-to-date schedule of meetings and events.
Sorting incoming files, paperwork, and the historical archives.
Acting as a greeter with access to a calendar of SGA members’ office hours.
Maintaining a basic understanding of cabinet members’ projects.
Office supplies and cleaning supplies inventory. 


Section 6: Questions about the Job
1. Why do you want to be Chief of Staff?

2. What experience do you have working with the SGA executive cabinet in the past?

3. Have you ever been involved with SGA administration or planning, and if so when and how?

4. How would you describe your ability to keep others on task?  

5. What are your qualifications for being Chief of Staff?

6. What are your top 3 priorities as Chief of Staff if you were hired today?

8. Have you ever worked in an office environment before, if so what did you do?

9. What areas of the SGA administration do you feel need to be better organized? 

7. Is there any other information that you would like to share with us that you feel we should know?

Section 3: SGA Equal Opportunity Policy

Section 4: Responsibilities of the Cabinet

In accordance with Title III, Chapter 9 Section 1 the responsibilities of the Cabinet are as follows;

1.   S/he shall be directly responsible for the effective implementation and execution of Acts of the SGA relevant to their administrative area.

2.   S/he shall be responsible for representing the President’s sentiments on matters relevant to their administrative area.

3.   S/he shall be directly responsible for the execution of all tasks prescribed for their administrative area by the Constitution of the SGA, the By-laws of the SGA, Acts of the SGA, or the President.

4.   S/he shall be responsible for submitting to the President and Senate, a written or verbal report on the activities and functions of their administrative area no less than once (1) every calendar month. In addition, any Senator may request a written or verbal report at any time.

5.   S/he shall serve as an ex-officio member of the Senate

Section 5: By-Laws of the Attorney General

Section 1 	The Attorney General shall:

1.    Act to effectively implement Title III of the By-laws of the SGA.

2.    Act, in conjunction and consultation with the Directing Attorney of Student Legal Services Office, as the chief legal counsel to the SGA. The Attorney General shall be responsible for meeting with the Directing Attorney of Student Legal Services on a monthly basis, at least or they shall have resigned by non-action. 

3.     Act as the President’s liaison to the Student Judiciary, the Dean of Students Office, and the University Conduct System.

4.     File charges with the Dean of Student’s office for violations of the Code of Student Conduct relevant to the Constitution of the SGA, the By-laws of the SGA or Acts of the SGA.

5. 	Be directly responsible for the official judicial records of the SGA including, but not limited to Student Judiciary Majority Rulings.

6. 	Be directly responsible for the hiring of the Deputy Attorney General and the four Conduct Advisors

Supervise and coordinate the Conduct Advisors Program. The Conduct Advisors   shall:

Assist any students charged by the University by providing an explanation of the charges brought against the student and in-depth information regarding the Conduct Process.
Assist any students who express an interest in filing a charge through the Dean of Students Office.
Be proficient and actively engage in critically analyzing the Code of Student Conduct and Residential Life Community Standards.
Receive training from Student Legal Services prior to advising any student.
Abide to the office protocols determined by the Attorney General and the Deputy Attorney General.
Assist the Attorney General and/or the Deputy Attorney General to perform their duties.
Meet with an attorney in Student Legal Services once every 45 days or the Conduct Advisor shall have resigned by non-action.

8. 	Be an ex-officio member of the Senate Administrative Affairs Committee.

9.   Be an ex-officio member of the Senate Administrative Affairs Committee Rules and Ethics Sub-Committee, and shall assist said sub-committee in the research and development of legislation.

9.   Act as a member of the Student Legal Services Office Advisory Committee.

11.	 Act, in conjunction with students, Student Legal Services and offices under Student Activities and Campus Life to review the Code of Student Conduct.

Section 2	The Attorney General may elect to represent any person(s) before the Student Judiciary.

Section 3	The Attorney General will have the authority to hire a Deputy Attorney General. The Deputy Attorney General shall assist the Attorney General to perform their position as mandated by the by-laws.
a. The Deputy Attorney General must also act in the capacity as a Conduct Advisor.

Section 4	The files in the Office of the Attorney General shall be exempt from Title 1 Chapter 6 entitled “Public Records” in order to protect confidentiality.

Section 6: Question about the Job 
Why do you want to be Attorney General?

Do you have any prior legal/law related training or qualifications, and if so what?

Do you have experience working with the SLSO (Student Legal Services Office) here at UMass, and if so how?

How do you view the SGA or more specifically the Attorney General can help undergraduate students here on and off campus?

Are you prepared to help students who are in a difficult and often emotional situation, and if so how will you do this?

If you were given the job of Attorney General today what would be you top 3 priorities, and how would you accomplish these key priorities?  

 Is there any other information that you would like to share with us that you feel we should know?

Section 5: The Secretary of Diversity Issues By-Laws 

Section 1 	The Secretary of Diversity Issues shall:

S/he shall be directly responsible for advocating on behalf of a diverse student representative governance body. Diverse student representative, for the purposes of this position, shall be defined as working with the following groups:

CMASS and other groups that advocate for typically underrepresented student communities.

The UMASS Greek Community including all the fraternities, the Interfraternal Greek Council, the Multicultural Greek Council, Pan-Hellanic Council and the National Pan-Hellanic Council

The RSOs and other organizations widely used by the UMASS community, of a religious nature. 

The students identified as disabled by Disabilities Services and be the liaison to that office. 

S/he shall be responsible for convening a campus-wide Diversity Roundtable that shall 
meet no less than one (1) time per academic month to discuss campus wide diversity issues. 

S/he shall be responsible for advocating and sup
Supporting all appropriate Acts and Resolutions of the Student Government Association relative to diversity.

Work with the Vice President, the Speaker, and Associate Speaker to promote Fall Senate elections to diverse campus populations.

S/he shall be responsible for obtaining and distributing information regarding outlets of diversity on campus upon request.

Be an ex-officio member of The Diversity and Student Engagement Committee, and shall assist said committee in outreach to a diverse student population. 

Section 6: Questions about the Job 
1. Why do you want to be Secretary of Diversity?

2. What experience do you have working with On-Campus RSOs, Agencies, student groups that pertain to furthering diversity related goals here at UMass?

3. What experience do you have working with off-campus institutions pertaining to the furthering of diversity related goals?  

4. What would you identify as issues of diversity that should be prioritized by the SGA? 

5. What would your top 3 goals be as Secretary of Diversity if you were hired today?

6. What experiences have you had in the past that make you feel you are qualified for this position?

7. Is there any other information that you would like to share with us that you feel we should know?

5.   S/he shall serve as an ex-officio member of the Senate

Section 5: The Secretary of Finance By-laws:

1.  The Secretary of Finance is responsible for ensuring compliance of ESO with the financial policies of the SGA.  S/he is responsible for the keeping of accurate financial records and is responsible for ensuring that all ESO accounts are in order. S/he shall ensure that all agencies, area governments, and student businesses are financially solvent.  

2.  The Secretary of Finance shall be responsible for appointing and giving direction to the SGA auditor who shall assist the Secretary of Finance in systematically auditing accounts

3.  The Secretary of Finance shall be accountable to the SGA president, and shall receive their direction from him/her.

4.  The Secretary of Finance shall schedule weekly meetings with the Business Manager of The Center for Student Development (CSD) to review ESO discrepancies and to develop policy that addresses ESO financial issues.

5.  The Secretary of Finance shall serve as a mechanism for ESO financial support; s/he is responsible for long-term and short-term analysis of the SATF. S/he shall maintain records, and be abreast of issues including but not limited to: Administrative Overhead recharge policy, Copyright deficit/charges for Established Student Organizations,, and SATF allocation.

6. Tasks of the Secretary of Finance including but not limited to: 

Managing Budgets of
Senate Operations
SGA Revenue account
SGA Stabilization account

Advising the Ways & Means and Finance Committee Chairs on financial issues that surface during the course of their term.

Oversight of S-1 Budget spending to

I. Signing off on fee account transfers
Reviewing unusual expenditures for appropriateness
Setting in conjunction with CSD Business Center, year-end spending guidelines for Established Student Organizations.
Managing SGA fund-raising efforts

E. Evaluating expenses of the Student Activities Trust Fund

The Secretary of Finance will have the authority to appoint an auditor.
The auditor shall assist the Secretary of Finance in systematically auditing accounts.
The Secretary of Finance will have the authority to freeze student group accounts on the SATF
The Secretary of Finance must keep abreast of groups spending and be aware if any RSO has a deficit in either of their accounts.  This information is available from the Business department of Student Activities Center.
The Secretary of Finance will advise be RSO fifteen (15) days prior to suspension, s/he will also advise Student Activities Center at least fifteen (15) days prior.
Group suspension must be put in writing, and the Secretary of Finance will be responsible for maintaining a record of all suspensions and notices.
The Secretary of Finance shall inform and consult with the Secretary of the Registry when freezing an ESO.

7. Secretary of Finance shall hold Signature Responsibility as defined by the 	University system.

8. The monthly report shall include a summary expenditure of the SGA Operations     account (fee and revenue).

9. The Secretary of Finance will have the authority to appoint an SGA Treasurer. The SGA Treasurer shall initiate and develop fund-raising efforts for the SGA Operations account. All such revenues are to aid in the execution of business for the SGA. The SGA Treasurer shall also assist in the oversight of spending and running balances on all SGA accounts, which shall include:

A. The SGA Operations account (fee and revenue)
B. The campaign fund
C. Finance Reserves
D. Capitalization and equipment fund
E. Senate operations
F. Short-term stabilization funds
G. SGA Readership Program
H. New Group Reserve

Section 6: Questions about the Job
1. Why do you want to be Secretary of Finance?

2. Have you even served as a Treasurer or Financial Officer of a RSO, Agency or Student Business; if so what was you positon and what did you do in that position?

3. Have you ever been involved with SGA financial administration or planning, and if so when and how?

4. Are you familiar with UMass Summit software?  

5. What are your qualifications for being Secretary of Finance?

6. What are your top 3 priorities as Secretary of Finance if you were hired today?

7. Is there any other information that you would like to share with us that you feel we should know?

Section 2: Mission Statement of the SGA
To establish and protect the democratic system for undergraduate university governance; to promote the general welfare of all university undergraduate students. To create and maintain strong lines of communication between students and university administrators; to work toward greater transparency in administrative decisions. To protect the accessibility and affordability of the university for all students. To work to acknowledge, appreciate, and expand the diversity of the student body, including socioeconomic, racial, religious, cultural, gender, sexual orientation, and political characteristics. To provide leadership opportunities and development for all undergraduate students and to set the standards which other schools strive to uphold when leading their students into the future.


Section 3: SGA Equal Opportunity Policy  

No person, having qualified for SGA membership in the manner prescribed by Title 1, Chapter 1, Section 1, of the By-laws of the SGA, shall be denied the rights and privileges of SGA membership, on the basis of age, marital status, physical ability, class, national origin, political affiliation, race, religion, sex, sexual orientation, or any other category or group of individuals protected by either federal, state, or local anti-discrimination statutes and by-laws.

Section 4: Responsibilities of the Cabinet

In accordance with Title III, Chapter 9 Section 1 the responsibilities of the Cabinet are as follows;

1.   S/he shall be directly responsible for the effective implementation and execution of Acts of the SGA relevant to their administrative area.

2.   S/he shall be responsible for representing the President’s sentiments on matters relevant to their administrative area.

3.   S/he shall be directly responsible for the execution of all tasks prescribed for their administrative area by the Constitution of the SGA, the By-laws of the SGA, Acts of the SGA, or the President.

4.   S/he shall be responsible for submitting to the President and Senate, a written or verbal report on the activities and functions of their administrative area no less than once (1) every calendar month. In addition, any Senator may request a written or verbal report at any time.

5.   S/he shall serve as an ex-officio member of the Senate


Section 5: The Secretary of Public Relations and Recruitment By-Laws

Section 1	The Secretary of Public Relations and Recruitment shall:

Act as the President's media coordinator to the campus media and coordinate the SGA's distribution of information on campus. Furthermore, they must be responsible for press releases about SGA activities to campus news media organizations.

a. Be responsible for providing information on open positions in the SGA, Area Government, Faculty Senate, and Vice Chancellor’s Advisory Boards.

b. Maintain the SGA’s social media pages such as Campus Pulse, Facebook,  	Twitter, and Instagram.

i. Promotional posts may be created by the Secretary upon request, which shall be posted within one (1) business day unless a follow-up email is sent explaining the reason for delay or denial.

ii. Include regular updates about SGA on goings (examples include Senate meetings, Town Hall meetings, events, etc.)

iii. The Secretary will be responsible for live updates, via social media, during Senate meetings, highlighting announcements, reports, motions, and other important points.

Send out a monthly SGA newsletter to the Dean of Students to be forwarded to all SGA members, which highlights significant events and activities in the SGA.

Help the Chancellor of Elections market SGA Elections while maintaining viewpoint neutrality in regards to all individual campaigns when acting as Secretary of Public Relations and Recruitment.

Actively recruit SGA members to run for Senate seats and all open positions within the SGA.

Be responsible for organizing and coordinating the SGA’s involvement during the New Student Orientations, and during the semester.

This requires being present on campus during the summer for at least half of the summer’s NSO sessions.

Be a resource to RSOs for messaging and promotional help on events that promote a positive UMass image. 

Work with Area Governments, RHA, and any other relevant officials to organize outreach meetings, events and canvassing campaigns in the dorms, DC’s, and off-campus living areas to get input from and build relationships with students and to inform and educate students about existing campaigns
Work actively with the Secretary of Finance to establish and maintain a marketing budget for events and SGA promotional materials. 




Section 6: Questions about the Job

Why do you want to be Secretary of PR and Recruitment?

Do you have any expertise in Social Media platforms such as Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, etc...? 

Do you have experience working with digital graphics software such as Photoshop etc...? 

How do you view the SGA or more specifically reach out to the student body in general?

Have you ever been involved with RSO’s, Agencies, or other campus organizations PR efforts, and if so how?

If you were given the job of Secretary of PR and Recruitment today what would be you top 3 priorities, and how would you accomplish these key priorities?  

 Is there any other information that you would like to share with us that you feel we should know?

Section 5: The Secretary of the Registry By-Laws

Section 1 	The Secretary of the Registry shall:

1.   Act to effectively implement Title VII of the By-laws of the SGA.

2.   Be empowered to suspend the Charter of an RSO or agency which is in violation of the Constitution of the SGA, the By-laws of the SGA, or an Act of the SGA.

Act as the President’s liaison to Registered Student Organizations, Agencies, and Student Activities and Involvement.

Work to assist RSOs and Agencies in the advertisement of their events


Be directly responsible for the official Registered Student Organization records of the SGA including, but not limited to, the Charters and/or Constitutions of Registered Student Organizations. The Secretary of the Registry shall ensure that all RSOs and Agencies have their updated Charter/Constitution available on Campus Pulse.

Be an ex-officio member of the Administrative Affairs Committee and shall assist the committee with research and development of legislation.

Be responsible for assigning and maintaining student space in the Student Union, in accordance with Title VII. The Secretary shall be empowered to determine which student spaces shall be assigned to RSOs and Agencies as offices, and what space shall be assigned for other uses, including but not limited to RSO Storage Rooms and SGA-Student Conference Rooms.
The Secretary of the Registry shall be responsible for ensuring the upkeep of RSO and Agency offices after they are assigned.
The Secretary of the Registry shall be responsible for assigning and maintaining storage locker spaces dedicated to ESOs.
The Secretary of the Registry shall be responsible for the upkeep and scheduling of the SGA-Student Conference rooms.

9. Have the power to appoint an Undersecretary of the Registry. The Undersecretary of the Registry shall assist the Secretary in the carrying out of their duties and shall serve as an additional resource to RSOs.

Section 6: Questions about the Job

Why do you want to be Secretary of the Registry?

Do you have any prior experience working with RSOs or agencies on campus?

Section 5: The Secretary of Sustainability

Section 1      The Secretary of Sustainability shall:
1. Act as the liaison to the President for students, faculty and administration on all matters pertaining to the environment and offer advice to cabinet members for collaborative projects.

2. Serve as a liaison to, and help to coordinate the efforts of, the following groups
a. Sustainability Coordinator and the Sustainability Initiative
b. The Eco-Rep Program and any other student-led academic initiatives
c. Any environmentally-related Registered Student Organizations 
d. Any subsequent groups that emerge as leaders in campus sustainability
3. Chair the Sustainability Steering Committee (SSC)
Facilitate SSC votes on applications for the Sustainability, Innovation and Engagement Fund (SIEF)
4. Write legislation pertaining to environmental policy on campus.
5. Research current sustainability initiatives on campus, as well as potential initiatives that could bolster the University’s environmental sustainability.
6. Ensure that student and administrative environmental initiatives are communicated to the student body.
7. Be responsible for hiring and giving direction to the Bike Share Manager. 
The Bike Share Manager shall be responsible for the overseeing of the expansion, advertising, and day-to-day operations of the Bike Share Program, which shall include but not be limited to:
i. Maintaining waivers for the program. 
ii. Signing bikes in and out of the SGA office. 
iii. Coordinating advertising and social media marketing with the Secretary of Public Relations & Recruitment
iv. Ensuring bikes are maintained by implementing contracts between the Bike Share and Bike Co-op and following up on repairs and regular maintenance. 
v. Maintain the finances of the bike share program in conjunction with the Secretary of Finance, including the proposal of a yearly budget for the program.

Section 6: Questions for the Job


Why do you want to be Secretary of Suitability?

Do you have any prior experience working with campus stainability efforts, and if so what?

Do you have experience working with the SGA on issues related to the Game day challenge or Bike Share? 

How do you view the SGA or more specifically the Secretary of Sustainability can help the campus community?

Do you have any stability credentials, certificates, or trainings; and if so what are they?

If you were given the job of Secretary of Sustainability today what would be you top 3 priorities, and how would you accomplish these key priorities?  

 Is there any other information that you would like to share with us that you feel we should know?

DocsList.Name: SNA Transition Form.docx
DocsList.Data:
MAPPING OUT YOUR ORGANIZATION

Name of Organization: Student Nurses Association

Mission: 

The purpose of the Student Nurses Association is to: 

A. To assume responsibility for contributing to nursing education in order to provide for the highest quality of health care.

B. To provide programs representative of fundamental interests and concerns to nursing students.

C. To aid in the development of the whole person, his/her professional role, his/her responsibility for health care of people in all walks of life.

Executive Board Positions: 

President- Runs and plans meetings, discusses the budget with the Dean of the College of Nursing, organizes events, leads the board in making decisions about the organization.  Plans the budget for the National Student Nurses Association Convention, responsible holder of the credit card on this trip, and works with the dean of the College of Nursing and RSO to plan this trip. 

Current: Nicholas Morey
nmorey@umass.edu
(508) 631-5567
New (President-Elect): Amanda Poussard 
apoussard@umass.edu
(781) 484-8945

Vice President- Responsible for keeping track of the attendance each meeting, works with treasurer to keep track of who has paid their yearly dues, decorates the SNA board in the College of Nursing each year to keep the students aware of what the organization is involved in, provides support to the president, helps run and organize meetings and events. 

Current: Emily Cooper 
epcooper@umass.edu
(508) 963-2192 
New: Not yet elected 

Treasurer- Collect dues, organize fundraisers, deposit and manage funds.  

Current: Laura Morrissey
lemorrissey@umass.edu
(518) 813-0668
New (Treasurer- Elect): Katie Sullivan 
katrsullivan@umass.edu
(413) 682-4663

Secretary- Responsible for writing the minutes for each meeting, sharing the minutes with the members of the SNA, and informing the members of upcoming events and meetings via email. 

Current: Kate Price
kaprice@umass.edu
(913) 424-0849 
New: Not yet elected

Social Actions Coordinator- Responsible for working with organizations to plan events and volunteer opportunities.  

Current: Austin Houghton
ahoughton@umass.edu
(413) 297-9933 
New: Not yet elected


Election Process: 

Anyone is allowed to run for a position on the board as long as they have paid their yearly dues, attended at least two-thirds of the meetings during the year, and attended two minor events or one major event organized by the Student Nurses Association during that year.  The members of the Student Nurses Association are notified of the meeting during which the election will take place in advance.  Those running for a position on the board give a speech at the meeting and then the members present at the meeting vote.  The votes are collected by the current board and counted. The winner is then immediately announced. 

Transition Plan: 

The president and president-elect work closely throughout the semester, during which the president teaches the president-elect how to lead the Student Nurses Association and the details of their responsibilities.  The treasurer and treasurer-elect work together similarly throughout the year.  The newly elected vice president, secretary, and social actions coordinator are given guidance by those who have just held the position.  A binder containing the necessary information specific to each role is then passed down to each new members of the board.

DocsList.Name: Constitution of the Student Organization Resource Center.docx
DocsList.Data:
Student Organization Resource Center
Constitution

Article I: Name
The organization outlined in this constitution shall be called the Student Organization Resource Center hereafter referred to as SORC.

Free Speech and Non-Discrimination Clause
Rights to Free Speech
The University of Massachusetts is a public institution. Under the U.S. Constitution, certain rights are guaranteed when faculty and staff interact with students. The Constitutional aspects of the university/student relationship are especially implicated in the context of First Amendment rights of free speech and freedom to associate.

Non-Discrimination 
The University of Massachusetts Amherst prohibits discrimination on the basis of race, color, religion, creed, sex, age, marital status, national origin, mental or physical disability, political belief or affiliation, veteran status, sexual orientation, gender identity and expression, genetic information and any other class of individuals protected from discrimination under state or federal law in any aspect of the access to, admission, or treatment of students in its programs and activities, or in employment and application for employment. Furthermore, University policy includes prohibitions of harassment of students and employees, i.e., racial harassment, sexual harassment, and retaliation for filing complaints of discrimination. 

Article II: Purpose 
Aim
The SORC is the first stop for Established Student Organizations questions and support. The SORC is staffed by students trained in skills to support ESOs and their members. Many of the student staff members are members and leaders of ESOs themselves and they have firsthand knowledge of what is needed to function as an ESO here at UMass.  
Objectives 
The SORC will provide resources for ESOs to plan and coordinate their events, requesting services that ESOs need in order for them to successfully and effectively execute their events.  
The SORC will provide ESOs access to their fee and revenue funds, in order for them to purchase resources that are essential for them to successfully achieve their organization’s mission.  
The SORC will receive, log and manage ESO packages and mails. The SORC also provides printing services and various other resources so ESOs can build marketing materials for their organization such as bulletin boards.
The SORC staff will provide SA&I documents and forms.
The SORC staff will manage the calendars of both Student Activities and Involvement Advisors, and the Business Center Office Account Specialist.
The SORC will provide Tix services for ESO events.  
The SORC will provide ESO access to book the SORC’s conference room, and the SORC’s common space. 
Article III: Use of Name and Logo

The use of the name or logo of the Student Organization Resource Center for any purpose other than official business is prohibited unless approved by the SORC’s manager/director.

Article IV: Structure and Organization

Structure
The SORC shall consist of a Manager, Graduate Assistant, Event Consultants, and Organizations Resource Specialists.
The SORC manager will hire a Graduate Assistant, the Event Consultants, and the Organizational Resource Specialists.  
Organization 
SORC Staff meetings shall be held once weekly throughout the academic year, unless extenuating circumstances require an alteration in scheduling. 
Article V: Role of the SORC Manager

Job Summary
Under the general supervision of the Associate Director of Student Activities and Involvement (SAI), oversee peer advising of student organization leaders in all aspects of event planning and organizational development, including training students to provide programming support to Established Student Organizations (ESOs). Responsible for overseeing and managing the Student Organization Resource Center (SORC). Serve as a generalist and work as team member in all areas of SAI, including the development of campus-wide programs and events, advising student organizations, and training of student leaders.
Primary Responsibility 
Oversee and manage operation of the SORC, providing organizational and event planning advising, resources, and services to over 300 established student organizations (ESOs) and to SAI staff, for example: develop annual budget, utilize Pro-Card for purchases, approve invoice payment, maintain financial records; develop, implement, and adhere to related procedures and policies; maintain inventory of office and event supplies; supervise staff and office on a day-to-day basis; assess and report on ESO status; submit recommendations for removal of ESO recognition to SGA; establish long-term goals.
 Hire, train, and supervise student assistant manager, event consultants (ECO), and organization resource specialists (ORS) to staff the SORC for approximately 60 hours weekly during the academic year. Evaluate job performance of SORC student employees. 
Oversee all aspects of routine ESO event planning: assess and approve events for needs and parameters; determine venue requirements and arrange for space and services; ensure compliance with university policy; assess risk and implement related risk management strategies; conduct contract negotiations, prepare contracts, submit high cost and/or more complicated contracts for approval; and oversee post-event assessment.
Supervise event cash handling procedures and operations and event ticket pre-sales for all ESO events, including deposits. Establish and evaluate related policies and risk management procedures; supervise ticketing staff; and implement ticketing software.
 Plan and implement campus-wide programming including First Week, Homecoming, UMass Night Out, and New Students Orientation as a member of the Student Activities Team. Participate in staff on-call rotation and supervision of night and weekend events.
Manage and oversee implementation of software programs and social media utilized by SAI for ESOs, including Campus Pulse, University Tickets, and social media platforms; implement marketing strategies, as set by committee, that relate to social media. Train users in coordination with Assistant Director for RSO
Other Responsibilities
Performs related duties as assigned or required to meet Department, Executive Area/Division, and University goals and objectives.
Understands responsibilities with respect to Title IX, Cleary and other compliance requirements. 
Demonstrates capacity, skill and willingness to engage students and contribute to student success.

Article VI: Role of the Graduate Assistant of the SORC 

Job Summary and Primary Responsibilities
A member of Student Activities and Involvement (SAI), the Graduate Assistant for Student Organization Resources will manage and supervise student staff of the Student Organization Resource Center (SORC) providing support and information to Established Student Organizations (ESOs) and SAI staff. Oversee social media and marking initiatives for SAI and the SORC. Oversee the event development process by working closely with ESOs and ECOs. Assess support and resource needs of ESOs and SAI customers on an ongoing basis working closely with SAI event coordinator, other staff, and ESOs; process and implement ways to meet those needs.
Article VII: Role of the Assistant Manager of Operations of the SORC 

Job Summary
This position is designed to create a substantial leadership experience for individuals looking forward to further develop their supervisory and strategic thinking skills. The person holding this position will assist on the Organization Resource Specialists operations supervised by the SORC Graduate Assistant.
Primary Responsibilities
Supervise Organization Resource Specialist and ensure that the daily operations of the ORSs run smoothly and efficiently.
Schedule staff meetings for ORs and ECO. 
Assist SORC GA in conducting the ORS staff meeting.
Attending biweekly meeting with SORC GA 
Monitoring the supplemental hours and TIX shift.


Article VIII: Role of the Assistant Manager of Event Logistics

Job Summary
This position is designed to create a substantial leadership experience for individuals looking to further develop their supervisory and strategic thinking skills. The person holding this position will work as an integral part of the Student Activities and Involvement operations team and will collaborate with professional staff members within the department and across campus to create positive relationships and drive future initiatives.
Primary Responsibilities
Supervise Event Consultants and ensure that the daily operations of the Events Team (Event Consultants, Scheduling Assistant, and Scheduling Coordinator) run smoothly and efficiently.
Assist Event Consultants with providing event development support for ESOs and GSOs.
Serve as liaison between the SORC and Student Activities and Involvement and pertinent Campus Center staff (i.e., meet regularly with Campus Center Events Office and their supervisor).
Overseeing the event ticket staffing operation including creating event bags and schedules for upcoming events to ensure all requests for ticketing are met.
Attending a weekly individual meeting with the Operations Manager.
Serve as liaison for campus partners (including UMass Catering, Campus Center Events Office, UMass Police Department, Physical Plant, Fine Arts Center, etc.).
Generate event-related reports including cash variance reports, weekly TIX reports, and monthly events calendar.
Conduct meetings with Event Consultants and Events Team.
Along with Operations Manager, provide periodic staff development in-service trainings.
Providing ongoing assessments of event ticketing and events consulting operations and make appropriate recommendations for improvements to the Operations Manager.
Provide event support (i.e., First Week Events, fall and spring ESOs Expos, special events in the SORC, etc.).
Must be available to work evening and weekend TIX events.
Other duties as assigned.
Article IX: Role of the Organization Resource Specialist of the SORC
Job Summary
The Student Development Specialist serves as a liaison between ESOs leaders and SAI staff and assists ESOs in the completion of daily business.
Primary Responsibilities
Under the supervision of the Graduate Assistant, works directly with Established Student Organizations (ESOs) leaders, members, and the campus community through face-to-face, electronic, and telephone interactions
Resolves ESOs requests, questions and complaints- frequently requiring analysis of situations to determine best use of resources
Assists ESOs in the completion of purchase order forms, SASP card requests, and other ESO forms as necessary
Maintain and update online schedule for Student Activities and Involvement Advisors and Account Specialists
Sells pre-sale and in-person tickets for ESO events and is responsible for appropriate cash-handling and event cash reconciliation
Responsible for distribution of incoming ESO packages, mail, and other items as need
Maintains database of ESO lock boxes and bulletin board keys, to ensure protocols and procedures are upheld
Updates the Campus Pulse website with pertinent ESO information, notification of events, and assists ESOs with event and space requests as needed
Posts flyers for upcoming ESO, Student Activities and Involvement, Housing, and other departments events and programming
Assists with Established Student Organization Training planning, facilitation, and attendance sheets
Provide event support (i.e., First Week Events, fall and spring ESO Expos, special events in the SORC, etc.)
Other duties as assigned
Article X: Role of Event Consultant of the SORC
Job Summary
The Event Consultant assists ESO leaders with event planning and connecting them with the appropriate campus and external resources to make their event a success.
Primary Responsibilities
Under the supervision of the Graduate Assistant, assists ESO leaders in preparing paperwork for event development. Completes paperwork for assigned events and meets with ESOs when necessary. Reviews and advises ESOs on event budgets.
Upholds all policies and procedures for ESO event planning as outlined in the SR training and the Event Management Manual.
Maintains event computer and paper files following a prescribed system for event development and management; enters data in computer files.
Must be available to work evening and weekend TIX events.
Occasionally work as front desk receptionist (based on office schedule and SDS availability; for duties and responsibilities, please see description below)
Provide event support (i.e., First Week Events, fall and spring ESO Expos, special events in the SORC, etc.)
Sells pre-sale and in-person tickets for ESO events and is responsible for appropriate cash-handling and event cash reconciliation
Other duties as assigned.
Secondary responsibilities
Works directly with Established Student Organization (ESO) leaders, members, and the campus community through face-to-face, electronic, and telephone interactions
Resolves ESO requests, questions and complaints- frequently requiring analysis of situations to determine best use of resources
Assists ESOs in the completion of purchase order forms, SASP card requests, and other ESO forms as necessary
Maintain and update online schedule for SAI Advisors and Business Center Account Specialists
Responsible for distribution of incoming ESO packages, mail, and other items as need
Maintains database of ESO lock boxes and bulletin board keys, to ensure protocols and procedures are upheld
Updates the Campus Pulse website with pertinent ESO information, notification of events, and assists ESOs with event and space requests as needed
Posts flyers for upcoming ESO, Student Engagement, Housing, and other departments events and programming
Assists with Established Student Organization (ESO) orientation planning, facilitation, and attendance sheets
Article XI: Role of Tix Representatives
Job Summary
Tix Representatives assists ESOs during their events with wrist bands distribution, cash handling, reconciliation and deposits of their events.
Primary Responsibilities
Tix Representatives shall sign up for a minimum of 3 shifts per semester.
Manage cash registers during an event.
Manage and distribute Online and comp list tickets during an event.
Manage and distribute wrist bands during an event.

Article XII: Finances
Fiscal Management 
At the end of the fall semester the SORC Manager will work with the Graduate Assistant to create a budget request for the next fiscal year to submit to the Student Government Association in the spring semester. 
Monetary Compensation for Undergraduate Staff
Payroll begins fall semester and ends the last day of classes for spring semester. Minimum wage pay for ten to twenty (10-20) hours per week, depending of the position. 
Article XIII: Undergraduate Staff Job Applications
Hired Positions
SORC Manager shall re-hire all ORS, ECO and Tix Representative positions every spring semester, and whenever its vacant.
Article XIV: Student Organization Resource Center Advisory Board
Purpose
It is the purpose of the SORCAB to insure that the SORC is responsive to the varied needs of both undergraduate and graduate registered student organizations. The SORCAB shall be responsible for effective functioning of the SORC with regard to the mission and goals stated herein. 
Membership
Student Members
There shall be five (5) undergraduate student members of the SORCAB. The President of Student Government Association or his or her representative shall be a member.  The President of Student Government Association shall appoint four (4) undergraduate students to the SORCAB. These members will represent RSOs’ concerns about their needs, and the effectiveness of the SORC’s service. 
There shall be three (3) graduate student members of the SORCAB. The President of the Graduate Student Senate or his or her representative shall be a member. The Graduate Student Senate, subject to majority consent of the Graduate Student Senate, shall appoint two (2) graduate students to SORCAB. These members will represent GSOs’ concerns about their needs, and the effectiveness of the SORC’s service. 
Other Members
The Executive Director of Student Engagement shall appoint one (1) professional staff of the Student Activities and to the SORCAB. The professional staff or his or her representative will represent Student Activities and Involvement concerns’ about their needs, and the effectiveness of the SORC.
The SORC Manager shall be a member of the SORCAB. The SORC Manager will represent the SORC’s administrative concerns and needs.
There shall be two (2) undergraduate student staff of the SORC members of the SORCAB. The Assistant Manager of Events Logistics or his or her representative shall be a member, and the Assistant Manager of Operations or his or her representative shall be members in the SORCAB. Both Assistant Managers will represent SORC’s staff concern and their needs in order to effectively provide service to student groups.
The Director of Business Center or his or her representative shall be a member of SORCAB. The Director or his or her representative will represent the SORC’s financial needs and concerns, and its effectiveness. 
The Director of Sales and Marketing for Auxiliary Enterprises or his or her representative shall be a member in the SORCAB. The Director of Sales and Marketing for Auxiliary Enterprises will represent the Events Office’s concerns and needs from the SORC.
All student, faculty, administrator shall have voting power.
All members shall assume their duties at the first meeting of the SORCAB following their appointment. The Student Government and Graduate Student Senate Presidents are responsible for notifying the Chairperson in writing of the names effective appointments dates of their representatives.
All members shall serve a one (1) year term and may be reappointed.
Recall appointments.
The student, faculty, administrative, and attorney members may be called by a two-third (2/3) vote of all members of the SORCAB.
Officers
There shall be a Chairperson of the SORCAB selected from among the members. He or she shall be the chief executive officer of the SORCAB. The Chairperson shall be responsible for the calling of meetings and shall be the primary contact between the SORCAB, Executive Director of Student Engagement, the University administration, and between the SORCAB and the respective student governments. 
There shall be a Secretary/Treasurer of the SORCAB selected from among the student members. The Secretary/Treasurer shall be responsible for the recording and distribution of minutes, and the maintenance of all SORCAB minutes and records. 
Officers may be recalled by a two-thirds (2/3) vote of the SORCAB for significant documented dereliction of duties at a meeting where quorum shall be seven (7) members. 
Article XV: Amending the Constitution
The SORC Constitution may be amended by a 2/3 vote of the Advisory Board membership at a regularly scheduled meeting.

Using Feedback in Interpersonal Relationships.pdf
DocsList.Data:
USING FEEDBACK IN RELATIONSHIPS1 

Givers 

• Voluntary 
• Immediate (or soon) 
• Descriptive of behavior (what the person does) 
• Specific 
• Constructive intent 
• Changeable focus 
• Owned (I feel____when you do_____) 
• Message sent is checked for clarity 
• Seeks information about the other person’s intentions. 

Receivers 

• Requested (or allowed) 
• Specify areas you wish to receive feedback 
• Assert your own personal needs 
• Recognize the risk involved for the other person 
• Message heard is reflected back to the giver and checked for clarity as needed 
• Change behavior (or not) 

= = NOT: 

• Attacking 
• Defending 
• Avoiding 

        = = WORK THAT IS INVOLVED: 

• Openness to learn 
• Helping others learn 
• Respecting different cultural and communication styles 
• Safety issues 
• Managing strong reactions/emotions 
• Acknowledging power dynamics 
• Checking with others 
• Modeling 
• Trust self and others 
• Practice 

1 Ximena Zúñiga (1997), Social Justice Education, UMass-Amherst   
Adapted from Mark Chesler (1993), University of Michigan Ann Arbor.

DocsList.Name: Key_Concepts_for_Interactive_Communication.pdf
DocsList.Data:
Key Concepts for Interactive Communication1 

Key Concepts & Examples: 
Active Listening – Listening without interrupting. Listening without judging or reacting to what is 
being said. Communicating attentiveness to the speaker with your facial expression and other non-
verbal behaviors (nodding ones head, eye contact, attentive body posture, etc.). The main goal is 
hearing and receiving a message with understanding. 

Purposeful Sending – Giving out a message in a way that allows the intended message to be heard. 

Paraphrasing – Stating what you heard using your own words so that the speaker knows the message 
was received. At times you may need to ask clarifying questions to be sure you know what has been 
said. 

Examples of Paraphrasing: 

I heard you say that ______________ 
From what you said, it sounds like you felt _______________ 

Example of Asking Clarifying Questions: 

When you said _______________ did you mean _______ or __________? 

Feedback – Information to speaker about the effectiveness of communication by describing an 
observed act of communication or behavior without judging the message or the person. It is specific. It 
is both affirming (positive) and constructive (about something you would like changed). 

Feedback to the Speaker and/or Listener 

I noticed that you did ___ when I or ____ said __________ 
I felt heard when you said ___________ or did ____________. 
I wasn’t sure if you had heard me when I said ________or did_________. 
When you said/did ___________I felt_____________ because _________. 
When you said/did ____________ I felt____________ 

Roles: 
Speaker – Sends a message to the listener using symbols that convey ideas and feelings. This message 
includes both unconscious and conscious symbols that can be verbal as well as  non-verbal. 

Listener – Hears what the speaker says and responds to the messages by paraphrasing or asking 
clarifying questions as a way of providing feedback to the speaker about the reception of the message 
heard. 

Observer – Observes how the speaker and listener communicate verbally and non-verbally. Focuses on 
the use of words, actions or reactions of speaker and listener. Seeks to provide concise and descriptive 
feedback to role of the speaker and listener in interactive communication, not judging or evaluating.  

1 Zúñiga, X. & Cytron-Walker, A. (2003). Exploring differences & common ground. Social Justice 

Education Concentration. University of Massachusetts Amherst.   Adapted from Bidol, P. (1986). 
Interactive Communication. In I. Bardwell, P. Bidol, & N. Manning (Eds.), Alternative Environmental 
Conflict Management Approaches: A Citizen’s Model. Ann Arbor School of Natural Resources (pp. 
205-208). Ann Arbor, MI: University of Michigan School of Natural Resources. 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
                                                 
 
 Directions for Active Listening & Feedback Activity  

•  Step 1: Participants to take a few minutes to think about the questions posted 

on newsprint and jot down some thoughts as needed (@ 2-3 minutes) 

•  Step 2: Speaker speaks without interruption focusing on purposeful sending 

(@ 3 minutes) 

•  Step 3:Listener actively listens and paraphrases in his or her own words what 
s/he heard so the speaker knows the message was received; asks clarifying 
questions if needed (see examples on Key Concepts for Interactive 
Communication handout)  (@ 3 minutes). 

•  Step 4: Speaker and Listener check in and talk about how was to speak and 

listen (@ 2 minutes) 

•  Step 5: Observer shares descriptive observations of verbals and non-verbals 
and (words, actions, reactions that communicate purposeful sending and 
actively listening and paraphrasing).  Jotting down notes while speaker and 
listener are interacting enhances the role o the observer (@ 3 minutes) 

•  Step 6: Speaker, Listener and Observer compare notes and debrief (@ 3 

minutes) 

•  Step 7: Switch roles (and switch roles again until you complete the 3 rounds).

DocsList.Name: SiGN_Constitution_Updated_FALL2016.docx
DocsList.Data:
Constitution of Students In Graduate Nutrition (SIGN)
Name.
A. The official name of this club shall be "Students in Graduate Nutrition” (SIGN)

Purpose
The purpose of SIGN to build community and cohesiveness within the department, network with our student peers and faculty members, and create a platform for more exposure to professional and career development within nutrition.

Membership
A. Membership in this club shall be open to all University of Massachusetts Amherst Department of Nutrition graduate students regardless of age, sex, race, religion, color, creed, national origin, and handicap or veteran status. A “voting” member must attend at least one meeting per semester.

Election of Officers
A. The SIGN offices are voluntary. A person may nominate him/herself
for a position. If there is more than one nomination for a position, then the SIGN
members will vote on a secret ballot through campus pulse. 
The position will be given to the person with the
majority of the votes. The offices are president, vice president, secretary, treasurer, and website/media relations manager. The GSS Senator may also participate in the officer meetings and vote as part of the executive board. Each office is held for one academic year, or 1 semester if club starts/re-starts mid-year. Elections for following academic year will be held in early April and done through GSS campus pulse election system. If an officer graduates in December, a special election will be held to fill the position for the remainder of the academic year.

Executive Board
A. President
The president will be responsible for creating a
semester meeting schedule and possibly maintaining a Google calendar. The president will be responsible with the vice president and grad student liaison for recruiting and organizing guest speakers.
The president and treasurer will be responsible for room reservations for official events. The president and vice president will be responsible for disseminating or organizing any scholarship information, academic workshops, etc. to SIGN The president will be responsible for coordinating the elections for the upcoming year. President shall have signature responsibility and attend all financial trainings. The president will maintain the web page Campus Pulse and the email mailing list of members and contacts. The secretary will be responsible for advertising the meetings (once at the beginning of the semester, and prior to each meeting via email to the mailing list).
B. Treasurer
The treasurer will be responsible for the accounting and have signature responsibility and attend all financial trainings. The treasurer will keep a log of the
SIGN’s monetary activities, grouped by semester. The treasurer will be
responsible for reimbursements (including, but not limited to, food and supplies). The treasurer will be responsible with the president for room reservations for official events. The treasurer will be responsible for the monetary transactions regarding any fundraising. 
C. Secretary
The secretary will be responsible for all meeting minutes. The secretary will keep a record of each official club event and send minutes to the mailing list about what occurred at the event. 
The secretary will have shared responsibility for advertising fundraisers. Secretary will also be “vibes” watcher in meeting and facilitate diplomatic communication between members and board members.

D. GSS Senate Representative/Event Coordinator Joint Role
The senator will acts as a liaison between the Graduate Student Senate and SIGN, as well as be responsible correspondence contact person for all events and PR activities on campus. Responsible for e-mail correspondence with guest speakers.

E. Media Relations Specialist
The media relations specialist will be responsible for maintaining the online persona of the Facebook page for the organization. 

Committees/Subcommittees
Temporary committees may be created at the discretion of the organization and must consist of at least three (3) members.

Meetings
A. Meetings will be held a minimum of three times per semester. Each meeting will start
with a summary of the previous meeting (given by the secretary) and a summary of the SIGN monetary usage (given by the treasurer).
B. Notification of all club meetings should be posted at least three (3) days in advance of
Meeting on e-mail and posters.

Amendments
After original constitution is constructed, any amendments may be amended by two-thirds (2/3) of the voting members. Any Voting member may propose an amendment that will then be voted on at the following general meeting, after which an accepted amendment must be filed with the GSS.

DocsList.Name: Constitution 2023-2024.pdf
DocsList.Data:
Charter for the University of Massachusetts, Amherst’s
Students to End Alzheimer’s Disease
Adopted November 1st, 2023 in Amherst, Massachusetts through unanimous decision.

Mission Statement

SEAD (Student’s to End Alzheimer’s Disease) is a student-led organization dedicated to raising
awareness about Alzheimer's disease, advocating for Alzheimer's research and support, and working
towards the goal of ending Alzheimer's disease. SEAD’s mission is to be educative, to inform the student
body on the nature of the disease as well as advances and efforts within the world of Alzheimer’s
research. Actively working towards the promotion of brain health throughout the greater campus,
members of UMass Amherst SEAD will actively participate in club meetings – both entertaining and
didactic –, participate in volunteerism, fundraising, as well as advocacy. We firmly believe the people of
Amherst, the students within the Five-Colleges, and those living within the Berkshire community deserve
an outlet of knowledge and understanding on this fatal disease and we intend to serve as just that,

 working
to make a positive impact by increasing public understanding of Alzheimer's and promoting efforts to find
a cure or improve the quality of life for those living with the condition.

Membership
I. All students at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst, those in surrounding Five Colleges, as

well as the general public shall be eligible for membership to UMass SEAD.

A. However, only University of Massachusetts, Amherst students have the ability to vote on

club proceedings, in any capacity, and amendments.

II. Membership shall be established after a prospective member has attended two meetings and

informs the Secretary that they wish to be an established member.

Meetings

A. UMass SEAD will conduct general meetings on a weekly to biweekly basis. B. The
President will chair meetings, unless otherwise designated by the President themselves. C. The
purpose of the meetings will be:

a. Planning activities, fundraising events/initiatives
b. Group bonding
c. Educative meetings to discuss Alzheimer’s disease, Alzheimer’s research, etc. (any

informative Alzheimer’s related topic)

d. Other topics deemed necessary (permitting room for less structured club meetings, when

necessary/reasonable)

D. SEAD board members emphasize the importance of allowing these meetings to be a safe space

for both asking questions as well as sharing information or related anecdotes. Respectful, honest
conversation is at the core of our beliefs.

E. Decisions of importance will be made at the meetings by a majority vote of the general

membership.

a. Quorum (50% + 1) of the current, active voting membership must be present in order for

votes to be taken

A. The officers of UMass Amherst SEAD shall be:

Executive Board

a. President (Co-Presidents are permissible, if deemed reasonable)
b. Vice President (Co-Vice Presidents are permissible, if deemed reasonable)
c. Treasurer
d. Secretary
e. Events and Media Coordinator

B. Each officer shall serve a one-year term, starting the day after the last day of classes in the Spring

semester (or the earliest possible date)

a. If unable to fill the role by this specified date, the officer’s term will begin on the earliest
possible date. The term will continue to end on the original specified date, therefore the
officer will simply serve a truncated term.

 C. Officers shall be eligible for re-election to serve multiple terms; therefore, term limit durations are

dependent solely upon reelection results.

D. The President:

a. The President shall be the Chief Executive Officer of UMass Amherst SEAD. b.
They will be responsible for all aspects pertaining to the functioning of the group. c.
The President shall have Signature Responsibility.
d. The President is responsible for collaboration with the Student Government Association

and assumes responsibility for the actions of other executive members.

E. The Vice President:

a. The Vice President shall be the second in command of the RSO.
b. The Vice President shall take over for the President when they are not present. c. The
Vice President shall be the liaison between SEAD and the SGA, Student Activities and
Involvement, and other campus offices.
d. Co-Vice presidency is permissible with specifics on role distinction up to the discretion of

the President.

F. The Treasurer

a. The Treasurer shall be the Chief Financial Officer of the RSO.
b. The Treasurer shall be responsible for maintaining the group’s finances.
c. The Treasurer shall be responsible for submitting an annual budget request to the SGA, if

necessary.

d. The Treasurer shall have Signature Responsibility, for requests involving finances. This
responsibility comes only after the President’s approval of the request or if they are
unavailable to make such approvals.

G. The Secretary:

a. The Secretary shall be responsible for maintaining all records for SEAD. i. This includes,

but not limited to, all minutes, advertising, fundraising materials, inquiries, and all
other documents relevant to the functioning of the group.
ii. ii. These records should, in all possible cases, be kept confidential and be collected
electronically. The documents shall be passed on from current to future
Secretary during the transition period.

b. The Secretary shall record minutes at all official group meetings.
c. The Secretary shall maintain up-to-date membership lists.

H. The Events and Media Coordinator:

a. The Events and Media Coordinator shall be responsible for maintaining the group’s social

media accounts and publications as well as Campus Pulse Pages.

The President must approve all post or email updates prior to publication.

b. The Events and Media Coordinator shall create events for the members to participate in.
c. The Events and Media Coordinator shall organize the volunteer opportunities for the
members.

Officer Elections
A. Officer elections for the upcoming academic year shall take place during the month of April.
B. Officer elections shall take place in two stages:

 a. The nomination meeting and the online election.

C. The nomination meeting shall be the first meeting in April.
D. The Executive Board shall announce the exact date, time, and location of the nomination meeting

no later than two weeks prior.

E. The nomination meeting will be run according to the following procedure:
a. Any non-election business shall be dealt with first.

b. Once all other business is taken care of, the President shall publicly announce

nominations to be open.

c. During the nomination period, any voting member shall be granted one singular vote, for
each role, of which they are permitted to designate to any candidate, even themselves. i.
Any voting member may only be nominated to one position.

d. In order for the nomination to be official, it shall need to be seconded by another voting

member.

e. The nomination period shall remain open until motion is made, seconded, and approved

by a unanimous consent, to close nominations.

f. After the nomination period is closed, the President will read from the minutes the names
of the candidates who have been nominated. Each nominee/member may then elect
whether or not to accept or reject their nomination.

g. All nominees that have accepted the nomination will be given the opportunity to address
the general membership for 5 minutes, and to take questions from the membership for 5
minutes. The nominees for President will go first, followed by the Vice President,
Treasurer, and Secretary. The nominees will present first by position and then by the
order in which they were nominated.

F. The second phase of the election shall be the online election period, and it shall adhere to the

following procedure:

a. Directly following the nominating meeting, the Secretary shall set up an election on the

group’s Campus Pulse page. They shall include only the names of the members that have
been nominated at the nomination meeting and consequently accepted said invitation;
only nominated members will be elected.

b. The election shall be open from the day after the nomination meeting to the day prior to
the next scheduled meeting (ensuring ample time is provided; at least one week). c.
Following the close of the election period, the Secretary shall prepare an election report,
including the winners and the total vote counts for each candidate. The President and
Secretary, at the meeting directly following the close of elections, shall present this report.
The Secretary shall also view the vote report available on Campus Pulse to ensure that only
voting members have voted. If any non-member voted, the election will be deemed invalid
and the election period will be re-done, under the supervision of the Secretary of the
Registry.

i. The Secretary may seek assistance from the Student Activities and Involvement
Center of the Secretary of the Registry for any Campus Pulse or election related
issues.

d. The Executive Board shall use the time in between the election and the end of their terms

to train the newly elected officers.

e. The newly elected officers shall take power following the final day of classes of the

 Spring semester.

f. If any issues arise during this process, or if any member wishes to appeal the results, the

question may be taken by any member or officer to the Student Judiciary

Removal of Officers

A. Any officer may be impeached from office for failure to perform the duties of their office or for

conduct detrimental to the club or its ambitions.

B. The following procedure must be followed in order to impeach an officer: a. A motion must be

made and seconded during an official and regularly scheduled general body meeting to
impeach an officer.
b. At the following general body meeting, the member making the motion of impeachment
shall have 15 minutes to present their case against the officer. This shall be the time to
present any evidence and/or witness relevant to impeachment. These 15 minutes shall not
be interrupted for any reason, other than if the petitioner decides to take questions from
membership.

c. Following the presentation of evidence from the petitioner, the accused officer will have
15 minutes to present their defense and any evidence or witnesses they wish. These 15
minutes shall not be interrupted for any reason, other than if the officer decides to take
questions from membership.

d. Following the presentations from the petitioner and the officer, a vote shall be taken.

Two-thirds of the general membership must vote in favor of impeachment in order for an
officer to be removed.

e. If the voting results in impeachment, the officer shall immediately surrender their office.
f. If the officer in question is the President, the meeting in which the impeachment took
place shall then be chaired by the Vice President.
g. If any issues arise during this process, or if either party wishes to appeal the results, the

question may be taken by any member or officer to the Student Judiciary.

Officer Vacancies
A. If the President resigns or is impeached, the Vice President/Co-Vice Presidents shall immediately

take over as President.

a. If there is a Co-President, said co-president will assume sole presidential role. B. If the
Vice President, Treasurer, or Secretary resigns or is impeached, a special election shall be held for
the position, following the same procedures as enumerated in “Officer Election” section of this
charter.
C. The remaining members of the Executive Board shall schedule a special election at a regularly

scheduled meeting between one and three weeks from the date in which the officer role becomes
vacant. The Secretary shall inform the general membership of the date of the special election no
less than one week prior.

D. Degree of immediate transparency to general membership will be assessed on a case-to-case

basis.

Resolving Disputes

 A. Disputes arising between members on matters of RSO policy shall be dealt with through majority

votes of the general membership.

B. Disputes arising between members on other matters shall be dealt with through mediation. a.

Mediation consists of a meeting involving both parties and a mediator with the purpose of
coming to a solution and putting the issue to rest.
b. The President shall mediate disputes between members.
c. Should the President be involved in the dispute, or should either party not be satisfied by
the result of the mediation, any party may request that the Secretary of the Registry mediate.
The results of mediation with the Secretary of Registry shall be final.

Free Speech
A. All members of UMass Amherst SEAD are entitled and welcomed to embrace freedom of speech

and consequently will not, under any circumstances, be deprived of the opportunity to voice an
opinion with the group. Derivation from our strict policy against discrimination, in any form, will
result in immediate expulsion from the club – regardless of position held or length of
membership.

Amendment
A. This charter may be amended by a 2/3 vote of the general membership at any regularly scheduled

meeting.

B. A motion to amend may be made and seconded by any member at a meeting of the general

membership. The motion shall be presented at the meeting in which the motion is made. Voting
on the motion shall take place at the following meeting. Prior to voting, the President shall allow
for a period of debate.

a. After being approved by the membership, the amendment itself, and an updated version
of the charter, shall be submitted to the Secretary of the Registry for final approval.

2023-2024 Semester Executive Board
President: Benjamin Brown, Political Science and Spanish (Pre-Law), Class of 2024
Co-Vice President: Danial Khan, Computer Science, Class of 2024
Co-Vice President: Sophia Tsekov, Biomedical Engineering (Pre-Med), Class of 2024
Treasurer: Yana Djotova, Computer Science, Class of 2025
Secretary: Joshua Altman, Mechanical Engineering and Mathematics, Class of 2025
Events and Media Coordinator: Emily Cooper, Computer Science and OIM, Class of
2024
