Charter for the University of Massachusetts’
Students to End Alzheimer’s Disease

Adopted August 1, 2015 in Amherst, Massachusetts

Mission Statement

The mission of UMass Students to End Alzheimer’s Disease is to educate the student body
of the advances and efforts within the world of Alzheimer’s disease. While promoting brain
health throughout campus, members of UMass SEAD will actively participate in
volunteerism, outreach, and advocacy all while supporting the Alzheimer’s Association and
relating societies in their mission to end Alzheimer’s disease and related
neurodegenerative disorders. We believe the people of Amherst, the students within the
Five-Colleges, and those living within Berkshire community deserve an outlet of knowledge
and understanding surrounding this fatal disease. We intend to hold fundraising events to
support the research efforts and care costs of those affected, participate in health-related
walks and host educational events on campus. These efforts will provide an outlet for the
student body to gain understanding and support of Alzheimer’s disease and other
dementias.
I. Membership

 A. All students at the University of Massachusetts, students at the surrounding Five
Colleges and the general public shall be eligible to be members of UMass SEAD. I.
However, only University of Massachusetts, Amherst students have  the ability to
vote.
B. Membership shall be established after a prospective member has attended two meetings
and informs the Secretary that they wish to be an established member.

II. Meetings

A. UMass SEAD will conduct general meetings on a monthly basis.
B. The President will chair meetings.
C. The purpose of weekly meetings will be:

1. Planning Activities, future fundraising, etc.
2. Group bonding
3. Updates on Alzheimer’s research and triumphs in the field
4. Story-Sharing relating to Alzheimer’s (caregiver/familial

experience, etc)

5. Other topics deemed necessary

D. Decisions of importance will be made at the meetings by a majority vote of the
general membership.

1. Quorum (50% + 1) of the voting membership must be present in

order for votes to be taken.

III. The Executive Board

A. The officers of UMass SEAD shall be:

1. President
2. Vice President
3. Treasurer
4. Secretary
5. Events and Media Coordinator

B. Each officer shall serve a one-year term, starting the day after the last day of classes

in the Spring semester.

C. Officers shall be eligible for re-election to serve multiple terms.
D. The President

1. The President shall be the Chief Executive Officer of UMass SEAD. He or she

will be responsible for all aspects of the functioning of the group.

2. The President shall have Signature Responsibility.

3. The President is responsible for collaboration with the Student Government

Association and for the actions of the other executive members.

 E. The Vice President

1. The Vice President shall be the second in command of the RSO.
2. The Vice President shall take over for the President when he or she is not

present.

3. The Vice President shall be the liaison between SEAD and the SGA, Student

Activities and Involvement, and other campus offices.

F. The Treasurer

1. The Treasurer shall be the Chief Financial Officer of the RSO.
2. The Treasurer shall be responsible for maintaining the group’s finances.  3.
The Treasurer shall be responsible for submitting an annual budget request  to
the SGA, if necessary.
4. The Treasurer shall have Signature Responsibility, for requests involving

finances. This responsibility comes only after the President is unavailable or
has approved of the request.

G. The Secretary

1. The Secretary shall be responsible for maintaining all records for SEAD.
i. This is including but not limited to, all minutes, advertising,

fundraising materials, inquiries, and all other documents relevant to
the functioning of the group.

ii. These records should, in all possible cases, be kept confidential and be
collected electronically. The documents shall be passed on from

current to the future Secretary during the transition period.

2. The Secretary shall record minutes at all official group meetings.
3. The Secretary shall maintain up-to-date membership lists.

H. The Events and Media Coordinator

1. The Events and Media Coordinator shall create events for the members to

participate in.

2. The Events and Media Coordinator shall organize the volunteer

opportunities for the members.

3. The Events and Media Coordinator shall be responsible for maintaining the

group’s social media and Campus Pulse Pages.

i. The President prior to posting must approve of all social media

updates.

IV. Officer Elections

1. Officer elections for the upcoming academic year shall take place during the

month of April.

2. Officer elections shall take place in two stages: the nomination meeting and

 the online election.

3. The nomination meeting shall meeting shall be the first meeting in April.  a.
The Executive Board shall announce the exact date, time, and location  of the
nomination meeting no later than two weeks prior.

4. The nomination meeting will be run according to the following procedure:
a. Any non-election business shall be dealt with first.

b. Once all other business is taken care of, the President shall announce

nomination to be open.

c. During the nomination period, any voting member shall nominate any

voting member, including himself or herself, to a position.

i. In order for the nomination to be official, it shall need to be

seconded by another voting member.

ii. Any voting member may only be nominated to one position.  d. The
nomination period shall remain open until motion is made,  seconded,
and approved by a unanimous consent, to close

nominations.

e. After the nomination period is closed, the President will read from the
minutes the names of the candidates who have been nominated. Each
member nominated may then chose to accept or reject the
nomination.

f. All nominees that have accepted the nomination will be given the

opportunity to address the general membership for 5 minutes, and to
take questions from the membership for 5 minutes. The nominees for
President will go first, followed by the Vice President, Treasurer, and
Secretary. The nominees will present first by position and then by the
order in which they were nominated.

5. The second phase of the election shall by the online election period, and it

shall adhere to the following procedure.

a. Directly following the nominating meeting, the Secretary shall set up
an election on the group’s Campus Pulse page. He or she shall include
only the names of the members that have been nominated at the
nomination meeting; only nominated members will be elected.
b. The election shall be open from the day after the nomination meeting

to the day prior to the next scheduled meeting.

c. Following the close of the election period, the Secretary shall prepare
an election report, including the winners and the total vote counts for
each candidate. The Secretary at the meeting directly following the  close
of elections shall present this report. The Secretary shall also  view the

 vote report available on Campus Pulse to ensure that only  voting
members have voted. If any non-member voted, the election
will be deemed invalid and the election period will be re-done, under
the supervision of the Secretary of the Registry.

i. The Secretary may seek assistance from the Student Activities

and Involvement Center of the Secretary of the Registry for any
Campus Pulse or election related issues.

6. The Executive Board shall use the time in between the election and the end of

their terms to train the newly elected officers.

7. The newly elected officers shall take power following the final day of classes

of the Spring semester.

8. If any issues arise during this process, or if any member wishes to appeal the
results, the question may be taken by any member or officer to the Student
Judiciary.

V. Removal of Officers

A. Any officer may be impeached from office for failure to perform the duties of their

office or for conduct that is detrimental to the group.

B. The following procedure must be followed in order for an officer to be impeached:
a. A motion must be made and seconded during an official and regularly  scheduled
general body meeting to impeach an officer.

b. At the following general body meeting, the member making the motion of
impeachment shall have 15 minutes to present their case against the officer.
This shall be the time to present any evidence and/or witness relevant to
impeachment. These 15 minutes shall not be interrupted for any reason,  other
than if the petitioner decides to take questions from membership.
c. Following the presentation of evidence from the petitioner, the accused
officer will have 15 minutes to present their defense and any evidence or
witnesses they wish. These 15 minutes shall not be interrupted for any  reason,
other than if the officer decides to take questions from membership.
d. Following the presentations from the petitioner and the officer, a vote shall
be taken. Two-thirds of the general membership must vote in favor of
impeachment in order for an officer to be removed.

e. If the voting results in impeachment, the officer shall immediately surrender

his or her office.

f. If the officer in question is the President, the meeting in which the

impeachment took place shall then be chaired by the Vice

 President.

g. If any issues arise during this process, or if either party wishes to appeal the
results, the question may be taken by any member or officer to the Student
Judiciary.

VI. Officer Vacancies

A. If the President resigns or is impeached, the Vice President shall immediately take

over as President.

B. If the Vice President, Treasurer, or Secretary resigns or is impeached, a special

election shall be held for the position, following the same procedures as section IV of
this charter.

C. The remaining members of the Executive Board shall schedule a special election at a
regularly scheduled meeting between 1 and 3 weeks from the date the office became
vacant. The Secretary shall inform the general membership of the date of the special
election no less than 1-week prior.

VII. Resolving Disputes

A. Disputes arising between members on matters of RSO policy shall be dealt with

through majority votes of the general membership.

B. Disputes arising between members on other matters shall be dealt with through

mediation.

a. Mediation consists of a meeting involving both parties and a mediator with

the purpose of coming to a solution and putting the issue to rest.

b. The President shall mediate disputes between members.
c. Should the President be involved in the dispute, or should either party not be
satisfied by the result of the mediation, any party may request that the  Secretary
of the Registry mediate. The results of mediation with the

Secretary of Registry shall be final.

VIII. Free Speech

A. All members of UMass SEAD are entitled to freedom of speech and will not under
any circumstances be deprived of the opportunity to share their opinion with the
group.

IX. Amendment

 A. This charter may be amended by a 2/3 vote of the general membership at a

regularly scheduled meeting.

I. A motion to amend may be made and seconded by any member at a meeting  of
the general membership. The motion shall be presented at the meeting in
which the motion is made. Voting on the motion shall take place at the
following meeting. Prior to voting, the President shall allow for a period of
debate.

II. After being approved by the membership, the amendment itself, and an

updated version of the charter, shall be submitted to the Secretary of the
Registry for final approval.

For the 2021 Fall Semester, the Executive Board will be as follows:
President, Megan Brown, Kinesiology, Class of 2022
Vice President, Thanh Nha Ngoc Tran, Communication Disorders, Class of 2023
Treasurer, Sidrat Siddiqui, Chemistry, Class of 2023
Secretary, Margaret Becker, Accounting and Hospitality and Tourism Management, Class of
2022
Events and Media Coordinator, Kathryn Langenhorst, Public Health, Class of 2023

DocsList.Name: Constitution of the Super Smash Bros. Club 2023
UMass_SSB_Club_Charter_2019_2020.docx
DocsList.Data:
Charter for The UMass Super Smash Bros. Club (Smash Club) 2019-2020

Adopted __DATE__ in Amherst, MA
Mission Statement

The mission of the UMass Super Smash Bros. Club is to provide an avenue for Smash Bros. players to meet each other for both competitive and casual purposes. We provide a means for casual play, as well as tournaments, rankings, and prizes for the competitive players. The main focus of the club is on the two games with a large competitive scene, which are Super Smash Bros. Melee for the Nintendo Gamecube (2001), and Super Smash Bros. Ultimate for the Nintendo Switch (2018). However, members are also encouraged to play and bring any Smash-style games they are interested in, including but not limited to Super Smash Bros. (N64, 1999), Project M (Wii, 2011), and Rivals of Aether (PC, 2017). Club meetings consist of playing the games, as well as coordinating travel to larger events, and running competitive brackets. Smash Club is a means for students to get together with fellow fans, learn to play in a competitive environment, and have an alternative to weekend partying. By being involved in the Smash Bros. community on a local and national level, we hope to spread the love of our favorite game, and keep that love going for many years to come. 


Membership
All students at the University of Massachusetts Amherst and the general public shall be eligible to be members of Smash Club.
Only University of Massachusetts Amherst undergraduates shall be eligible to vote.
Membership shall be established after a prospective member attends two meetings and informs an officer of the Executive Board that they wish to be a member.
The Smash Club is granted license to record and use any and all types of video that its members record during club meetings, including camera recordings, live-stream broadcasts (for example, on the Twitch.tv), and captured gameplay footage.
Meetings
Smash Club shall have general body meetings on a weekly basis.
Meetings shall be chaired by the President.
The purpose of the meetings shall be:
Playing Super Smash Bros. games
Planning tournaments and travel to tournaments.
Participating in “friendlies” (relaxed matches between members).
Participating in tournament brackets.
Discussing general Smash-related news, such as new techniques, characters, games, tournaments, etc.
All decisions will be made by the Executive Board, with decisions largely taking general body’s feedback into account.
Input will be provided by the general body during meetings, as well as through online means such as our Facebook page, Campus Pulse page, etc.
If the board fails to come to a full consensus, the officers should vote on the decision.
In the case that the decision is tied in votes, the President makes the final decision.
The Executive Board
The officers of the Smash Club shall be:
President
Vice President
Treasurer
Secretary
Officer shall serve a term of one year, starting the day after the last day of classes in the Spring semester.
Officers shall be eligible for re-election to multiple terms.
The President
The President shall be the Chief Executive Officer of the RSO. They shall be responsible for all aspects of the functioning of the group.
The President shall have Signature Responsibility. 
The Vice President
The Vice President shall be the second in command of the RSO.
The Vice President shall help the President in their duties.
The Vice President shall take over for the President when they are not present.
The Vice President shall be the liaison between the Smash Club and the SGA, Student Activities and Involvement, and other campus offices.
The Treasurer
The Treasurer shall be the Chief Financial Officer of the RSO.
The Treasurer shall be responsible for maintaining the group’s finances.
The Treasurer shall be responsible for submitting an annual budget request to the SGA, if necessary.
The Treasurer shall have Signature Responsibility.
The Secretary
The Secretary shall be responsible for maintaining all records for the RSO.
All advertising and other documents relevant to the functioning of the group shall be considered records.
These records shall, in all possible cases, be collected electronically and shall be passed on from the current to the future Secretary during the transition period.
The Secretary shall maintain up to date membership lists.
The Secretary shall be responsible for maintaining the group’s social media and Campus Pulse pages.
Officer Elections
Officer elections shall take place during the month of March.
Officer elections shall take place in two stages: the nomination meeting and the election meeting.
The nomination meeting shall be the first general body meeting in March.
The Executive Board shall announce the exact date, time, and location of the nominating meeting no later than two weeks prior.
The nominating meeting will be run according to the following procedure:
The President shall announce nomination to be open. 
During the nomination period, any voting member can nominate themselves for a position by informing an officer of the club.
A voting member may only be nominated to one position.
If the voting member is not present, they may still inform the club officer at a time outside of the meeting.
The nomination period shall remain open for one week.
The next meeting after the nomination meeting will be the election meeting, and will run according to the following procedure:
The President shall announce the names of the members that have nominated for a position. At this point, any nominees may choose to withdraw their nomination for any reason.
For each position, the following procedure will occur: 
The order of positions shall be in the following order: Secretary, Treasurer, Vice President, President.
Each candidate will be given five minutes to speak to the general body if they so choose.
For the next five minutes, voting members, including other candidates, may ask questions to the candidates for that position.
Ballots will be handed out to voting members including the names of each candidate and position.
After 10 minutes, the ballots will be collected and tallied by one officer.
A different officer will than verify this tally.
The newly elected officers will be announced at the end of the meeting, and tally totals shall not be disclosed.
The Executive Board shall use the time in between the election and the end of their terms to train the newly elected officers.
The newly elected officers shall take power following the final day of classes of the Spring semester.
If any issues arise during this process, or if any member wishes to appeal the results, the question may be taken by any member or officer to the Student Judiciary.
Removal of Officers
Any officer may be impeached from office for failure to perform the duties of their office or for conduct that is detrimental to the group.
The following procedure must be followed in order for an officer to be impeached:
A motion must be made and seconded during an official and regularly scheduled general body meeting to impeach an officer.
At the following general body meeting, the member making the motion of impeachment shall have 15 minutes to present their case against the officer. This shall be the time to present any evidence and/or witnesses relevant to the impeachment. These 15 minutes shall not be interrupted for any reason, other than if the petitioner decides to take questions from the membership.
Following the presentation of evidence from the petitioner, the accused officer will have 15 minutes to present their defense and any evidence or witnesses they wish. These 15 minutes shall not be interrupted for any reason, other than if the officer decides to take questions from the general membership.
Following the presentations from the petitioner and the accused officer, a vote shall be taken. 2/3 of the general membership must vote in favor of impeachment in order to remove the officer.
If the voting results in impeachment, the officer shall immediately surrender his or her office.
If the officer in question is the President, the meeting in which the impeachment is considered shall be chaired by the Vice President.
If any issues arise during this process, or if either party wishes to appeal the results, the question may be taken by any member or officer to the Student Judiciary.
Officer Vacancies
If the President resigns or is impeached, the Vice President shall immediately take over as President.
If the Vice President, Treasurer, or Secretary resigns or is impeached, a special election shall be held for that position, following the same procedures as section IV of this charter.
The remaining members of the Executive Board shall schedule a special election at a regularly scheduled meeting between 1 and 3 weeks from the date the office become vacant. The Secretary shall inform the general body of the date of the special election no less than 1 week prior.
Resolving Disputes
Disputes arising between members on matters of RSO policy shall be dealt with by the Executive Board.
Disputes arising between members on other matters shall be dealt with through mediation.
Mediation consists of a meeting involving both parties and a mediator with the purpose of coming to a solution and putting the issue to rest.
The President shall mediate disputes between members.
Should the President be involved in the dispute, or should either party no be satisfied by the result of the mediation, any party may request that the Secretary of the Registry mediate. The results of mediation with the Secretary of the Registry shall be final.
Conduct Protocol
Should any member feel the need to bring up a conduct report to the Executive Board, they may contact any of the officers to report a problem.
The Executive Board will discuss the situation, potentially meeting with the member who contacted them for further details.
The Executive Board will decide an a “type” for the situation, and proceed to deal with it in the following way:
Type A: Personal conflict between club members
No action or meeting with executive board
Type B: Intimidating, distracting, disruptive, rude, or disrespectful behavior
Clear warning from executive board
Type C: Repeat Type A/Type B offenses, or more serious behavior such as threatening harm
Temporary removal from Smash Club, subject to review by the board at a specified future date.
Type D: Violence, sexual harassment, sexual assault
Permanent removal from Smash Club, and report sent to UMass.
The Secretary will store a log of the situation for future reference.
 Free Speech
All members of the Smash Club are entitled to freedom of speech and will not under any circumstances be deprived of the opportunity to share their opinion with the group. 
Non-Discrimination
Under Federal and State law, the Smash Club prohibits discrimination based on race, color, national origin, religion, sex, gender identity (including gender expression), sexual orientation, disability, age, marital status, family/parental status, income derived from a public assistance program, political beliefs, or reprisal or retaliation for prior civil rights activity. Refer to SGA policy for further details.
In addition, the Smash Club prohibits discrimination based on gameplay, character preference, or game preference.
Amendment
This charter may be amended by a 2/3 vote of the general membership at a regularly scheduled meeting.
A motion to amend may be made and seconded by any member at a meeting of the general membership. The motion shall be presented at the meeting in which the motion is made. Voting on the motion shall take place at the following meeting. Prior to voting, the President shall allow for a period of debate.
After being approved by the membership, the amendment itself, and an updated version of the Charter, shall be submitted to the Secretary of the Registry for final approval.

DocsList.Name: UMass_SSB_Club_Charter_2019_2020.docx
DocsList.Data:
Charter for The UMass Super Smash Bros. Club (Smash Club) 2019-2020

Adopted 10/07/2019 in Amherst, MA
Mission Statement

The mission of the UMass Super Smash Bros. Club is to provide an avenue for Smash Bros. players to meet each other for both competitive and casual purposes. We provide a means for casual play, as well as tournaments, rankings, and prizes for the competitive players. The main focus of the club is on the two games with a large competitive scene, which are Super Smash Bros. Melee for the Nintendo Gamecube (2001), and Super Smash Bros. Ultimate for the Nintendo Switch (2018). However, members are also encouraged to play and bring any Smash-style games they are interested in, including but not limited to Super Smash Bros. (N64, 1999), Project M (Wii, 2011), and Rivals of Aether (PC, 2017). Club meetings consist of playing the games, as well as coordinating travel to larger events, and running competitive brackets. Smash Club is a means for students to get together with fellow fans, learn to play in a competitive environment, and have an alternative to weekend partying. By being involved in the Smash Bros. community on a local and national level, we hope to spread the love of our favorite game, and keep that love going for many years to come. 


Membership
All students at the University of Massachusetts Amherst and the general public shall be eligible to be members of Smash Club.
Only University of Massachusetts Amherst undergraduates shall be eligible to vote.
Membership shall be established after a prospective member attends two meetings and informs an officer of the Executive Board that they wish to be a member.
The Smash Club is granted license to record and use any and all types of video that its members record during club meetings, including camera recordings, live-stream broadcasts (for example, on the Twitch.tv), and captured gameplay footage.
Meetings
Smash Club shall have general body meetings on a weekly basis.
Meetings shall be chaired by the President.
The purpose of the meetings shall be:
Playing Super Smash Bros. games
Planning tournaments and travel to tournaments.
Participating in “friendlies” (relaxed matches between members).
Participating in tournament brackets.
Discussing general Smash-related news, such as new techniques, characters, games, tournaments, etc.
All decisions will be made by the Executive Board, with decisions largely taking general body’s feedback into account.
Input will be provided by the general body during meetings, as well as through online means such as our Facebook page, Campus Pulse page, etc.
If the board fails to come to a full consensus, the officers should vote on the decision.
In the case that the decision is tied in votes, the President makes the final decision.
The Executive Board
The officers of the Smash Club shall be:
President
Vice President
Treasurer
Secretary
Officer shall serve a term of one year, starting the day after the last day of classes in the Spring semester.
Officers shall be eligible for re-election to multiple terms.
The President
The President shall be the Chief Executive Officer of the RSO. They shall be responsible for all aspects of the functioning of the group.
The President shall have Signature Responsibility. 
The Vice President
The Vice President shall be the second in command of the RSO.
The Vice President shall help the President in their duties.
The Vice President shall take over for the President when they are not present.
The Vice President shall be the liaison between the Smash Club and the SGA, Student Activities and Involvement, and other campus offices.
The Treasurer
The Treasurer shall be the Chief Financial Officer of the RSO.
The Treasurer shall be responsible for maintaining the group’s finances.
The Treasurer shall be responsible for submitting an annual budget request to the SGA, if necessary.
The Treasurer shall have Signature Responsibility.
The Secretary
The Secretary shall be responsible for maintaining all records for the RSO.
All advertising and other documents relevant to the functioning of the group shall be considered records.
These records shall, in all possible cases, be collected electronically and shall be passed on from the current to the future Secretary during the transition period.
The Secretary shall maintain up to date membership lists.
The Secretary shall be responsible for maintaining the group’s social media and Campus Pulse pages.
Officer Elections
Officer elections shall take place during the month of March.
Officer elections shall take place in two stages: the nomination meeting and the election meeting.
The nomination meeting shall be the first general body meeting in March.
The Executive Board shall announce the exact date, time, and location of the nominating meeting no later than two weeks prior.
The nominating meeting will be run according to the following procedure:
The President shall announce nomination to be open. 
During the nomination period, any voting member can nominate themselves for a position by informing an officer of the club.
A voting member may only be nominated to one position.
If the voting member is not present, they may still inform the club officer at a time outside of the meeting.
The nomination period shall remain open for one week.
The next meeting after the nomination meeting will be the election meeting, and will run according to the following procedure:
The President shall announce the names of the members that have nominated for a position. At this point, any nominees may choose to withdraw their nomination for any reason.
For each position, the following procedure will occur: 
The order of positions shall be in the following order: Secretary, Treasurer, Vice President, President.
Each candidate will be given five minutes to speak to the general body if they so choose.
For the next five minutes, voting members, including other candidates, may ask questions to the candidates for that position.
Ballots will be handed out to voting members including the names of each candidate and position.
After 10 minutes, the ballots will be collected and tallied by one officer.
A different officer will than verify this tally.
The newly elected officers will be announced at the end of the meeting, and tally totals shall not be disclosed.
The Executive Board shall use the time in between the election and the end of their terms to train the newly elected officers.
The newly elected officers shall take power following the final day of classes of the Spring semester.
If any issues arise during this process, or if any member wishes to appeal the results, the question may be taken by any member or officer to the Student Judiciary.
Removal of Officers
Any officer may be impeached from office for failure to perform the duties of their office or for conduct that is detrimental to the group.
The following procedure must be followed in order for an officer to be impeached:
A motion must be made and seconded during an official and regularly scheduled general body meeting to impeach an officer.
At the following general body meeting, the member making the motion of impeachment shall have 15 minutes to present their case against the officer. This shall be the time to present any evidence and/or witnesses relevant to the impeachment. These 15 minutes shall not be interrupted for any reason, other than if the petitioner decides to take questions from the membership.
Following the presentation of evidence from the petitioner, the accused officer will have 15 minutes to present their defense and any evidence or witnesses they wish. These 15 minutes shall not be interrupted for any reason, other than if the officer decides to take questions from the general membership.
Following the presentations from the petitioner and the accused officer, a vote shall be taken. 2/3 of the general membership must vote in favor of impeachment in order to remove the officer.
If the voting results in impeachment, the officer shall immediately surrender his or her office.
If the officer in question is the President, the meeting in which the impeachment is considered shall be chaired by the Vice President.
If any issues arise during this process, or if either party wishes to appeal the results, the question may be taken by any member or officer to the Student Judiciary.
Officer Vacancies
If the President resigns or is impeached, the Vice President shall immediately take over as President.
If the Vice President, Treasurer, or Secretary resigns or is impeached, a special election shall be held for that position, following the same procedures as section IV of this charter.
The remaining members of the Executive Board shall schedule a special election at a regularly scheduled meeting between 1 and 3 weeks from the date the office become vacant. The Secretary shall inform the general body of the date of the special election no less than 1 week prior.
Resolving Disputes
Disputes arising between members on matters of RSO policy shall be dealt with by the Executive Board.
Disputes arising between members on other matters shall be dealt with through mediation.
Mediation consists of a meeting involving both parties and a mediator with the purpose of coming to a solution and putting the issue to rest.
The President shall mediate disputes between members.
Should the President be involved in the dispute, or should either party no be satisfied by the result of the mediation, any party may request that the Secretary of the Registry mediate. The results of mediation with the Secretary of the Registry shall be final.
Conduct Protocol
Should any member feel the need to bring up a conduct report to the Executive Board, they may contact any of the officers to report a problem.
The Executive Board will discuss the situation, potentially meeting with the member who contacted them for further details.
The Executive Board will decide an a “type” for the situation, and proceed to deal with it in the following way:
Type A: Personal conflict between club members
No action or meeting with executive board
Type B: Intimidating, distracting, disruptive, rude, or disrespectful behavior
Clear warning from executive board
Type C: Repeat Type A/Type B offenses, or more serious behavior such as threatening harm
Temporary removal from Smash Club, subject to review by the board at a specified future date.
Type D: Violence, sexual harassment, sexual assault
Permanent removal from Smash Club, and report sent to UMass.
The Secretary will store a log of the situation for future reference.
 Free Speech
All members of the Smash Club are entitled to freedom of speech and will not under any circumstances be deprived of the opportunity to share their opinion with the group. 
Non-Discrimination
Under Federal and State law, the Smash Club prohibits discrimination based on race, color, national origin, religion, sex, gender identity (including gender expression), sexual orientation, disability, age, marital status, family/parental status, income derived from a public assistance program, political beliefs, or reprisal or retaliation for prior civil rights activity. Refer to SGA policy for further details.
In addition, the Smash Club prohibits discrimination based on gameplay, character preference, or game preference.
Amendment
This charter may be amended by a 2/3 vote of the general membership at a regularly scheduled meeting.
A motion to amend may be made and seconded by any member at a meeting of the general membership. The motion shall be presented at the meeting in which the motion is made. Voting on the motion shall take place at the following meeting. Prior to voting, the President shall allow for a period of debate.
After being approved by the membership, the amendment itself, and an updated version of the Charter, shall be submitted to the Secretary of the Registry for final approval.

How to Use This Form

Recreation Club Allocation Committee - Budget Request Form

Review your entire budget breakdown and select those expenses that you would like paid for by the Univeristy of Massachusetts Amherst through an allocation of SGA funds from the Recreation Club Council Allocations Commmittee. Prioritize the items from most important (1) to least important (up to 10). All items, including individual trips 
or items of equipment, should be listed separately.

How the Recreation Club Allocation Committee Will Use This Form

The Recreation Club Council Allocation Committee will review this form and other resources for allocation.  Each club will have the opportunity to explain its priority list, provide additional information regarding budget expenses and estimated income, and clarify any items during its scheduled budget hearing before the Recreation Club 
Council Allocation Committee during the allocation process.

Allocation and Spending by Category

Clubs will be allocated money by category, with allocated funds required to be spent in that category. You may adjust expenditures within category (if you request to fund a trip to Miami and you change that to Atlanta, that is acceptable).  But, to move money between categories (such as from Travel to Equipment) will require a special 
request  to the Recreation Club Council for approval.

DocsList.Name: CONSTITUTION OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MASSACHUSETTS SYNCHRONIZED.docx
DocsList.Data:
CONSTITUTION OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MASSACHUSETTS SYNCHRONIZED
SKATING CLUB

Article I

The name of this organization shall be the University of Massachusetts Synchronized
Skating Team.

Article II
OBJECTIVES

Section 1
To establish an atmosphere which encourages skaters to learn the correct techniques
and motions of skating. To run a synchronized skating team in accordance with
United States Figure Skating
Section 2
To recruit skaters from UMass to represent the university in collegiate figure
skating competitions and exhibitions.
Section 3
To educate the five college community about the efforts and determination of the
UMass Figure Skating Club.

Article III
MEMBERSHIPS

Section 1
Membership in the UMSST shall be open to male and female students of the
University and to all men and women of the five-college community, their
dependents, staff, faculty, and alumni.
Section 2
There will be two types of members, being voting and non-voting. Voting members
include UMass undergraduates only. Non-voting members are students of the
remaining four colleges or anyone else.
Section 3
All members (voting and non-voting) must pay a membership fee.
Section 4
Four meetings must be attended per semester to attain voting membership.

Article IV
OFFICERS

Section I
Officers will be appointed in the club as follows, President, Vice-president,
Secretary, and Treasurer. Only undergraduates of UMass can be officers. Two
persons will have signature responsibility, the president and the treasurer.
Section 2
Office Positions will open up for re-elections at the end of the spring semester each
year.
Section 3
Fifty one percent must vote for officer elections.
Article V
ELECTIONS

Section 1
Voting will take place within the one hour meeting held every week by voting
members. Non-voting members encouraged to attend meetings. Members will
nominate candidates for positions they choose to elect them for. An anonymous vote
will take place through written ballot. Each member will choose a candidate for
president, vice-president, secretary, and treasurer.
Section 2
The president is in charge of overseeing all club activities, as well as
planning/directing meetings and delegating duties.
Section 3
The Vice-President aids the president in all the above activities as well as
encouraging new memberships.
Section 4
The treasurer collects membership dues, negotiates finance spending with the R.S.O
and announces the treasurer’s report at the end of each semester.
Section 5
The secretary takes the minutes of each meeting, types all necessary documents for
the club and updates the phone list periodically.
Section 6
There must be a 50% plus 1 vote for the elected officers to take position.

Article VI
MEETINGS

Section 1
Meetings will have a set time to meet every other week during the fall and spring
semester.
Section 2
The president and vice-president are entitled to schedule a place and time for
meetings. They hold the right to call emergency meetings.

Article VII
QUORUM

Section1
Fifty one percent of the present members of the club must be present for a meeting
to take place.

Article VIII
REFERENDUM

Section 1
Voting for the office elections shall take place in the last week of April. Candidates
must be nominated by a fellow club member in order to be elected.

Article IX
AMENDMENTS

Section 1
The members of the club may bring up proposals of ideas during set meeting times.
Section 2
Fifty one percent majority vote must be reached and amendments must be
submitted to Secretary of Registry.

Article X
RATIFICATION

Section 1
Each member of the UMass Figure Skating Club must abide by these rules
configured here on this constitution articles I through article X.
Section 2
Ratification shall be voted on upon by majority vote of 51% of the organization. The
Secretary of Registry must approve all amendments.

Section 3
Copies of this constitution shall be made available to all members

Table Tennis Club Constitution.docx
DocsList.Data:
RSO Constitution for
Table Tennis Club

Article I-Name
Sec 1.1
The name of the organization shall be the Table Tennis Club.
Article II-Purpose and Goal
Sec 2.1
For purposes of recreation and competition within the UMass & five college community and the national level. The group will bring together talented and amateur players who are looking to learn and further their talent in the sport as well as open doors for future endeavors in the sport. This can be achieved by hosting on campus training sessions, open play sessions, and tournaments as well as attending off campus competitive tournaments.
Article III-Mission Statement
Sec 3.1
The goal of this club is to provide students and other community members with an opportunity to play table tennis on a regular basis in a friendly, competitive environment. This will be accomplished with a greater club that holds regular meetings open to all types of players at any skill level. Part of this club will be a competitive team that will hold tryouts for admittance. This team will actively practice and train in preparation for competition in the NCTTA (National Collegiate Table Tennis Association) across the northeast and the country. 
Article IV-Membership
Sec 4.1-Eligibility
Membership shall be open but not limited to anyone in the five-college area regardless of sex, creed, religion, race, sexual orientation, or physical or mental ability.
The club reserves the right to deny or revoke any membership for people outside the five-college community for non-discriminatory reasons.
Voting/active members must pay dues.
There will be a membership fee collected per semester.
Sec 4.2-Requirment
Active membership is defined as attending at least one
 meeting a month or five meetings per semester total.
A meeting is defined as any scheduled gathering of the club.
Sec 4.3-Voting Members
Voting members shall be limited to UMass Students
Voting Members shall also be limited to active members
Sec 4.4-Discipline
All members are expected to abide by the constitution of this RSO
All members are expected to uphold UMass, SGA State, and Federal laws while actively participating in any club event
Every member shall agree with the anti-hazing policy
Sec 4.5-Resolving Disputes
Any disputes arising from member associate with the club should not be addressed personally, but presented before the Executive Board 
If Executive Board is unable to resolve the disputes with two meeting sessions the issue will be presented before all active members who will determine a course of action.
Sec 4.6-Expulsion
Members with recurring, ongoing, or irreconcilable issues risk expulsion from the club 
Members violation Sec 4.4 will be expelled from the club
Reasons of expulsion shall first be validated by the Executive Board 
Article V-Freedom of Speech
All members have a right to freedom of speech and expression
However, this RSO does not approve of any harmful speech that serves to actively harm any members in any way. 
Partaking of any type of hate speech to any club members or in the club environment may be grounds for expulsion
Article VI-Constitution Amendment
A 2/3 majority of present members can vote for a constitution amendment only once a semester
The Executive Board has the right to veto or deny any addition or subtraction of articles or sections in the constitution that are against school, state, or SGA guideline
The Executive Board shall be responsible for updating information as deemed necessary by the school
Article VII-Ratification
A 2/3 vote of all present members and the approval of the SGA secretary of the Registry shall initially ratify the constitution of the UMass Table Tennis Club.
Article VIII-Governance
	Sec 7.1-Election Process
All officers must be elected by a simple majority vote of the voting members in attendance at a regularly scheduled meeting
Voting shall take place at no later than two weeks before the final exams of spring semester
Sec 7.2-Legnth of Terms
All officers shall hold a one year-long term and may run again when the term has ended
Sec 7.3-Eligibility
All candidates running for office shall be voting members
Member hoping to have signature responsibilities are responsible for completing whatever required trainings deemed necessary by SAI and the SGA
Sec 7.4-Offices and Responsibility
President
Organize and facilitate meetings
May have signature authority
Club representative to RSO meeting or campus-body meetings
Take charge of all meetings
Shall be group contact to UMass and five college community
Hold one veto power over the voting members
Vice President
Organize meetings
Act as intern President if the President cannot perform said duties
May hold signature responsibilities
Treasurer
Organize meetings
Track and report on club finances
Hold Signature responsibility
Complete annual budget
Collect club member dues
Secretary
Organize meetings
Track signatures for attendance
Responsible for election procedure
Count ballots 
Sec 7.5-Discipline
All members of the Executive Board shall be answerable to other voting and non-voting members for their action
Executive Board members can be terminated from their positions by a simple majority vote of 2/3 
Executive Board members are not above the law or the club Constitution and may be disciplined according to Sec 4.5

DocsList.Name: TTRPG Strategic Plan (24-29).pdf
DocsList.Data:
UMass Tabletop RPG Club Strategic Plan

2024 - 2029

Mission

The mission of the UMass Tabletop RPG Club (TTRPG) is to create spaces for students

to enjoy and discover tabletop games. Through our club, members will participate and learn

about each of these games without regards to any social or economic barriers. Anyone,

regardless of background, should be able to enjoy this hobby, and to meet friends and colleagues

along the way.

Vision

Ensuring this hobby is open to a large and diverse audience, and mitigating social and

economic barriers are the primary goals of our organization.

Values

1. Inclusivity - The TTRPG Club values inclusivity and actively works to create a safe and

welcoming environment for individuals of all backgrounds and identities. We believe that

tabletop gaming is for everyone and strive to promote diversity and acceptance within our

club and the larger gaming community.

 2. Community - Another core value of the TTRPG Club is the sense of community that we

foster among our members. We believe that tabletop gaming is an excellent way to

connect with others and build lasting friendships. We encourage collaboration,

communication, and teamwork in our games and events, promoting a strong sense of

camaraderie among our members.

3. Creativity - The TTRPG Club values creativity and encourages its members to explore

their imaginations and think outside the box. We believe that tabletop gaming is a unique

platform for self-expression and a fun way to exercise one's creativity. From character

creation to problem-solving in games, we celebrate and embrace individuality and

creative thinking.

4. Collaboration - Collaboration is another essential value of the TTRPG Club. In tabletop

gaming, players must work together to achieve a common goal, making it a great way to

develop teamwork skills. We encourage our members to communicate and cooperate with

each other and promote a supportive and cooperative atmosphere within the club.

5. Learning and Growth - The TTRPG Club believes in the power of learning and

personal growth through gaming. We provide opportunities for our members to explore

and learn about different tabletop games, game theory, and related skills such as

miniature painting and dice making. We also encourage our members to take on

leadership roles and actively involve themselves in the planning and organization of club

events, providing valuable experience and growth opportunities.

 Goals

Year 1 - Grow Community and Expand Resources

● Expand our resource library to include books representative of the plethora of game

systems that exist, as well as collect dice, figurines, and other tabletop tools for game use.

We plan to expand our resources for members by adding a few new books, manuals, and

gaming tools to our library.

● Collaborate with other RSO's on planned events, such as joint game nights or workshops.

● Foster and grow a welcoming community for tabletop gaming here at UMass Amherst,

through weekly meetings and events. Our main focus for this year will be on growing our

community of members and creating a welcoming environment for all. This may include

creating new events or activities that promote inclusivity and diversity within our group.

Year 2 - Expand Horizons

● Continue to update and expand our resource library, ensuring we have a variety of game

systems and materials available for our members. We will work to update and improve

our existing resources for members. This may involve replacing old or damaged

materials, or adding new and popular game systems to our collection.

● Develop relationships and connections with RSO’s we have not previously worked with.

We will also continue to collaborate with other RSO's on planned events, such as joint

game nights or workshops.

 ● Maintain a welcoming and inclusive community for all members, actively promoting a

safe and respectful environment.

Year 3 - Solidify Club Resources

● Develop methods for 3D-Printing our own resources and providing our club members

with access to them.

● Guarantee the accessibility of all our resources to all our members. This may involve

updating and adding new materials to our library, as well as purchasing additional gaming

tools and equipment for member use.

Year 4 - Maintain our Strong Community

● Foster strong relationships and partnerships with several other RSO's, hosting joint events

and activities throughout the year.

● Maintain a safe and welcoming environment for all members, continuously advocating

for inclusivity and diversity within our community.

Year 5 - Evaluate and Update to Address new Challenges

● Our relationships with other RSO's and the university will remain a priority, as we

collaborate on events and programs to promote inclusivity and diversity within our

community. We will work closely with other RSO's and the university to host larger and

more diverse events, such as conventions or gaming conferences.

● As always, our main goal will be to foster a welcoming and safe space for all individuals

to enjoy the tabletop gaming hobby. We will continue to prioritize and promote a safe

 and inclusive community for all members, actively addressing any challenges or concerns

that may arise.

Financial Strategy

In the past, the club’s financial management has been dependent on the requests we make

to the SGA each Fall. Our budgets weren’t always complete, sections would often get declined.

Our financial strategy for this year and the future is to heavily refine our budget creation. We

plan to greatly improve our methods for handling budget requests and guaranteeing that we

submit a quality, well-thought-out, request. We must have a firm grasp and understanding on

what supplies are necessary for our club so that our budgets reflect that, and we can look into

further fundraising opportunities if we are not allotted the amount we need. Typically, we have

received enough yearly funds, and have only needed to fundraise through our yearly Live

Stream. Our club is committed to providing the appropriate resources for our members to enjoy

the tabletop hobby, so prioritizing our fundraising efforts is a must.

Annual Fundraising Strategy

Fall: Submit budget request to the SGA

$2,000-$3,000

Spring: UMass Gives Community Live Stream event

$200

Our Annual Estimated Expenses

1. Tabletop Resources (New Books)

2. Miniatures (including Paint) and Encounter Grids

3. Event Supplies (decor, cleaning supplies, etc.)

 Marketing and Recruitment Strategy

Our marketing and recruitment strategy for the Tabletop Role Playing Game Club

includes utilizing various platforms to reach potential members. This includes having an active

and engaging Instagram page where we share updates about upcoming events and pictures from

our meetings.

In addition to our online presence, we also have a presence on campus through physical

posters that we put up in high traffic areas, such as the student union and the library.

During the club fair, we make sure to have a table set up with colorful and visually

appealing displays to attract students walking by. We have our members ready to chat and

answer any questions they may have about the club.

Additionally, we collaborate with other clubs and organizations on campus to reach a

larger audience. This includes participating in events and activities hosted by other clubs, as well

as promoting their events on our social media platforms.

Overall, our marketing and recruitment strategy aims to create a strong and diverse

community of tabletop role playing game enthusiasts at our university. We strive to be visible,

approachable, and inclusive in all of our efforts to attract new members.

DocsList.Name: Constitution of the Tabletop Role Playing Game Club - 2024.pdf
DocsList.Data:
Constitution of the Tabletop Role
Playing Game Club

Fall 2023

Article 1 - Mission Statement

The Tabletop Role Playing Game Club, also to be known as Tabletop RPG Club or

Tabletop Club, is a group of hobbyists and individuals joined into one organization in order to
provide and foster a safe and welcoming community for members to socialize, connect, and
enjoy this hobby with others. We also seek to provide the administrative benefits of being a
registered student organization to this community, mainly the ability to access a shared library of
books, manuals and other game supplies, as well as the ability to rent out dedicated spaces on
campus for meeting and running events.

The philosophy behind the foundation of this organization is to provide a safe and
welcoming space for any individual to learn about and participate in the growing tabletop
gaming hobby. As of now, there is no other registered student organization dedicated to tabletop
role playing, and the Tabletop RPG Club seeks to provide a unified place for that community to
grow and thrive at UMass Amherst.

The Tabletop RPG Club seeks to run a variety of activities, projects and events

tangential to the role playing game hobby, such as club-wide meetings for running games, game
theory workshops and learning sessions, as well as miniature painting events and dice making
nights.

Amongst our goals for the next five years, we plan to:

● Expand our resource library to include books representative of the plethora of game

systems that exist, as well as collect dice, figurines, and other tabletop tools for game
use.

● Collaborate with other RSO’s on planned events.

● Foster and grow a welcoming community for tabletop gaming here at UMass Amherst.

Article 2 - Membership

Official membership to the Tabletop RPG Club shall not be limited by race, color, sex,

sexuality, gender, or any other factor which promotes disunity or segregation. Official
membership to Tabletop Club is granted following enrollment in Tabletop Club via UMass
Campus Pulse. All members who have joined the club via Campus Pulse may vote during
elections.

 Article 3 - Meeting Process

General Body Meetings

This is where the core of our tabletop games are played and arranged. These meetings

are typically held weekly. An outline of meetings is as follows: club announcements and then
coordinated gameplay. The Vice President and/or Secretary lead General Body meetings.
Additionally, the only meetings when the presence of all voting members will be requested and
expected is the meetings where the E-board for the upcoming year is elected and where the
constitution is amended or revised.

E-Board Planning Meetings

When deciding important decisions regarding club expenditures and budgets, planning

and organization of club events, etc. E-Board meetings will be held. All members of the E-board
must be notified at least 24 hours in advance of E-Board Meetings, and at least 3 members of
the E-Board must attend each E-Board meeting.

Article 4 - Executive Board

The Tabletop RPG Club shall elect the following officers each year, for a term of one
year, spanning from the first general body meeting of the organization in the Fall academic
semester, through to the first general body meeting of the organization in the Fall of the next
year. New officer elections are held during the academic year, as described in Article 5 -
Election procedure. If a board member must step down during the year, an election will be held
within two weeks of their resignation.

The officer positions are as follows:

President

One who shall allocate the usage of the club space, coordinate club events, and act as a

liaison in dealing with the student government or other like-minded or associated registered
student organizations. The president shall also hold signature responsibility.

Vice President

One who shall assist in the scheduling and allocation of space to individual groups within
the organization. The Vice President shall also act as an ambassador to the student government
or other like-minded or associated registered student organizations alongside the President.
Furthermore, the Vice President shall also reside over the general body meeting, as well as the
day to day responsibilities of the organization.

 Secretary

One who shall handle membership records, and maintain necessary paperwork for the
organization to function. Any records maintained by another member of the cabinet is to have
an identical copy in the Secretary's files.

The secretary shall also be responsible for regularly checking the club email, and either

responding to messages or forwarding them to the relevant E-Board member who can. In
addition, the secretary will make necessary announcements for future meetings and events.

Treasurer

One who shall maintain records of all business transactions, guard the treasury ledgers,

and collect all dues (should they be enacted) and donations for deposit into the revenue
accounts. The Treasurer shall also hold signature responsibility.

Librarian

One who shall keep a record regarding the shared club library of books, manuals, dice,

miniatures and other relevant materials, and maintain this library. The librarian shall also
manage the signing-out and rental of shared club property for free use by members.

Article 5 - Election Procedure

Elections shall be held in a general body meeting of the organization in which at least

two-thirds of the active SGA members in the club are in attendance. All undergraduate club
members present are permitted to vote, and virtual ballots will be provided to all club members
who cannot be present. This election shall take place by the last Saturday of March.

If a board member must step down during the school year, an election will be held within

two weeks of their resignation.

If an E-board position becomes open between the Fall and Spring semester, then a
special election will be held on the second Saturday after the start of the Spring semester.

The Secretary will keep records of all election proceedings. Should the removal of an

officer be proposed or necessary, the organization will follow the process described in the
“When accused” section of Article 6.

Article 6 - Crime and Punishment

Any of Tabletop RPG club member may be charged for committing the following offenses:

 Minor Crimes: Willful disruption of meetings, violation of building rules, minor property

damage, and other activities that deliberately cause discomfort to members or those in the
surrounding environment. Punishment for minor crimes shall include up to 2 months suspension
from all Tabletop RPG events.

Major Crimes: Attempts to compromise the integrity, safety, and/or property of the
Tabletop RPG and/or its members, including acts of theft or endangerment of members or
property. Punishment for major crimes shall include up to 1 year suspension from all Tabletop
RPG events and office access, with possible lifetime suspension for repeat offenses.

Any Tabletop RPG officer convicted of Major Crimes shall immediately be removed from

office. The offending officer is permanently banned from holding any Tabletop RPG office.

When accused: The accused officer will be notified of their allegations, and given the

period of one week to amend or dispute the accusations. Following this, officers shall hold a
vote during an E-Board meeting to determine the appropriate level and punishment of the
crime, and the officers should also determine that the crime was committed beyond a
reasonable doubt. Said votes must be unanimous, not including the officer accused of the crime.
Once this has been decided, the next General Body Meeting will hold a vote, following the
procedure outlined in Article 5 for our elections, and we will require at least a two-thirds vote of
the general membership in order to remove an officer and/or member.

Article 7 - Constitutional Amendment

Constitutional changes and/or issues may be proposed by contacting an officer, who will

bring the issue to the attention of the other officers, all of whom will then announce and
schedule an organization-wide vote to take place on the next general body meeting of the
organization as a whole. Proposed changes will be finalized if a two-thirds majority of opinion is
established among the general assembly, and will be implemented after approval by the
Undergraduate Oversight Committee, objectionable as defined by official University policy.

Article 8 - Statements of Inclusion and Safety

The Tabletop RPG club prohibits discrimination under Federal and State law, based on
race, color, national origin, religion, sex, gender identity (including gender expression), sexual
orientation, disability, age, marital status, family/parental status, income derived from a public
assistance program, political beliefs, or reprisal or retaliation for prior civil rights activity.
Violation of these principles shall result in a hearing process for the violator for removal from the
club, as detailed in Article 5 - Election Procedure and Officer or Member Removal. As a part of
the Tabletop RPG club, all members have the freedom of speech and expression, and under no
circumstances shall a member’s freedom of speech or expression be infringed.

Any criminal attempt to compromise the integrity, safety, and/or property of the Tabletop
RPG Club or its members, or blatant disregard of University of Amherst rules will be reported to

 the necessary authorities, and result in immediate removal from the organization without a
hearing.

Constitution of the Tabletop Role Playing Game Club  
Fall 2019 

Article 1 - Mission Statement 

The Tabletop Role Playing Game Club, also to be known as Tabletop RPG Club 
or Tabletop Club, is a group of hobbyists and individuals joined into one organization in 
order to provide and foster a safe and welcoming community for members to socialize, 
connect, and enjoy this hobby with others. We also seek to provide the administrative 
benefits of being a registered student organization to this community, mainly the ability 
to access a shared library of books, manuals and other game supplies, as well as the 
ability to rent out dedicated spaces on campus for meeting and running events.  

The philosophy behind the foundation of this organization is to provide a safe 
and welcoming space for any individual to learn about and participate in the growing 
tabletop gaming hobby. As of now, there is no registered student organization 
dedicated to tabletop role playing, and the Tabletop RPG Club seeks to provide a 
unified place for that community to grow and thrive at UMass Amherst.  

The Tabletop RPG Club seeks to run a variety of activities, projects and events 

tangential to the role playing game hobby, such as club-wide meetings for running 
games, game theory workshops and learning sessions, as well as miniature painting 
events and dice making nights. 

Amongst our goals for the next five years, we plan to:  

● Expand our resource library to include books representative of the plethora of 
game systems that exist, as well as collect dice and figurines for game use. 

● Conduct fundraising events in order to expand our club resources. 
● Foster and grow a welcoming community for tabletop gaming here at UMass 

Amherst as this rapidly growing hobby continues to increase in popularity over 
the next five years. 

Article 2 - Membership 

Official membership to the Tabletop RPG Club shall not be limited by race, color, 

sex, sexuality, gender, or any other factor which promotes disunity or segregation. 
Official membership to Tabletop Club is granted following enrollment in Tabletop Club 
via UMass Campus Pulse. Any official member is immediately considered an eligible 
voting member.  

Article 3 - Meeting Process 

The Tabletop RPG Club shall hold official business meetings as deemed 
necessary, with a maximum of two per month. These meetings will request the 
presence of all members of the organization, but will be recorded and disbursed for all 
members to access. During these meetings any new business can be proposed, votes 
can be cast, and will be presided over by the Vice President. 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Meetings of the general assembly for purposes that are not specifically for official 
business do not fall under the two-per-month limit for business meetings. These general 
meetings have a multifunctional purpose, and may include some minor official business 
if it is more convenient to handle it in this fashion. Such meetings will also be presided 
over by the Vice President.  

The process for making decisions within the meetings will be as follows: 

At the beginning of an official business meeting, any member may make a 

motion to discuss new business. If passed by the general assembly, there shall be a 
deliberation by all members. After the deliberation has completed, there shall be 
another vote by a show of hands, to pass the new business. In order to pass, there 
must be a two-thirds majority. 

Article 4 - Executive Board 

The Tabletop RPG Club shall elect the following officers each year, for a term of 
one year, spanning from the first official business meeting of the organization in the Fall 
academic semester, through to the first official business meeting of the organization in 
the Fall of the next year. New officer elections are held during the academic year, as 
described in Article 5 - Election procedure. 

The officer positions are as follows:  

One who shall allocate individual groups’ usage of the club space, 

President: 
coordinate club events, and act as a liaison in dealing with the student government or 
other like-minded or associated registered student organizations. The president shall 
also hold signature responsibility. 

 One who shall assist in the scheduling and allocation of space to 

Vice President:
individual groups within the organization. The Vice President shall also act as an 
ambassador to the student government or other like-minded or associated registered 
student organizations alongside the President. Furthermore, the Vice President shall 
also reside over the general body meeting, as well as the day to day responsibilities of 
the organization. 

Secretary:
 One who shall record the minutes of the business meetings, handle 
membership records, and maintain necessary paperwork for the organization to 
function. Any records maintained by another member of the cabinet is to have an 
identical copy in the Secretary's files. 

 One who shall maintain records of all business transactions, guard the 

Treasurer:
treasury ledgers, and collect all dues (should they be enacted) and donations for 
deposit into the revenue accounts. The Treasurer shall also hold signature 
responsibility. 

Librarian: 

One who shall keep a record regarding the shared club library of books, 

 
 
 
 
​
 
​
 
​
 
​
 
​
 manuals, dice, miniatures and other relevant materials, and maintain this library. The 
librarian shall also manage the signing-out and rental of shared club property for free 
use by members. 

Article 5 - Election Procedure and Officer or Member Removal 

Elections shall be held in an official business meeting of the organization in 

which at least two thirds of the active SGA members are in attendance. This election 
shall take place before April 1st, at a date dictated by the decision of the general 
assembly at an official business meeting. The meeting to decide what date the election 
shall be held on must, at minimum, be held two weeks in advance of the date of the 
proposed election. At the date of the election, a vote shall be held by means of paper 
ballot, and each eligible voting member may submit one vote per ballot. Separate 
ballots shall be held for each designated officer position. 

An active officer can step down at any time during the academic year, provided 

that an election to fill the position is scheduled to be held at an official business meeting 
no less than one week before the officer steps down. In the event of an officer vacancy, 
an election shall be scheduled and held in the same fashion. Similar processes shall be 
held for other special elections. 

Written minutes of elections as recorded by the secretary, as well as video and 

audio recordings of the proceedings, shall be disbursed for the free access by all 
members. 

If a movement is made at an official business meeting, as defined by the 
procedures for making a movement outlined in Article 3 - Meeting Process, to remove 
an officer or member, the officer or member shall be expressly notified of the 
movement. A hearing shall be scheduled within one week of the proposed removal 
movement, where the general assembly, as well as the officer or member in question, 
may address the issue of the membership or officer position. At this hearing, a vote 
shall be scheduled for the next official business meeting regarding the issue. A vote by 
hand shall be held, requiring at least a two-thirds majority vote proportional to the 
entirety of the general membership. If at least two-thirds of all official members of the 
organization do not move to remove the officer or member, the officer or member in 
question shall not be removed from the organization or from their executive board 
position. If two-thirds of all official members do move to remove the officer or member in 
question, the individual shall be removed from the organization or from their executive 
board position. A list shall be kept by the secretary of those removed from the 
organization by this process. 

Article 6 - Constitutional Amendment 

Constitutional changes and/or issues may be proposed by contacting an officer, 

who will bring the issue to the attention of the other officers, all of whom will then 
announce and schedule an organization-wide vote to take place on the next official 
meeting of the organization as a whole. Proposed changes will be finalized if a 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 two-thirds majority of opinion is established among the general assembly, and will be 
implemented after approval by the Secretary of the Registry, objectionable as defined 
by official University policy. 

Article 7 - Statements of Inclusion and Safety 

The Tabletop RPG club prohibits discrimination under Federal and State law, 
based on race, color, national origin, religion, sex, gender identity (including gender 
expression), sexual orientation, disability, age, marital status, family/parental status, 
income derived from a public assistance program, political beliefs, or reprisal or 
retaliation for prior civil rights activity. Violation of these principles shall result in a 
hearing process for the violator for removal from the club, as detailed in Article 5 - 
Election Procedure and Officer or Member Removal. As a part of the Tabletop RPG 
club, all members have the freedom of speech and expression, and under no 
circumstances shall a member’s freedom of speech or expression be infringed. 

Any criminal attempt to compromise the integrity, safety, and/or property of the 
Tabletop RPG Club or its members, or blatant disregard of University of Amherst rules 
will be reported to the necessary authorities, and result in immediate removal from the 
organization without a hearing.
