DocsList.Data:
THE CONSTITUTION OF THE TAIWANESE AND CHINESE STUDENTS’ 
ASSOCIATION AT THE UNIVERSITY OF MASSACHUSETTS AT AMHERST 

ARTICLE I – NAME 

Aug 10, 2020 
Constitution Last Amended: 
​

The name of this organization shall be the Taiwanese and Chinese Students’ Association of the 
University of Massachusetts at Amherst (UMass Amherst), herein denoted TCSA. 

ARTICLE II – ORDER OF CONDUCT 

Section 1 

TCSA is established as a cultural organization and is registered within the institute of UMass 
Amherst as such. TCSA’s Charter Date is 1964 and TCSA is part of the Cultural Council.  

Section 2 

Social and cultural functions shall be held to promote social interactions as well as to promote 
further awareness and recognition of the Taiwanese and Chinese culture. However, TCSA 
1
cannot guarantee that aspects of other cultures will be incorporated into any of its activities . 
All functions can be held to the general public as part of an outreach effort. 

Section 3 

If any conflict arises among the executive board or its members, the individuals must report to 
the President and Vice President. If they cannot reach a conclusion, they must report to the 
Advisors. Individuals uninvolved must remain as unbiased as possible. If they feel biased, we 
must report to the CSD Advisor and must provide evidence of the situation. 

ARTICLE III – MISSION STATEMENT 

Section 1 

The primary purpose of TCSA is to share Taiwan’s and China’s rich culture, history, and 
traditions within UMass Amherst and the surrounding communities by contributing to the 
University’s cultural diversity and all who are interested. Additional specific themes within the 
exploration of culture, history, and traditions, that may be broached in TCSA events include, 
are not limited to
, advocacy, activism, mental health awareness, representation in society, etc. 
​
These themes will be handled in an educational and conversational manner.  

but 

Section 2 

1 TCSA will try to emphasize the Taiwanese and Chinese cultures in its events. However, TCSA recognizes that all 
cultures are intertwined and interconnected in various ways and that specific cultures are integrated from other 
cultures. Therefore, the separation of any single cultural aspect of one culture from another is irrelevant and is not 
supported by TCSA. 

1 

 
​
 The secondary purpose of TCSA is to promote peaceful interactions between Taiwanese, 
Chinese, Taiwanese-American, Chinese-American, and any other students or people of UMass 
Amherst or its surrounding communities with an interest in the culture. 

Section 3 

The tertiary
international students into the campus community. 

purpose of TCSA is to welcome and ease the transition of new students and 

Section 4 

Examples of the kind of activities, projects, and events TCSA plans to engage in include, 
but are 
not limited to
, an annual Cultural Night Market, celebrations for holidays such as Mid-Autumn 
​
Festival, Lunar New Year. TCSA likewise plans to engage in and support other registered student 
organizations, local chapters of Greek organizations, and the Yuri Kochiyama Cultural Center 
which parallel and uphold TCSA’s objectives and purposes. 

Section 5 

TCSA’s philosophy is to welcome all, from all walks of life to learn more about Taiwan and China 
and their respective cultures, histories, and traditions. TCSA will strive to remain a safe space 
for students and community members. 

Section 6 

TCSA’s goals for the next five academic years is to begin to welcome advocacy for Asian Pacific 
Islander Americans (APIA) through steps such as attending the East Coast Asian American 
Student Union (ECAASU) Conference. In addition, TCSA plans to foster stronger connections 
with student cultural organizations within the greater Five College Consortium.  

ARTICLE IV – MEMBERSHIP 

Section 1 

Membership in TCSA shall not be discriminated in the UMass Amherst community, its 
surrounding communities, and their dependents. TCSA prohibits discrimination under Federal 
and State Law, based on: race, color, national origin, religion, sex, gender identity (including 
gender expression), sexual orientation, disability, age, marital status, family/parental status, 
income derived from public assistance program, political beliefs, or reprisal or retaliation for 
prior civil rights activity.  

Section 2 

Membership shall not be restricted to individuals from Taiwan, China or of Taiwanese or 
Chinese descent. All individuals are welcome. 

Section 3 

General membership shall be offered to all undergraduate and graduate students of UMass 

2 

 
​
 
​
​
 Amherst; however, only active members shall have the right to vote. Active members are 
defined as those who have attended at least two general meetings and one large event per 
semester. Honorary members are defined as those who were previous executive board 
members; however, honorary members shall not have the right to vote .  

2

Section 4 

TCSA has the right to refuse or cancel membership to anyone who attempts to involve this 
cultural organization into politics, religion, or like causes, which results or may possibly result in 
the endangerment of this organization or in any disputes involving TCSA or among its members. 

Section 5 

Under no circumstances shall a member’s freedom of speech or expression be infringed upon. 

Should  we add an exception of allowing TCSA to remove individuals who are expressing hate 
speech.  

ARTICLE V –

GOVERNANCE 

Section 1 

The primary governing body of this organization shall be composed of undergraduate students 
and shall consist of the positions of President, Vice President, Secretary, and Treasurer (herein 
denoted Big 4). In order to be in these four positions, candidates must have at least one year of 
experience as an executive board member of TCSA. 

Section 1.1 - President 

 - The President shall oversee all activities of TCSA and serve as 
Primary Responsibilities
​
guidance and advise the rest of the governing body of TCSA. They will also serve as the 
main point of contact for Cultural Night Market guest performer relations and 
communication among University administration. The President shall work closely with 
the Secretary to maintain management and organization of the entire governing body of 
TCSA. 

 - The President shall ratify election results. In addition, the 
Secondary Responsibilities
​
President shall be in charge of re-registering TCSA every academic year. The President 
will also be in charge of maintaining locker keys for the academic year and registering 
TCSA in various activities expos and fairs. 

Section 1.2 - Vice President 

2 Since TCSA is a student organization of UMass Amherst, its undergraduate and graduate members shall be 
responsible for the proceedings of this organization. Therefore, active members shall have the right to vote, 
whereas honorary members 

. 
shall not be granted this responsibility in order to prevent biased opinions

3 

 
 
​
 
​
​
​
  Along with the Secretary, the Vice President shall be 
Primary Responsibilities -
​
responsible for assuming the duties of the President in their absence and maintaining a 
record of general membership meetings. The Vice President shall work closely with the 
Treasurer to maintain TCSA’s account balances and budgets.  

Secondary Responsibilities -
 The Vice President will be in charge of enforcing attendance 
​
policy upon executive board members. 

Section 1.3 - Secretary 

Primary Responsibilities -
 Along with the Vice President, the Secretary shall be 
​
responsible for assuming the duties of the President in their absence and maintaining a 
record of general membership meetings. The Secretary shall facilitate meeting agendas 
and maintain accurate meeting minutes. The meeting minutes shall be uploaded onto 
Campus Pulse at the minimum of once a month.  

Secondary Responsibilities -
 The secretary shall oversee the organization e-mail and 
​
organization-associated contacts. *** 

Section 1.4 - Treasurer 

Primary Responsibilities -
 The Treasurer shall be responsible for controlling and 
​
recording all financial transactions. Additional responsibilities include updating the 
executive board with fee and revenue account balances upon request. The Treasurer 
shall be the primary member in charge of facilitating applications for University 
sponsored grants; and will complete the required training in order to complete travel 
forms.  

Secondary Responsibilities -
 The Treasurer shall look into opportunities for outside 
​
funding and grants beyond the ECSA Grant and Arts Council Grant. 

Section 2 

The Treasurer must hold signature responsibility. Either the President or the Vice President 
shall also hold signature responsibility. Event Management training must be completed by 
either the President and/or the Vice President. Organizational Development training must by 
either the President or Vice President, and the Secretary. 

Section 3 

The secondary governing body of this organization shall be composed of undergraduate 
students and shall consist of the positions of Creative IT, Event Coordinators, Historian, Public 
Relations, and Undergraduate Liaison. These positions will be instated on a need basis.  

Section 3.1 - Creative IT 

The Creative IT(s) shall be responsible for creating graphics for the Historian and Public 

4 

 
 
 Relations officers to use when maintaining communications with general members in 
regards to events. 

Section 3.2 - Event Coordinator 

The Event Coordinator(s) shall be responsible for timely submission of event requests 
for all TCSA events. They shall foster connections with the SORC and SAI to ensure 
events are approved and necessary documents are completed.  

Section 3.3 - Historian 

The Historian(s) shall be in charge of taking and editing photographs and videos of 
events for documentation and sharing with general body members. They shall work 
closely with the Public Relations officer(s) and Creative IT(s) in maintaining 
communications with general members. Historian(s) shall also be responsible for 
ensuring that one t-shirt per academic year is archived for the RSO.  

Section 3.4 - Public Relations 

Public Relations officer(s) will be in charge of maintaining communications with general 
body members through avenues such as, 
Instagram. In addition, they shall reach out to University administration and Student 
Government Association (SGA) with invitations to events. They shall also ensure TCSA 
events are listed on various event calendars within the Five College Consortium. 

, email, Facebook, and 
but not limited to
​

Section 3.5 - Undergraduate Liaison 

The Undergraduate Liaison(s) shall be the point of contact between TCSA and other 
student organizations at UMass Amherst and the Five College Consortium. Examples of 
such student organizations include other cultural registered student organizations, 
chapters of Greek organizations, and the Yuri Kochiyama Cultural Center. They shall be 
in charge of reaching out to foster connections and collaborations with the 
aforementioned student organizations. They shall also attend different events and SGA 
Senate meetings. 

Section 4  

The tertiary governing body of this organization shall be composed of undergraduate or 
graduate students or alumni. The only position within this governing body shall be Advisors. 
Advisors have to have had prior experience as an executive board member either in the primary 
or secondary governing body of TCSA. The advisor positions will be instated on a need basis.  

Section 4.1 - Advisors 

The Advisor(s) shall be points of contact for the primary and secondary governing body 
of TCSA to refer to for guidance and support. They shall not be in charge of any 
actionable responsibilities on a day to day basis. Their primary responsibility is to be a 

5 

 
​
 source of support, reference, and give advice to the current executive board. 

Section 5 

If an executive board member leaves TCSA and wants to return, they must be voted through a 
formal election. However, that member cannot run for the top four positions once they return. 
An exception will exist for executive board members studying abroad - these members may run 
for a top four position upon express approval of other active executive board members. 

Section 6 

3

The election of executive-board members, which consisted of the aforementioned primary 
officers  and secondary officers who are instated by need, shall take place each academic 
semester, or year, by condition,
such as leaving the group and filling officer vacancies. Only 
active members will be able to vote and run for positions. The primary positions will only be 
available to the executive board. Elections will consist of nominations, applicant speeches, 
questions and answers, and deliberation and final decisions.  

Elections will be held during regularly scheduled general body meetings with two-thirds of the 
active SGA members of TCSA in attendance. Special elections will be held likewise on a need 
basis in events such as, 

, officer vacancies.  
but not limited to
​

Election for the following academic year will take place prior to April 1st with results reported 
to TCSA’s CSD Advisor. Records will be uploaded onto TCSA’s Campus Pulse page and Google 
Drive. Updated rosters of TCSA’s executive board will be updated in Campus Pulse and made 
known to the general members. 

Section 7 

Newly elected officers shall become official executive board members a week after the election, 
upon notification. 

Section 8 

general

 members and at least one half of the voting members present at any 

Any officers in an elected position can be impeached by the affirmative vote of at least 
two-thirds of the
meeting. Before such an impeachment takes place, all current voting members must be notified 
as to which meeting the said vote will take place and under what circumstances the 
impeachment is under. The officer in question will be notified at least two weeks prior to their 
impeached and must be given reasonable opportunity to address their membership. 

Section 9 

Meetings will occur at least once a week during the active academic year, with the exception of 
breaks, holidays, and unforeseen circumstances. In meetings, discussion for all upcoming 
events shall be discussed by all members in attendance. The President shall chair the meeting 

3Primary officers are also referred to as the Big 4. These positions consist of President, Vice President, Treasurer, 
and Secretary.  

6 

 
​
 
​
​
​
 
​
​
 with support from the Vice President, Secretary, and Treasurer. All meetings require an 
attendance of at least one half of the staff members to be present in order to fulfill the 
quorum. If the quorum is not reached, the meeting shall not proceed because no decision can 
be made. Decisions will be made by majority rule, with discussion and subsequent approval and 
acceptance by the minority of the original decision. 

ARTICLE VI – AMENDMENT AND ARTICLES 

Section 1 

Amendment of this constitution can be made any time by the affirmative vote of at least 
two-thirds of the voting and at least one half of the staff members present at any meeting. 
Votes are subject to presidential veto, which can be overridden by at least one-half of the staff 
members voting at the second ballot. 

Section 2 

Articles to this constitution shall be governed as amendments per section 1. 

Section 3 

Any amendment made to the constitution has to follow the approval of the Student 
Government Association (SGA) via the Secretary of Registry.

Mission Statement

The UMass Tap Team is consistently
seeking excellence in creating an
inviting and inclusive community for
our members while also fostering
opportunities for students on
campus to explore the dynamic
techniques of tap dancing.

 S T R A T E G I C   P L A N
2 0 2 0 - 2 0 2 5

OUR VISION

We intend to spread our love for tap dancing

throughout UMass and the five colleges through

crafting a welcoming, creative environment and

guiding students to learn tap techniques. Through

showcases and workshops, we will engage the

student body by increasing the awareness of the

historic style. 

VALUES: 

Inclusivity - We are welcoming to all

students of the five colleges who share a

passion for tap. 

Creativity - Everyone is invited to share

their artistic views and explore new

techniques.

Collaboration - We intend to not only work

within our team, but with other RSOs and

arts programs.

Dedication - This is a team where members

are committed to imploring and showcasing

exemplary technique. 

Enjoyment - Foster environments that

utilizes the creative outlet that the style of

tap dance is for students. 

P A G E   0 3

 5 YEAR PLAN

UMASS TAP TEAM

2020-2021

Establish ourselves as an RSO and spreading awareness of the style of tap on

campus. 

Create our social media, email, and other communication threads for students.

Attend the activites fair in the Spring .

2021-2022

Continue to increase our presence on campus while expanding our team by at least

10% for the academic year. 

Hold auditions at a time deemed accessible for the most amount of

participation. 

Continue to attend the activities fair.

Partner with at least one performative RSO  to unify  and collaborate with for

performances.

2022-2023

Generate a fundraising campaign to accommodate for the growing team and

purchase flooring to tap on. 

Analyze the trends that student body engages with to create a successful

campaign.

Utilize resources available and seek out budgetary guidance in quick and

effective manner. 

2023-2024

Develop a tap technique program to integrate diverse populations of UMass and
the five colleges. 

Research related programming for that academic year to cultivate a
partnership. 
Host a series that incorporates the educational and diverse history of tap
techniques to share with the students. 

2024-2025

Strengthen our own leadership skills and  cultivated partnerships.

Engage with campus wide student leadership training programs.

Host a  multi RSO team bonding event to strengthen relationships of all team

members.

Strategic Plan 2020-2025

The UMass Tap Team will elect a social chair to oversee all social
media marketing campaigns. Platforms such as Facebook,

UMTT will also attend campus wide events such as the Activities
Fair to engage the student body. Promotional tools to help

Auditions and showcases/performances will be marketed using

DocsList.Name: The UMass Tap Team Constitution.pdf
DocsList.Data:
The UMass Tap Team Constitution 

Article I. Name: 

The name of this registered student organization (RSO) is The UMass Tap Team, which may also be 
recognized as UMTT.  

Article II. Mission Statement: 

The UMass Tap Team is consistently seeking excellence in creating an inviting and inclusive community 
for our members while also fostering opportunities for students on campus to explore the dynamic 
techniques of tap dancing. 

Article III. Membership: 

I. All undergraduate students of the University of Massachusetts - Amherst are eligible to join UMTT. 

II. Membership is also open to all undergraduate students of the Five-College Consortium. 

III. Membership requirements:  

1. Prospective members must attend an audition process (See Article V).  
2. Members must be able to attend 80% of the semester practices to participate in the Showcase. The 
Captain and/or Co-Captain may excuse absences for academic purposes, personal and family 
emergencies, and health issues . Frequent absences will constitute grounds for expulsion from the 
RSO. 

IV. All members hold the right to: 

1. Contribute to UMTT’s choreography. 
2. Vote for officers at the end of every year and semesters if a position becomes available.  
3. Run for an officer position. 
4. Present by-law changes for consideration by the group during the time allotted for such purposes. 
5. Leave the club at any time. 

Article IV. Officers: 

I. President, also known as Captain 

1. The Captain, as chief presiding officer of UMTT, shall: 

a. Lead choreography during practices 
b. Designate the date, time, and location of practice 
c. Book each week’s practice space 
d. Hold Signature Responsibility for UMTT 

 e. Coordinate and preside over officer elections for the next year 
f. Be a mentor for the Co-Captain(s) 
g. Coordinate the showcase and other performances 

II. Vice President, also known as Co-Captain 

1. The Co-Captain shall: 

a. Assist the Captain in all of their duties 
b. Assume the position and responsibilities of Captain in the event that the current Captain 

has vacated their position or is unwilling or unable to fulfill their duties 

c. Assume the role of Captain if they resign during the school year and an election cannot 

take place 

d. Assist in the coordination of the showcase and other performances 
e. Have the opportunity to choreograph routines 

III. Treasurer, also known as Co-Captain 

1. The Treasurer, as the chief financial officer of UMTT, shall: 

a. Lead and coordinate all fundraising activities for UMTT 
b. Manage all current financial assets of UMTT 
c. Hold Signature Responsibility for UMTT 
d. Apply for funding from the SGA Ways and Means Committee  
e. Apply for an emergency funding request from the SGA Finance Committee if necessary  
f. Have the opportunity to choreograph routines  

IV. Secretary, also known as Co-Captain 

1. The Secretary shall: 

a. Advertise for the purpose of recruiting potential members at the beginning of every 

season 

b. Be responsible for updating UMTT’s bylaws as they are amended 
c. Send out weekly emails/messages with updates and reminders 
d. Coordinate tabling at University of Massachusetts Activities Expo 
e. Take attendance at the start of every practice 
f. Have the opportunity to choreograph routines  

V. Event Coordinator, also known as Social Chair 

1. The Event Coordinator shall: 

a. Organize social events for UMTT 
b. Collaborate with the other members of the executive board to create social events that 

will enhance the experience of UMTT members 

c. Develop open classes with executive board and team members  
d. Oversee and manage social media accounts and communication 

 e. Have the opportunity to choreograph routines  

Article V. Auditions: 

As stated in Article III, prospective members must audition for placement on the team. Audition timelines 
will be determined on a semester basis by the Captain and Co-Captain(s). The Captain and Co-Captain(s) 
will oversee the audition process and make executive decisions on who will be allowed to be a part of the 
group based on feedback and their better judgement. The general body members are highly encouraged to 
be present at the auditions and give praise when due to all those who audition and serve as part of the 
discussion for UMTT auditions. Auditions will cover fundamental techniques of tap.  

Article VI. Practices: 

The UMTT practice schedule will be determined by the Captain and Co-Captain(s) at the start of the 
semester. Days and times may vary from semester to semester depending on the Captain, Co-Captain(s), 
and team’s availability. The frequency of practices may increase when scheduled performances are 
approaching. There will be mandatory dress rehearsals before all performances. Failure to attend these 
mandatory rehearsals may result in the inability to perform for the rest of the semester. One can only miss 
a mandatory performance when given permission to do so by the Captain and/or Co-Captain(s). 

Article VII. Lessons: 

The UMTT will hold lessons for the greater student body throughout the academic semesters. These 
practices will start on a date chosen by the Captain/Co-Captain(s). The purpose of these lessons is to 
educate UMass students on the art of tap dance and enhance their student experience by creating a fun and 
non-judgemental place for them to learn, or enhance, new skills.  

Article VIII. Amendments: 

Any member of the UMTT may propose amendments to these bylaws during the first practice of each 
month. The amendment shall be proposed by the sponsor(s) before the entire membership present at the 
meeting. Following the presentation of the proposed amendment, a debate or discussion may be held, with 
the Captain serving as moderator. For the amendment to be proposed, there must be a two-thirds majority. 
The Captain will then distribute ballots to every member in attendance and the proposed amendment will 
be voted on. The amendment shall be considered passed if two-thirds of the present members vote in the 
affirmative at the current meeting. If the Captain is the sponsor of the proposed amendment, they shall 
appoint another member of the E-Board to serve as the moderator during the debate/discussion period. 

 
 
  
  
 Every member in attendance may vote on the proposed changes, regardless of whether they are acting as 
moderator.  After conducting a majority vote, the proposed changes will be shown to the Secretary of the 
Registry thereafter in order to be fully approved.  

Article IX. Elections: 

Elections for executive board positions will be held before April 1st.  A person must be in the RSO for at 
least two consecutive semesters in order to run for an executive board position. To run, they must submit 
their name to the current Captain. The Captain then will put everyone’s name on a secret ballot on 
Campus Pulse. The candidates will have two to three minutes to present a campaign speech to the RSO 
members on the day of elections during a regularly scheduled general body meeting. Then, all members 
who are returning for the next semester may vote by ballot. Those who are not returning for the next 
semester must abstain from voting. A candidate needs a two-third majority to win the position. In the case 
that this does not happen, the Captain and Co-Captain will choose from the top candidates. Any candidate 
who wishes to run for an E-Board position should plan on being at UMass for the full year that they will 
be in office. In other words, those who are planning on studying abroad are not permitted to run for a 
position.   

Article X. Removal of Officers: 
I. Any officer may be impeached from office for failure to perform the duties of their office or for conduct 
that is detrimental to the group. 
II. The following procedure must be followed for an officer to be impeached: 

1. A motion must be made and seconded during an official and regularly scheduled general body 

meeting to impeach an officer. 

2. At the following general body meeting, the member making the motion of impeachment shall 
have 15 minutes to present their case against the officer. This shall be the time to present any 
evidence and/or witnesses relevant to the impeachment. These 15 minutes shall not be interrupted 
for any reason, other than if the petitioner decides to take questions from the membership. 

3. Following the presentation of evidence from the petitioner, the accused officer will have 15 

minutes to present their defense and any evidence or witnesses they wish. These 15 minutes shall 
not be interrupted for any reason, other than if the officer decides to take questions from the 
general membership. 

4. Following the presentations from the petitioner and the accused officer, a vote shall be taken. 

Two-thirds of the general membership must vote in favor of impeachment in order for an officer 
to be removed. 
If the voting results in impeachment, the officer shall immediately surrender their office. 
If the officer in question is the Captain, the meeting in which the impeachment is considered shall 
be chaired by the Co-Captain (Vice President). 
If any issues arise during this process, or if either party wishes to appeal the results, the question 
may be taken by any member or officer to the Student Judiciary. 

5.
6.

7.

  
 
 
 Article XI. Officer Vacancies: 

I.

II.

III.

If the Captain resigns or is impeached, the Co-Captain (Vice President) shall immediately take 
over as Captain. 
If the Vice President, Treasurer, Secretary, or Event Coordinator resigns or is impeached, a 
special election shall be held for that position, following the same procedures as Article IX of this 
constitution.  
The remaining members of the Executive Board shall schedule a special election at a regularly 
scheduled meeting between one and three weeks from the date the office becomes vacant. The 
Secretary shall inform the general membership of the date of the special election no less than one 
week prior.  

Article XII. Resolving Disputes: 

I.

​Disputes arising between members on matters of RSO policy shall be dealt with through a 
two-thirds majority vote of the general membership. 
II.
Disputes arising between members on other matters shall be dealt with through mediation. 
III. Mediation consists of a meeting involving both parties and a mediator with the purpose of coming 

IV.
V.

to a solution and putting the issue to rest. 
The Captain shall mediate disputes between members. 
Should the Captain be involved in the dispute, or should either party not be satisfied by the result 
of the mediation, any party may request that the SGA Secretary of the Registry mediate. The 
results of mediation with the SGA Secretary of the Registry shall be final. 

Article XIII. Free Speech: 
All members of the UMTT are entitled to freedom of speech, deemed by the First Amendment, and will 
not under any circumstances be deprived of the opportunity to share their opinion with the group. Any 
member is encouraged to present input on choreography, how the practice is run, or other decisions 
involving the whole group, in order to create a collaborative environment.  

Article XIV: Non-Discrimination Clause 
Under no circumstances will a person be discriminated against based on age, sexual orientation, gender 
identity, disability, marital status, race, color, national origin, religion, sex, family/parental status, income, 
political beliefs, or civil rights activity.

DocsList.Name: TLS_Constitution2021.docx
DocsList.Data:
Constitution of That’s Life Science 
University of Massachusetts Amherst
Second Edition
ARTICLE I - Name and Purpose
Section 1 Name of the Organization: The organization shall be named “That’s Life Science.”
Section 2 Purpose: That’s Life Science is a blog and outreach organization created by University of Massachusetts Amherst life science graduate students. We write and organize events for the general public. There are three main purposes of our organization. First is to create and foster a community of life science graduate students from different programs/departments by collaborating on projects of common interest. Through inter-program peer-editing, committees, group meetings, and outreach events, students have many avenues to interact with one another on a frequent basis. Our group serves as a new network for life science graduate students. Second is to provide opportunities for graduate students to practice science communication and engage in outreach. Contributors write and edit blog posts geared toward a general adult audience (high school age and up) and/or organize in-person outreach events for people of all ages, allowing us to practice effectively communicating with non-scientists. Currently, science communication is not integrated into science training at the undergraduate or graduate level. This organization provides us with a regular means to practice writing for, and communicating with nonscientists in a collaborative atmosphere. Third is to introduce a broad range of scientific concepts to the general public both in person, and through a popular medium: the internet. We believe everyone should have access to science and we want to provide a bridge between academia and the general public. This will be accomplished by regularly organizing and participating in local outreach opportunities, as well as publishing life science-based blog posts on our website. This content will additionally be shared through a mailing list, social media, and with other science educators interested in using blog writing as a teaching tool. 
ARTICLE II - Membership, Membership Fees, Non-Discrimination Policy
Section 1 General Definition of Membership: Membership shall be open to University of Massachusetts Amherst students interested in writing about life science. 
Section 2 Active Membership: Active members are those who write two blog posts and edit four blog posts a year. Members can be considered active if they are contributing significantly in other ways (e.g., managing the website, administrative roles, outreach committee, etc). This definition is subject to change as we grow in contributor numbers. 
Section 3 Non-Discrimination Policy: That’s Life Science does not discriminate for any purpose on the basis of race, ethnicity, linguistic abilities, religion, sexual identity, political affiliation, disability status, or marital status.
Section 4 Membership Fees: Active members will not need to provide a fee at this time.
ARTICLE III - Officers, Duties, and Terms 
We have three main officer positions who coordinate the Life Science Blog committees among themselves and with the University of Massachusetts Amherst. All new holders of these positions will need to attend any required GSS trainings. 
Presidents/Co-Chairs - The Presidents/Co-Chairs will be responsible for coordinating the That’s Life Science committees and organizing the agenda for group meetings. Tasks that are not appropriate for established committees will be completed by the Presidents/Co-Chairs (e.g. organizing vote for the next Presidents or Co-Chairs, group emails). The Presidents/Co-Chairs may also help the GSS Representative to communicate with GSS or UMass Amherst administration. The Presidents/Co-chairs will update the constitution annually in time for GSO applications. 
Treasurer - The Treasurer will be responsible for managing finance related training, committee fund requests, donation campaigns, and updating all members on our budget each semester.
Graduate Student Senate (GSS) Representative - The GSS Representative serves as the main liaison between That’s Life Science and GSS. The Representative will coordinate creation of the annual funding requests and hold treasurer responsibilities. Any internal requests for money (e.g. domain name, food for group meeting, etc.) will need to be approved by the GSS Representative. 
ARTICLE IV - Election and Appointment Procedures 
Section 1 Election Schedule: The election for all executive committee positions shall be held at the end of April of each year. The election day shall be announced immediately prior to the general meeting.
Section 2 Nomination Schedule: 10 days before the election, a notice shall be thoroughly distributed by the Presidents/Co-Chairs to announce the election and to invite nominations for each position. (If the Presidents/Co-Chairs are running for reelection, an objective third party will be asked to coordinate the elections.)
Section 3 Nomination Eligibility: Any active member may be nominated for any position. Any active member may nominate any active member including her/himself.
Section 4 Nomination Acceptance: 8 days before the election, each nominee shall be given one day to accept or decline the nomination of her/his name. Each nominee shall be only permitted to accept a nomination for one full position only.
Section 5 Campaigning Period: Beginning 7 days before the election, each nominee shall be permitted to forward a statement to the Presidents/Co-Chairs to be posted on a webpage devoted to nominees’ statements.
Section 6 Election Period: On days and times decided in the prior general meeting, a vote collection box shall be left in a neutral and secure area. A method for votes in absentia shall be determined in a general meeting. The group may also use anonymous voting via online means (e.g. Survey Monkey) if a group meeting is not possible. 
Section 7 Votes Counting: Votes shall be counted by a suitable, impartial third person.
Section 8 Determinations: A winner shall receive a majority of votes. In the event of a tie, the leading candidates sharing the tie shall participate in a runoff election following the general procedures in sections 5 through 7.
Section 9 Appointment Procedures: In the event of a sudden or continued vacancy in an executive position, the Chair may choose to appoint an active member to the position in a temporary manner until an election can be held for the position.
ARTICLE V - Meetings
Section 1 General Meetings
There will be at least one general meeting per semester that will be held towards the end of the semester. The committees will meet more frequently throughout the semester, based on their individual tasks at hand.
Section 2 Special Meetings
Generally, the Presidents/Co-chairs will call for and organize meetings. If need be, any blog member can call for a general meeting as well as a committee meeting, the latter being a more likely event. In order to call a meeting, a schedule polling website, such as Doodle, will be used to find a time when the largest amount of members can attend. All members will be notified via email about date and location of each meeting. 
Section 3 Rules of Conduct and Speech
Meetings will be run by the officers who will prepare an agenda for that meeting (whether it’s the Presidents/Co-Chairs, GSS Rep, or a committee). Any member can raise topics for discussion, including votes on decisions, ideas, and committee updates. Members and officers should always be respectful of one another when speaking.
Section 4 Voting
Voting for issues that require member consideration and/or are of significance will be carried out via anonymous online polling. A deadline will be set granting at least 3 days for members to vote. As members receive this time to vote on each matter, there will be no requirement for how many members need to vote for results to be valid. Passing a measure requires 51% of the votes, unless multiple options are debated in which case the measure with the highest number of votes will be passed.
ARTICLE VI - Rights and Privileges of Members 
Section 1 General Rights of Members
All members have the right to write posts for the blog and get peer feedback, as well as join whichever committee they wish to join. All members have the right to attend and speak in meetings held by That’s Life Science. Members have the right to write about whatever topics they wish, so long as they are within the scope of life science and are not written in a controversial or incendiary manner. If uncomfortable in any writing or editing situation, members have the right to consult a peer in a leadership position for advice on how to proceed (this would generally be handled by the Managing Editor Committee). 
Section 2 Voting Rights of Active Members
All active members may vote and all votes are equal. 
Section 3 Other Rights of Active Members
N/A
ARTICLE VII – Committees

1. Managing Editors Committee: 
Develop and maintain a statement of the blog’s policies on article topics, writing style, and appropriate image usage.
Help keep peer editors on schedule  
Monitor that the peer­ editing process is working effectively
Periodically review and revise the editing and feedback rubric/guidelines
Protect confidentiality
Treat all authors with courtesy, objectivity, honesty, and transparency
Proofread each blog post before uploading to website 
Handle any issues that may come up in posts such as controversial topics or disrespectful editing. This includes checking for correct citation and appropriate use of external figures. 
2. Design Committee: 
Plan, create, and edit a web page for That’s Life Science such that it is both visually appealing as well as easy to navigate.
Develop a blog logo.
Upload final posts to the development website for proofing and deal with any issues in post aesthetics.
Schedule weekly uploads to the production website for post publication.
3. Communications and Outreach Committee:
Maintain social media outlets (Facebook, Twitter, Flickr, Youtube, weekly newsletters, comment moderation, etc.)
Market to build the readership, including developing relationships with local and other communities to increase outreach potential.
Work with design committee to optimize website traffic
If additional fundraising is needed, this committee will organize fundraising efforts.
Organize and attend in-person outreach events/opportunities to practice science communication, advertise for That’s Life Science, and share life science related information
ARTICLE VIII - Amendments to the Constitution 
Section 1 Proposal: A member may propose an amendment by distributing it in written format and reading it aloud in a meeting. Voting of a proposal may not take place in the same meeting as that in which the proposal was made. Following the meeting, the proposal shall be made known to all members of the TLS.
Section 2 Approval: During the next general meeting, and only after a thorough discussion to the satisfaction of all members present for the voting of a proposal, a vote shall be taken on its approval provided that quorum is available. The amendment must secure two thirds of the votes available during the meeting.
Section 3 Recording: Any successful amendment shall be recorded and copies of the new constitution shall be presented on the TLS website and made available in paper format. Two paper copies shall be stored for record-keeping purposes.

DocsList.Name: Constitution The Diabetes Link UMA.pdf
DocsList.Data:
The Constitution of The Diabetes Link: Umass Amherst Chapter 

Article I-Name  
The name of the organization shall be The Diabetes Link: Umass Amherst Chapter 

Article II-Purpose 
It shall be the purpose of The Diabetes Link to connect students with Type 1 diabetes in 
order to provide social support, information, and access to new technologies. We will 
also help to change policies, raise awareness and spread knowledge about Type 1 
diabetes on campus and in the community in order to make it a healthier environment for 
students with Type 1 diabetes to live.  

Article III-Membership  
Section A: Membership is open to anyone interested in improving their own health, 
supporting a friend/loved one with diabetes, increasing awareness, and making life on 
campus healthier and less complicated for students.  

Section B: Dues and collection procedures (if any) 
The amount of annual dues shall be determined each year by the president of the 
organization and dependent upon which activities need funding. It is our intention that no 
dues be collected.  

Article IV-Voting 
Section A: A quorum will be determined by president and will be dependent upon how 
many members join the organization. 
Section B: Each member in good standing may vote. 
Section C: Proxy voting is allowed by the following process: 
The president shall allow the vice president to proceed with voting duties when the 
president is absent. 

Article V-Officers 
Section A: The Diabetes Link: Umass Amherst shall have a President, Vice President, 
Secretary and/or Treasurer, and Advisor. These officers comprise the Executive 
Committee or Board. 
Section B: All officers must be members of The Diabetes Link: Umass Amherst 
Section C: The term of the first semester’s office shall be September 5, 2023 to 
December 23, 2023 The term of the second semester’s office shall be December 24, 2023 
to May 25, 2024. 
Section D: Election of officers shall be held the prior semester and will be agreed upon 
again at the beginning of the new semester. 
At least two weeks notice shall be given before the election meeting. Applications from 
candidates will be due one week before the election meeting and will be evaluated by the 
president to determine which candidates are elected.  
Section E: Any officer may be removed from membership by a three-fourths vote of the 
Executive Board. Any officer removed may appeal to the general membership. Said 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 officer shall be considered reinstated with two-thirds approval of the members.  
Section F: Any vacancy which may occur in an office shall be filled by appointment by 
the president pending ratification at the next group business meeting. 

Article VI- Officers Responsibilities 
Section A: The President 
1. The president shall be the chief executive officer  
2. The president shall appoint all committee chairpersons 
3. The president, with approval of the executive board, directs the budget  
4. Vacancies in offices will be filled by appointment of the President with approval of the 
general membership. 
Section B: The Vice President 
1. The vice president shall be the parliamentarian for the organization. 
2. The vice president shall assume the duties of the president should the office become 
vacant, or in the absence of the president. 
3. The vice president will keep and have available current copies of the constitution. 
4. The vice president will be responsible for scheduling programs. 
Section C: The Secretary  
1. The secretary shall be responsible for keeping the minutes of all meetings and the 
meetings of the executive board. 
2. The secretary will provide a copy of the minutes for each officer and keep a master 
file. 
3. The secretary shall maintain a complete and accurate account of attendance and 
membership status. 
Section D: Treasurer 
1. The treasurer shall keep a current record of all financial transactions. 
2. The treasurer shall develop quarterly reports containing a list of all receipts and 
disbursements and distribute them among the membership. 
3. The treasurer will be responsible for checking the accuracy of all bills and invoices and 
paying them correctly and on time. 
4. The treasurer will perform other duties as directed by the president. 
Section E: Advisor 
1. The advisor shall assist the group in their execution of roles and responsibilities. 
2. The advisor shall provide feedback to the organization regarding its operation and 
functioning. 
3. The advisor shall serve as a resource. 
4. The advisor should provide advice upon request, and also should share knowledge, 
expertise, and experience with the group. 
5. The advisor will be a nonvoting member of the organization. 

Article VII-Structure of Group Committees 
Section A: Committee Identification and Appointment 
The following committees (other than Executive Board) shall be appointed by the 
President subject to ratification by the organization during a regular business meeting. 

 
 
 
 1. Social  Committee  

2. Fundraising Committee 

3. Community Service Committee 

Section B: The duties of the standing committees shall include:  
1. The Social Committee shall plan social events and meetings.  

2. The Fundraising Committee will be in charge of community sponsors, fundraising 
events, etc. 

3.The Community Service Committee will organize community events and run a 
mentorship style program with children and youth with diabetes in the community. 

Article VIII-Notice of Meetings 
Section A: The times for regularly scheduled meetings shall be decided upon at the 
beginning of each semester based on members schedules 

Section B: At least 7 days notice shall be given for each regular business meeting.  

Section C: Special or emergency meetings may be called with less than 3 days notice by 
the Executive Board. 

Section D: The meetings shall include a quorum, order of business, and disposition of the 
minutes. 

Article IX: Parliamentary Procedure 
Section A: If a question is brought up by one of the members of the committee or by one 
of the officers, a discussion of the whole group will commence, followed by voting on 
the topic, if necessary.

DocsList.Data:
Charter of The Massachusetts Daily Collegian

This document shall be accessible to all Collegian Employees as well as the Student Government
Association.
Article I: Name

Section  1: The name of this organization is The Massachusetts  Daily Collegian.

Article IT: Purpose

Section  1: The basic purpose of the organization shall be to provide three types of interrelated senices:
1A. To provide the University community with a daily newspaper committed to its role as a forum for information; diverse viewpoints, and debate. The newspaper is guided by responsibilities to truth, accuracy, and the public's right to know.
lB. To provide the University undergraduate community with the educational and vocational
experiences that result from producing a daily newspaper.
lC. To provide a diverse newspaper that represents the entire University community.

Article III: Employment and Membership

Section 1: Collegian Staffstatus is defined as any undergraduate  student, full- or part-time, at the
University of Massachusetts, Amherst, who fills a regular, paid, or appointed staff position.
lA. UMass undergraduate students may attain Collegian Staff status upon having six (6) stories published in The Collegian. After achieving Collegian Staff status, one must have at least three (3) stories published in The Collegian each semester thereafter to maintain this title.
lB. UMass undergraduate students in the Photography department may attain Collegian Staff
status upon having four (4) photos published inThe Collegian within one (1) month. After achieving Staff status, one must have at least three (3) photos published in The Collegian each month of printing thereafter to maintain this title.
lC. UMass undergraduate students may attain Collegian Staff status as columnists upon having
six (6) columns published in The Collegian within one (1) semester. After achieving Staff status, one must have at least three (3) columns published in The Collegian each semester thereafter to maintain this title.
lD. UMass faculty and graduate students, Five College students, and other members of the community may write for The Collegian as Collegian Correspondents,  but can never achieve Collegian Staff status.
IE. The Editor in Chief will be elected into office as per the procedures of Bylaw I.
IE. Business Staff will be hired as per the procedures of Bylaw IT. IF. Graphics Staff will be hired as per the procedures of Bylaw ill.
lG. Newsroom managers and editors will be hired as per the procedures of Bylaw IV.

Section 2: Staff members must attend Staff meetings. Failure to attend such meetings will result in penalties as described in Bylaw V. Department  managers may grant exemptions at any time.

Ar ticle IV: Execu tive Boar d

Section 1: The seven (7) voting members of The Collegian Executive Board shall inch}de (1) Editor in Chief, chairperson, (2) Managing Editor, (3) Business Manager, (4) Production Manager, (5) Night Supervisor, (6) Advertising Manager, and (7) Ad vertising Production Manager or Editorial Production Manager. 	·
lA. The Editor in Chief and the Production Manager shall decide at the beginning of the school year if the Advertising or Editorial Production Manager will sit on the Executive Board.

Section 2: The Executive Board shall oversee and coordinate  operations ofthe newspaper by discussing



and determining general  polices and procedures that shall  be executed  by the newspaper as a whole. They  will also address  issues that have evolved at secondary board meetings. Individual members are then responsible for conveying this information to their respective  boards.

Section 3: The Executive Board  is responsible for the operations of The Collegian through the last day of spring  semester classes. As each member  of the Executive Board  is elected or hired, he or she will attend  meetings as a voting member.
3A. The current  Editor in Chief will break  all ties.

Section 4: The Executive Board  will meet weekly  at a time convenient for all board members. Quorum is four (4) memberS.
4A. Failure to serve the position  in a diligent manner will result in a Warning, as outlined in
BylawXIll.

Section 5: The current  Executive board shall officially hire all members of the Executive board  for the
·following'year. A majority  vote of the current members is needed  to approve  all new executive board  hires. Quorum is (4) executive board members. The Editor in Chief shall break  all ties.

Article V: Secondary Boards

Section 1: Each of the three (3) Collegian departments will have its own board: Board of Editors, Business Board, and Graphics Board. In addition the Editorial Board  shapes The Collegian's daily  public opinion.
lA. All boards will have power and authority within their own departments.
lB. All boards will report to and are responsible to the Executive Board, and ultimately the entire staff.
lC. Failure  to serve the position  in a diligent manner will result in a Warning, as outlined in
Bylaw:xm.

Section 2: Board  of Editors is responsible for determining editorial content of the newspaper, aside  from policy  editorials.
2A. Find a complete listing of Board of Editors members outlined in Bylaw  VI.
2B. Board  of Editors  members  will discuss and implement policies  voted on by its members in an effort  to improve the organization, efficiency, and integrity of the editorial  departments. The board will also discuss  issues of coverage, objecti  ·ty accuracy, and community relations.
2C. The board  will hear appeals from  Collegian   taff in The Newsroom as per the procedures of
BylawVll.
2D. All Board  of Editors  members  will serve one {1) yearlong term on the board. This term  will commence following the last day of spring semester class during  the year he or she was hired.

Section 3: Business Board  represents the business, finance, advertising, human  resources and distribution departments.
3A. Find a complete listing of Business Board members outlined  in Bylaw VITI.
3B. The Business Board  is responsible for providing the Business Manager  and Editor in Chief with input regarding forecasting and cash budgeting at the beginning of each semester. The board handles all issues regarding The Collegian's accounts payable, accounts receivable, revenue and expenses, purchases, payroll  and promotions, size and advertising content. Also included in these discussions will be any and all issues concerning the ongoing activities of the Business office.
3C. The board  will hear appeals from  Collegian Business Staff as per the procedures of
Bylaw IX.
3D. All Business Board  members  will serve  one (1) yearlong term on the board. This term will
\	commence following the last day of spring  semester class during the year he or she was hired.

Section 4: Graphics Board  represents both advertising and editorial production.
4A. Find a complete listing  of Graphics Board members outlined  in Bylaw X.



4B. The Graphics Board is responsible for all production aspects of The Collegian. On a
basis, this will include page mark-ups as well as addressing nightly problems and graphics st) e changes. The Graphics Board will strive to ensure The Collegian maintains a consistent graphics style  to acliieve consistent completion time every night, to properly maintain and seek
improvement in the equipment, to educate the entire Collegian staff on the production process, and
to get the entire staff involved in production.
4C. The board will hear appeals from Collegian Graphi 	Staff as per the procedures of Bylaw XI.
4D. All Graphics Board members ID1l serve one (1) yearlong term on 	e board. This term will
commence following the last day of 	ring semester call during the year he or she was hired.

Section 5: Editorial Board is responsible for drafting and approving policy editorials indi<	· g The Collegian's editorial stance on a variety of issues. Policy editorials are printed on    e opinion page and are clearly marked as the opinion of The Collegian.
SA. Find a complete listing of Editorial Board members outlined in Bylaw XII.
SB. Editorial Board members must contnbute ideas for editorials. Knowledge of current e  ents is essential to make an informed decision on an editorial stance. Members must also help compose editorials and stand behind board decisions.
SC. All Editorial Board members will serve one (1) yearlong term on the board. This term will commence following the last day of spring semester call during the year he or she was hired.

Article VI: The Massachusetts Daily Collegian Policy Guide

Section 1: To ensure The Collegian operates most efficiently, the Executive Board may, when necessary, implement polices affecting any or all departments. Subsequent rulings passed by the Executive Board will be based on these polices.
lA. These policies shall be documented in The Massachusetts Daily Collegian Policy Guide. Among its defining Articles will be included The Collegian's Code of Ethics. Copies of this
guide will be freely available to all Collegian Staff members, as well as Collegian Correspondents. lB. All policies implemented by the Executive Board must conform to the guidelines set by Articles in The Massachusetts Daily Collegian  Charter and all of its Bylaws.

Section 2: Amendments may be made to The Collegian  Policy Guide at any time. ·
2A. Any Collegian Staff member may submit an amendment proposal in writing to the Executive
Board. He or she will designate any Board member(s) to bring up this proposal for consideration.
2B. The secondary board chairperson in the department(s) the proposed amendment will affect will then submit the proposal before their secondary board(s) for review and recommendations.
2C. Chairpersons will retum with feedback, and the Executive Board will then vote on the proposal. A vote of five (5) or more in favor is needed to pass an amendment.

Article VII: Disciplinary Actions

Section 1: Collegian Staff status as well as Collegian Correspondent status may be officially Warned, suspended, or revoked by a Staff or Correspondent member's supervisor, as per the procedures of Bylaw XIII.
lA. Cause for a Warning, suspension, or dismissal will be based on (1) failure to competently perform the position's duties, paid or unpaid, to which the person has been elected, appointed, or hired, (2) a performance of such duties in a way to be detrimental to the best interests of The Collegian, and (3) failure to follow The Collegian  Charter or Policy Guide.
lB. All Warnings, suspensions, and dismissals must be accompanied with a signed letter explaining the reason for the disciplinary action and outlining the procedure for appeals as per Article VIII. All letters of suspension must inform the recipient that he or she may be dismissed if his or her job performance is not corrected. The Editor in Chief must first approve all letters. If the letter is for the Editor in Chief, the Managing Editor must give approval. All letters of suspension,  warning or dismissal must be filed with the Human Resources department.



Article VIII: Appea ls

Section 1:  Responsibility and authority of all appeals shall be in accordance with the Flowchart attached at the end of the Bylaws, and may be appealed up the ladder of responsibility to the department Boards, the Executive Board, and ultimately the entire Collegian staff.


Section 2: Each department head (Managing Editor, Production Manager, and Business Manager) has the authority to overturn the decision of an editor, supervisor, or manager within his or her department. 	.
Section 3: A department head's decision may be appealed to his or her department's Board, which has
power to overturn the decision with a majority vote, or to the Editor in Chief, who has the power to overturn the decision.
Section 3a. A decision by a Board or the Editor in Chief may be appealed to The Collegian Executive
oard, wh ch has the power to overturn the decision with a majority vote.
Section4: All appeals must be in written form and submitted to the proper manager/editor/board. All appeals must be filed with the Human Resources Department.



Article IX: Amendments
Section 1 Amendments to the Charter shall become permanent by a vote of more than 50 percent of those who attend a staff meeting convened for this purpose. Quorum for said meeting shall be one third of the staff. Quorum shall be determined by the Editor in Chief.

Section 2 Amendments to the Charter may be proposed by any staff member and shall be submitted to the Editor in Chief, who will promptly bring it to the Executive Board. The Board shall vote on submitting the amendment to a staff meeting vote within two weeks of the date the proposed amendment was received by the Editor in Chief. A two-thirds vote of Executive Board in favor is required to submit the proposal to the staff.

Section 3 If the Executive Board refuses to submit a proposed amendment to a staff vote, a staff 111ember may force such a vote by submitting a petition to the Editor in Chief with the signatures of more than 50 percent of the staff members within three weeks of the proposal's rejection by the Executive Board. The Editor in Chief shall determine whether the petition has garnered' more than_
50 percent. If the petition is valid, the staff meeting must be held not more than two weeks after the petition was submitted to the Editor in Chief.

Article X: Ratifica tion
Section 1: This Charter shall be ratified and take full effect upon a uillmimous vote of the Collegian
Executive Board. 	' This Charter was ratified by a unanimous vote of the Collegian Executive Board on 9/1/04

Bylaw Section of The Massachusetts Daily Collegian Cha rter

This document shall be available to all Collegian Employees.

Bylaw I: Editor  in Chief Elections

Section 1: Collegian Staff will elect The Editor in Chief into office.
lA. The Executive Board will set the election date and format and officially announce it to the Staff: The board will accept applications for ihe position from the official announcement until a week prior to the first candidate debate.
lB. Any Collegian Staff member can run in the election.
1C. A candidate must be elected by more than a 50 percent of the votes cast in the election. If no candidate receives more than 50 percent, a run-off election will be held no more than two weeks
after the initial election between the top two vote getters.
lD. Any Stitff member, as defmed in Article III, Sec., is eligible to vote for Editor in Chie£

Section 2: In case of a vacancy in the Editor in Chief position, the Managing Editor will assume responsibility for the office until an emergency staff meeting is convened to elect a new Editor in Chief. The meeting must take place within five (5) days of the declared vacancy. A 50 percent plus one vote of the staff attending such a meeting is required to elect the new Editor in Chie£

Section 3: Appeals of election results shall be directed to the Executive Board.

Bylaw II: Business Staff Hiring

Section 1: Appropriate managers shall be responsible for hiring staffers within their appropriate sub departments within the Business office.
lA. Business manager shall have final authority in hiring within the Business office.
Section 2: All applications for hiring must be written. A formal interview must be conducted for all positions with at least two members of the business office in attendance of thinterview.
Section 3: All new hires shall fill out the appropriate paperwork as deemed necessary by the Human
Resources department. Failure to do so shall result in pay being delayed or forfeited.

Bylaw ill: Graphics Staff Hiring

Section 1: Appropriate managers shall be responsible for hiring staffers within their appropriate sub departments within the Graphics department.
lA. Production manager shall have final authority in hiring within the Graphics office. Section 2: All applications for hiring must be written. A formal interview must be conducted for all
positions with at least two members of the graphics department in attendance of the interview. Section 3: All new hires shall fill out the appropriate paperwork as deemed necessary by the Human
Resources department. Failure to do so shall result in pay being delayed or forfeited.

Bylaw VI: Newsroom Managers and Editors Hiring

I
Section 1: Appropriate editors/managers shall be responsible for hiring staffers within their appropriate sub
departments within the Newsroom
lA. Managing Editor shall have final authority in hiring within the Newsroom.
Section 2: All applications for hiring must be written. A formal interview must be conducted for all positions with at least two members of the newsroom in attendance of the interview.
Section 3: All new hires shall fill out the appropriate paperwork as deemed necessary by the Human
Resources department Failure to do so shall result in pay being delayed or forfeited.



Bylaw V: Staff Meeting Penalties

Section 1: Failure to attend three (3) consecutive Staff meetings or five (5) staff meetings per semester will
result in a Warning, as outlined in Bylaw XIII.  Department managers may grant exceptions.

Bylaw VI: Board of Editors Roster

Section 1: All Senior Desk Editors and Assistant Desk Editors will serve on the Board of Editors, as well as The Newsroom's three (3) Top Editors.
lA. The seventeen (17) voting members of the Board of Editors will include: Managing Editor, chairperson (1)
Arts and Living Senior Desk Editor (I)  Arts and Living Assistant Desk Editors (2) Comics Senior Desk Editor (1) Editorial/Opinion  Senior Desk Editor (1) Editorial/Opinion Assistant Desk Editor (1) News Senior DeskEditor (1)
News Assistant Desk Editors (2) Photography Senior Desk Editor (1) Photography Assistant Desk Editor (1) Sports Senior Desk Editor (1)
Sports Assistant Desk Editors (2)
Night Supervisor (1) Editor in Chief (1)
lB. The Managing Editor will break all ties.
lC. Collegian Website technician(s) should attend Board of Editors meetings upon request from the Managing Editor or the Editor in Chief.
lD. The Board of Editors will meet weekly. Quorum is nine (9) members.

Bylaw VII: Newsroom Collegian Staff appeals to Board  of Editors
Section 1: All appeals within the Newsroom must be written and filed with the Human re ources Department. Appeals should be submitted to the Managing Editor for review/vote during the subsequent Board of Editors meeting. If after two weeks the appeal has not been brought before the Board of Editors, the appeal may be submitted to the Editor in Chief for review.

Bylaw VIII: Business  Board Roster

Section 1: All Managers and Assistant Managers of the Business departments will serve on the Business
Board, as well as Editor in Chief. 	·
lA. The ten (10) voting members of Business  Board will include: Business Manager, chairperson (1)
Assistant Business Manager (1) Adyertising  Manager (1)
Assistant Advertising Manager (1) Finance Manager (1)
Assistant Finance Manager (1)
/  Circulation/Distribution (to be determined at the start of the year) Manager (1) Human Resource Manager (1)
Special Issues Coordinator (1) .
Editor irtChief(l)
lB. The Business Manager will break all ties.
lC. The non voting members shall include: Accounting Clerk (1) Marketing interns/managers (if
applicable)
lD. The Business Board will meet weekly. Quorum is six (6) members.



Bylaw IX: Business Staff appeals to Business Board
Section 1: All appeals within the Business office must be written and flied with the Human resources
Department. Appeals should be submitted to the Business Manager for review/vote during the subsequent Business Board meeting. If after two weeks the appeal has not been brought before the Business Board, the appeal may be submitted to the Editor in Chieffor review.



Bylaw X: Graphics Board Roster

Section 1: All Managers of the Graphics department will serie on Graphics Board, as well as two (2) Top
Editors.
lA. The five (5) voting members of the Graphics Board will include:
Production Manager, chairperson (1) Advertising Production Manager (1) Editorial Production Manager (1) Night Supervisor (1)
Editor in Chief(1)
lB. The Production Manager will break all ties.
lC. The Graphics Boardwill meet weekly. Quorum is four (4) members.

Bylaw XI: Graphics Staff appeals to Graphics Board

Section 1: All appeals within the Graphics Department must be written and filed with the Human resources Department. Appeals should be submitted to the Production Manager for review/vote during the subsequent Graphics Board meeting. If after two weeks the appeal has not been brought before the Graphics Board the appeal may be submitted to the Editor in Chief for review.



Bylaw XII: Editorial Board Roster

Section 1: The EditoriaVOpinion Desk Editors and The Newsroom's three (3) Top Editors will serve on the
Editorial Board.
lA. The seven (7) voting members of the Editorial Board will include: EditoriaVOpinion Senior Desk Editor, chairperson (1) EditoriaVOpinion Assistant Desk Editor (1)
Managing Editor (1)
Night Supervisor (1) Editor in Chief (1)
Business Room representative (1)
Graphics Room representative (1)
lB. The EditoriaVOpinion Senior Desk Editor will break all ties.
lC. The Editorial Board will meet weekly. Quorum is four (4) members.

Bylaw XIII: Warnings, Suspensions, a nd Dismissal Procedures

Section 1: Executive Board members may be suspended without pay or dismissed from their jobs.
lA. The Editor in Chief may suspend without pay for a period of one (1) to five (5) publishing days any Board member. An Executive Board vote of five (5) or more in favor is needed to ratify or overturn this suspension.
lB. ThEditor in Chief may dismiss any Board member. A combined vote with members of the Executive Board and the Staff in said Board member's department must be obtained within one week to ratify or overturn this dismissal. The Editor in Chief will oversee this meeting.  A vote of two thirds in favor of the dismissal will ratify the decision. Quorum is two thirds of all relevant Staff members.	'



1C. A petition calling for the dis  issal of a Board n;1ember must be signed by one third of the Staff in said Board membesrdepartment and subrnltted to the Editor in Chief. Procedures will continue from there as per Bylaw XIII, Section  lB.  If the petition is against the Editor in Chief, the petition will be submitted to the Managing Editor, who will carry out the duties of Bylaw XIII, Section  lB.

Section 2: Staff members may be Warned, suspended without pay, or dismissed from their jobs.
2A. The Editor in Chief, the Managing Editor, Business Manager, and Production Manager may each Warn, suspend· without pay for a period of one (1) to five (5) publishing days, or disrnlss a Staff member or Correspondent in his or her department.
2B. Disrnlssal follows two or more Warnings upon approval from the Editor in Chief. Staff members and Correspondents may be dismissed without prior Waming(s) in extreme cases upon approval from the Editor in Chief. Warnings are deleted from record after each fiscal year.
2C. If the Editor in Chief acquires two or more Warnings through secondary board meetings and dismissal is.Proposed, the procedures of Bylaw XIII, Section lC will be followed.

Bylaw XIV: Amendments to Bylaws
Section 1: Any member of the staffm;ly submit an amendment to the bylaws. The amendment should be submitted to the Editor in Chief, who shall bring the amendment up for review/vote of the Executive Board. Section 2: Amendments to the bylaws shall become permanent by a unanimous vote by The Collegian Executive Board. Quorum shall be all members of the Executive Board.


This Bylaw Section was ratified by a unanimous vote of Collegian Executive Board on 9/1104.

DocsList.Name: Turf Club Budget Description.docx
DocsList.Data:
Turf Club Budget Description

The Turf Club is a group that strives to further the academic and professional development of Turfgrass Management students. We mentor younger students, provide academic assistance, and organize an internship fair to aid them in the search for their internships. We do lawn work in the fall to fundraise for our trips to national turf conferences where we compete in the Turf Bowl academic competitions. Our budget request outlines our need for financial assistance from the University to supplement our trips to national competitions and represent UMass at such events. We learn, network and compete at these conferences each year, it is integral for us to send as many as possible that have shown the drive and perseverance to become accomplished turf professionals. Thank you for your time and consideration.

The Constitution of the University of Massachusetts Women’s Ultimate Frisbee Club (1).pdf
DocsList.Data:
The Constitution of the University of Massachusetts Women’s Ultimate Frisbee Club 

Updated, 09/10/2016 

Article I: Name 

Sec 1: The name of the organization is the Lady Zoo, formerly known as Zoo Disc Women, officially 

known as Women’s Ultimate Frisbee Club. 

Article II: Objective 

Sec 1: The objective of the team is to successfully compete in USA sanctioned Ultimate Frisbee 

Tournaments. The goal is to qualify for the national tournament at the end of the season and advance as 

far as possible. 

Article III: Mission Statement 

Sec 1: Zoo Disc Women is an organization dedicated to female athletes interested in the sport of Ultimate 

Frisbee. We would like to promote the knowledge and enjoyment of Ultimate Frisbee through recruiting 

and practice. We also want to increase the skill level of the members involved in the organization. 

Finally, we want to be positive ambassadors of the University at intercollegiate competitions by being 

competitive and demonstrating sportsmanship. 

Article IV: Membership 

Membership in this organization will not be restricted on the basis of race, color, religion, ethnicity, 

national origin, physical or mental disability, sexual orientation, veteran status, gender identity, gender 

expression, sex, or age.   

Section 1: The qualifications for membership in this club are as follows: 

● Must be currently enrolled at the University of Massachusetts Amherst 

● Must be able to commit a minimum of 6 hours per week to the organization barring any class or 

personal conflict. The team must be notified via email of any absence that will occur before 

practice that day. 

 ● All members are asked to attend all scheduled tournaments, barring any academic or personal 

reasons. Team members must notify captains beforehand if a conflict should occur. 

● All members are expected to pay dues that include all travel accommodations, uniform costs, and 

USAU membership fees.. 

Section 2: Types of Membership:  

● Active – Currently enrolled UMass Amherst students who attend meetings, organization 

functions, and pay dues.  Only active members may vote on matters directly affecting the 

organization and its functioning, including but not limited to elections, constitutional 

amendments, and other motions put forth in general body meetings. 

● Honorary – Alumni or community members who express interest and attend meetings and/or 

organization functions regularly   

Sec 3: Warning’s and Revocation of Membership 

● Should a member conduct themselves in a way that is deemed unbefitting or unsportsmanlike or 

breaks any rules or policies set forth by the University's Student Code of Conduct, their 

membership eligibility will be brought before the Executive Board and the RSO advisor will be 

contacted immeditley. The Executive Board will vote on the member’s membership status and the 

vote must be unanimous in order for a warning to take place. 

● A formal warning will consist of a two week suspension for team travel and social events. The 

warning will last for two weeks. The member, during this time may attend practice and make 

efforts to show improvements. 

● After the two week period the executive board must vote unanimously to revoke the membership 

of the individual or to lift the warning. A split decision will be brought to a coach or the RSO 

advisor to determine an outcomes. 

● Following a formal warning without a revocation of membership, the member must continue to 

uphold the team and universities policies and standards. No member shall been given more than 

two warnings. Any grounds for a third warning will lead to the immediate revocation of 

membership. 

Article V: Team Officers: 

 Sec 1: Team officers are team members who are voted into office by majority vote of the team and are 

comprised of the following positions: 

A. President 

B. Vice President 

C. Treasurer 

D. Secretary 

Sec 2: All officer positions are one­year terms. Freshmen are not permitted to be officers unless no 

sophomores, juniors or seniors want the position. 

Sec 3: Officers are selected by holding a team meeting where potential officers nominate themselves for a 

specific position. After team members are nominated, the team votes by secret or public ballot for each 

position. A graduating senior or coach tallies votes and majority wins. 

Sec 4: If an officer is not doing their job the team will vote on whether or not to keep them in office and a 

75% majority vote removes them from her position. 

Sec 5: Each year both the president and the treasurer must gain signature responsibility by attending an 

RSO meeting in September to handle all financial aspects of the team. 

Article VI: Amendments 

Sec 1: Amendments to the constitution shall become permanent by majority vote by officers.
