DocsList.Name: Official Copy of UPC Constitution (3_2023).docx
DocsList.Data:
University Programming Council 
Constitution
Updated with Executive Board Amendments on April 20th, 2021. 

Article I: Name
The organization outlined in this constitution shall be called the University Programming Council hereafter referred to as UPC.

Article II: Purpose

Aim

UPC is a student-run organization that plans and executes innovative campus-wide events for the students of UMass Amherst and the surrounding community. UPC aims to provide students with an abundance of safe, educational, and entertaining events.

Objectives

UPC will sponsor and integrate social, educational, recreational, and multicultural activities at the University of Massachusetts Amherst, consistently evaluating these programs and assessing the needs of the University community in order to provide meaningful developmental opportunities and experiences, as well as provide a more enjoyable and purposeful life for all members of the University of Massachusetts Amherst community. UPC will be responsive to minority and women’s interests and will facilitate awareness and appreciation of a wide variety of programming.

UPC will encourage widespread participation in its programs and provide opportunities for all members and volunteers involved to enhance their leadership, program planning, and program implementation skills. UPC will train and educate the UMass Amherst students about the workings of the entertainment industry and event promotion, as well as the importance of group dynamics and staff relations.

UPC will, through its programs, promote interest in the University of Massachusetts Amherst, and cooperate with all Umass Amherst departments and organizations, and the Amherst and the Five College community.

UPC will positively represent the University of Massachusetts Amherst at regional and national workshops, conferences, and conventions on leadership, student activities, and programming.

UPC will be responsible for surveying and communicating with the students at the University of Massachusetts Amherst and serve as a resource for other programming organizations.

UPC will be an Agency and will be governed as such.

UPC will provide a culminating musical event each spring semester.

Article III: Use of Name and Logo

The use of the name or logo of the University Programming Council for any purpose other than official business is prohibited unless approved by UPC staff.

Article IV: Structure and Organization

Structure

UPC shall consist of an Executive Board, Event Coordinators, and a General Body.

The purpose of the Executive Board is to provide leadership for the University Programming Council. The Executive Board will consist of 5 voting members: Executive Director, Associate Director, Director of Finance, Director of Internal Affairs, and Director of Marketing. Event Coordinators will be appointed by the Executive Board members and Programming Council advisors. 

The Director of Internal Affairs, Director of Marketing, and all Event Coordinators must have been General Body members for no less than one full semester pending extenuating circumstances. The Associate Director and Director of Finance must have served as another Executive Board member or Event Coordinator for no less than one full academic school year. The Executive Director must have served as another Executive Board member for no less than one full academic school year.

Executive Board Installation for the University Programming Board will take place the week after Spring Concert. In the event that there is no Spring Concert, the officers will be installed at the end of the third week in April. The rising Executive Board will be elected by the end of the first week of April.

Executive Board Members:

Executive Director: The Executive Director is responsible for the overall coordination of the University Programming Council and serves as the main representative of UPC to the campus community. The Executive Director will create the agenda and preside over all Executive Board and General Body meetings. The Executive Director will be paid minimum wage for a total of 20 hours per week.

Associate Director: The Associate Director of the University Programming Council works closely with the Executive Director to accomplish the mission and goals of UPC. Duties of the Associate Director include creating the agenda and presiding over all Event Coordinator meetings, conducting one-on-one meetings with each of the Event Coordinators once per semester, and seeking out collaborative opportunities between UPC and other campus organizations. The Associate Director will be paid minimum wage for a total of 15 hours per week.

Director of Finance: The Director of Finance will be responsible for supervising all financial activities relating to all branches of the University Programming Council. Duties of the Director of Finance include submitting end-of-the-semester financial reports to the Executive Director, producing appropriate financial information as requested or required, collecting receipts, submitting budget requests to the Student Government Association and other university entities, and helping the Event Coordinator or General Body with grant applications. The Director of Finance shall also receive signature responsibility from the Student Engagement and Leadership. The Director of Finance will be paid minimum wage for a total of 15 hours per week. 

Director of Internal Affairs: The Director of Internal Affairs of the University Programming Council is charged with the organizational aspects of UPC including membership recruitment and communications. This position also includes keeping all UPC members properly informed on meetings and events, as well as keeping track of member requirements and voting membership status. The Director of Internal Affairs is in charge of the general organization of the group and its information. The Director of Internal Affairs will be paid minimum wage for a total of 15 hours per week.

Director of Marketing: The Director of Marketing of the University Programming Council is responsible for leading all Marketing Initiatives. Duties of the Director of Marketing include overseeing all Social Media postings, poster design and printing, promotional materials, and the timing/distribution of all marketing and promotions. The Director of Marketing will work with University Print Services, Social Media, and other entities to make sure that UPC and all events are well publicized. The Director of Marketing must be able to use any relevant software and be well-versed in poster creation. They will also work with a Marketing Coordinator who will be responsible for implementing new and innovative ideas to promote UPC and the events put on by UPC, including but not limited to posters, promotions, tabling, and social media. The Director of Marketing will be paid minimum wage for a total of 15 hours per week.

Contracts: All Executive Board Members will sign a contract upon taking office. This contract should be read and signed by the executive board member and submitted to the UPC Staff Advisor. Failure to uphold the responsibilities outlined in the contract and in this Constitution will result in Performance Review and/or Removal from Office.

Event Coordinators are responsible for the ongoing functioning and operation of their respective event committees. Each coordinator is responsible for planning and implementing a minimum of two different events per academic year (the length of the appointed position). The Event Coordinators are the main users of the UPC event planning process and work closely with the Executive Board and UPC advisors. Event coordinators include:
Speakers
Multicultural Coordinator(s) 
Concerts Coordinator(s)
Special Event Coordinator(s)
Late Night Event Coordinator(s)
Marketing Coordinator(s)
Performing Arts Coordinator(s) 
Social Event Coordinator (s)
Production Specialist. (s)
Policy and Finance Event Coordinator

Event Coordinator Membership Requirements:
Voting requirements with the exception of (2) Late Night movies as opposed to 2 Sunday and 2 Friday

Contracts: All Event Coordinators will sign a contract upon taking office.This contract should be read and signed by the Event Coordinator and submitted to their Executive Board Advisor Failure to uphold the responsibilities outlined on the contract and in this Constitution will result in Performance Review and/or Removal from Office.

Organization

UPC General Body meetings shall be held once weekly throughout the academic year, unless extenuating circumstances require an alteration in scheduling.

Executive Board meetings shall be held at least once weekly throughout the academic school year.

Event Coordinators will attend Executive Board meetings upon request with at least 24 hours notice. With the discretion of the Associate Director, there shall be bi-weekly meetings between Event Coordinators and the Executive Board.

Quorum:

A quorum of Executive Board members shall consist of all members present.

A quorum of the General Body shall consist of a simple majority of voting members. 

A quorum of Event Coordinators shall consist of a two-thirds majority.

A quorum of the General Body, Event Coordinators, and Executive Board is necessary to constitute a binding vote.

Article V: Role of the Advisor

The Advisor of The University Programming Council shall play a supportive role in the administration of the organization. She or he shall not have a vote in the University Programming Council. They shall work with the Executive Board to determine policy or programming decisions to be voted on by the Voting Membership. Specific responsibilities include the following:

The Advisor shall serve as a resource person who can answer questions, provide advice and make suggestions concerning programming and policymaking.

The Advisor shall advise and assist the Executive Board in the research, development, implementation and evaluation of the programs.

The Advisor shall provide continuity during periods of leadership transition.

The Advisor shall counsel the Executive Board in regulations, policies, and standard procedures of the University.

The Advisor shall represent the best interests of the Programming Council in all relations with members of the University community.

The Advisor shall assist in negotiating and signing all contracts as the University requires.

The Advisor shall be present for all official meetings of the Executive Board. The Advisor shall attend the first General Body meeting of the semester and on other times when requested by EBoard no less than 24 hours in advance. 
The Advisor is able to place any Executive Board member under Performance Review due to failure to uphold responsibilities as laid out in the contract or this Constitution. If necessary, the Advisor can also step in to Remove an Executive Board member from Office, should the Executive Board itself be unable to make the decision. 

Article VI: Membership

 	Membership in the University Programming Council is open to any undergraduate student in good standing at the Five Colleges and Mount Ida. UPC will not discriminate from membership because of race, color, religion, creed, sex, gender, age, marital status, national origin, mental, or physical disability, political belief, or affiliation, veteran status, sexual orientation, or any other class of individuals protected from discrimination under state or federal law.

All UPC members including the Executive Board will sit on the General Body, participating in all events and programming organized by the Programming Council.

Voting Membership

There shall be an open number of voting members of UPC.

To qualify as a voting member, one must attend all meetings with three unexcused absences. The number of excused absences allowed will be determined by the current Director of Internal Affairs

Voting members must assist at 50% of the events organized by UPC per semester excluding Spring Concert, work two Friday and two Sunday movies, and 3 flyering/tabling events per semester. This shift can include: tabling in the Campus Center Concourse, and/or being available in the UPC office in order to display involvement for the council and to make a lasting impression upon the UMass community. The number of events will include those before the new member joined. If a member cannot attend an event due to extenuating circumstances, including illness, an exam, class, or a family emergency, they must email the Director of Internal Affairs on or before the day of the event. To make up for the absence, said member must do UPC hours equivalent to the length of an event shift. This can include flyering parties, tabling, an extra movie, a second shift at another event, social media interaction, or coordinating with the Executive Director for extra UPC hours. Accurate membership records shall be kept and made available through the Director of Internal Affairs. 

In order to be eligible to work at the spring concert, one must join no later than the fourth week of the spring semester, and must also be a voting member.


Non-Voting Membership 

There shall be an unlimited number of non-voting members.

In order to become a non-voting member, one must attend a UPC General Body meeting, or work at one (1) UPC event.

Non-voting members have the right to be recognized and to make suggestions at all UPC General Body meetings.

Article VII: Finances

Fiscal Management

During each semester of each academic year, the Executive Director will work with the Director of Finance to create a projected working budget for the Programming Council. The working budget shall serve as a general outline for proposal planning, but will not dictate a limit to the total amount of a program proposal.

At the end of each semester each Event Coordinator will submit a proposed event and budget for the current semester and a projected budget for the next semester to the Director of Finance.

UPC shall seek additional funding as necessary to ensure low-ticket costs to UMass Amherst students, and the financial feasibility of events.

Monetary Compensation for Executives

The Programming Council Advisors will decide which positions are compensated at the beginning of each semester.

Payroll begins the Fall semester and ends the last day of classes for Spring semester. Minimum wage pay for ten to twenty (10-20) hours per week, depending on position. Optional Summer payroll is available for no more than three(3) Executive Board members, no more than  forty (40) hours per week each. The Late Night Programmers will be paid minimum wage for no more than five (5) hours per week.

Co-sponsorships

There shall be a predetermined budget allocated by the Director of Finances per semester for co-sponsorships.

RSOs interested in co-sponsoring an event with UPC must submit a Co-sponsorship form for review by the Executive Board providing a description of and all costs associated with the program.

UPC shall take into consideration any co-sponsorship proposal from an RSO that reflects UPC’s aims and objectives. 


Article VIII: Program Proposals

Before planning an event, Event Coordinators must propose potential programming to the Executive Board for review during an Executive Board/Event Coordinators meeting. This proposal shall include all details of a proposed program, including a description of the program and all costs associated with the program. Program Proposals must be approved by the Executive Board by a simple majority vote.

Any proposal that involves working with another group or organization must include a Co-sponsorship agreement that must be submitted with the Programming Proposal and approved by the Director of Finance.

The Executive Board will have primary responsibility in regards with coordinating, planning, and organizing Spring Concert. The Event Coordinators will also be involved with the main responsibilities, alongside specific Executive Board members.

The Executive Board Elect will have primary responsibility in regards with coordinating, planning, and executing the Homecoming Parade, beginning after their election in the spring. They will continue this responsibility as they become the full Executive Board in the summer and fall.

Article IX: Annual Election

Elected Positions

UPC shall annually elect officers to all five of the Executive Board positions of Executive Director, Associate Director, Director of Finance, Director of Internal Affairs, and Director of Marketing. All Executive Board Applicants will be required to fill out an application to be reviewed by the outgoing Eboard and Advisors. Eboard elects will be required to give a speech to the general body and the general body will have a chance to vote anonymously. These votes will be considered by the outgoing Eboard and advisors when making final decisions on the incoming Eboard.

The newly elected Executive Board with the assistance of the Advisors will appoint Event Coordinators based upon the application process.

 Applications

Election applications and nominations will be taken for all Executive Board positions beginning on the fourth General Body meeting after the start of the spring semester.

Election Committee

The Election Committee shall consist of the outgoing Executive Board and Advisors.

If an outgoing Executive Board member is applying for a position, they will sit out of any meetings discussing that particular position.

The Election Committee shall supervise and document the election procedures.

The Election Committee shall introduce candidates to the General Body, and monitor speeches and questioning.

The Election Committee shall announce and inform the General Body of election plans, procedures, and voting criteria.

The Election Committee shall make a head count at the door of the election meeting.

The Election Committee shall supervise the layout and printing of ballots, distribution, safeguarding, and counting of ballots.

The Election Committee shall announce the applicants to the General Body.

IV) Procedures

Eligibility
Any active voting UPC member may run for Event Coordinator.

To run for the Executive Board positions of Director of Internal Affairs or Director of Marketing, the nominee must have been a General Body member for no less than one full semester. To run for the Executive Board positions of Executive Director, Associate Director, or Director of Finance, the nominee must have served as another Executive Board member or Event Coordinator for no less than two semesters (can include the semester they are running for position in).

Extenuating Circumstances: A voting general body member who wishes to run for one of the aforementioned Executive Board positions must submit a nomination which will be voted on by the Election Committee. 

There shall be an observation period from the time elected to the last day of classes. Terms shall begin immediately following the last day of classes of the spring semester.

In any extenuating circumstances where there are no eligible candidates, the sitting eboard will vote on whether or not a member can run for the position.

Applications

An unlimited number of applications shall be taken.

There must be at least one (1) applicant for each position, and the            application period may be extended to insure this.

An applicant may run for only one (1) Executive Board position.

Elections
Voting shall occur only after each candidate or ticket has the opportunity to address the General Body and respond to the Body’s questions.

Candidates may actively campaign in a fair, non-slanderous manner; deviations shall be the discretion of the Associate Director.

All applicants may address the body for five (5) minutes at the election meeting, after which questions may be asked of all the candidates.

Elections will be held by the first week of April or to the closest date required for reactivation for the club.

Voting

Each eligible voter may cast only one (1) secret ballot per position.

Ballot Counting

The Election Committee shall count the ballots.

Results shall be made available to the candidates within 24 hours, and announced at the next General Body meeting.

Recounts

Any margin of victory of less than five (5) votes shall constitute an automatic recount.

Any candidate may request in writing to the Associate Director within 24 hours of the original count.

Candidates may not be present for recounts, but may be represented by two (2) witnesses.

Ties and Protests

In the event of an exact tie, election shall be determined by secret ballot at the next General Body meeting.

Consideration of protests against the election for reasons other than recounts shall be held by the Advisors, pending reception within 48 hours of the election announcement to the General Body, a petition signed by half of the voting members of UPC.

A ruling on the protest by the Executive Board shall be considered final.

Finalizing the Election

The Associate Director shall announce the final results to the Executive Board and General Body.

The ballots shall be destroyed once election results are confirmed by the election committee.

Event Coordinators

UPC members interested in Event Coordinator positions must submit an application to the current Executive Board.

All Event Coordinator positions shall be filled over the summer by the Eboard. 

Event Coordinators will take office once confirmed by the newly elected Executive Board.

Article X: Resignations and Removal of Staff Members
Resignations

Resignations must be submitted to the Executive Board in writing one week prior to removal procedure.

Performance Review

Grounds for Performance Review shall include willful abuse of the constitution or policies of UPC; inefficiencies in the performance of one’s duties; misappropriation of UPC funds; or behavior unbecoming of an Executive Board or Event Coordinator.

The Performance Review process must begin by Executive Board vote of 4/5 or Advisor’s discretion.

The Associate Director shall inform an Event Coordinator if they are being placed under Performance Review and the reasoning. The Associate Director will follow up in one month to re-evaluate the Event Coordinator and either end the Performance Review or move them into the Removal process.

The Advisor shall inform an Executive Board member if they are being placed under Performance Review and the reasoning. The Advisor will follow up in one month to re-evaluate the Executive Board member and either end the Performance Review or move them into the Removal process.


Removals

Grounds for Removal shall include willful abuse of the constitution or policies of UPC; inefficiencies in the performance of one’s duties; misappropriation of UPC funds; behavior unbecoming of an Executive Board or Event Coordinator.

Removal process must begin by Executive Board vote of 4/5 or Advisor’s discretion.

Advisor agreement shall be necessary to remove an Executive Board member and a case for Removal will be presented at the next Executive Board meeting.

A 4/5 vote of UPC Executive Board shall be necessary to remove an Event Coordinator.

Executive Board members and Event Coordinators have the option of resigning prior to the removal procedure. 

Vacancies

Vacancies shall be filled within two weeks of the position opening. Refer to Procedures for voting policy for filling vacancies.

Article XI: Amendments

The UPC Executive Board shall review the UPC Constitution annually at the UPC Executive Board Retreat.

Submitting Amendments

Any voting member of UPC may propose an amendment in writing to the UPC Executive Board. The Executive Board shall report its recommendation to the General Body within a month of submission.

Ratifying Amendments

Any proposed amendment must be announced and tabled for two (2) weeks before being voted upon.

A majority of voting members at the General Body meeting when amendment is proposed is necessary to ratify an amendment.

An amendment becomes effective immediately upon ratification unless a specific provision in the amendment dictates otherwise.

Amendments shall not be retroactive unless a specific provision in the amendment dictates otherwise.

Article XII: Parliamentary Authority

Quorum is two-thirds of the General Body. A simple majority of the quorum is necessary to pass any vote that is not addressed in the Constitution.

Article XIII: Committees

Multicultural Coordinator(s):The multicultural coordinator(s) Will collaborate with small clubs/organizations on campus and financially aid them to put on events. The purpose of the cultural collaborations event coordinator is to bring people to the University of Massachusetts Amherst campus whose experience in international and domestic affairs, the sciences, the humanities, and the arts qualify them to interpret, explain, and raise questions about life in all its dimensions. The program will keep the University community sensitive to the world in which it exists and stimulate critical thought and debate by presenting a diverse range of opinions. Furthermore, the programs will seek to encourage thoughtful reflection and dialogue on contemporary issues in order to promote and enlighten the intellectual environment at the University of Massachusetts Amherst. Multicultural Coordinators will put on at least one event per semester.
Speakers Coordinator(s):   the purpose is to bring people to the University of Massachusetts Amherst campus whose experience in international and domestic affairs, the sciences, the humanities, and the arts qualify them to interpret, explain, and raise questions about life in all its dimensions. The program will keep the University community sensitive to the world in which it exists and stimulate critical thought and debate by presenting a diverse range of opinions. Furthermore, the programs will seek to encourage thoughtful reflection and dialogue on contemporary issues in order to promote and enlighten the intellectual environment at the University of Massachusetts Amherst. The Speakers Coordinator(s) will consult with academic departments, campus offices, and RSOs in bringing speakers who are entertaining, diverse, informative, and accomplished in their fields. The Speakers Coordinator(s) will put on at least one event per semester.

Special Events:   The Special Events Coordinator(s) will focus on traditional UMass Amherst events including Big Chill and any other innovative and fun programming ideas. The Special Events Coordinator(s) will put on one event per semester.

Late Night Programming:   The Late Night Programming Event Coordinator(s) will focus on events that occur over the weekend. The primary task of the Event Coordinator(s) is the management of the Late Night programming, including movies, comedy nights, magic shows, etc. Both coordinators will be on payroll for minimum wage for no more than five (5) hours per week. The Late Night Coordinator(s) will put on one event every weekend of the semester, excluding holiday weekends or breaks.

Marketing:  The Marketing Coordinator(s) which includes Street Team, Social Media, Technical Marketing, and Photography ECs will be responsible for implementing new and innovative ideas to promote UPC and the events put on by UPC, including but not limited to posters, promotions, tabling, and social media. They will work directly with the Director of Marketing to ensure this implementation. There will also be a Marketing Team, which will take part in flyering, tabling, distributing promotions, posting to social media, taking photos or video at UPC events, and being trained in poster design.

Performing Arts:   The Performing Arts Coordinator(s) will provide international artistic events from diverse arts disciplines, including but not limited to dance companies, famous artists, and other cultural activities. The Performing Arts Coordinator(s) will work with the Fine Arts Center and other campus organizations and departments for collaborations. The Performing Arts Coordinator(s) will put on at least one  event per semester.

Social:  The Social Coordinator(s) will provide a sense of family within the group through the use of ice-breakers, group social events, and the end of the year Banquet.  They will also connect the group to the community through events involving community service and fundraising, and through the annual Spirit on the Concourse event during Homecoming.

Production Specialists:  The Production Specialists(s) will keep inventory, organize, and manage the UPC equipment and closet. They will also be trained in the use of the UPC sound system and will assist with its set-up and operation at UPC events. They will also manage any renting of UPC equipment.

Policy and Finance: The Policy and Finance Coordinator(s) will be the agency's representative at all SGA meetings advocating for the agency. They also will work on updates to the constitution and assist the Finance Board member with the budget and other expense updates. The event coordinator will also be in charge of handling any situations that arise regarding policy.

DocsList.Name: Official VSA Constitution 2019-2020.pdf
DocsList.Data:
ARTICLE I: TITLE 

Section 1.  The title of this organization shall be “Vietnamese Student Association.” 

ARTICLE II: PURPOSE 

Section 1.  The Vietnamese Student Association's mission is: 
A. To create a supportive atmosphere for all Vietnamese students at the University of 
Massachusetts Amherst. 
B. To serve the needs and interests of Vietnamese students at the University of Massachusetts at 
Amherst. 
Section 2.  The Vietnamese Student Association's goals are: 
A. To advocate unity among the Vietnamese community. 
B. To promote the views, voices, and experiences of the Vietnamese students. 
C. To promote the understanding and awareness of the culture among Vietnamese students and 
other students at the University of Massachusetts, students in the Five-College area, and the 
surrounding communities. 

ARTICLE III: MEMBERSHIP 

Section 1. All undergraduate and graduate students are eligible for full membership in the 
association including students of the Five-College area are eligible for membership.  
All members must abide by the articles of this Constitution. 
Section 2.  There shall be one type of memberships to allow for a diverse organization, offering 
opportunities for involvement in the association to all people. 
Section 3. 
A. All General Members are all undergraduate or graduate students, who have attended at least 
one meeting and event every semester of the association. Documentation of all who attended the 
meeting and events will be taken. 
B. Only executive board officers of the association may hold voting privileges, nominating 
privileges, and candidacy privileges. 

ARTICLE IV: THE EXECUTIVE BOARD 

Section 1. 
A. The executive board will consist of ten officers: President, Vice President, Secretary, 
Treasurer, Co-Event Coordinators, Co-Public Relations, Liaison, and Historian. 
B. The officers of the executive board will be elected by the executive members of this 
association. 
C. Those executive officers of this association shall be eligible to run for any executive position 
stated in this constitution. 
D. The officers of the executive board shall fulfill each of their perspective duties as defined by 
this constitution. 
E. Specific organizational duties of the Executive board members are contingent upon the 
individual request of the President. 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 F. Members of the Executive board hold “general members” status and are pardoned from 
payment to any participated association programming on this campus. 
G. All members of the executive board are obliged to attend all functions of the associations. 
Section 2. 
A. The executive board will hold weekly meeting throughout the academic year as determined 
by the president. The president of the executive board may call special meetings within a 
minimum 24 hours notice. 
B. All members of the executive board are required to attend all executive board meetings with 
(5) unexcused absences. 
C. Any executive member whose unexcused absences exceeds five times will be subject to 
dismissal from the executive board. 
D. Any executive member can call for an emergency meeting upon consultation and agreement 
with two other officers. 
E. All final decisions in the executive board meetings will be determined by majority vote of the 
executive board members. 
Section 3.  The executive board members will establish the agenda for all general meetings of 
this association. The officers of the executive board will preside over each of these meetings. 

ARTICLE V: PRESIDENT 

Section 1. The President of the association shall be the Chief Executive Officer. 
Section 2.The President shall serve as the main representative and speaker of the association. 
Section 3. 
A The President shall preside over all meetings and supervise all activities. 
B. The President shall chair and facilitate all executive boards meetings. 
C. The President shall delegate responsibilities to other members of executive board. 
Section 4. 
A. The President shall initiate decision making decision making by overseeing the referendum 
and mandating the votes of the executive members. 
B. The President shall remain neutral on all referendum and will not be allowed to cast a vote. 
C. The President shall only be allowed to cast a vote as an additional volition to establish an 
absolute ruling among tied decisions. 

ARTICLE VI: VICE-PRESIDENT 

Section 1. 
A. The Vice-President shall be the Chief Administrative Executive Officer of the association. 
B. The Vice-President shall work closely with the President to coordinate all activities. 
C. The Vice-President shall work in place of President be able to executive their duties. 
Section 2. 
A. The Vice President shall coordinate all office procedures and shall manage all duties of the 
office with the Secretary. 
B. The Vice President shall make all final decisions in regards to office procedures. 
Section 3.  The Vice President shall have signature responsibilities. 

ARTICLE VII: SECRETARY 

 
 
 
 
 
 Section 1. 
A. The Secretary shall be Chief Archivist Officer of the association. 
B. The Secretary shall make documented recordings of all events and keep comprehensive files 
of all events. The Secretary shall record minutes of all meetings and file them in an orderly 
manner. 
Section 2. 
A. The Secretary shall work closely with the Vice-President to create a working office 
environment. The Secretary shall work closely with the executive board to create a functioning 
history of the association and complete set of archives 

ARTICLE VIII: TREASURER 

Section 1. 
A. The Treasurer shall be the Chief Financial Executive Officer of the Association. 
B. The Treasurer shall handle all financial transactions and shall create a working budget as 
requested by the President. 
Section 2. The Treasurer shall have signature responsibilities. 
Section 3.  The Treasurer shall record all financial activities of the association. The treasurer 
shall be prepared to accurate weekly reports of the financial status of the association. 

ARTICLE IX: EVENT COORDINATOR 

Section 1. 
A. The Event Coordinator shall be responsible for all social events in the interest to the 
association's members. 
B. The Event Coordinator shall be responsible for booking rooms for events through Campus 
Pulse 
C. The Event Coordinator shall be responsible for completing non-monetary related forms for 
our events. 
D. The Event Coordinator shall be responsible for recruiting and coordinating volunteers for 
sponsored events and activities.  
E. The Event Coordinator shall work closely with the Public Relations Officer to efficiently 
promote all events held by The Association. 

ARTICLE X: PUBLIC RELATIONS 

Section 1. 
A. The Public Relations Officers shall be responsible for publicizing all the association's 
activities and events 
B. The Public Relations Officers shall be responsible for informing the general members and any 
other who express common goals as this association of all meetings and other activities within 
the association. 
C. The Public Relations Officers will work together equally to help promote and advertise the 
association’s events 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 D. The Public Relations Officers shall work closely with the Event Coordinator to promote all 
events held by the association. 

ARTICLE XI: LIAISON 

Section 1. 
A. The Liaison shall be responsible for communicating between other organizations on campus 
for event collaborations and with other Vietnamese Students Associations at other universities. 
B. The Liaison shall be responsible for attending all necessary RSO training meetings and/or 
required cultural meetings  

ARTICLE XIII: ELECTIONS 

Section 1. 
A. An official elections meeting must be announced no less than one meeting prior to the 
meeting. 
B. Official elections meeting for the new executive board should take place by the April 1st. 
C. Only current executive board members will have voting privileges  
D. All candidates must be present at the time of the official election are held 
Section 2. 
A. Voting for a candidate shall be done on a closed ballot sheet. 
B. All position shall be voted upon separately, beginning with the President and continuing as 
listed by the constitution 
C. All candidates running for an executed board position shall be elected to office by the present 
majority vote. 
D. In the event of the absence of an officer and a position remains open, the President has the 
right to appoint a temporary officer to the position until the next time an official election might 
be held. 
Section 3.  
A. In the event that there is only one candidate nominee running for an executive board position 
in an official election meeting, voting shall proceed through vote by acclamation. 
Section 4. 
A. Votes shall be privately counted by (3) designated members, one of which whom shall be 
from the current executive board (not running for that office.) Numbers of votes shall not be 
disclosed unless permission is granted by all candidates of that position. 
B. If numbers are to be disclosed, they must be made public to all individuals including 
candidates. 
C. A recount of votes may be requested by any member of the executive board if there is any 
suspicion of a faulty count of votes. 
D. The entire electoral process shall be run by the highest executive board member who will not 
run for a position. That particular executive board member will not be eligible to be nominated 
or elected during that particular official elections meeting. 

ARTICLE XIV: RESIGNATIONS 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Section 1. All resignations before the completion of an officer's term must be in writing and 
brought before the executive board. 

ARTICLE XV: RECALLS 

Section 1. Impeachment of a member of the executive board may be presented to the President 
by any fellow officer and shall mandate an investigation by the President. 
Section 2. 
A. The officer shall present the impeachment to the President with a detailed explanation of the 
accused officer's violation of the constitution. In turn, that officer shall remain anonymous until 
the actual impeachment process has begun. 
B. The President shall proceed with an investigation into the matter and shall meet with the 
accused officer, to alert them of the charge of the impeachment, to discuss the issue with the 
entire board, and to ask for a resignation if the entire board feels that there has been a violation of 
the constitution. 
C. The accused officer shall be allowed to defend their position before asked to leave the 
meeting. 
D. At least two out of three executive board officers shall be required to remove an officer.  
E. The officer shall be dismissed without possibility of readmittance for an executive position in 
this association.  
Section 3. The following guidelines shall be observed. 
A. The President shall present statement of impeachment before the executive board. 
B. Remaining members of the executive board shall debate and vote on the issue whether of a 
recall of the accused officer should take place. 
C. The majority vote shall rule. The President shall abstain from voting. 
Section 4.   
A. Impeachment of the President shall be brought forward to the Vice President and the Vice 
President shall follow the above guidelines as the President. 

ARTICLE XVI: AMENDMENTS 

Section 1.  Amendments to the Constitution shall be introduced by an Officer of the executive 
board, which then shall be examined by the executive board, and shall be passed by a majority 
vote by all board members. 

ARTICLE XVII: CONSTITUTIONAL POWERS 

Section 1.  VSA shall be governed in its activities by this constitution. 
Section 2. The specification of powers outlined in this constitution shall not be construed as 
limiting to any other powers possessed by the members VSA, or of the organization itself. 

ARTICLE XVIII: RATIFICATION 

Section 1.  The constitution shall be amended by the executive board for ratification on an annual 
basis. The Constitution shall be ratified by majority vote of the executive board.  

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Section 2.  The constitution shall be presented by the executive board on an annual basis for 
ratification. The Constitution shall be ratified by a vote by acclamation of all present board 
members.  

ARTICLE XVIV: SPEECH 
Section 1. VSA shall promote freedom of speech among all members and executive board 
members. 
Section 2. VSA is an all-inclusive RSO, that welcomes students of every race, color, national 
origin, religion, sex, gender identity, sexual orientation, disability, age, marital status, 
family/parental status, income derived from a public assistance program, political beliefs, or 
reprisal or retaliation for prior civil rights activity, and more.

Section 1.
A. The Treasurer shall be the Chief Financial Executive Officer of the Association.
B. The Treasurer shall handle all financial transactions and shall create a working budget as requested by the President.
Section 2. The Treasurer shall have signature responsibilities.
Section 3.  The Treasurer shall record all financial activities of the association. The treasurer shall be prepared to accurate weekly reports of the financial status of the association.

ARTICLE IX: EVENT COORDINATOR

Section 1.
A. The Event Coordinator shall be responsible for all social events in the interest to the association's members.
B. The Event Coordinator shall be responsible for booking rooms for events through Campus Pulse
C. The Event Coordinator shall be responsible for completing non-monetary related forms for our events.
D. The Event Coordinator shall be responsible for recruiting and coordinating volunteers for sponsored events and activities. 
E. The Event Coordinator shall work closely with the Public Relations Officer to efficiently promote all events held by The Association.

ARTICLE X: PUBLIC RELATIONS

Section 1.
A. The Public Relations Officers shall be responsible for publicizing all the association's activities and events
B. The Public Relations Officers shall be responsible for informing the general members and any other who express common goals as this association of all meetings and other activities within the association.
C. The Public Relations Officers will work together equally to help promote and advertise the association’s events
D. The Public Relations Officers shall work closely with the Event Coordinator to promote all events held by the association.


ARTICLE XI: LIAISON

Section 1.
A. The Liaison shall be responsible for communicating between other organizations on campus for event collaborations and with other Vietnamese Students Associations at other universities.
B. The Liaison shall be responsible for attending all necessary RSO training meetings and/or required cultural meetings 


ARTICLE XIII: ELECTIONS

Section 1.
A. An official elections meeting must be announced no less than one meeting prior to the meeting.
B. Official elections meeting for the new executive board should take place by the end of April
C. Only current executive board members will have voting privileges 
D. All candidates must be present at the time of the official election are held
Section 2.
A. Voting for a candidate shall be done on a closed ballot sheet.
B. All position shall be voted upon separately, beginning with the President and continuing as listed by the constitution
C. All candidates running for an executed board position shall be elected to office by the present majority vote 
D. In the event of the absence of an officer and a position remains open, the President has the right to appoint a temporary officer to the position until the next time an official election might be held.
Section 3. 
A. In the event that there is only one candidate nominee running for an executive board position in an official election meeting, voting shall proceed through vote by acclamation.
Section 4.
A. Votes shall be privately counted by (3) designated members, one of which whom shall be from the current executive board (not running for that office.) Numbers of votes shall not be disclosed unless permission is granted by all candidates of that position.
B. If numbers are to be disclosed, they must be made public to all individuals including candidates.
C. A recount of votes may be requested by any member of the executive board if there is any suspicion of a faulty count of votes.
D. The entire electoral process shall be run by the highest executive board member who will not run for a position. That particular executive board member will not be eligible to be nominated or elected during that particular official elections meeting.

ARTICLE XIV: RESIGNATIONS

Section 1. All resignations before the completion of an officer's term must be in writing and brought before the executive board.

ARTICLE XV: RECALLS

Section 1. Impeachment of a member of the executive board may be presented to the President by any fellow officer and shall mandate an investigation by the President.
Section 2.
A. The officer shall present the impeachment to the President with a detailed explanation of the accused officer's violation of the constitution. In turn, that officer shall remain anonymous until the actual impeachment process has begun.
B. The President shall proceed with an investigation into the matter and shall meet with the accused officer, to alert him/ her of the charge of the impeachment, to discuss the issue with the entire board, and to ask for a resignation if the entire board feels that there has been a violation of the constitution.
C. The accused officer will be dismissed immediately without possibility of readmittance to the executive board. 
Section 3. The following guidelines shall be observed.
A. The President shall present statement of impeachment before the executive board.
B. Remaining members of the executive board shall debate and vote on the issue whether of a recall of the accused officer should take place.
C. The majority vote shall rule. The President shall abstain from voting.
Section 4.  
A. Impeachment of the President shall be brought forward to the Vice President and the Vice President shall follow the above guidelines as the President.

ARTICLE XVI: AMENDMENTS

Section 1.  Amendments to the Constitution shall be introduced by an Officer of the executive board, which then shall be examined by the executive board, and shall be passed by a majority vote by all board members.

ARTICLE XVII: CONSTITUTIONAL POWERS

Section 1.  VSA shall be governed in its activities by this constitution.
Section 2. The specification of powers outlined in this constitution shall not be construed as limiting to any other powers possessed by the members VSA, or of the organization itself.

ARTICLE XVIII: RATIFICATION

Section 1.  The constitution shall be amended by the executive board for ratification on an annual basis. The Constitution shall be ratified by majority vote of the executive board. 
Section 2.  The constitution shall be presented by the executive board on an annual basis for ratification. The Constitution shall be ratified by a vote by acclamation of all present board members.

DocsList.Name: UMass_Women's_Volleyball_Constitution__Bylaws.docx
DocsList.Data:
UMass Women’s Volleyball Constitution 

Article I
The name of the organization will be UMASS Women’s Club Volleyball.
Article II
Our mission as a club team is to compete at a high level in the Northeast Women’s Club Volleyball League. We expect to compete year-round at various tournaments throughout Massachusetts, Connecticut, New Hampshire, and Rhode Island. In pursuit of this mission, we plan to travel to schools like Northeastern, Boston College, Dartmouth, and other state schools in the New England area and hope to maintain a high rank in our division. We also plan to travel nationally to compete in the NCVF National Tournament for which we qualify each year. Our greatest goal is to maintain a high level of performance during practice and tournaments in order to continue our success as a club volleyball team.
Article III
Membership to the UMass Women’s Club Volleyball team is open to all students of the University of Massachusetts Amherst.
Membership will be based upon tryouts held at the beginning of the academic year. Students pay a fee of $5 to attend 3 days of tryouts and are evaluated based on their skills and the general needs of the team. We then finalize a roster of about 12-16 girls out of the usual 100+ girls who typically tryout.
Membership will last for the entirety of the academic year in which a member has registered. We are a very competitive team and expect that all members are present at practice 3 days a week and attend all tournaments each semester unless excused.
Article IV
President - is responsible for organizing practices and tournaments, keeping the RSO active and overseeing the other officers.  The president will have SR.
Vice President - is responsible for organizing practices and tournaments and keeping the RSO active.  
Treasurer - is responsible for handling the overall budget and spending/fundraising activities. The Treasurer will have SR.
Secretary - is responsible for keeping track of attendance, overseeing the actions of the other officers, and helping with various activities as needed.

DocsList.Name: ZBT Theta Alpha Constitution.docx
DocsList.Data:
CONSTITUTION

THETA ALPHA CHAPTER 
ZETA BETA TAU FRATERNITY 
UNIVERSITY OF MASSACHUSETTS AMHERST
PREAMBLE
We, the members of the Theta Alpha Chapter of the Zeta Beta Tau Fraternity at the University of Massachusetts Amherst, in order to foster and perpetuate the ties of brotherhood, to advance the ideals and purposes of the Zeta Beta Tau Fraternity, to encourage and promote intellectual awareness, and to develop and strengthen leadership qualities, do ordain and establish this Constitution.
ARTICLE I: NAME AND PURPOSE
Section 1: Name  
The chapter shall be the known as the Theta Alpha Chapter of the Zeta Beta Tau Fraternity and may be symbolized by the letters ZBT.
Section 2: Purpose
The purpose of the chapter is to stimulate, develop and encourage among its members the principles of intellectual awareness, social responsibility, integrity, and brotherly love.
ARTICLE II: DEFINITIONS
Henceforth, the word Chapter shall be used to describe the Theta Alpha Chapter of Zeta Beta Tau. Henceforth, the word University shall be used to describe the University of Massachusetts Amherst. Furthermore, the word Brother shall be used to describe any initiated member of the Theta Alpha Chapter of ZBT in good standing.
ARTICLE III: MEMBERSHIP
Section 1: Eligibility
a. Any male student of good moral character who is enrolled full time at the University of Massachusetts Amherst shall be eligible for membership.
Section 2: Bids
The recruit must attain a positive 80% vote of all active brothers to receive a bid. 
The President is obligated to override individual ‘no’ votes if he believes they were cast with prejudice. 
Section 3: Four-Year Loyalty Rule
a. Each member shall furnish full fraternal, moral, and financial support to the Chapter for a period of four college years, or until such member secures a degree, whichever period is shorter.
b. The chapter’s Executive Board shall determine the interpretation and application of this rule, and any exception thereof, if any.
Section 4: To become a member of the chapter, the prospective member must have been voted on by the chapter, receive a bid, and be initiated using the Fraternity’s initiation ceremony.
Section 5: Active Membership
Only students in good standing with the University who have been duly initiated can be considered active members. 
Active membership shall only be bestowed upon persons who are contributing their moral, physical and financial support to the perpetuation of the chapter. 
There is no inactive status in the chapter. 
A brother shall transition from active membership to alumni status if and only if the brother leaves the University. 
ARTICLE IV: OFFICERS OF THE EXECUTIVE BOARD 
Section 1: Titles, Terms and Eligibility
The elected officers of this chapter shall consist of, in order of chain of command, a President, Internal Vice President, External Vice President, Treasurer, Secretary, and Sergeant-at- Arms. These officers comprise the Executive Board, whose powers and responsibilities are outlined in Article V, Section 1. 
Each officer shall hold his office for exactly one calendar year, beginning with the meeting in which the officer is sworn into office. 
To be able to hold office in this chapter, a brother must be in good standing with both the University and the Fraternity. Any brother suspended for withdrawal of fraternal, moral and financial support shall be ineligible during the duration of suspension. Any brother who is on academic, residential or any other probation from the University shall be ineligible to hold office. 
All officers must have a 2.5 minimum cumulative GPA or have achieved a 2.5 GPA for each of the two full semesters prior to their nomination and maintain at least a 2.5 GPA for their term of office. GPA is based on a 4.0 scale. 
Section 2: Nominations
Nominations for all officers will take place at the third to last meeting of the fall semester. 
A brother cannot be nominated for two different officer positions. 
Section 3: Election Procedures
Elections shall take place in order of chain of command. 
Nominees shall be elected if they receive a majority of votes casted in closed written ballot. No proxy vote shall be allowed. If no majority is achieved, a second election shall be held between the two top contenders. 
Section 4: Oath of Office
a. Before assuming office, each officer-elect shall recite the following oath with their right hand raised: “I do solemnly swear / that I will faithfully execute / the duties of ___________ / of the Theta Alpha Chapter / of the Zeta Beta Tau Fraternity / and will to the best of my ability / observe, protect, and defend / the Constitution and policies of the Theta Alpha Chapter of the Zeta Beta Tau Fraternity.”
b. The outgoing President must administer the oath of office. In the case where the outgoing President is indisposed, a Trustee, Advisor, or past President may administer the oath.
Section 5: Vacancies
If the office of President becomes vacant, the Internal Vice President shall be the acting President until a special election can be held for the position of President for the remainder of his term. 
Other officers’ vacancies shall be filled by special election in the same fashion as for the office of President. 
Section 6: Impeachment
Any elected officer may be impeached at any regular Chapter meeting, provided that a written bill of charges, signed by 50% of active members in good standing has been presented to the officer in question at the regular Chapter meeting prior to the vote. 
The officer in question shall be given time to respond to charges against him at the meeting when the vote shall be taken. 
Voting shall be by secret ballot of those in attendance and in good standing. The following question shall be posed to the quorum: “Should Brother _________ be allowed to continue to be the __________?” 
A 75% vote in the negative is needed for impeachment. No proxy vote shall be allowed. 
In the event that the President is under impeachment, the Treasurer shall chair the meeting. 
If the officer is removed from office, a vacancy for that office shall be declared immediately. 
An officer may be tried only once for any charges. 
Section 7: Provisional Government
In the unlikely event that all members of the executive board may be found incapacitated or under University investigation, University probation, or deemed unfit to govern the Chapter due to ineligibility as dictated by Article IV, Section 1, a provisional government will be initiated and will hold Executive Board powers until an emergency election meeting can be held or original board members may be deemed fit to reclaim their office. 
The President of the provisional government shall be the oldest born active member in good standing of the oldest active fraternal class. Such President shall hold no Presidential Privilege, as they were not democratically elected to office. 
The other officer positions shall be chosen in a similar fashion, in the order outlined by Article IV, Section 1, Paragraph A. 
Section 8: Duties of Officers
President: The President shall be the chief officer and administrative head of the Fraternity. He shall be chairman of the Fraternity's Executive Board.
He shall countersign all Fraternity checks and documents. 
He shall appoint all committee chairmen as well as a house manager and steward, and any other assistant’s that may be required. 
He shall cast no vote at any meeting, except in the event of an equal division of votes and the Semi-Annual Brotherhood Review Vote. 
Presidential Privilege: The President shall retain the option of over-ruling or instituting decisions that he feels are vital to the health and well being of the Chapter and its ideals. This privilege is intended as a last resort when the democratic process fails. 
The sole restriction to this Privilege shall be the Chapter President cannot use this right to overrule any sanctions imposed by Honor Court. 
Internal Vice President: The Internal Vice President shall serve as the President's chief troubleshooter, and shall fulfill the duties of President in the event of his absence or disability.
a. He will be in charge of overseeing the following committees: Brotherhood Development, Recruitment, Ritual, Formal, Risk Management, Alumni and Parental Relations, Academics and any other committees assigned to him by the Executive Board.

b. The Internal Vice President is also responsible for maintaining and distributing a Fraternity calendar with all pertinent events, and may serve as a counter-signer on all Fraternity Checks and Documents. The Internal Vice President shall also carry out any duties assigned to him by the President.
External Vice President: The External Vice President will be in charge of overseeing the following committees: Fundraising, Social, Athletics, Greek Council, Historian, Philanthropy, Sweetheart and any other committees assigned to him by the Executive Board. The External Vice President shall also carry out any duties assigned to him by the President.
Treasurer: The Treasurer shall work with the Trustees, Advisor, President, and Internal Vice President in collecting, holding, and disbursing moneys of the Fraternity.
All checks shall require two signatures - that of the Treasurer and the counter-signature of the President or Internal Vice President. 
The Treasurer shall be responsible for administering of an annual budget, based on fees voted by the Fraternity's members. The Treasurer shall render a complete financial report of the Fraternity's financial condition weekly and annually. 
The Treasurer shall keep a ledger, which will list all financial transactions of the Fraternity. All deposits must be witnessed by the President or Internal Vice President and counter-signed in the ledger. A record of all deposits, checks written, donations, and funds raised must also be kept in this ledger both for the chapter and for individual Brother Accounts. 
Secretary: The Secretary shall perform all necessary secretarial duties of the Fraternity.
He shall keep a roster and permanent minutes of all chapter meetings and of all chapter events. 
He shall be in charge of all the Fraternity's correspondence, whether written or electronic. 
He must maintain permanent files of all committee minutes and of all letters and/or emails received and sent. 
The Secretary is responsible for the distribution of minutes to the active members, Advisors and Trustees. 
The Secretary will directly oversee the house manager and steward committee. 
Sergeant-at-Arms: The Sergeant-at-Arms shall stand guard at the door at all meetings, allowing only Brothers entrance. The Sergeant at Arms shall be the parliamentarian of the Fraternity, and shall Chair the Honor Court. He shall act as the voice for active members during any closed session and/or meetings of the Executive Board and as such provide counter arguments to ensure an educated decision is reached on behalf of the Chapter.
ARTICLE V: STANDING COMMITTEES
Section 1: 
The standing committees shall be: Executive Board, Honor Court, Academics, Alumni and Parent Relations, Athletics, Philanthropy, Fundraising, Risk Management, Brotherhood Development, Ritual, Social, Webmaster, House Manager, and Recruitment.
Section 2: 
The President has the right to propose new Committees, ratified by a majority vote at any regular meeting. No proxy votes will be allowed.
Section 3: 
Each committee shall have a chairman, who is to be appointed by the President and/or Vice-Presidents with the unanimous approval of the Executive Board.
Section 4: 
All committees must file in writing regular progress reports and present to the chapter any accomplishments and future goals on a weekly basis. Failure to do so may result in the removal of the committee chair.
ARTICLE VI: POWERS AND DUTIES OF STANDING COMMITTEES
Section 1: Responsibilities of the Executive Board
To act as the final authority in all matters pertaining to the interpretation of the Constitution and its bylaws. 
To make recommendations to the chapter on matters requiring a vote. 
To serve as the final appeals body in the matter of fines. 
To confer with the chapter advisors and the house corporation on matters requiring its attention. 
To appoint all committee chairmen. 
To keep all meetings open to all members. (The President or presiding officer may ask any members to leave said meeting, if at his discretion he feels the member’s conduct is detrimental to the purpose of the meeting. The President may also ask that non-elected members not speak during meetings.) 
To have all powers otherwise mentioned in the Constitution and bylaws. 
To review the performance of all committee chairmen quarterly and determine if they should continue serving. 
To allow the Chapter to overrule by a two-thirds vote any decision not deemed final by the Executive Board. 
To discuss committee tasks, productivity, and upcoming events. 
To approve reduction of dues as may be necessary for individual brothers. 


ARTICLE VII: MEETINGS 
Section 1: Regular Meetings
Regular Chapter meetings will be held weekly. 
In case of an emergency or necessity, the President may change the meeting time or date given 12 hours’ notice. 
All brothers must be present at every chapter meeting unless excused by the President or Secretary. 
Section 2: Executive Board Meetings
Executive Board meetings will be held at least once a week and may not be held immediately prior to chapter. 
In case of emergency or necessity, the day and hour may be changed by the President on 12 hours’ notice. 
Non-Executive Board members may attend an Executive Board Meeting by invitation only. 
Section 3: Special Meetings
The President may call special meetings with the approval of the Executive Board, and with at least 12 hours’ notice. 
The purpose of the meeting must be clearly stated in the request. 
No business shall be transacted at a special meeting other than what the meeting was called for. 
Every brother must be present at a special meeting unless excused by the President. 


ARTICLE VIII: FINANCES 
Section 1: Fees and Dues
Every brother must pay his bill to or make financial arrangements with the Treasurer within the first week of classes each term. 
Every new initiate must pay his bill to or make financial arrangements with the Treasurer within two weeks of his first chapter meeting.
c. When a brother makes financial arrangements with the Treasurer, said member must sign a binding promissory note.
d. Failure to pay or make arrangements shall result in charges brought against them in Honor Court.
Section 1: Other Debts
Any other debt incurred between brothers or between a brother and the Chapter must be repaid within two weeks following the date incurred. 
Failure to pay in a timely fashion will result in the daily addition of interest until the debt is paid in full. 
ARTICLE IX: EXPULSION 
Section 1: Expulsion Procedure
Upon conviction of a Federal, State, University or Fraternal crime, a member is subject to immediate review by the Honor Court. 
Any member who, upon sufficient presentation of evidence to the Honor Court, is found to be guilty of: gross misconduct under the law; violation of school rules; or withdrawal of Fraternal, financial or moral support, shall be subject to immediate expulsion. 
The member must be given the opportunity to speak to the entire Chapter in his own defense, if he so chooses, and a 3/5 majority of a quorum casted by closed written ballot is required for any expulsion. No proxy vote will be allowed. 
Section 2: Appeals
a. Appeals shall be handled according to National Discipline procedures (Article X of the National Constitution).
ARTICLE X: POLICY
Section 1: Policy is to be defined as the rules and/or procedures that shall be considered proper and accepted for all fraternal operations, so long as it is not in conflict with the Constitution. The In the event of such a conflict, the Constitution shall take precedence.
Section 2: Policy shall be detailed in a separate document.
Section 3: Adoption of Policy
Any proposed policy from the Chapter must be submitted in writing, at a regular meeting of the chapter, or at a special meeting for which the policy in question is the subject. 
One week following written submission of the proposed policy the Chapter may ratify it with a majority vote. 
The President may implement policy using Presidential Privilege. 
Section 4: Amendment of Policy
Policy may be amended by a simple majority vote at any chapter meeting. 
All such amendments must be submitted in writing one week before the meeting where the vote is to be held.
ARTICLE XI: AMENDMENTS
Section 1: This Constitution may be amended by a two-thirds vote of all brothers in good standing. Notice of proposed amendments must be presented to the full fraternity in writing at a regular meeting at least one week before the meeting at which it is to be voted upon.
Section 2: No Presidential Privilege will be authorized to amend this Constitution. The Presidential Privilege will be limited only to chapter Policies.
ARTICLE XII: ENABLING CLAUSE
Section 1: This Constitution shall take effect by a vote of unanimous approval by the Founding Fathers of the Theta Alpha Chapter of the Zeta Beta Tau Fraternity. Thereafter this Constitution shall be the absolute authority on all matters related to the Chapter, and shall be upheld and defended by each and every brother who takes an oath of initiation.
SIGNATURES (current E-Board as of January 1, 2019)
Justin Maccagnan 
Samuel Wiesman 
Nicholas Penta 
Justin Noddell
Nicholas Meredith
